editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.head: Dryden's VIRGIL Printed for Iacob Tonon

div.p: THE WORKS OF VIRGIL: Containing His PASTORALS, GEORGICS, AND AENEIS.
Tranlated into Englih Vere; By Mr. DRYDEN.
Adorn'd with a Hundred Sculptures.
LONDON, Printed for Jacob Tonon, at the Judges-Head in Fleettreet, near the Inner-Temple-Gate, MDCXCVII.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE Hugh Lord Clifford, BARON of Chudleigh.
div.p:
I HAVE found it not more difficult to Tranlate Virgil, than to find uch Patrons as I deire for my Tranlation. For though England is not wanting in a Learned Nobility, yet uch are my unhappy Circumtances, that they have confin'd me to a narrow choice. To the greater part, I have not the Honour to be known; and to ome of them I cannot hew at preent, by any publick Act, that grateful Repect which I hall ever bear them in my heart. Yet I have no reaon to complain of Fortune, ince in the midt of that abundance I could not poibly have choen better, than the Worthy Son of o Illutrious a Father. He was the Patron of my Manhood, when I Flourih'd in the opinion of the World; though with mall advantage to my Fortune, 'till he awaken'd the remembrance of my Royal Mater. He was that Pollio, or that Varus, who introduc'd me to Augutus: And tho' he oon dimis'd himelf from State-Affairs, yet in the hort time of his Adminitration he hone o powerfully upon me, that like the heat of a Ruian-Summer, he ripen'd the Fruits of Poetry in a cold Clymate; and gave me wherewithal to ubit at leat, in the long Winter which ucceeded. What I now offer to your Lordhip, is the wretched remainder of a ickly Age, worn out with Study, and oppres'd by Fortune: without other upport than the Contancy and Patience of a Chritian. You, my Lord, are yet in the flower of your Youth, and may live to enjoy the benefits of the Peace which is promis'd Europe: I can only hear of that Bleing: for Years, and, above all things, want of health, have hut me out from haring in the happines. The Poets, who condemn their Tantalus to Hell, had added to his Torments, if they had plac'd him in Elyium, which is the proper Emblem of my Condition. The Fruit and the Water may reach my Lips, but cannot enter: And if they cou'd, yet I want a Palate as well as a Digetion. But it is ome kind of pleaure to me, to pleae
thoe whom I repect. And I am not altogether out of hope, that thee Patorals of Virgil may give your Lordhip ome delight, though made Englih by one, who carce remembers that Paion which inpir'd my Author when he wrote them. Thee were his firt Eay in Poetry, (if the Ceiris was not his:) And it was more excuable in him to decribe Love when he was young, than for me to Tranlate him when I am Old. He died at the Age of fifty two, and I began this Work in my great Clymacterique. But having perhaps a better contitution than my Author, I have wrong'd him les, conidering my Circumtances, than thoe who have attempted him before, either in our own, or any Modern Language. And though this Verion is not void of Errours, yet it comforts me that the faults of others are not worth finding. Mine are neither gros nor frequent, in thoe Eclogues, wherein my Mater has rais'd himelf above that humble Stile in which Patoral delights, and which I mut confefs is proper to the Education and Convere of Shepherds: for he found the trength of his Genius b • times, and was even in his youth preluding to his Georgics, and his Aeneis. He cou'd not forbear to try his Wings, though his Pinions were not harden'd to maintain a long laborious flight. Yet ometimes they bore him to a pitch as lofty, as ever he was able to reach afterwards. But when he was admonih'd by his ubject to decend, he came down gently circling in the air, and inging to the ground. Like a Lark, melodious in her mounting, and continuing her Song 'till he alights: till preparing for a higher flight at her next ally, and tuning her voice to better muick. The Fourth, the Sixth, and the Eighth Patorals, are clear Evidences of this truth. In the three firt he contains himelf within his bounds; but Addreing to Pollio, his great Patron, and himelf no vulgar Poet, he no longer cou'd retrain the freedom of his Spirit, but began to aert his Native Character, which is ublimity. Putting himelf under the conduct of the ame Cumaean Sybil, whom afterwards he gave for a Guide to his Aeneas. 'Tis true he was enible of his own boldnes; and we know it by the Paulo Majora, which begins his Fourth Eclogue. He remember'd, like young Manlius, that he was forbidden to Engage; but what avails an expres Command to a youthful Courage, which preages Victory in the attempt? Encourag'd with Succes, he proceeds farther in the Sixth, and invades the Province of Philoophy. And notwithtanding that Phoebus had forewarn'd him of Singing Wars, as he there confees, yet he preum'd that the earch of Nature was as free to him as to Lucretius, who at his Age explain'd it according to the Principles of Epicurus. In his Eighth Eclogue, he has innovated nothing; the former part of it being the Complaint and Depair of a foraken Lover: the latter, a Charm of an Enchantres, to renew a lot Affection. But the Complaint perhaps contains ome Topicks which are above the Condition of his Perons; and our Author eems to have made his Herdmen omewhat too Learn'd for their Profeion: The Charms are alo of the ame nature, but both were Copied from Theocritus, and had receiv'd the applaue of former Ages in their Original. There is a kind of Ruticity in all thoe pompous Veres; omewhat of a Holiday Shepherd trutting in his Country Buskins. The like may be oberv'd, both in the Pollio, and the Silenus; where the Similitudes are drawn from the Woods and Meadows. They eem to me to repreent our Poet betwixt a Farmer, and a Courtier, when he left Mantua for Rome, and dret himelf in his bet Habit to appear before his Patron: Somewhat too fine for the place from whence he came, and yet retaining part of its implicity. In the Ninth Patoral he Collects ome Beautiful paages which were catter'd in Theocritus, which he cou'd not inert into any of his former Eclogues, and yet
was unwilling they hou'd be lot. In all the ret he is equal to his Sicilian Mater, and oberves like him a jut decorum, both of the Subject, and the Perons. As particularly in the Third Patoral; where one of his Shepherds decribes a Bowl, or Mazer, curiouly Carv'd.
In Medio duo igna: Conon, & quis fuit alter,
Decripit radio, totum qui Gentibus orbem.
He remembers only the name of Conon, and forgets the other on et purpoe: (whether he means Anaximander or Eudoxus I dipute not,) but he was certainly forgotten, to hew his Country Swain was no great Scholar.

After all, I mut confes that the Boorih Dialect of Theocritus has a ecret charm in it, which the Roman Language cannot imitate, though Virgil has drawn it down as low as poibly he cou'd; as in the Cujum pecus, and ome other words, for which he was o unjutly blam'd by the bad Criticks of his Age, who cou'd not ee the Beauties of that merum Rus, which the Poet decrib'd in thoe expreions. But Theocritus may jutly be preferr'd as the Original, without injury to Virgil, who modetly contents himelf with the econd place, and glories only in being the firt who tranplanted Patoral into his own Country; and brought it there to bear as happily as the Cherry-trees which Lucullus brought from Pontus.

Our own Nation has produc'd a third Poet in this kind, not inferiour to the two former. For the Shepherd's Kalendar of Spencer, is not to be match'd in any Modern Language. Not even by Tao's Amynta, which infinitely trancends Guarinis's Pator-Fido, as having more of Nature in it, and being almot wholly clear from the wretched affectation of Learning. I will ay nothing of the Pifcatory Eclogues, becaue no modern Latin can bear Criticim. 'Tis no wonder that rolling down through o many barbarous Ages, from the Spring of Virgil, it bears along with it the filth and ordures of the Goths and Vandals. Neither will I mention Monieur Fontinelle, the living Glory of the French. 'Tis enough for him to have excell'd his Mater Lucian, without attempting to compare our mierable Age with that of Virgil, or Theocritus. Let me only add, for his reputation,
—Si Pergama dextrâ
Defendi point, etiam hâc defena fuient.

But Spencer being Mater of our Northern Dialect; and skill'd in Chaucer's Englih, has o exactly imitated the Doric of Theocritus, that his Love is a perfect Image of that Paion which God infus'd into both Sexes, before it was corrupted with the Knowledge of Arts, and the Ceremonies of what we call good Manners.

My Lord, I know to whom I dedicate: And cou'd not have been induc'd by any motive to put this part of Virgil, or any other, into unlearned Hands. You have read him with pleaure, and I dare ay, with admiration in the Latine, of which you are a Mater. You have added to your Natural Endowments, which without flattery are Eminent, the upertructures of Study, and the knowledge of good Authors. Courage, Probity, and Humanity are inherent in you. Thee Vertues have ever been habitual to the Ancient Houe of Cumberland, from whence you are decended, and of which our Chronicles make o honourable mention in the long Wars betwixt the Rival Families of York and Lancater. Your Forefathers have aerted the Party which they choe 'till death, and dy'd for its defence in the Fields of Battel. You have beides the freh remembrance of your Noble Father; from whom you never can degenerate.
—Nec imbellem, feroces
Progenerant Aquilam Columbae.
It being almot morally impoible for you to be other than you are by kind; I need neither praie nor incite your Vertue. You are acquainted with the Roman Hitory, and know without my information that Patronage and Clienthip always decended from the Fathers to the Sons; and that the ame Plebeian Houes, had recoure to the ame Patrician Line, which had formerly protected them: and follow'd their Principles and Fortunes to the lat. So that I am your Lordhip's by decent, and part of your Inheritance. And the natural inclination, which I have to erve you, adds to your paternal right, for I was wholly yours from the firt moment, when I had the happines and honour of being known to you. Be pleas'd therefore to accept the Rudiments of Virgil's Poetry: Courely Tranlated I confes, but which yet retains ome Beauties of the Author, which neither the barbarity of our Language, nor my unskilfulnes cou'd o much ully, but that they appear ometimes in the dim mirrour which I hold before you. The Subject is not unuitable to your Youth, which allows you yet to Love, and is proper to your preent Scene of Life. Rural Recreations abroad, and Books at home, are the innocent Pleaures of a Man who is early Wie; and gives Fortune no more hold of him, than of neceity he mut. 'Tis good, on ome occaions to think beforehand as little as we can; to enjoy as much of the preent as will not endanger our futurity; and to provide our elves of the Vertuoo's Saddle, which will be ure to amble, when the World is upon the hardet trott. What I humbly offer to your Lordhip, is of this nature. I wih it pleaant, and am ure 'tis innocent. May you ever continue your eteem for Virgil; and not leen it, for the faults of his Tranlatour; who is with all manner of Repect, and ene of Gratitude,

closer.signed: Your Lordhip's mot Humble, and mot Obedient Servant, JOHN DRYDEN.

div.head: THE LIFE OF Pub. Virgilius Maro.
div.p:
VIRGIL was born at Mantua, which City was built no les than Three Hundred Years before Rome; and was the Capital of the New Hetruria, as himelf, no les Antiquary, than Poet, aures us. His Birth is aid to have happen'd in the firt Conulhip of Pompey the Great, and Lic. Craus; but ince the Relater of this preently after contradicts himelf; and Virgil's manner of Addreing to Octavius, implies a greater difference of Age than that of Seven Years, as appears by his Firt Patoral, and other places; it is reaonable to et the Date of it omething backward: And the Writer of his Life having no certain Memorials to work upon, eems to have pitched upon the two mot Illutrious Conuls he could find about that time, to ignalize the Birth of o Eminent a Man. But it is beyond all Quetion, that he was Born on, or near the Fifteenth of October. Which Day was kept Fetival in honour of his Memory, by the Latin, as the Birth-Day of Homer was by the Greek Poets. And o near a reemblance there is, betwixt the Lives of thee two famous Epic Writers, that Virgil eems to have follow'd the Fortune of the other, as well as the Subject and manner of his Writing. For Homer is aid to have been of very mean Parents, uch as got their Bread by Day-labour; o is Virgil. Homer is aid to be Bae Born; o is Virgil. The former to have been born in the open Air, in a Ditch, or by the Bank of a River; o is the latter. There was a Poplar Planted near the place of Virgil's Birth, which uddenly grew up to an unuual heighth and bulk, and to which the Supertitious Neighbourhood attributed marvellous Vertue. Homer had his Poplar too, as Herodotus relates, which was viited with great Veneration. Homer is decrib'd by one of the Ancients, to have been of a lovenly and neglected Meen and Habit, o was Virgil. Both were of a very delicate and ickly Contitution: Both addicted to Travel, and the tudy of Atrology: Both had their Compoitions uurp'd by others: Both Envy'd and traduc'd during their Lives. We know not o much as the true Names of either of them with any exactnes: For the Criticks are not yet agreed how the word [Virgil] hould be Written; and of Homer's Name there is no certainty at all. Whooever
hall conider this Parallel in o many particulars; (and more might be added) would be inclin'd to think, that either the ame Stars Rul'd trongly at the Nativities of them both, or what is a great deal more probable; that the Latin Grammarians wanting Materials for the former part of Virgil's Life, after the Legendary Fahion, upply'd it out of Herodotus; and like ill Face-Painters, not being able to hit the true Features, endeavour'd to make amends by a great deal of impertinent Landcape and Drapery.

Without troubling the Reader with needles Quotations, now, or afterwards; the mot probable Opinion is, that Virgil was the Son of a Servant, or Aitant to a wandring Atrologer; who practis'd Phyic. For Medicus, Magus, as Juvenal oberves, uually went together; and this coure of Life was follow'd by a great many Greeks and Syrians; of one of which Nations it eems not improbable, that Virgil's Father was. Nor could a Man of that Profeion have choen a fitter place to ettle in, than that mot Supertitious Tract of Italy; which by her ridiculous Rites and Ceremonies as much enlav'd the Romans, as the Romans did the Hetrurians by their Arms. This Man therefore having got together ome Money, which Stock he improv'd by his Skill in Planting and Husbandry, had the good Fortune, at lat, to Marry his Maters Daughter, by whom he had Virgil; and this Woman eems, by her Mothers ide, to have been of good Extraction; for he was nearly related to Quintilius Varus, whom Paterculus aures us to have been an Illutrious, tho' not Patrician Family; and there is honourable mention made of it in the Hitory of the econd Carthaginian War. It is certain, that they gave him very good Education, to which they were inclin'd; not o much by the Dreams of his Mother, and thoe preages which Donatus relates, as by the early indications which he gave of a weet Dipoition, and Excellent Wit. He paed the firt Seven Years of his Life at Mantua, not Seventeen, as Scaliger micorrects his Author; for the initia aetatis can hardly be uppoed to extend o far. From thence he removed to Cremona, a Noble Roman Colony, and afterwards to Milan. In all which places he proecuted his Studies with great application; he read over, all the bet Latin, and Greek Authors, for which he had convenience by the no remote ditance of Mareils, that famous Greek Colony, which maintain'd its Politenes, and Purity of Language, in the midt of all thoe Barbarous Nations amongt which it was eated: And ome Tincture of the latter eems to have decended from them down to the Modern French. He frequented the mot Eminent Profeors of the Epicurean Philoophy, which was then much in vogue, and will be always in declining and ickly States. But finding no atisfactory Account from his Mater Syron, he pas'd over to the Academick School, to which he adher'd the ret of his Life, and deerv'd, from a great Emperour, the Title of the Plato of Poets. He compos'd at leiure hours a great number of Veres, on various Subjects; and deirous rather of a great, than early Fame, he permitted his Kinman, and Fellow-tudent Varus, to derive the Honour of one of his Tragedies to himelf. Glory neglected in proper time and place, returns often with large Increae, and o he found it: For Varus afterwards prov'd a great Intrument of his Rie: In hort, it was here that he form'd the Plan, and collected the Materials of all thoe excellent Pieces which he afterwards finih'd, or was forc'd to leave les perfect by his Death. But whether it were the Unwholomnes of his Native Air,
of which he omewhere complains, or his too great abtinence, and Night-watchings at his Study, to which he was always addicted, as Augutus oberves; or poibly the hopes of improving himelf by Travel, he reolv'd to Remove to the more Southern Tract of Italy; and it was hardly poible for him not to take Rome in his Way; as is evident to any one who hall cat an Eye on the Map of Italy: And therefore the late French Editor of his Works is mitaken, when he aerts that he never aw Rome, 'till he came to Petition for his Etate: He gain'd the Acquaintance of the Mater of the Hore to Octavius, and Cur'd a great many Dieaes of Hores, by methods they had never heard of: It fell out, at the ame time, that a very fine Colt, which promied great Strength and Speed, was preented to Octavius: Virgil aur'd them, that he came of a faulty Mare, and would prove a Jade, upon trial it was found as he had aid; his Judgment prov'd right in everal other intances, which was the more urprizing, bebecaue the Romans knew leat of Natural Caues of any civiliz'd Nation in the World: And thoe Meteors, and Prodigies which cot them incredible Sums to expiate, might eaily have been accounted for, by no very profound Naturalit. It is no wonder, therefore, that Virgil was in o great Reputation, as to be at lat Introduced to Octavius himelf. That Prince was then at variance with Marc. Antony, who vex'd him with a great many Libelling Letters, in which he reproaches him with the baenes of his Parentage, that he came of a Scrivener, a Ropemaker, and a Baker, as Suetonius tells us: Octavius finding that Virgil had paed o exact a judgment upon the Breed of Dogs, and Hores, thought that he poibly might be able to give him ome Light concerning his own. He took him into his Cloet, where they continu'd in private a coniderable time. Virgil was a great Mathematician, which, in the Sene of thoe times, took in Atrology: And if there be any thing in that Art, which I can hardly believe; if that be true which the Ingenious De le Chambre aerts confidently; that from the Marks on the Body, the Configuration of the Planets at a Nativity may be gathered, and the Marks might be told by knowing the Nativity, never had one of thoe Artits a fairer Opportunity to hew his skill, than Virgil now had; for Octavius had Moles upon his Body, exactly reembling the Contellation call'd ra Major. But Virgil had other helps: The Predictions of Cicero, and Catulus, and that Vote of the Senate had gone abroad, that no Child Born at Rome, in the Year of his Nativity, hould be bred up; becaue the Seers aur'd them that an Emperour was Born that Year. Beides this, Virgil had heard of the Ayrian, and Egyptian Prophecies, (which in truth, were no other but the Jewih,) that about that time a great King was to come into the World. Himelf takes notice of them, Aen. 6. where he ues a very ignificant Word, (now in all Liturgies) hujus in adventu, o in another place, adventante Dea.

l.hi: At his foreeen approach already quake,

q.l: Ayrian Kingdoms, and Moeotis Lake.
Nile hears him knocking at his even-fold Gates—

div.p:
Every one knows whence this was taken: It was rather a mitake, than impiety in Virgil, to apply thee Propheies to the Peron of Octavius, it being a uual piece of flattery for near a Hundred Years together, to attribute them to their Emperours, and other great Men. Upon the whole
matter, it is very probable, that Virgil Predicted to him the Empire at this time. And it will appear yet the more, if we conider that he aures him of his being receiv'd into the Number of the Gods, in his Firt Patoral, long before the thing came to pas; which Prediction eems grounded upon his former Mitake. This was a ecret, not to be divulg'd at that time, and therefore it is no wonder that the light Story in Donatus was given abroad to palliate the matter. But certain it is, that Octavius dimied him with great Marks of eteem, and earnetly recommended the Protection of Virgil's Affairs to Pollio, then Lieutenant of the Ci-Alpine Gaule, where Virgil's Patrimony lay. This Pollio from a mean Original, became one of the mot Coniderable Perons of his time: A good General, Orator, States-man, Hitorian, Poet, and Favourer of Learned Men; above all, he was a Man of Honour in thoe critical times: He had join'd with Octavius, and Antony, in revenging the Barbarous Aaination of Julius Caear: When they two were at variance, he would neither follow Antony, whoe coures he deteted, nor join with Octavius againt him, out of a grateful Sene of ome former Obligations. Augutus, who thought it his interet to oblige Men of Principles, notwithtanding this, receiv'd him afterwards into Favour, and promoted him to the highet Honours. And thus much I thought fit to ay of Pollio, becaue he was one of Virgil's greatet Friends. Being therefore eas'd of Dometick cares, he purues his Journey to Naples: The Charming ituation of that Place, and view of the beautiful Villa's of the Roman Nobility, equalling the Magnificence of the greatet Kings; the Neighbourhood of the Baiae, whither the Sick reorted for recovery, and the States-man when he was Politickly Sick; whither the wanton went for Pleaure, and witty Men for good Company; the wholeomnes of the Air, and improving Converation, the bet Air of all, contributed not only to the re-etablihing his Health; but to the forming of his Style, and rendring him Mater of that happy turn of Vere, in which he much urpaes all the Latins, and in a les advantageous Language, equals even Homer himelf. He propos'd to ue his Talent in Poetry, only for Scaffolding to Build a convenient Fortune, that he might Proecute with les interruption, thoe Nobler Studies to which his elevated Genius led him, and which he decribes in thee admirable Lines.

l.hi: Me verò primùm dulces ante omnia Muae
Quarum acra fero ingenti perculus amore,

Accipiant, caeli
que vias, & idera montrent,

Defectus Solis varios, Lunae
que labores:

q.l: nde tremor terris, &c.

div.p:
But the current of that Martial Age, by ome trange Antiperitais drove o violently towards Poetry, that he was at let carried down with the tream. For not only the Young Nobility, but Octavius, and Pollio, Cicero in his Old Age, Julius Caear, and the Stoical Brutus, a little before, would needs be tampering with the Mues; the two latter had taken great care to have their Poems curiouly bound, and lodg'd in the mot famous Libraries; but neither the Sacrednes of thoe places, nor the greatnes of their Names, cou'd preerve ill Poetry. Quitting therefore the Study of the Law, after having pleaded but one Caue with indifferent Succes, he reolv'd to puh his Fortune this way, which he eems to have dicontinu'd for ome time, and that may be the reaon why the
Culex, his firt Patoral, now extant, has little beides the novelty of the Subject, and the Moral of the Fable, which contains an exhortation to gratitude, to recomend it; had it been as correct as his other pieces, nothing more proper and pertinent cou'd have at that time bin addreed to the Young Octavius, for the Year in which he Preented it, probably at the Baiae, eems to be the very ame, in which that Prince conented (tho' with eeming reluctance) to the Death of Cicero, under whoe Conulhip he was Born, the preerver of his Life, and chief intrument of his advancement. There is no reaon to quetion its being genuine, as the late French Editor does; its meanes, in comparion of Virgil's other Works, (which is that Writers only Objection) confutes himelf: For Martial, who certainly aw the true Copy, peaks of it with contempt; and yet that Patoral equals, at leat, the addres to the Dauphin which is prefix'd to the late Edition. Octavius, to unbend his mind from application to publick buines, took frequent turns to Baiae, and Sicily; where he compos'd his Poem call'd Sicelides, which Virgil eems to allude to, in the Patoral beginning Sicelides Muae; this gave him opportunity of refrehing that Princes Memory of him, and about that time he wrote his Aetna. Soon after he eems to have made a Voyage to Athens, and at his return preented his Ceiris, a more elaborate Piece, to the Noble and Eloquent Meala. The forementioned Author groundlely taxes this as uppoititious: For beides other Critical marks, there are no les than Fifty, or Sixty Veres, alter'd indeed and polih'd, which he inerted in the Patorals, according to his fahion: and from thence they were called Eclogues, or Select Bucolics: We thought fit to ue a Title more intelligible, the reaon of the other being ceas'd; and we are upported by Virgil's own authority, who exprely calls them Carmina Patorum. The French Editor is again mitaken, in aerting, that the Ceiris is borrow'd from the Ninth of Ovid's Metamorphois; he might have more reaonably conjectur'd it, to be taken from Parthenius, the Greek Poet, from whom Ovid borrow'd a great part of his Work. But it is indeed taken from neither, but from that Learn'd, unfortunate Poet Apollonius Rhodius, to whom Virgil is more indebted, than to any other Greek Writer, excepting Homer. The Reader will be atisfied of this, if he conult that Author in his own Language, for the Tranlation is a great deal more obcure than the Original.

Whilt Virgil thus enjoy'd the weets of a Learn'd Privacy, the Troubles of Italy cut off his little Subitance; but by a trange turn of Human Affairs, which ought to keep good Men from ever depairing; the los of his Etate prov'd the effectual way of making his Fortune. The occaion of it was this; Octavius, as himelf relates, when he was but Nineteen Years of Age, by a Materly troke of Policy, had gain'd the Veteran Legions into his Service, (and by that tep, out-witted all the Republican Senate:) They grew now very clamorous for their Pay: The Treaury being Exhauted, he was forc'd to make Aignments upon Land, and none but in Italy it elf would content them. He pitch'd upon Cremona as the mot ditant from Rome; but that not uffiing, he afterwards threw in part of the State of Mantua. Cremona was a Rich and noble Colony, etled a little before the Invaion of Hannibal. During that Tedious and Bloody War, they had done everal important Services to the Common-Wealth. And when Eighteen other Colonies, pleading Poverty and Depopulation, refus'd to contribute Money, or to raie Recruits; they of Cremona voluntarily
paid a double Quota of both: But pat Services are a fruitles Plea; Civil Wars are one continued Act of Ingratitude: In vain did the Mierable Mothers, with their famihing Infants in their Arms, fill the Streets with their Numbers, and the Air with Lamentations; the Craving Legions were to be atisfi'd at any rate. Virgil, involv'd in the common Calamity, had recoure to his old Patron Pollio, but he was, at this time, under a Cloud; however, compaionating o worthy a Man, not of a make to truggle thro' the World, he did what he could, and recommended him to Mecaenas, with whom he till kept a private Correpondence. The Name of this great Man being much better known than one part of his Character, the Reader, I preume, will not be dipleas'd if I upply it in this place.

Tho' he was of as deep Reach, and eaie dipatch of Buines as any in his time, yet he deignedly liv'd beneath his true Character. Men had oftentimes medled in Publick Affairs, that they might have more ability to furnih for their Pleaures: Mecaenas, by the honetet Hypocriie that ever was, pretended to a Life of Pleaure, that he might render more effectual Service to his Mater. He eem'd wholly to amue himelf with the Diverions of the Town, but under that Mask he was the greatet Miniter of his Age. He would be carried in a careles, effeminate poture thro' the Streets in his Chair, even to the degree of a Proverb, and yet there was not a Cabal of ill dipos'd Perons which he had not early notice of; and that too in a City as large as London and Paris, and perhaps two or three more of the mot populous put together. No Man better undertood that Art o neceary to the Great; the Art of declining Envy: Being but of a Gentleman's Family, not Patrician, he would not provoke the Nobility by accepting invidious Honours; but wiely atisfi'd himelf that he had the Ear of Augutus, and the Secret of the Empire. He eems to have committed but one great Fault, which was the truting a Secret of high Conequence to his Wife; but his Mater, enough Uxorious himelf, made his own Frailty more excuable, by generouly forgiving that of his Favourite. He kept in all his Greatnes exact meaures with his Friends; and chuing them wiely, found, by Experience, that good Sene and Gratitude are almot ineparable. This appears in Virgil and Horace; the former, beides the Honour he did him to all Poterity, return'd his Liberalities at his Death: The other, whom Mecaenas recommended with his lat Breath, was too generous to tay behind, and enjoy the Favour of Augutus: He only deir'd a place in his Tomb, and to mingle his Ahes with thoe of his deceaed Benefactor. But this was Seventeen Hundred Years ago. Virgil, thus powerfully upported, thought it mean to Petition for himelf alone, but reolutely olicits the Caue of his whole Country, and eems, at firt, to have met with ome Encouragement: But the matter cooling, he was forc'd to it down contented with the Grant of his own Etate. He goes therefore to Mantua, produces his Warrant to a Captain of Foot, whom he found in his Houe; Arrius who had eleven Points of the Law, and fierce of the Services he had rendred to Octavius, was o far from yielding Poeion, that words growing betwixt them, he wounded him dangerouly, forc'd him to fly, and at lat to wim the River Mincius to ave his Life. Virgil, who us'd to ay, that no Virtue was o neceary as Patience, was forc'd to drag a fick Body half the length of Italy, back again to Rome, and by the way, probably, compos'd his Ninth Patoral, which may eem to have been
made up in hate out of the Fragments of ome other pieces; and naturally enough repreents the diorder of the Poets Mind, by its disjointed Fahion, tho' there be another Reaon to be given elewhere of its want of Connexion. He handomly tates his Cae in that Poem, and with the pardonable Reentments of Injur'd Innocence, not only claims Octavius's Promie, but hints to him the uncertainty of Human Greatnes and Glory: All was taken in good part by that Wie Prince: At lat effectual Orders were given: About this time, he Compos'd that admirable Poem, which is et firt, out of repect to Caear; for he does not eem either to have had leiure, or to have been in the Humour of making o olemn an Acknowledgment, 'till he was poes'd of the Benefit. And now he was in o great Reputation and Interet, that he reolved to give up his Land to his Parents, and himelf to the Court. His Patorals were in uch Eteem, that Pollio, now again in high Favour with Caear, deir'd him to reduce them into a Volume. Some Modern Writer, that has a contant flux of Vere, would tand amaz'd how Virgil could employ three whole Years in reviing five or ix hundred Veres, mot of which, probably, were made ome time before; but there is more reaon to wonder how he could do it o oon in uch Perfection. A coure Stone is preently fahion'd; but a Diamond, of not many Karats, is many Weeks in Cutting, and in Polihing many more. He who put Virgil upon this, had a Politick good end in it.

The continu'd Civil Wars had laid Italy almot wate; the Ground was Uncultivated and Untock'd; upon which enu'd uch a Famine, and Inurrection, that Caear hardly cap'd being Ston'd at Rome; his Ambition being look'd upon by all Parties as the principal occaion of it. He et himelf therefore with great Indutry to promote Country-Improvements; and Virgil was erviceable to his Deign, as the good keeper of the Bees, Georg. 4.

q.l: Tinnituque cie, & matris quate cymbala circum,
Ipae conident—

div.p:
That Emperour afterwards thought it matter worthy a publick Incription Rediit cultus Agris. Which eems to be the motive that Induced Macaenas, to put him upon Writing his Georgics, or Books of Husbandry: A deign as new in Latin Vere, as Patorals, before Virgil were in Italy; which Work took up Seven of the mot vigorous Years of his Life; for he was now at leat Thirty four Years of Age; and here Virgil hines in his Meridian. A great part of this Work eems to have been rough-drawn before he left Mantua, for an Ancient Writer has oberv'd that the Rules of Husbandry laid down in it, are better Calculated for the Soil of Mantua, than for the more Sunny Climate of Naples; near which place, and in Sicily, he finih'd it. But let his Genius hould be depreed by apprehenions of want, he had a good Etate ettled upon him, and a Houe in the Pleaantet part of Rome; the Principal Furniture of which was a well-choen Library, which tood open to all comers of Learning and Merit; and what recommended the ituation of it mot, was the Neighbourhood of his Mecaenas; and thus
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
he cou'd either viit Rome, or return to his Privacy at Naples, thro' a Pleaant Rode adorn'd on each ide with pieces of Antiquity, of which he was o great a Lover, and in the intervals of them, eem'd almot one continu'd Street of three days Journey.

Caear having now Vanquih'd Sextus Pompeius, a Spring-tide of Properities breaking in upon him, before he was ready to receive them as he ought, fell ick of the Imperial Evil, the deire of being thought omething more than Man. Ambition is an infinite Folly: When it has attain'd to the utmot pitch of Humane Greatnes, it oon falls to making pretenions upon Heaven. The crafty Livia would needs be drawn in the Habit of a Prietee by the Shrine of the new God: And this became a Fahion not to be dipens'd with amongt the Ladies: The Devotion was wondrous great amongt the Romans, for it was their Interet, and, which ometimes avails more, it was the Mode. Virgil, tho' he depis'd the Heathen Supertitions, and is o bold as to call Saturn and Janus, by no better a Name than that of Old Men, and might deerve the Title of Subverter of Supertitions, as well as Varro, thought fit to follow the Maxim of Plato his Mater; that every one hould erve the Gods after the Uage of his own Country, and therefore was not the lat to preent his Incene, which was of too Rich a Compoition for uch an Altar: And by his Addres to Caear on this occaion, made an unhappy Precedent to Lucan and other Poets which came after him, Geor. 1. and 3. And this Poem being now in great forwardnes, Caear, who in imitation of his Predeceor Julius, never intermitted his Studies in the Camp, and much les in other places, refrehing himelf by a hort tay in a pleaant Village of Campania, would needs be entertained with the rehearal of ome part of it. Virgil recited with a marvellous Grace, and weet Accent of Voice, but his Lungs failing him, Mecaenas himelf upplied his place for what remained. Such a piece of condecenion wou'd now be very urprizing, but it was no more than cutomary amongt Friends, when Learning pas'd for Quality. Lelius, the econd Man of Rome in his time, had done as much for that Poet, out of whoe Dros he would ometimes pick Gold; as himelf aid, when one found him reading Ennius: (the like he did by ome Veres of Varro, and Pacuvius, Lucretius, and Cicero, which he inerted into his Works.) But Learned Men then liv'd eay and familiarly with the great: Augutus himelf would ometimes it down betwixt Virgil and Horace, and ay jeatingly, that he ate betwixt Sighing and Tears, alluding to the Athma of one, and Rheumatick Eyes of the other; he would frequently Correpond with them, and never leave a Letter of theirs unanwered: Nor were they under the contraint of formal Supercriptions in the beginning, nor of violent Superlatives at the cloe of their Letter: The invention of thee is a Modern Refinement. In which this may be remarked, in paing, that (humble Servant) is repect, but (Friend) an affront, which notwithtanding implies the former, and a great deal more. Nor does true Greatnes loe by uch Familiarity; and thoe who have it not, as Mecaenas and Pollio had, are not to be accounted Proud, but rather very Dicreet, in their Reerves. Some Play-houe Beauties do wiely to be een at a ditance, and to have the Lamps twinckle betwixt them and the Spectators.

But now Caear, who tho' he were none of the greatet Souldiers, was certainly the greatet Traveller, of a Prince, that had ever
been, (for which Virgil o dexterouly Complements him, Aeneid. 6.) takes a Voyage to Aegypt, and having happily finih'd that War, reduces that mighty Kingdom into the Form of a Province; over which he appointed Gallus his Lieutenant. This is the ame Peron to whom Virgil addrees his Tenth Patoral; changing, in compliance to his Requet, his purpoe of limiting them to the number of the Mues. The Praies of this Gallus took up a coniderable part of the Fourth Book of the Georgics, according to the general conent of Antiquity: But Caear would have it put out, and yet the Seam in the Poem is till to be dicern'd; and the matter of Aritaeus's recovering his Bees, might have been dipatched in les compas, without fetching the Caues o far, or intereing o many Gods and Goddees in that Affair. Perhaps ome Readers may be inclin'd to think this, tho' very much labour'd, not the mot entertaining part of that Work; o hard it is for the greatet Maters to Paint againt their Inclination. But Caear was content he hou'd be mention'd in the lat Patoral, becaue it might be taken for a Satyrical ort of Commendation; and the Character he there tands under, might help to excue his Cruelty, in putting an Old Servant to death for no very great Crime.

And now having ended, as he begins his Georgics, with olemn mention of Caear, an Argument of his Devotion to him: He begins his Aeneis, according to the common account, being now turn'd of Forty. But that Work had been, in truth, the Subject of much earlier Meditation. Whil't he was working upon the firt Book of it, this p • age, o very remarkable in Hitory, fell out, in which Virgil had a great hare.

Caear, about this time, either cloy'd with Glory, or terrifi'd by the Example of his Predeceor; or to gain the Credit of Moderation with the People, or poibly to feel the Pule of his Friends, deliberated whether he hould retain the Soveraign Power, or retore the Commonwealth. Agrippa, who was a very honet Man, but whoe View was of no great extent, advis'd him to the latter; but Mecaenas, who had throughly tudied his Mater's Temper, in an Eloquent Oration, gave contrary Advice. That Emperour was too Politick to commit the over-ight of Cromwell, in a deliberation omething reembling this. Cromwell had never been more deirous of the Power, than he was afterwards of the Title of King: And there was nothing, in which the Heads of the Parties, who were all his Creatures, would not comply with him: But by too vehement Allegation of Arguments againt it, he, who had out-witted every body beides, at lat out-witted himelf, by too deep diimulation: For his Council, thinking to make their Court by aenting to his judgment, voted unanimouly for him againt his Inclination; which urpriz'd and troubled him to uch a degree, that as oon as he had got into his Coach, he fell into a Swoon. But Caear knew his People better, and his Council being thus divided, he ask'd Virgil's Advice: Thus a Poet had the Honour of determining the greatet Point that ever was in Debate, betwixt the Son-in-Law, and Favourite of Caear. Virgil deliver'd his Opinion in Words to this effect. The change of a Popular into an Abolute Government, has generally been of very ill Conequence: For betwixt the Hatred of the People, and Injutice of the Prince, it of neceity comes to pas that they live in ditrut, and mutual Apprehenions. But if the Commons knew a jut Peron, whom they entirely conided in, it would be for the advantage of all Parties, that uch a one hould be their Soveraign: Wherefore if you hall continue to adminiter Jutice impartially, as hitherto you have done, your Power will prove afe to your elf, and beneficial
to Mankind. This excellent Sentence, which eems taken out of Plato, (with whoe Writings the Grammarians were not much acquainted, and therefore cannot reaonably be upected of Forgery in this matter,) contains the true tate of Affairs at that time: For the Commonwealth Maxims were now no longer practicable; the Romans had only the haughtines of the Old Commonwealth left, without one of its Vi • tues. And this Sentence we find, almot in the ame words, in the firt Book of the Aeneis, which at this time he was writing; and one might wonder that none of his Commentators have taken notice of it. he Compares a Tempet to a Popular Inurrection, as Cicero had compar'd a Sedition to a Storm, a little before.

q.l: Ac veluti magno in populo, cum aepe coorta et
Seditio, aevitque animis ignobile vulgus
Jamque faces, ac axa volant, furor armae minitrat.
Tum pietate gravem, & meritis i forte virum quem
Conpexere ilent, arrectiq • e auribus adtant.
Ille regit dictis animos, & pectora mulcet.

div.p: Piety and Merit were the two great Virtues which Virgil every where attributes to Augutus, and in which that Prince, at leat Politickly, if not o truly, fix'd his Character, as appears by the Marmor Anc <…> . and everal of his Medals. Franhemius, the Learn'd Supplementor of Livy, has inerted this Relation into his Hitory; nor is there any good Reaon, why Ruaeus hould account it fabulous. The Title of a Poet in thoe days did not abate, but heighten the Character of the gravet Senator. Virgil was one of the bet and wiet Men of his time, and in o popular eteem, that one hundred Thouand Romans roe when he came into the Theatre, and paid him the ame Repect they us'd to Caear himelf, as Tacitus aures us. And if Augutus invited Horace to ait him in Writing his Letters, and every body knows that the recripta Imperatorum were the Laws of the Empire; Virgil might well deerve a place in the Cabinet-Council.

And now Virgil proecutes his Aeneis, which had Anciently the Title of the Imperial Poem, or Roman Hitory, and deervedly; for though he were too Artful a Writer to et down Events in exact Hitorical order, for which Lucan is jutly blam'd; yet are all the mot coniderable Affairs and Perons of Rome compriz'd in this Poem. He deduces the Hitory of Italy from before Saturn to the Reign of King Latinus; and reckons up the Succeors of Aeneas, who Reign'd at Alba, for the pace of three hundred Years, down to the Birth of Romulus; decribes the Perons and principal Exploits of all the Kings, to their Expulion, and the ettling of the Commonwealth. After this, he touches promicuouly the mot remarkable Occurrences at home and abroad, but inits more particularly upon the Exploits of Augutus; inomuch, that tho' this Aertion may appear, at firt, a little urprizing; he has in his Works deduc'd the Hitory of a coniderable part of the World from its Original, thro' the Fabulous and Heroick Ages, thro' the Monarchy and Commonwealth of Rome, for the pace of four Thouand Years, down to within les than Forty of our Saviour's time, of whom he has preerv'd a mot Illutrious Prophecy. Beides this, he points at many remarkable Paages of Hitory under eign'd Names: the detruction of Alba, and Veii, under that of Troy: The Star Venus, which, Varro ays, guided Aeneas in his Voyage to Italy, in that Vere,
Matre deâ montrante viam.
Romulus his Lance taking Root, and Budding, is decrib'd in that Paage concerning Polydorus, lib. 3.

q.l: —Confixum ferrea texit
Telorum eges, & jaculis increvit acutis.

div.p:
The Stratagem of the Trojans boring Holes in their Ships, and inking them, left the Latins hould Burn them, under that Fable of their being transform'd into Sea-Nymphs: And therefore the Ancients had no uch Reaon to condemn that Fable as groundles and aburd. Cocles wimming the River Tyber, after the Bridge was broken down behind him, is exactly painted in the Four lat Veres of the Ninth Book, under the Character of Turnus. Marius hiding himelf in the Moras of Minturnae, under the Peron of Sinon:
Limooque lacu per Noctem obcurus in ulvâ
Delitus—

Thoe Veres in the Second Book concerning Priam;
Jacet ingens littore truncus, &c.
eem originally made upon Pompey the Great. He eems to touch the Imperious, and Intriguing Humour of the Empres Livia, under the Character of Juno. The irreolute and weak Lepidus is well repreented under the Peron of King Latinus; Augutus with the Character of Pont. Max. under that of Aeneas; and the rah Courage (always Unfortunate in Virgil) of Marc Anthony in Turnus; the railing Eloquence of Cicero in his Phillipics is well imitated in the Oration of Drances; the dull faithful Agrippa, under the peron of Achates; accordingly this Character is flat: Achates kills but one Man, and himelf receives one light Wound, but neither ays nor does any thing very coniderable in the whole Poem. Curio, who old his Country for about Two hundred Thouand Pound, is touch'd in that Vere.
Vendidit hic auro patriam, dominumque potentem.
Impouit.—
Livy relates that preently after the death of the two Scipio's in Spain, when Martius took upon him the Command, a Blazing Meteor hone around his Head, to the atonihment of his Souldiers: Virgil transfers this to Aeneas.
Laetaque vomunt duo tempora flammas.
It is trange that the Commentators have not taken notice of this. Thus the ill Omen which happen'd a little before the Battel of Thraimen, when ome of the Centurions Lances took Fire miraculouly, is hinted in the like accident which befel Acetes, before the Burning of the Trojan Fleet in Sicily. The Reader will eaily find many more uch Intances. In other Writers there is often well cover'd Ignorance; in Virgil, conceal'd Learning.

His ilence of ome Illutrious Perons is no les worth obervation. He ays nothing of Scaevola, becaue he attempted to Aainate a King, tho' a declar'd Enemy. Nor of the Younger Brutus; for he effected what the other endeavour'd. Nor of the Younger Cato, becaue he was an implacable Enemy of Julius Caear; nor could the mention of him be pleaing to Augutus; and that Paage
His Dantem jura Catonem,
may relate to his Office, as he was a very evere Cenor. Nor would he name Cicero, when the occaion of mentioning him came full in his way; when he peaks of Catiline; becaue he afterwards approv'd the Murder of Caear, tho' the Plotters were too wary to trut the Orator with their Deign. Some other Poets knew the Art of Speaking well; but Virgil, beyond this, knew the admirable Secret of being eloquently ilent. Whatoever was mot curious in Fabius Pictor, Cato the Elder, Varro, in the Aegyptian Antiquities, in the Form of Sacrifice, in the Solemnities
of making Peace and War, is preerv'd in this Poem. Rome is till above ground, and flourihing in Virgil. And all this he does with admirable brevity. The Aeneis was once near twenty times bigger than he left it; o that he pent as much time in blotting out, as ome Moderns have done in Writing whole Volumes. But not one Book has his finihing Strokes: The ixth eems one of the mot perfect, the which, after long entreaty, and ometimes threats of Augutus, he was at lat prevail'd upon to recite: This fell out about four Years before his own Death: That of Marcellus, whom Caear deign'd for his Succeor, happen'd a little before this Recital: Virgil therefore with his uual dexterity, inerted his Funeral Panegyrick in thoe admirable Lines, beginning,
O nate, ingentem luctum ne quaere tuorum, &c.
His Mother, the Excellent Octavia, the bet Wife of the wort Husband that ever was, to divert her Grief, would be of the Auditory. The Poet artificially deferr'd the naming Marcellus, 'till their Paions were rais'd to the highet; but the mention of it put both Her and Augutus into uch a Paion of weeping, that they commanded him to proceed no further; Virgil anwer'd, that he had already ended that Paage. Some relate, that Octavia fainted away; but afterwards he preented the Poet with two Thouand one Hundred Pounds, odd Money; a round Sum for Twenty Seven Veres. Another Writer ays, that with a Royal Magnificence, he order'd him May Plate, unweigh'd, to a great value.

And now he took up a Reolution of Travelling into Greece, there to et the lat Hand to this Work; purpoing to devote the ret of his Life to Philoophy, which had been always his principal Paion. He jutly thought it a foolih Figure for a grave Man to be over-taken by Death, whilt he was weighing the Cadence of Words, and meauring Veres; unles Neceity hould contrain it, from which he was well ecur'd by the liberality of that I earned Age. But he was not aware, that whilt he allotted three Years for the Reviing of his Poem, he drew Bills upon a failing Bank: For unhappily meeting Augutus at Athens, he thought himelf oblig'd to wait upon him into Italy, but being deirous to ee all he could of the Greek Antiquities, he fell into a languihing Ditemper at Megara; this, neglected at firt, prov'd Mortal. The agitation of the Veel, for it was now Autumn, near the time of his Birth, brought him o low, that he could hardly reach Brindii. In his Sicknes he frequently, and with great importunity, call'd for his Scrutore, that he might Burn his Aeneis, but Augutus interpoing by his Royal Authority, he made his lat Will, of which omething hall be aid afterwards. And conidering probably how much Homer had been disfigur'd by the Arbitrary Compilers of his Works, oblig'd Tucca and Varius to add nothing, nor o much as fill up the Breaks he left in his Poem. He order'd that his Bones hould be carried to Naples, in which place he had pas'd the mot agreeable part of his Life. Augutus, not only as Executor, and Friend, but according to the Duty of the Pont. Max. when a Funeral happen'd in his Family, took care himelf to ee the Will punctually executed. He went out of the World with all that calmnes of Mind with which the Ancient Writer of his Life ays he came into it. Making the Incription of his Monument himelf; for he began and ended his Poetical Compoitions with an Epitaph. And this he made exactly according to the Law of his Mater Plato on uch occaions, without the leat oftentation.

q.l: I ung Flocks, Tillage, Heroes; Mantua gave
Me Life, Branduium Death, Naples a Grave.

l.hi: A hort Account of his Peron, Manners and Fortune.

div.p: HE was of a very warthy Complexion, which might proceed from the Southern Extraction of his Father, tall and wide-houlder'd, o that he may be thought to have decrib'd himelf under the Character of Muaeus, whom he calls the bet of Poets.

q.l: —Medium nam plurima turba
Hunc habet, atque humeris ex tantem upicit altis.

div.p: His Sicklines, Studies, and the Troubles he met with, made his Hair gray before the uual time; he had an heitation in his Speech, as many other great Men: It being rarely found that a very fluent Elocution, and depth of judgment meet in the ame Peron. His Apect and Behaviour rutick, and ungraceful: And this defect was not likely to be rectify'd in the place where he firt liv'd, nor afterwards, becaue the weaknes of his Stomach would not permit him to ue his Exercies; he was frequently troubled with the Head-ach, and pitting of Blood; pare of Dyet, and hardly drank any Wine. Bahful to a fault; and when People crouded to ee him, he would lip into the next Shop, or by-paage, to avoid them. As this Character could not recommend him to the fair Sex; he eems to have as little conideration for them as Euripides himelf. There is hardly the Character of one good Woman to be found in his Poems: He ues the Word [Mulier] but once in the whole Aeneis, then too by way of Contempt, rendring literally a piece of a Vere out of Homer. In his Patorals he is full of invectives againt Love: In the Georgics he appropriates all the rage of it to the Females. He makes Dido, who never deerv'd that Character, Lutful and Revengeful to the utmot degree; o as to dye devoting her Lover to detruction; o changeable, that the Detinies themelves could not fix the time of her Death. But Iris, the Emblem of Incontancy, mut determine it. Her Siter is omething wore. He is o far from paing uch a Complement upon Helen, as the grave Old Councellour in Homer does, after nine Years War, when upon the ight of her he breaks out into this Rapture in the preence of King Priam,

l.hi: None can the caue of thee long Wars depie;

q.l: The Cot bears no proportion to the Prize:
Majetick Charms in every Feature hine;
Her Air, her Port, her accent is Divine.
However let the fatal Beauty go, &c.

div.p:
Virgil is o far from this complaiant Humour, that his Heroe falls into an unmanly and ill-tim'd deliberation, whether he hould not kill her in a Church; which directly contradicts what Deiphobus ays of her, Aeneid 6. in that place where every body tells the truth. He transfers the dogged Silence of Ajax his Ghot, to that of Dido; tho' that be no very natural Character to an injur'd Lover, or a Woman. He brings in the Trojan Matrons etting their own Fleet on Fire; and running afterwards, like Witches on their Sabbat, into the Woods. He betows indeed ome Ornaments upon the Character of Camilla; but oon abates his Favour, by calling her apera & horrenda Virgo: He places her in the Front of the line for an ill Omen of the Battel, as one of the Ancients has oberv'd; (we may oberve, on this occaion, it is an Art peculiar to Virgil, to intimate the Event by ome preceding Accident.) He hardly ever decribes the riing of the Sun, but with ome circumtance which foreignifies the Fortune of the Day. For intance, when Aeneas leaves Africa and Queen Dido, he thus decribes the fatal Morning:
Tithoni croceum linguens Aurora cubile.
[And for the Remark, we tand indebted to the curious Pencil of Pollio.] The Mourning Fields (Aeneid. 6.) are crowded with Ladies of a lot Reputation:
Hardly one Man gets admittance, and that is Caeneus, for a very good Reaon. Latinus his Queen is turbulent, and ungovernable, and at lat hangs her elf: And the fair Lavinia is diobedient to the Oracle, and to the King, and looks a little flickering after Turnus. I wonder at this the more, becaue Livy repreents her as an excellent Peron, and who behav'd her elf with great Widom in her Regency during the minority of her Son: So that the Poet has done her Wrong, and it reflects on her Poterity. His Goddees make as ill a Figure; Juno is always in a rage, and the Fury of Heaven: Venus grows o unreaonably confident, as to ask her Husband to forge Arms for her Batard Son; which were enough to provoke one of a more Phlegmatick Temper than Vulcan was. Notwithtanding all this raillery of Virgil's, he was certainly of a very Amorous dipoition, and has decrib'd all that is mot delicate in the Paion of Love; but he Conquer'd his natural Inclinations by the help of Philoophy; and refin'd it into Friendhip, to which he was extreamly enible. The Reader will admit of or reject the following Conjecture, with the free leave of the Writer, who will be equally pleas'd either way. Virgil had too great an Opinion of the Influence of the Heavenly Bodies: An Ancient Writer ays, that he was born under the Sign of Virgo, with which Nativity perhaps he pleas'd himelf, and would exemplifie her Vertues in his Life. Perhaps it was thence that he took his Name of Virgil and Parthenias, which does not necearily ignifie Bae-born. Donatus, and Servius, very good Grammarians, give a quite contrary ene of it. He eems to make alluion to this Original of his Name in that Paage,
Illo Virgilium me tempore dulcis alebat,
Parthenope.

And this may erve to illutrate his Complement to Caear, in which he invites him into his own Contellation,
Where, in the void of Heaven, a place is free,
Betwixt the Scorpion, and the Maid for thee.
Thus placing him betwixt Jutice and Power, and in a Neighbour Manion to his own; for Virgil uppos'd Souls to acend again to their proper Stars. Being therefore of this Humour, it is no wonder that he refus'd the Embraces of the Beautiful Plotia, when his indicreet Friend almot threw her into his Arms.

But however he tood affected to the Ladies, there is a dreadful Accuation brought againt him for the mot unnatural of all Vices, which by the Malignity of Humane nature has found more Credit in latter times than it did near his own. This took not its rie o much from the Alexis, in which Patoral there is not one immodet Word; as from a ort of ill-nature, that will not let any one be without the imputation of ome Vice; and principally becaue he was o trict a follower of Socrates and Plato. In order therefore to his Vindication, I hall take the matter a little higher.

The Cretans were Anciently much addicted to Navigation, inomuch that it became A Greek Proverb, (tho' omitted, I think, by the Indutrious Eramus,) A Cretan that does not know the Sea. Their Neighbourhood gave them occaion of frequent Commerce with the Phaenicians, that accured People, who infected the Wetern World with endles Supertitions, and gros immoralities. From them it is probable, that the Cretans learn'd this infamous Paion, to which they were o much addicted, that Cicero remarks, in his Book de Rep. that it was a digrace for a young Gentleman to be without Lovers. Socrates, who was a great Admirer of the Cretan Contitutions, et his excellent Wit to find out ome good Caue, and Ue of this Evil Inclination, and therefore gives an Account, wherefore
Beauty is to be lov'd, in the following Paage; for I will not trouble the Reader, weary perhaps already with a long Greek Quotation. There is but one Eternal, Immutable, niform Beauty; in contemplation of which, our Soveraign Happines does conit: And therefore a true Lover coniders Beauty and Proportion as o many Steps and Degrees, by which he may acend from the particular to the general, from all that is lovely of Feature, or regular in Proportion, or charming in Sound, to the general Fountain of all Beauty and Perfection. And if you are o much tranported with the ight of Beautiful Perons, as to wih neither to Eat or drink, but pas your whole Life in looking on them; to what extaie would it raie you to behold the Original Beauty, not fill'd up with Fleh and Blood, or varnih'd with a fading mixture of Colours, and the ret of Mortal Trifles and Fooleries, but eparate, unmix'd, uniform, and divine, &c. Thus far Socrates, in a train, much beyond the Socrate Cre¯tien of Mr. Balac: And thus that admirable Man lov'd his Phoedon, his Charmides, and Theatetus; and thus Virgil lov'd his Alexander, and Cebes, under the feign'd Name of Alexis: He receiv'd them illiterate, but return'd them to their Maters, the one a good Poet, and the other an excellent Grammarian: And to prevent all poible Miinterpretations, he warily inerted into the liveliet Epiode in the whole Aeneis, thee words,
Nius amore pio pueri.
And in the Sixth, Quique pii vates. He feems fond of the Words, catus, pius, Virgo, and the Compounds of it; and ometimes tretches the Ue of that word further than one would think he reaonably hould have done, as when he attributes it to Paiphaé her elf.

Another Vice he is Tax'd with, is Avarice; becaue he dy'd Rich, and o indeed he did in comparion of modern Wealth; his Etate amounts to near Seventy Five Thouand Pounds of our Money: But Donatus does not take notice of this as a thing extraordinary; nor was it eteem'd o great a Matter, when the Cah of a great part of the World lay at Rome; Antony himelf betow'd at once Two Thouand Acres of Land in one of the bet Provinces of Italy, upon a ridiculous Poet, who is nam'd by Cicero and Virgil. A late Cardinal us'd to purchae ill flattery at the Expence of 100000 Crowns a Year. But beides Virgil's other Benefactors, he was much in favour with Augutus, whoe Bounty to him had no limits, but uch as the Modety of Virgil precrib'd to it. Before he had made his own Fortune, he etled his Etate upon his Parents and Brothers; ent them Yearly large Sums, o that they liv'd in great Plenty and Repect; and at his Death, divided his Etate betwixt Duty and Gratitude, leaving one half to his Relations, and the other to Mecenas, to Tucca and Varius, and a coniderable Legacy to Augutus, who had introduc'd a politick Fahion of being in every bodies Will; which alone was a fair Revenue for a Prince. Virgil hews his detetation of this Vice, by placing in the front of the Damn'd thoe who did not relieve their Relations and Friends; for the Romans hardly ever extended their Liberality further; and therefore I do not remember to have met in all the Latin Poets, one Character o noble as that hort one in Homer.

q.l: — < in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > —

div.p:
On the other hand, he gives a very advanc'd place in Elyium to good Patriots, &c. Oberving in all his Poem, that Rule o Sacred amongt the Romans, That there hou'd be no Art allow'd, which did not tend to the improvement of the People in Virtue. And this was the Principle too of our Excellent Mr. Waller, who us'd to ay that he wou'd raze any Line out of his Poems, which did not imply ome Motive to Virtue; but he was unhappy in the choice of the Subject of his admirable vein in Poetry. The
Countes of C. was the Helen of her Country. There is nothing in Pagan Philoophy more true, more jut, and regular than Virgil's Ethics; and it is hardly poible to it down to the erious peruual of his Works, but a Man hall rie more dipos'd to virtue and goodnes, as well as mot agreeably entertain'd. The contrary to which dipoition, may happen ometimes upon the reading of Ovid, of Martial, and everal other econd rate Poets. But of the Craft and Tricking part of Life, with which Homer abounds, there is nothing to be found in Virgil; and therefore Plato, who gives the former o many good words, perfumes, Crowns, but at lat Complementally Banihes him his Commonwealth, wou'd have intreated Virgil to tay with him, (if they had liv'd in the ame Age,) and intruted him with ome important Charge in his Government. Thus was his Life as chat as his Stile, and thoe who can Critick his Poetry, can never find a blemih in his Manners; and one would rather wih to have that purity of Mind, which the Satyrit himelf attributes to him; that friendly dipoition, and evennes of temper, and patience, which he was Mater of in o eminent a degree, than to have the honour of being Author of the Aeneis, or even of the Georgics themelves.

Having therefore o little relih for the uual amuements of the world, he proecuted his Studies without any coniderable interruption, during the whole coure of his Life, which one may reaonably conjecture to have been omething longer than 52 years; and therefore it is no wonder that he became the mot general Scholar that Rome ever bred, unles ome one hould except Varro. Beides the exact knowledge of Rural Affairs, he undertood Medicine, to which Profeion he was deign'd by his Parents. A Curious Florit, on which Subject one wou'd wih he had writ, as he once intended: So profound a Naturalit, that he has olv'd more Phaenomena of Nature upon ound Principles, than Aritotle in his Phyics. He tudied Geometry, the mot oppoite of all Sciences to a Poetick Genius, and Beauties of a lively imagination; but this promoted the order of his Narrations, his propriety of Language, and clearnes of Expreion, for which he was jutly call'd the Pillar of the Latin Tongue. This Geometrical Spirit was the caue, that to fill up a Vere he would not inert one uperfluous word; and therefore deerves that Character which a Noble and Judicious Critick has given him, Eay of Poetry. That he never ays too little nor too much. Nor cou'd any one ever fill up the Veres he left imperfect. There is one upply'd near the beginning of the Firt Book; Virgil left the Vere thus.
—Hic illius arma,
Hic currus fuit—
the ret is none of Virgil's.

He was o good a Geographer, that he has not only left us the finet decription of Italy that ever was; but beides, was one of the few Ancients who knew the true Sytem of the Earth, its being Inhabited round about under the Torrid Zone, and near the Poles. Metrodorus, in his five Books of the Zones, jutifies him from ome Exceptions made againt him by Atronomers. His Rhetorick was in uch general eteem, that Lectures were read upon it in the Reign of Tiberius, and the Subject of Declamations taken out of him. Pollio himelf, and many other Ancients Commented him. His Eteem degenerated into a kind of Supertition. The known Story of Mr. Cowley is an intance of it. But the ortes Virgilianae were condemn'd by St. Augutin, and other Cauits. Abienus, by an odd Deign, put all Virgil and Livy into Iambick Vere; and the Pictures of thoe two were hung in the mot Honourable place of Publick Libraries, and the Deign of taking them down, and detroying Virgil's Works, was look'd upon as one of the mot Extravagant amongt the many Brutih Frenzies of Caligula.

div.head: PREFACE TO THE PASTORALS, With a hort DEFENCE of VIRGIL, Againt ome of the Reflections of Monieur Fontanelle.
div.p:
AS the Writings of greatet Antiquity are in Vere, o of all orts of Poetry, Patorals eem the mot Ancient; being form'd upon the Model of the Firt Innocence, and Simplicity, which the Moderns, better to dipence themelves from imitating, have wiely thought fit to treat as Fabulous, and impracticable; and yet they, by obeying the unophiticated Dictates of Nature, enjoy'd the mot valuable Bleings of Life; a vigorous Health of Body, with a contant erenity, and freedom of Mind, whilt we, with all our fanciful Refinements, can carcely pas an Autumn without ome acces of a Feaver, or a whole Day, not ruffled by ome unquiet Paion. He was not then look'd upon as a very Old Man; who reach'd to a greater Number of Years, than in thee times an ancient Family can reaonably pretend to; and we know the Names of everal, who aw, and practis'd the World for a longer pace of time, than we can read the Account of in any one entire Body of Hitory. In hort, they invented the mot ueful Arts, Patorage, Tillage, Geometry, Writing, Muick, Atronomy, &c. Whilst the Moderns, like Extravagant Heirs, made rich by their Indutry, ingratefully deride the good Old Gentlemen, who left them the Etate. It is not therefore to be wonder'd at, that Patorals are fallen into Dieteem, together with that Fahion of Life, upon which they were grounded. And methinks, I ee the Reader already uneaie at this Part of Virgil, counting the Pages, and poting to the Aeneis; o delightful an entertainment is the very Relation of publick Michief, and laughter, now become to Mankind: and yet Virgil pas'd a much different judgment on his own Works: He valu'd mot this part, and his Georgics, and depended upon them for his Reputation with Poterity: But Cenures himelf in one of his Letters to Augutus, for medling with Heroics, the Invention of a degenerating Age. This is the Reaon that the Rules of Patoral, are o little known or tudied. Aritotle, Horace, and the Eay of Poetry, take no notice of it. And Mr. Boileau, one of the mot accurate of the Moderns, becaue he never loes the Ancients out of his Sight, betows carce half a Page on it.
It is the Deign therefore of the few following pages, to clear this ort of Writing from vulgar Prejudices; to vindicate our Author from ome unjut Imputations; to look into ome of the Rules of this ort of Poetry, and Enquire what ort of Verification is mot proper for it, in which point we are o much inferiour to the Ancients; that this Conideration alone, were enough to make ome Writers think as they ought, that is, Meanly, of their own Performances.

As all orts of Poetry conit in imitation; Patoral is the imitation of a Shepherd conider'd under that Character: It is requiite therefore to be a little inform'd of the Condition, and Qualification of thee Shepherds.

One of the Ancients has oberv'd truly, but Satyrically enough, that Mankind is the Meaure of every thing: And thus by a gradual improvement of this mitake, we come to make our own Age and Countrey the Rule and Standard of others, and our elves at lat the meaure of them all. We figure the Ancient Countrey-men like our own, leading a painful Life in Poverty and Contempt, without Wit, or Courage, or Education: But Men had quite different Notions of thee things, for the firt four Thouand Years of the World; Health and Strength were then in more eteem than the refinements of Pleaure; and it was accounted a great deal more Honourable to Till the Ground, or keep a Flock of Sheep, than to diolve in Wantonnes, and effeminating Sloath. Hunting has now an Idea of Quality join'd to it, and is become the mot important Buines in the Life of a Gentleman; Antiently it was quite otherways. Mr. Fleury has everely remark'd, that this Extravagant Paion for Hunting is a trong Proof of our Gothic Extraction, and hews an affinity of Humour with the Savage Americans. The Barbarous Franks and other Germans, (having neither Corn, nor Wine of their own growth,) when they pas'd the Rhine, and poes'd themelves of Countreys better Cultivated, left the Tillage of the Land to the Old Proprietors; and afterwards did hazard their Lives as freely for their Diverion, as they had done before for their neceary ubitance. The Englih gave this age the Sacred tamp of Fahion, and from hence it is that mot of our Terms of Hunting are French. The Reader will, I hope, give me his Pardon for my freedom on this Subject, ince an ill Accident, occaion'd by Hunting, has kept England in pain, thee everal Months together, for one of the bet, and greatet Peers which he has bred for ome Ages; no les Illutrious for Civil Vertues, and Learning, than his Ancetors were for all their Victories in France.

But there are ome Prints till left of the Ancient Eteem for Husbandry and their plain Fahion of Life in many of our Sir-Names, and in the Ecutcheons of the mot Ancient Families, even thoe of the greatet Kings, the Roes, the Lillies, the Thitle, &c. It is generally known, that one of the principal Caues of the Depoing of Mahomet the 4th, was, that he would not allot part of the Day to ome manual Labour, according to the Law of Mahomet, and Ancient Practice of his Predeceors. He that reflects on this will be the les urpriz'd to find that Charlemaign Eight Hundred Years ago, order'd his Children to be intructed in ome Profeion. And Eight Hundred Years yet higher, that Augutus wore no Cloaths but uch as were made by the Hands of the Empres, and her Daughters; and Olympias did the ame for Alexander the Great. Nor will he wonder that the Romans, in great exigency, ent for their Dictator from the Plow, whoe whole Etate was but of Four Acres; too little a pot now for the Orchard, or Kitchin-Garden of a Private Gentleman. It is commonly known, that the Founders of three the mot renown'd Monarchies in the World, were Shepherds: And the Subject of Husbandry has been adorn'd
by the Writings and Labour of more than twenty Kings. It ought not therefore to be matter of urprize to a Modern Writer, that Kings, the Shepherds of the People in Homer, laid down their firt Rudiments in tending their mute Subjects; nor that the Wealth of Ulyes conited in Flocks and Herds, the Intendants over which, were then in equal eteem with Officers of State in latter times. And therefore Eumaeus is call'd < in non-Latin alphabet > in Homer; not o much becaue Homer was a lover of a Countrey Life, to which he rather eems avere, but by reaon of the Dignity and Greatnes of his Trut, and becaue he was the Son of a King, tollen away, and Sold by the Phaenician Pyrates, which the Ingenious Mr. Cowley eems not to have taken notice of. Nor will it eem trange, that the Mater of the Hore to King Latinus, in the Ninth Aeneid, was found in the homely Employment of cleaving Blocks, when news of the firt Skirmih betwixt the Trojans and Latins was brought to him.

Being therefore of uch Quality, they cannot be uppos'd o very ignorant and unpolih'd; the Learning and good breeding of the World was then in the hands of uch People. He who was choen by the conent of all Parties to arbitrate o delicate an affair, as which was the fairet of the three Celebrated Beauties of Heaven; he who had the addres to debauch away Helen from her Husband, her Native Country, and from a Crown, undertood what the French call by the too oft name of Gallantry; he had Accomplihments enough, how ill ue oever he made of them. It eems therefore that Mr. F. had not duly conider'd the matter, when he reflected o everely upon Virgil, as if he had not oberv'd the Laws of decency in his Patorals, in making Shepherds peak to things beide their Character, and above their Capacity. He tands amaz'd that Shepherds hould thunder out, as he exprees himelf, the formation of the World, and that too according to the Sytem of Epicurus. In truth, ays he, page 176. I cannot tell what to make of this whole piece; (the Sixth Pat.) I can neither comprehend the Deign of the Author, nor the Connexion of the parts; firt come the Ideas of Philoophy, and preently after thoe incoherent Fables, &c. To expoe him yet more, he ubjoyns, it is Silenus himelf who makes all this aburd Dicoure. Virgil ays indeed that he had drank too much the day before; perhaps the Debauch hung in his head when he compos'd this Poem, &c. Thus far Mr. F. who, to the digrace of Reaon, as himelf ingenuouly owns, firt built his Houe, and then tudied Architecture; I mean firt Compos'd his Eclogues, and then tudied the Rules. In anwer to this, we may oberve, firt, that this very Patoral which he ingles out to triumph over, was recited by a Famous Player on the Roman Theatre, with marvellous applaue; inomuch that Cicero who had heard part of it only, order'd the whole to be rehears'd, and truck with admiration of it, conferr'd then upon Virgil the Glorious Title of Magnae pes alterae Romae. Nor is it Old Donatus only who relates this, we have the ame account from another very Credible and Ancient Author; o that here we have the judgment of Cicero, and the People of Rome, to confront the ingle Opinion of this adventrous Critick. A Man ought to be well aur'd of his own Abilities, before he attack an Author of etablih'd Reputation. If Mr. F. had perus'd the fragments of the Phaenician Antiquity, trac'd the progres of Learning thro' the Ancient Greek Writers, or o much as Conulted his Learned Countrey-Man Huetius, he would have found, (which
falls out unluckily for him) that a Chaldaean Shepherd dicover'd to the Aegyptians and Greeks the Creation of the World. And what Subject more fit for uch a Patoral, than that Great Affair which was firt notified to the World by one of that Profeion? Nor does it appear, (what he takes for granted) that Virgil decribes the Original of the World according to the Hypotheis of Epicurus; he was too well een in Antiquity to commit uch a gros Mitake; there is not the leat mention of Chance in that whole paage, nor of the Clinamen Principiorum, o peculiar to Epicurus's Hypotheis. Virgil had not only more Piety, but was of too nice a Judgment to introduce a God denying the Power and Providence of the Deity, and inging a Hymn to the Atoms, and Blind Chance. On the contrary, his Decription agrees very well with that of Moes; and the Learn'd Commentator D'Acier, who is o confident that Horace had perus'd the Sacred Hitory, might with greater Reaon have affirm'd the ame thing of Virgil. For, beides that Famous Paage in the Sixth Aeneid, (by which this may be illutrated,) where the word Principio is us'd in the front of both by Moes and Virgil, and the Seas are firt mention'd, and the Spiritus intus alit, which might not improbably, as Mr. D'Acier would ugget, allude to the Spirit moving upon the face of the Waters; But omitting this parallel place, the ucceive formation of the World is evidently decrib'd in thee words,
Rerum paulatim umere formas;
