And 'tis hardly poible to render more literally that vere of Moes,

Let the Waters be gathered into one place, and let the dry Land appear, than in this of Virgil,
Jam durare olum, & dicludere Nerea Ponto.
After this the formation of the Sun is decrib'd (exactly in the Moaical order,) and next the production of the firt Living Creatures, and that too in a mall number, (till in the ame method.)

q.l: Rara per ignotos errent animalia montes.

div.p: And here the foreaid Author would probably remark, that Virgil keeps more exactly to the Moaick Sytem, than an Ingenious Writer, who will by no means allow Mountains to be coaeval with the World. Thus much will make it probable at leat, that Virgil had Moes in his thoughts rather than Epicurus, when he compos'd this Poem. But it is further remarkable, that this paage was taken from a Song attributed to Apollo, who himelf too unluckily had been a Shepherd, and he took it from another yet more ancient, compos'd by the firt Inventer of Muick, and at that time a Shepherd too; and this is one of the Noblet Fragments of Greek Antiquity; and becaue I cannot uppoe the Ingenious Mr. F. one of their number, who pretend to cenure the Greeks, without being able to ditinguih Greek from Epheian Characters, I hall here et down the Lines from which Virgil took this paage, tho' none of the Commentators have oberv'd it.

q.l: — < in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

div.p: So that our Poet here with great Judgment, as always, follows the ancient Cutom of beginning their more Solemn Songs with the Creation, and does it too mot properly under the peron of a Shepherd; and thus the firt and bet Employment of Poetry was to compoe Hymns in Honour of the Great Creator of the Univere.

Few words will uffice to anwer his other Objections. He demands why thoe everal Transformations are mention'd in that Poem? And is not Fable then the Life and Subject of Poetry? Can himelf aign a more proper Subject of Patoral, than the Saturnia Regna, the Age and Scene of this kind of Poetry? What Theme more fit for the Song of a God, or to imprint Religious awe, than the Omnipotent Power of transforming the Species of Creatures at their pleaure? Their Families liv'd in Groves, near clear Springs; and what better warning could be given to the hopeful young Shepherds, than that they hould not gaze too much into the Liquid dangerous Looking-glas, for fear of being toln by the Water-Nymphs, that is, falling and being drown'd, as Hylas was? Paiphea's montrous paion for a Bull, is certainly a Subject enough fitted for Bucolic's? Can Mr. F. Tax Silenus for fetching too far the Transformation of the Siters of Phaeton into Trees, when perhaps they at at that very time under the hopitable hade of thoe Alders or Poplars? Or the Metamorphoes of Philomela into that ravihing Bird, which makes the weetet muick of the Groves? If he had look'd into the Ancient Greek Writers, or o much as Conulted honet Servius, he would have dicover'd that under the Allegory of this drunkennes of Silenus, the refinement and exaltation of Mens Minds by Philoophy was intended. But if the Author of thee Reflections can take uch flights in his Wine, it is almot pity that drunkennes hou'd be a Sin, or that he hou'd ever want good tore of Burgundy, and Champaign. But indeed he eems not to have ever drank out of Silenus his Tankard, when he made either his Critique, or Patorals.

His Cenure on the Fourth eems wore grounded than the other; it is Entituled in ome ancient Manucripts, The Hitory of the Renovation of the World; he complains that he cannot undertand what is meant by thoe many Figurative Expreions: But if he had conulted the younger Voius his Diertation on this Patoral, or read the Excellent Oration of the Emperour Contantine, made French by a good Pen of their own, he would have found there the plain inerpretation of all thoe Figurative Expreions; and withall, very trong proofs of the truth of the Chritian Religion; uch as Converted Heathens, as Valerianus, and others: And upon account of this Piece, the mot Learn'd of the Latin Fathers calls Virgil a Chritian, even before Chritianity. Cicero takes notice of it in his Books of Divination, and Virgil probably had put it in Vere a coniderable time before the Edition of his Patorals. Nor does he appropriate it to Pollio, or his Son, but Complementally dates it from his Conulhip. And therefore ome one who had not o kind thoughts of Mr. F. as I, would be inclin'd to think him as bad a Catholick as Critick in this place.
I pas by, in repect therefore to ome Books he has wrote ince, a great part of this, and hall only touch briefly ome of the Rules of this ort of Poem.

The Firt is, that an air of Piety upon all occaions hould be maintain'd in the whole Poem: This appears in all the Ancient Greek Writers; as Homer, &c. And Virgil is o exact in the obervation of it, not only in this Work, but in his Aeneis too, that a Celebrated French Writer taxes him for permitting Aeneas to do nothing without the aitance of ome God. But by this it appears, at leat, that Mr. St. Eur. is no Janenit.

Mr. F. eems a little defective in this point; he brings in a pair of Shepherdees diputing very warmly, whether Victoria, (none of the fittet Names for a Shepherdes) be a Goddes, or a Woman. Her great condecenion and compaion, her affability and goodnes, none of the meanet Attributes of the Divinity, pas for convincing Arguments that he could not poibly be a Goddes.
Les Déees toûjours fieres & mépriantes
Ne raureroiént point les Bergeres tremblantes
Par d'obligeans dicours, des ouris gracieux;
Mais tu l'as veu; cette Augute Peronne
Qui vient de paroitre en ces lieux
Prend oin de raurer au moment qu'elle étonne.
Sa bonté decendant ans peine juqu'à nous.
In hort, he has too many Divine Perfections to be a Deity, and therefore he is a Mortal [which was the thing to be prov'd.] It is directly contrary to the practice of all ancient Poets, as well as to the Rules of decency and Religion, to make uch odious Comparions. I am much urpriz'd therefore that he hould ue uch an argument as this.
Cloris, as-tu veu des Déees
Avoir un air i facile & i doux?
Was not Aurora, and Venus, and Luna, and I know not how many more of the Heathen Deities too eaie of acces to Tithonus, to Anchies, and to Endimion? Is there any thing more Sparkih and better humour'd than Venus her accoting her Son in the Dearts of Lybia? or than the behaviour of Pallas to Diomedes, one of the mot perfect and admirable Pieces of all the Iliads; where he condecends to rally him o agreeably; and notwithtanding her evere Vertue, and all the Enigns of Majety, with which he o terribly adorns her elf, condecends to ride with him in his Chariot? But the Odyes are full of greater intances of condecenion than this.

This brings to mind that Famous paage of Lucan, in which he prefers Cato to all the Gods at once, Victrix caua deis placuit ed victa Catoni. Which Brelaeuf has render'd o flatly, and which may be thus Paraphras'd.

q.l: Heaven meanly with the Conquerour did comply,
But Cato rather than ubmit would die.

div.p: It is an unpardonable preumption in any ort of Religion to complement their Princes at the expence of their Deities.
But letting that pas, this whole Eclogue is but a long Paraphrae of a trite Vere in Virgil, and Homer, Nec vox Hominem onat, O Dea certe.
So true is that Remark of the Admirable E. of Rocomon, if apply'd to the Romans, rather I fear than to the Englih, ince his own Death.

l.U: terling Line,

q.l: Drawn to French Wire, would thro' whole pages hine.

div.p: Another Rule is, that the Characters hould repreent that Ancient Innocence, and unpractis'd Plainnes, which was then in the World. P. Rapine has gather'd many Intances of this out of Theocritus, and Virgil; and the Reader can do it as well himelf. But Mr. F. trangres'd this Rule, when he hid himelf in the Thicket, to liten to the private Dicoure of the two Shepherdees. This is not only ill Breeding at Verailles; the Arcadian Shepherdees themelves would have et their Dogs upon one for uch an unpardonable piece of Rudenes.

A Third Rule is, That there hould be ome Ordonnance, ome Deign, or little Plot, which may deerve the Title of a Patoral Scene. This is every where oberv'd by Virgil, and particularly remarkable in the firt Eclogue; the tandard of all Patorals; a Beautiful Landcape preents it elf to your view, a Shepherd with his Flock around him, reting ecurely under a preading Beech, which furnih'd the firt Food to our Ancetors. Another in quite different Situation of Mind and Circumtances, the Sun etting, the Hopitality of the more fortunate Shepherd, &c. And here Mr. F. eems not a little wanting.

A Fourth Rule, and of great importance in this delicate ort of Writing, is, that there be choice diverity of Subjects; that the Eclogues, like a Beautiful Propect, hould Charm by its Variety. Virgil is admirable in this Point, and far urpaes Theocritus, as he does every where, when Judgment and Contrivance have the principal part. The Subject of the firt Patoral is hinted above.

The Second contains the Love of Coridon for Alexis, and the eaonable reproach he gives himelf, that he left his Vines half prun'd, (which according to the Roman Rituals, deriv'd a Cure upon the Fruit that grew upon it) whilt he puru'd an Object undeerving his Paion.
The Third, a harp Contention of two Shepherds for the Prize of Poetry.
The Fourth contains the Dicoure of a Shepherd Comforting himelf in a declining Age, that a better was enuing.

The Fifth a Lamentation for a Dead Friend, the firt draught of which is probably more Ancient than any of the Patorals now extant; his Brother being at firt intended; but he afterwards makes his Court to Augutrus, by turning it into an Apotheis of Julius Caear.
The Sixth is the Silenus.
The Seventh, another Poetical Dipute, firt Compos'd at Mantua.
The Eighth is the Decription of a depairing Lover, and a Magical Charm.
He ets the Ninth after all thee, very modetly, becaue it was particular to himelf; and here he would have ended that Work, if Gallus had not prevail'd upon him to add one more in his Favour.
Thus Curious was Virgil in diverifying his Subjects. But Mr. F. is a great deal too niform; begin where you pleae, the Subject is till the ame. We find it true what he ays of himelf,

He eems to take Patorals and Love-Veres for the ame thing. Has Humaen Nature no other Paion? Does not Fear, Ambition, Avarice, Pride, a Capricio of Honour, and Lazines it elf often Triumph over Love? But this Paion does all, not only in Patorals, but on Modern Tragedies too. A Heroe can no more Fight, or be Sick, or Dye, than he can be Born without a Woman. But Dramatic's have been compos'd in compliance to the Humour of the Age, and the prevailing Inclination of the great, whoe Example has a very powerful Influence, not only in the little Court behind the Scenes, but on the great Theatre of the World. This inundation of Love-Veres 'tis not o much an effect of their Amorounes, as of immoderate Self-love. This being the only ort of Poetry, in which the Writer can, not only without Cenure, but even with Commendation, talk of himelf. There is generally more of the Paion of Narcius, than concern for Chloris and Corinna in this whole Affair. Be pleas'd to look into almot any of thoe Writers, and you hall meet every where that eternal Moy, which the admirable Pachal o judiciouly condemns. Homer can never be enough admir'd for this one o particular Quality, that he never peaks of himelf, either in the Iliad, or the Odyes; and if Horace had never told us his Genealogy, but left it to the Writer of his Life, perhaps he had not been a loer by it. This Conideration might induce thoe great Criticks, Varius and Tucca, to raze out the four firt Veres of the Aeneis, in great meaure, for the ake of that unlucky Ille ego. But extraordinary Genius's have a ort of Prerogative, which may dipence them from Laws, binding to Subject-Wits. However, the Ladies have the les Reaon to be pleas'd with thoe Addrees, of which the Poet takes the greater hare to himelf. Thus the Beau prees into their Dreing-Room, but it is not o much to adore their fair Eyes, as to adjut his own Steenzkirk and Peruke, and et his Countenance in their Glas.

A fifth Rule, (which one may hope will not be conteted) is that the Writer hould hew in his Compoitions, ome competent skill of the Subject matter, that which makes the Character of the Perons introduc'd. In this, as in all other Points of Learning, Decency, and Oeconomy of a Poem, Virgil much excells his Mater Theocritus. The Poet is better skill'd in Husbandry than thoe that get their Bread by it. He decribes the Nature, the Dieaes, the Remedies, the proper places, and Seaons, of Feeding, of Watering their Flocks; the Furniture, Diet; the Lodging and patimes of his Shepherds. But the Perons brought in by Mr. F. are Shepherds in Maquerade, and handle their Sheep-Hook as awkardly, as they do their Oaten-Reed. They Saunter about with their chers Moutons, but they relate as little to the Buines in hand, as the Painter's Dog, or a Dutch Ship, does to the Hitory deign'd. One would upect ome of them, that intead of leading out their Sheep
into the Plains of Mont-Brion, and Marcilli, to the flowry Banks of Lignon, or the Charanthe; that they are driving directly, à la boucherie, to make Money of them. I hope hereafter Mr. F. will chue his Servants better.

A ixth Rule is, That as the Style ought to be natural, clear, and elegant, it hould have ome peculiar relih of the Ancient Fahion of Writing. Parables in thoe times were frequently us'd, as they are till by the Eatern Nations; Philoophical Quetions, Aenigma's, &c. and of this we find Intances in the Sacred Writings, in Homer, Contemporary with King David, in Herodotus, in the Greek Tragedians; this piece of Antiquity is imitated by Virgil with great judgment and dicretion: He has propos'd one Riddle which has never yet been olv'd by any of his Commentators. Tho' he knew the Rules of Rhetorick, as well as Cicero himelf; he conceals that skill in his Patorals, and keeps cloe to the Character of Antiquity: Nor ought the Connexions and Tranitions to be very trict, and regular; this would give the Patorals an Air of Novelty, and of this neglect of exact Connexions, we have intances in the Writings of the Ancient Chinees, of the Jews and Greeks, in Pindar, and other Writers of Dithyrambics, in th • Chorus's of Aechylus, Sophocles, and Euripides. If Mr. F. and Ruaeus, had conider'd this, the one wou'd have par'd his Critic of the Sixth, and the other, his Reflections upon the Ninth Patoral. The over-crupulous care of Connexions, makes the Modern Compoitions oftentimes tedious and flat: And by the omiion of them it comes to pas, that the Penees of the incomparable Mr. Pacal, and perhaps of Mr. Bruyere, are two of the mot Entertaining Books which the Modern French can boat of. Virgil, in this point, was not only faithful to the Character of Antiquity, but Copies after Nature her elf. Thus a Meadow, where the Beauties of the Spring are profuely blended together, makes a more delightful Propect, than a curious Knot of orted Flowers in our Gardens; and we are much more tranported with the Beauty of the Heavens, and admiration of their Creator, in a clear Night, when we behold Stars of all Magnitudes, promicuouly moving together, than if thoe glorious Lights were rank'd in their everal Orders, or reduc'd into the finet Geometrical Figures.

Another Rule omitted by P. Rapine, as ome of his are by me, (for I do not deign an entire Treatie in this Preface,) is, that not only the Sentences hould be hort, and mart, upon which account, he jutly blames the Italian, and French, as too Talkative, but that the whole piece hould be o too. Virgil transgres'd this Rule in his firt Patorals, I mean thoe which he compos'd at Mantua, but rectifi'd the Fault in his Riper Years. This appears by the Culex, which is as long as five of his Patorals put together. The greater part of thoe he finih'd, have les than a Hundred Veres, and but two of them exceed that Number. But the Silenus, which he eems to have deign'd for his Mater-piece, in which he introduces a God inging, and he too full of Inpiration, (which is intended by that ebriety, which Mr. F. o unreaonably ridicules,) tho' it go thro' o vat a Field of Matter, and comprizes the Mythology of near Two Thouand Years, conits but of Fifty Lines; o that its brevity is no les admirable, than the ubject Matter; the noble Fahion of handling it, and the Deity peaking. Virgil keeps up his Characters in this repect too, with the trictet decency: For Poetry and Patime was not the Buines of Mens Lives in thoe days, but only their eaonable Recreation after neceary Labours. And therefore the length of ome of the Modern Italian, and Englih Compoitions, is againt the Rules of this kind of Poey.

I hall add omething very briefly touching the Verification of Patorals, tho' it be a mortifying Conideration to the Moderns. Heroic Vere, as it is commonly call'd, was us'd by the Latins in this ort of Poem, as very Ancient and Natural. Lyrics, Iambics, &c. being Invented afterwards: but there is o great a difference in the Numbers, of which it may be compounded, that it may pas rather for a Genus, than Species, of Vere. Whooever hall compare the numbers of the three following Veres, will quickly be enible of the truth of this Obervation.
div.q: Tityre, tu patulae recubans ub tegmine fagi.
div.p: The firt of the Georgics, Quid faciat laetas egetes, quo ydere terram. and of the Aeneis.
div.q: Arma, virumque cano, Trojae qui Primus ab oris.
div.p:
The Sound of the Veres, is almot as different as the Subjects. But the Greek Writers of Patoral, uually limited themelves to the Example of the firt; which Virgil found o exceedingly difficult, that he quitted it, and left the Honour of that part to Theocritus. It is indeed probable, that what we improperly call rhyme, is the mot Ancient ort of Poetry; and Learned Men have given good Arguments for it; and therefore a French Hitorian commits a gros mitake, when he attributes that Invention to a King of Gaul, as an Englih Gentleman does, when he makes a Roman Emperour the Inventor of it. But the Greeks who undertood fully the force and power of Numbers, oon grew weary of this Childih ort of Vere, as the Younger Voius jutly calls it, and therefore thoe rhyming Hexameters, which Plutarch oberves in Homer himelf, eem to be the Remains of a barbarous Age. Virgil had them in uch abhorrence, that he would rather make a fale Syntax, than what we call a Rhime, uch a Vere as this
Vir precor xori, frater uccurre Sorori. Was paable in Ovid, but the nice Ears in Augutus his Court could not pardon Virgil, for At Regina Pyra. So that the principal Ornament of Modern Poetry, was accounted deformity by the Latins, and Greeks; it was they who invented the different terminations of words, thoe happy compoitions, thoe hort monoyllables, thoe tranpoitions for the elegance of the ound and ene, which are wanting o much in modern Languages. The French ometimes crowd together ten, or twelve Monoyllables, into one disjoynted Vere; they may undertand the nature of, but cannot imitate, thoe wonderful Spondees of Pythagoras, by which he could uddenly pacifie a Man that was in a violent tranport of anger; nor thoe wift numbers of the Priets of Cybele, which had the force to enrage the mot edate and Phlegmatick Tempers. Nor can any Modern put into his own Language the Energy of that ingle Poem of Catullus,
Super alta vectus, Atys &c. Latin is but a corrupt dialect of Greek; and the French, Spanih, and Italian, a corruption of Latine; and therefore a Man might as well go about to peruade me that Vinegar is a Nobler Liquor than Wine, as that the modern Compoitions can be as graceful and harmonious as the Latine it elf. The Greek Tongue very naturally falls into Iambicks, and therefore the diligent Reader may find ix or even and twenty of them in thoe accurate Orations of Iocrates. The Latin as naturally falls into Heroic; and therefore the beginning of Livy's Hitory is half an Hexameter, and that of Tacitus an entire one. The Roman Hitorian decribing the glorious effort of a Colonel to break thro' a Brigade of the Enemies, jut after the defeat at Cannae, falls, unknowingly, into a Vere not unworthy Virgil himelf.

q.l:
Haec ubi dicta dedit, tringit gladium, cuneo
que
Facto per medios, &c.

div.p: Ours and the French can at bet but fall into Blank Vere, which is a fault in Proe. The misfortune indeed is common to us both, but we deerve more compaion, becaue we are not vain of our Barbarities. As Age brings Men back into the tate and infirmities of Childhood, upon the fall of their Empire, the Romans doted into Rhime, as appears ufficiently by the Hymns of the Latin Church; and yet a great deal of the French Poetry does hardly deerve that poor title. I hall give an intance out of a Poem which had the good luck to gain the Prize in 1685, for the Subject deerv'd a Nobler Pen.

q.l: Tous les jours ce grand Roy des autres Roys l'exemple,
S'ouvre un nouveau chemin au faite de ton temple, &c.

div.p: The Judicious Malherbe exploded this ort of Vere near Eighty Years ago. Nor can I forbear wondering at that paage of a Famous Academician, in which he, mot compaionately, excues the Ancients for their not being o exact in their Compoitions, as the Modern French, becaue they wanted a Dictionary, of which the French are at lat happily provided. If Cicero and Demothenes had been o lucky as to have had a Dictionary, and uch a Patron as Cardinal Richelieu, perhaps they might have apir'd to the honour of Balzac's Legacy of Ten Pounds, Le prix de l'Eloquence.

On the contrary, I dare aert that there are hardly ten Lines in either of thoe great Orators, or even in the Catalogue of Homer's Ships, which is not more harmonious, more truly Rythmical, than mot of the French, or Englih Sonnets; and therefore they loe, at leat, one half of their native Beauty by Tranlation.

I cannot but add one Remark on this occaion, that the French Vere is oftentimes not o much as Rhime, in the lowet Sene; for the Childih repetition of the ame Note cannot be call'd Muick; uch Intances are infinite, as in the forecited Poem.
'Epris
Mepris
Trophee
Orphee
caché;
cherché.

Mr. Boileau himelf has a great deal of this < in non-Latin alphabet > , not by his own neglect, but purely by the faultines and poverty of the French Tongue. Mr. F.
at lat goes into the exceive Paradoxes of Mr. Perrault, and boats of the vat number of their Excellent Songs, preferring them to the Greek and Latin. But an ancient Writer of as good Credit, has aur'd us, that Seven Lives would hardly uffice to read over the Greek Odes; but a few Weeks would be ufficient, if a Man were o very idle as to read over all the French. In the mean-time I hould be very glad to ee a Catalogue of but fifty of theirs with
Eay of Poetry. Exact propriety of word and thought. Notwithtanding all the high Encomiums, and mutual Gratulations which they give one another; (for I am far-from cenuring the whole of that Illutrious Society, to which the Learned World is much oblig'd) after all thoe Golden Dreams at the L'Ouvre, that Modern Pieces will be as much valu'd ten, or twelve Ages hence, as the ancient Greek, or Roman, I can no more get it into my head that they will lat o long, than I could believe the Learned Dr. H—K. [of the Royal Society,] if he hould pretend to hew me a Butterflye that had liv'd a thouand Winters.

When Mr. F. wrote his Eclogues, he was o far from equalling Virgil, or Theocritus, that he had ome pains to take before he could undertand in what the principal Beauty, and Graces of their Writings do conit.

epigraph.q: Cum mortuis non nii larvae luctantur.

div.head: To Mr. Dryden, on his Excellent Tranlation of VIRGIL.

lg.l: WHen e're Great VIRGIL's lofty Vere I ee,
The Pompous Scene Charms my admiring Eye:
There different Beauties in perfection meet;
The Thoughts as proper, as the Numbers weet:
And When wild Fancy mounts a daring height,
Judgment teps in, and moderates her flight.
Wiely he manages his Wealthy Store,
Still ays enough, and yet implies till more:
For tho'the weighty Sene be cloely wrought,
The Reader's left t'improve the pleaing thought.
Hence we depair'd to ee an Englih dres
Should e're his Nervous Energy expres;
For who could that in fetter'd Rhyme incloe,
Which without los can carce be told in Proe?
But you, Great Sir, his Manly Genius raie;
And make your Copy hare an equal praie.
O how I ee thee in oft Scenes of Love,
Renew thoe Paions he alone could move!
Here Cupid's Charms are with new Art expret,
And pale Eliza leaves her peaceful ret:
Leaves her Eliium, as if glad to live,
To Love, and Wih, to Sigh, Depair and Grieve,
And Die again for him that would again deceive.
Nor does the Mighty Trojan les appear
Than Mars himelf amidt the torms of War.
Now his fierce Eyes with double fury glow,
And a new dread attends th' impending blow:
The Daunian Chiefs their eager rage abate,
And tho' unwounded, eem to feel their Fate.
Long the rude fury of an ignorant Age,
With barbarous pight prophan'd his Sacred Page.
The heavy Dutchmen with laborious toil,
Wreted his Sene, and cramp'd his vigorous Style:
No time, no pains the drudging Pedants pare;
But till his Shoulders mut the burthen bear.
While thro' the Mazes of their Comments led,
We learn not what he writes, but what they read.
Yet thro' thee Shades of unditinguih'd Night
Appear'd ome glimmering intervals of Light;
'Till mangled by a vile Tranlating Sect,
Like Babes by Witches in Effigie rackt:
'Till Ogleby, mature in dulnes roe,
And Holbourn Dogrel, and low chiming Proe,
His Strength and Beauty did at once depoe.
But now the Magick Spell is at an end,
Since even the Dead in you have found a Friend.
You free the Bard from rude Oppreor's Power,
And grace his Vere with Charms unknown before:
He, doubly thus oblig'd, mut doubting tand,
Which chiefly hould his Gratitude command;
Whether hould claim the Tribute of his Heart,
The Patron's Bounty, or the Poet's Art.
Alike with wonder and delight we view'd
The Roman Genius in thy Vere renew'd:
We aw thee raie oft Ovid's Amorous Fire,
And fit the tuneful Horace to thy Lyre:
We aw new gall imbitter Juvenal's Pen,
And crabbed Perius made politely plain:
Virgil alone was thought too great a task;
What you could carce perform, or we durt ask:
A Task! which Waller's Mue could ne're engage;
A Task! too hard for Denham's tronger rage:
Sure of Succes they ome light Sallies try'd,
But the fenc'd Coat their bold attempts defy'd:
With fear their o're-match'd Forces back they drew,
Quitted the Province Fate reerv'd for you.
In vain thus Philip did the Perians torm;
A Work his Son was detin'd to perform.
O had Rocommon Eay of Tranlated Vere. pag. 26. liv'd to hail the day,
And Sing loud Poeans thro' the crowded way;
When you in Roman Majety appear,

l.hi: Which none know better, and none come o near:

lg.l: The happy Author would with wonder ee,
His Rules were only Prophecies of thee:
And were he now to give Tranlators light,
He'd bid them only read thy Work, and write.
For this great Task our loud applaue is due;
We own old Favours, but mut pres for new.
Th' expecting World demands one Labour more;
And thy lov'd Homer does thy aid implore,
To right his injur'd Works, and et them free
From the lewd Rhymes of groveling Ogleby.
Then hall his Vere in graceful Pomp appear,
Nor will his Birth renew the ancient jar;
On thoe Greek Cities we hall look with corn,
And in our Britain think the Poet Born.

div.head: To Mr. Dryden on his Tranlation of VIRGIL.

lg.l: WE read, how Dreams and Viions heretofore,
The Prophet, and the Poet cou'd inpire;
And make 'em in unuual Rapture oar,
With Rage Divine, and with Poetick Fire.
O could I find it now!—Wou'd Virgil's Shade
But for a while vouchafe to bear the Light;
To grace my Numbers, and that Mue to aid,
Who ings the Poet, that has done him right.
It long has been this Sacred Author's Fate,
To lye at ev'ry dull Tranlator's Will;
Long, long his Mue has groan'd beneath the weight
Of mangling Ogleby's preumptuous Quill.
Dryden, at lat, in his Defence aroe;
The Father now is righted by the Son:
And while his Mue endeavours to dicloe
That Poet's Beauties, he declares her own.
In your mooth, pompous Numbers dret, each Line,
Each Thought, betrays uch a Majetick Touch;
He cou'd not, had he finih'd his Deign,
Have wiht it better, or have done o much.
You like his Heroe, though your elf were free;
And dientangl'd from the War of Wit;
You, who ecure might others danger ee,
And afe from all malicious Cenure it:
Yet becaue Sacred Virgil's Noble Mue,
O'relay'd by Fools, was ready to expire:
To rique your Fame again, you boldly chue,
Or to redeem, or perih with your Sire.
Ev'n firt and lat, we owe him half to you,
For that his Aeneids mis'd their threatned Fate,
Was—that his Friends by ome Prediction knew,
Hereafter who correcting hould tranlate.
But hold my Mue, thy needles Flight retrain,
nles like him thou cou'dt a Vere indite:
To think his Fancy to decribe, is vain,
Since nothing can dicover Light, but Light.
'Tis want of Genius that does more deny;
'Tis Fear my Praie hou'd make your Glory les.
And therefore, like the modet Painter, I
Mut draw the Vail, where I cannot expres.

div.head: To Mr. DRYDEN.
div.l: NO undiputed Monarch Govern'd yet
With Univeral Sway the Realms of Wit:
Nature cou'd never uch Expence afford,
Each everal Province own'd a everal Lord.
A Poet then had his Poetick Wife,
One Mue embrac'd, and Married for his Life.
By the tale thing his appetite was cloy'd,
His Fancy lened, and his Fire detroy'd.
But Nature grown extravagantly kind,
With all her Treaures did adorn your Mind.
The different Powers were then united found,
And you Wit's Univeral Monarch Crown'd.
Your Mighty Sway your great Deert ecures,
And ev'ry Mue and ev'ry Grace is yours.
To none confin'd, by turns you all enjoy,
Sated with this, you to another flye.
So Sultan-like in your Seraglio tand,
While wihing Mues wait for your Command.
Thus no decay, no want of vigour find,
Sublime your Fancy, boundles is your Mind.
Not all the blats of time can do you wrong,
Young pight of Age, in pight of Weaknes trong.
Time like Alcides, trikes you to the ground,
You like Antaeus from each fall rebound.

div.head: To Mr. Dryden on his VIRGIL.

lg.l: TIS aid that Phidias gave uch living Grace,
To the carv'd Image of a beauteous Face,
That the cold Marble might ev'n eem to be
The Life, and the true Life, the Imag'ry.
You pas that Artit, Sir, and all his Powers,
Making the bet of Roman Poets ours;
With uch Effect, we know not which to call
The Imitation, which th' Original.
What Virgil lent, you pay in equal Weight,
The charming Beauty of the Coin no les;
And uch the Majety of your Impres,
You eem the very Author you tranlate.
'Tis certain, were he now alive with us,
And did revolving Detiny contrain,
To dres his Thoughts in Englih o're again,
Himelf cou'd write no otherwie than thus.
His old Encomium never did appear
So true as now; Romans and Greeks ubmit,
Something of late is in our Language writ,
More nobly great than the fam'd Iliads were.

div.head: To Mr. Dryden on his Tranlations.

lg.l: AS Flow'rs tranplanted from a Southern Sky,
But hardly bear, or in the raiing dye,
Miing their Native Sun, at bet retain
But a faint Odour, and but live with Pain:
So Roman Poetry by Moderns taught,
Wanting the Warmth with which its Author wrote,
Is a dead Image, and a worthles Draught.
While we transfue, the nimble Spirit flies,
Ecapes uneen, evaporates, and dyes.
Who then attempt to hew the Ancients Wit,
Mut copy with the Genius that they writ.
Whence we conclude from thy tranlated Song,
So jut, o warm, o mooth, and yet o trong,
Thou Heav'nly Charmer! Soul of Harmony!
That all their Geniues reviv'd in thee.
Thy Trumpet ounds, the dead are rais'd to Light,
New-born they rie, and take to Heav'n their Flight;
Deckt in thy Vere, as clad with Rayes, they hine
All Glorify'd, Immortal and Divine.
As Britain, in rich Soil abounding wide,
Furnih'd for Ue, for Luxury, and Pride,
Yet preads her wanton Sails on ev'ry Shore,
For Foreign Wealth, inatiate till of more;
To her own Wooll, the Silks of Aia joins,
And to her plenteous Harvets, Indian Mines:
So Dryden, not contented with the Fame
Of his own Works, tho' an immortal Name,
To Lands remote he ends his learned Mue,
The Noblet Seeds of Foreign Wit to chue.
Feating our Sene o many various Ways,
Say, Is't thy Bounty, or thy Thirt of Praie?
That by comparing others, all might ee,
Who mot excell'd, are yet excell'd by thee.

div.head: ERRATA.
In the Dedicatory Preface to the Marques of Normanby.
div.p: PAg. 7. line 32. read, of Republican Principles in his Heart. p. 9. where Atis is mention'd as having a claim by Succeion before Aeneas, my Memory betray'd me; for had I conulted Virgil, he calls not the Son of Polites by the name of Atis, but of Priamus. 'Tis true he mentions Atis immediately afterwards, on the account of the Atian Family, from which Julius Caear was decended by his Grandmother, as I have there mention'd. p. 26. towards the bottom of this Page here is a gros Errour, which is eaily corrected, by reading Ten Months intead of Three: the Sene will direct you to the place. p. 28. In the quotation of a vere of Virgil's; for contie r. confie. p. 30 f. Juturna took his opportunity, r. this opportunity. There are other Errata both in fale pointing, and omiions of words, both in the Preface and the Poem, which the Reader will correct without my trouble. I omit them, becaue they only lame my Englih, not detroy my meaning.

div.head: Some of the mot coniderable Errata.
div.p: PAtoral 2. l. 43. r. nor corn the Pipe. Pat. 4. l. 36. for Cold r. Gold. Pat. 6. l. 72. f. this r. thy. In the ame Pat. l. 1. f. Scicilian r. Sicilian. Pat. 8. l. 19. read the whole line thus; Scarce from the World the Shades of Night withdrew. Georgic 1. l. 96. after the word Arbute place the Comma; not after the next word Hazle, as it is printed, which detroys the Sene. The whole Vere is to be thus read, The thin-leav'd Arbute, hazle Graffs receives. l. 139. the note of Interrogation is fale at the end of the Line, it ought to be a Period. l. 393. f. skins r. skims. Geor. 2. l. 203. and 204. the Rhymes of both are fale printed: intead of Wars and prepares, r. War and prepare in the ingular. l. 296. f. tracts r. tracks. Geor. 4. l. 354. And Worms that hun the Light, r. and Lizards hunning Light. Aeneid 1. l. 79. f. Elus r. Eolus. l. 97. r. Eolus again. l. 640. f. Fate r. Fame. l. 1054. f. Dimede r. Diomede. Aen. 2. l. 2. f. the lofty Couch r. his lofty Couch. Aen. 3. l. 40. f. Horrour r. Terrour. l. 142. blot out the Period at the end of the Vere, and place a Comma. Aen. 4. l. 824. f. pious pious r. pious Prince. Aen 5. l. 188. f. ptwo r. Prow. Aen. 6. l. 488. f. but but r. but once only. l. 747. f. van r. vain. l. 1133. f. three r. two. Aen. 7. l. 43. dele the Period at the end of the Vere. l. 266. f. On, (the firt word of the Vere,) r. In. l. 446. f. native Land, r. another Land. l. 549. f. crowns her Lance, r. wreaths her Lance. l. 68. f. fill. r. feed. l. 732. f. reinfor'd r. reinforc'd. l. 946. f. roie Fields r. dewy Fields. l. 1087. f. yied r. yield. Aen. 8. l. 674. f. lifeles Limbs, r. litles Limbs. Aen. 10 l. 497. blot out the Period at the end of the Vere, and place a Comma. l. 735. f. hall. r. will. l. 864. f. loving Lord r. Sov'raign Lord. l. 924. f. Planks were r. Plank was. l. 1286. f. Sholuder r. Shoulder. l. 1311. f. to his Throat the Sword apply'd, r. to the Sword his Throat apply'd. Aen. 11. l. 120. f. Heads and Hands r. their loaded Hands. l. 528. f. Heros r. Heroes.

p.hi: Directions to the Binders, how to place the everal Parts of this Book in Binding.

5. The Names of the econd Subcribers.
7. The Dedication to the Earl of Cheterfield, with an Eay on the Georgics.
9. The Dedication to the Marques of Normanby.

div.head: THE NAMES OF THE SUBSCRIBERS TO THE Cuts of Virgil, Each Subcription being Five Guineas.
The Names of the econd SUBSCRIBERS.

list.head: B.
list.item: Will. Blathwayt, Eq Secretary of War.
Mr. Jo. Bowes, Prebend of Durham.

list.head: C.

figure.head: Ec. 1. l. 1
figure.p: To the Right Honble John Lord Sommers Baron of Eresham Ld High Chancellr: of England &c.

div.head: Virgil's Patorals.
The Firt Patoral. OR Tityrus and Meliboeus.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Occaion of the Firt Patoral was this. When Augutus had etled himelf in the Roman Empire, that he might reward his Veteran Troops for their pat Service, he ditributed among 'em all the Lands that lay about Cremona and Mantua: turning out the right Owners for having ided with his Enemies. Virgil was a Sufferer among the ret; who afterwards recover'd his Etate by Mecaenas's Interceion, and as an Intance of his Gratitude compos'd the following Patoral; where he ets out his own Good Fortune in the Peron of Tityrus, and the Calamities of his Mantuan Neighbours in the Character of Meliboeus.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: BEneath the Shade which Beechen Boughs diffue,
You Tity'rus entertain your Silvan Mue:
Round the wide World in Banihment we rome,
Forc'd from our pleaing Fields and Native Home:
While tretch'd at Eae you ing your happy loves:
And Amarillis fills the hady Groves.

sp.speaker: TITYRUS.
sp.l: Thee bleings, Friend, a Deity betow'd:
For never can I deem him les than God.
The tender Firtlings of my Woolly breed
Shall on his holy Altar often bleed.
He gave my Kine to graze the Flowry Plain:
And to my Pipe renew'd the Rural Strain.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: I envy not your Fortune, but admire,
That while the raging Sword and watful Fire
Detroy the wretched Neighbourhood around,
No Hotile Arms approach your happy ground.
Far diff'rent is my Fate: my feeble Goats
With pains I drive from their foraken Cotes.
And this you ee I carcely drag along,
Who yeaning on the Rocks has left her Young;
(The Hope and Promie of my failing Fold:)
My los by dire Portents the Gods foretold:
For had I not been blind I might have een
You riven Oak, the fairet of the Green,
And the hoare Raven, on the blated Bough,
With frequent Crokes preag'd the coming Blow.
But tell me, Tityrus, what Heav'nly Power
Preerv'd your Fortunes in that fatal Hour?

sp.speaker: TITYRUS.
sp.l: Fool that I was, I thought Imperial Rome
Like Mantua, where on Market-days we come,
And thether drive our tender Lambs from home.
So Kids and Whelps their Syres and Dams expres:
And o the Great I meaur'd by the Les.
But Country Towns, compar'd with her, appear
Like Shrubs, when lofty Cyprees are near.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: What great Occaion call'd you hence to Rome?

sp.speaker: TITYRUS.
sp.l: Freedom, which came at length, tho' low to come:
Nor did my Search of Liberty begin,
Till my black Hairs were chang'd upon my Chin.
Nor Amarillis wou'd vouchafe a look,
Till Galeatea's meaner bonds I broke.
Till then a helples, hopeles, homely Swain,
I ought not freedom, nor apir'd to Gain:
Tho' many a Victim from my Folds was bought,
And many a Cheee to Country Markets brought,
Yet all the little that I got, I pent,
And till return'd as empty as I went.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: We tood amaz'd to ee your Mitres mourn;
Unknowing that he pin'd for your return:
We wonder'd why he kept her Fruit, o long,
For whom o late th' ungather'd Apples hung.
But now the Wonder ceaes, ince I ee
She kept them only, Tityrus, for thee.
For thee the bubling Springs appear'd to mourn,
And whip'ring Pines made vows for thy return.

sp.speaker: TITYRUS.
sp.l: What hou'd I do! while here I was enchain'd,
No glimpe of Godlike Liberty remain'd?
Nor cou'd I hope in any place, but there,
To find a God o preent to my Pray'r.
There firt the Youth of Heav'nly Birth I view'd;
For whom our Monthly Victims are renew'd.
He heard my Vows, and graciouly decreed
My Grounds to be retor'd, my former Flocks to feed.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: O Fortunate Old Man! whoe Farm remains
For you ufficient, and requites your pains,
Tho' Ruhes overpread the Neighb'ring Plains.
Tho' here the Marhy Grounds approach your Fields,
And there the Soyl a tony Harvet yields.
Your teeming Ewes hall no trange Meadows try,
Nor fear a Rott from tainted Company.
Behold yon bord'ring Fence of Sallow Trees
Is fraught with Flow'rs, the Flow'rs are fraught with Bees:
The buiie Bees with a oft murm'ring Strain
Invite to gentle leep the lab'ring Swain.
While from the Neighb'ring Rock, with Rural Songs,
The Pruner's Voice the pleaing Dream prolongs;
Stock-Doves and Turtles tell their Am'rous pain,
And from the lofty Elms of Love complain.

sp.speaker: TITYRUS.
sp.l: Th' Inhabitants of Seas and Skies hall change,
And Fih on hoar and Stags in Air hall range,
The banih'd Parthian dwell on Arar's brink,
And the blue German hall the Tigris drink:
E're I, foraking Gratitude and Truth,
Forget the Figure of that Godlike Youth.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: But we mut beg our Bread in Climes unknown,
Beneath the corching or the freezing Zone.
And ome to far Oaxis hall be old;
Or try the Lybian Heat, or Scythian Cold.
The ret among the Britans be confin'd;
A Race of Men from all the World di-join'd.
O mut the wretched Exiles ever mourn,
Nor after length of rowl'ing Years return?
Are we condem'd by Fates unjut Decree,
No more our Houes and our Homes to ee?
Or hall we mount again the Rural Throne,
And rule the Country Kingdoms, once our own!
Did we for thee Barbarians plant and ow,
On thee, on thee, our happy Fields betow?
Good Heav'n, what dire Effects from Civil Dicord flow!
Now let me graff my Pears, and prune the Vine;
The Fruit is theirs, the Labour only mine.
Farewel my Patures, my Paternal Stock,
My fruitful Fields, and my more fruitful Flock!
No more, my Goats, hall I behold you climb
The teepy Cliffs, or crop the flow'ry Thyme!
No more, extended in the Grot below,
Shall ee you browzing on the Mountain's brow
The prickly Shrubs; and after on the bare,
Lean down the Deep Abys, and hang in Air.
No more my Sheep hall ip the Morning Dew;
No more my Song hall pleae the Rural Crue:,
Adieu, my tuneful Pipe! and all the World adieu!

sp.speaker: TITYRUS.
sp.l: This Night, at leat, with me forget your Care;
Chenuts and Curds and Cream hall be your fare:
The Carpet-ground hall be with Leaves o'repread;
And Boughs hall weave a Cov'ring for your Head.
For ee yon unny Hill the Shade extends;
And curling Smoke from Cottages acends.

div.head: The Second Patoral. OR, ALEXIS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Commentators can by no means agree on the Peron of Alexis, but are all of opinion that ome Beautiful Youth is meant by him, to whom Virgil here makes Love; in Corydon's Language and Simplicity. His way of Courthip is wholly Patoral: He complains of the Boys Coynes, recommends himelf for his Beauty and Skill in Piping; invites the Youth into the Country, where he promies him the Diverions of the Place; with a uitable Preent of Nuts and Apples: But when he finds nothing will prevail, he reolves to quit his troubleome Amour, and betake himelf again to his former Buines.

div.l: Young Corydon, th' unhappy Shepherd Swain,
The fair Alexis lov'd, but lov'd in vain:
And underneath the Beechen Shade, alone,
Thus to the Woods and Mountains made his moan.
Is this, unkind Alexis, my reward,
And mut I die unpitied, and unheard?
Now the green Lizard in the Grove is laid,
The Sheep enjoy the coolnes of the Shade;
And Thetilis wild Thime and Garlike beats
For Harvet Hinds, o'repent with Toyl and Heats:
While in the corching Sun I trace in vain
Thy flying footteps o're the burning Plain.
The creaking Locuts with my Voice conpire,
They fry'd with Heat, and I with fierce Deire.
How much more eaie was it to utain
Proud Amarillis, and her haughty Reign,
The Scorns of Young Menalcas, once my care,
Tho' he was black, and thou art Heav'nly fair.

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Thomas Earle of Pembroke and Montgomery, Lord Privy Seale & <…>
figure.head: Pat: 2.

div.l: Trut not too much to that enchanting Face;
Beauty's a Charm, but oon the Charm will pas:
White Lillies lie neglected on the Plain,
While dusky Hyacinths for ue remain.
My Paion is thy Scorn; nor wilt thou know
What Wealth I have, what Gifts I can betow:
What Stores my Dairies and my Folds contain;
A thouand Lambs that wander on the Plain:
New Milk that all the Winter never fails,
And all the Summer overflows the Pails:

l.U: ung not weeter to his Herd,

div.l: When ummon'd Stones the Theban Turrets rear'd.
Nor am I o deform'd; for late I tood
Upon the Margin of the briny Flood:
The Winds were till, and if the Glas be true,
With Daphnis I may vie, tho' judg'd by you.
O leave the noiie Town, O come and ee
Our Country Cotts, and live content with me!
To wound the Flying Deer, and from their Cotes
With me to drive a-Field, the browzing Goats:
To pipe and ing, and in our Country Strain
To Copy, or perhaps contend with Pan.
Pan taught to joyn with Wax unequal Reeds,
Pan loves the Shepherds, and their Flocks he feeds:
Nor corns the Pipe; Amyntas, to be taught,
With all his Kies would my Skill have bought.
Of even mooth joints a mellow Pipe I have,
Which with his dying Breath Damaetas gave:
And aid, This, Corydon, I leave to thee;
For only thou deerv't it after me.
His Eyes Amyntas durt not upward lift,
For much he grudg'd the Praie, but more the Gift.
Beides two Kids that in the Valley tray'd,
I found by chance, and to my fold convey'd:
They drein to bagging Udders every day;
And thee hall be Companions of thy Play.
Both fleck'd with white, the true Arcadian Strain,
Which Thetilis had often beg'd in vain:
And he hall have them, if again he ues,
Since you the Giver and the Gift refue.
Come to my longing Arms, my lovely care,
And take the Preents which the Nymphs prepare.
White Lillies in full Caniters they bring,
With all the Glories of the Purple Spring,
The Daughters of the Flood have earch'd the Mead
For Violets pale, and cropt the Poppy's Head:
The Short Narcius and fair Daffodil,
Pancies to pleae the Sight, and Caia weet to mell:
And et oft Hyacinths with Iron blue,
To hade marh Marigolds of hining Hue.
Some bound in Order, others looely trow'd,
To dres thy Bow'r, and trim thy new Abode.
My elf will earch our planted Grounds at home,
For downy Peaches and the gloie Plum:
And thrah the Chenuts in the Neighb'ring Grove,
Such as my Amarillis us'd to love.
The Laurel and the Myrtle weets agree;
And both in Noegays hall be bound for thee.
Ah, Corydon, ah poor unhappy Swain,
Alexis will thy homely Gifts didain:
Nor, hould't thou offer all thy little Store,
Will rich Iolas yield, but offer more.
What have I done, to name that wealthy Swain,
So powerful are his Preents, mine o mean!
The Boar amidt my Crytal Streams I bring;
And Southern Winds to blat my flow'ry Spring.
Ah, cruel Creature, whom dot thou depie?
The Gods to live in Woods have left the Skies.
And Godlike Paris in th' Idean Grove,
To Priam's Wealth prefer'd Oenone's Love.
In Cities which he built, let Pallas Reign;
Tow'rs are for Gods, but Forrets for the Swain.
The greedy Lyones the Wolf purues,
The Wolf the Kid, the wanton Kid the Browze:
Alexis thou art chas'd by Corydon;
All follow ev'ral Games, and each his own.
See from afar the Fields no longer moke,
The weating Steers unharnas'd from the Yoke,
Bring, as in Triumph, back the crooked Plough;
The Shadows lengthen as the Sun goes Low.
Cool Breezes now the raging Heats remove;
Ah, cruel Heaven! that made no Cure for Love!
I wih for balmy Sleep, but wih in vain:
Love has no bounds in Pleaure, or in Pain.
What frenzy, Shepherd, has thy Soul poes'd,
Thy Vinyard lies half prun'd, and half undres'd.
Quench, Corydon, thy long unanwer'd fire:
Mind what the common wants of Life require.
On willow Twigs employ thy weaving care:
And find an eaier Love, tho' not o fair.

div.head: The Third Patoral. OR, PALAEMON.
Menalcas, Damaetas, Palaemon.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Damaetas and Menalcas, after ome mart trokes of Country Railery, reolve to try who has the mot Skill at a Song; and accordingly make their Neighbour Palaemon Judge of their Performances: Who, after a full hearing of both Parties, declares himelf unfit for the Deciion of o weighty a Controverie, and leaves the Victory undetermin'd.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: HO, Groom, what Shepherd owns thoe ragged Sheep?

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Aegon's they are, he gave 'em me to keep.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Unhappy Sheep of an Unhappy Swain,
While he Neaera courts, but courts in vain,
And fears that I the Damel hall obtain;
Thou, Varlet, dot thy Mater's gains devour:
Thou milk't his Ewes, and often twice an hour;
Of Gras and Fodder thou defraud't the Dams:
And of their Mothers Duggs the tarving Lambs.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Good words, young Catamite, at leat to Men:
We know who did your Buines, how, and when.
And in what Chappel too you plaid your prize;
And what the Goats oberv'd with leering Eyes:
The Nymphs werekind, and laught, and there your afety lies.

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Charles Sackvill Earle of Dorsett & Midleseoc Lord Chamberlain of his Majts. houehould &c.
figure.head: Pat 3.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Yes, when I crept the Hedges of the Leys;
Cut Micon's tender Vines, and tole the Stays.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Or rather, when beneath yon ancient Oak,
The Bow of Daphnis and the Shafts you broke:
When the fair Boy receiv'd the Gift of right;
And but for Michief, you had dy'd for pight.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: What Nonene wou'd the Fool thy Mater prate,
When thou, his Knave, can't talk at uch a rate!
Did I not ee you, Racal, did I not!
When you lay nug to nap young Damon's Goat?
His Mungril bark'd, I ran to his relief,
And cry'd, There, there he goes; top, top the Thief.
Dicover'd and defeated of your Prey,
You culk'd behind the Fence, and neak'd away.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: An honet Man may freely take his own;
The Goat was mine, by inging fairly won.
A olemn match was made; He lot the Prize,
Ask Damon, ask if he the Debt denies;
I think he dares not, if he does, he lyes.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Thou ing with him, thou Booby; never Pipe
Was o profan'd to touch that blubber'd Lip:
Dunce at the bet; in Streets but carce allow'd
To tickle, on thy Straw, the tupid Crowd.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: To bring it to the Trial, will you dare
Our Pipes, our Skill, our Voices to compare?
My Brinded Heifar to the Stake I lay;
Two Thriving Calves he uckles twice a day:
And twice beides her Beetings never fail
To tore the Dairy, with a brimming Pail.
Now back your inging with an equal Stake.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: That hou'd be een, if I had one to make.
You know too well I feed my Father's Flock:
What can I wager from the common Stock?
A Stepdame too I have, a cured he,
Who rules my Hen-peck'd Sire, and orders me.
Both number twice a day the Milky Dams;
And once he takes the tale of all the Lambs.
But ince you will be mad, and ince you may
Supect my Courage, if I hould not lay;
The Pawn I proffer hall be full as good:
Two Bowls I have, well turn'd of Beechen Wood;
Both by divine Alcimedon were made;
To neither of them yet the Lip is laid.
The Lids are Ivy, Grapes in cluters lurk,
Beneath the Carving of the curious Work.
Two Figures on the ides embos'd appear;
Conon, and what's his Name who made the Sphere,
And hew'd the Seaons of the liding Year,
Intructed in his Trade the Lab'ring Swain,
And when to reap, and when to owe the Grain?

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: And I have two, to match your pair, at home;
The Wood the ame, from the ame Hand they come:
The kimbo Handles eem with Bears-foot carv'd;
And never yet to Table have been erv'd:
Where Orpheus on his Lyre laments his Love,
With Beats encompas'd, and a dancing Grove:
But thee, nor all the Proffers you can make,
Are worth the Heifar which I et to take.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: No more delays, vain Boater, but begin:
I prophecy before-hand I hall win.

l.U: hall be Judge how ill you rhime,

sp.l: I'll teach you how to brag another time.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Rhymer come on, and do the wort you can:
I fear not you, nor yet a better Man.
With Silence, Neighbour, and Attention wait:
For 'tis a buines of a high Debate.

sp.speaker: PALAEMON.
sp.l: Sing then; the Shade affords a proper place;
The Trees are cloath'd with Leaves, the Fields with Gras;
The Blooms blow; the Birds on buhes ing;
And Nature has accomplih'd all the Spring.
The Challenge to Damaetas hall belong,

l.U: hall utain his under Song:

sp.l: Each in his turn your tuneful numbers bring;
In turns the tuneful Mues love to ing.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: From the great Father of the Gods above
My Mue begins; for all is full of Jove;
To Jove the care of Heav'n and Earth belongs;
My Flocks he blees, and he loves my Songs.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Me Phoebus loves; for He my Mue inpires;
And in her Songs, the warmth he gave, requires.
For him, the God of Shepherds and their Sheep,
My bluhing Hyacinths, and my Bays I keep.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: With pelted Fruit, me Galatea plyes;
Then tripping to the Woods the Wanton hies:
And wihes to be een, before he flies.
But from my frowning Fair, more Ills I find,
Than from the Wolves, and Storms, and Winter-wind.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: The Kids with pleaure browze the buhy Plain,
The Show'rs are grateful to the welling Grain:
To teeming Ewes the Sallow's tender tree;
But more than all the World my Love to me.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Pollio my Rural Vere vouchafes to read:
A Heyfar, Mues, for your Patron breed.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: My Pollio writes himelf, a Bull be bred,
With purning Heels, and with a butting Head.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Who Pollio loves, and who his Mue admires,
Let Pollio's fortune crown his full deires.
Let Myrrh intead of Thorn his Fences fill:
And Show'rs of Hony from his Oaks ditil.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Who hates not living Bavius, let him be
(Dead Maevius) damn'd to love thy Works and thee:
The ame ill tate of Sene wou'd erve to join
Dog Foxes in the Yoak, and heer the Swine.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Ye Boys, who pluck the Flow'rs, and poil the Spring,
Beware the ecret Snake, that hoots a ting.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Graze not too near the Banks, my jolly Sheep,
The Ground is fale, the running Streams are deep:
See, they have caught the Father of the Flock;
Who drys his Fleece upon the neighb'ring Rock.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: From Rivers drive the Kids, and ling your Hook;
Anon I'll wah 'em in the hallow Brook.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: But fair Amyntas comes unask'd to me;
And offers Love; and its upon my knee:
Not Delia to my Dogs is known o well as he.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: To the dear Mitres of my Love-ick Mind,
Her Swain a pretty Preent has deign'd:
I aw two Stock-doves billing, and e're long
Will take the Net, and Hers hall be the Young.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Ten ruddy Wildings in the Wood I found,
And tood on tip-toes, reaching from the ground;
I ent Amyntas all my preent Store;
And will, to Morrow, end as many more.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: The lovely Maid lay panting in my arms;
And all he aid and did was full of Charms.
Winds on your Wings to Heav'n her Accents bear;
Such words as Heav'n alone is fit to hear.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Ah! what avails it me, my Love's delight,
To call you mine, when abent from my ight!
I hold the Nets, while you purue the Prey;
And mut not hare the Dangers of the Day.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: I keep my Birth-day: end my Phillis home;
At Sheering-time, Iolas, you may come.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: With Phillis I am more in grace than you:
Her Sorrow did my parting-teps purue:
Adieu my Dear, he aid, a long Adieu.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: The Nightly Wolf is baneful to the Fold,
Storms to the Wheat, to Budds the bitter Cold;

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: To fold, my Flock; when Milk is dry'd with heat,
In vain the Milk-maid tugs an empty Teat.

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: How lank my Bulls from plenteous pature come!
But Love that drains the Herd, detroys the Groom.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: My Flocks are free from Love; yet look o thin,
Their bones are barely cover'd with their Skin.
What magick has bewitch'd the woolly Dams,
And what ill Eyes beheld the tender Lambs?

sp.speaker: DAMAETAS.
sp.l: Say, where the round of Heav'n, which all contains,
To three hort Ells on Earth our ight retrains:
Tell that, and rie a Phoebus for thy pains.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Nay tell me firt, in what new Region prings
A Flow'r, that bears incrib'd the names of Kings:
And thou halt gain a Preent as Divine
As Phoebus elf; for Phillis hall be thine.

sp.speaker: PALAEMON.
sp.l: So nice a diff'rence in your Singing lyes,
That both have won, or both deerv'd the Prize.
Ret equal happy both; and all who prove
The bitter Sweets, and pleaing Pains of Love.
Now dam the Ditches, and the Floods retrain:
Their moiture has already drench'd the Plain.

div.head: The Fourth Patoral. OR, POLLIO.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Poet celebrates the Birth-day of Saloninus, the Son of Pollio, born in the Conulhip of his Father, after the taking of Salonae, a City in Dalmatia. Many of the Veres are tranlated from one of the Sybils, who propheie of our Saviour's Birth.

figure.p: To the Right Honble. Lionel Cranfeild Sackvill Lord Buck hurst, eldest son of Charles Earle of Dorsett & Midlesex.
figure.head: Pat: 4.

div.l: SIcilian Mue begin a loftier train!
Though lowly Shrubs and Trees that hade the Plain,
Delight not all; Sicilian Mue, pepare
To make the vocal Woods deerve a Conul's care.
The lat great Age, foretold by acred Rhymes,
Renews its finih'd Coure, Saturnian times
Rowl round again, and mighty years, begun
From their firt Orb, in radiant Circles run.
The bae degenerate Iron-off-pring ends;
A golden Progeny from Heav'n decends;
O chat Lucina peed the Mother's pains,
And hate the glorious Birth; thy own Apollo reigns!
The lovely Boy, with his aupicious Face,
Shall Pollio's Conulhip and Triumph grace;
Majetick Months et out with him to their appointed Race.
The Father banih'd Virtue hall retore,
And Crimes hall threat the guilty world no more.
The Son hall lead the life of Gods, and be
By Gods and Heroes een, and Gods and Heroes ee.
The jarring Nations he in peace hall bind,
And with paternal Virtues rule Mankind.
Unbidden Earth hall wreathing Ivy bring,
And fragrant Herbs (the promies of Spring)
As her firt Off'rings to her Infant King.
The Goats with trutting Dugs hall homeward peed,
And lowing Herds, ecure from Lyons feed.
His Cradle hall with riing Flow'rs be crown'd;
The Serpents Brood hall die: the acred ground
Shall Weeds and pois'nous Plants refue to bear,
Each common Buh hall Syrian Roes wear.
But when Heroick Vere his Youth hall raie,
And form it to Hereditary Praie;
Unlabour'd Harvets hall the Fields adorn,
And cluter'd Grapes hall bluh on every Thorn.
The knotted Oaks hall how'rs of Honey weep,
And through the Matted Gras the liquid Cold hall creep.
Yet, of old Fraud ome footteps hall remain,
The Merchant till hall plough the deep for gain:
Great Cities hall with Walls be compas'd round;
And harpen'd Shares hall vex the fruitful ground.
Another Typhis hall new Seas explore,
Another Argos land the Chiefs, upon th' Iberian Shore.
Another Helen other Wars create,
And great Achilles urge the Trojan Fate:
But when to ripen'd Man-hood he hall grow,
The greedy Sailer hall the Seas forego;
No Keel hall cut the Waves for foreign Ware;
For every Soil hall every Product bear.
The labouring Hind his Oxen hall disjoyn,
No Plow hall hurt the Glebe, no Pruning-hook the Vine:
Nor Wooll hall in diembled Colours hine.
But the luxurious Father of the Fold,
With native Purple, or unborrow'd Gold,
Beneath his pompous Fleece hall proudly weat:
And under Tyrian Robes the Lamb hall bleat.
The Fates, when they this happy Web have pun,

l.U: hall bles the acred Clue, and bid it moothly run.

div.l: Mature in years, to ready Honours move,
O of Coeletial Seed! O foter Son of Jove!
See, lab'ring Nature calls thee to utain
The nodding Frame of Heav'n, and Earth, and Main;
See to their Bae retor'd, Earth, Seas, and Air,
And joyful Ages from behind, in crowding Ranks appear.
To ing thy Praie, wou'd Heav'n my breath prolong,
Inuing Spirits worthy uch a Song;
Not Thracian Orpheus hould trancend my Layes,
Nor Linus crown'd with never-fading Bayes:
Though each his Heav'nly Parent hou'd inpire;
The Mue intruct the Voice, and Phoebus tune the Lyre.
Shou'd Pan contend in Vere, and thou my Theme,
Arcadian Judges hou'd their God condemn.
Begin, aupicious Boy, to cat about
Thy Infant Eyes, and with a mile, thy Mother ingle out;
Thy Mother well deerves that hort delight,
The naueous Qualms of ten long Months and Travel to requite.
Then mile; the frowning Infant's Doom is read,
No God hall crown the Board, nor Goodes bles the Bed.

div.head: The Fifth Patoral. OR, DAPHNIS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Mopus and Menalcas, two very expert Shepherds at a Song, begin one by conent to the Memory of Daphnis; who is uppos'd by the bet Criticks to repreent Julius Caear. Mopus laments his Death, Menalcas proclaims his Divinity. The whole Eclogue coniting of an Elegie and an Apotheois.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: SInce on the Downs our Flocks together feed,
And ince my Voice can match your tuneful Reed,
Why it we not beneath the grateful Shade,
Which Hazles, intermix'd with Elms, have made?

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: Whether you pleae that Silvan Scene to take,
Where whitling Winds uncertain Shadows make:
Or will you to the cooler Cave ucceed,
Whoe Mouth the curling Vines have overpread?

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Your Merit and your Years command the Choice:
Amyntas only rivals you in Voice.

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: What will not that preuming Shepherd dare,
Who thinks his Voice with Phoebus may compare?

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Begin you firt; if either Alcon's Praie,
Or dying Phillis have inpir'd your Lays:

figure.p: To the Right Honble. James Bertie, Earle of Abingdon, and Baron Norreys of Rycott Cheife Justice, and Justice in Eyre of all his Majts.—Parcks Forests, and Chaces on the South ide of Trent: and Ld Lieutenant and Custos Rotulorum of the County of Oxon.
figure.head: Pat: 5: 1.

sp.l: If her you mourn, or Codrus you commend,
Begin, and Tityrus your Flock hall tend.

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: Or hall I rather the ad Vere repeat,
Which on the Beeches bark I lately writ:
I writ, and ung betwixt; now bring the Swain
Whoe Voice you boat, and let him try the Strain.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Such as the Shrub to the tall Olive hows,
Or the pale Sallow to the bluhing Roe;
Such is his Voice, if I can judge aright,
Compar'd to thine, in weetnes and in height.

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: No more, but it and hear the promis'd Lay,
The gloomy Grotto makes a doubtful day.
The Nymphs about the breathles Body wait
Of Daphnis, and lament his cruel Fate.
The Trees and Floods were witnes to their Tears:
At length the rumour reach'd his Mother's Ears.
The wretched Parent, with a pious hate,
Came running, and his lifeles Limbs embrac'd.
She igh'd, he ob'd, and, furious with depair,
She rent her Garments, and he tore her Hair:
Accufing all the Gods and every Star.
The Swains forgot their Sheep, nor near the brink
Of running Waters brought their Herds to drink.
The thirty Cattle, of themelves, abtain'd
From Water, and their gray Fare didain'd.
The death of Daphnis Woods and Hills deplore,
They cat the ound to Lybia's deart Shore;
The Lybian Lyons hear, and hearing roar.
Fierce Tygers Daphnis taught the Yoke to bear;
And firt with curling Ivy dres'd the Spear:
Daphnis did Rites to Bacchus firt ordain;
And holy Revels for his reeling Train.
As Vines the Trees, as Grapes the Vines adorn,
As Bulls the Herds, and Fields the Yellow Corn;
So bright a Splendor, o divine a Grace,
The glorious Daphnis cat on his illutrious Race.
When envious Fate the Godlike Daphnis took,
Our guardian Gods the Fields and Plains forook:
Pales no longer well'd the teeming Grain,
Nor Phoebus fed his Oxen on the Plain:
No fruitful Crop the ickly Fields return;
But Oats and Darnel choak the riing Corn.
And where the Vales with Violets once were crown'd,
Now knotty Burrs and Thorns digrace the Ground.
Come, Shepherds, come, and trow with Leaves the Plain;
Such Funeral Rites your Daphnis did ordain.
With Cypres Boughs the Crytal Fountains hide,
And oftly let the running Waters glide;
A lating Monument to Daphnis raie;
With this Incription to record his Praie,
Daphnis, the Fields Delight, the Shepherd's Love,
Renown'd on Earth, and deify'd above.
Whoe Flock excell'd the fairet on the Plains,
But les than he himelf urpas'd the Swains.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Oh Heavenly Poet! uch thy Vere appears,
So weet, o charming to my ravih'd Ears,
As to the weary Swain, with cares oppret,
Beneath the Silvan Shade, refrehing Ret:
As to the feavorih Travellor, when firt
He finds a Crytal Stream to quench his thirt.
In inging, as in piping, you excell;
And carce your Mater could perform o well.
O fortunate young Man, at leat your Lays
Are next to his, and claim the econd Praie.
Such as they are my rural Songs I join,
To raie our Daphnis to the Pow'rs Divine;
For Daphnis was o good, to love what-e're was mine.

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: How is my Soul with uch a Promie rais'd!
For both the Boy was worthy to be prais'd,
And Stimichon has often made me long,
To hear, like him, o oft o weet a Song.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Daphnis, the Guet of Heav'n, with wondring Eyes,
Views in the Milky Way, the tarry Skyes:
And far beneath him, from the hining Sphere,
Beholds the moving Clouds, and rolling Year.
For this, with chearful Cries the Woods reound;
The Purple Spring arrays the various ground:
The Nymphs and Shepherds dance; and Pan himelf is Crown'd.
The Wolf no longer prowls for nightly Spoils,
Nor Birds the Sprindges fear, nor Stags the Toils:
For Daphnis reigns above; and deals from thence
His Mothers milder Beams, and peaceful Influence.
The Mountain tops unhorn, the Rocks rejoice;
The lowly Shrubs partake of Humane Voice.
Aenting Nature, with a gracious nod,
Proclaims him, and alutes the new-admitted God.
Be till propitious, ever good to thine:
Behold four hallow'd Altars we deign;
And two to thee, and two to Phoebus rie;
On each is offer'd Annual Sacrifice.
The holy Priets, at each returning year,
Two Bowls of Milk, and two of Oil hall bear;
And I my elf the Guets with friendly Bowls will chear.
Two Goblets will I crown with parkling Wine,
The gen'rous Vintage of the Chian Vine;
Thee will I pour to thee, and make the Nectar thine.
In Winter hall the Genial Feat be made
Before the fire; by Summer in the hade.

l.U: hall perform the Rites Divine;

sp.l: And Lictian Aegon in the Song hall join.
Alpheibaeus, tripping, hall advance;
And mimick Satyrs in his antick Dance.
When to the Nymphs our annual Rites we pay,
And when our Fields with Victims we urvey:
While avage Boars delight in hady Woods,
And finny Fih inhabit in the Floods;
While Bees on Thime, and Locuts feed on Dew,
Thy grateful Swains thee Honours hall renew.
Such Honours as we pay to Pow'rs Divine,
To Bacchus and to Ceres, hall be thine.
Such annual Honours hall be giv'n, and thou
Shalt hear, and halt condemn thy Suppliants to their Vow.

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: What Preent worth thy Vere can Mopus find!
Not the oft Whipers of the Southern Wind,
That play through trembling Trees, delight me more;
Nor murm'ring Billows on the ounding Shore;
Nor winding Streams that through the Valley glide;
And the carce cover'd Pebbles gently chide.

sp.speaker: MENALCAS.
sp.l: Receive you firt this tuneful Pipe; the ame
That play'd my Coridon's unhappy Flame.
The ame that ung Neaera's conqu'ring Eyes;
And, had the Judge been jut, had won the Prize.

sp.speaker: MOPSUS.
sp.l: Accept from me this Sheephook in exchange,
The Handle Bras; the Knobs in equal range.
Antigenes, with Kies, often try'd
To beg this Preent, in his Beauty's Pride;
When Youth and Love are hard to be deny'd.
But what I cou'd refue, to his Requet,
Is yours unask'd, for you deerve it bet.

div.head: The Sixth Patoral. OR, SILENUS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Two young Shepherds Chromis and Mnaylus, having been often promis'd a Song by Silenus, chance to catch him aleep in this Patoral; where they bind him hand and foot, and then claim his Promie. Silenus finding they wou'd be put off no longer, begins his Song; in which he decribes the Formation of the Univere, and the Original of Animals, according to the Epicurean Philoophy; and then runs through the mot urpriing Transformations which have happen'd in Nature ince her Birth. This Patoral was deign'd as a Complement to Syro the Epicurean, who intructed Virgil and Varus in the Principles of that Philoophy. Silenus acts as Tutor, Chromis and Mnaylus as the two Pupils.

div.l: I Firt transferr'd to Rome Scicilian Strains:
Nor bluh'd the Dorick Mue to dwell on Mantuan Plains.
But when I try'd her tender Voice, too young;
And fighting Kings, and bloody Battels ung,
Apollo check'd my Pride; and bade me feed
My fatning Flocks, nor dare beyond the Reed.
Admonih'd thus, while every Pen prepares
To write thy Praies, Varus, and thy Wars,
My Pat'ral Mue her humble Tribute brings;
And yet not wholly uninpir'd he ings.
For all who read, and reading, not didain
Thee rural Poems, and their lowly Strain,
The name of Varus oft incrib'd hall ee,
In every Grove, and every vocal Tree;
And all the Silvan reign hall ing of thee:

figure.p: To the Right Honble. Hugh Lord Vicount Cholmondely of Kelles in the Kingdom of Ireland and Baron of Wichmalbank in the Kingdom of England.
figure.head: Pat:6.

div.l: Thy name, to Phoebus and the Mues known,
Shall in the front of every Page be hown;
For he who ings thy Praie, ecures his own.
Proceed, my Mue: Two Satyrs, on the ground,
Stretch'd at his Eae, their Syre Sylenus found.
Dos'd with his fumes, and heavy with his Load,
They found him noring in his dark abode;
And eis'd with Youthful Arms the drunken God.
His roie Wreath was dropt not long before,
Born by the tide of Wine, and floating on the floor.
His empty Can, with Ears half worn away,
Was hung on high, to boat the triumph of the day.
Invaded thus, for want of better bands,
His Garland they untring, and bind his hands:
For by the fraudful God deluded long,
They now reolve to have their promis'd Song.
Aegle came in, to make their Party good;
The fairet Nais of the neighbouring Flood,
And, while he tares around, with tupid Eyes,
His Brows with Berries, and his Temples dyes.
He finds the Fraud, and, with a Smile, demands
On what deign the Boys had bound his hands.
Looe me, he cry'd; 'twas Impudence to find
A leeping God, 'tis Sacriledge to bind.
To you the promis'd Poem I will pay;
The Nymph hall be rewarded in her way.
He rais'd his voice; and oon a num'rous throng
Of tripping Satyrs crowded to the Song.
And Sylvan Fauns, and Savage Beats advanc'd,
And nodding Forets to the Numbers danc'd.
Not by Haemonian Hills the Thracian Bard,
Nor awful Phoebus was on Pindus heard,
With deeper ilence, or with more regard.
He ung the ecret Seeds of Nature's Frame;
How Seas, and Earth, and Air, and active Flame,
Fell through the mighty Void; and in their fall
Were blindly gather'd in this goodly Ball.
The tender Soil then tiffning by degrees,
Shut from the bounded Earth, the bounding Seas.
Then Earth and Ocean various Forms dicloe;
And a new Sun to the new World aroe.
And Mits condens'd to Clouds obcure the Skie;
And Clouds diolv'd, the thirty Ground upply.
The riing Trees the lofty Mountains grace:
The lofty Mountains feed the Savage Race.
From thence the birth of Man the Song puru'd,
And how the World was lot, and how renew'd.
The Reign of Saturn, and the Golden Age;
Prometheus Theft, and Jove's avenging Rage.
The Cries of Argonauts for Hylas drown'd;
With whoe repeated Name the Shoars reound.
Then mourns the madnes of the Cretan Queen;
Happy for her if Herds had never been.
What fury, wretched Woman, eiz'd thy Breat!
The Maids of Argos (tho with rage poes'd,
Their imitated lowings fill'd the Grove)
Yet hun'd the guilt of this prepot'rous Love.
Nor ought the Youthful Husband of the Herd;
Tho tender and untry'd the Yoke he fear'd.
Tho oft and white as flakes of falling Snow;
And carce his budding Horns had arm'd his brow.
Ah, wretched Queen! you range the pathles Wood;
While on a flowry Bank he chaws the Cud:
Or leeps in Shades, or thro' the Foret roves;
And roars with anguih for his abent Loves.
Ye Nymphs, with toils, his Foret-walk urround;
And trace his wandring Footteps on the ground.
But, ah! perhaps my Paion he didains;
And courts the milky Mothers of the Plains.
We earch th'ungrateful Fugitive abroad;
While they at home utain his happy load.
He ung the Lover's fraud; the longing Maid,
With golden Fruit, like all the Sex, betray'd.
The Siters mourning for their Brother's los;
Their Bodies hid in Barks, and furr'd with Mos.
How each a riing Alder now appears;
And o're the Po ditils her Gummy Tears.
Then ung, how Gallus by a Mues hand,
Was led and welcom'd to the acred Strand.
The Senate riing to alute their Guet;
And Linus thus their gratitude expres'd.
Receive this Preent, by the Mues made;
The Pipe on which th' Acraean Pator play'd:
With which of old he charm'd the Savage Train:
And call'd the Mountain Ahes to the Plain.
Sing thou on this, thy Phoebus; and the Wood
Where once his Fane of Parian Marble tood.
On this his ancient Oracles reheare;
And with new Numbers grace the God of Vere.
Why hou'd I ing the double Scylla's Fate,
The firt by Love transform'd, the lat by Hate.
A beauteous Maid above, but Magick Arts,
With barking Dogs deform'd her neather parts.
What Vengeance on the paing Fleet he pour'd,
The Mater frighted, and the Mates devour'd.
Then ravih'd Philomel the Song expret;
The Crime reveal'd; the Siters cruel Feat;
And how in Fields the Lapwing Tereus reigns;
The warbling Nightingale in Woods complains.
While Progne makes on Chymney tops her moan;
And hovers o're the Palace once her own.
Whatever Songs beides, the Delphian God
Had taught the Laurels, and the Spartan Flood,

l.U: ung: the Vales his Voice rebound;

div.l: And carry to the Skies the acred Sound.
And now the etting Sun had warn'd the Swain
To call his counted Cattle from the Plain:
Yet till th' unweary'd Syre purues the tuneful Strain.
Till unperceiv'd the Heav'ns with Stars were hung:
And udden Night urpriz'd the yet unfinih'd Song.

div.head: The Seventh Patoral. OR, MELIBOEUS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Meliboeus here gives us the Relation of a harp Poetical Contet between Thyris and Corydon; at which he himelf and Daphnis were preent; who both declar'd for Corydon.

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Henry Lord Herbert Baron of Chirbury. &c.
figure.head: Pat: 7.

div.l: BEneath a Holm, repair'd two jolly Swains;
Their Sheep and Goats together graz'd the Plains.
Both young Arcadians, both alike inpir'd
To ing, and anwer as the Song requir'd.
Daphnis, as Umpire, took the middle Seat;
And Fortune thether led my weary Feet.
For while I fenc'd my Myrtles from the Cold,
The Father of my Flock had wander'd from the Fold.
Of Daphnis I enquir'd; he, miling, aid,
Dimis your Fear, and pointed where he fed.
And, if no greater Cares diturb your Mind,
Sit here with us, in covert of the Wind.
Your lowing Heyfars, of their own accord,
At wat'ring time will eek the neighb'ring Ford.
Here wanton Mincius windes along the Meads,
And hades his happy Banks with bending Reeds:
And ee from yon old Oak, that mates the Skies,
How black the Clouds of warming Bees arie.
What hou'd I do! nor was Alcippe nigh,
Nor abent Phillis cou'd my care upply,
To houe, and feed by hand my weaning Lambs,
And drain the trutting Udders of their Dams?
Great was the trife betwixt the Singing Swains:
And I preferr'd my Pleaure to my Gains.
Alternate Rhime the ready Champions choe:
Thee Corydon rehears'd, and Thyris thoe.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Yee Mues, ever fair, and ever young,
Ait my Numbers, and inpire my Song.
With all my Codrus O inpire my Breat,
For Codrus after Phoebus ings the bet.
Or if my Wihes have preum'd too high,
And tretch'd their bounds beyond Mortality,
The praie of artful Numbers I reign:
And hang my Pipe upon the Sacred Pine.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: Arcadian Swains, your Youthful Poet crown
With Ivy Wreaths; tho urly Codrus, frown.
Or if he blat my Mue with envious Praie,
Then fence my Brows with Amuletts of Bays.
Let his ill Arts or his malicious Tongue
Shou'd poyon, or bewitch my growing Song.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Thee Branches of a Stag, this tusky Boar
(The firt eay of Arms untry'd before)
Young Mycon offers, Delia, to thy Shrine;
But peed his hunting with thy Pow'r divine,
Thy Statue then of Parian Stone hall tand;
Thy Legs in Buskins with a Purple Band.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: This Bowl of Milk, thee Cakes, (our Country Fare,)
For thee, Priapus, yearly we prepare.
Becaue a little Garden is thy care.
But if the falling Lambs increae my Fold,
Thy Marble Statue hall be turn'd to Gold.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Fair Galathea, with thy ilver Feet,
O, whiter than the Swan, and more than Hybla weet;
Tall as a Poplar, taper as the Bole,
Come charm thy Shepherd, and retore my Soul.
Come when my lated Sheep, at night return;
And crown the ilent Hours, and top the roy Morn.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: May I become as abject in thy ight,
As Sea-weed on the Shore, and black as Night:
Rough as a Bur, deform'd like him who chaws
Sardinian Herbage to contract his Jaws;
Such and o montrous let thy Swain appear,
If one day's Abence looks not like a Year.
Hence from the Field, for Shame: the Flock deerves
No better Feeding, while the Shepherd tarves.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Ye moy Springs, inviting eaie Sleep,
Ye Trees, whoe leafy Shades thoe moy Fountains keep,
Defend my Flock, the Summer heats are near,
And Blooms on the welling Vines appear.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: With heapy Fires our chearful Hearth is crown'd;
And Firs for Torches in the Woods abound:
We fear not more the Winds, and wintry Cold,
Than Streams the Banks, or Wolves the bleating Fold.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Our Woods, with Juniper and Chenuts crown'd,
With falling Fruits and Berries paint the Ground;
And lavih Nature laughs, and trows her Stores around.
But if Alexis from our Mountains fly,
Ev'n running Rivers leave their Channels dry.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: Parch'd are the Plains, and frying is the Field,
Nor with'ring Vines their juicy Vintage yield.
But if returning Phillis bles the Plain,
The Gras revives; the Woods are green again;
And Jove decends in Show'rs of kindly Rain.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: The Poplar is by great Alcides worn:
The Brows of Phoebus his own Bays adorn.
The branching Vine the jolly Bacchus loves;
The Cyprian Queen delights in Mirtle Groves.
With Hazle, Phillis crowns her flowing Hair,
And while he loves that common Wreath to wear;
Nor Bays, nor Myrtle Bows, with Hazle hall compare.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: The towring Ah is fairet in the Woods;
In Gardens Pines, and Poplars by the Floods:
But if my Lycidas will eae my Pains,
And often viit our foraken Plains;
To him the tow'ring Ah hall yield in Woods;
In Gardens Pines, and Poplars by the Floods.

sp.speaker: MELIBOEUS.
sp.l: I've heard: and, Thyris, you contend in vain:
For Corydon, young Corydon hall reign,
The Prince of Poets, on the Mantuan Plain.

div.head: The Eighth Patoral. OR, PHARMACEUTRIA.

argument.head: The Argument.
