argument.p: This Patoral contains the Songs of Damon and Alpheiboeus. The firt of 'em bewails the los of his Mitres, and repines at the Succes of his Rival Mopus. The other repeats the Charms of ome Enchantres, who endeavour'd by her Spells and Magic to make Daphnis in Love with her.

figure.p: To the Rigt Honble: Charles Ld Clifford Baron of Lounsbrough in the County of York
figure.head: past. 8

lg.l: THE mournful Mue of two depairing Swains,
The Love rejected, and the Lovers' pains;
To which the alvage Linxes litning tood,
The Rivers tood on heaps, and top'd the running Flood,
The hungry Herd their needful Food refue;
Of two depairing Swains, I ing the mournful Mue.
Great Pollio, thou for whom thy Rome prepares
The ready Triumph of thy finih'd Wars,
Whither Timavus or th' Illirian Coat,
Whatever Land or Sea thy preence boat;
Is there an hour in Fate reerv'd for me,
To Sing thy Deeds in Numbers worthy thee?
In numbers like to thine, cou'd I reheare
Thy lofty Tragick Scenes, thy labour'd Vere;
The World another Sophocles in thee,
Another Homer hou'd behold in me:
Amidt thy Laurels let this Ivy twine,
Thine was my earlyet Mue; my latet hall be thine.
Scarce from our upper World the Shades withdrew;
Scarce were the Flocks refreh'd with Morning Dew,
When Damon tretch'd beneath an Olive Shade,
And wildly taring upwards, thus inveigh'd
Againt the concious Gods, and curs'd the cruel Maid.
Star of the Morning, why dot thou delay?
Come, Lucifer, drive on the lagging Day.
While I my Nia's perjur'd Faith deplore;
Witnes ye Pow'rs, by whom he fally wore!
The Gods, alas, are Witnees in vain;
Yet hall my dying Breath to Heav'n complain.
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
The Pines of Maenalus, the vocal Grove,
Are ever full of Vere, and full of Love:
They hear the Hinds, they hear their God complain;
Who uffer'd not the Reeds to rie in vain:
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
Mopus triumphs; he weds the willing Fair:
When uch is Nia's choice, what Lover can depair!
Now Griffons join with Mares; another Age
Shall ee the Hound and Hind their Thirt awage,
Promicuous at the Spring: Prepare the Lights,
O Mopus! and perform the bridal Rites.
Scatter thy Nuts among the crambling Boys:
Thine is the Night; and thine the Nuptial Joys.
For thee the Sun declines: O happy Swain!
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
O, Nia! Jutly to thy Choice condemn'd,
Whom hat thou taken, whom hat thou contemn'd!
For him, thou hat refus'd my browzing Herd,
Scorn'd my thick Eye-brows, and my haggy Beard.
Unhappy Damon ighs, and ings in vain:
While Nia thinks no God regards a Lover's pain.
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
I view'd thee firt; how fatal was the View!
And led thee where the ruddy Wildings grew,
High on the planted hedge, and wet with Morning Dew.
Then carce the bending Branches I cou'd win;
The callow Down began to cloath my Chin;
I aw, I perih'd; yet indulg'd my Pain:
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
I know thee, Love; in Dearts thou wert bred;
And at the Dugs of Salvage Tygers fed:
Alien of Birth, Uurper of the Plains:
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strains.
Relentles Love the cruel Mother led,
The Blood of her unhappy Babes to hed:
Love lent the Sword; the Mother truck the blow;
Inhuman he; but more inhuman thou.
Alien of Birth, Uurper of the Plains:
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strains.
Old doting Nature change thy Coure anew:
And let the trembling Lamb the Wolf purue:
Let Oaks now glitter with Heperian Fruit,
And purple Daffodils from Alder hoot.
Fat Amber let the Tamarisk ditil:
And hooting Owls contend with Swans in Skill.
Hoare Tity'rus trive with Orpheus in the Woods:
And challenge fam'd Arion on the Floods.
Or, oh! let Nature ceae; and Chaos reign:
Begin with me, my Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
Let Earth be Sea; and let the whelming Tide,
The lifeles Limbs of luckles Damon hide:
Farewel, ye ecret Woods, and hady Groves,
Haunts of my Youth, and concious of my Loves!
From yon high Cliff I plunge into the Main;
Take the lat Preent of thy dying Swain:
And ceae, my ilent Flute, the weet Maenalian Strain.
Now take your Turns, ye Mues, to reheare
His Friend's Complaint; and mighty Magick Vere.
Bring running Water; bind thoe Altars round
With Fillets; and with Vervain trow the Ground:
Make fat with Frankincene the acred Fires;
To re-inflame my Daphnis with Deires.
'Tis done, we want but Vere. Retore, my Charms,
My lingring Daphnis to my longing Arms.
Pale Phoebe, drawn by Vere from Heav'n decends:
And Circe chang'd with Charms Ulyes Friends.
Vere breaks the Ground, and penetrates the Brake;
And in the winding Cavern plits the Snake.
Vere fires the frozen Veins: Retore, my Charms,
My lingring Daphnis to my longing Arms.
Around his waxen Image, firt I wind
Three woollen Fillets, of three Colours join'd:
Thrice bind about his thrice devoted head,
Which round the acred Altar thrice is led.
Unequal Numbers pleae the Gods: my Charms,
Retore my Daphnis to my longing Arms.
Knit with three knots, the Fillets, knit 'em treight;
And ay, Thee Knots to Love I conecrate.
Hate, Amaryllis, hate; retore, my Charms,
My lovely Daphnis to my longing Arms.
As Fire this Figure hardens, made of Clay;
And this of Wax with Fire conumes away;
Such let the Soul of cruel Daphnis be;
Hard to the ret of Women; oft to me.
Crumble the acred Mole of Salt and Corn,
Next in the Fire the Bays with Brimtone burn.
And while it crackles in the Sulphur, ay,
This, I for Daphnis burn; thus Daphnis burn away.
This Laurel is his Fate: Retore, my Charms,
My lovely Daphnis to my longing Arms.
As when the raging Heyfar, through the Grove,
Stung with Deire, purues her wand'ring Love;
Faint at the lat, he eeks the weedy Pools,
To quench her thirt, and on the Ruhes rowls:
Careles of Night, unmindful to return,
Such fruitles Fires perfidious Daphnis burn.
While I o corn his Love; Retore, my Charms,
My lingring Daphnis to my longing Arms.
Thee Garments once were his; and left to me;
The Pledges of his promis'd Loyalty:
Which underneath my Threhold I betow;
Thee Pawns, O acred Earth! to me my Daphnis owe.
As thee were his, o mine is he; my Charms,
Retore their lingring Lord to my deluded Arms.
Thee poys'nous Plants, for Magick ue deign'd,
(The noblet and the bet of all the baneful Kind,)
Old Moeris brought me from the Pontick Strand:
And cull'd the Michief of a bounteous Land.
Smear'd with thee pow'rful Juices, on the Plain,
He howls a Wolf among the hungry Train:
And oft the mighty Negromancer boats,
With thee, to call from Tombs the talking Ghots:
And from the roots to tear the tanding Corn;
Which, whirld aloft, to ditant Fields is born.
Such is the trength of Spells; retore, my Charms,
My lingring Daphnis to my longing Arms.
Bear out thee Ahes; cat 'em in the Brook;
Cat backwards o're your head, nor turn your look:
Since neither Gods, nor Godlike Vere can move,
Break out ye mother'd Fires, and kindle mother'd Love.
Exert your utmot pow'r, my lingring Charms,
And force my Daphnis to my longing Arms.
See, while my lat endeavours I delay,
The waking Ahes rie, and round our Altars play!
Run to the Threhold, Amaryllis, hark,
Our Hylas opens, and begins to bark.
Good Heav'n! may Lovers what they wih believe;
Or dream their wihes, and thoe dreams deceive!
No more, my Daphnis comes; no more, my Charms;
He comes, he runs, he leaps to my deiring Arms.

div.head: The Ninth Patoral. OR, LYCIDAS, and MOERIS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: When Virgil, by the Favour of Augutus, had recover'd his Patrimony near Mantua, and went in hope to take Poeion, he was in danger to be lain by Arius the Centurion, to whom thoe Lands were aign'd by the Emperour, in reward of his Service againt Brutus and Caius. This Patoral therefore is fill'd with complaints of his hard Uage; and the Perons introduc'd, are the Bayliff of Virgil, Moeris, and his Friend Lycidas.

figure.p: To the Right Honble. Marquis of Hartington the Duke of William Lord Eldest Son to His Grace the Duke of Devonhire.
figure.head: Pat: <…>

sp.speaker: LYCIDAS.
sp.l: HO Moeris! whether on thy way o fat?
This leads to Town.

sp.speaker: MOERIS.
sp.l: O Lycidas, at lat
The Time is come I never thought to ee,
(Strange Revolution for my Farm and me)
When the grim Captain in a urly Tone
Cries out, pack up ye Racals, and be gone.
Kick'd out, we et the bet Face on't we cou'd,
And thee two Kids, t' appeae his angry Mood,
I bear, of which the Furies give him good.

sp.speaker: LYCIDAS.
sp.l: Your Country Friends were told another Tale;
That from the loaping Mountain to the Vale,
And dodder'd Oak, and all the Banks along,

l.U: av'd his Fortune with a Song.

sp.speaker: MOERIS.
sp.l: Such was the News, indeed, but Songs and Rhymes
Prevail as much in thee hard Iron Times,
As would a plump of trembling Fowl, that rie
Againt an Eagle ouing from the Skies.
And had not Phoebus warn'd me by the croak
Of an old Raven, from a hollow Oak,
To hun debate, Menalcas had been lain,
And Moeris not urviv'd him, to complain.

sp.speaker: LYCIDAS.
sp.l: Now Heav'n defend! cou'd barb'rous Rage induce
The Brutal Son of Mars, t' inult the acred Mue!
Who then hou'd ing the Nymphs, or who reheare
The Waters gliding in a moother Vere!
Or Amaryllis praie, that Heav'nly Lay,
That horten'd as we went, our tedious Way.
O Tity'rus, tend my Herd, and ee them fed;
To Morning Patures, Evening Waters led:
And 'ware the Lybian Ridgils butting Head.

sp.speaker: MOERIS.
sp.l: Or what unfinih'd He to Varus read;
Thy Name, O Varus (if the kinder Pow'rs
Preerve our Plains, and hield the Mantuan Tow'rs,
Obnoxious by Cremona's neighb'ring Crime,)
The Wings of Swans, and tronger pinion'd Rhyme,
Shall raie aloft, and oaring bear above
Th' immortal Gift of Gratitude to Jove.

sp.speaker: LYCIDAS.
sp.l: Sing on, ing on, for I can ne're be cloy'd,
So may thy Swarms the baleful Eugh avoid:
So may thy Cows their burden'd Bags ditend,
And Trees to Goats their willing Branches bend.
Mean as I am, yet have the Mues made
Me free, a Member of the tuneful trade:
At leat the Shepherds eem to like my Lays,
But I dicern their Flatt'ry from their Praie:
I nor to Cinna's Ears, nor Varus dare apire;
But gabble like a Gooe, amidt the Swan-like Quire.

sp.speaker: MOERIS.
sp.l: 'Tis what I have been conning in my Mind:
Nor are they Veres of a Vulgar Kind.
Come, Galatea, come, the Seas forake;
What Pleaures can the Tides with their hoare Murmurs make?
See, on the Shore inhabits purple Spring;
Where Nightingales their Love-ick Ditty fing;
See, Meads with purling Streams, with Flow'rs the Ground,
The Grottoes cool, with hady Poplars crown'd,
And creeping Vines on Arbours weav'd around.
Come then, and leave the Waves tumultuous roar,
Let the wild Surges vainly beat the Shore.

sp.speaker: LYCIDAS.
sp.l: Or that weet Song I heard with uch delight;
The ame you ung alone one tarry Night;
The Tune I till retain, but not the Words.

sp.speaker: MOERIS.
sp.l: Why, Daphnis, dot thou earch in old Records,
To know the Seaons when the Stars arie?
See Caear's Lamp is lighted in the Skies:
The Star, whoe Rays the bluhing Grapes adorn,
And well the kindly ripening Ears of Corn.
Under this influence, graft the tender Shoot;
Thy Childrens Children hall enjoy the Fruit.
The ret I have forgot, for Cares and Time
Change all things, and untune my Soul to Rhime:
I cou'd have once ung down a Summer's Sun,
But now the Chime of Poetry is done.
My Voice grows hoare; I feel the Notes decay,
As if the Wolves had een me firt to Day.
But thee, and more than I to mind can bring,
Menalcas has not yet forgott to ing.

sp.speaker: LYCIDAS.
sp.l: Thy faint Excues but inflame me more;
And now the Waves rowl ilent to the Shore.
Huht Winds the topmot Branches carcely bend,
As if thy tuneful Song they did attend:
Already we have half our way o'recome;
Far off I can dicern Bianor's Tomb;
Here, where the Labourer's hands have form'd a Bow'r
Of wreathing Trees, in Singing wate an Hour.
Ret here thy weary Limbs, thy Kids lay down,
We've Day before us yet, to reach the Town:
Or if e're Night the gath'ring Clouds we fear,
A Song will help the beating Storm to bear.
And that thou may't not be too late abroad,
Sing, and I'll eae thy Shoulders of thy Load.

sp.speaker: MOERIS.
sp.l: Ceae to requet me, let us mind our way;
Another Song requires another Day.
When good Menalcas comes, if he rejoyce,
And find a Friend at Court, I'll find a Voice.

div.head: The Tenth Patoral. OR, GALLUS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Gallus a great Patron of Virgil, and an excellent Poet, was very deeply in Love with one Citheris, whom he calls Lycoris; and who had foraken him for the Company of a Souldier. The Poet therefore uppoes his Friend Gallus retir'd in his heighth of Melancholy into the Solitudes of Arcadia (the celebrated Scene of Patorals;) where he repreents him in a very languihing Condition with all the Rural Deities about him, pitying his hard Uage, and condoling his Misfortune.

figure.p: To the Right Hon••e. Charles Montague Esqr: one of the Lords Commrs. of his Majts. Treasury, Chancellor, and under Treasurer of his Majts. Excheqr. and one of his Majts. Most Honble. Privy Councill.
figure.head: Pat: 10.

div.l: THY acred Succour, Arethua, bring,
To crown my Labour: 'tis the lat I ing.
Which proud Lycoris may with Pity view;
The Mue is mournful, tho' the Numbers few.
Refue me not a Vere, to Grief and Gallus due.
So may thy Silver Streams beneath the Tide,
Unmix'd with briny Seas, ecurely glide.
Sing then, my Gallus, and his hopeles Vows;
Sing, while my Cattle crop the tender Browze.
The vocal Grove hall anwer to the Sound,
And Echo, from the Vales, the tuneful Voice rebound.
What Lawns or Woods withheld you from his Aid,
Ye Nymphs, when Gallus was to Love betray'd;
To Love, unpity'd by the cruel Maid?
Not teepy Pindus cou'd retard your Coure,
Nor cleft Parnaus, nor th' Aonian Source:
Nothing that owns the Mues cou'd upend
Your Aid to Gallus, Gallus is their Friend.
For him the lofty Laurel tands in Tears;
And hung with humid Pearls the lowly Shrub appears.
Maenalian Pines the Godlike Swain bemoan;
When pread beneath a Rock he igh'd alone;
And cold Lycaeus wept from every dropping Stone.
The Sheep urround their Shepherd, as he lyes:
Bluh not, weet Poet, nor the name depie:
Along the Streams his Flock Adonis fed;
And yet the Queen of Beauty blet his Bed.
The Swains and tardy Neat-herds came, and lat
Menalcas, wet with beating Winter Mat.
Wond'ring, they ask'd from whence aroe thy Flame;
Yet, more amaz'd, thy own Apollo came.
Fluh'd were his Cheeks, and glowing were his Eyes:
Is he thy Care, is he thy Care, he cries?
Thy fale Lycoris flies thy Love and thee;
And for thy Rival tempts the raging Sea,
The Forms of horrid War, and Heav'ns Inclemency.
Sylvanus came: his Brows a Country Crown
Of Fennel, and of nodding Lillies, drown.
Great Pan arriv'd; and we beheld him too,
His Cheeks and Temples of Vermilion Hue.
Why, Gallus, this immod'rate Grief, he cry'd:
Think't thou that Love with Tears is atisfi'd?
The Meads are ooner drunk with Morning Dews;
The Bees with flow'ry Shrubs, the Goats with Brouze.
Unmov'd, and with dejected Eyes, he mourn'd:
He paus'd, and then thee broken Words return'd.
'Tis pat; and Pity gives me no Relief:
But you, Arcadian Swains, hall ing my Grief:
And on your Hills, my lat Complaints renew;
So ad a Song is onely worthy you.
How light wou'd lye the Turf upon my Breat,
If you my Suff'rings in your Songs expret?
Ah! that your Birth and Bus'nes had been mine;
To penn the Sheep, and pres the welling Vine!
Had Phyllis or Amyntas caus'd my Pain,
Or any Nymph, or Shepherd on the Plain,
Tho Phyllis brown, tho black Amyntas were,
Are Violets not weet, becaue not fair?
Beneath the Sallows, and the hady Vine,
My Loves had mix'd their pliant Limbs with mine;
Phyllis with Myrtle Wreaths had crown'd my Hair,
And oft Amyntas ung away my Care.
Come, ee what Pleaures in our Plains abound;
The Woods, the Fountains, and the flow'ry ground.
As you are beauteous, were you half o true,
Here cou'd I live, and love, and dye with only you.
Now I to fighting Fields am ent afar,
And trive in Winter Camps with toils of War;
While you, (alas, that I hou'd find it o!)
To hun my ight, your Native Soil forgo,
And climb the frozen Alps, and tread th' eternal Snow.
Ye Frots and Snows her tender Body pare,
Thoe are not Limbs for Yicles to tear.
For me, the Wilds and Dearts are my Choice;
The Mues, once my Care; my once harmonious Voice.
There will I ing, foraken and alone,
The Rocks and hollow Caves hall echo to my Moan.
The Rind of ev'ry Plant her Name hall know;
And as the Rind extends, the Love hall grow.
Then on Arcadian Mountains will I chae
(Mix'd with the Woodland Nymphs) the Salvage Race.
Nor Cold hall hinder me, with Horns and Hounds,
To thrid the Thickets, or to leap the Mounds.
And now methinks o're teepy Rocks I go;
And ruh through ounding Woods, and bend the Parthian Bow:
As if with Sports my Sufferings I could eae,
Or by my Pains the God of Love appeae.
My Frenzy changes, I delight no more
On Mountain tops, to chace the tusky Boar;
No Game but hopeles Love my thoughts purue:
Once more ye Nymphs, and Songs, and ounding Woods adieu.
Love alters not for us, his hard Decrees,
Not tho beneath the Thracian Clime we freeze;
Or Italy's indulgent Heav'n forgo;
And in mid-Winter tread Scythonian Snow.
Or when the Barks of Elms are corch'd, we keep
On Meroes burning Plains the Lybian Sheep.
In Hell, and Earth, and Seas, and Heav'n above,
Love conquers all; and we mut yield to Love.
My Mues, here your acred Raptures end:
The Vere was what I ow'd my uff'ring Friend.
This while I ung, my Sorrows I deceiv'd,
And bending Oiers into Baskets weav'd.
The Song, becaue inpir'd by you, hall hine:
And Gallus will approve, becaue 'tis mine.
Gallus, for whom my holy Flames renew,
Each hour, and ev'ry moment rie in view:
As Alders, in the Spring, their Boles extend;
And heave o fiercely, that the Bark they rend.
Now let us rie, for hoarenes oft invades
The Singer's Voice, who ings beneath the Shades.
From Juniper, unwholom Dews ditill,
That blat the ooty Corn; the with'ring Herbage kill;
Away, my Goats, away: for you have browz'd your fill.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE PHILIP Earl of Cheterfield, &c.
div.p:
I Cannot begin my Addres to your Lordhip, better than in the words of Virgil,
—Quod optanti, Divum promittere Nemo
Auderet, volvenda Dies, en, attulit ultrò.
Seven Years together I have conceal'd the longing which I had to appear before you: A time as tedious as Aeneas pas'd in his wandring Voyage, before he reach'd the promis'd Italy. But I conider'd, that nothing which my meannes cou'd produce, was worthy of your Patronage. At lat this happy Occaion offer'd, of Preenting to you the bet Poem of the bet Poet. If I balk'd this opportunity, I was in depair of finding uch another; and if I took it, I was till uncertain whether you wou'd vouchafe to accept it from my hands. 'Twas a bold venture which I made, in deiring your permiion to lay my unworthy Labours at your feet. But my rahnes has ucceeded beyond my hopes: And you have been pleas'd not to uffer an Old Man to go dicontented out of the World, for want of that protection, of which he had been o long Ambitious. I have known a Gentleman in digrace, and not daring to appear before King Charles the Second, though he much deir'd it: At length he took the confidence to attend a fair Lady to the Court; and told His Majety, that under her protection he had preum'd to wait on him. With the ame humble confidence I preent my elf before your Lordhip, and attending on Virgil hope a gracious reception. The Gentleman ucceeded, becaue the powerful Lady was his Friend; but I have too much injur'd my great Author, to expect he hould intercede for me. I wou'd have Tranlated him, but according to the litteral French and Italian Phraes, I fear I have traduc'd him. 'Tis the fault of many a well-meaning Man, to be officious in a wrong place, and do a prejudice, where he had endeavour'd to do a ervice. Virgil wrote his Georgics in the full trength and vigour of his Age, when his Judgment was at the height, and before his Fancy was declining. He had, (according to our homely Saying) his full wing at this Poem, beginning it about the Age of Thirty Five; and carce concluding it before he arriv'd at Forty. 'Tis oberv'd both of him, and Horace, and I believe it will hold in all great Poets; that though they wrote before with a certain heat of Genius which inpir'd them, yet that heat was not perfectly digeted. There is requir'd a continuance of warmth to ripen the bet and Noblet Fruits. Thus Horace in his Firt and Second
Book of Odes, was till riing, but came not to his Meridian 'till the Third. After which his Judgment was an overpoize to his Imagination: He grew too cautious to be bold enough, for he decended in his Fourth by low degrees, and in his Satires and Epitles, was more a Philoopher and a Critick than a Poet. In the beginning of Summer the days are almot at a tand, with little variation of length or hortnes, becaue at that time the Diurnal Motion of the Sun partakes more of a Right Line, than of a Spiral. The amè is the method of Nature in the frame of Man. He eems at Forty to be fully in his Summer Tropick; omewhat before, and omewhat after, he finds in his Soul but mall increaes or decays. From Fifty to Threecore the Ballance generally holds even, in our colder Clymates: For he loes not much in Fancy; and Judgment, which is the effect of Obervation, till increaes: His ucceeding years afford him little more than the tubble of his own Harvet: Yet if his Contitution be healthful, his Mind may till retain a decent vigour; and the Gleanings of that Ephraim, in Comparion with others, will urpas the Vintage of Abiezer. I have call'd this omewhere by a bold Metaphor, a green Old Age; but Virgil has given me his Authority for the Figure.
div.q:
Jam Senior; ed Cruda Deo, viridi
que Senectus.
div.p:
Amongst thoe few who enjoy the advantage of a latter Spring, your Lordhip is a rare Example: Who being now arriv'd at your great Clymacterique, yet give no proof of the leat decay in your Excellent Judgment, and comprehenion of all things, which are within the compas of Humane ndertanding. Your Converation is as eaie as it is intructive, and I cou'd never oberve the leat vanity or the leat auming in any thing you aid: but a natural unaffected Modety, full of good ene, and well digeted. A clearnes of Notion, expres'd in ready and untudied words. No Man has complain'd, or ever can, that you have dicours'd too long on any Subject: for you leave us in an eagernes of Learning more; pleas'd with what we hear, but not atisfy'd, becaue you will not peak o much as we cou'd wih. I dare not excue your Lordhip from this fault; for though 'tis none in you, 'tis one to all who have the happines of being known to you. I mut confes the Criticks make it one of Virgil's Beauties, that having aid what he thought convenient, he always left omewhat for the imagination of his Readers to upply: That they might gratifie their fancies, by finding more, in what he had written, than at firt they cou'd; and think they had added to his thought, when it was all there before-hand, and he only av'd himelf the expence of words. However it was, I never went from your Lordhip, but with a longing to return, or without a hearty Cure to him who invented Ceremonies in the World, and put me on the nec • ity of withdrawing, when it was my interet as well as my deire, to have given you a much longer trouble. I cannot imagine (if your Lordhip will give me leave to peak my thoughts) but you have had a more than ordinary vigour in your Youth. For too much of heat is requir'd at firt, that there may not too little be left at lat. A Prodigal Fire is only capable of large remains: And yours, my Lord, till burns the clearer in declining. The Blaze is not o fierce as at the firt, but the Smoak is wholly vanih'd; and your Friends who tand about you, are not only enible of a chearful warmth, but are kept at an awful ditance by its force. In my mall Obervations of Mankind, I have ever ound, that uch as are not rather too full of Spirit when they are young, degenerate to dullnes in their Age. Sobriety in our riper years is the effect of a well-concocted warmth; but where
the Principles are only Phlegm, what can be expected from the waterih Matter, but an inipid Manhood, and a tupid old Infancy; Dicretion in Leading-trings, and a confirm'd ignorance on Crutches? Virgil in his Third Georgic, when he decribes a Colt, who promies a Courer for the Race, or for the Field of Battel, hews him the firt to pas the Bridge, which trembles under him, and to tem the torrent of the flood. His beginnings mut be in rahnes; a Noble Fault: But Time and Experience will correct that Errour, and tame it into a deliberate and well-weigh'd Courage; which knows both to be cautious and to dare, as occaion offers. Your Lordhip is a Man of Honour, not only o untain'd, but o unquetion'd, that you are the living Standard of that Heroick Vertue; o truly uch, that if I wou'd flatter you, I cou'd not. It takes not from you, that you were born with Principles of Generoity and Probity: But it adds to you, that you have cultivated Nature, and made thoe Principles, the Rule and Meaure of all your Actions. The World knows this, without my telling: Yet Poets have a right of Recording it to all Poterity. Dignum Laude Virum, Mua vetat Mori. Epaminondas, Lucullus, and the two firt Caears, were not eteem'd the wore Commanders, for having made Philoophy, and the Liberal Arts their Study. Cicero might have been their Equal, but that he wanted Courage. To have both thee Vertues, and to have improv'd them both, with a oftnes of Manners, and a weetnes of Converation, few of our Nobility can fill that Character: One there is, and o conpicuous by his own light, that he needs not

To be Nobly Born, and of an Ancient Family, is in the extreams of Fortune, either good or bad; for Virtue and Decent are no Inheritance. A long Series of Ancetours hews the Native with great advantage at the firt; but if he any way degenerate from his Line, the leat Spot is viible on Ermine. But to preerve this whitenes in its Original Purity, you, my Lord, have, like that Ermine, foraken the common Track of Buines, which is not always clean: You have choen for your elf a private Greatnes, and will not be polluted with Ambition. It has been oberv'd in former times, that none have been o greedy of Employments, and of managing the Publick, as they who have leat deerv'd their Stations. But uch only merit to be call'd Patriots, under whom we ee their Country Flourih. I have laugh'd ometimes (for who wou'd always be a Heraclitus?) when I have reflected on thoe Men, who from time to time have hot themelves into the World. I have een many Succeions of them; ome bolting out upon the Stage with vat applaue, and others his'd off, and quitting it with digrace. But while they were in action, I have contantly oberv'd, that they eem'd deirous to retreat from Buines: Greatnes they aid was naueous, and a Crowd was troubleome; a quiet privacy was their Ambition. Some few of them I believe aid this in earnet, and were making a proviion againt future want, that they might enjoy their Age with eae: They aw the happines of a private Life, and promis'd to themelves a Bleing, which every day it was in their power to poes. But they deferr'd it, and linger'd till at Court, becaue they thought they had not yet enough to make them happy: They wou'd have more, and laid in to make their Solitude Luxurious. A wretched Philoophy, which Epicurus never taught them in his Garden: They lov'd the propect of this
quiet in reverion, but were not willing to have it in poeion; they wou'd firt be Old, and made as ure of Health and Life, as if both of them were at their dipoe. But put them to the neceity of a preent choice, and they preferr'd continuance in Power: Like the Wretch who call'd Death to his aitance, but refus'd it when he came. The Great Scipio was not of their Opinion, who indeed ought Honours in his Youth, and indur'd the Fatigues with which he purchas'd them. He erv'd his Country when it was in need of his Courage and his Conduct, 'till he thought it was time to erve himelf: But dimounted from the Saddle, when he found the Beat which bore him, began to grow retiff and ungovernable. But your Lordhip has given us a better Example of Moderation. You aw betimes that Ingratitude is not confin'd to Commonwealths; and therefore though you were form'd alike, for the greatet of Civil Employments, and Military Commands, yet you puh'd not your Fortune to rie in either; but contented your elf with being capable, as much as any whooever, of defending your Country with your Sword, or aiting it with your Counel, when you were call'd. For the ret, the repect and love which was paid you, not only in the Province where you live, but generally by all who had the happines to know you, was a wie Exchange for the Honours of the Court: A place of forgetfulnes, at the bet, for well deervers. 'Tis neceary for the polihing of Manners, to have breath'd that Air, but 'tis infectious even to the bet Morals to live always in it. 'Tis a dangerous Commerce, where an honet Man is ure at the firt of being Cheated; and he recovers not his Loes, but by learning to Cheat others. The undermining Smile becomes at length habitual; and the drift of his plauible Converation, is only to flatter one, that he may betray another. Yet 'tis good to have been a looker on, without venturing to play; that a Man may know fale Dice another time, though he never means to ue them. I commend not him who never knew a Court, but him who forakes it becaue he knows it. A young Man deerves no praie, who out of melancholy Zeal leaves the World before he has well try'd it, and runs headlong into Religion. He who carries a Maidenhead into a Cloyter, is ometimes apt to loe it there, and to repent of his Repentance. He only is like to endure Auterities, who has already found the inconvenience of Pleaures. For almot every Man will be making Experiments in one part or another of his Life: And the danger is the les when we are young: For having try'd it early, we hall not be apt to repeat it afterwards. Your Lordhip therefore may properly be aid to have choen a Retreat; and not to have choen it 'till you had maturely weigh'd the advantages of riing higher with the hazards of the fall. Res non parta labore, ed relicta, was thought by a Poet, to be one of the requiites to a happy Life. Why hou'd a reaonable Man put it into the power of Fortune to make him mierable, when his Ancetours have taken care to releae him from her? Let him venture, ays Horace, Qui Zonam perdidit. He who has nothing, plays ecurely, for he may win, and cannot be poorer if he loes. But he who is born to a plentiful Etate, and is Ambitious of Offices at Court, ets a take to Fortune, which he can eldom anwer: If he gains nothing, he loes all, or part of what was once his own; and if he gets, he cannot be certain but he may refund.

In hort, however he ucceeds, 'tis Covetounes that induc'd him firt to play, and Covetounes is the undoubted ign of ill ene at bottom. The Odds are againt him that he loes, and one los may be of more conequence to him, than all his former winnings. 'Tis like the preent War of the Chritians againt the Turk; every year they gain a Victory, and by that a Town; but if they are once defeated, they loe a Province at a blow, and endanger the afety of the whole Empire. You, my Lord, enjoy your quiet in a Garden,
where you have not only the leiure of thinking, but the pleaure to think of nothing which can dicompoe your Mind. A good Concience is a Port which is Land-lock'd on every ide, and where no Winds can poibly invade, no Tempets can arie. There a Man may tand upon the Shore, and not only ee his own Image, but that of his Maker, clearly reflected from the unditurb'd and ilent waters. Reaon was intended for a Bleing, and uch it is to Men of Honour and Integrity; who deire no more, than what they are able to give themelves; like the happy Old Coricyan, whom my Author decribes in his Fourth Georgic; whoe Fruits and Salads on which he liv'd contented, were all of his own growth, and his own Plantation. Virgil eems to think that the Bleings of a Country Life are not compleat, without an improvement of Knowledge by Contemplation and Reading.

q.l: O Fortunatos nimium, bona i ua norint
Agricolas!

div.p: 'Tis but half poeion not to undertand that happines which we poes: A foundation of good Sene, and a cultivation of Learning, are requir'd to give a eaoning to Retirement, and make us tate the bleing. God has betow'd on your Lordhip the firt of thee, and you have betow'd on your elf the econd. Eden was not made for Beats, though they were uffer'd to live in it, but for their Mater, who tudied God in the Works of his Creation. Neither cou'd the Devil have been happy there with all his Knowledge, for he wanted Innocence to make him o. He brought Envy, Malice, and Ambition into Paradie, which our'd to him the weetnes of the Place. Wherever inordinate Affections are, 'tis Hell. Such only can enjoy the Country, who are capable of thinking when they are there, and have left their Paions behind them in the Town. Then they are prepar'd for Solitude; and in that Solitude is prepar'd for them Et ecura quies, & necia fallere vita.

As I began this Dedication with a Vere of Virgil, o I conclude it with another. The continuance of your Health, to enjoy that Happines which you o well deerve, and which you have provided for your elf, is the incere and earnet Wih of

closer.signed: Your Lordhip's mot Devoted, and mot Obedient Servant, JOHN DRYDEN.

div.head: AN ESSAY ON THE GEORGICS.
div.p: VIRGIL may be reckon'd the firt who introduc'd three new kinds of Poetry among the Romans, which he Copied after three the Greatet Maters of Greece. Theocritus and Homer have till diputed for the advantage over him in Patoral and Heroicks, but I think all are Unanimous in giving him the precedence to Heiod in his Georgies. The truth of it is, the Sweetnes and Ruticity of a Patoral cannot be o well expret in any other Tongue as in the Greek, when rightly mixt and qualified with the Doric Dialect; nor can the Majety of an Heroick Poem any where appear o well as in this Language, which has a Natural greatnes in it, and can be often render'd more deep and onorous by the Pronunciation of the Ionians. But in the middle Stile, where the Writers in both Tongues are on a Level: we ee how far Virgil has excell'd all who have written in the ame way with him.

There has been abundance of Criticim pent on Virgil's Patorals and Aeneids, but the Georgics are a Subject which none of the Criticks have ufficiently taken into their Conideration; mot of 'em paing it over in ilence, or cating it under the ame head with Patoral; a diviion by no means proper, unles we uppoe the Stile of a Hubandman ought to be imitated in a Georgic as that of a Shepherd is in Patoral. But tho' the Scene of both thee Poems lies in the ame place; the Speakers in them are of a quite different Character, ince the Precepts of Husbandry are not to be deliver'd with the implicity of a Plow-Man, but with the Addres of a Poet. No Rules therefore that relate to Patoral, can any way affect the Georgics, which fall under that Clas of Poetry which conits in giving plain and direct Intructions to the Reader; whether they be Moral Duties, as thoe of Theognis and Pythagoras; or Philoophical Speculations, as thoe of Aratus and Lucretius; or Rules of Practice, as thoe of Heiod and Virgil. Among thee different kinds of Subjects, that which the Georgics goes upon, is I think the meanet and the leat improving, but the mot pleaing and delightful. Precepts of Morality, beides the Natural Corruption of our Tempers, which makes us avere to them, are o abtracted from Ideas of Sene, that they eldom give an
opportunity for thoe Beautiful Decriptions and Images which are the Spirit and Life of Poetry. Natural Philoophy has indeed enible Objects to work upon, but then it often puzzles the Reader with the Intricacy of its Notions, and perplexes him with the multitude of its Diputes. But this kind of Poetry I am now peaking of, addrees it elf wholly to the Imagination: It is altogether Converant among the Fields and Woods, and has the mot delightful part of Nature for its Province. It raies in our Minds a pleaing variety of Scenes and Landskips, whilt it teaches us: and makes the dryet of its Precepts look like a Decription. A Georgic therefore is ome part of the Science of Husbandry put into a pleaing Dres, and et off with all the Beauties and Embellihments of Poetry. Now ince this Science of Husbandry is of a very large extent, the Poet hews his Skill in ingling out uch Precepts to preceed on, as are ueful, and at the ame time mot capable of Ornament. Virgil was o well acquainted with this Secret, that to et off his firt Georgic, he has run into a et of Precepts, which are almot foreign to his Subject, in that Beautiful account he gives us of the Signs in Nature, which precede the Changes of the Weather.

And if there be o much Art in the choice of fit Precepts, there is much more requir'd in the Treating of 'em; that they may fall in after each other by a Natural unforc'd Method, and hew themelves in the bet and mot advantagious Light. They hou'd all be o finely wrought together into the ame Piece, that no coure Seam may dicover where they joyn; as in a Curious Brede of Needle-Work, one Colour falls away by uch jut degrees, and another ries o inenibly, that we ee the variety, without being able to ditinguih the total vanihing of the one from the firt appearance of the other. Nor is it ufficient to range and dipoe this Body of Precepts into a clear and eaie Method, unles they are deliver'd to us in the mot pleaing and agreeable manner: For there are everal ways of conveying the ame Truth to the Mind of Man, and to chue the pleaantet of thee ways, is that which chiefly ditinguihes Poetry from Proe, and makes Virgil's Rules of Husbandry pleaanter to read than Varro's. Where the Proe-writer tells us plainly what ought to be done, the Poet often conceals the Precept in a decription, and repreents his Country-Man performing the Action in which he wou'd intruct his Reader. Where the one ets out as fully and ditinctly as he can, all the parts of the Truth, which he wou'd communicate to us; the other ingles out the mot pleaing Circumtance of this Truth, and o conveys the whole in a more diverting manner to the Undertanding. I hall give one Intance out of a multitude of this nature, that might be found in the Georgics, where the Reader may ee the different ways Virgil has taken to expres the ame thing, and how much pleaanter every manner of Expreion is, than the plain and direct mention of it wou'd have been. It is in the Second Georgic where he tells us what Trees will bear Grafting on each other.

l.hi: Et aepe alterius ramos impune videmus,

Vertere in alterius, mutatam
que ; inita mala
Ferre pyrum, & prunis lapidoa rubecere corna.

Cataneae fagos, ornu
que ; incanuit albo

q.l:
Flore pyri: Glandem
que ; ues fregere ub ulmis.
—Nec longum tempus: & ingens
Exijt ad Coelum ramis felicibus arbos;

Miratur
que novas frondes, & non ua poma.

div.p: Here we ee the Poet conider'd all the Effects of this Union between Trees of different kinds, and took notice of that Effect which had the mot urprize, and by conequence the mot delight in it, to expres the capacity that was in them of being thus united. This way of Writing is every where much in ue among the Poets, and is particularly practis'd by Virgil, who loves to ugget a Truth indirectly, and without giving us a full and open view of it: To let us ee jut o much as will naturally lead the Imagination into all the parts that lie conceal'd. This is wonderfully diverting to the Undertanding, thus to receive a Precept, that enters as it were through a By-way, and to apprehend an Idea that draws a whole train after it: For here the Mind, which is always delighted with its own Dicoveries, only takes the hint from the Poet, and eems to work out the ret by the trength of her own faculties.

But ince the inculcating Precept upon Precept, will at length prove tireom to the Reader, if he meets with no other Entertainment, the Poet mut take care not to encumber his Poem with too much Buines; but ometimes to relieve the Subject with a Moral Reflection, or let it ret a while for the ake of a pleaant and pertinent digreion. Nor is it ufficient to run out into beautiful and diverting digreions (as it is generally thought) unles they are brought in aptly, and are omething of a piece with the main deign of the Georgic: for they ought to have a remote alliance at leat to the Subject, that o the whole Poem may be more uniform and agreeable in all its parts. We hou'd never quite loe ight of the Country, tho' we are ometimes entertain'd with a ditant propect of it. Of this nature are Virgil's Decriptions of the Original of Agriculture, of the Fruitfulnes of Italy, of a Country Life, and the like, which are not brought in by force, but naturally rie out of the principal Argument and Deign of the Poem. I know no one digreion in the Georgics that may eem to contradict this Obervation, beides that in the latter end of the Firt Book, where the Poet launches out into a dicoure of the Battel of Pharalia, and the Actions of Augutus: But it's worth while to conider how admirably he has turn'd the coure of his narration into its proper Channel, and made his Husbandman concern'd even in what relates to the Battel, in thoe inimitable Lines,
Scilicet & tempus veniet, cum finibus illis
Agricola in curvo terram molitus aratro,
Exea inveniet cabra rubigine pila:
Aut gravibus ratris galeas pulabit inanes,
Grandia
que effois mirabitur oa epulchris.
And afterwards peaking of Augutus's Actions, he till remembers that Agriculture ought to be ome way hinted at throughout the whole Poem.

q.l: —Non ullus Aratro
Dignus honos: qualent abductis arva colonis:
Et curvae rigidum falces conflantur in Enem.

div.p: We now come to the Stile which is proper to a Georgic; and indeed this is the part on which the Poet mut lay out all his trength, that his words may be warm and glowing, and that every thing he decribes may immediately preent it elf, and rie up to the Reader's view. He ought in particular to be careful of not letting his Subject debae his Stile, and betray him into a meannes of Expreion, but every where to keep up his Vere in all the Pomp of Numbers, and Dignity of words.

I think nothing which is a Phrae or Sayingin common talk, hou'd be admitted into a erious Poem: becaue it takes off from the Solemnity of the expreion, and gives it too great a turn of Familiarity: much les ought the low Phraes and Terms of Art, that are adapted to Husbandry, have any place in uch a Work as the Georgic, which is not to appear in the natural implicity and nakednes of its Subject, but in the pleaantet Dres that Poetry can betow on it. Thus Virgil, to deviate from the common form of words, wou'd not make ue of Tempore but Sidere in his firt Vere, and every where ele abounds with Metaphors, Grecims, and Circumlocutions, to give his Vere the greater Pomp, and preerve it from inking into a Plebeian Stile. And herein conits Virgil's Mater-piece, who has not only excell'd all other Poets, but even himelf in the Language of his Georgics; where we receive more trong and lively Ideas of things from his words, than we cou'd have done from the Objects themelves: and find our Imaginations more affected by his Decriptions, than they wou'd have been by the very ight of what he decribes.

I hall now, after this hort Scheme of Rules, conider the different ucces that Heiod and Virgil have met with in this kind of Poetry, which may give us ome further Notion of the Excellence of the Georgics. To begin with Heiod; If we may gues at his Character from his Writings, he had much more of the Husbandman than the Poet in his Temper: He was wonderfully Grave, Dicreet, and Frugal, he liv'd altogether in the Country, and was probably for his great Prudence the Oracle of the whole Neighbourhood. Thee Principles of good Husbandry ran through his Works, and directed him to the choice of Tillage, and Merchandie, for the Subject of that which is the mot Celebrated of them. He is every where bent on Intruction, avoids all manner of Digreions, and does not tir out of the Field once in the whole Georgic. His Method in decribing Month after Month with its proper Seaons and Employments, is too grave and fimple; it takes off from the urprize and variety of the Poem, and makes the whole look but like a modern Almanack in Vere. The Reader is carried through a coure of Weather, and may beforehand gues whether he is to meet with Snow or Rain, Clouds or Sunhine in the next Decription. His Decriptions indeed have abundance of Nature in them, but then it is Nature in her implicity and undres. Thus when he peaks of January; the Wild-Beats, ays he, run hivering through the Woods with their Heads tooping to the ground, and their Tails clapt between their Legs; the Goats and Oxen are almot flead with Cold; but it is not o bad with the Sheep, becaue they have a thick Coat of Wooll about 'em. The Old Men too are bitterly pincht with the Weather, but the young Girls feel nothing of it, who it at home
with their Mothers by a warm Fire-ide. Thus does the Old Gentleman give himelf up to a looe kind of Tattle, rather than endeavour after a jut Poetical Decription. Nor has he hewn more of Art or Judgment in the Precepts he has given us, which are own o very thick, that they clog the Poem too much, and are often o minute and full of Circumtances, that they weaken and un-nerve his Vere. But after all, we are beholding to him for the firt rough sketch of a Georgic: where we may till dicover omething venerable in the Anticknes of the Work; but if we wou'd ee the Deign enlarg'd, the Figures reform'd, the Colouring laid on, and the whole Piece finih'd, we mut expect it from a greater Mater's hand.

Virgil has drawn out the Rules for Tillage and Planting into Two Books, which Heiod has dipatcht in half a one; but has o rais'd the natural rudenes and implicity of his Subject with uch a ignificancy of Expreion, uch a Pomp of Vere, uch variety of Tranitions, and uch a olemn Air in his Reflections, that if we look on both Poets together, we ee in one the plainnes of a down-right Country-Man, and in the other, omething of a Rutick Majety, like that of a Roman Dictator at the Plow-Tail. He delivers the meanet of his Precepts with a kind of Grandeur, he breaks the Clods and toes the Dung about with an air of gracefulnes. His Prognotications of the Weather are taken out of Aratus, where we may ee how judiciouly he has pickt out thoe that are mot proper for his Husbandman's Obervation; how he has enforc'd the Expreion, and heighten'd the Images which he found in the Original.

The Second Book has more wit in it, and a greater boldnes in its Metaphors than any of the ret. The Poet with a great Beauty applies Oblivion, Ignorance, Wonder, Deire and the like to his Trees. The lat Georgic has indeed as many Metaphors, but not o daring as this; for Humane Thoughts and Paions may be more naturally acrib'd to a Bee, than to an Inanimate Plant. He who reads over the Pleaures of a Country Life, as they are decrib'd by Virgil in the latter end of this Book, can carce be of Virgil's Mind, in preferring even the Life of a Philoopher to it.

We may I think read the Poet's Clime in his Decription, for he eems to have been in a weat at the Writing of it.
—O Quis me gelidis ub Montibus Haemi
Sitat, & ingenti ramorum protegat umbr â!
And is every where mentioning among his chief Pleaures, the coolnes of his Shades and Rivers, Vales and Grottos, which a more Northern Poet wou'd have omitted for the decription of a Sunny Hill, and Fire-ide.

The Third Georgic eems to be the mot labour'd of 'em all; there is a wonderful Vigour and Spirit in the decription of the Hore and Chariot-Race. The force of Love is repreented in Noble Intances, and very Sublime Expreions. The Scythian Winter-piece appears o very cold and bleak to the Eye, that a Man can carce look on it without hivering. The Murrain at the end has all the expreivenes
that words can give. It was here that the Poet train'd hard to outdo Lucretius in the decription of his Plague; and if the Reader wou'd ee what ucces he had, he may find it at large in Scaliger.

But Virgil eems no where o well pleas'd, as when he is got among his Bees in the Fourth Georgic: And Ennobles the Actions of o trivial a Creature, with Metaphors drawn from the mot important Concerns of Mankind. His Veres are not in a greater noie and hurry in the Battels of Aeneas and Turnus, than in the Engagement of two Swarms. And as in his Aeneis he compares the Labours of his Trojans to thoe of Bees and Pimires, here he compares the Labours of the Bees to thoe of the Cyclops. In hort, the lat Georgic was a good Prelude to the Aeneis; and very well hew'd what the Poet could do in the decription of what was really great, by his decribing the Mock-grandeur of an Inect with o good a grace. There is more pleaantnes in the little Platform of a Garden, which he gives us about the middle of this Book, than in all the pacious Walks and Water-works of Rapin's. The Speech of Proteus at the end can never be enough admir'd, and was indeed very fit to conclude o Divine a Work.

After this particular account of the Beauties in the Georgics, I hou'd in the next place endeavour to point out its imperfections, if it has any. But tho' I think there are ome few parts in it that are not o Beautiful as the ret, I hall not preume to name them, as rather upecting my own Judgment, than I can believe a fault to be in that Poem, which lay o long under Virgil's Correction, and had his lat hand put to it. The firt Georgic was probably Burlequ'd in the Author's Lifetime; for we till find in the Scholiats a Vere that ridicules part of a Line Tranlated from Heiod. Nudus Ara, ere Nudus—And we may eaily gues at the Judgment of this extraordinary Critick, whoever he was, from his Cenuring this particular Precept. We may be ure Virgil wou'd not have Tranlated it from Heiod, had he not dicover'd ome Beauty in it; and indeed the Beauty of it is what I have before oberv'd to be frequently met with in Virgil, the delivering the Precept o indirectly, and ingling out the particular circumtance of Sowing and Plowing naked, to ugget to us that thee Employments are proper only in the hot Seaon of the Year.

I hall not here compare the Stile of the Georgics with that of Lucretius, which the Reader may ee already done in the Preface to the Second Volume of Micellany Poems; but hall conclude this Poem to be the mot Compleat, Elaborate, and finiht Piece of all Antiquity. The Aeneis indeed is of a Nobler kind, but the Georgic is more perfect in its kind. The Aeneid has a greater variety of Beauties in it, but thoe of the Georgic are more exquiite. In hort, the Georgic has all the perfection that can be expected in a Poem written by the greatet Poet in the Flower of his Age, when his Invention was ready, his Imagination warm, his Judgment ettled, and all his Faculties in their full Vigour and Maturity.

div.head: Virgil's Georgics.
The Firt Book of the Georgics.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Poet, in the beginning of this Book, propounds the general Deign of each Georgic: And after a olemn Invocation of all the Gods who are any way related to his Subject, he addrees himelf in particular to Augutus, whom he complements with Divinity; and after trikes into his Buines. He hews the different kinds of Tillage proper to different Soils, traces out the Original of Agriculture, gives a Catalogue of the Husbandman's Tools, pecifies the Employments pecultar to each Seaon, decribes the changes of the Weather, with the Signs in Heaven and Earth that fore-bode them. Intances many of the Prodigies that happen'd near the time of Julius Caear's Death. And huts up all with a Supplication to the Gods for the Safety of Augutus, and the Prefervation of Rome.

figure.p: To Sr Thomas Trevor of the Inner Temple Knight His Majestys Attorny Generall.
figure.head: Geor: 1 L. 1

lg.l: WHat makes a plenteous Harvet, when to turn
The fruitful Soil, and when to owe the Corn;
The Care of Sheep, of Oxen, and of Kine;
And how to raie on Elms the teeming Vine:
The Birth and Genius of the frugal Bee,
I ing, Mecaenas, and I ing to thee.
Ye Deities! who Fields and Plains protect,
Who rule the Seaons, and the Year direct;
Bacchus and fot'ring Ceres, Pow'rs Divine,
Who gave us Corn for Mat, for Water Wine.
Ye Fawns, propitious to the Rural Swains,
Ye Nymphs that haunt the Mountains and the Plains,
Join in my Work, and to my Numbers bring
Your needful Succour, for your Gifts I ing.
And thou, whoe Trident truck the teeming Earth,
And made a Paage for the Courers Birth.
And thou, for whom the Caean Shore utains
Thy Milky Herds, that graze the Flow'ry Plains.
And thou, the Shepherds tutelary God,
Leave, for a while, O Pan! thy lov'd Abode:
And, if Arcadian Fleeces be thy Care,
From Fields and Mountains to my Song repair.
Inventor, Pallas, of the fat'ning Oyl,
Thou Founder of the Plough and Plough-man's Toyl;
And thou, whoe Hands the Shrowd-like Cypres rear;
Come all ye Gods and Goddees, that wear
The rural Honours, and increae the Year.
You, who upply the Ground with Seeds of Grain;
And you, who well thoe Seeds with kindly Rain:
And chiefly thou, whoe undetermin'd State
Is yet the Buines of the Gods Debate:
Whether in after Times to be declar'd
The Patron of the World, and Rome's peculiar Guard,
Or o're the Fruits and Seaons to preide,
And the round Circuit of the Year to guide.
Pow'rful of Bleings, which thou trew't around,
And with thy Goddes Mother's Myrtle crown'd.
Or wilt thou, Caear, chue the watry Reign,
To mooth the Surges, and correct the Main?
Then Mariners, in Storms, to thee hall pray,
Ev'n utmot Thule hall thy Pow'r obey;
And Neptune hall reign the Faces of the Sea.
The wat'ry Virgins for thy Bed hall trive,
And Tethys all her Waves in Dowry give.
Or wilt thou bles our Summers with thy Rays,
And eated near the Ballance, poie the Days:
Where in the Void of Heav'n a Space is free,
Betwixt the Scorpion and the Maid for thee.
The Scorpion ready to receive thy Laws,
Yields half his Region, and contracts his Claws.
Whatever part of Heav'n thou halt obtain,
For let not Hell preume of uch a Reign;
Nor let o dire a Thirt of Empire move
Thy Mind, to leave thy Kindred Gods above.
Tho' Greece admires Elyium's blet Retreat,
Tho' Proerpine affects her ilent Seat,
And importun'd by Ceres to remove,
Prefers the Fields below to thoe above.
But thou, propitious Caear, guide my Coure,
And to my bold Endeavours add thy Force.
Pity the Poet's and the Ploughman's Cares,
Int'ret thy Greatnes in our mean Affairs,
And ue thy elf betimes to hear our Pray'rs.
While yet the Spring is young, while Earth unbinds
Her frozen Boom to the Wetern Winds;
While Mountain Snows diolve againt the Sun,
And Streams, yet new, from Precipices run.
Ev'n in this early Dawning of the Year,
Produce the Plough, and yoke the turdy Steer,
And goad him till he groans beneath his Toil,
'Till the bright Share is bury'd in the Soil.
That Crop rewards the greedy Peaant's Pains,
Which twice the Sun, and twice the Cold utains,
And burts the crowded Barns, with more than promis'd Gains.
But e're we tir the yet unbroken Ground,
The various Coure of Seaons mut be found;
The Weather, and the etting of the Winds,
The Culture uiting to the ev'ral Kinds
Of Seeds and Plants; and what will thrive and rie,
And what the Genius of the Soil denies.
This Ground with Bacchus, that with Ceres uits:
That other loads the Trees with happy Fruits.
A fourth with Gras, unbidden, decks the Ground:
Thus Tmolus is with yellow Saffron crown'd:
India, black Ebon and white Ivory bears:
And oft Idume weeps her od'rous Tears.
Thus Pontus ends her Beaver Stones from far;
And naked Spanyards temper Steel for War.
Epirus for th' Elean Chariot breeds,
(In hopes of Palms,) a Race of running Steeds.
This is the Orig'nal Contract; thee the Laws
Impos'd by Nature, and by Nature's Caue,
On undry Places, when Deucalion hurl'd
his Mother's Entrails on the deart World:
Whence Men, a hard laborious Kind, were born.
Then borrow part of Winter for thy Corn;
And early with thy Team the Gleeb in Furrows turn.
That while the Turf lies open, and unbound,
Succeeding Suns may bake the Mellow Ground.
But if the Soil be barren, only car
The Surface, and but lightly print the Share,
When cold Arcturus ries with the Sun:
Let wicked Weeds the Corn hou'd over-run
In watry Soils; or let the barren Sand
Shou'd uck the Moiture from the thirty Land.
Both thee unhappy Soils the Swain forbears,
And keeps a Sabbath of alternate Years:
That the pent Earth may gather heart again;
And, better'd by Ceation, bear the Grain.
At leat where Vetches, Pule, and Tares have tood,
And Stalks of Lupines grew (a tubborn Wood:)
Th' enuing Seaon, in return, may bear
The bearded product of the Golden Year.
For Flax and Oats will burn the tender Field,
And leepy Poppies harmful Harvets yield.
But weet Viciitudes of Ret and Toyl
Make eay Labour, and renew the Soil.
Yet prinkle ordid Ahes all around,
And load with fat'ning Dung thy fallow Ground.
Thus change of Seeds for meagre Soils is bet;
And Earth manur'd, not idle, though at ret.
Long Practice has a ure Improvement found,
With kindled Fires to burn the barren Ground;
When the light Stubble, to the Flames reign'd,
Is driv'n along, and crackles in the Wind.
Whether from hence the hollow Womb of Earth
Is warm'd with ecret Strength for better Birth,
Or when the latent Vice is cur'd by Fire,
Redundant Humours thro' the Pores expire;
Or that the Warmth ditends the Chinks, and makes
New Breathings, whence new Nourihment he takes;
Or that the Heat the gaping Ground contrains,
New Knits the Surface, and new Strings the Veins;
Let oaking Show'rs hou'd pierce her ecret Seat,
Or freezing Boreas chill her genial Heat;
Or corching Suns too violently beat.
Nor is the Profit mall, the Peaant makes;
Who mooths with Harrows, or who pounds with Rakes
The crumbling Clods: Nor Ceres from on high
Regards his Labours with a grudging Eye;
Nor his, who plows acros the furrow'd Grounds,
And on the Back of Earth inflicts new Wounds:
For he with frequent Exercie Commands
Th' unwilling Soil, and tames the tubborn Lands.
Ye Swains, invoke the Pow'rs who rule the Sky,
For a moit Summer, and a Winter dry:
For Winter drout rewards the Peaant's Pain,
And broods indulgent on the bury'd Grain.
Hence Myia boats her Harvets, and the tops
Of Gargarus admire their happy Crops.
When firt the Soil receives the fruitful Seed,
Make no delay, but cover it with peed:
So fenc'd from Cold; the plyant Furrows break,
Before the urly Clod reits the Rake.
And call the Floods from high, to ruh amain
With pregnant Streams, to well the teeming Grain.
Then when the fiery Suns too fiercely play,
And hrivell'd Herbs on with'ring Stems decay,
The wary Ploughman, on the Mountain's Brow,
Undams his watry Stores, huge Torrents flow;
And, ratling down the Rocks, large moiture yield,
Temp'ring the thirty Fever of the Field.
And let the Stem, too feeble for the freight,
Shou'd carce utain the head's unweildy weight,
Sends in his feeding Flocks betimes t'invade
The riing bulk of the luxuriant Blade;
E're yet th'apiring Off-pring of the Grain
O'retops the ridges of the furrow'd Plain:
And drains the tanding Waters, when they yield
Too large a Bev'rage to the drunken Field.
But mot in Autumn, and the how'ry Spring,
When dubious Months uncertain weather bring;
When Fountains open, when impetuous Rain
Swells haty Brooks, and pours upon the Plain;
When Earth with Slime and Mud is cover'd o're,
Or hollow places pue their wat'ry Store.
Nor yet the Ploughman, nor the lab'ring Steer,
Sutain alone the hazards of the Year:
But glutton Geee, and the Strymonian Crane,
With foreign Troops, invade the tender Grain:
And tow'ring Weeds malignant Shadows yield;
And preading Succ'ry choaks the riing Field.
The Sire of Gods and Men, with hard Decrees,
Forbids our Plenty to be bought with Eae:
And wills that Mortal Men, inur'd to toil,
Shou'd exercie, with pains, the grudging Soil.
Himelf invented firt the hining Share,
And whetted Humane Indutry by Care:
Himelf did Handy-Crafts and Arts ordain;
Nor uffer'd Sloath to rut his active Reign.
E're this, no Peaant vex'd the peaceful Ground;
Which only Turfs and Greens for Altars found:
No Fences parted Fields, nor Marks nor Bounds
Ditinguih'd Acres of litigious Grounds:
But all was common, and the fruitful Earth
Was free to give her unexacted Birth.
Jove added Venom to the Viper's Brood,
And well'd, with raging Storms, the peaceful Flood:
Commiion'd hungry Wolves t' infet the Fold,
And hook from Oaken Leaves the liquid Gold.
Remov'd from Humane reach the chearful Fire,
And from the Rivers bade the Wine retire:
That tudious Need might ueful Arts explore;
From furrow'd Fields to reap the foodful Store:
And force the Veins of clahing Flints t' expire
The lurking Seeds of their Coeletial Fire.
Then firt on Seas the hollow'd Alder wam;
Then Sailers quarter'd Heav'n, and found a Name
For ev'ry fix'd and ev'ry wandring Star:
The Pleiads, Hyads, and the Northern Car.
Then Toils for Beats, and Lime for Birds were found,
And deep-mouth Dogs did Forret Walks urround:
And cating Nets were pread in hallow Brooks,
Drags in the Deep, and Baits were hung on Hooks.
Then Saws were tooth'd, and ounding Axes made;
(For Wedges firt did yielding Wood invade.)
And various Arts in order did ucceed,
(What cannot endles Labour urg'd by need?)
Firt Ceres taught, the Ground with Grain to ow,
And arm'd with Iron Shares the crooked Plough;
When now Dodonian Oaks no more upply'd
Their Mat, and Trees their Forret-fruit deny'd.
Soon was his Labour doubl'd to the Swain,
And blating Mildews blackned all his Grain.
Tough Thitles choak'd the Fields, and kill'd the Corn,
And an unthrifty Crop of Weeds was born.
Then Burrs and Brambles, an unbidden Crew
Of graceles Guets, th' unhappy Field ubdue:
And Oats unblet, and Darnel domineers,
And hoots its head above the hining Ears.
So that unles the Land with daily Care
Is exercis'd, and with an Iron War,
Of Rakes and Harrows, the proud Foes expell'd,
And Birds with clamours frighted from the Field;
Unles the Boughs are lopp'd that hade the Plain,
And Heav'n invok'd with Vows for fruitful Rain,
On other Crops you may with envy look,
And hake for Food the long abandon'd Oak.
Nor mut we pas untold what Arms they wield,
Who labour Tillage and the furrow'd Field:
Without whoe aid the Ground her Corn denys,
And nothing can be own, and nothing rie.
The crooked Plough, the Share, the towr'ing height
Of Waggons, and the Cart's unweildy weight;
The Sled, the Tumbril, Hurdles and the Flail,
The Fan of Bacchus, with the flying Sail.
Thee all mut be prepar'd, if Plowmen hope
The promis'd Bleing of a Bounteous Crop.
Young Elms with early force in Copes bow,
Fit for the Figure of the crooked Plough.

figure.p: To Sr Iohn Hawles of Lincolns Inn in the County of Midlesex Knt: His Majestyes Solicitor Genll:
figure.head: Geor. 1. L. 240.

lg.l: Of eight Foot long a fatned Beam prepare,
On either ide the Head produce an Ear,
And ink a Socket for the hining Share.
Of Beech the Plough-tail, and the bending Yoke;
Or ofter Linden harden'd in the Smoke.
I cou'd be long in Precepts, but I fear
So mean a Subject might offend your Ear.
Delve of convenient Depth your thrahing Floor;
With temper'd Clay, then fill and face it o're:
And let the weighty Rowler run the round,
To mooth the Surface of th' unequal Ground;
Let crack'd with Summer Heats the flooring flies,
Or inks, and thro' the Crannies Weeds arie.
For undry Foes the Rural Realm urround:
The Field Moue builds her Garner under ground,
For gather'd Grain the blind laborious Mole,
In winding Mazes works her hidden Hole.
In hollow Caverns Vermine make abode,
The hiing Serpent, and the welling Toad:
The Corn devouring Weezel here abides,
And the wie Ant her wintry Store provides.
Mark well the flowring Almonds in the Wood;
If od'rous Blooms the bearing Branches load,
The Glebe will anwer to the Sylvan Reign,
Great Heats will follow, and large Crops of Grain.
But if a Wood of Leaves o're-hade the Tree,
Such and o barren will thy Harvet be:
In vain the Hind hall vex the thrahing Floor,
For empty Chaff and Straw will be thy Store.
Some teep their Seed, and ome in Cauldrons boil
With vigorous Nitre, and with Lees of Oyl,
O're gentle Fires; th' exuberant Juice to drain,
And well the flatt'ring Husks with fruitful Grain.
Yet is not the Succes for Years aur'd,
Tho choen is the Seed, and fully cur'd;
Unles the Peaant, with his Annual Pain,
Renews his Choice, and culls the larget Grain.
Thus all below, whether by Nature's Cure,
Or Fates Decree, degen'rate till to wore.
So the Boats brawny Crew the Current tem,
And, low advancing, truggle with the Stream:
But if they lack their hands, or ceae to trive,
Then down the Flood with headlong hate they drive.
Nor mut the Ploughman les oberve the Skies,
When the Kidds, Dragon, and Arcturus rie,
Than Saylors homeward bent, who cut their Way
Thro' Helle's tormy Streights, and Oyter-breeding Sea.
But when Atrea's Ballance, hung on high,
Betwixt the Nights and Days divides the Sky,
Then Yoke your Oxen, ow your Winter Grain;
'Till cold December comes with driving Rain.
Lineeed and fruitful Poppy bury warm,
In a dry Seaon, and prevent the Storm.
Sow Beans and Clover in a rotten Soyl,
And Millet riing from your Annual Toyl;
When with his Golden Horns, in full Cariere,
The Bull beats down the Barriers of the Year;
And Arg • s and the Dog forake the Northern Sphere.
But if your Care to Wheat alone extend,
Let Maja with her Siters firt decend,
And the bright Gnoian Diadem downward bend:
Before you trut in Earth your future Hope;
Or ele expect a litles lazy Crop.
Some Swains have own before, but mot have found
A husky Harvet, from the grudging Ground.
Vile Vetches wou'd you ow, or Lentils lean,
The Growth of Egypt, or the Kidney-bean?
Begin when the low Waggoner decends,
Nor ceae your owing till Mid-winter ends:
For this, thro' twelve bright Signs Apollo guides
The Year, and Earth in ev'ral Climes divides.
Five Girdles bind the Skies, the torrid Zone
Glows with the paing and repaing Sun.
Far on the right and left, th' extreams of Heav'n,
To Frots and Snows, and bitter Blats are giv'n.
Betwixt the midt and thee, the Gods aign'd
Two habitable Seats for Humane Kind:
And cros their limits cut a loping way,
Which the twelve Signs in beauteous order way.
Two Poles turn round the Globe; one een to rie
O're Scythian Hills, and one in Lybian Skies.
The firt ublime in Heav'n, the lat is whirl'd
Below the Regions of the nether World.
Around our Pole the piry Dragon glides,
And like a winding Stream the Bears divides;
The les and greater, who by Fates Decree
Abhor to dive beneath the Southern Sea:
There, as they ay, perpetual Night is found
In ilence brooding on th' unhappy ground:
Or when Aurora leaves our Northern Sphere,
She lights the downward Heav'n, and ries there.
And when on us he breaths the living Light,
Red Veper kindles there the Tapers of the Night.
From hence uncertain Seaons we may know;
And when to reap the Grain, and when to ow:
Or when to fell the Furzes, when 'tis meet
To pread the flying Canvas for the Fleet.
Oberve what Stars arie or diappear;
And the four Quarters of the rolling Year.
But when cold Weather and continu'd Rain,
The lab'ring Husband in his Houe retrain:
Let him forecat his Work with timely care,
Which ele is huddl'd, when the Skies are fair:
Then let him mark the Sheep, or whet the hining Share.
Or hollow Trees for Boats, or number o're
His Sacks, or meaure his increaing Store:
Or harpen Stakes, or head the Forks, or twine
The Sallow Twigs to tye the tragling Vine:
Or wicker Baskets weave, or aire the Corn,
Or grinded Grain betwixt two Marbles turn.
No Laws, Divine or Human, can retrain
From neceary Works, the lab'ring Swain.
Ev'n Holy-days and Feats permiion yield,
The Meads to water, and to fence the Field,
To Fire the Brambles, nare the Birds, and teep
In wholom Water-falls the woolly Sheep.
And oft the drudging As is driv'n, with Toyl,
To neighb'ring Towns with Apples and with Oyl:
Returning late, and loaden home with Gain
Of barter'd Pitch, and Hand-mills for the Grain.
The lucky Days, in each revolving Moon,
For Labour chue: The Fifth be ure to hun;
That gave the Furies and pale Pluto Birth,
And arm'd, againt the Skies, the Sons of Earth.
With Mountains pil'd on Mountains, thrice they trove
To cale the teepy Battlements of Jove:
And thrice his Lightning and red Thunder play'd,
And their demolih'd Works in Ruin laid.
The Sev'nth is, next the Tenth, the bet to joyn
Young Oxen to the Yoke, and plant the Vine.
Then Weavers tretch your Stays upon the Weft:
The Ninth is good for Travel, bad for Theft.
Some Works in dead of Night are better done;
Or when the Morning Dew prevents the Sun.

figure.p: To Joseph Jekyll of the middle Temple Esq
figure.head: Geo: 1. l. 390

lg.l: Parch'd Meads and Stubble mow, by Phoebe's Light;
Which both require the Coolnes of the Night:
For Moiture then abounds, and Pearly Rains
Decend in Silence to refreh the Plains.
The Wife and Husband equally conpire,
To work by Night, and rake the Winter Fire:
He harpens Torches in the glim'ring Room,
She hoots the flying Shuttle through the Loom:
Or boils in Kettles Mut of Wine, and Skins
With Leaves, the Dregs that overflow the Brims.
And till the watchful Cock awakes the Day,
She ings to drive the tedious hours away.
But in warm Weather, when the Skies are clear,
By Daylight reap the Product of the Year:
And in the Sun your golden Grain diplay,
And thrah it out, and winnow it by Day.
Plough naked, Swain, and naked ow the Land,
For lazy Winter numbs the lab'ring Hand.
In Genial Winter, Swains enjoy their Store,
Forget their Hardhips, and recruit for more.
The Farmer to full Bowls invites his Friends,
And what he got with Pains, with Pleaure pends.
So Saylors, when ecap'd from tormy Seas,
Firt crown their Veels, then indulge their Eae.
Yet that's the proper Time to thrah the Wood
For Mat of Oak, your Father's homely Food.
To gather Laurel-berries, and the Spoil
Of bloody Myrtles, and to pres your Oyl.
For talking Cranes to et the guileful Snare,
T' incloe the Stags in Toyls, and hunt the Hare.
With Balearick Slings, or Gnoian Bow,
To perecute from far the flying Doe.
Then, when the Fleecy Skies new cloath the Wood,
And cakes of rutling Ice come rolling down the Flood.
Now ing we tormy Stars, when Autumn weighs
The Year, and adds to Nights, and hortens Days;
And Suns declining hine with feeble Rays:
What Cares mut then attend the toiling Swain;
Or when the low'ring Spring, with lavih Rain,
Beats down the lender Stem and bearded Grain:
While yet the Head is green, or lightly well'd
With Milky-moiture, over-looks the Field.
Ev'n when the Farmer, now ecure of Fear,
Sends in the Swains to poil the finih'd Year:
Ev'n while the Reaper fills his greedy hands,
And binds the golden Sheafs in brittle bands:
Oft have I een a udden Storm arie,
From all the warring Winds that weep the Skies:
The heavy Harvet from the Root is torn,
And whirl'd aloft the lighter Stubble born;
With uch a force the flying rack is driv'n;
And uch a Winter wears the face of Heav'n:
And oft whole heets decend of lucy Rain,
Suck'd by the pongy Clouds from off the Main:
The lofty Skies at once come pouring down,
The promis'd Crop and golden Labours drown.
The Dykes are fill'd, and with a roaring ound
The riing Rivers float the nether ground;
And Rocks the bellowing Voice of boiling Seas rebound.
The Father of the Gods his Glory hrowds,
Involv'd in Tempets, and a Night of Clouds.
And from the middle Darknes flahing out,
By fits he deals his fiery Bolts about.
Earth feels the Motions of her angry God,
Her Entrails tremble, and her Mountains nod;
And flying Beats in Forets eek abode:
Deep horrour eizes ev'ry Humane Breat,
Their Pride is humbled, and their Fear confes'd:

figure.p: To Thomas Vernon of Hanbury in Worcester - Shire Esq
figure.head: Geo: 1 L 475

lg.l: While he from high his rowling Thunder throws,
And fires the Mountains with repeated blows:
The Rocks are from their old Foundations rent;
The Winds redouble, and the Rains augment:
The Waves on heaps are dah'd againt the Shoar,
And now the Woods, and now the Billows roar.
In fear of this, oberve the tarry Signs,
Where Saturn houes, and where Hermes joins.
But firt to Heav'n thy due Devotions pay,
And Annual Gifts on Ceres Altars lay.
When Winter's rage abates, when chearful Hours
Awake the Spring, and Spring awakes the Flow'rs,
On the green Turf thy careles Limbs diplay,
And celebrate the mighty Mother's day.
For then the Hills with pleaing Shades are crown'd,
And Sleeps are weeter on the ilken Ground:
With milder Beams the Sun ecurely hines;
Fat are the Lambs, and lucious are the Wines.
Let ev'ry Swain adore her Pow'r Divine,
And Milk and Honey mix with parkling Wine:
Let all the Quire of Clowns attend the Show,
In long Proceion, houting as they go;
Invoking her to bles their yearly Stores,
Inviting Plenty to their crowded Floors.
Thus in the Spring, and thus in Summer's Heat,
Before the Sickles touch the ripening Wheat,
On Ceres call; and let the lab'ring Hind
With Oaken Wreaths his hollow Temples bind:
On Ceres let him call, and Ceres praie,
With uncouth Dances, and with Country Lays.
And that by certain igns we may preage
Of Heats and Rains, and Wind's impetuous rage,
The Sov'reign of the Heav'ns has et on high
The Moon, to mark the Changes of the Skye:
When Southern blats hou'd ceae, and when the Swain
Shou'd near their Folds his feeding Flocks retrain.
For e're the riing Winds begin to roar,
The working Seas advance to wah the Shoar:
Soft whipers run along the leavy Woods,
And Mountains whitle to the murm'ring Floods:
Ev'n then the doubtful Billows carce abtain
From the tos'd Veel on the troubled Main:
When crying Cormorants forake the Sea,
And tretching to the Covert wing their way:
When portful Coots run skimming o're the Strand;
When watchful Herons leave their watry Stand,
And mounting upward, with erected flight,
Gain on the Skyes, and oar above the ight.
And oft before tempet'our Winds arie,
The eeming Stars fall headlong from the Skies;
And, hooting through the darknes, guild the Night
With weeping Glories, and long trails of Light:
And Chaff with eddy Winds is whirl'd around,
And dancing Leaves are lifted from the Ground;
And floating Feathers on the Waters play.
But when the winged Thunder takes his way
From the cold North, and Eat and Wet ingage,
And at their Frontiers meet with equal rage,
The Clouds are cruh'd, a glut of gather'd Rain
The hollow Ditches fills, and floats the Plain,
And Sailors furl their dropping Sheets amain.
Wet weather eldom hurts the mot unwie,
So plain the Signs, uch Prophets are the Skies:
The wary Crane foreees it firt, and ails
Above the Storm, and leaves the lowly Vales:
The Cow looks up, and from afar can find
The change of Heav'n, and nuffs it in the Wind.
The Swallow skims the River's watry Face,
The Frogs renew the Croaks of their loquacious Race.
The careful Ant her ecret Cell forakes,
And drags her Egs along the narrow Tracks.
At either Horn the Rainbow drinks the Flood,
Huge Flocks of riing Rooks orake their Food,
And, crying, eek the Shelter of the Wood.
Beides, the ev'ral orts of watry Fowls,
That wim the Seas, or haunt the tanding Pools:
The Swans that ail along the Silver Flood,
And dive with tretching Necks to earch their Food.
Then lave their Backs with prinkling Dews in vain,
And tem tke Stream to meet the promis'd Rain.
The Crow with clam'rous Cries the Show'r demands,
And ingle talks along the Deart Sands.
The nightly Virgin, while her Wheel he plies,
Foreees the Storm impending in the Skies,
When parkling Lamps their putt'ring Light advance,
And in the Sockets Oyly Bubbles dance.
Then after Show'rs, 'tis eaie to decry
Returning Suns, and a erener Sky:
The Stars hine marter, and the Moon adorns,
As with unborrow'd Beams, her harpen'd Horns.
The filmy Goamer now flitts no more,
Nor Halcyons bask on the hort Sunny Shoar:
Their Litter is not tos'd by Sows unclean,
But a blue droughty Mit decends upon the Plain.
And Owls, that mark the etting Sun, declare
A Star-light Evening, and a Morning fair.
Tow'ring aloft, avenging Nius flies,
While dar'd below the guilty Scylla lies.
Where-ever frighted Scylla flies away,
Swift Nius follows, and purues his Prey.
Where injur'd Nius takes his Airy Coure,
Thence trembling Scylla flies and huns his Force.
This punihment purues th' unhappy Maid,
And thus the purple Hair is dearly paid.
Then, thrice the Ravens rend the liquid Air,
And croaking Notes proclaim the ettled fair.
Then, round their Airy Palaces they fly,
To greet the Sun; and eis'd with ecret Joy,
When Storms are over-blown, with Food repair
To their foraken Nets, and callow Care.
Not that I think their Breats with Heav'nly Souls
Inpir'd, as Man, who Detiny controls.
But with the changeful Temper of the Skies,
As Rams condene, and Sun-hine rarifies;
So turn the Species in their alter'd Minds,
Compos'd by Calms, and dioompos'd by Winds.
From hence proceeds the Birds harmonious Voice:
From hence the Cows exult, and frisking Lambs rejoice.
Oberve the daily Circle of the Sun,
And the hort Year of each revolving Moon:
By them thou halt foreee the following day;
Nor hall a tarry Night thy Hopes betray.
When firt the Moon appears, if then he hrouds
Her ilver Crecent, tip'd with able Clouds;
Conclude he bodes a Tempet on the Main,
And brews for Fields impetuous Floods of Rain.
Or if her Face with fiery Fluhing glow,
Expect the ratling Winds aloft to blow.
But four Nights old, (for that's the uret Sign,)
With harpen'd Horns if glorious then he hine:
Next Day, nor only that, but all the Moon,
Till her revolving Race be wholly run;
Are void of Tempets, both by Land and Sea,
And Saylors in the Port their promis'd Vow hall pay.
Above the ret, the Sun, who never lies;
Foretels the change of Weather in the Skies:
For if he rie, unwilling to his Race,
Clouds on his Brows, and Spots upon his Face;
Or if thro' Mits he hoots his ullen Beams,
Frugal of Light, in looe and tragling Streams:
Supect a driling Day, with Southern Rain,
Fatal to Fruits, and Flocks, and promis'd Grain.
Or if Aurora, with half open'd Eyes,
And a pale ickly Cheek, alute the Skies;
How hall the Vine, with tender Leaves, defend
Her teeming Cluters, when the Storms decend?
When ridgy Roofs and Tiles can carce avail,
To barr the Ruin of the ratling Hail.
But more than all, the etting Sun urvey,
When down the Steep of Heav'n he drives the Day.
For oft we find him finihing his Race,
With various Colours erring on his Face;
If fiery red his glowing Globe decends,
High Winds and furious Tempets he portends.
But if his Cheeks are woln with livid blue,
He bodes wet Weather by his watry Hue.
If dusky Spots are vary'd on his Brow,
And, treak'd with red, a troubl'd Colour how;
That ullen Mixture hall at once declare
Winds, Rain, and Storms, and Elemental War:
What dep'rate Madman then wou'd venture o're
The Frith, or haul his Cables from the Shoar?
But if with Purple Rays he brings the Light,
And a pure Heav'n reigns to quiet Night:
No riing Winds, or falling Storms, are nigh:
But Northern Breezes through the Forret fly:
And drive the rack, and purge the ruffl'd Sky.
Th' unerring Sun by certain Signs declares,
What the late Ev'n, or early Morn prepares:
And when the South projects a tormy Day,
