And when the clearing North will puff the Clouds away.
The Sun reveals the Secrets of the Sky;
And who dares give the Source of Light the Lye?
The change of Empires often he declares,
Fierce Tumults, hidden Treaons, open Wars.
He firt the Fate of Caear did foretel,
And pity'd Rome, when Rome in Caear fell.
In Iron Clouds conceal'd the Publick Light:
And Impious Mortals fear'd Eternal Night.
Nor was the Fact foretold by him alone:
Nature her elf tood forth, and econded the Sun.
Earth, Air, and Seas, with Prodigies were ign'd,
And Birds obcene, and howling Dogs divin'd.
What Rocks did Aetna's bellowing Mouth expire
From her torn Entrails! and what Floods of Fire!
What Clanks were heard, in German Skies afar,
Of Arms and Armies, ruhing to the War!
Dire Earthquakes rent the olid Alps below,
And from their Summets hook th' Eternal Snow.
Pale Specters in the cloe of Night were een;
And Voices heard of more than Mortal Men.
In ilent Groves, dumb Sheep and Oxen poke;
And Streams ran backward, and their Beds forook:
The yawning Earth diclos'd th' Abys of Hell:
The weeping Statues did the Wars foretel;
And Holy Sweat from Brazen Idols fell.
Then riing in his Might, the King of Floods,
Ruht thro' the Forrets, tore the lofty Woods;
And rolling onward, with a weepy Sway,
Bore Houes, Herds, and lab'ring Hinds away.

figure.p: To William Dobyns of Lincolns Inn Esq.
figure.head: Geo 1: 625.

lg.l: Blood prang from Wells, Wolfs howl'd in Towns by Night,
And boding Victims did the Priets affright.
Such Peals of Thunder never pour'd from high;
Nor Light'ning flah'd from o erene a Sky.
Red Meteors ran along th' Etherial Space;
Stars diappear'd, and Comets took their place.
For this, th' Emathian Plains once more were trow'd
With Roman Bodies, and jut Heav'n thought good
To fatten twice thoe Fields with Roman Blood.
Then, after length of Time, the lab'ring Swains,
Who turn the Turfs of thoe unhappy Plains,
Shall ruty Piles from the plough'd Furrows take,
And over empty Helmets pas the Rake.
Amaz'd at Antick Titles on the Stones,
And mighty Relicks of Gygantick Bones.
Ye home-born Deities, of Mortal Birth!
Thou Father Romulus, and Mother Earth,
Goddes unmov'd! whoe Guardian Arms extend
O're Thucan Tiber's Coure, and Roman Tow'rs defend;
With youthful Caear your joint Pow'rs ingage,
Nor hinder him to ave the inking Age.
O! let the Blood, already pilt, atone
For the pat Crimes of curt Laomedon!
Heav'n wants thee there, and long the Gods, we know,
Have grudg'd thee, Caear, to the World below.
Where Fraud and Rapine, Right and Wrong confound;
Where impious Arms from ev'ry part reound,
And montrous Crimes in ev'ry Shape are crown'd.
The peaceful Peaant to the Wars is pret;
The Fields lye fallow in inglorious Ret.
The Plain no Pature to the Flock affords,
The crooked Scythes are treightned into Swords:
And there Euphrates her oft Off-pring Arms,
And here the Rhine rebellows with Alarms:
The neighb'ring Cities range on ev'ral ides,
Perfidious Mars long plighted Leagues divides,
And o're the wated World in Triumph rides.
So four fierce Courers tarting to the Race,
Scow'r thro' the Plain, and lengthen ev'ry Pace:
Nor Reigns, nor Curbs, nor threat'ning Cries they fear,
But force along the trembling Charioteer.

div.head: The Second Book of the Georgics.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Subject of the following Book is Planting. In handling of which Argument, the Poet hews all the different Methods of raiing Trees: Decribes their Variety; and gives Rules for the management of each in particular. He then points out the Soils in which the everal Plants thrive bet: And thence takes occaion to run out into the Praies of Italy. After which he gives ome Directions for dicovering the Nature of every Soil; precribes Rules for the Dreing of Vines, Olives, &c. And concludes the Georgic with a Panegyric on a Country Life.

figure.p: To Sr: William Bowyer Baronet of Denham Court in the County of Bucks.
figure.head: Geor: 2. L. 1.

lg.l: THus far of Tillage, and of Heav'nly Signs;
Now ing my Mue the growth of gen'rous Vines:
The hady Groves, the Woodland Progeny,
And the low Product of Minerva's Tree.
Great Father Bacchus! to my Song repair;
For clutring Grapes are thy peculiar Care:
For thee large Bunches load the bending Vine,
And the lat Bleings of the Year are thine.
To thee his Joys the jolly Autumn owes,
When the fermenting Juice the Vat o'reflows.
Come trip with me, my God, come drench all o're
Thy Limbs in Mut of Wine, and drink at ev'ry Pore.
Some Trees their birth to bounteous Nature owe:
For ome without the pains of Planting grow.
With Oiers thus the Banks of Brooks abound,
Sprung from the watry Genius of the Ground:
From the ame Principles grey Willows come;
Herculean Poplar, and the tender Broom.
But ome from Seeds inclos'd in Earth arie:
For thus the matful Chenut mates the Skies.
Hence rie the branching Beech and vocal Oke,
Where Jove of old Oraculouly poke.
Some from the Root a riing Wood dicloe;
Thus Elms, and thus the alvage Cherry grows.
Thus the green Bays, that binds the Poet's Brows,
Shoots and is helter'd by the Mother's Boughs.
Thee ways of Planting, Nature did ordain,
For Trees and Shrubs, and all the Sylvan Reign.
Others there are, by late Experience found:
Some cut the Shoots, and plant in furrow'd ground:
Some cover rooted Stalks in deeper Mold:
Some cloven Stakes, and (wond'rous to behold,)
Their harpen'd ends in Earth their footing place,
And the dry Poles produce a living Race.
Some bowe their Vines, which bury'd in the Plain,
Their tops in ditant Arches rie again.
Others no Root require, the Lab'rer cuts
Young Slips, and in the Soil ecurely puts.
Ev'n Stumps of Olives, bar'd of Leaves, and dead,
Revive, and oft redeem their wither'd head.
'Tis uual now, an Inmate Graff to ee,
With Inolence invade a Foreign Tree:
Thus Pears and Quinces from the Crabtree come;
And thus the ruddy Cornel bears the Plum.
Then let the Learned Gard'ner mark with care
The Kinds of Stocks, and what thoe Kinds will bear:
Explore the Nature of each ev'ral Tree;
And known, improve with artful Indutry:
And let no pot of idle Earth be found,
But cultivate the Genius of the Ground.
For open Imarus will Bacchus pleae;
Taburnus loves the hade of Olive Trees.
The Virtues of the ev'ral Soils I ing,
Mecaenas, now thy needful Succour bring!
O thou! the better part of my Renown,
Inpire thy Poet, and thy Poem crown:
Embarque with me, while I new Tracts explore,
With flying ails and breezes from the hore:
Not that my ong, in uch a canty pace,
So large a Subject fully can embrace:
Not tho I were upply'd with Iron Lungs,
A hundred Mouths, fill'd with as many Tongues:
But teer my Veel with a teady hand,
And coat along the Shore in ight of Land.
Nor will I tire thy Patience with a train
Of Preface, or what ancient Poets feign.
The Trees, which of themelves advance in Air,
Are barren kinds, but trongly built and fair:
Becaue the vigour of the Native Earth
Maintains the Plant, and makes a Manly Birth.
Yet thee, receiving Graffs of other Kind,
Or thence tranplanted, change their alvage Mind:
Their Wildnes loe, and quitting Nature's part,
Obey the Rules and Dicipline of Art.
The ame do Trees, that, prung from barren Roots
In open fields, tranplanted bear their Fruits.
For where they grow the Native Energy
Turns all into the Subtance of the Tree,
Starves and detroys the Fruit, is only made
For brawny bulk, and for a barren hade.
The Plant that hoots from Seed, a ullen Tree
At leiure grows, for late Poterity;
The gen'rous flavour lot, the Fruits decay,
And alvage Grapes are made the Birds ignoble prey.
Much labour is requir'd in Trees, to tame
Their wild diorder, and in ranks reclaim.
Well mut the ground be dig'd, and better dres'd,
New Soil to make, and meliorate the ret.
Old Stakes of Olive Trees in Plants revive;
By the ame Methods Paphian Myrtles live:
But nobler Vines by Propagation thrive.
From Roots hard Hazles, and from Cyens rie
Tall Ah, and taller Oak that mates the Skies:
Palm, Poplar, Firr, decending from the Steep
Of Hills, to try the dangers of the Deep.
The thin-leav'd Arbute Hazle, graffs receives,
And Planes huge Apples bear, that bore but Leaves.
Thus Matful Beech the britly Chenut bears,
And the wild Ah is white with blooming Pears.
And greedy Swine from grafted Elms are fed,
With falling Acorns, that on Oaks are bred.
But various are the ways to change the tate
Of Plants, to Bud, to Graff, t' Inoculate.
For where the tender Rinds of Trees dicloe
Their hooting Gems, a welling Knot there grows;
Jut in that pace a narrow Slit we make,
Then other Buds from bearing Trees we take:
Inerted thus, the wounded Rind we cloe,
In whoe moit Womb th' admitted Infant grows.
But when the moother Bole from Knots is free,
We make a deep Inciion in the Tree;
And in the olid Wood the Slip incloe,
The bat'ning Batard hoots again and grows:
And in hort pace the laden Boughs arie,
With happy Fruit advancing to the Skies.
The Mother Plant admires the Leaves unknown,
Of Alien Trees, and Apples not her own.
Of vegetable Woods are various Kinds,
And the ame Species are of ev'ral Minds.
Lotes, Willows, Elms, have diff'rent Forms allow'd,
So fun'ral Cypres riing like a Shrowd.

figure.p: To Gilbert Dolbin of Thindon in Northampton-Shire Esq
figure.head: Geo: 2 L 145.

lg.l: Fat Olive Trees of undry Sorts appear:
Of undry Shapes their unctuous Berries bear.
Radij long Olives, Orchit's round produce,
And bitter Pauia, pounded for the Juice.
Alcinous Orchard various Apples bears:
Unlike are Bergamotes and pounder Pears.
Nor our Italian Vines produce the Shape,
Or Tat, or Flavour of the Lesbian Grape.
The Thaian Vines in richer Soils abound,
The Mareotique grow in barren Ground.
The Pythian Grape we dry: Lagaean Juice,
Will tamm'ring Tongues, and tagg'ring Feet produce.
Rathe ripe are ome, and ome of later kind,
Of Golden ome, and ome of Purple Rind.
How hall I praie the Raethean Grape divine,
Which yet contends not with Falernian Wine!
Th' Aminean many a Conulhip urvives,
And longer than the Lydian Vintage lives?
Or high Phanaeus King of Chian growth:
But for large quantities, and lating both,
The les Argitis bears the Prize away.
The Rhodian, acred to the Solemn Day,
In econd Services is pour'd to Jove;
And bet accepted by the Gods above.
Nor mut Bumatus his old Honours loe,
In length and largenes like the Dugs of Cows.
I pas the ret, whoe ev'ry Race and Name,
And Kinds, are les material to my Theme.
Which who wou'd learn, as oon may tell the Sands,
Driv'n by the Wetern Wind on Lybian Lands.
Or number, when the blut'ring Eurus roars,
The Billows beating on Ionian Shoars.
Nor ev'ry Plant on ev'ry Soil will grow;
The Sallow loves the watry Ground, and low.
The Marhes, Alders; Nature eems t'ordain
The rocky Cliff for the wild Ahe's reign:
The baleful Yeugh to Northern Blats aigns;
To Shores the Myrtles, and to Mounts the Vines.
Regard th' extremet cultivated Coat,
From hot Arabia to the Scythian Frot:
All ort of Trees their ev'ral Countries know;
Black Ebon only will in India grow:
And od'rous Frankincene on the Sabaean Bough.
Balm lowly trickles through the bleeding Veins
Of happy Shrubs, in Idumaean Plains.
The green Egyptian Thorn, for Med'cine good;
With Ethiops hoary Trees and woolly Wood,
Let others tell: and how the Seres pin
Their fleecy Forets in a lender Twine.
With mighty Trunks of Trees on Indian hoars,
Whoe height above the feather'd Arrow oars,
Shot from the toughet Bow; and by the Brawn
Of expert Archers, with vat Vigour drawn.
Sharp tated Citrons Median Climes produce:
Bitter the Rind, but gen'rous is the Juice:
A cordial Fruit, a preent Antidote
Againt the direful Stepdam's deadly Draught:
Who mixing wicked Weeds with Words impure,
The Fate of envy'd Orphans wou'd procure.
Large is the Plant, and like a Laurel grows,
And did it not a diff'rent Scent dicloe,
A Laurel were: the fragrant Flow'rs contemn
The tormy Winds, tenacious of their Stem.
With this the Medes, to lab'ring Age, bequeath
New Lungs, and cure the ournes of the Breath.
But neither Median Woods, (a plenteous Land,)
Fair Ganges, Hermus rolling Golden Sand,
Nor Bactria, nor the richer Indian Fields,
Nor all the Gummy Stores Arabia yields;
Nor any foreign Earth of greater Name,
Can with weet Italy contend in Fame.
No Bulls, whoe Notrils breath a living Flame,
Have turn'd our Turf, no Teeth of Serpents here
Were own, an armed Hot, and Iron Crop to bear.
But fruitful Vines, and the fat Olives fraight,
And Harvets heavy with their fruitful weight,
Adorn our Fields; and on the chearful Green,
The grazing Flocks and lowing Herds are een.
The Warrior Hore, here bred, is taught to train,
There flows Clitumnus thro' the flow'ry Plain;
Whoe Waves, for Triumphs after prop'rous Wars,
The Victim Ox, and nowy Sheep prepares.
Perpetual Spring our happy Climate ees,
Twice breed the Cattle, and twice bear the Trees;
And Summer Suns recede by low degrees.
Our Land is from the Rage of Tygers freed,
Nor nourihes the Lyon's angry Seed;
Nor pois'nous Aconite is here produc'd,
Or grows unknown, or is, when known, refus'd.
Nor in o vat a length our Serpents glide,
Or rais'd on uch a piry Volume ride.
Next add our Cities of Illutrious Name,
Their cotly Labour and tupend'ous Frame:
Our Forts on teepy Hills, that far below
See wanton Streams, in winding Valleys flow.
Our twofold Seas, that wahing either ide,
A rich Recruit of Foreign Stores provide.
Our pacious Lakes; thee, Larius, firt; and next
Benacus, with tempet'ous Billows vext.
Or hall I praie thy Ports, or mention make
Of the vat Mound, that binds the Lucrine Lake.
Or the didainful Sea, that, hut from thence,
Roars round the Structure, and invades the Fence.
There, where ecure the Julian Waters glide,
Or where Avernus Jaws admit the Tyrrhene Tide.
Our Quarries deep in Earth, were fam'd of old,
For Veins of Silver, and for Ore of Gold.
Th' Inhabitants themelves, their Country grace;
Hence roe the Marian and Sabellian Race:
Strong limb'd and tout, and to the Wars inclin'd,
And hard Ligurians, a laborious Kind.
And Volcians arm'd with Iron-headed Darts.
Beides an Off-pring of undaunted Hearts,
The Decij, Marij, great Camillus came
From hence, and greater Scipio's double Name:
And mighty Caear, whoe victorious Arms,
To farthet Aia, carry fierce Alarms:
Avert unwarlike Indians from his Rome;
Triumph abroad, ecure our Peace at home.
Hail, weet Saturnian Soil! of fruitful Grain
Great Parent, greater of Illutrious Men.
For thee my tuneful Accents will I raie,
And treat of Arts diclos'd in Ancient Days:
Once more unlock for thee the acred Spring,
And old Acraean Vere in Roman Cities ing.
The Nature of their ev'ral Soils now ee,
Their Strength, their Colour, their Fertility:
And firt for Heath, and barren hilly Ground,
Where meagre Clay and flinty Stones abound;
Where the poor Soil all Succour eems to want,
Yet this uffices the Palladian Plant.
Undoubted Signs of uch a Soil are found,
For here wild Olive-hoots o'repread the ground,
And heaps of Berries trew the Fields around.
But where the Soil, with fat'ning Moiture fill'd,
Is cloath'd with Gras, and fruitful to be till'd:
Such as in chearful Vales we view from high;
Which dripping Rocks with rowling Streams upply,
And feed with Ooze; where riing Hillocks run
In length, and open to the Southern Sun;
Where Fern ucceeds, ungrateful to the Plough,
That gentle ground to gen'rous Grapes allow.
Strong Stocks of Vines it will in time produce,
And overflow the Vats with friendly Juice.
Such as our Priets in golden Goblets pour
To Gods, the Givers of the chearful hour.
Then when the bloated Thucan blows his Horn,
And reeking Entrails are in Chargers born.
If Herds or fleecy Flocks be more thy Care,
Or Goats that graze the Field, and burn it bare:
Then eek Tarentum's Lawns, and farthet Coat,
Or uch a Field as haples Mantua lot:
Where Silver Swans ail down the wat'ry Rode,
And graze the floating Herbage of the Flood.
There Crytal Streams perpetual tenour keep,
Nor Food nor Springs are wanting to thy Sheep.
For what the Day devours, the nightly Dew
Shall to the Morn in Perly Drops renew.
Fat crumbling Earth is fitter for the Plough,
Putrid and looe above, and black below:
For Ploughing is an imitative Toil,
Reembling Nature in an eaie Soil.
No Land for Seed like this, no Fields afford
So large an Income to the Village Lord:
No toiling Teams from Harvet-labour come
So late at Night, o heavy laden home.
The like of Foret Land is undertood,
From whence the pleenful Ploughman grubs the Wood,
Which had for length of Ages idle tood.
Then Birds forake the Ruines of their Seat,
And flying from their Nets their Callow Young forget.
The coure lean Gravel, on the Mountain ides,
Scarce dewy Bev'rage for the Bees provides:
Nor Chalk nor crumbling Stones, the food of Snakes,
That work in hollow Earth their winding Tracts.
The Soil exhaling Clouds of ubtile Dews,
Imbibing moiture which with eae he pews;
Which ruts not Iron, and whoe Mold is clean,
Well cloath'd with chearful Gras, and ever green,
Is good for Olives and apiring Vines;
Embracing Husband Elms in am'rous twines,
Is fit for feeding Cattle, fit to owe,
And equal to the Pature and the Plough.
Such is the Soil of fat Campanian Fields,
Such large increae Veuvian Nola yields:
And uch a Country cou'd Acerra boat,
Till Clanius overflow'd th' unhappy Coat.
I teach thee next the diff'ring Soils to know;
The light for Vines, the heavyer for the Plough.
Chue firt a place for uch a purpoe fit,
There dig the olid Earth, and ink a Pit:
Next fill the hole with its own Earth agen,
And trample with thy Feet, and tread it in:
Then if it rie not to the former height
Of uperfice, conclude that Soil is light;
A proper Ground for Paturage and Vines.
But if the ullen Earth, o pres'd, repines
Within its native Manion to retire,
And tays without, a heap of heavy Mire;

figure.p: To George London of his maties: Royall Garden in St James^'s Park Gent.
figure.head: Geo 2 L <…>

lg.l: 'Tis good for Arable, a Glebe that asks
Tough Teams of Oxen, and laborious Tasks.
Salt Earth and bitter are not fit to ow,
Nor will be tam'd or mended with the Plough.
Sweet Grapes degen'rate there, and Fruits declin'd
From their firt flav'rous Tate, renounce their Kind.
This Truth by ure Experiment is try'd;
For firt an Ofier Colendar provide
Of Twigs thick wrought, (uch toiling Peaants twine,
When thro' treight Paages they trein their Wine;)
In this cloe Veel place that Earth accurs'd,
But fill'd brimful with wholom Water firt;
Then run it through, the Drops will rope around,
And by the bitter Tate dicloe the Ground.
The fatter Earth by handling we may find,
With Eae ditinguih'd from the meagre Kind:
Poor Soil will crumble into Dut, the Rich
will to the Fingers cleave like clammy Pitch:
Moit Earth produces Corn and Gras, but both
Too rank and too luxuriant in their Growth.
Let not my Land o large a Promie boat,
Let the lank Ears in length of Stem be lot.
The heavier Earth is by her Weight betray'd,
The lighter in the poiing Hand is weigh'd:
'Tis eay to ditinguih by the Sight
The Colour of the Soil, and black from white.
But the cold Ground is difficult to know,
Yet this the Plants that proper there, will how;
Black Ivy, Pitch Trees, and the baleful Yeugh.
Thee Rules conider'd well, with early Care,
The Vineyard detin'd for thy Vines prepare:
But, long before the Planting, dig the Ground,
With Furrows deep that cat a riing Mound:
The Clods, expos'd to Winter Winds, will bake:
For putrid Earth will bet in Vineyards take,
And hoary Frots, after the painful Toyl
Of delving Hinds, will rot the Mellow Soil.
Some Peaants, not t' omit the nicet Care,
Of the ame Soil their Nurery prepare,
With that of their Plantation; let the Tree
Tranlated, hould not with the Soil agree.
Beide, to plant it as it was, they mark
The Heav'ns four Quarters on the tender Bark;
And to the North or South retore the Side,
Which at their Birth did Heat or Cold abide.
So trong is Cutom; uch Effects can Ue
In tender Souls of pliant Plants produce.
Chue next a Province, for thy Vineyards Reign,
On Hills above, or in the lowly Plain:
If fertile Fields or Valleys be thy Choice,
Plant thick, for bounteous Bacchus will rejoice
In cloe Plantations there: But if the Vine
On riing Ground be plac'd, or Hills upine,
Extend thy looe Battalions largely wide,
Opening thy Ranks and Files on either Side:
But marhall'd all in order as they Stand,
And let no Souldier traggle from his Band.
As Legions in the Field their Front diplay,
To try the Fortune of ome doubtful Day,
And move to meet their Foes with ober Pace,
Strict to their Figure, tho' in wider Space;
Before the Battel joins, while from afar
The Field yet glitters with the Pomp of War,
And equal Mars, like an impartial Lord,
Leaves all to Fortune, and the dint of Sword;
So let thy Vines in Intervals be et,
But not their Rural Dicipline forget:
Indulge their Width, and add a roomy Space,
That their extreamet Lines may carce embrace:
Nor this alone t'indulge a vain Delight,
And make a pleaing Propect for the Sight:
But, for the Ground it elf this only Way,
Can equal Vigour to the Plants convey;
Which crowded, want the room, their Branches to diplay.
How deep they mut be planted, woud't thou know?
In hallow Furrows Vines ecurely grow.
Not o the ret of Plants; for Joves own Tree,
That holds the Woods in awful Sov'raignty,
Requires a depth of Lodging in the Ground;
And, next the lower Skies, a Bed profound:
High as his topmot Boughs to Heav'n acend,
So low his Roots to Hell's Dominion tend.
Therefore, nor Winds, nor Winters Rage o'rethrows
His bulky Body, but unmov'd he grows.
For length of Ages lats his happy Reign,
And Lives of Mortal Man contend in vain.
Full in the midt of his own Strength he tands,
Stretching his brawny Arms, and leafy Hands;
His Shade protects the Plains, his Head the Hills commands
The hurtful Hazle in thy Vineyard hun;
Nor plant it to receive the etting Sun:
Nor break the topmot Branches from the Tree;
Nor prune, with blunted Knife, the Progeny.
Root up wild Olives from thy labour'd Lands:
For parkling Fire, from Hinds unwary Hands,
Is often catter'd o're their unctuous rinds,
And after pread abroad by raging Winds.
For firt the mouldring Flame the Trunk receives,
Acending thence, it crackles in the Leaves:
At length victorious to the Top apires,
Involving all the Wood with moky Fires,
But mot, when driv'n by Winds, the flaming Storm,
Of the long Files detroys the beauteous Form.
In Ahes then th' unhappy Vineyard lies,
Nor will the blated Plants from Ruin rie:
Nor will the wither'd Stock be green again,
But the wild Olive hoots, and hades th' ungrateful Plain.
Be not educ'd with Widom's empty Shows,
To tir the peaceful Ground when Boreas blows.
When Winter Frots contrain the Field with Cold,
The fainty Root can take no teady hold.
But when the Golden Spring reveals the Year,
And the white Bird returns, whom Serpents fear:
That Seaon deem the bet to plant thy Vines.
Next that, is when Autumnal Warmth declines:
E're Heat is quite decay'd, or Cold begun,
Or Capricorn admits the Winter Sun.
The Spring adorns the Woods, renews the Leaves;
The Womb of Earth the genial Seed receives.
For then Almighty Jove decends, and pours
Into his buxom Bride his fruitful Show'rs.
And mixing his large Limbs with hers, he feeds
Her Births with kindly Juice, and foters teeming Seeds.
Then joyous Birds frequent the lonely Grove,
And Beats, by Nature tung, renew their Love.
Then Fields the Blades of bury'd Corn dicloe,
And while the balmy Wetern Spirit blows,
Earth to the Breath her Boom dares expoe.
With kindly Moiture then the Plants abound,
The Gras ecurely prings above the Ground;
The tender Twig hoots upward to the Skies,
And on the Faith of the new Sun relies.
The werving Vines on the tall Elms prevail,
Unhurt by Southern Show'rs or Northern Hail.
They pread their Gems the genial Warmth to hare:
And boldly trut their Buds in open Air.
In this oft Seaon (o weet Poets ing)
The World was hatch'd by Heav'ns Imperial King:
In prime of all the Year, and Holydays of Spring.
Earth knew no Seaon then, but Spring alone:
On the moit Ground the Sun erenely hone:
Then Winter Winds their blutring Rage forbear,
And in a ilent Pomp proceeds the mighty Year.
Sheep oon were ent to people flow'ry Fields,
And alvage Beats were banih'd into Wilds.
Then Heav'n was lighted up with Stars; and Man,
A hard relentles Race, from Stones began.
Nor cou'd the tender, new Creation, bear
Th' exceive Heats or Coldnes of the Year:
But chill'd by Winter, or by Summer fir'd,
The middle Temper of the Spring requir'd.
When Infant Nature was with Quiet crown'd,
And Heav'ns Indulgence brooded on the Ground.
For what remains, in depth of Earth ecure
Thy cover'd Plants, and dung with hot Manure;
And Shells and Gravel in the Ground incloe;
For thro' their hollow Chinks the Water flows:
Which, thus imbib'd, returns in mity Dews,
And teeming up, the riing Plant renews.
Some Husbandmen, of late, have found the Way,
A hilly Heap of Stones above to lay,
And pres the Plants with Sherds of Potters Clay.
This Fence againt immod'rate Rain they found:
Or when the Dog-tar cleaves the thirty Ground.
Be mindful when thou hat intomb'd the Shoot,
With Store of Earth around to feed the Root;
With Iron Teeth of Rakes and Prongs, to move
The cruted Earth, and looen it above.
Then exercie thy trugling Steers to plough
Betwixt thy Vines, and teach thy feeble Row
To mount on Reeds, and Wands, and, upward led,
On Ahen Poles to raie their forky Head.
On thee new Crutches let them learn to walk,
Till werving upwards, with a tronger Stalk,
They brave the Winds, and, clinging to their Gu
On tops of Elms at length triumphant ride.
But in their tender Nonage, while they pread
Their Springing Leafs, and lift their Infant Head,
And upward while they hoot in open Air,
Indulge their Child-hood, and the Nureling pare.
Nor exercie thy Rage on new-born Life,
But let thy Hand upply the Pruning-knife;
And crop luxuriant Straglers, nor be loath
To trip the Branches of their leafy Growth:
But when the rooted Vines, with teady Hold,
Can clap their Elms, then Husbandman be bold
To lop the diobedient Boughs, that tray'd
Beyond their Ranks: let crooked Steel invade
The lawles Troops, which Dicipline diclaim,
And their uperfluous Growth with Rigour tame.
Next, fenc'd with Hedges and deep Ditches round,
Exclude th' incroaching Cattle from thy Ground,
While yet the tender Gems but jut appear,
Unable to utain th' uncertain Year;
Whoe Leaves are not alone foul Winter's Prey,
But oft by Summer Suns are corch'd away;
And wore than both, become th' unworthy Browze
Of Buffal'os, alt Goats, and hungry Cows.
For not December's Frot that burns the Boughs,
Nor Dog-days parching Heat that plits the Rocks,
Are half o harmful as the greedy Flocks:
Their venom'd Bite, and Scars indented on the Stocks.

figure.p: To John Loving Esq of Little Ealing in the County of Middleex.
figure.head: Geor. 2. l. 530.

lg.l: For this the Malefactor Goat was laid
On Bacchus's Altar, and his forfeit paid.
At Athens thus old Comedy began,
When round the Streets the reeling Actors ran;
In Country Villages, and croing ways,
Contending for the Prizes of their Plays:
And glad, with Bacchus, on the graie oil,
Leapt o're the Skins of Goats bemear'd with Oyl.
Thus Roman Youth deriv'd from ruin'd Troy,
In rude Saturnian Rhymes expres their Joy:
With Taunts, and Laughter loud, their Audience pleae,
Deform'd with Vizards, cut from Barks of Trees:
In jolly Hymns they praie the God of Wine,
Whoe Earthen Images adorn the Pine;
And there are hung on high, in honour of the Vine:
A madnes o devout the Vineyards fills.
In hollow Valleys and on riing Hills;
On what e're ide he turns his honet face,
And dances in the Wind, thoe Fields are in his grace.
To Bacchus therefore let us tune our Lays,
And in our Mother Tongue reound his Praie.
Thin Cakes in Chargers, and a Guilty Goat,
Dragg'd by the Horns, be to his Altars brought;
Whoe offer'd Entrails hall his Crime reproach,
And drip their Fatnes from the Hazle Broach.
To dres thy Vines new labour is requir'd,
Nor mut the painful Husbandman be tir'd:
For thrice, at leat, in Compas of the Year,
Thy Vineyard mut employ the turdy Steer,
To turn the Glebe; beides thy daily pain
To break the Clods, and make the Surface plain:
T'unload the Branches or the Leaves to thin,
That uck the Vital Moiture of the Vine.
Thus in a Circle runs the Peaant's Pain,
And the Year rowls within it elf again.
Ev'n in the lowet Months, when Storms have hed
From Vines the hairy Honours of their Head;
Not then the drudging Hind his Labour ends;
But to the coming Year his Care extends:
Ev'n then the naked Vine he perecutes;
His Pruning Knife at once Reforms and Cuts.
Be firt to dig the Ground, be firt to burn
The Branches lopt, and firt the Props return
Into thy Houe, that bore the burden'd Vines;
But lat to reap the Vintage of thy Wines.
Twice in the Year luxuriant Leaves o'rehade
The incumber'd Vine; rough Brambles twice invade:
Hard Labour both! commend the large exces
Of pacious Vineyards; cultivate the les.
Beides, in Woods the Shrubs of prickly Thorn,
Sallows and Reeds, on Banks of Rivers born,
Remain to cut; for Vineyards ueful found,
To tay thy Vines, and fence thy fruitful Ground.
Nor when thy tender Trees at length are bound;
When peaceful Vines from Pruning Hooks are free,
When Husbands have urvey'd the lat degree,
And utmot Files of Plants, and order'd ev'ry Tree;
Ev'n when they ing at eae in full Content,
Inulting o're the Toils they underwent;
Yet till they find a future Task remain;
To turn the Soil, and break the Clods again:
And after all, their Joys are unincere,
While falling Rains on ripening Grapes they fear.
Quite oppoite to thee are Olives found,
No dreing they require, and dread no wound;
Nor Rakes nor Harrows need, but fix'd below,
Rejoyce in open Air, and unconcerndly grow.
The Soil it elf due Nourihment upplies:
Plough but the Furrows, and the Fruits arie:
Content with mall Endeavours, 'till they pring.
Soft Peace they figure, and weet Plenty bring:
Then Olives plant, and Hymns to Pallas ing.
Thus Apple Trees, whoe Trunks are trong to bear
Their preading Boughs, exert themelves in Air:
Want no upply, but tand ecure alone,
Not truting foreign Forces, but their own:
'Till with the ruddy freight the bending Branches groan.
Thus Trees of Nature, and each common Buh,
Uncultivated thrive, and with red Berries bluh.
Vile Shrubs are horn for Browze: the tow'ring hight
Of unctuous Trees, are Torches for the Night.
And hall we doubt, (indulging eaie Sloath,)
To ow, to et, and to reform their growth?
To leave the lofty Plants; the lowly kind,
Are for the Shepherd, or the Sheep deign'd.
Ev'n humble Broom and Oiers have their ue,
And Shade for Sleep, and Food for Flocks produce;
Hedges for Corn, and Honey for the Bees:
Beides the pleaing Propect of the Trees.
How goodly looks Cytorus, ever green
With Boxen Groves, with what delight are een
Narycian Woods of Pitch, whoe gloomy hade,
Seems for retreat of thoughtful Mues made!
But much more pleaing are thoe Fields to ee,
That need not Ploughs, nor Human Indutry.
Ev'n cold Caucaean Rocks with Trees are pread,
And wear green Forets on their hilly Head.
Tho' bending from the blat of Eatern Storms,
Tho' hent their Leaves, and hatter'd are their Arms;
Yet Heav'n their various Plants for ue deigns:
For Houes Cedars, and for Shipping Pines.
Cypres provides for Spokes, and Wheels of Wains:
And all for Keels of Ships, that cour the watry Plains.
Willows in Twigs are fruitful, Elms in Leaves,
The War, from tubborn Myrtle Shafts receives:
From Cornels Jav'lins, and the tougher Yeugh
Receives the bending Figure of a Bow.
Nor Box, nor Limes, without their ue are made,
Smooth-grain'd, and proper for the Turner's Trade:
Which curious Hands may kerve, and Steel with Eae invade.
Light Alder tems the Po's impetuous Tide,
And Bees in hollow Oaks their Hony hide.
Now ballance, with thee Gifts, the fumy Joys
Of Wine, attended with eternal Noie.
Wine urg'd to lawles Lut the Centaurs Train,
Thro' Wine they quarrell'd, and thro' Wine were lain.
Oh happy, if he knew his happy State!
The Swain, who, free from Buines and Debate;
Receives his eay Food from Nature's Hand,
And jut Returns of cultivated Land!
No Palace, with a lofty Gate, he wants,
T' admit the Tydes of early Viitants.
With eager Eyes devouring, as they pas,
The breathing Figures of Corinthian Bras.
No Statues threaten, from high Pedetals;
No Perian Arras hides his homely Walls,
With Antick Vets; which thro' their hady fold,
Betray the Streaks of ill diembl'd Gold.
He boats no Wool, whoe native white is dy'd
With Purple Poyon of Ayrian Pride.
No cotly Drugs of Araby defile,
With foreign Scents, the Sweetnes of his Oyl.
But eaie Quiet, a ecure Retreat,
A harmles Life that knows not how to cheat,
With homebred Plenty the rich Owner bles,
And rural Pleaures crown his Happines.
Unvex'd with Quarrels, unditurb'd with Noie,
The Country King his peaceful Realm enjoys:
Cool Grots, and living Lakes, the Flow'ry Pride
Of Meads, and Streams that thro' the Valley glide;
And hady Groves that eaie Sleep invite,
And after toilome Days, a weet repoe at Night.
Wild Beats of Nature in his Woods abound;
And Youth, of Labour patient, plow the Ground,
Inur'd to Hardhip, and to homely Fare.
Nor venerable Age is wanting there,
In great Examples to the Youthful Train:
Nor are the Gods ador'd with Rites prophane.
From hence Atrea took her Flight, and here
the Prints of her departing Steps appear.
Ye acred Mues, with whoe Beauty fir'd,
My Soul is ravih'd, and my Brain inpir'd:
Whoe Priet I am, whoe holy Fillets wear;
Wou'd you your Virgil's firt Petition hear,
Give me the Ways of wandring Stars to know:
The Depths of Heav'n above, and Earth below.
Teach me the various Labours of the Moon,
And whence proceed th' Eclipes of the Sun.
Why flowing Tides prevail upon the Main,
And in what dark Reces they hrink again.
What hakes the olid Earth, what Caue delays
The Summer Nights, and hortens Winter Days.
But if my heavy Blood retrain the Flight
Of my free Soul, apiring to the Height
Of Nature, and unclouded Fields of Light:
My next Deire is, void of Care and Strife,
To lead a oft, ecure, inglorious Life.
A Country Cottage near a Crytal Flood,
A winding Vally, and a lofty Wood.
Some God conduct me to the acred Shades,
Where Bacchanals are ung by Spartan Maids.
Or lift me high to Hemus hilly Crown;
Or in the Plains of Tempe lay me down:
Or lead me to ome olitary Place,
And cover my Retreat from Human Race.
Happy the Man, who, tudying Nature's Laws,
Thro' known Effects can trace the ecret Caue.
His Mind poeing, in a quiet tate,
Fearles of Fortune, and reign'd to Fate.
And happy too is he, who decks the Bow'rs
Of Sylvans, and adores the Rural Pow'rs:
Whoe Mind, unmov'd, the Bribes of Courts can ee;
Their glitt'ring Baits, and Purple Slavery.
Nor hopes the People's Praie, nor fears their Frown,
Nor, when contending Kindred tear the Crown,
Will et up one, or pull another down.
Without Concern he hears, but hears from far,
Of Tumults and Decents, and ditant War:
Nor with a Supertitious Fear is aw'd,
For what befals at home, or what abroad.
Nor envies he the Rich their heapy Store,
Nor with a helples Hand condoles the Poor.
He feeds on Fruits, which, of their own accord,
The willing Ground, and laden Trees afford.
From his lov'd Home no Lucre him can draw;
The Senates mad Decrees he never aw;
Nor heard, at bawling Bars, corrupted Law.
Some to the Seas, and ome to Camps reort,
And ome with Impudence invade the Court.
In foreign Countries others eek Renown,
With Wars and Taxes others wate their own.
And Houes burn, and houhold Gods deface,
To drink in Bowls which glitt'ring Gems enchae:
To loll on Couches, rich with Cytron Steds,
And lay their guilty Limbs in Tyrian Beds.
This Wretch in Earth intombs his Golden Ore,
Hov'ring and brooding on his bury'd Store.
Some Patriot Fools to pop'lar Praie apire,
By Publick Speeches, which wore Fools admire.
While from both Benches, with redoubl'd Sounds,
Th' Applaue of Lords and Commoners abounds.
Some through Ambition, or thro' Thirt of Gold;
Have lain their Brothers, or their Country old:
And leaving their weet Homes, in Exile run
To Lands that lye beneath another Sun.
The Peaant, innocent of all thee Ills,
With crooked Ploughs the fertile Fallows tills;
And the round Year with daily Labour fills.
From hence the Country Markets are upply'd:
Enough remains for houhold Charge beide;
His Wife, and tender Children to utain,
And gratefully to feed his dumb deerving Train.
Nor ceae his Labours, till the Yellow Field
A full return of bearded Harvet yield:
A Crop o plenteous, as the Land to load,
O'recome the crowded Barns, and lodge on Ricks abroad.
Thus ev'ry ev'ral Seaon is employ'd:
Some pent in Toyl, and ome in Eae enjoy'd.
The yeaning Ewes prevent the pringing Year;
The laded Boughs their Fruits in Autumn bear.
'Tis then the Vine her liquid Harvet yields,
Bak'd in the Sun-hine of acending Fields.
The Winter comes, and then the falling Mat,
For greedy Swine, provides a full repat.
Then Olives, ground in Mills, their fatnes boat,
And Winter Fruits are mellow'd by the Frot.
His Cares are eas'd with Intervals of blis,
His little Children climbing for a Kis,
Welcome their Father's late return at Night;
His faithful Bed is crown'd with chat delight.
His Kine with welling Udders ready tand,
And, lowing for the Pail, invite the Milker's hand.
His wanton Kids, with budding Horns prepar'd,
Fight harmles Battels in his homely Yard:
Himelf in Rutick Pomp, on Holy-days,
To Rural Pow'rs a jut Oblation pays;
And on the Green his careles Limbs diplays.
The Hearth is in the midt; the Herdmen round
The chearful Fire, provoke his health in Goblets crown'd.
He calls on Bacchus, and propounds the Prize;
The Groom his Fellow Groom at Buts defies;
And bends his Bow, and levels with his Eyes.
Or tript for Wretling, mears his Limbs with Oyl,
And watches with a trip his Foe to foil.
Such was the life the frugal Sabines led;
So Remus and his Brother God were bred:
From whom th' autere Etrurian Virtue roe,
And this rude life our homely Fathers choe.
Old Rome from uch a Race deriv'd her birth,
(The Seat of Empire, and the conquer'd Earth:)
Which now on ev'n high Hills triumphant reigns,
And in that compas all the World contains.
E're Saturn's Rebel Son uurp'd the Skies,
When Beats were only lain for Sacrifice:
While peaceful Crete enjoy'd her ancient Lord,
E're ounding Hammers forg'd th' inhumane Sword:

figure.p: To William Walsh of Abberley in Worcester-shire Esq
figure.head: Geo: 2. l. 760.

lg.l: E're hollow Drums were beat, before the Breath
Of brazen Trumpets rung the Peals of Death;
The good old God his Hunger did awage
With Roots and Herbs, and gave the Golden Age.
But over labour'd with o long a Coure,
Tis time to et at eae the moaking Hore.

div.head: The Third Book of the Georgics.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This Book begins with an Invocation of ome Rural Deities, and a Compliment to Augutus: After which Virgil directs himelf to Mecaenas, and enters on his Subject. He lays down Rules for the Breeding and Management of Hores, Oxen, Sheep, Goats, and Dogs: And interweaves everal pleaant Decriptions of a Chariot-Race, of the Battel of the Bulls, of the Force of Love, and of the Scythian Winter. In the latter part of the Book he relates the Dieaes incident to Cattel; and ends with the Decription of a fatal Murrain that formerly rag'd among the Alps.

lg.l: THY Fields, propitious Pales, I rehere;
And ing thy Patures in no vulgar Vere,
Amphryian Shepherd; the Lycaean Woods;
Arcadia's flow'ry Plains, and pleaing Floods.
5 All other Themes, that careles Minds invite,
Are worn with ue; unworthy me to write.
Buiri's Altars, and the dire Decrees
Of hard Euritheus, ev'ry Reader ees:
Hylas the Boy, Latona's erring Ile,
And Pelop's Iv'ry Shoulder, and his Toil
For fair Hippodamé, with all the ret
Of Grecian Tales, by Poets are expret:
New ways I mut attempt, my groveling Name
To raie aloft, and wing my flight to Fame.
I, firt of Romans hall in Triumph come
From conquer'd Greece, and bring her Trophies home:
With Foreign Spoils adorn my native place;
And with Idume's Palms, my Mantua grace.
Of Parian Stone a Temple will I raie,
Where the low Mincius through the Vally trays:

figure.p: To the most Noble and Illustrious Prince Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox Earl of Marh and Darnley Baron of Siterington Knight of the most noble Order of the Garter.
figure.head: Geo 3 l 1

lg.l: Where cooling Streams invite the Flocks to drink:
And Reeds defend the winding Waters Brink.
Full in the midt hall mighty Caear tand:
Hold the chief Honours; and the Dome command.
Then I, conpicuous in my Tyrian Gown,
(Submitting to his Godhead my Renown)
A hundred Courers from the Goal will drive;
The rival Chariots in the Race hall trive.
All Greece hall flock from far, my Games to ee;
The Whorlbat, and the rapid Race, hall be
Reerv'd for Caear, and ordain'd by me.
My elf, with Olive crown'd, the Gifts will bear:
Ev'n now methinks the publick houts I hear:
The paing Pageants, and the Pomps appear.
I, to the Temple will conduct the Crew:
The Sacrifice and Sacrificers view;
From thence return, attended with my Train,
Where the proud Theatres dicloe the Scene:
Which interwoven Britains eem to raie,
And hew the Triumph which their Shame diplays.
High o're the Gate, in Elephant and Gold,
The Crowd hall Caear's Indian War behold;
The Nile hall flow beneath; and on the ide,
His hatter'd Ships on Brazen Pillars ride.
Next him Niphates with inverted Urn,
And dropping Sedge, hall his Armenia mourn;
And Aian Cities in our Triumph born.
With backward Bows the Parthians hall be there;
And, purring from the Fight confes their Fear.
A double Wreath hall crown our Caear's Brows;
Two differing Trophies, from two different Foes.
Europe with Africk in his Fame hall join;
But neither Shoar his Conquet hall confine.
The Parian Marble, there, hall feem to move,
In breathing Statues, not unworthy Jove.
Reembling Heroes, whoe Etherial Root,
Is Jove himelf, and Caear is the Fruit.
Tros and his Race the Sculptor hall employ;
And he the God, who built the Walls of Troy.
Envy her elf at lat, grown pale and dumb;
(By Caear combated and overcome)
Shall give her Hands; and fear the curling Snakes
Of lahing Furies, and the burning Lakes:
The Pains of famiht Tantalus hall feel;
And Siyphus that labours up the Hill
The rowling Rock in vain; and curt Ixion's Wheel.
Mean time we mut purue the Sylvan Lands;
(Th' abode of Nymphs,) untouch'd by former Hands:
For uch, Maecenas, are thy hard Commands.
Without thee nothing lofty can I ing;
Come then, and with thy elf thy Genius bring:
With which inpir'd, I brook no dull delay.
Cytheron loudly calls me to my way;
Thy Hounds, Taygetus, open and purue their Prey.
High Epidaurus urges on my peed,
Fam'd for his Hills, and for his Hores breed:
From Hills and Dales the chearful Cries rebound:
For Echo hunts along; and propagates the ound.
A time will come, when my maturer Mue,
In Caear's Wars, a Nobler Theme hall chue.
And through more Ages bear my Soveraign's Praie;
Than have from Tithon pat to Caear's Days.
The Generous Youth, who tudious of the Prize,
The Race of running Courers multiplies;
Or to the Plough the turdy Bullock breeds,
May know that from the Dam the worth of each proceeds:
The Mother Cow mut wear a low'ring look,
Sour headed, trongly neck'd, to bear the Yoke.
Her double Dew-lap from her Chin decends:
And at her Thighs the pondrous burthen ends.
Long are her ides and large, her Limbs are great;
Rough are her Ears, and broad her horny Feet.
Her Colour hining Black, but fleck'd with white;
She toes from the Yoke; provokes the Fight:
She ries in her Gate, is free from Fears;
And in her Face a Bull's Reemblance bears:
Her ample Forehead with a Star is crown'd;
And with her length of Tail he weeps the Ground.
The Bull's Inult at Four he may utain;
But, after Ten, from Nuptial Rites refrain.
Six Seaons ue; but then releae the Cow,
Unfit for Love, and for the lab'ring Plough.
Now while their Youth is fill'd with kindly Fire,
Submit thy Females to the luty Sire:
Watch the quick motions of the frisking Tail,
Then erve their fury with the ruhing Male,
Indulging Pleaure let the Breed hou'd fail.
In Youth alone, unhappy Mortals live;
But, ah! the mighty Blis is fugitive;
Dicolour'd Sicknes, anxious Labours come,
And Age, and Death's inexorable Doom.
Yearly thy Herds in vigour will impair;
Recruit and mend 'em with thy Yearly care:
Still propagate, for till they fall away,
'Tis Prudence to prevent th' entire decay.
Like Diligence requires the Courer's Race;
In early Choice; and for a longer pace.
The Colt, that for a Stallion is deign'd,
By ure Preages hows his generous Kind,
Of able Body, ound of Limb and Wind.
Upright he walks, on Paterns firm and traight;
His Motions eay; prancing in his Gate.
The firt to lead the Way, to tempt the Flood;
To pas the Bridge unknown, nor fear the trembling Wood.
Dauntles at empty Noies; lofty neck'd;
Sharp headed, Barrel belly'd, broadly back'd.
Brawny his Chet, and deep, his Colour gray;
For Beauty dappled, or the brightet Bay:
Faint white and Dun will carce the Rearing pay.
The fiery Courer, when he hears from far,
The prightly Trumpet, and the houts of War,
Pricks up his Ears; and trembling with Delight,
Shifts place, and paws; and hopes the promis'd Fight.
On his right Shoulder his thick Mane reclin'd,
Ruffles at peed; and dances in the Wind.
His horny Hoofs are jetty black, and round;
His Chine is double; tarting, with a bound
He turns the Turf, and hakes the olid Ground.
Fire from his Eyes, Clouds from his Notrils flow:
He bears his Rider headlong on the Foe.
Such was the Steed in Graecian Poets fam'd,
Proud Cyllarus, by Spartan Cator tam'd:
Such Courers bore to Fight the God of Thrace;
And uch, Achilles, was thy warlike Race.
In uch a Shape, old Saturn did retrain
His Heav'nly Limbs, and flow'd with uch a Mane.
When, half urpriz'd, and fearing to be een,
The Leacher gallop'd from his Jealous Queen:
Ran up the ridges of the Rocks amain;
And with hrill Neighings fill'd the Neigb'ring Plain.
But worn with Years, when dire Dieaes come,
Then hide his not Ignoble Age, at Home:
In Peace t' enjoy his former Palms and Pains;
And gratefully be kind to his Remains.
For when his Blood no Youthful Spirits move,
He languihes and labours in his Love.
And when the prightly Seed hou'd wiftly come,
Dribling he drudges, and defrauds the Womb.
In vain he burns, like fainty Stubble Fires;
And in himelf his former elf requires.
His Age and Courage weigh: Nor thoe alone,
But note his Father's Virtues with his own;
Oberve if he didains to yield the Prize;
Of Los impatient, proud of Victories.
Hat thou beheld, when from the Goal they tart,
The Youthful Charioteers with beating Heart,
Ruh to the Race; and panting, carcely bear
Th' extreams of feaverih hope, and chilling Fear;
Stoop to the Reins, and lah with all their force;
The flying Chariot kindles in the Coure:
And now aloft; and now alow they fly,
Now eem to ink in Earth, and now to touch the Sky;
No top, no tay, but Clouds of Sand arie;
Spurn'd, and cat backward on the Follower's Eyes.
The hindmot blows the foam upon the firt:
Such is the love of Praie, an Honourable Thirt.
Bold Ericthonius was the firt, who join'd
Four Hores for the rapid Race deign'd;
And o're the duty Wheels preiding ate;
The Lapythae to Chariots, added State
Of Bits and Bridles; taught the Steed to bound;
To run the Ring, and trace the mazy round.
To top, to fly, the Rules of War to know:
T' obey the Rider; and to dare the Foe.
To chue a Youthful Steed, with Courage fir'd;
To breed him, break him, back him, are requir'd
Experienc'd Maters; and in undry Ways:
Their Labours equal, and alike their Praie.
But once again the batter'd Hore beware,
The weak old Stallion will deceive thy care.
Though Famous in his Youth for force and peed,
Or was of Argos or Epirian breed,
Or did from Neptune's Race, or from himelf proceed.
Thee things premis'd, when now the Nuptial time
Approaches for the tately Steed to climb;
With Food inable him, to make his Court;
Ditend his Chine, and pamper him for port.
Feed him with Herbs, whatever thou can't find,
Of generous warmth; and of alacious kind.
Then Water him, and (drinking what he can)
Encourage him to thirt again, with Bran.
Intructed thus, produce him to the Faire;
And joyn in Wedlock to the longing Mare.
For if the Sire be faint, or out of cae,
He will be copied in his famih'd Race:
And ink beneath the pleaing Task aign'd;
(For all's too little for the craving Kind.)
As for the Females, with indutrious care
Take down their Mettle, keep 'em lean and bare;
When concious of their pat delight, and keen
To take the leap, and prove the port agen;
With canty meaure then upply their food;
And, when athirt, retrain 'em from the flood:
Their Bodies harras, ink 'em when they run;
And fry their melting Marrow in the Sun.
Starve 'em, when Barns beneath their burthen groan,
And winnow'd Chaff, by wetern winds is blown.
For Fear the ranknes of the welling Womb
Shou'd cant the paage, and confine the room.
Let the Fat Furrows hou'd the ene detroy
Of Genial Lut; and dull the Seat of Joy.
But let 'em uck the Seed with greedy force;
And there encloe the Vigour of the Hore.
No more of Courers yet: We now proceed
To teeming Kine; and their laborious breed.
Firt let 'em run at large; and never know
The taming Yoak, or draw the crooked Plough.
Let 'em not leap the Ditch, or wim the Flood;
Or lumber o're the Meads; or cros the Wood.
But range the Forret, by the ilver ide
Of ome cool Stream, where Nature hall provide
Green Gras and fat'ning Clover for their fare!
And Moy Caverns for their Evening lare:
With Rocks above, to hield the harp Nocturnal air.
About th' Alburnian Groves, with Holly green,
Of winged Inects mighty warms are een:
This flying Plague (to mark its quality;)
Oetros the Grecians call: Aylus, we:
A fierce loud buzzing Breez; their tings draw blood;
And drive the Cattel gadding through the Wood.
Seiz'd with unuual pains, they loudly cry,
Tanagrus hatens thence; and leaves his Channel dry.
This Cure the jealous Juno did invent;
And firt imploy'd for Io's Punihment.
To hun this Ill, the cunning Leach ordains
In Summer's Sultry Heats (for then it reigns)
To feed the Females, e're the Sun arie,
Or late at Night, when Stars adorn the Skies.
When he has calv'd, then et the Dam aide;
And for the tender Progeny provide.
Ditinguih all betimes, with branding Fire;
To note the Tribe, the Lineage, and The Sire.
Whom to reerve for Husband of the Herd;
Or who hall be to Sacrifice preferr'd;
Or whom thou halt to turn thy Glebe allow;
To harrow Furrows, and utain the Plough:
The ret, for whom no Lot is yet decreed,
May run in Patures, and at pleaure feed.
The Calf, by Nature and by Genius made
To turn the Glebe, breed to the Rural Trade.
Set him betimes to School; and let him be
Intructed there in Rules of Husbandry:
While yet his youth is flexible and green;
Nor bad Examples of the World has een.
Early begin the tubborn Child to break;
For his oft Neck, a upple Collar make
Of bending Oiers; and (with time and care
Enur'd that eaie Servitude to bear)
Thy flattering Method on the Youth purue:
Join'd with his School-Fellows, by two and two,
Perwade 'em firt to lead an empty Wheel,
That carce the dut can raie; or they can feel:
In length of Time produce the lab'ring Yoke
And hining Shares, that make the Furrow moak.
E're the licentious Youth be thus retrain'd,
Or Moral Precepts on their Minds have gain'd;
Their wanton appetites not only feed
With delicates of Leaves, and marhy Weed,
But with thy Sickle reap the ranket land:
And miniter the blade, with bounteous hand.
Nor be with harmful parimony won
To follow what our homely Sires have done;
Who fill'd the Pail with Beetings of the Cow:
But all her Udder to the Calf allow.
If to the Warlike Steed thy Studies bend,
Or for the Prize in Chariots to contend;
Near Pia's Flood the rapid Wheels to guide,
Or in Olympian Groves aloft to ride,
The generous Labours of the Courer, firt
Mut be with ight of Arms and ounds of Trumpets nurt:
Inur'd the groaning Axle-tree to bear;
And let him clahing Whips in Stables hear.
Sooth him with Praie, and make him undertand
The loud Applaues of his Mater's Hand:
This from his Weaning, let him well be taught;
And then betimes in a oft Snaffle wrought:
Before his tender Joints with Nerves are knit;
Guiltles of Arms, and trembling at the Bit.
But when to four full Springs his years advance,
Teach him to run the round, with Pride to prance;
And (rightly manag'd) equal time to beat;
To turn, to bound in meaure; and Curvet.
Let him, to this, with eaie pains be brought:
And eem to labour, when he labours not.
Thus, form'd for peed, he challenges the Wind;
And leaves the Scythian Arrow far behind:
He cours along the Field, with looen'd Reins;
And treads o light, he carcely prints the Plains.
Like Boreas in his Race, when ruhing forth,
He weeps the Skies, and clears the cloudy North:
The waving Harvet bends beneath his blat;
The Foret hakes, the Groves their Honours cat;
He flies aloft, and with impetuous roar
Purues the foaming Surges to the Shoar.
Thus o're th' Elean Plains, thy well-breath'd Hore
Sutains the goring Spurs, and wins the Coure.
Or, bred to Belgian Waggons, leads the Way;
Untir'd at night, and chearful all the Day.
When once he's broken, feed him full and high:
Indulge his Growth, and his gaunt ides upply.
Before his Training, keep him poor and low;
For his tout Stomach with his Food will grow;
The pamper'd Colt will Dicipline didain,
Impatient of the Lah, and retiff to the Rein.
Wou'dt thou their Courage and their Strength improve,
Too oon they mut not feel the tings of Love.
Whether the Bull or Courer be thy Care,
Let him not leap the Cow, nor mount the Mare.
The youthful Bull mut wander in the Wood;
Behind the Mountain, or beyond the Flood:
Or, in the Stall at home his Fodder find;
Far from the Charms of that alluring Kind.
With two fair Eyes his Mitres burns his Breat;
He looks, and languihes, and leaves his Ret;
Forakes his Food, and pining for the Las,
Is joyles of the Grove, and purns the growing gras.
The oft Seducer, with enticing Looks,
The bellowing Rivals to the Fight provokes.
A beauteous Heifer in the Woods is bred;
The tooping Warriours, aiming Head to Head,
Engage their clahing Horns; with dreadful Sound
The Foret rattles, and the Rocks rebound.
They fence, they puh, and puhing loudly roar;
Their Dewlaps and their Sides are bath'd in Gore.
Nor when the War is over, is it Peace;
Nor will the vanquih'd Bull his Claim releae:
But feeding in his Breat his ancient Fires,
And curing Fate, from his proud Foe retires.
Driv'n from his Native Land, to foreign Grounds,
He with a gen'rous Rage reents his Wounds;
His ignominious Flight, the Victor's boat,
And more than both, the Loves, which unreveng'd he lot.
Often he turns his Eyes, and, with a Groan,
Surveys the pleaing Kingdoms, once his own.

figure.p: To Sr Iustinian Isham of Lamport in Northampton Shire Barronet
figure.head: Geo 3. L 340.

lg.l: And therefore to repair his Strength he tries:
Hardning his Limbs with painful Exercie,
And rough upon the flinty Rock he lies.
On prickly Leaves, and on harp Herbs he feeds,
Then to the Prelude of a War proceeds.
His Horns, yet ore, he tries againt a Tree:
And meditates his abent Enemy.
He nuffs the Wind, his heels the Sand excite;
But, when he tands collected in his might,
He roars, and promies a more uccesful Fight.
Then, to redeem his Honour at a blow,
He moves his Camp, to meet his careles Foe.
Not with more Madnes, rolling from afar,
The pumy Waves proclaim the watry War.
And mounting upwards, with a mighty Roar,
March onwards, and inult the rocky hoar.
They mate the middle Region with their height;
And fall no les, than with a Mountain's weight;
The Waters boil, and belching from below
Black Sands, as from a forceful Engine throw.
Thus every Creature, and of every Kind,
The ecret Joys of weet Coition find:
Not only Man's Imperial Race; but they
That wing the liquid Air; or wim the Sea,
Or haunt the Deart, ruh into the flame:
For Love is Lord of all; and is in all the ame.
'Tis with this rage, the Mother Lion tung,
Scours o're the Plain; regardles of her young:
Demanding Rites of Love; he ternly talks;
And hunts her Lover in his lonely Walks.
'Tis then the hapeles Bear his Den forakes;
In Woods and Fields a wild detruction makes.
Boars whet their Tusks; to battel Tygers move;
Enrag'd with Hunger, more enrag'd with Love.
Then wo to him, that in the deart Land
Of Lybia travels, o're the burning Sand.
The Stallion nuffs the well-known Scent afar;
And norts and trembles for the ditant Mare:
Nor Bits nor Bridles can his Rage retrain;
And rugged Rocks are interpos'd in vain:
He makes his way o're Mountains, and contemns
Unruly Torrents, and unfoorded Streams.
The britled Boar, who feels the pleaing Wound,
New grinds his arming Tusks, and digs the Ground.
The leepy Leacher huts his little Eyes;
About his churning Chaps the frothy bubbles rie:
He rubs his ides againt a Tree; prepares
And hardens both his Shoulders for the Wars.
What did the Youth, when Love's unerring Dart
Transfixt his Liver; and inflam'd his heart?
Alone, by night, his watry way he took;
About him, and above, the Billows broke:
The Sluces of the Skie were open pread;
And rowling Thunder rattl'd o're his Head.
The raging Tempet call'd him back in vain;
And every boding Omen of the Main.
Nor cou'd his Kindred; nor the kindly Force
Of weeping Parents, change his fatal Coure.
No, not the dying Maid who mut deplore
His floating Carcas on the Setian hore.
I pas the Wars that potted Linx's make
With their fierce Rivals, for the Females ake:
The howling Wolves, the Matiffs amorous rage;
When ev'n the fearul Stag dares for his Hind engage.
But far above the ret, the furious Mare,
Barr'd from the Male, is frantick with depair.
For when her pouting Vent declares her pain,
She tears the Harnes, and he rends the Reyn;
For this; (when Venus gave them rage and pow'r)
Their Maters mangl'd Members they devour;
Of Love defrauded in their longing Hour.
For Love they force thro' Thickets of the Wood,
They climb the teepy Hills, and tem the Flood.
When at the Spring's approach their Marrow burns,
(For with the Spring their genial Warmth returns)
The Mares to Cliffs of rugged Rocks repair,
And with wide Notrils nuff the Wetern Air:
When (wondrous to relate) the Parent Wind,
Without the Stallion, propagates the Kind.
Then fir'd with amorous rage, they take their Flight
Through Plains, and mount the Hills unequal height;
Nor to the North, nor to the Riing Sun,
Nor Southward to the Rainy Regions run,
But boring to the Wet, and hov'ring there,
With gaping Mouths, they draw prolifick air:
With which impregnate, from their Groins they hed
A limy Juice, by fale Conception bred.
The Shepherd knows it well; and calls by Name
Hippomanes, to note the Mother's Flame.
This, gather'd in the Planetary Hour,
With noxious Weeds, and pell'd with Words of pow'r
Dire Stepdames in the Magick Bowl infue;
And mix, for deadly Draughts, the poys'nous Juice.
But time is lot, which never will renew,
While we too far the pleaing Path purue;
Surveying Nature, with too nice a view.
Let this uffice for Herds: our following Care
Shall woolly Flocks, and haggy Goats declare.
Nor can I doubt what Oyl I mut betow,
To raie my Subject from a Ground o low:
And the mean Matter which my Theme affords,
T'embellih with Magnificence of Words.
But the commanding Mue my Chariot guides;
Which o're the dubious Cliff ecurely rides:
And pleas'd I am, no beaten Road to take:
But firt the way to new Dicov'ries make.
Now, acred Pales, in a lofty train,
I ing the Rural Honours of thy Reign.
Firt with aiduous care, from Winter keep
Well fodder'd in the Stalls, thy tender, Sheep.
Then pread with Straw, the bedding of thy Fold;
With Fern beneath, to fend the bitter Gold.
That free from Gouts thou may't preerve thy Care:
And clear from Scabs, produc'd by freezing Air.
Next let thy Goats officiouly be nurs'd;
And led to living Streams; to quench their Thirt.
Feed 'em with Winter-brouze, and for their lare
A Cot that opens to the South prepare:
Where basking in the Sun-hine they may lye,
And the hort Remnants of his Heat enjoy.
This during Winter's drily Reign be done:
'Till the new Ram receives th' exalted Sun:
For hairy Goats of equal profit are
With woolly Sheep, and ask an equal Care.
'Tis true, the Fleece, when drunk with Tyrian Juice,
Is dearly old; but not for needful ue:
For the allacious Goat encreaes more;
And twice as largely yields her milky Store.
The till ditended Udders never fail;
But when they eem exhauted well the Pail.
Mean time the Pator hears their hoary Beards;
And eaes of their Hair, the loaden Herds.
Their Camelots, warm in Tents, the Souldier hold;
And hield the wretched Mariner from Cold.
On Shrubs they brouze, and on the bleaky Top
Of rugged Hills, the thorny Bramble crop.

figure.p: To the Right Worshipfull Sr. Thomas Mompeson of Bathampton in the County of Wilts, Knight.
figure.head: Geor: 3. l. 465

lg.l: Attended with their Family they come
At Night unask'd, and mindful of their home;
And carce their welling Bags the threhold overcome.
So much the more thy diligence betow
In depth of Winter, to defend the Snow:
By how much les the tender helples Kind,
For their own ills, can fit Proviion find.
Then miniter the browze, with bounteous hand;
And open let thy Stacks all Winter tand.
But when the Wetern Winds with vital pow'r
Call forth the tender Gras, and budding Flower;
Then, at the lat, produce in open Air
Both Flocks; and end 'em to their Summer fare.
Before the Sun, while Heperus appears;
Firt let 'em ip from Herbs the pearly tears
Of Morning Dews: And after break their Fat
On Green-word Ground; (a cool and grateful tate:)
But when the day's fourth hour has drawn the Dews,
And the Sun's ultry heat their thirt renews;
When creaking Grahoppers on Shrubs complain,
Then lead 'em to their wat'ring Troughs again.
In Summer's heat, ome bending Valley find,
Clos'd from the Sun, but open to the Wind:
Or eek ome ancient Oak, whoe Arms extend
In ample breadth, thy Cattle to defend:
Or olitary Grove, or gloomy Glade:
To hield 'em with its venerable Shade.
Once more to wat'ring lead; and feed again
When the low Sun is inking to the Main.
When riing Cynthia heds her ilver Dews;
And the cool Evening-breeze the Meads renews:
When Linnets fill the Woods with tuneul ound,
And hollow hoars the Halcyons Voice rebound.
Why hou'd my Mue enlarge on Lybian Swains;
Their catter'd Cottages, and ample Plains?
Where oft the Flocks, without a Leader tray;
Or through continu'd Dearts take their way;
And, feeding, add the length of Night to day.
Whole Months they wander, grazing as they go;
Nor Folds, nor hopitable Harbour know.
Such an extent of Plains, o vat a pace
Of Wilds unknown, and of untated Gras
Allures their Eyes: The Shepherd lat appears,
And with him all his Patrimony bears:
His Houe and houehold Gods! his trade of War,
His Bow and Quiver; and his truty Cur.
Thus, under heavy Arms, the Youth of Rome
Their long laborious Marches overcome;
Chearly their tedious Travels undergo:
And pitch their udden Camp before the Foe.
Not o the Scythian Shepherd tends his Fold;
Nor he who bears in Thrace the bitter cold:
Nor he, who treads the bleak Meotian Strand;
Or where proud Iter rouls his yellow Sand.
Early they tall their Flocks and Herds; for there
No Gras the Fields, no Leaves the Forets wear.
The frozen Earth lies buried there, below
A hilly heap, ev'n Cubits deep in Snow:
And all the Wet Allies of tormy Boreas blow.
The Sun from far, peeps with a ickly face;
Too weak the Clouds, and mighty Fogs to chace;
When up the Skies, he hoots his roie Head;
Or in the ruddy Ocean eeks his Bed.
Swift Rivers, are with udden Ice contrain'd;
And tudded Wheels are on its back utain'd.
An Hotry now or Waggons; which before
Tall Ships of burthen, on its Boom bore.

figure.p: To John Dormer of Rowhan in the County of Oxford Esq
figure.head: Geo: 3: L 570.

lg.l: The brazen Cauldrons, with the Frot are flaw'd;
The Garment, tiff with Ice, at Hearths is thaw'd.
With Axes firt they cleave the Wine, and thence
By weight, the olid portions they dipence.
From Locks uncomb'd, and from the frozen Beard,
Long Iicles depend, and crackling Sounds are heard.
Mean time perpetual Sleet, and driving Snow,
Obcure the Skies, and hang on Herds below.
The tarving Cattle perih in their Stalls,
Huge Oxen tand enclos'd in wint'ry Walls
Of Snow congeal'd; whole Herds are bury'd there
Of mighty Stags, and carce their Horns appear.
The dext'rous Huntman wounds not thee afar,
With Shafts, or Darts, or makes a ditant War
With Dogs; or pitches Toyls to top their Flight:
But cloe engages in unequal Fight.
And while they trive in vain to make their way
Through hills of Snow, and pitifully bray;
Aaults with dint of Sword, or pointed Spears,
And homeward, on his Back, the joyful burthen bears.
The Men to ubterranean Caves retire;
Secure from Cold; and crowd the chearful Fire:
With Trunks of Elms and Oaks, the Hearth they load,
Nor tempt th' inclemency of Heav'n abroad.
Their jovial Nights, in frollicks and in play
They pas, to drive the tedious Hours away.
And their cold Stomachs with crown'd Goblets cheer,
Of windy Cider, and of barmy Beer.
Such are the cold Ryphean Race; and uch
The avage Scythian, and unwarlike Dutch.
Where Skins of Beats, the rude Barbarians wear;
The poils of Foxes, and the furry Bear.
Is Wool thy care? Let not thy Cattle go
Where Buhes are, where Burs and Thitles grow;
Nor in too rank a Pature let 'em feed:
Then of the puret white elect thy Breed.
Ev'n though a nowy Ram thou halt behold,
Prefer him not in hate, for Husband to thy Fold.
But earch his Mouth; and if a warthy Tongue
Is underneath his humid Pallat hung;
Reject him, let he darken all the Flock;
And ubtitute another from thy Stock.
Twas thus with Fleeces milky white (if we
May trut report,) Pan God of Arcady
Did bribe thee Cynthia; nor didt thou didain
When call'd in woody hades, to cure a Lover's pain.
If Milk be thy deign; with plenteous hand
Bring Clover-gras; and from the marhy Land
Salt Herbage for the fodd'ring Rack provide;
To fill their Bags, and well the milky Tide:
Thee raie their Thirt, and to the Tate retore
The avour of the Salt, on which they fed before.
Some, when the Kids their Dams too deeply drain,
With gags and muzzles their oft Mouths retrain.
Their morning Milk, the Peaants pres at Night:
Their Evening Meal, before the riing Light
To Market bear: or paringly they teep
With eas'ning Salt, and tor'd, for Winter keep.
Nor lat, forget thy faithful Dogs: but feed
With fat'ning Whey the Matiffs gen'rous breed;
And Spartan Race: who for the Folds relief
Will proecute with Cries the Nightly Thief:
Repule the prouling Wolf, and hold at Bay,
The Mountain Robbers, ruhing to the Prey.
With cries of Hounds, thou may't purue the fear
Of flying Hares, and chace the fallow Deer;
Rouze from their deart Dens, the bril'd Rage
Of Boars, and beamy Stags in Toyls engage.
With moak of burning Cedar cent thy Walls:
And fume with tinking Galbanum thy Stalls:
With that rank Odour from thy dwelling Place
To drive the Viper's brood, and all the venom'd Race.
For often under Stalls unmov'd, they lye,
Obcure in hades, and hunning Heav'ns broad Eye.
And Snakes, familiar, to the Hearth ucceed,
Dicloe their Eggs, and near the Chimny breed.
Whether, to roofy Houes they repair,
Or Sun themelves abroad in open Air,
In all abodes of petilential Kind,
To Sheep and Oxen, and the painful Hind.
Take, Shepherd take, a plant of tubborn Oak;
And labour him with many a turdy troak:
Or with hard Stones, demolih from a-far
His haughty Cret, the eat of all the War.
Invade his hiing Throat, and winding pires;
'Till tretch'd in length, th' unfolded Foe retires.
He drags his Tail; and for his Head provides:
And in ome ecret cranny lowly glides;
But leaves expos'd to blows, his Back and batter'd ides.
In fair Calabria's Woods, a Snake is bred,
With curling Cret, and with advancing Head:
Waving he rolls, and makes a winding Track;
His Belly potted, burniht is his Back:
While Springs are broken, while the Southern Air
And dropping Heav'ns, the moiten'd Earth repair,
He lives on tanding Lakes, and trembling Bogs,
And fills his Maw with Fih, or with loquacious Frogs.
But when, in muddy Pools, the water inks;
And the chapt Earth is furrow'd o're with Chinks;
He leaves the Fens, and leaps upon the Ground;
And hiing, rowls his glaring Eyes around.
With Thirt inflam'd, impatient of the heats,
He rages in the Fields, and wide Detruction threats.
Oh let not Sleep, my cloing Eyes invade,
In open Plains, or in the ecret Shade,
When he, renew'd in all the peckl'd Pride
Of pompous Youth, has cat his lough aide:
And in his Summer Liv'ry rowls along:
Erect, and brandihing his forky Tongue,
Leaving his Net, and his imperfect Young;
And thoughtles of his Egs, forgets to rear
The hopes of Poyon, for the foll'wing Year.
The Caues and the Signs hall next be told,
Of ev'ry Sicknes that infects the Fold.
A cabby Tetter on their pelts will tick,
When the raw Rain has pierc'd 'em to the quick:
Or earching Frots, have eaten through the Skin,
Or burning Iicles are lodg'd within:
Or when the Fleece is horn, if weat remains
Unwah'd, and oaks into their empty Veins:
When their defenceles Limbs, the Brambles tear;
Short of their Wool, and naked from the Sheer.
Good Shepherds after heering, drench their Sheep,
And their Flocks Father (forc'd from high to leap)
Swims down the Stream, and plunges in the deep.
They oint their naked Limbs with mother'd Oyl;
Or from the Founts where living Sulphurs boyl,
They mix a Med'cine to foment their Limbs;
With Scum that on the molten Silver wims.
Fat Pitch, and black Bitumen, add to thee,
Beides, the waxen labour of the Bees:
And Hellebore, and Squills deep rooted in the Seas,
Receits abound; but earching all thy Store,
The bet is till at hand, to launch the Sore:

figure.p: To Fredrick Filney of Filney Hall in Hant-Shire Esq
figure.head: Geo 3: L 721

lg.l: And cut the Head; for till the Core be found,
The ecret Vice is fed, and gathers Ground:
While making fruitles Moan, the Shepherd tands,
And, when the launching Knife requires his hands,
Vain help, with idle Pray'rs from Heav'n demands.
Deep in their Bones when Feavers fix their eat,
And rack their Limbs; and lick the vital heat;
The ready Cure to cool the raging Pain,
Is underneath the Foot to breath a Vein.
This remedy the Scythian Shepherds found:
Th' Inhabitants of Thracia's hilly Ground,
And Gelons ue it; when for Drink and Food
They mix their cruddl'd Milk with Hores Blood.
But where thou eet a ingle Sheep remain
In hades aloof, or couch'd upon the Plain;
Or litlely to crop the tender Gras;
Or late to lag behind, with truant pace;
Revenge the Crime; and take the Traytor's head,
E're in the faultles Flock the dire Contagion pread.
On Winter Seas we fewer Storms behold,
Than foul Dieaes that infect the Fold.
Nor do thoe ills, on ingle Bodies prey;
But oft'ner bring the Nation to decay;
And weep the preent Stock, and future Hope away.
A dire Example of this Truth appears:
When, after uch a length of rowling Years,
We ee the naked Alps, and thin Remains
Of catter'd Cotts, and yet unpeopl'd Plains:
Once fill'd with grazing Flocks, the Shepherds happy Reigns.
Here from the vicious Air, and ickly Skies,
A Plague did on the dumb Creation rie:
During th' Autumnal Heats th' Infection grew,
Tame Cattle, and the Beats of Nature lew.
Poys'ning the Standing Lakes; and Pools Impure:
Nor was the foodful Gras in Fields ecure.
Strange Death! For when the thirty fire had drunk
Their vital Blood, and the dry Nerves were hrunk;
When the contracted Limbs were cramp'd, ev'n then
A wat'rih Humour well'd and ooz'd agen:
Converting into Bane the kindly Juice,
Ordain'd by Nature for a better ue.
The Victim Ox, that was for Altars pret,
Trim'd with white Ribbons, and with Garlands dret,
Sunk of himelf, without the Gods Command:
Preventing the low Sacrificer's Hand.
Or, by the holy Butcher, if he fell,
Th' inpected Entrails, cou'd no Fates foretel.
Nor, laid on Altars, did pure Flames arie;
But Clouds of mouldring Smoke, forbad the Sacrifice.
Scarcely the Knife was redden'd with his Gore,
Or the black Poyon tain'd the andy Floor.
The thriven Calves in Meads their Food forake,
And render their weet Souls before the plenteous Rack.
The fawning Dog runs mad; the wheaing Swine
With Coughs is choak'd; and labours from the Chine:
The Victor Hore, forgetful of his Food,
The Palm renounces, and abhors the Flood.
He paws the Ground, and on his hanging Ears
A doubtful Sweat in clammy drops appears:
Parch'd is his Hide, and rugged are his Hairs.
Such are the Symptoms of the young Dieae;
But in time's proces, when his pains encreae,
He rouls his mournful Eyes, he deeply groans
With patient obbing, and with manly Moans.
He heaves for Breath: which, from his Lungs upply'd,
And fetch'd from far, ditends his lab'ring ide.
To his rough Palat, his dry Tongue ucceeds;
And roapy Gore, he from his Notrils bleeds.
A Drench of Wine has with ucces been us'd;
And through a Horn, the gen'rous Juice infus'd:
Which timely taken op'd his cloing Jaws;
But, if too late, the Patient's death did caue.
For the too vig'rous Doe, too fiercely wrought;
And added Fury to the Srength it brought.
Recruited into Rage, he grinds his Teeth
In his own Fleh, and feeds approaching Death.
Ye Gods, to better Fate, good Men dipoe;
And turn that Impious Errour on our Foes!
The Steer, who to the Yoke was bred to bow,
(Studious of Tillage; and the crooked Plough)
Falls down and dies; and dying pews a Flood
Of foamy Madnes, mix'd with clotted Blood.
The Clown, who curing Providence repines,
His Mournful Fellow from the Team disjoyns:
With many a groan, forakes his fruitles care;
And in th' unfinih'd Furrow, leaves the Share.
The pineing Steer, no Shades of lofty Woods,
Nor flow'ry Meads can eae; nor Crytal floods
Roul'd from the Rock: His flabby Flanks decreae;
His Eyes are ettled in a tupid peace.
His bulk too weighty for his Thighs is grown;
And his unweildy Neck, hangs drooping down.
Now what avails his well-deerving Toil
To turn the Glebe; or mooth the rugged Soil!
And yet he never upt in olemn State,
Nor undigeted Feats did urge his Fate;
Nor day, to Night, luxuriouly did joyn;
Nor urfeited on rich Campanian Wine.
Simple his Bev'rage; homely was his Food;
The wholom Herbage, and the running Flood:
No dreadful Dreams awak'd him with affright;
His Pains by Day, ecur'd his Ret by Night.
'Twas then that Buffalo's, ill pair'd, were een
To draw the Carr of Jove's Imperial Queen
For want of Oxen: and the lab'ring Swain
Scratch'd with a Rake, a Furrow for his Grain:
And cover'd, with his hand, the hallow Seed again.
He Yokes himelf, and up the Hilly height,
With his own Shoulders, draws the Waggon's weight.
The nightly Wolf, that round th' Encloure proul'd
To leap the Fence; now plots not on the Fold.
Tam'd with a harper Pain. The fearful Doe
And flying Stag, amidt the Grey-Hounds go:
And round the Dwellings roam of Man, their fiercer Foe.
The caly Nations of the Sea profound,
Like Shipwreck'd Carcaes are driv'n aground:
And mighty Phocae, never een before
In hallow Streams, are tranded on the hore.
The Viper dead, within her Hole is found:
Defenceles was the helter of the ground.
The water-Snake, whom Fih and Paddocks fed,
With taring Scales lies poyon'd in his Bed:
To Birds their Native Heav'ns contagious prove,
From Clouds they fall, and leave their Souls above.
Beides, to change their Pature 'tis in vain:
Or trut to Phyick; Phyick is their Bane.
The Learned Leaches in depair depart:
And hake their Heads, deponding of their Art.
Tiiphone, let looe from under ground,
Majetically pale, now treads the round:
Before her drives Dieaes, and affright;
And every moment ries to the ight:
Apiring to the Skies; encroaching on the light.
The Rivers and their Banks, and Hills around,
With lowings, and with dying Bleats reound.
At length, he trikes an Univeral Blow;
To Death at once whole Herds of Cattle go:
Sheep, Oxen, Hores fall; and, heap'd on high,
The diff'ring Species in Confuion lie.
'Till warn'd by frequent ills, the way they found,
To lodge their loathom Carrion underground.
For, ueles to the Currier were their Hides:
Nor cou'd their tainted Fleh with Ocean Tides
Be freed from Filth; nor cou'd Vulcanian Flame
The Stench abolih; or the Savour tame.
Nor afely cou'd they hear their fleecy Store;
(Made drunk with poys'nous Juice, and tiff with Gore:)
Or touch the Web: But if the Vet they wear,
Red Bliters riing on their Paps appear,
And flaming Carbuncles; and noiom Sweat,
And clammy Dews, that loathom Lice beget:
'Till the low creeping Evil eats his way,
Conumes the parching Limbs; and makes the Life his prey.

div.head: The Fourth Book of the Georgics.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Virgil has taken care to raie the Subject of each Georgic: In the Firt he has only dead Matter on which to work. In the econd he jut teps on the World of Life, and decribes that degree of it which is to be found in Vegetables. In the third he advances to Animals. And in the lat, ingles out the Bee, which may be reckon'd the mot agacious of 'em, for his Subject.

p.hi: In this Georgic he hews us what Station is mot proper for the Bees, and when they begin to gather Honey: how to call 'em home when they warm; and how to part 'em when they are engag'd in Battel. From hence he takes occaion to dicover their different Kinds; and, after an Excurion relates their prudent and politick Adminitration of Affairs and the everal Dieaes that often rage in their Hives, with the proper Symptoms and Remedies of each Dieae. In the lat place he lays down a method of repairing their Kind, uppoing their whole Breed lot; and gives at large the Hitory of its Invention.

lg.l: THE Gifts of Heav'n my foll'wing Song purues,
Aerial Honey, and Ambroial Dews.
Maecenas, read this other part, that ings
Fmbattel'd Sqadrons and advent'rous Kings:
A mighty Pomp, tho' made of little Things.
Their Arms, their Arts, their Manners I dicloe,
And how they War, and whence the People roe:
Slight is the Subject, but the Praie not mall,
If Heav'n ait, and Phoebus hear my Call.
Firt, for thy Bees a quiet Station find,
And lodge 'em under Covert of the Wind:
For Winds, when homeward they return, will drive
The loaded Carriers from their Ev'ning Hive.
Far from the Cows and Goats inulting Crew,
That trample down the Flow'rs, and bruh the Dew:
The painted Lizard, and the Birds of Prey,
Foes of the frugal Kind, be far away.

figure.p: To Richard Norton of Southwick in Hant-shire Esq.
figure.head: Geo 4: L 1

lg.l: The Titmoue, and the Peckers hungry Brood,
And Progne, with her Boom tain'd in Blood:
Thee rob the trading Citizens, and bear
The trembling Captives thro' the liquid Air;
And for their callow young a cruel Feat prepare.
But near a living Stream their Manion place,
Edg'd round with Mos, and tufts of matted Gras:
And plant (the Winds impetuous rage to top,)
Wild Olive Trees, or Palms, before the buiy Shop:
That when the youthful Prince, with loud allarm,
Calls out the vent'rous Colony to warm;
When firt their way thro' yielding Air they wing,
New to the Pleaures of their native Spring;
The Banks of Brooks may make a cool retreat
For the raw Souldiers from the calding Heat:
And neighb'ring Trees, with friendly Shade invite
The Troops unus'd to long laborious Flight.
Then o're the running Stream, or tanding Lake,
A Paage for thy weary People make;
With Oier Floats the tanding Water trow;
Of may Stones make Bridges, if it flow:
That basking in the Sun thy Bees may lye,
And reting there, their flaggy Pinions dry:
When late returning home, the laden Hot,
By raging Winds is wreck'd upon the Coat.
Wild Thyme and Sav'ry et around their Cell,
