Sweet to the Tate, and fragrant to the Smell:
Set rows of Roemary with flow'ring Stem,
And let the purple Vi'lets drink the Stream.
Whether thou build the Palace of thy Bees
With twited Oiers, or with Barks of Trees;
Make but a narrow Mouth: for as the Cold
Congeals into a Lump the liquid Gold;
So 'tis again diolv'd by Summer's heat,
And the weet Labours both Extreams defeat.
And therefore, not in vain, th' indutrious Kind
With dawby Wax and Flow'rs the Chinks have lin'd.
And, with their Stores of gather'd Glue, contrive
To top the Vents, and Crannies of their Hive.
Not Birdlime, or Idean Pitch produce
A more tenacious Mas of clammy Juice.
Nor Bees are lodg'd in Hives alone, but found
In Chambers of their own, beneath the Ground:
Their vaulted Roofs are hung in Pumices,
And in the rotten Trunks of hollow Trees.
But plaiter thou the chinky Hives with Clay,
And leafy Branches o're their Lodgings lay.
Nor place them where too deep a Water flows,
Or where the Yeugh their pois'nous Neighbour grows:
Nor rot red Crabs t' offend the nicenes of their Noe.
Nor near the teaming Stench of muddy Ground;
Nor hollow Rocks that render back the Sound,
And doubled Images of Voice rebound.
For what remains, when Golden Suns appear,
And under Earth have driv'n the Winter Year:
The winged Nation wanders thro' the Skies,
And o're the Plains, and hady Forret flies:
Then tooping on the Meads and leafy Bow'rs;
They skim the Floods, and ip the purple Flow'rs.
Exalted hence, and drunk with ecret Joy,
Their young Succeion all their Cares employ:
They breed, they brood, intruct and educate,
And make Proviion for the future State:
They work their waxen Lodgings in their Hives,
And labour Honey to utain their Lives.
But when thou eet a warming Cloud arie,
That weeps aloft, and darkens all the Skies:

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Sr. William Trumbull Kt. Principall Secretary of State & one of his Maities: Most Honble: Priry Councill.
figure.head: Geo: 4. l. 85.

lg.l: The Motions of their haty Flight attend;
And know to Floods, or Woods, their airy march they bend.
Then Melfoil beat, and Honey-uckles pound,
With thee alluring Savours trew the Ground;
And mix with tinkling Bras, the Cymbals droning Sound.
Streight to their ancient Cells, recall'd from Air,
The reconcil'd Deerters will repair.
But if intetine Broils allarm the Hive,
(For two Pretenders oft for Empire trive)
The Vulgar in divided Factions jar;
And murm'ring Sounds proclaim the Civil War.
Inflam'd with Ire, and trembling with Didain,
Scarce can their Limbs, their mighty Souls contain.
With Shouts, the Cowards Courage they excite,
And martial Clangors call 'em out to fight:
With hoare Allarms the hollow Camp rebounds,
That imitates the Trumpets angry Sounds:
Then to their common Standard they repair;
The nimble Horemen cour the Fields of Air.
In form of Battel drawn, they iue forth,
And ev'ry Knight is proud to prove his Worth.
Pret for their Country's Honour, and their King's,
On their harp Beaks they whet their pointed Stings;
And exercie their Arms, and tremble with their Wings.
Full in the midt, the haughty Monarchs ride,
The truty Guards come up, and cloe the Side;
With Shouts the daring Foe to Battel is defy'd.
Thus in the Seaon of unclouded Spring,
To War they follow their undaunted King:
Crowd thro'their Gates, and in the Fields of Light,
The hocking Squadrons meet in mortal Fight:
Headlong they fall from high, and wounded wound,
And heaps of laughter'd Souldiers bite the Ground.
Hard Hailtones lye not thicker on the Plain;
Nor haken Oaks uch Show'rs of Acorns rain.
With gorgeous Wings the Marks of Sov'raign way,
The two contending Princes make their way;
Intrepid thro' the midt of danger go;
Their friends encourage, and amaze the Foe.
With mighty Souls in narrow Bodies pret,
They challenge, and encounter Breat to Breat;
So fix'd on Fame, unknowing how to fly,
And obtinately bent to win or dye;
That long the doubtful Combat they maintain,
Till one prevails (for one can only Reign.)
Yet all thoe dreadful deeds, this deadly fray,
A cat of catter'd Dut will oon alay,
And undecided leave the Fortune of the day.
When both the Chiefs are und'red from the Fight,
Then to the lawful King retore his Right.
And let the watful Prodigal be lain,
That he, who bet deerves, alone may reign.
With eae ditinguih'd is the Regal Race,
One Monarch wears an honet open Face;
Large are his Limbs, and Godlike to behold,
His Royal Body hines with pecks of Gold,
And ruddy Skales; for Empire he deign'd,
Is better born, and of a Nobler Kind.
That other looks like Nature in digrace,
Gaunt are his ides, and ullen is his face:
And like their grizly Prince appears his gloomy Race:
Grim, ghatly, rugged, like a thirty train
That long have travel'd through a deart plain,
And pet from their dry Chaps the gather'd dut again.
The better Brood, unlike the Batard Crew,
Are mark'd with Royal treaks of hining hue;
Glitt'ring and ardent, though in Body les:
From thee at pointed Seaons hope to pres
Huge heavy Honey-Combs, of Golden Juice,
Not only weet, but pure, and fit for ue:
T'allay the Strength and Hardnes of the Wine,
And with old Bacchus, new Metheglin join.
But when the Swarms are eager of their play,
And loath their empty Hives, and idly tray,
Retrain the wanton Fugitives, and take
A timely Care to bring the Truants back.
The Task is eay: but to clip the Wings
Of their high-flying Arbitrary Kings:
At their Command, the People warm away;
Confine the Tyrant, and the Slaves will tay.
Sweet Gardens, full of Saffron Flow'rs, invite
The wandring Gluttons, and retard their Flight.
Beides, the God obcene, who frights away,
With his Lath Sword, the Thiefs and Birds of Prey.
With his own hand, the Guardian of the Bees,
For Slips of Pines, may earch the Mountain Trees:
And with wild Thyme and Sav'ry, plant the Plain,
'Till his hard horny Fingers ake with Pain:
And deck with fruitful Trees the Fields around,
And with refrehing Waters drench the Ground.
Now, did I not o near my Labours end,
Strike Sail, and hat'ning to the Harbour tend;
My Song to Flow'ry Gardens might extend.
To teach the vegetable Arts, to ing
The Paetan Roes, and their double Spring:
How Succ'ry drinks the running Streams, and how
Green Beds of Parley near the River grow;
How Cucumers along the Surface creep,
With crooked Bodies, and with Bellies deep.
The late Narcius, and the winding Trail
Of Bears-foot, Myrtles green, and Ivy pale.
For where with tately Tow'rs Tarentum tands,
And deep Galeus oaks the yellow Sands,
I chanc'd an Old Corycian Swain to know,
Lord of few Acres, and thoe barren too;
Unfit for Sheep or Vines, and more unfit to ow:
Yet lab'ring well his little Spot of Ground,
Some catt'ring Potherbs here and there he found:
Which cultivated with his daily Care,
And bruis'd with Vervain, were his frugal Fare.
Sometimes white Lyllies did their Leaves afford,
With wholom Poppy-flow'rs, to mend his homely Board:
For late returning home he up'd at eae,
And wiely deem'd the Wealth of Monarchs les:
The little of his own, becaue his own, did pleae.
To quit his Care, he gather'd firt of all
In Spring the Roes, Apples in the Fall:
And when cold Winter plit the Rocks in twain,
And Ice the running Rivers did retrain,
He trip'd the Bears-foot of its leafy growth;
And, calling Wetern Winds, accus'd the Spring of loath.
He therefore firt among the Swains was found,
To reap the Product of his labour'd Ground,
And queee the Combs with Golden Liquor Crown'd.
His Limes were firt in Flow'rs, his lofty Pines,
With friendly Shade, ecur'd his tender Vines.
For ev'ry Bloom his Trees in Spring afford,
An Autumn Apple was by tale retor'd.
He knew to rank his Elms in even rows;
For Fruit the grafted Peartree to dipoe:
And tame to Plums, the ournes of the Sloes.
With preading Planes he made a cool retreat,
To hade good Fellows from the Summer's heat.
But treighten'd in my pace, I mut forake
This Task; for others afterwards to take.
Decribe we next the Nature of the Bees,
betow'd by Jove for ecret Services:
When by the tinkling Sound of Timbrels led,
The King of Heav'n in Cretan Caves they fed.
Of all the Race of Animals, alone
The Bees have common Cities of their own:
And common Sons, beneath one Law they live,
And with one common Stock their Traffick drive.
Each has a certain home, a ev'ral Stall:
All is the States, the State provides for all.
Mindful of coming Cold, they hare the Pain:
And hoard, for Winter's ue, the Summer's gain.
Some o're the Publick Magazines preide,
And ome are ent new Forrage to provide:
Thee drudge in Fields abroad, and thoe at home
Lay deep Foundations for the labour'd Comb,
With dew, Narcius Leaves, and clammy Gum.
To pitch the waxen Flooring ome contrive:
Some nure the future Nation of the Hive:
Sweet Honey ome condene, ome purge the Grout;
The ret, in Cells apart, the liquid Nectar hut.
All, with united Force, combine to drive
The lazy Drones from the laborious Hive.
With Envy tung, they view each others Deeds:
With Diligence the fragrant Work proceeds.
As when the Cyclops, at th' Almighty Nod,
New Thunder haten for their angry God:
Subdu'd in Fire the Stubborn Mettal lyes,
One brawny Smith the puffing Bellows plyes;
And draws, and blows reciprocating Air:
Others to quench the hiing Mas prepare:
With lifted Arms they order ev'ry Blow,
And chime their ounding Hammers in a Row;
With trokes of Anvils Aetna groans below.
Strongly they trike, huge Flakes of Flames expire,
With Tongs they turn the Steel, and vex it in the Fire.
If little things with great we may compare,
Such are the Bees, and uch their native Care:
Studious of Honey, each in his Degree,
The youthful Swain, the grave experienc'd Bee:
That in the Field; this in Affairs of State,
Employ'd at home, abides within the Gate:
To fortify the Combs, to build the Wall,
To prop the Ruins let the Fabrick fall:
But late at Night, with weary Pinions come
The labr'ring Youth, and heavy laden home.
Plains, Meads, and Orchards all the day he plies,
The gleans of yellow Thime ditend his Thighs:
He poils the Saffron Flow'rs, he ips the blues
Of Vi'lets, wilding Blooms, and Willow Dews.
Their Toyl is common, common is their Sleep;
They hake their Wings when Morn begins to peep;
Ruh through the City Gates without delay,
Nor ends their Work, but with declining Day:
Then having pent the lat remains of Light,
They give thir Bodies due repoe at Night:
When hollow Murmurs of their Ev'ning Bells,
Dimis the leepy Swains, and toll 'em to their Cells.
When once in Beds their weary Limbs they teep,
No buzzing Sounds diturb thir Golden Sleep.
'Tis acred Silence all. Nor dare they tray,
When Rain is promis'd, or a tormy Day:
But near the City Walls their Watring take,
Nor Forrage far, but hort Excurions make.
And as when empty Barks on Billows float,
With andy Ballat Sailors trim the Boat;
So Bees bear Gravel Stones, whoe poiing Weight
Steers thro' the whitling Winds their teddy Flight.
But what's more trange, their modet Appetites,
Avere from Venus, fly the nuptial Rites.
No lut enervates their Heroic Mind,
Nor wats their Strength on wanton Woman-Kind.
But in their Mouths reide their Genial Pow'rs,
They gather Children from the Leaves and Flow'rs.
Thus make they Kings to fill the Regal Seat;
And thus their little Citizens create:
And waxen Cities build, and Palaces of State.
And oft on Rocks their tender Wings they tear,
And ink beneath the Burthens which they bear.
Such Rage of Honey in their Boom beats:
And uch a Zeal they have for flow'ry Sweets.
Thus tho' the race of Life they quickly run;
Which in the pace of even hort Years is done,
Th' immortal Line in fure Succeion reigns,
The Fortune of the Family remains:
And Grandires Grandons the long Lit contains.
Beides, not Egypt, India, Media more
With ervile Awe, their Idol King adore:
While he urvives, in Concord and Content
The Commons live, by no Diviions rent;
But the great Monarch's Death diolves the Government.
All goes to Ruin, they themelves contrive
To rob the Honey, and ubvert the Hive.
The King preides, his Subjects Toil urveys;
The ervile Rout their careful Caear praie:
Him they extol, they worhip him alone,
They crowd his Levees, and upport his Throne:
They raie him on their houlders with a Shout:
And when their Sov'raigns Quarrel calls 'em out,
His Foes to mortal Combat they defy,
And think it honour at his feet to die.
Induc'd by uch Examples, ome have taught
That Bees have Portions of Etherial Thought:
Endu'd with Particles of Heavenly Fires:
For God the whole created Mas inpires;
Thro' Heav'n, and Earth, and Oceans depth he throws
His Influence round, and kindles as he goes.
Hence Flocks, and Herds, and Men, and Beats, and Fowls
With Breath are quicken'd; and attract their Souls.
Hence take the Forms his Precience did ordain,
And into him at length reolve again.
No room is left for Death, they mount the Sky,
And to their own congenial Planets fly.
Now when thou hat decreed to eize their Stores,
And by Prerogative to break their Doors:
With prinkl'd Water firt the City choak,
And then purue the Citizens with Smoak.
Two Honey Harvets fall in ev'ry Year:
Firt, when the pleaing Pleiades appear,
And pringing upward purn the briny Seas:
Again, when their affrighted Quire urveys
The watry Scorpion mend his Pace behind,
With a black Train of Storms, and winter Wind;
They plunge into the Deep, and afe Protection find.
Prone to Revenge, the Bees, a wrathful Race,
When once provok'd aault th' Agreor's Face:
And through the purple Veins a paage find;
There fix their Stings, and leave their Souls behind.
But if a pinching Winter thou foreee,
And woud't preerve thy famih'd Family;
With fragant Thyme the City fumigate,
And break the waxen Walls to ave the State.
For lurking Lizards often lodge, by Stealth,
Within the Suburbs, and purloyn their Wealth.
And Worms that hun the Light, a dark Retreat
Have found in Combs, and undermin'd the Seat.
Or lazy Drones, without their Share of Pain;
In Winter Quarters free, devour the Gain:
Or Waps infet the Camp with loud Alarms,
And mix in Battel with unequal Arms:
Or ecret Moaths are there in Silence fed;
Or Spiders in the Vault, their nary Webs have pred.
The more oppres'd by Foes, or Famine pin'd;
The more increae thy Care to ave the inking Kind.
With Greens and Flow'rs recruit their empty Hives,
And eek freh Forrage to utain their Lives.
But ince they hare with us one common Fate,
In Health and Sicknes, and in Turns of State;
Oberve the Symptoms when they fall away,
And languih with inenible Decay.
They change their Hue, with hagger'd Eyes they tare,
Lean are their Looks, and hagged is their Hair:
And Crowds of dead, that never mut return
To their lov'd Hives, in decent Pomp are born:
Their Friends attend the Here, the next Relations Mourn.
The ick, for Air before the Portal gap,
Their feeble Legs within each other clap.
Or idle in their empty Hives remain,
Benum'd with Cold, and litles of their Gain.
Soft Whipers then, and broken Sounds are heard,
As when the Woods by gentle Winds are tir'd.
Such tifled noie as the cloe Furnace hides,
Or dying Murmurs of departing Tides.
This when thou eet, Galbanean Odours ue,
And Honey in the ickly Hive infue.
Thro' reeden Pipes convey the Golden Flood,
T' invite the People to their wonted Food.
Mix it with thicken'd Juice of odden Wines,
And Raiins from the Grapes of Pythian Vines:
To thee add pounded Galls, and Roes dry,
And with Cecropian Thyme, trong cented Centaury.
A Flow'r there is that grows in Meadow Ground,
Amellus call'd, and eay to be found;
For from one Root the riing Stem betows
A Wood of Leaves, and vi'let-purple Boughs:
The Flow'r it elf is glorious to behold,
And hines on Altars like refulgent Gold:
Sharp to the Tate, by Shepherds near the Stream
Of Mella found, and thence they gave the Name.
Boyl this retoring Root in gen'rous Wine,
And et beide the Door, the ickly Stock to dine.
But if the lab'ring Kind be wholly lot,
And not to be retriev'd with Care or Cot;
'Tis time to touch the Precepts of an Art,
Th' Arcadian Mater did of old impart:
And how he tock'd his empty Hives again;
Renew'd with putrid Gore of Oxen lain.
An ancient Legend I prepare to ing,
And upward follow Fame's immortal Spring.
For where with ev'n-fold Horns myterious Nile
Surrounds the Skirts of Egypt's fruitful Ile,
And where in Pomp the Sun-burnt People ride
On painted Barges, o're the teeming Tide,
Which pouring down from Ethiopian Lands,
Makes green the Soyl with Slime, and black prolific Sands;
That length of Region, and large Tract of Ground,
In this one Art a ure relief have found.
Firt, in a place, by Nature clos, they build
A narrow Flooring, gutter'd, wall'd, and til'd.
In this, four Windows are contriv'd, that trike
To the four Winds oppos'd, their Beams oblique.
A Steer of two Years old they take, whoe Head
Now firt with burnih'd Horns begins to pread:
They top his Notrils, while he trives in vain
To breath free Air, and truggles with his Pain.
Knock'd down, he dyes: his Bowels bruis'd within,
Betray no Wound on his unbroken Skin.
Extended thus, in this obcene Abode,
They leave the Beat; but firt weet Flow'rs are trow'd
Beneath his Body, broken Boughs and Thyme,
And pleaing Caia jut renew'd in prime.
This mut be done, e're Spring makes equal Day,
When Wetern Winds on curling Waters play:
E're painted Meads produce their Flow'ry Crops,
Or Swallows twitter on the Chimney Tops.
The tainted Blood, in this cloe Prion pent,
Begins to boyl and through the Bones ferment.
Then, wondrous to behold, new Creatures rie,
A moving Mas at firt, and hort of Thighs;
'Till hooting out with Legs, and imp'd with Wings,
The Grubs proceed to Bees with pointed Stings:
And more and more affecting Air, they try
Their tender Pinions, and begin to fly:
At length, like Summer Storms from preading Clouds,
That burt at once, and pour impetuous Floods;
Or Flights of Arrows from the Parthian Bows,
When from afar they gaul embattel'd Foes;
With uch a Tempet thro' the Skies they Steer;
And uch a form the winged Squadrons bear.
What God, O Mue! this ueful Science taught?
Or by what Man's Experience was it brought?
Sad Aritaeus from fair Tempe fled,
His Bees with Famine, or Dieaes dead:
On Peneus's Banks he tood, and near his holy Head.
And while his falling Tears the Stream upply'd,
Thus mourning, to his Mother Goddes cry'd.
Mother Cyrene, Mother, whoe abode
Is in the depth of this immortal Flood:
What boots it, that from Phoebus's Loyns I pring,
The third by him and thee, from Heav'ns high King?
O! Where is all thy boated Pity gone,
And Promie of the Skies to thy deluded Son?
Why didt thou me, unhappy me, create?
Odious to Gods, and born to bitter Fate.
Whom carce my Sheep, and carce my painful Plough,
The needul Aids of Human Life allow;
So wretched is thy Son, o hard a Mother thou.
Proceed, inhuman Parent in thy Scorn;
Root up my Trees, with Blites detroy my Corn;
My Vineyards Ruin, and my Sheepfolds burn.
Let looe thy Rage, let all thy Spite be hown,
Since thus thou hat't the Praies of thy Son.
But from her Moy Bow'r below the Ground,
His careful Mother heard the Plaintive ound;
Encompas'd with her Sea-green Siters round.
One common Work they ply'd: their Ditaffs full
With carded Locks of blue Mileian Wool.
Spio with Drymo brown, and Xanthe fair,
And weet Phyllodoce with long dihevel'd Hair:
Cydippe with Licorias, one a Maid,
And one that once had call'd Lucina's Aid.
Clio and Beroe, from one Father both,
Both girt with Gold, and clad in particolour'd Cloth.
Opis the meek, and Deiopeia proud;

l.U: oftly, with Ligaea loud;

lg.l: Thalia joyous, Ephyre the ad,
And Arethua once Diana's Maid,
But now, her Quiver left, to Love betray'd.
To thee, Climene the weet Theft declares,
Of Mars and Vulcans unavailing Cares:
And all the Rapes of Gods, and ev'ry Love,
From antient Chaos down to youthful Jove.
Thus while he ings, the Siters turn the Wheel,
Empty the wooly Rock, and fill the Reel.
A mournful Sound, agen the Mother hears;
Agen the mournful Sound invades the Siter's Ears:
Starting at once from their green Seats, they rie;
Fear in their Heart, Amazement in their Eyes.
But Arethua leaping from her Bed,
Firt lifts above the Waves her beauteous Head;
And, crying from afar, thus to Cyrene aid.
O Siter! not with caueles Fear poet,
No Stranger Voice diturbs thy tender Breat.
'Tis Ariteus, 'tis thy darling Son,
Who to his careles Mother makes his Moan.
Near his Paternal Stream he adly tands,
With down-cat Eyes, wet Cheeks, and folded Hands:
Upbraiding Heav'n from whence his Lineage came,
And cruel calls the Gods, and cruel thee, by Name.
Cyrene mov'd with Love, and eiz'd with Fear,
Cries out, conduct my Son, conduct him here:
'Tis lawful for the Youth, deriv'd from Gods,
To view the Secrets of our deep Abodes.
At once he wav'd her Hand on either ide,
At once the Ranks of welling Streams divide.
Two riing Heaps of liquid Crytal tand,
And leave a Space betwixt, of empty Sand.
Thus afe receiv'd, the downward track he treads,
Which to his Mother's watry Palace leads.
With wond'ring Eyes he views the ecret Store
Of Lakes, that pent in hollow Caverns, roar.
He hears the crackling Sound of Coral Woods,
And ees the ecret Source of ubterranean Floods.
And where, ditinguih'd in their ev'ral Cells,
The Fount of Phais; and of Lycus dwells;
Where wift Enipeus in his Bed appears,
And Tiber his Majetick Forehead rears.
Whence Anio flows, and Hypanis, profound,
Breaks through th' oppoing Rocks with raging Sound.
Where Po firt iues from his dark abodes,
And, awful in his Cradle, rules the Floods.
Two Golden Horns on his large Front he wears,
And his grim Face a Bull's Reemblance bears.
With rapid Coure he eeks the acred Main,
And fattens, as he runs, the fruitful Plain.
Now to the Court arriv'd, th' admiring Son
Beholds the vaulted Roofs of Pory Stone;
Now to his Mother Goddes tells his Grief,
Which he with Pity hears, and promies Relief.
Th' officious Nymphs, attending in a Ring,
With Waters drawn from their perpetual Spring,
From earthly dregs his Body purify,
And rub his Temples, with fine Towels, dry:
Then load the Tables with a lib'ral Feat,
And honour with full Bowls their friendly Guet.
The acred Altars are involv'd in Smoak,
And the bright Quire their kindred Gods invoke.

figure.p: To Sr Bartholomen Shower of the Midle Temple. Knt.
figure.head: Go: 4. l. 535.

lg.l: Two Bowls the Mother fills with Lydian Wine;
Then thus, Let thee be pour'd, with Rites divine,
To the great Authors of our wat'ry Line.
To Father Ocean, this; and this, he aid,
Be to the Nymphs his acred Siters paid,
Who rule the wat'ry Plains, and hold the woodland Shade.
She prinkl'd thrice, with Wine, the Vetal Fire,
Thrice to the vaulted Roof the Flames apire.
Rais'd with o blet an Omen, he begun,
With Words like thee, to chear her drooping Son.
In the Carpathian Bottom makes abode
The Shepherd of the Seas, a Prophet and a God;
High o're the Main in wat'ry Pomp he rides,
His azure Carr and finny Courers guides:
Proteus his Name: to his Pallenian Port,
I ee from far the weary God reort.
Him, not alone, we River Gods adore,
But aged Nereus hearkens to his Lore.
With ure foreight, and with unerring Doom,
He ees what is, and was, and is to come.
This Neptune gave him, when he gave to keep
His caly Flocks, that graze the wat'ry deep.
Implore his Aid, for Proteus onely knows
The ecret Caue, and Cure of all thy Woes.
But firt the wily Wizard mut be caught,
For uncontrain'd he nothing tells for naught;
Nor is with Pray'rs, or Bribes, or Flatt'ry bought.
Surprie him firt, and with hard Fetters bind;
Then all his Frauds will vanih into Wind.
I will my elf conduct thee on thy Way,
When next the Southing Sun inflames the Day:
When the dry Herbage thirts for Dews in vain,
And Sheep, in Shades, avoid the parching Plain.
Then will I lead thee to his ecret Seat;
When weary with his Toyl, and corch'd with Heat,
The wayward Sire frequents his cool Retreat.
His Eyes with heavy Slumber overcat;
With Force invade his Limbs, and bind him fat:
Thus urely bound, yet be not over bold,
The lipp'ry God will try to looe his hold:
And various Forms aume, to cheat thy ight;
And with vain Images of Beats affright.
With foamy Tusks he eems a britly Boar,
Or imitates the Lion's angry Roar;
Breaks out in crackling Flames to hun thy Snares,
A Dragon hies, or a Tyger tares:
Or with a Wile, thy Caution to betray,
In fleeting Streams attempts to lide away.
But thou, the more he varies Forms, beware
To train his Fetters with a tricter Care:
'Till tiring all his Arts, he turns agen
To his true Shape, in which he firt was een.
This aid, with Nectar he her Son anoints;
Infuing Vigour through his mortal Joynts:
Down from his Head the liquid Odours ran;
He breath'd of Heav'n, and look'd above a Man.
Within a Mountain's hollow Womb, there lies
A large Reces, conceal'd from Human Eyes;
Where heaps of Billows, driv'n by Wind and Tide,
In Form of War, their wat'ry Ranks divide;
And there, like Centries et, without the Mouth abide:
A Station afe for Ships, when Tempets roar,
A ilent Harbour, and a cover'd Shoar.
Secure within reides the various God,
And draws a Rock upon his dark Abode.

figure.p: To Simon Harcourt of Stanton Harcourt in the County of Oxon Esq..
figure.head: Geo 4: L: 635.

lg.l: Hether with ilent Steps, ecure from Sight,
The Goddes guides her Son, and turns him from the Light:
Her elf, involv'd in Clouds, precipitates her Flight.
'Twas Noon; the ultry Dog-tar from the Sky
Scorch'd Indian Swains, the rivell'd Gras was dry;
The Sun with flaming Arrows pierc'd the Flood,
And, darting to the bottom, bak'd the Mud:
When weary Proteus, from the briny Waves,
Retir'd for Shelter to his wonted Caves:
His finny Flocks about their Shepherd play,
And rowling round him, pirt the bitter Sea.
Unweildily they wallow firt in Ooze,
Then in the hady Covert eek Repoe.
Himelf their Herdman, on the middle Mount,
Takes of his muter'd Flocks a jut Account.
So, eated on a Rock, a Shepherd's Groom
Surveys his Ev'ning Flocks returning Home:
When lowing Calves, and bleating Lambs, from far,
Provoke the prouling Wolf to nightly War.
Th' Occaion offers, and the Youth complies:
For carce the weary God had clos'd his Eyes;
When ruhing on, with houts, he binds in Chains
The drowzy Prophet, and his Limbs contrains.
He, not unmindful of his uual Art,
Firt in diembled Fire attempts to part:
Then roaring Beats, and running Streams he tryes,
And wearies all his Miracles of Lies:
But having hifted ev'ry Form to cape,
Convinc'd of Conquet, he reum'd his hape:
And thus, at length, in human Accent poke
Audacious Youth, what madnes cou'd provoke
A Mortal Man t' invade a leeping God?
What Buis'nes brought thee to my dark abode?
To this, th' audacious Youth; Thou know't full well
My Name, and Buis'nes, God, nor need I tell:
No Man can Proteus cheat; but Proteus leave
Thy fraudful Arts, and do not thou deceive.
Foll'wing the Gods Command, I come t'implore
Thy Help, my perih'd People to retore.
The Seer, who could not yet his Wrath awage,
Rowl'd his green Eyes, that parkl'd with his Rage;
And gnah'd his Teeth, and cry'd, No vulgar God
Purues thy Crimes, nor with a Common Rod.
Thy great Mideeds have met a due Reward,
And Orpheus's dying Pray'rs at length are heard.
For Crimes, not his, the Lover lot his Life,
And at thy Hands requires his murther'd Wife:
Nor (if the Fates ait not) cant thou cape
The jut Revenge of that intended Rape.
To hun thy lawles Lut, the dying Bride,
Unwary, took along the River's ide:
Nor, at her Heels perceiv'd the deadly Snake,
That kept the Bank, in Covert of the Brake.
But all her fellow Nymphs the Mountains tear
With loud Laments, and break the yielding Air:
The Realms of Mars remurmur'd all around,
And Echoes to th' Athenian Shoars rebound.
Th' unhappy Husband, Husband now no more,
Did on his tuneful Harp his Los deplore,
And ought, his mournful Mind with Muick to retore.
On thee, dear Wife, in Dearts all alone,
He call'd, igh'd, ung, his Griefs with Day begun,
Nor were they finih'd with the etting Sun.
Ev'n to the dark Dominions of the Night,
He took his way, thro' Forrets void of Light:
And dar'd amidt the trembling Ghots to ing,
And tood before th' inexorable King.
Th' Infernal Troops like paing Shadows glide,
And, lit'ning, crowd the weet Muician's ide.
Not flocks of Birds when driv'n by Storms, or Night,
Stretch to the Foret with o thick a flight.
Men, Matrons, Children, and th' unmarry'd Maid,
This whole Line is taken from the Marques of Normanby's Tranlation. The mighty Heroes more Majetic hade;
And Youths on Fun'ral Piles before their Parents laid.
All thee Cocytus bounds with qualid Reeds,
With Muddy Ditches, and with deadly Weeds:
And baleful Styx encompaes around,
With Nine low circling Streams, th' unhappy ground.
Ev'n from the depths of Hell the Damn'd advance,
Th' Infernal Manions nodding eem to dance;
The gaping three-mouth'd Dog forgets to narl,
The Furies harken, and their Snakes uncurl:

l.U: eems no more his Pains to feel,

lg.l: But leans attentive on his tanding Wheel.
All Dangers pat, at length the lovely Bride,
In afety goes, with her Melodious Guide;
Longing the common Light again to hare,
And draw the vital breath of upper Air:
He firt, and cloe behind him follow'd he,
For uch was Proerpine's evere Decree.
When trong Deires th' impatient Youth invade;
By little Caution and much love betray'd:
A fault which eay Pardon might receive,
Were Lovers Judges, or cou'd Hell forgive.
For near the Confines of Etherial Light,
And longing for the glimm'ring of a ight,
Th' unwary Lover cat his Eyes behind,
Forgetful of the Law, nor Mater of his Mind.
Straight all his Hopes exhal'd in empty Smoke;
And his long Toils were forfeit for a Look.
Three flahes of blue Light'ning gave the ign
Of Cov'nants broke, three peals of Thunder joyn.
Then thus the Bride; What fury eiz'd on thee,
Unhappy Man! to loe thy elf and Me?
Dragg'd back again by cruel Detinies,
An Iron Slumber huts my wimming Eyes.
And now farewel, involv'd in Shades of Night,
For ever I am ravih'd from thy ight.
In vain I reach my feeble hands, to joyn
In weet Embraces; ah! no longer thine!
She aid, and from his Eyes the fleeting Fair
Retir'd like ubtile Smoke diolv'd in Air;
And left her hopeles Lover in depair.
In vain, with folding Arms, the Youth aay'd
To top her flight, and train the flying Shade:
He prays, he raves, all Means in vain he tries,
With rage inflam'd, atonih'd with urprie;
But he return'd no more, to bles his longing Eyes.
Nor wou'd th' Infernal Ferry-Man once more
Be brib'd, to waft him to the farther hore.
What hou'd He do, who twice had lot his Love?
What Notes invent, what new Petitions move?
Her Soul already was conign'd to Fate,
And hiv'ring in the leaky Sculler ate.
For even continu'd Months, if Fame ay true,
The wretched Swain his Sorrows did renew;
By Strymon's freezing Streams he ate alone,
The Rocks were mov'd to pity with his moan:
Trees bent their heads to hear him ing his Wrongs,
Fierce Tygers couch'd around, and loll'd their fawning Tongues.
So, cloe in Poplar Shades, her Children gone,
The Mother Nightingale laments alone:
Whoe Net ome prying Churl had found, and thence,
By Stealth, convey'd th' unfeather'd Innocence.
But he upplies the Night with mournful Strains,
With one continu'd Tenor till complains;
Which fills the Forret, and the neighb'ring Plains.
Sad Orpheus thus his tedious Hours employs,
Avere from Venus, and from nuptial Joys.
Alone he tempts the frozen Floods, alone
Th' unhappy Climes, where Spring was never known:
He mourn'd his wretched Wife, in vain retor'd,
And Pluto's unavailing Boon deplor'd.
The Thracian Matrons, who the Youth accus'd,
Of Love didain'd, and Marriage Rites refus'd:
With Furies, and Nocturnal Orgies fir'd,
At length, againt his acred Life conpir'd.
Whom ev'n the alvage Beats had par'd, they kill'd,
And trew'd his mangl'd Limbs about the Field.
Then, when his Head, from his fair Shoulders torn,
Wah'd by the Waters, was on Hebrus born;
Ev'n then his trembling Tongue invok'd his Bride;
With his lat Voice, Eurydice, he cry'd,
Eurydice, the Rocks and River-banks reply'd.
This anwer Proteus gave, nor more he aid,
But in the Billows plung'd his hoary Head;
And where he leap'd, the Waves in Circles widely pread.
The Nymph return'd, her drooping Son to chear,
And bade him banih his uperfluous fear:
For now, aid he, the Caue is known, from whence
Thy Woe ucceeded, and for what Offence:
The Nymphs, Companions of th'unhappy Maid,
This punihment upon thy Crimes have laid;
And ent a Plague among thy thriving Bees.
With Vows and uppliant Pray'rs their Pow'rs appeae:
The oft Napaean Race will oon repent
Their Anger, and remit the Punihment.
The ecret in an eay Method lies;
Select four Brawny Bulls for Sacrifice,
Which on Lycaeus graze, without a Guide;
Add four fair Heifars yet in Yoke untry'd:
For thee, four Altars in their Temple rear,
And then adore the Woodland Pow'rs with Pray'r.
From the lain Victims pour the treaming Blood,
And leave their Bodies in the hady Wood:
Nine Mornings thence, Lethean Poppy bring,
T' appeae the Manes of the Poets King:
And to propitiate his offended Bride,
A fatted Calf, and a black Ewe provide:
This finih'd, to the former Woods repair.
His Mother's Precepts he performs with care;
The Temple viits, and adores with Pray'r.
Four Altars raies, from his Herd he culls,
For Slaughter, four the fairet of his Bulls;
Four Heifars from his Female Store he took,
All fair, and all unknowing of the Yoke.
Nine Mornings thence, with Sacrifice and Pray'rs,
The Pow'rs aton'd, he to the Grove repairs.
Behold a Prodigy! for from within
The broken Bowels, and the bloated Skin,
A buzzing noie of Bees their Ears alarms,
Straight iue through the Sides aembling Swarms:
Dark as a Cloud they make a wheeling Flight,
Then on a neighb'ring Tree, decending, light:
Like a large Cluter of black Grapes they how,
And make a large dependance from the Bough.

figure.p: To the Honble: John Granville econd Son to John EARL of BATH one of the Com•s: appointed by Act of Parliamt: for Examining Taking & Stating the Publick Accounts of the Kingdome.
figure.head: Geor: 4: l. 795.

lg.l: Thus have I ung of Fields, and Flocks, and Trees,
And of the waxen Work of lab'ring Bees;
While mighty Caear, thund'ring from afar,
Seeks on Euphrates Banks the Spoils of War:
With conq'ring Arms aerts his Country's Caue,
With Arts of Peace the willing People draws:
On the glad Earth the Golden Age renews,
And his great Father's Path to Heav'n purues.
While I at Naples pas my peaceful Days,
Affecting Studies of les noiy Praie;
And bold, through Youth, beneath the Beechen Shade,
The Lays of Shepherds, and their Loves have plaid.

div.head: TO THE MOST HONOURABLE John, Lord Marques of Normanby, EARL of MULGRAVE, &c. AND Knight of the Mot Noble Order of the Garter.
div.p:
A HEROICK Poem, truly uch, is undoubtedly the greatet Work which the Soul of Man is capable to perform. The Deign of it, is to form the Mind to Heroick Virtue by Example; 'tis convey'd in Vere, that it may delight, while it intructs: The Action of it is always one, entire, and great. The leat and mot trivial Epiodes, or under-Actions, which are interwoven in it, are parts either neceary, or convenient to carry on the main Deign. Either o neceary, that without them the Poem mut be Imperfect, or o convenient, that no others can be imagin'd more uitable to the place in which they are. There is nothing to be left void in a firm Building; even the Cavities ought not to be fill'd with Rubbih, which is of a perihable kind, detructive to the trength: But with Brick or Stone, though of les pieces, yet of the ame Nature, and fitted to the Cranies. Even the leat portions of them mut be of the Epick kind; all things mut be Grave, Majetical, and Sublime: Nothing of a Foreign Nature, like the trifling Novels, which Aritotle and others have inerted in their Poems. By which the Reader is mis-led into another ort of Pleaure, oppoite to that which is deign'd in an Epick Poem. One raies the Soul and hardens it to Virtue, the other oftens it again and unbends it into Vice. One conduces to the Poet's aim, the compleating of his Work; which he is driving on, labouring and hat'ning in every Line: the other lackens his pace, diverts him from his Way, and locks him up like a Knight Errant in an Enchanted Catle, when he hould be puruing his firt Adventure. Statius, as Bou has well oberv'd, was ambitious of trying his trength with his Mater Virgil, as Virgil had before try'd his with Homer. The Grecian gave the two Romans an Example, in the Games which were Celebrated at the Funerals of Patroclus. Virgil imitated the Invention of Homer, but chang'd the Sports. But both the Greek and Latin Poet, took their occaions from the Subject; though to confes the Truth, they were both Ornamental, or at bet, convenient parts of it, rather than of neceity ariing
from it. Statius, who through his whole Poem, is noted for want of Conduct and Judgment; intead of taying, as he might have done, for the Death of Capaneus, Hippomedon, Tideus, or ome other of his Seven Champions, (who are Heroes all alike) or more properly for the Tragical end of the two Brothers, whoe Exequies the next Succeor had leiure to perform, when the Siege was rais'd, and in the Interval betwixt the Poets firt Action, and his econd; went out of his way, as it were on propene Malice to commit a Fault. For he took his opportunity to kill a Royal Infant, by the means of a Serpent, (that Author of all Evil) to make way for thoe Funeral Honours, which he intended for him. Now if this Innocent had been of any Relation to his Thebais; if he had either farther'd or hinder'd the taking of the Town, the Poet might have found ome orry Excue at leat, for detaining the Reader from the promis'd Siege. I can think of nothing to plead for him, but what I verily believe he thought himelf; which was, that as the Funerals of Anchies were olemniz'd in Sicily, o thoe of Archemorus hould be celebrated in Candy. For the lat was an Iland; and a better than the firt, becaue Jove was Born there. On thee terms, this Capaneus of a Poet ingag'd his two Immortal Predeceours, and his Succes was anwerable to his Enterprie.

If this Oeconomy mut be oberv'd in the minutet Parts of an Epick Poem, which, to a common Reader, eem to be detach'd from the Body, and almot independent of it; what Soul, tho' ent into the World with great advantages of Nature, cultivated with the liberal Arts and Sciences; converant with Hitories of the Dead, and enrich'd with Obervations on the Living, can be ufficient to inform the whole Body of o great a Work? I touch here but traniently, without any trict Method, on ome few of thoe many Rules of imitating Nature, which Aritotle drew from Homer's Iliads and Odyes, and which he fitted to the Drama; furnihing himelf alo with Obervations from the Practice of the Theater, when it flourih'd under Aechilus, Eurypides, and Sophocles. For the Original of the Stage was from the Epick Poem. Narration, doubtles, preceded Acting, and gave Laws to it: What at firt was told Artfully, was, in proces of time, repreented gracefully to the ight, and hearing. Thoe Epiodes of Homer, which were proper for the Stage, the Poets amplify'd each into an Action: Out of his Limbs they form'd their Bodies: What he had Contracted they Enlarg'd: Out of one Hercules were made infinite of Pigmies; yet all endued with humane Souls: For from him, their great Creator, they have each of them the Divinae particulam Aurae. They flow'd from him at firt, and are at lat reolv'd into him. Nor were they only animated by him, but their Meaure and Symetry was owing to him. His one, entire, and great Action was Copied by them according to the proportions of the Drama: If he finih'd his Orb within the Year, it uffic'd to teach them, that their Action being les, and being alo les diverify'd with Incidents, their Orb, of conequence, mut be circumcrib'd in a les compas, which they reduc'd, within the limits either of a Natural or an Artificial Day. So that as he taught them to amplifie what he had horten'd, by the ame Rule apply'd the contrary way, he taught them to horten what he had amplifi'd. Tragedy is the minature of Humane Life; an Epick Poem is the draught at length. Here, my Lord, I mut contract alo, for, before I was aware, I was almot running into a long digreion, to prove that there is no uch abolute neceity that the
time of a Stage-Action hou'd o trictly be confin'd to Twenty Four Hours, as never to exceed them, for which Aritotle contends, and the Grecian Stage has practis'd. Some longer pace, on ome occaions, I think may be allow'd, epecially for the Englih Theater, which requires more variety of Incidents than the French. Corneille himelf, after long Practice, was inclin'd to think, that the time allotted by the Ancients was too hort to raie and finih a great Action: And better a Mechanick Rule were tretch'd or broken, than a great Beauty were omitted. To raie, and afterwards to calm the Paions, to purge the Soul from Pride, by the Examples of Humane Mieries, which befall the greatet; in few words, to expel Arrogance, and introduce Compaion, are the great effects of Tragedy. Great, I mut confes, if they were altogether as true as they are pompous. But are Habits to be introduc'd at three Hours warning? Are radical Dieaes o uddenly remov'd? A Mountebank may promie uch a Cure, but a skilful Phyician will not undertake it. An Epick Poem is not in o much hate; it works leiurely; the Changes which it makes are low; but the Cure is likely to be more perfect. The effects of Tragedy, as I aid, are too violent to be lating. If it be anwer'd that for this Reaon Tragedies are often to be een, and the Doe to be repeated; this is tacitely to confes, that there is more Virtue in one Heroick Poem than in many Tragedies. A Man is humbled one Day, and his Pride returns the next. Chymical Medicines are oberv'd to Relieve oft'ner than to Cure: For 'tis the nature of Spirits to make wift impreions, but not deep. Galenical Decoctions, to which I may properly compare an Epick Poem, have more of Body in them; they work by their ubtance and their weight. It is one Reaon of Aritotle's to prove, that Tragedy is the more Noble, becaue it turns in a horter Compas; the whole Action being circumcrib'd within the pace of Four-and-Twenty Hours. He might prove as well that a Muhroom is to be preferr'd before a Peach, becaue it hoots up in the compas of a Night. A Chariot may be driven round the Pillar in les pace than a large Machine, becaue the Bulk is not o great: Is the Moon a more Noble Planet than Saturn, becaue he makes her Revolution in les than Thirty Days, and He in little les than Thirty Years? Both their Orbs are in proportion to their everal Magnitudes; and, conequently, the quicknes or lownes of their Motion, and the time of their circumvolutions, is no Argument of the greater or les Perfection. And beides, what Virtue is there in a Tragedy, which is not contain'd in an Epick Poem? Where Pride is humbled, Vertue rewarded, and Vice punih'd; and thoe more amply treated, than the narrownes of the Drama can admit? The hining Qualitiy of an Epick Heroe, his Magnanimity, his Contancy, his Patience, his Piety, or whatever Characteritical Virtue his Poet gives him, raies firt our Admiration: We are naturally prone to imitate what we admire: And frequent Acts produce a habit. If the Hero's chief quality be vicious, as for Example, the Choler and obtinate deire of Vengeance in Achilles, yet the Moral is Intructive: And beides, we are inform'd in the very propoition of the Iliads, that this anger was pernicious: That it brought a thouand ills on the Grecian Camp. The Courage of Achilles is propos'd to imitation, not his Pride and Diobedience to his General, nor his brutal Cruelty to his dead Enemy, nor the elling his Body to his Father. We abhor thee Actions while we read them, and what we abhor we never imitate: The Poet only hews them like Rocks or Quick-Sands, to be hun'd.

By this Example the Criticks have concluded that it is not neceary the Manners of the Heroe hould be virtuous. They are Poetically good if they are of a Piece. Though where a Character of perfect Virtue is et before us, 'tis more lovely: for there the whole Heroe is to be imitated. This is the Aeneas of our Author: this is that Idea of perfection in an Epick Poem, which Painters and Statuaries have only in their minds; and which no hands are able to expres. Thee are the Beauties of a God in a Humane Body. When the Picture of Achilles is drawn in Tragedy, he is taken with thoe Warts, and Moles, and hard Features, by thoe who repreent him on the Stage, or he is no more Achilles: for his Creatour Homer has o decrib'd him. Yet even thus he appears a perfect Heroe, though an imperfect Character of Vertue. Horace Paints him after Homer, and delivers him to be Copied on the Stage with all thoe imperfections. Therefore they are either not faults in a Heroick Poem, or faults common to the Drama. After all, on the whole merits of the Caue, it mut be acknowledg'd that the Epick Poem is more for the Manners, and Tragedy for the Paions. The Paions, as I have aid, are violent: and acute Ditempers require Medicines of a trong and peedy operation. Ill habits of the Mind are like Chronical Dieaes, to be corrected by degrees, and Cur'd by Alteratives: wherein though Purges are ometimes neceary, yet Diet, good Air, and moderate Exercie, have the greatet part. The Matter being thus tated, it will appear that both orts of Poetry are of ue for their proper ends. The Stage is more active, the Epick Poem works at greater leiure, yet is active too, when need requires. For Dialogue is imitated by the Drama, from the more active parts of it. One puts off a Fit like the Quinquina, and relieves us only for a time; the other roots out the Ditemper, and gives a healthful habit. The Sun enlightens and chears us, dipels Fogs, and warms the ground with his daily Beams; but the Corn is ow'd, increaes, is ripen'd, and is reap'd for ue in proces of time, and in its proper Seaon. I proceed from the greatnes of the Action, to the Dignity of the Actours, I mean to the Perons employ'd in both Poems. There likewie Tragedy will be een to borrow from the Epopee; and that which borrows is always of les Dignity, becaue it has not of its own. A Subject, 'tis true, may lend to his Soveraign, but the act of borrowing makes the King inferiour, becaue he wants, and the Subject upplies. And uppoe the Perons of the Drama wholly Fabulous, or of the Poet's Invention, yet Heroick Poetry gave him the Examples of that Invention, becaue it was firt, and Homer the common Father of the Stage. I know not of any one advantage, which Tragedy can boat above Heroick Poetry, but that it is repreented to the view, as well as read: and intructs in the Cloet, as well as on the Theatre. This is an uncontended Excellence, and a chief Branch of its Prerogative; yet I may be allow'd to ay without partiality, that herein the Actors hare the Poet's praie. Your Lordhip knows ome Modern Tragedies which are beautiful on the Stage, and yet I am confident you wou'd not read them. Tryphon the Stationer complains they are eldom ask'd for in his Shop. The Poet who Flourih'd in the Scene, is damn'd in the Ruelle; nay more, he is not eteem'd a good Poet by thoe who ee and hear his Extravagancies with delight. They are a ort of tately Futian, and lofty Childihnes. Nothing but Nature can give a incere pleaure; where that is not imitated, 'tis Groteque Painting, the fine Woman ends in a Fihes Tail.

I might alo add, that many things, which not only pleae, but are
real Beauties in the reading, wou'd appear aburd upon the Stage: and thoe not only the Specioa Miracula, as Horace calls them; of Transformations, of Scylla, Antiphates, and the Letrigons, which cannot be repreented even in Opera's; but the prowes of Achilles or Aeneas wou'd appear ridiculous in our Dwarf-Heroes of the Theatre. We can believe they routed Armies in Homer or in Virgil, but ne Hercules contraduos in the Drama. I forbear to intance in many things which the Stage cannot or ought not to repreent. For I have aid already more than I intended on this Subject, and hou'd fear it might be turn'd againt me; that I plead for the pre-eminence of Epick Poetry, becaue I have taken ome pains in tranlating Virgil; if this were the firt time that I had deliver'd my Opinion in this Dipute. But I have more than once already maintain'd the Rights of my two Maters againt their Rivals of the Scene, even while I wrote Tragedies my elf, and had no thoughts of this preent Undertaking. I ubmit my Opinion to your Judgment, who are better qualified than any Man I know to decide this Controverie. You come, my Lord, intructed in the Caue, and needed not that I hou'd open it. Your Eay of Poetry, which was publih'd without a Name, and of which I was not honour'd with the Confidence, I read over and over with much delight, and as much intruction: and, without flattering you, or making my elf more Moral than I am, not without ome Envy. I was loath to be inform'd how an Epick Poem hou'd be written, or how a Tragedy hou'd be contriv'd and manag'd in better Vere and with more judgment than I cou'd teach others. A Native of Parnaus, and bred up in the Studies of its Fundamental Laws, may receive new Lights from his Contemporaries, but 'tis a grudging kind of praie which he gives his Benefactors. He is more oblig'd than he is willing to acknowledge: there is a tincture of Malice in his Commendations. For where I own I am taught, I confes my want of Knowledge. A Judge upon the Bench, may, out of good Nature, or at leat interet, encourage the Pleadings of a puny Councellor, but he does not willingly commend his Brother Serjeant at the Bar, epecially when he controuls his Law, and expoes that ignorance which is made Sacred by his Place. I gave the unknown Author his due Commendation, I mut cones, but who can anwer for me, and for the ret of the Poets, who heard me read the Poem, whether we hou'd not have been better pleas'd to have een our own Names at the bottom of the Title Page? perhaps we commended it the more, that we might eem to be above the Cenure. We are naturally dipleas'd with an unknown Critick, as the Ladies are with a Lampooner, becaue we are bitten in the dark, and know not where to faten our Revenge. But great Excellencies will work their way through all orts of oppoition. I applauded rather out of decency than Affection; and was Ambitious, as ome yet can witnes, to be acquainted with a Man, with whom I had the honour to Convere, and that almot daily, for o many years together. Heaven knows if I have heartily forgiven you this deceit. You extorted a Praie which I hou'd willingly have given had I known you. Nothing had been more eaie than to commend a Patron of a long tanding. The World wou'd joyn with me, if the Encomiums were jut; and if unjut, wou'd excue a grateful Flatterer. But to come Anonymous upon me, and force me to commend you againt my interet, was not altogether o fair, give me leave to ay, as it was Politick. For by concealing your Quality, you might clearly undertand how your Work
ucceeded; and that the general approbation was given to your Merit not your Titles. Thus like Apelles you tood uneen behind your own Venus, and receiv'd the praies of the paing Multitude: the Work was commended, not the Author: And I doubt not this was one of the mot pleaing Adventures of your Life.

I have detain'd your Lordhip longer than I intended in this Dipute of preference betwixt the Epick Poem, and the Dramae: and yet have not formally anwer'd any of the Arguments which are brought by Aritotle on the other ide, and et in the fairet light by Dacier. But I uppoe, without looking on the Book, I may have touch'd on ome of the Objections. For in this Addres to your Lordhip, I deign not a Treatie of Heroick Poetry, but write in a looe Epitolary way, omewhat tending to that Subject, after the Example of Horace, in his Firt Epitle of the Second Book to Augutus Caear, and of that to the Pio's, which we call his Art of Poetry. In both of which he oberves no Method that I can trace, whatever Scaliger the Father, or Heinius may have een, or rather think they had een. I have taken up, laid down, and reum'd as often as I pleas'd the ame Subject: and this looe proceeding I hall ue thro' all this Prefatory Dedication. Yet all this while I have been Sailing with ome ide-wind or other toward the Point I propos'd in the beginning; the Greatnes and Excellency of an Heroick Poem, with ome of the difficulties which attend that work. The Comparion therefore which I made betwixt the Epopee and the Tragedy was not altogether a digreion; for 'tis concluded on all hands, that they are both the Mater-pieces of Humane Wit.

In the mean time I may be bold to draw this Corollary from what has been already aid, That the File of Heroick Poets is very hort: all are not uch who have aum'd that lofty Title in Ancient or Modern Ages, or have been o eteem'd by their partial and ignorant Admirers.

There have been but one great Ilias and one Aeneis in o many Ages. The next, but the next with a long interval betwixt, was the Jerualem: I mean not o much in ditance of time, as in Excellency. After thee three are entred, ome Lord Chamberlain hould be appointed, ome Critick of Authority hou'd be et before the door, to keep out a Crowd of little Poets, who pres for Admiion, and are not of Quality. Maevius wou'd be deafning your Lordhip's Ears with his Fortunam Priami, Cantabo, & Nobile Bellum. meer Futian, as Horace would tell you from behind, without preing forward, and more moak than fire. Pulci, Boyardo, and Arioto, wou'd cry out, make room for the Italian Poets, the decendants of Virgil in a right Line. Father Le Moin with his Saint Louis; and Scudery with his Alaric, for a godly King, and a Gothick Conquerour; and Chapelain wou'd take it ill that his Maid hou'd be refus'd a place with Helen and Lavinia. Spencer has a better plea for his Fairy-Queen, had his action been finih'd, or had been one. And Milton, if the Devil had not been his Heroe intead of Adam, if the Gyant had not foil'd the Knight, and driven him out of his trong hold, to wander through the World with his Lady Errant: and if there had not been more Machining Perons than Humane, in his Poem. After thee, the ret of our Englih Poets hall not be mention'd. I have that Honour for them which I ought to have: but if they are Worthies, they are not to be rank'd amongt
the three whom I have nam'd, and who are etablih'd in their Reputation.

Before I quitted the Comparion betwixt Epick Poetry and Tragedy, I hou'd have acquainted my Judge with one advantage of the former over the latter, which I now caually remember out of the Preface of Segrais before his Tranlation of the Aeneis, or out of Bou, no matter which. The tile of the Heroick Poem is and ought to be more lofty than that of the Drama. The Critick is certainly in the right, for the Reaon already urg'd: The work of Tragedy is on the Paions, and in Dialogue, both of them abhor trong Metaphors, in which the Epopee delights. A Poet cannot peak too plainly on the Stage: for Volat irrevocabile verbum; the ene is lot if it be not taken flying: but what we read alone we have leiure to diget. There an Author may beautifie his Sene by the boldnes of his Expreion, which if we undertand not fully at the firt, we may dwell upon it, 'till we find the ecret force and excellence. That which cures the Manners by alterative Phyick, as I aid before, mut proceed by inenible degrees; but that which purges the Paions, mut do its buines all at once, or wholly fail of its effect, at leat in the preent Operation, and without repeated Does. We mut beat the Iron while 'tis hot, but we may polih it at leiure. Thus, my Lord, you pay the Fine of my forgetfulnes, and yet the merits of both Caues are where they were, and undecided, 'till you declare whether it be more for the benefit of Mankind to have their Manners in general corrected, or their Pride and hard-heartednes remov'd.

I mut now come cloer to my preent buines: and not think of making more invaive Wars abroad, when like Hannibal, I am call'd back to the defence of my own Country. Virgil is attack'd by many Enemies: He has a whole Confederacy againt him, and I mut endeavour to defend him as well as I am able. But their principal Objections being againt his Moral, the duration or length of time taken up in the action of the Poem, and what they have to urge againt the Manners of his Hero, I hall omit the ret as meer Cavils of Grammarians: at the wort but caual lips of a Great Man's Pen, or inconiderable faults of an admirable Poem, which the Author had not leiure to review before his Death. Macrobius has anwer'd what the Ancients cou'd urge againt him: and ome things I have lately read in Tanneguy le Fevrè, Valois, and another whom I name not, which are carce worth anwering. They begin with the Moral of his Poem, which I have elewhere confes'd, and till mut own not to be o Noble as that of Homer. But let both be fairly tated, and without contradicting my firt Opinion, I can hew that Virgil's was as ueful to the Romans of his Age, as Homer's was to the Grecians of his; in what time oever he may be uppos'd to have liv'd and flourih'd. Homer's Moral was to urge the neceity of Union, and of a good undertanding betwixt Confederate States and Princes engag'd in a War with a Mighty Monarch: as alo of Dicipline in an Army, and obedience in the everal Chiefs, to the Supream Commander of the joynt Forces. To inculcate this, he ets forth the ruinous Effects of Dicord in the Camp of thoe Allies, occaion'd by the quarrel betwixt the General, and one of the next in Office under him. Agamemnon gives the provocation, and Achilles reents the injury. Both Parties are faulty in the Quarrel, and accordingly they are both punih'd: the Agreor is forc'd to ue for peace to his Inferiour, on dihonourable Conditions; the Deerter
reues the atisfaction offer'd, and his Obtinacy cots him his bet Friend. This works the Natural Effect of Choler, and turns his Rage againt him, by whom he was lat Affronted, and mot enibly. The greater Anger expels the les; but his Caracter is till preerv'd. In the mean time the Grecian Army receives Los on Los, and is half detroy'd by a Petilence into the Bargain.

As the Poet, in the firt part of the Example, had hewn the bad effects of Dicord, o after the Reconcilement, he gives the good effects of Unity. For Hector is lain, and then Troy mut fall. By this, 'tis probable, that Homer liv'd when the Perian Monarchy was grown formidable to the Grecians: and that the joint Endeavours of his Country-men, were little enough to preerve their common Freedom, from an encroaching Enemy. Such was his Moral, which all Criticks have allow'd to be more Noble than that of Virgil: though not adapted to the times in which the Roman Poet liv'd. Had Virgil flourih'd in the Age of Ennius, and addres'd to Scipio, he had probably taken the ame Moral, or ome other not unlike it. For then the Romans were in as much danger from the Carthaginian Commonwealth, as the Grecians were from the Perian Monarchy. But we are to conider him as writing his Poem in a time when the Old Form of Government was ubverted, and a new one jut Etablihed by Octavius Caear: In effect by force of Arms, but eemingly by the Conent of the Roman People. The Commonwealth had receiv'd a deadly Wound in the former Civil Wars betwixt Marius and Sylla. The Commons, while the firt prevail'd, had almot haken off the Yoke of the Nobility; and Marius and Cinna, like the Captains of the Mobb, under the pecious Pretence of the Publick Good, and of doing Jutice on the Oppreours of their Liberty, reveng'd themelves, without Form of Law, on their private Enemies. Sylla, in his turn, procrib'd the Heads of the advere Party: He too had nothing but Liberty and Reformation in his Mouth; (for the Caue of Religion is but a Modern Motive to Rebellion, invented by the Chritian Priethood, refining on the Heathen:) Sylla, to be ure, meant no more good to the Roman People than Marius before him, whatever he declar'd; but Sacrific'd the Lives, and took the Etates of all his Enemies, to gratifie thoe who brought him into Power: Such was the Reformation of the Government by both Parties. The Senate and the Commons were the two Baes on which it tood; and the two Champions of either Faction, each detroy'd the Foundations of the other ide: So the Fabrique of conequence mut fall betwxt them: And Tyranny mut be built upon their Ruines. This comes of altering Fundamental Laws and Contitutions. Like him, who being in good Health, lodg'd himelf in a Phyician's Houe, and was over-perwaded by his Landlord to take Phyick, of which he dyed, for the benefit of his Doctor. Stavo ben (was written on his Monument) ma, pertar meglio, to qui.

After the Death of thoe two Uurpers, the Commonwealth eem'd to recover, and held up its Head for a little time: But it was all the while in a deep Conumption, which is a flattering Dieae. Pompey, Craus, and Caear, had found the Sweets of Arbitrary Power; and each being a check to the others growth, truck up a fale Friendhip amongt themelves; and divided the Government betwixt them,
which none of them was able to aume alone. Thee were the publick Spirited Men of their Age, that is, Patriots for their own Interet. The Commonwealth look'd with a florid Countenance in their Management, pread in Bulk, and all the while was wating in the Vitals. Not to trouble your Lordhip with the Repetition of what you know: After the death of Craus, Pompey found himelf out-witted by Caear; broke with him, over-power'd him in the Senate, and caus'd many unjut Decrees to pas againt him: Caear thus injur'd, and unable to reit the Faction of the Nobles, which was now uppermot (for he was a Marian) had recoure to Arms; and his Caue was jut againt Pompey, but not againt his Country, whoe Contitution ought to have been acred to him; and never to have been Violated on the account of any private Wrong. But he prevail'd, and Heav'n declaring for him, he became a Providential Monarch, under the Title of Perpetual Dictator. He being Murther'd by his own Son, whom I neither dare commend, nor can jutly blame (though Dante in his Inferno, has put him and Caius, and Judas Icariot betwixt them, into the great Devil's Mouth) the Commonwealth popp'd up its Head for the third time, under Brutus and Caius, and then unk for ever.

Thus the Roman People were groly gull'd: twice or thrice over: and as often enlav'd in one Century, and under the ame pretence of Reformation. At lat the two Battles of Philippi, gave the deciive troak againt Liberty; and not long after, the Commonwealth was turn'd into a Monarchy, by the Conduct and good Fortune of Augutus. 'Tis true, that the depotick Power could not have fallen into better Hands, than thoe of the firt and econd Caear. Your Lordhip well knows what Obligations Virgil had to the latter of them: He aw, beide, that the Commonwealth was lot without reource: The Heads of it detroy'd; the Senate new moulded, grown degenerate; and either bought off, or thruting their own Necks into the Yoke, out of fear of being forc'd. Yet I may afely affirm for our great Author (as Men of good Sene are generally Honet) that he was till of Republick principles in Heart.
div.q: Secretique Piis, his dantem jura Catonem.
div.p:
I think, I need ue no other Argument to jutify my Opinion, than that of this one Line, taken from the Eighth Book of the Eneis. If he had not well tudied his Patron's Temper, it might have Ruin'd him with another Prince. But Augutus was not dicontented, at leat that we can find, that Cato was plac'd, by his own Poet, in Eliium; and there giving Laws to the Holy Souls, who deerv'd to be eparated from the Vulgar ort of good Spirits. For his Concience could not but whiper to the Arbitrary Monarch, that the Kings of Rome were at firt Elective, and Govern'd not without a Senate: That Romulus was no Hereditary Prince, and though, after his Death, he receiv'd Divine Honours, for the good he did on Earth, yet he was but a God of their own making: that the lat Tarquin was Expell'd jutly, for Overt-Acts of Tyranny, and Male-Adminitration; for uch are the Conditions of an Elective Kingdom: And I meddle not with others: being, for my own Opinion, of Montaigns Principles, that an Honet Man ought to be contented with that Form of Government, and with thoe Fundamental Contitutions of it, which he receiv'd from his Ancetors, and under which himelf was
Born: Though at the ame time he confes'd freely, that if he could have choen his Place of Birth, it hou'd have been at Venice: Which for many Reaons I dilike, and am better pleas'd to have been born an Englih Man.

But to return from my long rambling: I ay that Virgil having maturely weigh'd the Condition of the Times in which he liv'd: that an entire Liberty was not to be retriev'd: that the preent Settlement had the propect of a long continuance in the ame Family, or thoe adopted into it: that he held his Paternal Etate from the Bounty of the Conqueror, by whom he was likewie enrich'd, eteem'd and cherih'd: that this Conquerour, though of a bad kind, was the very bet of it: that the Arts of Peace flourih'd under him: that all Men might be happy if they would be quiet: that now he was in poeion of the whole, yet he har'd a great part of his Authority with the Senate: That he would be choen into the Ancient Offices of the Commonwealth, and Rul'd by the Power which he deriv'd from them; and Prorogu'd his Government from time to time: Still, as it were, threatning to dimis himelf from Publick Cares, which he exercis'd more for the common Good, than for any delight he took in greatnes: Thee things, I ay, being conider'd by the Poet, he concluded it to be the Interet of his Country to be o Govern'd: To infue an awful Repect into the People, towards uch a Prince: By that repect to confirm their Obedience to him; and by that Obedience to make them Happy. This was the Moral of his Divine Poem: Honet in the Poet: Honourable to the Emperour, whom he derives from a Divine Extraction; and reflecting part of that Honour on the Roman People, whom he derives alo from the Trojans; and not only profitable, but neceary to the preent Age; and likely to be uch to their Poterity. That it was the receiv'd Opinion, that the Romans were decended from the Trojans, and Julius Caear from Julus the Son of Aeneas, was enough for Virgil; tho' perhaps he thought not o himelf: Or that Aeneas ever was in Italy, which Bochartus manifetly proves. And Homer, where he ays that Jupiter hated the Houe of Priam, and was reolv'd to transfer the Kingdom to the Family of Aeneas, yet mentions nothing of his leading a Colony into a Foreign Country, and etling there: But that the Romans valued themelves on their Trojan Ancetry, is o undoubted a Truth, that I need not prove it. Even the Seals which we have remaining of Julius Caear, which we know to be Antique, have the Star of Venus over them, though they were all graven after his Death, as a Note that he was Deifi'd. I doubt not but it was one Reaon, why Augutus hould be o paionately concern'd for the preervation of the Aeneis, which its Author had Condemn'd to be Burnt, as an Imperfect Poem, by his lat Will and Tetament; was, becaue it did him a real Service as well as an Honour; that a Work hould not be lot where his Divine Original was Celebrated in Vere, which had the Character of Immortality tamp'd upon it.

Neither were the great Roman Families which flourih'd in his time, les oblig'd by him than the Emperour. Your Lordhip knows with what Addres he makes mention of them, as Captains of Ships, or Leaders in the War; and even ome of Italian Extraction are not forgotten. Thee are the ingle Stars which are prinkled through the Aeneis: But there are whole Contellations of them in the Fifth Book. And I could not but take notice, when I Tranlated it, of ome Favourite
Families to which he gives the Victory, and awards the Prizes, in the Peron of his Heroe, at the Funeral Games which were Celebrated in Honour of Anchies. I, Init not on their Names: But am pleas'd to find the Memmii amongt them, deriv'd from Mnetheus, becaue Lucretius Dedicates to one of that Family, a Branch of which detroy'd Corinth. I likewie either found or form'd an Image to my elf of the contrary kind; that thoe who lot the Prizes, were uch as had dioblig'd the Poet, or were in digrace with Augutus, or Enemies to Mecenas: And this was the Poetical Revenge he took. For genus irritabile Vatum, as Horace ays. When a Poet is throughly provok'd, he will do himelf Jutice, however dear it cot him, Animamque, in Vulnere ponit. I think thee are not bare Imaginations of my own, though I find no trace of them in the Commentatours: But one Poet may judge of another by himelf. The Vengeance we defer, is not forgotten. I hinted before, that the whole Roman People were oblig'd by Virgil, in deriving them from Troy; an Ancetry which they affected. We, and the French are of the ame Humour: They would be thought to decend from a Son, I think, of Hector: And we wou'd have our Britain, both Nam'd and Planted by a decendant of Aeneas. Spencer favours this Opinion what he can. His Prince Arthur, or whoever he intends by him, is a Trojan. Thus the Heroe of Homer was a Grecian, of Virgil a Roman, of Tao an Italian.
I have trangres'd my Bounds, and gone farther than the Moral led me. But if your Lordhip is not tir'd, I am afe enough.

Thus far, I think, my Author is defended. But as Augutus is till hadow'd in the Peron of Aeneas, of which I hall ay more, when I come to the Manners which the Poet gives his Hero: I mut prepare that Subject by hewing how dext'rouly he mannag'd both the Prince and People, o as to dipleae neither, and to do good to both, which is the part of a Wie and an Honet Man: And proves that it is poible for a Courtier not to be a Knave: I hall continue till to peak my Thoughts like a free-born Subject as I am; though uch things, perhaps, as no Dutch Commentator cou'd, and I am ure no French-man durt. I have already told your Lordhip my Opinion of Virgil; that he was no Arbitrary Man. Oblig'd he was to his Mater for his Bounty, and he repays him with good Counel, how to behave himelf in his new Monarchy, o as to gain the Affections of his Subjects, and deerve to be call'd the Father of his Country. From this Conideration it is, that he choe for the ground-work of his Poem, one Empire detroy'd, and another rais'd from the Ruins of it. This was jut the Parallel. Aeneas cou'd not pretend to be Priam's Heir in a Lineal Succeion: For Anchies the Heroe's Father, was only of the econd Branch of the Royal Family: And Helenus, a Son of Priam, was yet urviving, and might lawfully claim before him. It may be Virgil mentions him on that Account. Neither has he forgotten Atis, in the Fifth of his Aeneis, the Son of Polites, younget Son to Priam; who was lain by Pyrrhus, in the Second Book. Atis, then, the Favourite Companion of Acanius, had a better Right than he; tho' I know he was introduc'd by Virgil, to do Honour to the Family, from which Julius Caear was decended by the Mothers ide. Aeneas had only Married Creua, Priam's Daughter, and by her could have no Title, while any of the Male Iue were remaining. In this cae, the Poet gave him the next Title, which is, that of an Elective King. The remaining Trojans choe him to lead them forth,
and ettle them in ome Foreign Country. Ilioneus in his Speech to Dido, calls him exprely by the Name of King. Our Poet, who all this while had Augutus in his Eye, had no deire he hould eem to ucceed by any right of Inheritance, deriv'd from Julius Caear; uch a Title being but one degree remov'd from Conquet. For what was introduc'd by force, by force may be remov'd. 'Twas better for the People that they hould give, than he hould take. Since that Gift was indeed no more at bottom than a Trut. Virgil gives us an Example of this, in the Peron of Mezentius. He Govern'd Arbitrarily, he was expell'd: And came to the deerv'd End of all Tyrants. Our Author hews us another ort of Kinghip in the Peron of Latinus. He was decended from Saturn, and as I remember, in the Third Degree. He is decrib'd a jut and a gracious Prince; olicitous for the Welfare of his People; always Conulting with his Senate to promote the common Good. We find him at the head of them, when he enters into the Council-Hall. Speaking firt, but till demanding their Advice, and teering by it as far as the Iniquity of the Times wou'd uffer him. And this is the proper Character of a King by Inheritance, who is born a Father of his Country. Aeneas, tho' he Married the Heires of the Crown, yet claim'd no Title to it during the Life of his Father-in-Law. Pater arma Latinus habeto, &c. are Virgil's Words. As for himelf, he was contented to take care of his Country Gods, who were not thoe of Latium. Wherein our Divine Author eems to relate to the after practice of the Romans, which was to adopt the Gods of thoe they Conquer'd, or receiv'd as Members of their Commonwealth. Yet withal, he plainly touches at the Office of the High Priethood, with which Augutus was inveted: And which made his Peron more Sacred and inviolable, than even the Tribunitial Power. It was not therefore for nothing, that the mot Judicious of all Poets, made that Office vacant, by the Death of Panthus, in the Second Book of the Aeneis, for his Heroe ro ucceed in it; and conequently for Augutus to enjoy. I know not that any of the Commentatours have taken notice of that paage. If they have not, I am ure they ought: And if they have, I am not indebted to them for the Obervation: The words of Virgil are very plain.
div.q: Sacra, uoque tibi, commendat Troja Penates.
div.p: As for Augutus, or his Uncle Julius, claiming by decent from Aeneas; that Title is already out of doors. Aeneas ucceeded not, but was Elected. Troy was fore-doom'd to fall for ever.

l.hi: Potquam res Aiae, Priamique evertere Regnum,

q.l: Immeritum, vium uperis. Aeneis the 3d, line the 1t.

div.p: Augutus 'tis true, had once reolv'd to re-build that City, and there to make the Seat of Empire: But Horace writes an Ode on purpoe to deter him from that Thought; declaring the place to be accurs'd, and that the Gods would as often detroy it as it hou'd be rais'd. Hereupon the Emperour laid aide a Project o ungrateful to the Roman People: But by this, my Lord, we may conclude that he had till his Pedigree in his Head; and had an Itch of being thought a Divine King, if his Poets had not given him better Counel.

I will pas by many les material Objections, for want of room to Anwer them: What follows next is of great Importance, if the Criticks
can make out their Charge; for 'tis levell'd at the Manners which our Poet gives his Heroe; and which are the ame which were eminently een in his Augutus. Thoe Manners were Piety to the Gods, and a dutiful Affection to his Father; Love to his Relations; Care of his People; Courage and Conduct in the Wars; Gratitude to thoe who had oblig'd him; and Jutice in general to Mankind.

Piety, as your Lordhip ees, takes place of all, as the chief part of his Character: And the word in Latin is more full than it can poibly be expret in any Modern Language; for there it comprehends not only Devotion to the Gods, but Filial Love and tender Affection to Relations of all orts. As intances of this, the Deities of Troy and his own Penates are made the Companions of his Flight: They appear to him in his Voyage, and advie him; and at lat he re-places them in Italy, their Native Country. For his Father he takes him on his Back: He leads his little Son, his Wife follows him; but loing his Footteps through Fear or Ignorance, he goes back into the midt of his Enemies to find her; and leaves not his purute 'till her Ghot appears, to forbid his farther earch. I will ay nothing of his Duty to his Father while he liv'd; his Sorrow for his Death; of the Games intituted in Honour of his Memory; or eeking him, by his Command, even after Death, in the Elyian Fields. I will not mention his Tendernes for his Son, which every where is viible; Of his raiing a Tomb for Polydorus, the Obequies for Mienus, his pious remembrance of Deiphobus: The Funerals of his Nure: His Grief for Pallas, and his Revenge taken on his Murtherer; whom, otherwie by his Natural Compaion, he had forgiven: And then the Poem had been left imperfect: For we could have had no certain propect of his Happines, while the lat Obtacle to it was unremov'd. Of the other parts which compoe his Character, as a King, or as a General, I need ay nothing: The whole Aeneis is one continued Intance, of ome one or other of them: And where I find any thing of them tax'd, it hall uffice me, as briefly as I can, to vindicate my Divine Mater to your Lordhip, and by you to the Reader. But herein, Segrais, in his admirable Preface to his Tranlation of the Aeneis, as the Author of the Dauphin's Virgil jutly calls it; has prevented me. Him I follow; and what I borrow from him, am ready to acknowledge to him. For, impartially peaking, the French are as much better Criticks than the Englih, as they are wore Poets. Thus we generally allow that they better undertand the management of a War, than our Ilanders; but we know we are uperiour to them, in the day of Battel. They value themelves on their Generals; we on our Souldiers. But this is not the proper place to decide that Quetion, if they make it one. I hall ayperhaps as much of other Nations, and their Poets, excepting only Tao: and hope to make my Aertion good, which is but doing Jutice to my Country. Part of which Honour will reflect on your Lordhip, whoe Thoughts are always jut; your Numbers harmonious; your Words choen; your Expreions trong and manly; your Vere flowing, and your turns as happy as they are eaie. If you wou'd et us more Copies, your Example would make all Precepts needles. In the mean time, that little you have Written is own'd, and that particularly by the Poets, (who are a Nation not over-lavih of praie to their Contemporaries,) as a principal Ornament of our Language: But the weetet Eences are always confin'd in the mallet Glaes.

When I peak of your Lordhip, 'tis never a digreion, and therefore I need beg no pardon for it; but take up Segrais where I left him: And hall ue him les often than I have occaion for him. For his Preface is a perfect piece of Criticim, full and clear, and digeted into an exact Method; mine is looe, and, as I intended it, Epitolary. Yet I dwell on many things which he durt not touch: For 'tis dangerous to offend an Arbitrary Mater: And every Patron who has the Power of Augutus, has not his Clemency. In hort, my Lord, I wou'd not Tranlate him, becaue I wou'd bring you omewhat of my own. His Notes and Obervations on every Book, are of the ame Excellency; and for the ame Reaon I omit the greater part.

He takes notice that Virgil is Arraign'd for placing Piety before Valour; and making that Piety the chief Character of his Heroe. I have aid already from Bou, that a Poet is not oblig'd to make his Heroe a Virtuous Man: Therefore neither Homer nor Tao are to be blam'd, for giving what predominant quality they pleas'd to their firt Character. But Virgil, who deign'd to form a perfect Prince, and would ininuate, that Augutus, whom he calls Aeneas in his Poem, was truly uch, found himelf oblig'd to make him without blemih; thoroughly Virtuous; and a thorough Virtue both begins and ends in Piety. Tao, without quetion, oberv'd this before me; and therefore plit his Heroe in two. He gave Godfrey Piety, and Rinaldo Fortitude; for their chief Qualities or Manners. Homer, who had choen another Moral, makes both Agamemnon and Achilles vicious: For his deign was to intruct in Virtue, by hewing the deformity of Vice. I avoid repetitione of that I have aid above.
