What follows is Tranlated literally from Segrais.

Virgil had conider'd that the greatet Virtues of Augutus conited in the perfect Art of Governing his People; which caus'd him to Reign for more than Forty Years in great Felicity. He conider'd that his Emperour was Valiant, Civil, Popular, Eloquent, Politick, and Religious. He has given all thee Qualities to Aeneas. But knowing that Piety alone comprehends the whole Duty of Man towards the Gods; towards his County, and towards his Relations, he judg'd, that this ought to be his firt Character, whom he would et for a Pattern of Perfection. In reality, they who believe that the Praies which arie from Valour, are uperiour to thoe, which proceed from any other Virtues, have not conider'd (as they ought), that Valour, detitute of other Virtues, cannot render a Man worthy of any true eteem. That Quality which ignifies no more than an intrepid Courage, may be eparated from many others which are good, and accompany'd with many which are ill. A Man may be very Valiant, and yet Impious and Vicious. But the ame cannot be aid of Piety; which excludes all ill Qualities, and comprehends even Valour it elf, with all other Qualities which are good. Can we, for Example, give the praie of Valour to a Man who hou'd ee his Gods prophan'd, and hou'd want the Courage to defend them? To a Man who hou'd abandon his Father, or deert his King in his lat Neceity?

Thus far Segrais, in giving the preference to Piety before Valour. I will now follow him, where he coniders this Valour, or intrepid Courage, ingly in it elf; and this alo Virgil gives to his Aeneas, and that in a Heroical Degree.

Having firt concluded, that our Poet did for the bet in taking the firt Character of his Heroe, from that Eential Vertue on which the
ret depend, he proceeds to tell us, that in the Ten Years war of Troy, he was conider'd as the econd Champion of his Country; allowing Hector the firt place; and this, even by the Confeion of Homer, who took all occaions of etting up his own Countrymen the Grecians, and of undervaluing the Trojan Chiefs. But Virgil, (whom Segrais forgot to cite,) makes Diomede give him a higher Character for Strength and Courage. His Tetimony is this in the Eleventh Book.

q.l: —tetimus tela apera contra,
Contulimuque manus: Experto, credite, quantus
In clypeum afurgat, quo turbine torqueat hatam.
Si duo preterea tales Idaea tuliet
Terra viros; ultro Inachias veniet ad rbes
Dardanus, & veris lugeret Graecia fatis.
Quicquid apud durae ceatum et moenia Trojae,
Hectoris, Aeeneaeque manu victoria Grajûm
Haeit; & in decumum vetigia rettulit annum.
Ambo animis, ambo inignes praetantibus armis:
Hic pietate prior.

div.p: I give not here my Tranlation of thee Veres; though I think I have not ill ucceeded in them; becaue your Lordhip is o great a Mater of the Original, that I have no reaon to deire you hou'd ee Virgil and me o near together: But you may pleae, my Lord, to take notice, that the Latin Author refines upon the Greek; and ininuates, That Homer had done his Heroe Wrong, in giving the advantage of the Duel to his own Country-man: Though Diomedes was manifetly the econd Champion of the Grecians: And lyes preferr'd him before Ajax, when he choe him for the Companion of his Nightly Expedition: For he had a Head-piece of his own; and wanted only the fortitude of another, to bring him off with afety; and that he might compas his Deign with Honour.

The French Tranlator thus proceeds: They who accue Aeneas for want of Courage, either undertand not Virgil, or have read him lightly; otherwie they would not raie an Objection o eaie to be Anwer'd: Hereupon he gives o many intances of the Heroe's Valour, that to repeat them after him would tire your Lordhip, and put me to the unneceary trouble of Trancribing the greatet part of the three lat Aeneids. In hort, more could not be expected from an Amadis, a Sir Lancelot, or the whole round Table, than he performs. Proxima quaeque metit gladio, is the perfect Account of a Knight Errant. If it be reply'd, continues Segrais, that it was not difficult for him to undertake and atchieve uch hardy Enterprizes, becaue he wore Enchanted Arms. That Accuation, in the firt place, mut fall on Homer e're it can reach Virgil. Achilles was as well provided with them as Aeneas, though he was invulnerable without them: And, Arioto, the two Tao's, Bernardo and Torquato, even our own Spencer; in a word, all Modern Poets have Copied Homer as well as Virgil: He is neither the firt nor lat; but in the midt of them; and therefore is afe if they are o. Who knows, ays Segrais, but that his fated Armour was only an Allegorical Defence, and ignifi'd no more than that he was under the peculiar protection of the Gods; born, as the Atrologers will tell us out of Virgil (who was well vers'd in the Chaldaean Myteries) under the favourable influence of Jupiter, Venus, and the Sun: But I init not on this, becaue I know you believe not
there is uch an Art: though not only Horace and Perius, but Augutus himelf, thought otherwie. But in defence of Virgil, I dare poitively ay, that he has been more cautious in this particular than either his Predeceour, or his Decendants. For Aeneas was actually wounded, in the Twelfth of the Aeneis; though he had the ame God-Smith to Forge his Arms, as had Achilles. It eems he was no War-luck, as the Scots commonly call uch Men, who they ay, are Iron-free, or Lead-free. Yet after this Experiment, that his Arms were not impenetrable, when he was Cur'd indeed by his Mother's help, becaue he was that day to conclude the War by the death of Turnus, the Poet durt not carry the Miracle too far, and retore him wholy to his former Vigour: He was till too weak to overtake his Enemy; yet we ee with what Courage he attacks Turnus, when he faces and renews the Combate. I need ay no more, for Virgil defends himelf, without needing my aitance; and proves his Heroe truly to deerve that Name. He was not then a Second-rate Champion, as they would have him, who think Fortitude the firt Vertue in a Heroe. But being beaten from this hold, they will not yet allow him to be Valiant; becaue he wept more often, as they think, than well becomes a Man of Courage.

In the firt place, if Tears are Arguments of Cowardie, What hall I ay of Homer's Heroe? hall Achilles pas for timorous becaue he wept? and wept on les occaions than Aeneas? Herein Virgil mut be granted to have excell'd his Mater. For once both Heroes are decrib'd lamenting their lot Loves: Brieis was taken away by force from the Grecian: Cerua was lot for ever to her Huband. But Achilles went roaring along the alt Sea-hore, and like a Booby, was complaining to his Mother, when he hou'd have reveng'd his Injury by Arms. Aeneas took a Nobler Coure; for having ecur'd his Father and his Son, he repeated all his former Dangers to have found his Wife, if he had been above ground. And here your Lordhip may oberve the Addres of Virgil; it was not for nothing, that this Paage was related with all thee tender Circumtances. Aeneas told it; Dido hear'd it: That he had been o affectionate a Husband, was no ill Argument to the coming Dowager, that he might prove as kind to her. Virgil has a thouand ecret Beauties, tho' I have not leiure to remark them.

Segrais on this Subject of a Heroe's hedding Tears, oberves that Hitorians commend Alexander for weeping, when he read the mighty Actions of Achilles. And Julius Caear is likewie prais'd, when out of the ame Noble Envy, he wept at the Victories of Alexander. But if we oberve more cloely, we hall find, that the tears of Aeneas were always on a laudable Occaion. Thus he weeps out of Compaion, and tendernes of Nature, when in the Temple of Carthage he beholds the Pictures of his Friends, who Sacrific'd their Lives in Defence of their Country. He deplores the lamentable End of his Pilot Palinurus; the untimely death of young Pallas his Confederate; and the ret, which I omit. Yet even for thee Tears his wretched Criticks dare condemn him. They make Aeneas little better than a kind of a St. Swithen Heroe, always raining. One of thee Cenors is bold enough to argue him of Cowardie; when in the beginning of the Firt Book, he not only weeps, but trembles at an approaching Storm.

q.l: Ingemit & duplices tendens ad yderas palmas, &c.

div.p:
But to this I have anwer'd formerly; that his fear was not for himelf, but for his People. And who can give a Soveraign a better Commendation, or recommend a Heroe more to the affection of the Reader? They were threatned with a Tempet, and he wept; he was promis'd Italy, and therefore he pray'd for the accomplihment of that Promie. All this in the beginning of a Storm, therefore he hew'd the more early Piety, and the quicker ene of Compaion. Thus much I have urg'd elewhere in the defence of Virgil; and ince I have been inform'd, by Mr. Moyl, a young Gentleman, whom I can never ufficiently commend, that the Ancients accounted drowning an accured Death. So that if we grant him to have been afraid, he had jut occaion for that fear, both in relation to himelf, and to his Subjects. I think our Adveraries can carry this Argument no farther, unles they tell us that he ought to have had more confidence in the promie of the Gods: But how was he aur'd that he had undertood their Oracles aright? Helenus might be mitaken, Phoebus might peak doubtfully, even his Mother might flatter him, that he might proecute his Voyage, which if it ucceeded happily, he hou'd be the Founder of an Empire. For that he her elf was doubtful of his Fortune, is apparent by the Addres he made to Jupiter on his behalf. To which the God makes anwer in thee words:
Parce metu, Citherea, manent immota tuorum,
Fata tibi, &c.

Notwithtanding which, the Goddes, though comforted, was not aur'd: For even after this, through the coure of the whole Aeneis, he till apprehends the interet which Juno might make with Jupiter againt her Son. For it was a moot Point in Heaven, whether he cou'd alter Fate or not. And indeed, ome paages in Virgil wou'd make us upect, that he was of Opinion, Jupiter might deferr Fate, though he cou'd not alter it. For in the latter end of the Tenth Book, he introduces Juno begging for the Life of Turnus, and flattering her Husband with the power of changing Detiny. Tua qui potes, ora reflectas. To which he graciouly anwers:
Si mora praeentis lethi tempu
que caduco
Oratur Juveni, me
que hoc ita ponere entis,
Tolle fugâ Turnum, at
que intantibus Eripe fatis.
Hactenus indulie vacat. Sin altior itis
Sub precibus venia ulla latet, totum
que moveri,
Mutarive putas bellum, pes pacis inaneis.

But that he cou'd not alter thoe Decrees, the King of Gods himelf confees, in the Book above cited: when he comforts Hercules, for the death of Pallas, who had invok'd his aid, before he threw his Lance at Turnus.

q.l: —Trojae ub moenibus altis,
Tot Nati Cecidere Deûm; quin occidit unâ
Sarpedon mea progenies: etiam ua Turnum

Fata manent: meta
que dati pervenit ad aevi.

div.p:
Where he plainly acknowledges, that he cou'd not ave his own Son, or prevent the death which he foreaw. Of his power to deferr the blow, I once occaionally dicours'd with that Excellent Peron Sir Robert Howard: who is better converant than any Man I know, in the Doctrine of the Stoicks, and he et me right; from the concurrent tetimony of Philoophers and Poets, that Jupiter cou'd not retard the effects of Fate, even for a moment. For when I cited Virgil as favouring the contrary opinion in that Vere, Tolle fugâ Turnum, at
que intantibus eripe fatis.

He reply'd, and I think with an exact Judgment, that when Jupiter gave Juno leave to withdraw Turnus from the preent danger, it was becaue he certainly fore-knew that his Fatal hour was not come: that it was in Detiny for Juno at that time to ave him; and that he himelf obey'd Detiny, in giving her that leave.

I need ay no more in jutification of our Heroe's Courage, and am much deceiv'd, if he ever be attack'd on this ide of his Character again. But he is Arraign'd with more hew of Reaon by the Ladies; who will make a numerous Party againt him, for being fale to Love, in foraking Dido. And I cannot much blame them; for to ay the truth, 'tis an ill Precedent for their Gallants to follow. Yet if I can bring him off, with Flying Colours, they may learn experience at her cot; and for her ake, avoid a Cave, as the wort helter they can chue from a hower of Rain, epecially when they have a Lover in their Company.

In the firt place, Segrais oberves with much accutenes, that they who blame Aeneas for his inenibility of Love, when he left Carthage, contradict their former accuation of him, for being always Crying, Compaionate, and Effeminately enible of thoe Misfortunes which befell others. They give him two contrary Characters, but Virgil makes him of a piece, always grateful, always tender-hearted. But they are impudent enough to dicharge themelves of this blunder, by laying the Contradiction at Virgil's door. He, they ay, has hewn his Heroe with thee inconitent Characters: Acknowledging, and Ungrateful, Compaionate, and Hard-harted; but at the bottom, Fickle, and Self-intereted. For Dido had not only receiv'd his weather-beaten Troops before he aw him, and given them her protection, but had alo offer'd them an equal hare in her Dominion.

q.l: Vultis & his mecum pariter conidere Regnis?
rbem quam tatuo, vetra et.

div.p:
This was an obligement never to be forgotten: and the more to be conider'd, becaue antecedent to her Love. That paion, 'tis true, produc'd the uual effects of Generoity, Gallantry, and care to pleae, and thither we referr them. But when he had made all thee advances, it was till in his power to have refus'd them: After the Intrigue
of the Cave, call it Marriage, or Enjoment only, he was no longer free to take or leave; he had accepted the favour, and was oblig'd to be Contant, if he wou'd be grateful.

My Lord, I have et this Argument in the bet light I can, that the Ladies may not think I write booty: and perhaps it may happen to me, as it did to Doctor Cudworth, who has rais'd uch trong Objections againt the being of a God, and Providence, that many think he has not anwer'd them. You may pleae at leat to hear the advere Party. Segrais pleads for Virgil, that no les than an Abolute Command from Jupiter, cou'd excue this inenibility of the Heroe, and this abrupt departure, which looks o like extream ingratitude. But at the ame time, he does wiely to remember you, that Virgil had made Piety the firt Character of Aeneas: And this being allow'd, as I am afraid it mut, he was oblig'd, antecedent to all other Coniderations, to earch an Aylum for his Gods in Italy. For thoe very Gods, I ay, who had promis'd to his Race the Univeral Empire. Cou'd a Pious Man dipence with the Commands of Jupiter to atisfie his paion; or take it in the tronget ene, to comply with the obligations of his gratitude? Religion, 'tis true, mut have Moral Honety for its groundwork, or we hall be apt to upect its truth; but an immediate Revelation dipenes with all Duties of Morality. All Cauits agree, that Theft is a breach of the Moral Law: yet if I might preume to mingle Things Sacred with Prophane, the Iraelites only poil'd the Egyptians, not rob'd them, becaue the propriety was transferr'd; by a Revelation to their Law-giver. I confes Dido was a very Infidel in this Point: for he wou'd not believe, as Virgil makes her ay, that ever Jupiter wou'd end Mercury on uch an Immoral Errand. But this needs no Anwer; at leat no more than Virgil gives it: Fata obtant, placida
que viri Deus obtruit aures.
This notwithtanding, as Segrais confees, he might have hewn a little more enibility when he left her; for that had been according to his Character.
But let Virgil anwer for himelf; he till lov'd her; and truggled with his inclinations, to obey the Gods.

q.l: Curam ub Corde premebat,

Multa gemens; magno
que animum labefactus Amore.

div.p:
Upon the whole Matter, and humanely peaking, I doubt there was a fault omewhere; and Jupiter is better able to bear the blame, than either Virgil or Aeneas. The Poet it eems had found it out, and therefore brings the deerting Heroe and the foraken Lady to meet together in the lower Regions; where he excues himelf when 'tis too late, and accordingly he will take no atisfaction, nor o much as hear him. Now Segrais is forc'd to abandon his defence, and excues his Author, by aying that the Aeneis is an imperfect Work, and that Death prevented the Divine Poet from reviewing it; and for that Reaon he had condemn'd it to the fire; though at the ame time, his two Tranlators mut acknowledge, that the Sixth Book is the mot Correct of the whole Aeneis. Oh, how convenient is a Machine ometimes in a Heroick Poem! This of Mercury is plainly one, and Virgil was contrain'd to ue it here, or the honety of his Heroe
wou'd be ill-defended. And the Fair Sex however, if they had the Deertour in their power, wou'd certainly have hewn him no more mercy, than the Bacchanals did Orpheus. For if too much Contancy may be a fault ometimes, then want of Contancy, and Ingratitude after the lat Favour, is a Crime that never will be forgiven. But of Machines, more in their proper place: where I hall hew, with how much judgment they have been us'd by Virgil; and in the mean time pas to another Article of his defence on the preent Subject: where if I cannot clear the Heroe, I hope at leat to bring off the Poet; for here I mut divide their Caues. Let Aeneas trut to his Machine, which will only help to break his Fall, but the Addres is incomparable. Plato, who borrow'd o much from Homer, and yet concluded for the Banihment of all Poets, wou'd at leat have Rewarded Virgil, before he ent him into Exile. But I go farther, and ay, that he ought to be acquitted, and deerv'd beide, the Bounty of Augutus, and the gratitude of the Roman People. If after this, the Ladies will tand out, let them remember, that the Jury is not all agreed; for Octavia was of his Party, and was alo of the firt Quality in Rome; he was preent at the reading of the Sixth Aeneid, and we know not that he condemn'd Aeneas; but we are ure he preented the Poet, for his admirable Elegy on her Son Marcellus.

But let us conider the ecret Reaons which Virgil had, for thus framing this Noble Epiode, wherein the whole paion of Love is more exactly decrib'd than in any other Poet. Love was the Theme of his Fourth Book; and though it is the hortet of the whole Aeneis, yet there he has given its beginning, its progres, its traveres, and its concluion. And had exhauted o entirely this Subject, that he cou'd reume it but very lightly in the Eight enuing Books.

She was warm'd with the graceful appearance of the Heroe, he mother'd thoe Sparkles out of decency, but Converation blew them up into a Flame. Then he was forc'd to make a Confident of her whom he bet might trut, her own Siter, who approves the paion, and thereby augments it, then ucceeds her publick owning it; and after that, the conummation. Of Venus and Juno, Jupiter and Mercury I ay nothing, for they were all Machining work; but poeion having cool'd his Love, as it increas'd hers, he oon perceiv'd the change, or at leat grew upicious of a change; this upicion oon turn'd to Jealouie, and Jealouie to Rage; then he didains and threatens, and again is humble, and intreats; and nothing availing, depairs, cures, and at lat becomes her own Executioner. See here the whole proces of that paion, to which nothing can be added. I dare go no farther, let I hou'd loe the connection of my Dicoure.

To love our Native Country, and to tudy its Benefit and its Glory, to be intereed in its Concerns, is Natural to all Men, and is indeed our common Duty. A Poet makes a farther tep; for endeavouring to do honour to it, 'tis allowable in him even to be partial in its Caue; for he is not ty'd to truth, or fetter'd by the Laws of Hitory. Homer and Tao are jutly prais'd for chuing their Heroes out of Greece and Italy; Virgil indeed made his a Trojan, but it was to derive the Romans, and his own Augutus from him; but all the three Poets are manifetly partial to their Heroes, in favour of their Country. For Dares Phrygius reports of Hector, that he was lain Cowardly; Aeneas according to the bet account, lew not Mezentius, but was lain by him: and the Chronicles of Italy tell us little of that Rinaldo d'Etè
who Conquers Jerualem in Tao. He might be a Champion of the Church; but we know not that he was o much as preent at the Siege. To apply this to Virgil, he thought himelf engag'd in Honour to epoue the Caue and Quarrel of his Country againt Carthage. He knew he cou'd not pleae the Romans better, or oblige them more to Patronize his Poem, than by digracing the Foundres of that City. He hews her ungrateful to the Memory of her firt Husband, doting on a Stranger; enjoy'd, and afterwards foraken by him. This was the Original, ays he, of the immortal hatred betwixt the two Rival Nations. 'Tis true, he colours the falehood of Aeneas by an expres Command from Jupiter, to forake the Queen, who had oblig'd him: but he knew the Romans were to be his Readers, and them he brib'd, perhaps at the expence of his Heroe's honety, but he gain'd his Caue however; as Pleading before Corrupt Judges. They were content to ee their Founder fale to Love, for till he had the advantage of the Amour: It was their Enemy whom he forook, and he might have foraken him, if he had not got the tart of her: he had already forgotten her Vows to her Sichaeus; and varium & mutabile emper femina, is the harpet Satire in the fewet words that was ever made on Womankind; for both the Adjectives are Neuter, and Animal mut be undertood, to make them Grammar. Virgil does well to put thoe words into the mouth of Mercury. If a God had not poken them, neither durt he have written them, nor I tranlated them. Yet the Deity was forc'd to come twice on the ame Errand: and the econd time, as much a Heroe as Aeneas was, he frighted him. It eems he fear'd not Jupiter o much as Dido. For your Lordhip may oberve, that as much intent as he was upon his Voyage, yet he till delay'd it, 'till the Meenger was oblig'd to tell him plainly, that if he weigh'd not Anchor in the Night, the Queen wou'd be with him in the Morning. Notum
que furens quid femina poit; he was Injur'd, he was Revengeful, he was Powerful. The Poet had likewie before hinted, that her People were naturally perfidious: For he gives their Character in their Queen, and makes a Proverb of Punica fides, many Ages before it was invented.

Thus I hope, my Lord, that I have made good my Promie, and jutify'd the Poet, whatever becomes of the fale Knight. And ure a Poet is as much priviledg'd to lye, as an Ambaador, for the Honour and Interet of his Country; at leat as Sir Henry Wootton has defin'd.

This naturally leads me to the defence of the Famous Anachronim, in making Aeneas and Dido Contemporaries. For 'tis certain that the Heroe liv'd almot two hundred years before the Building of Carthage. One who imitates Bocaline, ays that Virgil was accus'd before Apollo for this Error. The God oon found that he was not able to defend his Favourite by Reaon, for the Cae was clear: he therefore gave this middle Sentence; That any thing might be allow'd to his Son Virgil on the account of his other Merits; That being a Monarch he had a dipening Power, and pardon'd him. But that this pecial Act of Grace might never be drawn into Example, or pleaded by his puny Succeors, in jutification of their ignorance; he decreed for the future, No Poet hou'd preume to make a Lady die for Love two hundred years before her Birth. To Moralize this Story, Virgil is the Apollo, who has this Dipening Power. His great Judgment made the Laws of Poetry, but he never made himelf a Slave to them:
Chronology at bet is but a Cobweb-Law, and he broke through it with his weight. They who will imitate him wiely, mut chue as he did, an obcure and a remote Aera, where they may invent at pleaure, and not be eaily contradicted. Neither he, nor the Romans had ever read the Bible, by which only his fale computation of times can be made out againt him: this Segrais ays in his defence, and proves it from his Learned Friend Bochartus, whoe Letter on this Subject, he has Printed at the end of the Fourth Aeneid, to which I referr your Lordhip, and the Reader. Yet the Credit of Virgil was o great, that he made this Fable of his own Invention pas for an Authentick Hitory, or at leat as credible as any thing in Homer. Ovid takes it up after him, even in the ame Age, and makes an ancient Heroine of Virgil's new-created Dido; Dictates a Letter for her jut before her death, to the ingrateful Fugitive; and very unluckily for himelf, is for meauring a Sword with a Man o much uperiour in force to him on the ame ubject. I think I may be Judge of this, becaue I have Tranlated both. The Famous Author of the Art of Love has nothing of his own, he borrows all from a greater Mater in his own profeion; and which is wore, improves nothing which he finds. Nature fails him, and being forc'd to his old hift, he has recoure to Witticim. This paes indeed with his Soft Admirers, and gives him the preference to Virgil in their eteem. But let them like for themelves, and not precribe to others, for our Author needs not their Admiration.

The Motives that induc'd Virgil to Coyn this Fable, I have hew'd already; and have alo begun to hew that he might make this Anacronim, by upereding the mechanick Rules of Poetry, for the ame Reaon, that a Monarch may dipene with, or upend his own Laws, when he finds it neceary o to do; epecially if thoe Laws are not altogether fundamental. Nothing is to be call'd a fault in Poetry, ays Aritotle, but what is againt the Art; therefore a Man may be an admirable Poet, without being an exact Chronologer. Shall we dare, continues Segrais, to condemn Virgil, for having made a Fiction againt the order of time, when we commend Ovid and other Poets who have made many of their Fictions againt the Order of Nature? For what are ele the plendid Miracles of the Metamorphoes? Yet thee are Beautiful as they are related; and have alo deep Learning and intructive Mythologies couch'd under them: But to give, as Virgil does in this Epiode, the Original Caue of the long Wars betwixt Rome and Carthage, to draw Truth out of Fiction, after o probable a manner, with o much Beauty, and o much for the Honour of his Country, was proper only to the Divine Wit of Maro; and Tao in one of his Dicoures, admires him for this particularly. 'Tis not lawful indeed, to contradict a Point of Hitory, which is known to all the World; as for Example, to make Hannibal and Scipio Contemporaries with Alexander; but in the dark Recees of Antiquity, a great Poet may and ought to feign uch things as he finds not there, if they can be brought to embelih that Subject which he treats. On the other ide, the pains and diligence of ill Poets is but thrown away, when they want the Genius to invent and feign agreeably. But if the Fictions be delightful, which they always are, if they be natural, if they be of a piece; if the beginning, the middle, and the end be in their due places, and artfully united to each other, uch Works can never fail of their deerv'd Succes. And uch is Virgil's Epiode of
Dido and Aeneas; where the ouret Critick mut acknowledge' that if he had depriv'd his Aeneis of o great an Ornament, becaue he found no traces of it in Antiquity, he had avoided their unjut Cenure, but had wanted one of the greatet Beauties of his Poem. I hall ay more of this, in the next Article of their Charge againt him, which is want of Invention. In the mean time I may affirm in honour of this Epiode, that it is not only now eteem'd the mot pleaing entertainment of the Aeneis, but was o accounted in his own Age; and before it was mellow'd into that reputation, which time has given it; for which I need produce no other tetimony, than that of Ovid, his Contemporary.

q.l: Nec pars ulla magis legitur de Corpore toto
Quam non legitimo faedere, junctus Amor.

div.p:
Where by the way, you may oberve, my Lord, that Ovid in thoe words, Non legitimo faedere junctus Amor, will by no means allow it to be a lawful Marriage betwixt Dido and Aeneas. He was in Banihment when he wrote thoe Veres, which I cite from his Letter to Augutus. You, Sir, ays he, have ent me into Exile for writing my Art of Love, and my wanton Elegies; yet your own Poet was happy in your good graces, though he brought Dido and Aeneas into a Cave, and left them there not over-honetly together. May I be o bold to ask your Majety, is it a greater fault to teach the Art of unlawful Love, than to hew it in the Action? But was Ovid the Court-Poet o bad a Courtier, as to find no other Plea to excue himelf, than by a plain accuation of his Mater? Virgil confes'd it was a Lawful Marriage betwixt the Lovers; that Juno the Goddes of Matrimony had ratify'd it by her preence, for it was her buines to bring Matters to that iue. That the Ceremonies were hort we may believe, for Dido was not only amorous, but a Widow. Mercury himelf, though employ'd on a quite contrary Errand, yet owns it a Marriage by an innuendo: Palchram
que
xorius rbem Extruis—He calls Aeneas not only a Husband, but upbraids him with being a fond Huband, as the word xorius implies. Now mark a little, if your Lordhip pleaes, why Virgil is o much concern'd to make this Marriage (for he eems to be the Father of the Bride himelf, and to give her to the Bridegroom) it was to make way for the Divorce which he intended afterwards; for he was a finer Flatterer than Ovid: and I more than conjecture that he had in his eye the Divorce which not long before had pas'd betwixt the Emperour and Scribonia. He drew this dimple in the Cheek of Aeneas, to prove Augutus of the ame Family, by o remarkable a Feature in the ame place. Thus, as we ay in our home-pun Englih Proverb, He kill'd two Birds with one tone; pleas'd the Emperour by giving him the reemblance of his Ancetor; and gave him uch a reemblance as was not candalous in that Age. For to leave one Wife and take another, was but a matter of Gallantry at that time of day among the Romans. Neque haec in faedera veni, is the very Excue which Aeneas makes, when he leaves his Lady. I made no uch Bargain with you at our Marriage, to live always drudging on at Carthage; my buines was Italy, and I never made a ecret of it. If I took my pleaure, had not you your hare of it? I leave you free at my departure, to comfort your elf with the next Stranger who happens to be Shipwreck'd on your Coat. Be as kind an Hotes as
you have been to me, and you can never fail of another Husband. In the mean time, I call the Gods to witnes, that I leave your Shore unwillingly; for though Juno made the Marriage, yet Jupiter Commands me to forake you. This is the effect of what he ays, when it is dihonour'd out of Latin Vere, into Englih Proe. If the Poet argued not aright, we mut pardon him for a poor blind Heathen, who knew no better Morals.

I have detain'd your Lordhip longer than I intended on this Objection: Which wou'd indeed weigh omething in a Spiritual Court; but I am not to defend our Poet there. The next I think is but a Cavil, though the Cry is great againt him, and has continu'd from the time of Macrobius to this preent Age. I hinted it before. They lay no les than want of Invention to his Charge. A capital Crime I mut acknowledge. For a Poet is a Maker, as the word ignifies: And who cannot make, that is, invent, has his Name for nothing. That which makes this Accuation look o trange at the firt ight, is, That he has borrow'd o many things from Homer, Appollonius Rhodius, and others who preceded him. But in the firt place, if Invention is to be taken in o trict a ene, that the Matter of a Poem mut be wholly new, and that in all its Parts; then Scaliger has made out, ays Segrais, that the Hitory of Troy was no more the Invention of Homer, than of Virgil. There was not an Old Woman, or almot a Child, but had it in their Mouths, before the Greek Poet or his Friends digeted it into this admirable order in which we read it. At this rate, as Solomon has told us, there is nothing new beneath the Sun: Who then can pas for an Inventor, if Homer, as well as Virgil mut be depriv'd of that Glory? Is Verailles the les a New Building, becaue the Architect of that Palace has imitated others which were built before it? Walls, Doors and Windows, Apartments, Offices, Rooms of convenience and Magnificence, are in all great Houes. So Decriptions Figures, Fables, and the ret, mut be in all Heroick Poems. They are the Common Materials of Poetry, furnih'd from the Magazine of Nature: Every Poet has as much right to them, as every Man has to Air or Water. Quid prohibetis Aquas? us communis aquarum et. But the Argument of the Work, that is to ay, its principal Action, the Oeconomy and Dipoition of it; thee are the things which ditinguih Copies from Originals. The Poet, who borrows nothing from others, is yet to be Born. He and the Jews Meias will come together. There are parts of the Aeneis, which reemble ome parts both of the Ilias and of the Odyes; as for Example, Aeneas decended into Hell, and lyes had been there before him: Aeneas lov'd Dido, and lyes lov'd Calypo: In few words, Virgil has imitated Homer's Odyes in his firt ix Books, and in his ix lat the Ilias. But from hence can we infer, that the two Poets write the ame Hitory? Is there no invention in ome other parts of Virgil's Aeneis? The dipoition of o many various matters, is not that his own? From what Book of Homer had Virgil his Epiode of Nyus and Euryalus, of Mezentius and Lauus? From whence did he borrow his Deign of bringing Aeneas into Italy, of Etablihing the Roman Empire on the Foundations of a Trojan Colony; to ay nothing of the honour he did his Patron, not only in his decent from Venus, but in making him o like him in his bet Features, that the Goddes might have mitaken Augutus for her Son. He had indeed the Story from common Fame, as Homer had his from the Egyptian Prietes. Aeneadum Genetrix was no more unknown to Lucretius than to him. But Lucretius taught him
not to form his Heroe; to give him Piety or Valour for his Manners; and both in o eminent a degree, that having done what was poible for Man, to ave his King and Country; his Mother was forc'd to appear to him and retrain his Fury, which hurry'd him to death in their Revenge. But the Poet made his Piety more uccesful; he brought off his Father and his Son; and his Gods witnes'd to his Devotion, by putting themelves under his Protection; to be re-plac'd by him in their promis'd Italy. Neither the Invention, nor the Conduct of this great Action, were owing to Homer or any other Poet. 'Tis one thing to Copy, and another thing to imitate from Nature. The Copyer is that ervile Imitator, to whom Horace gives no better a Name than that of Animal: He will not o much as allow him to be a Man. Raphael imitated Nature: They who Copy one of Raphael's Pieces, imitate but him, for his Work is their Original. They Tranlate him as I do Virgil; and fall as hort of him as I of Virgil. There is a kind of Invention in the imitation of Raphael; for though the thing was in Nature, yet the Idea of it was his own. lyes Travell'd, o did Aeneas; but neither of them were the firt Travellers; for Cain went into the Land of Nod, before they were born: And neither of the Poets ever heard of uch a Man. If lyes had been kill'd at Troy, yet Aeneas mut have gone to Sea, or he could never have arriv'd in Italy. But the deigns of the two Poets were as different as the Coures of their Heroes; one went Home, and the other ought a Home. To return to my firt imilitude: Suppoe Apelles and Raphael had each of them Painted a burning Troy; might not the Modern Painter have ucceeded as well as the Ancient, tho' neither of them had een the Town on Fire? For the draughts of both were taken from the Idea's which they had of Nature. Cities had been burnt before either of them were in Being. But to Cloe the Simile as I begun it; they wou'd not have deign'd after the ame manner. Apelles wou'd have ditinguih'd Pyrrhus from the ret of all the Grecians, and hew'd him forcing his entrance into Priam's Palace; there he had et him in the fairet Light, and given him the chief place of all his Figures, becaue he was a Grecian, and he wou'd do Honour to his Country. Raphael, who was an Italian, and decended from the Trojans, wou'd have made Aeneas the Heroe of his piece: And perhaps not with his Father on his Back; his Son in one hand, his Bundle of Gods in the other, and his Wife following; (for an Act of Piety, is not half o graceful in a Picture as an Act of Courage:) He would rather have drawn him killing Androgeos, or ome other, Hand to Hand; and the blaze of the Fires hou'd have darted full upon his Face, to make him conpicuous amongt his Trojans. This I think is a jut Comparion betwixt the two Poets in the Conduct of their everal deigns. Virgil cannot be aid to copy Homer: The Grecian had only the advantage of writing firt. If it be urg'd that I have granted a reemblance in ome parts; yet therein Virgil has excell'd him: For what are the Tears of Calypo for being left, to the Fury and Death of Dido? Where is there the whole proces of her Paion, and all its violent Effects to be found, in the languihing Epiode of the Odyes? If this be to Copy, let the Criticks hew us the ame Dipoition, Features, or Colouring in their Original. The like may be aid of the Decent to Hell; which was not of Homer's Invention neither: He had it from the Story of Orpheus and Eurydice. But to what end did lyes make that Journey? Aeneas undertook it by the expres Commandment of his Father's Ghot: There he was to
hew him all the ucceeding Heroes of his Race; and next to Romulus, (mark, if you pleae, the Addres of Virgil) his own Patron Augutus Caear. Anchies was likewie to intruct him, how to manage the Italian War; and how to conclude it with his Honour. That is, in other words, to lay the Foundations of that Empire which Augutus was to Govern. This is the Noble Invention of our Author: But it has been Copyed by o many Sign-pot Daubers; that now 'tis grown fulom, rather by their want of Skill, than by the Commonnes.

In the lat place I may afely grant, that by reading Homer, Virgil was taught to imitate his Invention: That is, to imitate like him; which is no more, than if a Painter tudied Raphael, that he might learn to deign after his manner. And thus I might imitate Virgil, if I were capable of writing an Heroick Poem, and yet the Invention be my own: But I hou'd endeavour to avoid a ervile Copying. I would not give the ame Story under other Names: With the ame Characters, in the ame Order, and with the ame Sequel: For every common Reader to find me out at the firt ight for a Plagiary: And cry, this I read before in Virgil, in a better Language, and in better Vere: This is like merry Andrew on the low Rope, copying lubberly the ame Tricks, which his Mater is dextrouly performing on the high.

I will trouble your Lordhip but with one Objection more; which I know not whether I found in Le Fevre or Valois, but I am ure I have read it in another French Critick, whom I will not name, becaue I think it is not much for his Reputation. Virgil, in the heat of Action, uppoe for Example, in decribing the fury of his Heroe in a Battel, when he is endeavouring to raie our concernments to the highet pitch, turns hort on the udden into ome imilitude, which diverts, ay they, your attention from the main Subject, and mipends it on ome trivial Image. He pours cold Water into the Caldron when his buines is to make it boil.

This Accuation is general againt all who wou'd be thought Heroick Poets; but I think it touches Virgil les than any. He is too great a Mater of his Art, to make a Blott which may o eaily be hit. Similitudes, as I have aid, are not for Tragedy, which is all violent, and where the Paions are in a perpetual ferment; for there they deaden where they hould animate; they are not of the nature of Dialogue, unles in Comedy: A Metaphor is almot all the Stage can uffer, which is a kind of Similitude comprehended in a word. But this Figure has a contrary effect in Heroick Poetry: There 'tis employ'd to raie the Admiration, which is its proper buines. And Admiration is not of o violent a nature as Fear or Hope, Compaion or Horrour, or any Concernment we can have for uch or uch a Peron on the Stage. Not but I confes, that Similitudes and Decriptions, when drawn into an unreaonable length, mut needs naueate the Reader. Once I remember, and but once; Virgil makes a Similitude of fourteen Lines; and his decription of Fame is about the ame number. He is blam'd for both; and I doubt not but he would have contracted them, had he liv'd to have review'd his Work: But Faults are no Precedents. This I have oberv'd of his Similitudes in general, that they are not plac'd, as our unoberving Criticks tell us, in the heat of any Action: But commonly in its declining: When he has warm'd us in his Decription, as much as poibly he can; then, let that warmth hould languih, he renews it by ome apt Similitude, which illutrates his Subject, and yet palls not his Audience. I need give your Lordhip
but one Example of this kind, and leave the ret to your Obervation, when next you review the whole Aeneis in the Original unblemih'd by my rude Tranlation. 'Tis in the firt Book, where the Poet decribes Neptune compoing the Ocean, on which Eolus had rais'd a Tempet, without his permiion. He had already chidden the Rebellious Winds for obeying the Commands of their Uurping Mater: He had warn'd them from the Seas, He had beaten down the Billows with his Mace; dipell'd the Clouds, retor'd the Sun-hine, while Triton and Cymothoe were heaving the Ships from off the Quick-Sands; before the Poet wou'd offer at a Similitude for illutration.

q.l: Ac, veluti magno in populo cùm aepe coorta et
Seditio, aevitque animis ignobile vulgus,
Jamque faces, & axa volant, furor arma minitrat;
Tum, pietate gravem, ac meritis i forte virum quem
Conpexere, ilent, arrectique auribus adtant:
Ille regit dictis animos, & pectora mulcet:
Sic cunctus pelagi cecidit fragor, aequora potquam
Propiciens genitor, caeloque invectus aperto
Flectit equos, currúque volans dat lora ecundo.

div.p: This is the firt Similitude which Virgil makes in this Poem: And one of the longet in the whole; for which Reaon I the rather cite it. While the Storm was in its fury, any Alluion had been improper: For the Poet cou'd have compar'd it to nothing more impetuous than it elf; conequently he could have made no Illutration. If he cou'd have illutrated, it had been an ambitious Ornament out of eaon, and would have diverted our Concernment: Nunc, non erat hice locus; and therefore he deferr'd it to its proper place.

Thee are the Criticims of mot moment which have been made againt the Aeneis, by the Ancients or Moderns. As for the particular Exceptions againt this or that paage, Macrobius and Pontanus have anwer'd them already. If I deir'd to appear more Learned than I am, it had been as eaie for me to have taken their Objections and Solutions, as it is for a Country Paron to take the Expoitions of the Fathers out of Junius and Tremellius: Or not to have nam'd the Authors from whence I had them: For o Ruaeus, otherwie a mot judicious Commentator on Virgil's Works, has us'd Pontanus, his greatet Benefactor, of whom, he is very ilent, and I do not remember that he once cites him.

What follows next, is no Objection; for that implies a Fault: And it had been none in Virgil, if he had extended the time of his Action beyond a Year. At leat Aritotle has et no precie limits to it. Homer's, we know, was within two Months: Tao I am ure exceeds not a Summer: And if I examin'd him, perhaps he might be reduc'd into a much les compas. Bou leaves it doubtful whether Virgil's Action were within the Year, or took up ome Months beyond it. Indeed the whole Dipute is of no more concernment to the common Reader, than it is to a Plough-man, whether February this Year had 28 or 29 Days in it. But for the atisfaction of the more Curious, of which number, I am ure your Lordhip is one; I will Tranlate what I think convenient out of Segrais, whom perhaps you have not read: For he has made it highly probable, that the Action of the Aeneis began in the Spring, and was not extended beyond the Autumn.
And we have known Campaigns that have begun ooner, and have ended later.

Ronard and the ret whom Segrais names, who are of Opinion that the Action of this Poem takes up almot a Year and half; ground their Calculation thus. Anchies dyed in Sicily at the end of Winter, or beginning of the Spring. Aeneas, immediately after the Interment of his Father, puts to Sea for Italy: He is urpriz'd by the Tempet decrib'd in the beginning of the firt Book; and there it is that the Scene of the Poem opens; and where the Action mut Commence. He is driven by this Storm on the Coats of Affrick: He tays at Carthage all that Summer, and almot all the Winter following: Sets Sail again for Italy jut before the beginning of the Spring; meets with contrary Winds, and makes Sicily the econd time: This part of the Action compleats the Year. Then he celebrates the Aniverary of his Father's Funerals, and hortly after arrives at Cumes, and from thence his time is taken up in his firt Treaty with Latinus; the Overture of the War; the Siege of his Camp by Turnus; his going for Succours to relieve it: His return: The raiing of the Siege by the firt Battel: The twelve days Truce: The econd Battel: The Aault of Laurentum, and the ingle Fight with Turnus; all which, they ay, cannot take up les than four or five Months more; by which Account we cannot uppoe the entire Action to be contain'd in a much les compas than a Year and half.
Segrais reckons another way; and his computation is not condemn'd by the learned Ruaeus, who compil'd and Publih'd the Commentaries on our Poet, which we call the Dauphin's Virgil.

He allows the time of Year when Anchies dyed; to be in the latter end of Winter, or the beginning of the Spring; he acknowledges that when Aeneas is firt een at Sea afterwards, and is driven by the Tempet on the Coat of Affrick, is the time when the Action is naturally to begin: He confees farther, that Aeneas left Carthage in the latter end of Winter; for Dido tells him in expres terms, as an Argument for his longer tay, Quinetiam Hyberno moliris ydere Claem.

But whereas Ronard's Followers uppoe that when Aeneas had buried his Father, he et Sail immediately for Italy, (tho' the Tempet drove him on the Coat of Carthage.) Segrais will by no means allow that Suppoition; but thinks it much more probable that he remain'd in Sicily 'till the midt of July or the beginning of Augut; at which time he places the firt appearance of his Heroe on the Sea; and there opens the Action of the Poem. From which beginning, to the Death of Turnus, which concludes the Action, there need not be uppos'd above ten Months of intermediate time: For arriving at Carthage in the latter end of Summer, taying there the Winter following; departing thence in the very beginning of the Spring; making a hort abode in Sicily the econd time, landing in Italy, and making the War, may be reaonably judg'd the buines but of three Months. To this the Ronardians reply, that having been for Seven Years before in quet of Italy, and having no more to do in Sicily, than to interr his Father; after that Office was perform'd, what remain'd for him, but, without delay, to purue his firt Adventure? To which Segrais anwers, that the Obequies of his Father, according to the Rites of the Greeks and
Romans, would detain him for many days: That a longer time mut be taken up in the refitting of his Ships, after o tedious a Voyage; and in refrehing his Weather-beaten Souldiers on a friendly Coat. Thee indeed are but Suppoitions on both ides, yet thoe of Segrais eem better grounded. For the Feat of Dido, when he entertain'd Aeneas firt, has the appearance of a Summer's Night, which eems already almot ended, when he begins his Story: Therefore the Love was made in Autumn; the Hunting follow'd properly when the Heats of that corching Country were declining: The Winter was pas'd in jollity, as the Seaon and their Love requir'd; and he left her in the latter end of Winter, as is already prov'd. This Opinion is fortify'd by the Arrival of Aeneas at the Mouth of Tyber; which marks the Seaon of the Spring, that Seaon being perfectly decrib'd by the inging of the Birds, aluting the dawn; and by the Beauty of the place, which the Poet eems to have painted exprely in the Seventh Aeneid.

q.l: Aurora in roeis fulgebat lutea bigis:
Cùm venti pouere; variae circumque, upraque
Auetae ripis volucres, & fluminis alveo,
Aethera mulcebant cantu.

div.p: The remainder of the Action requir'd but three Months more; for when Aeneas went for Succour to the Tucans, he found their Army in a readines to march; and wanting only a Commander: So that according to this Calculation, the Aeneis takes not up above a Year compleat, and may be comprehended in les compas.

This, amongt other Circumtances, treated more at large by Segrais, agrees with the riing of Orion, which caus'd the Tempet, decrib'd in the beginning of the firt Book. By ome paages in the Patorals, but more particularly in the Georgicks, our Poet is found to be an exact Atronomer, according to the Knowledge of that Age. Now Ilioneus (whom Virgil twice employs in Embaies, as the bet Speaker of the Trojans) attributes that Tempet to Orion in his Speech to Dido.
div.q: Cum ubito, aurgens fluctu nimbous Orion.
div.p: He mut mean either the Heliacal or Achronical riing of that Sign. The Heliacal riing of a Contellation, is when it comes from under the Rays of the Sun, and begins to appear before Day-light. The Achronical riing, on the contrary, is when it appears at the cloe of Day, and in oppoition of the Sun's diurnal Coure.
The Heliacal riing of Orion, is at preent computed to be about the ixth of July; and about that time it is, that he either caues, or preages Tempets on the Seas.
Segrais has oberv'd farther, that when Anna Counels Dido to tay Aeneas during the Winter; he peaks alo of Orion; Dum pelago deaevit hyems, & aquous Orion.

If therefore Ilioneus, according to our Suppoition, undertand the Heliacal riing of Orion: Anna mut mean the Achronical, which the different Epithetes given to that Contellation, eem to manifet. Ilioneus calls him nimbous, Anna aquous. He is tempetuous in the Summer
when he ries Heliacally, and Rainy in the Winter when he ries Achronically. Your Lordhip will pardon me for the frequent repetition of thee cant words; which I cou'd not avoid in this abbreviation of Segrais; who I think deerves no little commendation in this new Criticim. I have yet a word or two to ay of Virgil's Machines, from my own obervation of them. He has imitated thoe of Homer, but not Copied them. It was etablih'd long before this time, in the Roman Religion as well as in the Greek; that there were Gods; and both Nations, for the mot part, worhipp'd the ame Deities; as did alo the Trojans: From whom the Romans, I uppoe, wou'd rather be thought to derive the Rites of their Religion, than from the Grecians; becaue they thought themelves decended from them. Each of thoe Gods had his proper Office, and the chief of them their particular Attendants. Thus Jupiter had in propriety, Ganimede and Mercury; and Juno had Iris. It was not then for Virgil to create new Miniters; he mut take what he found in his Religion. It cannot therefore be aid that he borrow'd them from Homer, any more than Apollo, Diana, and the ret, whom he ues as he finds occaion for them, as the Grecian Poet did: But he invents the occaions for which he ues them. Venus, after the detruction of Troy, had gain'd Neptune entirely to her Party; therefore we find him buie in the beginning of the Aeneis, to calm the Tempet rais'd by Aeolus, and afterwards conducting the Trojan Fleet to Cumes in afety, with the los only of their Pilot; for whom he Bargains. I name thoe two Examples amongt a hundred which I omit; to prove that Virgil, generally peaking, employ'd his Machines in performing thoe things, which might poibly have been done without them. What more frequent then a Storm at Sea, upon the riing of Orion? What wonder, if amongt o many Ships there hou'd one be overet, which was commanded by Orontes; though half the Winds had not been there, which Aeolus employ'd? Might not Palinurus, without a Miracle, fall aleep, and drop into the Sea, having been over-wearied with watching, and ecure of a quiet paage, by his obervation of the Skies? At leat Aeneas, who knew nothing of the Machine of Somnus, takes it plainly in this Sene.

q.l: O nimium Coelo & Pelago confie ereno,
Nudus in ignotâ Palinure jacebis arenâ.

div.p: But Machines ometimes are pecious things to amue the Reader, and give a colour of probability to things otherwie incredible. And beides, it ooth'd the vanity of the Romans, to find the Gods o viibly concern'd in all the Actions of their Predeceors. We who are better taught by our Religion, yet own every wonderful Accident which befalls us for the bet, to be brought to pas by ome pecial Providence of Almighty God; and by the care of guardian Angels: And from hence I might infer, that no Heroick Poem can be writ on the Epicuraean Principles. Which I cou'd eaily demontrate, if there were need to prove it, or I had leiure.

When Venus opens the Eyes of her Son Aeneas, to behold the Gods who Combated againt Troy, in that fatal Night when it was urpriz'd; we hare the pleaure of that glorious Viion, (which Tao has not ill Copied in the acking of Jerualem.) But the Greeks had done their buines; though neither Neptune, Juno, or Pallas, had given them their Divine aitance. The mot crude Machine which Virgil ues, is in
the Epiode of Camilla, where Opis by the command of her Mitres, kills Aruns. The next is in the Twelfth Aeneid, where Venus cures her Son Aeneas. But in the lat of thee, the Poet was driven to a neceity; for Turnus was to be lain that very day: And Aeneas, wounded as he was, cou'd not have Engag'd him in ingle Combat, unles his Hurt had been miraculouly heal'd. And the Poet had conider'd that the Dittany which he brought from Crete, cou'd not have wrought o peedy an effect, without the Juice of Ambroia, which he mingled with it. After all, that his Machine might not eem too violent, we ee the Heroe limping after Turnus. The Wound was skin'd; but the trength of his Thigh was not retor'd. But what Reaon had our Author to wound Aeneas at o critical a time? And how came the Cuies to be wore temper'd than the ret of his Armour, which was all wrought by Vulcan and his Journey-men? Thee difficulties are not eaily to be olv'd, without confeing that Virgil had not life enough to correct his Work: Tho' he had review'd it, and found thoe Errours which he reolv'd to mend: But being prevented by Death, and not willing to leave an imperfect work behind him, he ordain'd, by his lat Tetament, that his Aeneis hould be burn'd. As for the death of Aruns, who was hot by a Goddes, the Machine was not altogether o outragious, as the wounding Mars and Venus by the Sword of Diomede. Two Divinities, one wou'd have thought, might have pleaded their Prerogative of Impaibility, or, at leat not to have been wounded by any mortal Hand. Beide that the < in non-Latin alphabet > which they hed, was o very like our common Blood, that it was not to be ditinguih'd from it, but only by the Name and Colour. As for what Horate ays in his Art of Poetry; that no Machines are to be us'd, unles on ome extraordinary occaion, Nec Deus interit, nii dignus vindice nodus. That Rule is to be apply'd to the Theatre, of which he is then peaking, and means no more than this, that when the Knot of the Play is to be unty'd, and no other way is left, for making the dicovery; then and not otherwie, let a God decend upon a Rope, and clear the Buines to the Audience: But this has no relation to the Machines which are us'd in an Epick Poem.

In the lat place, for the Dira, or Flying-Pet, which flapping on the Shield of Turnus, and fluttering about his Head, dihearten'd him in the Duel, and preag'd to him his approaching Death, I might have plac'd it more properly amongt the Objections. For the Criticks, who lay want of Courage to the Charge of Virgil's Heroe; quote this Paage as a main proof of their Aertion. They ay our Author had not only ecur'd him before the Duel, but alo in the beginning of it, had given him the advantage in impenetrable Arms, and in his Sword: (for that of Turnus was not his own, which was forg'd by Vulcan for his Father) but a Weapon which he had natch'd in hate, and by mitake, belonging to his Charioteer Meticus. That after all this, Jupiter, who was partial to the Trojan, and ditrutful of the Event, though he had hung the Ballance, and given it a jog of his hand to weigh down Turnus, thought convenient to give the Fates a collatteral Security, by ending the Screech-Owl to dicourage him. For which they quote thee words of Virgil.

q.l: Non me tua turbida virtus,
Terret ait; Dii me terrent, & Jupiter Hotis.

div.p:
In anwer to which, I ay, that this Machine is one of thoe which the Poet ues only for Ornament, and not out of Neceity. Nothing can be more Beautiful, or more Poetical than his decription of the three Dirae, or the etting of the Balance, which our Milton has borrow'd from him, but employ'd to a different end: For firt he makes God Almighty et the Scales for St. Michael and Sathan, when he knew no Combat was to follow; then he makes the good Angel's Scale decend, and the Devils mount; quite contrary to Virgil, if I have Tranlated the three Veres, according to my Author's Sene.
Jupiter ipe duas, aequato Examine lances
Sutinet; & fata imponit divera duorum:
Quem damnet labor, & quo vergat pondere lethum.

For I have taken thee words Quem damnet labor, in the Sene which Virgil gives them in another place; Damnabis tu quoque votis; to ignifie a properous Event. Yet I dare not condemn o great a Genius as Milton: For I am much mitaken if he alludes not to the Text in Daniel, where Belhazzar was put into the Balance, and found too light: This is digreion, and I return to my Subject. I aid above, that thee two Machines of the Balance, and the Dira, were only Ornamental, and that the ucces of the Duel had been the ame without them. For when Aeneas and Turnus tood fronting each other before the Altar, Turnus look'd dejected, and his Colour faded in his Face, as if he deponded of the Victory before the Fight; and not only he, but all his Party, when the trength of the two Champions was judg'd by the proportion of their Limbs, concluded it was impar pugna, and that their Chief was over-match'd: Whereupon Juturna (who was of the ame Opinion) took his opportunity to break the Treaty and renew the War. Juno her elf had plainly told the Nymph beforehand, that her Brother was to Fight Imparibus fatis; nec Diis, nec viribus aequis; So that there was no need of an Apparition to fright Turnus. He had the preage within himelf of his impending Detiny. The Dirae only erv'd to confirm him in his firt Opinion, that it was his Detiny to die in the enuing Combat. And in this ene are thoe words of Virgil to be taken.
Non me tua turbida virtus
Terret ait; Dii me terrent, & Jupiter Hotis.

I have dwelt o long on this Subject, that I mut contract what I have to ay, in reference to my Tranlation: Unles I wou'd well my Preface into a Volume, and make it formidable to your Lordhip, when you ee o many Pages yet behind. And indeed what I have already written either in jutification or praie of Virgil, is againt my elf; for preuming to Copy, in my coure Englih, the Thoughts and Beautiful Expreions of this inimitable Poet: Who flourih'd in an Age when his Language was brought to its lat perfection, for which it was particularly owing to him and Horace. I will give your Lordhip my Opinion, that thoe two Friends had conulted each others Judgment, wherein they hould endeavour to excel; and they eem to have pitch'd on Propriety of Thought, Elegance of Words, and Harmony of Numbers. According to this Model, Horace writ his Odes and Epods: For his Satires and Epitles, being intended wholly for intruction, requir'd another Style: Ornari res ipa negat, contenta doceri:

And therefore as he himelf profees, are Sermoni propiora, nearer Proe than Vere. But Virgil, who never attempted the Lyrick Vere, is every where Elegant, weet and flowing in his Hexameters. His words are not only choen, but the places in which he ranks them for the ound; he who removes them from the Station wherein their Mater ets them, poils the Harmony. What he ays of the Sybill's Prophecies, may be as properly apply'd to every word of his: They mut be read, in order as they lie; the leat breath dicompoes them, and omewhat of their Divinity is lot. I cannot boat that I have been thus exact in my Veres, but I have endeavour'd to follow the Example of my Mater: And am the firt Englihman, perhaps, who made it his deign to copy him in his Numbers, his choice of Words, and his placing them for the weetnes of the ound. On this lat Conideration, I have hun'd the Caeura as much as poibly I cou'd. For wherever that is us'd, it gives a roughnes to the Vere, of which we can have little need, in a Language which is over-tock'd with Cononants. Such is not the Latine, where the Vowels and Cononants are mix'd in proportion to each other: yet Virgil judg'd the Vowels to have omewhat of an over-balance, and therefore tempers their weetnes with Caeuras. Such difference there is in Tongues, that the ame Figure which roughens one, gives Majety to another: and that
was it which Virgil tudied in his Veres. Ovid ues it but rarely; and hence it is that his Verification cannot o properly be call'd weet, as lucious. The Italians are forc'd upon it, once or twice in every line, becaue they have a redundancy of Vowels in their Language. Their Metal is o oft, that it will not Coyn without Alloy to harden it. On the other ide, for the Reaon already nam'd, 'tis all we can do to give ufficient weetnes to our Language: We mut not only chue our words for Elegance, but for ound. To perform which, a Matery in the Language is requir'd; the Poet mut have a Magazine of Words, and have the Art to mannage his few Vowels to the bet advantage, that they may go the farther. He mut alo know the nature of the Vowels, which are more onorous, and which more oft and weet; and o dipoe them as his preent occaions require: All which, and a thouand ecrets of Verification beide, he may learn from Virgil, if he will take him for his Guide. If he be above Virgil, and is reolv'd to follow his own Verve (as the French call it,) the Proverb will fall heavily upon him; Who teaches himelf, has a Fool for his Mater.

Virgil employ'd Eleven Years upon his Aeneis, yet he left it as he thought himelf imperfect. Which when I eriouly conider, I wih, that intead of three years which I have pent in the Tranlation of his Works, I had four years more allow'd me to correct my Errours, that I might make my Verion omewhat more tolerable than it is. For a Poet cannot have too great a reverence for his Readers, if he expects his Labours hou'd urvive him. Yet I will neither plead my Age nor Sicknes in excue of the faults which I have made: That I wanted time is all I have to ay. For ome of my Subcribers grew o clamorous, that I cou'd no longer deferr the Publication. I hope from the Candour of your Lordhip, and your often experienc'd goodnes to me, that if the faults are not too many, you will make allowances with Horace.

q.l: Si plura nitent in Carmine, non ego paucis
Offendar macalis, quas aut incuria fudit,
Aut humana parùm cavit Natura.

div.p: You may pleae alo to oberve, that there is not, to the bet of my remembrance, one Vowel gaping on another for want of a Caeura, in this whole Poem. But where a Vowel ends a word, the next begins either with a Cononant, or what is its equivalent; for our W and H apirate, and our Dipthongues are plainly uch: The greatet latitude I take, is in the Letter Y, when it concludes a word, and the firt Syllable of the next begins with a Vowel. Neither need I have call'd this a latitude, which is only an explanation of this general Rule. That no Vowel can be cut off before another, when we cannot ink the Pronunciation of it: As He, She, Me, I, &c. Virgil thinks it ometimes a Beauty, to imitate the Licene of the Greeks, and leave two Vowels opening on each other, as in that Vere of the Third Patoral, Et uccus pecori & lac ubducitur Agnis.

But nobis non licet, ee tam diertis. At leat if we tudy to refine our Numbers. I have long had by me the Materials of an Englih Proodia, containing all the Mechanical Rules of Verification, wherein
I have treated with ome exactnes of the Feet, the Quantities, and the Paues. The French and Italians know nothing of the two firt; at leat their bet Poets have not practis'd them. As for the Paues, Malherb firt brought them into France, within this lat Century: And we ee how they adorn their Alexandrins. But as Virgil propounds a Riddle which he leaves unolv'd:
Dic quibus in terris, incripti nomina Regum
Nacantur flores, & Phyllida olus habeto.
So I will give your Lordhip another, and leave the Expoition of it to your acute Judgment. I am ure there are few who make Veres, have oberv'd the weetnes of thee two Lines in Coopers Hill.
Tho' deep, yet clear; though gentle, yet not dull;
Strong without rage, without o'reflowing, full.
And there are yet fewer who can find the Reaon of that weetnes. I have given it to ome of my Friends in Converation, and they have allow'd the Criticim to be jut. But ince the evil of fale quantities is difficult to be cur'd in any Modern Language; ince the French and the Italians as well as we, are yet ignorant what feet are to be us'd in Heroick Poetry; ince I have not trictly oberv'd thoe Rules my elf, which I can teach others; ince I pretend to no Dictatorhip among my Fellow-Poets; ince if I hou'd intruct ome of them to make well-running Veres, they want Genius to give them trength as well as weetnes; and above all, ince your Lordhip has advis'd me not to publih that little which I know, I look on your Counel as your Command, which I hall oberve inviolably, 'till you hall pleae to revoke it, and leave me at liberty to make my thoughts publick. In the mean time, that I may arrogate nothing to my elf, I mut acknowledge that Virgil in Latine, and Spencer in Englih, have been my Maters. Spencer has alo given me the boldnes to make ue ometimes of his Alexandrin Line, which we call, though improperly, the Pindarick; becaue Mr. Cowley has often employ'd it in his Odes. It adds a certain Majety to the Vere, when 'tis us'd with Judgment, and tops the ene from overflowing into another Line. Formerly the French, like us, and the Italians, had but five Feet, or ten Syllables in their Heroick Vere: but ince Ronard's time, as I uppoe, they found their Tongue too weak to upport their Epick Poetry, without the addition of another Foot. That indeed has given it omewhat of the run, and meaure of a Trimeter; but it runs with more activity than trength: Their Language is not trung with Sinews like our Englih. It has the nimblenes of a Greyhound, but not the bulk and body of a Matiff. Our Men and our Veres over-bear them by their weight; and Pondere non Numero, is the Britih Motto. The French have et up Purity for the Standard of their Language; and a Maculine Vigour is that of ours. Like their Tongue is the Genius of their Poets, light and trifling in comparion of the Englih; more proper for Sonnets, Madrigals, and Elegies, than Heroick Poetry. The turn on Thoughts and Words is their chief Talent, but the Epick Poem is too tately to receive thoe little Ornaments. The Painters draw their Nymphs in thin and airy Habits, but the weight of Gold and of Embroideries is reerv'd for Queens
and Goddees. Virgil is never frequent in thoe Turns, like Ovid, but much more paring of them in his Aeneis, than in his Patorals and Georgicks.
div.q: Ignocenda quidem, cirent i ignocere Manes.
div.p:
That turn is Beautiful indeed; but he employs it in the Story of Orpheus and Eurydice, not in his great Poem. I have us'd that Licene in his Aeneis ometimes: but I own it as my fault. 'Twas given to thoe who undertand no better. 'Tis like Ovid's Semivirum
que bovem, emibovem
que virum. The Poet found it before his Criticks, but it was a darling Sin which he wou'd not be perwaded to reform. The want of Genius, of which I have accus'd the French, is laid to their Charge by one of their own great Authors, though I have forgotten his Name, and where I read it. If Rewards cou'd make good Poets, their great Mater has not been wanting on his part in his bountiful Encouragements: For he is wie enough to imitate Augutus, if he had a Maro. The Triumvir and Procriber had decended to us in a more hideous form than they now appear, if the Emperour had not taken care to make Friends of him and Horace. I confes the Banihment of Ovid was a Blot in his Ecutcheon, yet he was only Banih'd, and who knows but his Crime was Capital, and then his Exile was a Favour? Arioto, who with all his faults, mut be acknowledg'd a great Poet, has put thee words into the mouth of an Evangelit, but whether they will pas for Gopel now, I cannot tell.

q.l: Non fu i anto ni benigno Auguto,
Come la tuba di Virgilio uona;
L'haver havuto, in poeia buon guto
La procrittione, iniqua gli perdona.

div.p:
But Heroick Poetry is not of the growth of France, as it might be of England, if it were Cultivated. Spencer wanted only to have read the Rules of Bou: for no Man was ever Born with a greater Genius, or had more Knowledge to upport it. But the performance of the French is not equal to their Skill; and hitherto we have wanted Skill to perform better. Segrais, whoe Preface is o wonderfully good, yet is wholly detitute of Elevation; though his Verion is much better than that of the two Brothers, or any of the ret who have attempted Virgil. Hannibal Caro is a great Name amongt the Italians, yet his Tranlation of the Aeneis is mot candalouly mean, though he has taken the advantage of writing in Blank Vere, and freed himelf from the hackles of modern Rhime: (if it be modern, for Le Clerc has told us lately, and I believe has made it out, that David's Palms were written in as errant Rhime as they are Tranlated.) Now if a Mue cannot run when he is unfetter'd, 'tis a ign he has but little peed. I will not make a digreion here, though I am trangely tempted to it; but will only ay, that he who can write well in Rhime, may write better in Blank Vere. Rhime is certainly a contraint even to the bet Poets, and thoe who make it with mot eae; though perhaps I have as little reaon to complain of that hardhip as any Man, excepting
Quarles, and Withers. What it adds to weetnes, it takes away from ene; and he who loes the leat by it, may be call'd a gainer: it often makes us werve from an Author's meaning. As if a Mark be et up for an Archer at a great ditance, let him aim as exactly as he can, the leat wind will take his Arrow, and divert it from the White. I return to our Italian Tranlatour of the Aeneis: He is a Foot-Poet, he Lacquies by the ide of Virgil at the bet, but never mounts behind him. Doctor Morelli, who is no mean Critick in our Poetry, and therefore may be preum'd to be a better in his own Language, has confirm'd me in this Opinion by his Judgment, and thinks withall, that he has often mitaken his Mater's Sene. I wou'd ay o, if I durt, but I am afraid I have committed the ame fault more often, and more groly: For I have foraken Ruaeus, (whom generally I follow) in many places, and made Expoitions of my own in ome, quite contrary to him. Of which I will give but two Examples, becaue they are o near each other in the Tenth Aeneid.
—Sorti Pater aequus utrique.
Pallas ays it to Turnus jut before they Fight. Ruaeus thinks that the word Pater is to be referr'd to Evander the Father of Pallas. But how cou'd he imagine that it was the ame thing to Evander, if his Son were lain, or if he overcame. The Poet certainly intended Jupiter the common Father of Mankind; who, as Pallas hop'd, wou'd tand an impartial Spectatour of the Combat, and not be more favourable to Turnus, than to him. The Second is not long after it, and both before the Duel is begun. They are the words of Jupiter, who comforts Hercules for the death of Pallas, which was immediately to enue, and which Hercules cou'd not hinder (though the young Heroe had addres'd his Prayers to him for his aitance:) Becaue the Gods cannot controul Detiny—the Vere follows. Sic ait; at
que oculos Rutulorum rejicit arvis. Which the ame Ruaeus thus contrues. Jupiter after he had aid this; immediately turns his eyes to the Rutulian Fields, and beholds the Duel. I have given this place another Expoition, that he turn'd his Eyes from the Field of Combat, that he might not behold a ight o unpleaing to him. The word Rejicit I know will admit of both enes; but Jupiter having confes'd that he could not alter Fate, and being griev'd he cou'd not, in conideration of Hercules, it eems to me that he hou'd avert his Eyes, rather than take pleaure in the Spectacle. But of this I am not o conident as the other, though I think I have follow'd Virgil's ene.

What I have aid, though it has the face of arrogance, yet is intended for the honour of my Country; and therefore I will boldly own, that this Englih Tranlation has more of Virgil's Spirit in it, than either the French, or the Italian. Some of our Country-men have tranlated Epiodes, and other parts of Virgil, with great Succes. As particularly your Lordhip, whoe Verion of Orpheus and Eurydice, is eminently good. Amongt the dead Authors, the Silenus of my Lord Rocommon cannot be too much commended. I ay nothing of Sir John Denham, Mr. Waller, and Mr. Cowley; 'tis the utmot of my Ambition to be thought their Equal, or not to be much
inferiour to them, and ome others of the Living. But 'tis one thing to take pains on a Fragment, and Tranlate it perfectly; and another thing to have the weight of a whole Author on my houlders. They who believe the burthen light, let them attempt the Fourth, Sixth or Eighth Patoral, the Firt or Fourth Georgick; and amongt the Aeneids, the Fourth, the Fifth, the Seventh, the Ninth, the Tenth, the Eleventh, or the Twelfth; for in thee I think I have ucceeded bet.

Long before I undertook this Work, I was no tranger to the Original. I had alo tudied Virgil's Deign, his dipoition of it, his Manners, his judicious management of the Figures, the ober retrenchments of his Sene, which always leaves omewhat to gratifie our imagination, on which it may enlarge at pleaure; but above all, the Elegance of his Expreions, and the harmony of his Numbers. For, as I have aid in a former Diertation, the words are in Poetry, what the Colours are in Painting. If the Deign be good, and the Draught be true, the Colouring is the firt Beauty that trikes the Eye. Spencer and Milton are the nearet in Englih to Virgil and Horace in the Latine; and have endeavour'd to form my Stile by imitating their Maters. I will farther own to you, my Lord, that my chief Ambition is to pleae thoe Readers, who have dicernment enough to prefer Virgil before any other Poet in the Latine Tongue. Such Spirits as he deir'd to pleae, uch wou'd I chue for my Judges, and wou'd tand or fall by them alone. Segrais has ditinguih'd the Readers of Poetry, according to their capacity of judging, into three Claes: (He might have aid the ame of Writers too if he had pleas'd.) In the lowet Form he places thoe whom he calls Les Petits Eprits: uch things as are our Upper-Gallery Audience in a Play-Houe; who like nothing but the Husk and Rhind of Wit; preferr a Quibble, a Conceit, an Epigram, before olid Sene, and Elegant Expreion: Thee are Mobb-Readers: If Virgil and Martial tood for Parliament-Men, we know already who wou'd carry it. But though they make the greatet appearance in the Field, and cry the loudet, the bet on't is, they are but a ort of French Hugonots, or Dutch Boors, brought over in Herds, but not Naturaliz'd: who have not Land of two Pounds per Annum in Parnaus, and therefore are not priviledg'd to Poll. Their Authors are of the ame level; fit to repreent them on a Mountebank's-Stage, or to be Maters of the Ceremonies in a Bear-Garden. Yet thee are they who have the mot Admirers. But it often happens, to their mortification, that as their Readers improve their Stock of Sene, (as they may by reading better Books, and by Converation with Men of Judgment,) they oon forake them: And when the Torrent from the Mountains falls no more, the welling Writer is reduc'd into his hallow Bed, like the Mançanares at Madrid, with carce water to moiten his own Pebbles. There are a middle ort of Readers (as we hold there is a middle tate of Souls) uch as have a farther inight than the former; yet have not the capacity of judging right; (for I peak not of thoe who are brib'd by a Party, and know better if they were not corrupted;) but I mean a Company of warm young Men, who are not yet arriv'd o far as to dicern the difference betwixt Futian, or otentatious Sentences, and the true ublime. Thee are above liking Martial, or Owen's Epigrams, but they wou'd certainly et Virgil below Statius, or Lucan. I need not ay their Poets are of the ame Pate with their Admirers. They affect greatnes in all they write, but 'tis a bladder'd greatnes, like that of the vain Man whom Seneca decribes: An ill habit of Body, full of
Humours, and well'd with Dropie. Even thee too deert their Authors, as their Judgment ripens. The young Gentlemen themelves are commonly mis-led by their Pedagogue at School, their Tutor at the Univerity, or their Governour in their Travels. And many of thoe three orts are the mot poitive Blockheads in the World. How many of thoe flatulent Writers have I known, who have unk in their Reputation, after Seven or Eight Editions of their Works? for indeed they are Poets only for young Men. They had great ucces at their firt appearance; but not being of God, as a Wit aid formerly, they cou'd not tand.
I have already nam'd two orts of Judges, but Virgil wrote for neither of them: and by his Example, I am not ambitious of pleaing the lowet, or the middle form of Readers.

He choe to pleae the mot Judicious: Souls of the highet Rank, and truet Undertanding. Thee are few in number; but whoever is o happy as to gain their approbation, can nover loe it, becaue they never give it blindly. Then they have a certain Magnetim in their Judgment, which attracts others to their Sene. Every day they gain ome new Proelyte, and in time become the Church. For this Reaon, a well-weigh'd Judicious Poem, which at its firt appearance gains no more upon the World than to be jut receiv'd, and rather not blam'd, than much applauded, ininuates it elf by inenible degrees into the liking of the Reader: The more he tudies it, the more it grows upon him; every time he takes it up, he dicovers ome new Graces in it. And whereas Poems which are produc'd by the vigour of Imagination only, have a glos upon them at the firt, which Time wears off; the Works of Judgment, are like the Diamond, the more they are polih'd, the more lutre they receive. Such is the difference betwixt Virgil's Aeneis, and Marini's Adone. And if I may be allow'd to change the Metaphor, I wou'd ay, that Virgil is like the Fame which he decribes; Mobilitate viget, vire
que acquirit eundo.

Such a ort of Reputation is my aim, though in a far inferiour degree, according to my Motto in the Title Page: Sequitur
