que Patrem, non paibus aequis; and therefore I appeal to the Highet Court of Judicature, like that of the Peers, of which your Lordhip is o great an Ornament.

Without this Ambition which I own, of deiring to pleae the Judices Natos, I cou'd never have been able to have done any thing at this Age, when the fire of Poetry is commonly extinguih'd in other Men. Yet Virgil has given me the Example of Entellus for my Encouragement: When he was well heated, the younger Champion cou'd not tand before him. And we find the Elder contended not for the Gift, but for the Honour; Nec dona moror. For Dampier has inform'd us, in his Voyages, that the Air of the Country which produces Gold, is never wholom.

I had long ince conider'd, that the way to pleae the bet Judges, is not to Tranlate a Poet literally; and Virgil leat of any other. For his peculiar Beauty lying in his choice of Words, I am excluded from it by the narrow compas of our Heroick Vere, unles I wou'd make ue of Monoyllables only, and thoe clog'd with Cononants, which
are the dead weight of our Mother-Tongue. 'Tis poible, I confes, though it rarely happens, that a Vere of Monoyllables may ound harmoniouly; and ome Examples of it I have een. My firt Line of the Aeneis is not harh:
Arms, and the Man I Sing, who forc'd by Fate, &c.
But a much better intance may be given from the lat Line of Manilius, made Englih by our Learned and Judicious Mr. Creech.
div.q: Nor could the World have born o fierce a Flame.
div.p: Where the many Liquid Cononants are plac'd o Artfully, that they give a pleaing ound to the Words, though they are all of one Syllable.

'Tis true, I have been ometimes forc'd upon it in other places of this Work, but I never did it out of choice: I was either in hate, or Virgil gave me no occaion for the Ornament of Words; for it eldom happens but a Monoyllable Line turns Vere to Proe, and even that Proe is rugged, and unharmonious. Philarchus, I remember, taxes Balzac for placing Twenty Monoyllables in file, without one diyllable betwixt them. The way I have taken, is not o treight as Metaphrae, nor o looe as Paraphrae: Some things too I have omitted, and ometimes have added of my own. Yet the omiions I hope, are but of Circumtances, and uch as wou'd have no grace in Englih; and the Additions, I alo hope, are eaily deduc'd from Virgil's Sene. They will eem (at leat I have the Vanity to think o), not tuck into him, but growing out of him. He tudies brevity more than any other Poet, but he had the advantage of a Language wherein much may be comprehended in a little pace. We, and all the Modern Tongues, have more Articles and Pronouns, beides igns of Tenes and Caes, and other Barbarities on which our Speech is built by the faults of our Forefathers. The Romans founded theirs upon the Greek: And the Greeks, we know, were labouring many hundred years upon their Language, before they brought it to perfection. They rejected all thoe Signs, and cut off as many Articles as they cou'd pare; comprehending in one word, what we are contrain'd to expres in two; which is one Reaon why we cannot write o conciely as they have done. The word Pater, for Example, ignifies not only a Father, but your Father, my Father, his or her Father, all included in a word.

This inconvenience is common to all Modern Tongues, and this alone contrains us to employ more words than the Ancients needed. But having before oberv'd, that Virgil endeavours to be hort, and at the ame time Elegant, I purue the Excellence, and forake the Brevity. For there he is like Ambergreace, a Rich Perfume, but of o cloe and glutinous a Body, that it mut be open'd with inferiour cents of Musk or Civet, or the weetnes will not be drawn out into another Language.

On the whole Matter, I thought fit to teer betwixt the two Extreams, of Paraphrae, and literal Tranlation: To keep as near my Author as I cou'd, without loing all his Graces, the mot Eminent of which, are in the Beauty of his words: And thoe words, I mut add, are always Figurative. Such of thee as wou'd retain their Elegance in our Tongue, I have endeavour'd to graff on it; but mot
of them are of neceity to be lot, becaue they will not hine in any but their own. Virgil has ometimes two of them in a Line; but the cantines of our Heroick Vere, is not capable of receiving more than one: And that too mut expiate for many others which have none. Such is the difference of the Languages, or uch my want of skill in chuing words. Yet I may preume to ay, and I hope with as much reaon as the French Tranlator, that taking all the Materials of this divine Author, I have endeavour'd to make Virgil peak uch Englih, as he wou'd himelf have poken, if he had been born in England, and in this preent Age. I acknowledge, with Segrais, that I have not ucceeded in this attempt, according to my deire: yet I hall not be wholly without praie, if in ome ort I may be allow'd to have copied the Clearnes, the Purity, the Eaines and the Magnificence of his Stile. But I hall have occaion to peak farther on this Subject, before I end the Preface.

When I mention'd the Pindarick Line, I hould have added, that I take another Licene in my Veres: For I frequently make ue of Triplet Rhymes, and for the ame Reaon: Becaue they bound the Sene. And therefore I generally join thee two Licenes together: And make the lat Vere of the Triplet a Pindarique: For beides, the Majety which it gives, it confines the ene within the barriers of three Lines, which wou'd languih if it were lengthen'd into four. Spencer is my Example for both thee priviledges of Englih Veres. And Chapman has follow'd him in his Tranlation of Homer. Mr. Cowley has given in to them after both: And all ucceeding Writers after him. I regard them now as the Magna Charta of Heroick Poetry; and am too much an Englih-man to loe what my Ancetors have gain'd for me. Let the French and Italians value themelves on their Regularity: Strength and Elevation are our Standard. I aid before, and I repeat it, that the affected purity of the French, has uninew'd their Heroick Vere. The Language of an Epick Poem is almot wholly figurative: Yet they are o fearful of a Metaphor, that no Example of Virgil can encourage them to be bold with afety. Sure they might warm themelves by that prightly Blaze, without approaching it o cloe as to inge their Wings; they may come as near it as their Mater. Not that I wou'd dicourage that purity of diction, in which he excels all other Poets. But he knows how far to extend his Franchies: And advances to the verge, without venturing a Foot beyond it. On the other ide, without being injurious to the Memory of our Englih Pindar, I will preume to ay, that his Metaphors are ometimes too violent, and his Language is not always pure. But at the ame time, I mut excue him. For through the Iniquity of the times, he was forc'd to Travel, at an Age, when, intead of Learning Foreign Languages, he hou'd have tudied the Beauties of his Mother Tongue: Which like all other Speeches, is to be cultivated early, or we hall never Write it with any kind of Elegance. Thus by gaining abroad he lot at home: Like the Painter in the Arcadia, who going to ee a Skirmih, had his Arms lop'd off: and return'd, ays Sir Philip Sydney, well intructed how to draw a Battel, but without a Hand to perform his Work.

There is another thing in which I have preum'd to deviate from him and Spencer. They both make Hemyticks (or half Veres) breaking off in the middle of a Line. I confes there are not many uch in the Fairy Queen: And even thoe few might be occaion'd by his unhappy choice
of o long a Stanza. Mr. Cowley had found out, that no kind of Staff is proper for an Heroick Poem; as being all too lirical: Yet though he wrote in Couplets, where Rhyme is freer from contraint, he frequently affects half Veres: of which we find not one in Homer, and I think not in any of the Grcek Poets, or the Latin, excepting only Virgil; and there is no quetion but he thought, he had Virgil's Authority for that Licene. But I am confident, our Poet never meant to leave him or any other uch a Precedent. And I ground my Opinion on thee two Reaons. Firt, we find no Example of a Hemytick in any of his Patorals or Georgicks. For he had given the lat finihing Strokes to both thee Poems: But his Aeneis he left o uncorrect, at leat o hort of that perfection at which he aim'd, that we know how hard a Sentence He pas'd upon it: And in the econd place, I reaonably preume, that he intended to have fill'd up all thoe Hemyticks, becaue in one of them we find the ene imperfect:
Quem tibi jam Trojâ—
Which ome foolih Gramarian, has ended for him, with a half Line of Nonene. Peperit fumante Crëua. For Acanius mut have been born ome Years before the burning of that City; which I need not prove. On the other ide we find alo, that he himelf fill'd up one Line in the ixth Aeneid, the Enthuiam eizing him, while he was reading to Augutus.

q.l: Mienum Aeolidem, quo non praetantior alter
Aere, ciere viros.—

div.p: To which he added in that tranport. Martemque accendere Cantu. And never was any Line more nobly finih'd; for the reaons which I have given in the Book of Painting. On thee Coniderations I have hun'd Hemyticks: Not being willing to imitate Virgil to a Fault; like Alexander's Courtiers, who affected to hold their Necks awry, becaue he cou'd not help it: I am confident your Lordhip is by this time of my Opinion; and that you will look on thoe half lines hereafter, as the imperfect products of a haty Mue: Like the Frogs and Serpents in the Nile; part of them kindled into Life; and part a lump of unform'd unanimated Mudd.

I am enible that many of my whole Veres, are as imperfect as thoe halves; for want of time to diget them better: But give me leave to make the Excue of Boccace: Who when he was upbraided, that ome of his Novels had not the Spirit of the ret, return'd this Anwer, that Charlemain who made the Paladins; was never able to raie an Army of them. The Leaders may be Heroes, but the multitude mut conit of Common Men.

I am alo bound to tell your Lordhip, in my own defence: That from the beginning of the firt Georgick to the end of the lat Aeneid; I found the difficulty of Tranlation growing on me in every ucceeding Book. For Virgil, above all Poets, had a tock, which I may call almot inexhautible of figurative, Elegant, and ounding Words. I who inherit but a mall portion of his Genius, and write in a Language o
much inferiour to the Latin, have found it very painful to vary Phraes, when the ame ene returns upon me. Even he himelf, whether out of neceity or choice, has often expres'd the ame thing in the ame words; and often repeated two or three whole Veres, which he had us'd before. Words are not o eaily Coyn'd as Money: And yet we ee that the Credit not only of Banks, but of Exchequers cracks, when little comes in, and much goes out. Virgil call'd upon me in every line for ome new word: And I paid o long, that I was almot Banckrupt. So that the latter end mut needs be more burdenom than the beginning or the middle. And conequently the Twelfth Aeneid cot me double the time of the firt and econd. What had become of me, if Virgil had tax'd me with another Book? I had certainly been reduc'd to pay the Publick in hammer'd Money for want of Mill'd; that is in the ame old Words which I had us'd before: And the Receivers mut have been forc'd to have taken any thing, where there was o little to be had.

Beides this difficulty (with which I have trugled, and made a hift to pas it over) there is one remaining, which is inuperable to all Tranlators. We are bound to our Author's Sene, though with the latitudes already mention'd (for I think it not o acred, as that one Iota mut not be added or diminih'd on pain of an Anathema.) But Slaves we are; and labour on another Man's Plantation; we dres the Vine-yard, but the Wine is the Owners: If the Soil be ometimes Barren, then we are ure of being courg'd: If it be fruitful, and our Care ucceeds, we are not thank'd; for the proud Reader will only ay, the poor drudge has done his duty. But this is nothing to what follows; for being oblig'd to make his Sene intelligible, we are forc'd to untune our own Veres, that we may give his meaning to the Reader. He who Invents is Mater of his Thoughts and Words: He can turn and vary them as he pleaes, 'till he renders them harmonious. But the wretched Tranlator has no uch priviledge: For being ty'd to the Thoughts, he mut make what Muick he can in the Expreion. And for this reaon it cannot always be o weet as that of the Original. There is a beauty of Sound, as Segrais has oberv'd, in ome Latin Words, which is wholly lot in any Modern Language. He intances in that Mollis Amaracus, on which Venus lays Cupid in the Firt Aeneid. If I hould Tranlate it Sweet Marjoram, as the word ignifies; the Reader would think I had mitaken Virgil: For thoe Village-words, as I may call them, gives us a mean Idea of the thing; but the Sound of the Latin is o much more pleaing, by the jut mixture of the Vowels with the Cononants, that it raies our Fancies, to conceive omewhat more Noble than a common Herb; and to pread Roes under him, and trew Lillies over him; a Bed not unworthy the Grandon of the Goddes.
If I cannot Copy his Harmonious Numbers, how hall I imitate his noble Flights; where his Thoughts and Words are equally ublime?

q.l: Quem quiquis tudet aemulari,
—Caeratis ope Dedalaeâ
Nititur pennis, vitreo daturus
Nomina Ponto.

div.p:
What Modern Language, or what Poet can expres the Majetick Beauty of this one Vere amongt a thouand others!
Aude Hopes contemnere opes, & te quoque dignum
Finge Deo.
For my part I am lot in the admiration of it: I contemn the World, when I think on it, and my elf when I Tranlate it.

Lay by Virgil, I beeech your Lordhip, and all my better ort of Judges, when you take up my Verion, and it will appear a paable Beauty, when the Original Mue is abent: But like Spencer's fale Florimel made of Snow, it melts and vanihes, when the true one comes in ight. I will not excue but jutifie my elf for one pretended Crime, with which I am liable to be charg'd by fale Criticks, not only in this Tranlation, but in many of my Original Poems; that I latinize too much. 'Tis true, that when I find an Englih word, ignificant and ounding, I neither borrow from the Latin or any other Language: But when I want at home, I mut eek abroad.

If ounding Words are not of our growth and Manufacture, who hall hinder me to Import them from a Foreign Country? I carry not out the Treaure of the Nation, which is never to return: but what I bring from Italy, I pend in England: Here it remains, and here it circulates; for if the Coyn be good, it will pas from one hand to another. I Trade both with the Living and the Dead, for the enrichment of our Native Language. We have enough in England to upply our neceity; but if we will have things of Magnificence and Splendour, we mut get them by Commerce. Poetry requires Ornament, and that is not to be had from our Old Teuton Monoyllables; therefore if I find any Elegant Word in a Claick Author, I propoe it to be Naturaliz'd, by uing it my elf: and if the Publick approves of it, the Bill paes. But every Man cannot ditinguih betwixt Pedantry and Poetry: Every Man therefore is not fit to innovate. Upon the whole matter, a Poet mut firt be certain that the Word he wou'd Introduce is Beautiful in the Latin; and is to conider, in the next place, whether it will agree with the Englih Idiom: After this, he ought to take the Opinion of judicious Friends, uch as are Learned in both Languages: And latly, ince no Man is infallible, let him ue this Licene very paringly; for if too many Foreign Words are pour'd in upon us, it looks as if they were deign'd not to ait the Natives, but to Conquer them.

I am now drawing towards a Concluion, and upect your Lordhip is very glad of it. But permit me firt, to own what Helps I have had in this Undertaking. The late Earl of Lauderdail, ent me over his new Tranlation of the Aeneis; which he had ended before I ingag'd in the ame Deign. Neither did I then intend it: But ome Propoals being afterwards made me by my Bookeller, I deir'd his Lordhip's leave, that I might accept them, which he freely granted; and I have his Letter yet to hew, for that permiion. He reolv'd to have Printed his Work; which he might have done two Years before I cou'd Publih mine: and had perform'd it, if Death had not prevented him. But having his Manucript in my hands, I conulted it as often as I doubted of my Author's ene. For no Man undertood Virgil better than that Learned Noble Man. His Friends, I hear, have yet another, and more Correct Copy of that Tranlation
by them: which had they pleas'd to have given the Publick, the Judges mut have been convinc'd, that I have not flatter'd him. Beides this help, which was not inconiderable, Mr. Congreve has done me the Favour to review the Aeneis; and compare my Verion with the Original. I hall never be aham'd to own, that this Excellent Young Man, has hew'd me many Faults, which I have endeavour'd to Correct. 'Tis true, he might have eaily found more, and then my Tranlation had been more Perfect.

Two other Worthy Friends of mine, who deire to have their Names conceal'd, eeing me traitned in my time, took Pity on me, and gave me the Life of Virgil, the two Prefaces to the Patorals, and the Georgics, and all the Arguments in Profe to the whole Tranlation. Which perhaps, has occaion'd a Report that the two Firt Poems are not mine. If it had been true, that I had taken their Veres for my own, I might have glory'd in their Aid; and like Terence, have farther'd the Opinion, that Scipio and Laelius join'd with me. But the ame Style being continu'd thro' the whole, and the ame Laws of Verification oberv'd, are proofs ufficient, that this is one Man's Work: And your Lordhip is too well acquainted with my manner, to doubt that any part of it is anothers.

That your Lordhip may ee I was in earnet, when I promis'd to haten to an end, I will not give the Reaons, why I Writ not always in the proper terms of Navigation, Land-Service, or in the Cant of any Profeion. I will only ay, that Virgil has avoided thoe proprieties, becaue he Writ not to Mariners, Souldiers, Atronomers, Gardners, Peaants, &c. but to all in general, and in particular to Men and Ladies of the firt Quality: who have been better Bred than to be too nicely knowing in the Terms. In uch caes, 'tis enough for a Poet to write o plainly, that he may be undertood by his Readers: To avoid impropriety, and not affect to be thought Learn'd in all things.

Scarce a word without an R. and the Vowels for the greater part onorous. The Prefacer began with Ille ego, which He was contrain'd to patch up in the Fourth line with At nunc, to make the Sene cohere. And if both thoe words are not notorious botches, I am much deceiv'd, though the French Tranlator thinks otherwie. For my own part, I am rather of Opinion, that they were added by Tucca and Varius, than Retrench'd.

I know it may be anwer'd by uch as think Virgil the Author of the four Lines; that he aerts his Title to the Aeneis, in the beginning of this Work, as he did to the two former, in the lat lines of the fourth Georgic. I will not reply otherwie to this, than by deiring them to compare thee four Lines with the four others; which we know are his, becaue no Poet but he alone could write them. If they cannot ditinguih Creeping from Flying, let them lay down Virgil, and take up Ovid de Ponto in his tead. My Mater needed not the aitance of that Preliminary Poet to prove his Claim. His own Majetick Meen dicovers him to be the King, amidt a Thouand Courtiers. It was a uperfluous Office, and therefore I wou'd not et thoe Veres in the Front of Virgil. But have rejected them to my own Preface.

l.hi: I, who before, with Shepherds in the Groves,
Sung to my Oaten Pipe, their Rural Loves,
And iuing thence, compell'd the Neighb'ring Field
A plenteous Crop of riing Corn to yield,
Manur'd the Glebe, and tock'd the fruitful Plain,

q.l: (A Poem grateful to the greedy Swain.) &c.

div.p: If there be not a tolerable Line in all thee ix, the Prefacer, gave me no occaion to write better. This is a jut Apology in this place. But I have done great Wrong to Virgil in the whole Tranlation: Want of Time, the Inferiority of our Language; the inconvenience of Rhyme, and all the other Excues I have made, may alleviate my Fault, but cannot jutiie the boldnes of my Undertaking. What avails it me to acknowledge freely, that I have not been able to do him right in any line? For even my own Confeion makes againt me; and it will always be return'd upon me, Why then did you attempt it? To which, no other Anwer can be made, than that I have done him les Injury than any of his former Libellers.

What they call'd his Picture, had been drawn at length, o many times, by the Daubers of almot all Nations, and till o unlike him, that I natch'd up the Pencil with didain: being atisfi'd before hand, that I cou'd make ome mall reemblance of him, though I mut be content with a wore likenes. A Sixth Patoral, a Pharmaceutria, a ingle Orpheus, and ome other Features, have been exactly taken: But thoe Holiday Authors writ for Pleaure; and only hew'd us what they cou'd have done, if they wou'd have taken pains, to perform the whole.

Be pleas'd, My Lord, to accept, with your wonted goodnes, this unworthy Preent, which I make you. I have taken off one trouble from you, of defending it, by acknowledging its Imperfections: And though ome part of them are cover'd in the Vere; (as Ericthonius
rode always in a Chariot, to hide his lamenes.) Such of them as cannot be conceal'd, you will pleae to connive at, though in the trictnes of your Judgment, you cannot Pardon. If Homer was allow'd to nod ometimes, in o long a Work, it will be no wonder if I often fall aleep. You took my Aureng-zeb into your Protection, with all his faults: And I hope here cannot be o many, becaue I Tranlate an Author, who gives me uch Examples of Correctnes. What my Jury may be, I know not; but 'tis good for a Criminal to plead before a favourable Judge: If I had aid Partial, wou'd your Lordhip have forgiven me? Or will you give me leave to acquaint the World, that I have many times been oblig'd to your Bounty ince the Revolution. Though I never was reduc'd to beg a Charity, nor ever had the Impudence to ask one, either of your Lordhip, or your Noble Kinman the Earl of Doret, much les of any other, yet when I leat expected it, you have both remember'd me. So inherent it is in your Family not to forget an Old Servant. It looks rather like Ingratitude on my part, that where I have been o often oblig'd, I have appear'd o eldom to return my thanks: and where I was alo o ure of being well receiv'd. Somewhat of Lazines was in the cae; and omewhat too of Modety: But nothing of Direpect, or of Unthankfulnes. I will not ay that your Lordhip has encourag'd me to this Preumption, let if my Labours meet with no ucces in Publick, I may expoe your Judgment to be Cenur'd. As for my own Enemies I hall never think them worth an Anwer; and if your Lordhip has any, they will not dare to Arraign you for your want of Knowledge in this Art, till they can produce omewhat betterof their own, than your Eay on Poetry. 'Twas on this Conideration, that I have drawn out my Preface to o great a length. Had I not addres'd to a Poet, and a Critick of the firt Magnitude, I had my elf been tax'd for want of Judgment, and ham'd my Patron for want of Undertanding. But neither will you, My Lord, o oon be tir'd as any other, becaue the Dicoure is on your Art; Neither will the Learned Reader think it tedious, becaue it is ad Clerum. At leat, when he begins to be weary, the Church Doors are open. That I may purue the Allegory with a hort Prayer, after a long Sermon:
May you Live happily and long, for the Service of your Country, the Encouragement of good Letters and the Ornament of Poetry; which cannot be wih'd more earnetly by any Man, than by

closer.signed: Your Lordhips, mot Humble, Mot Obliged, and mot Obedient Servant. John Dryden.

figure.p: To his Royall Highnes PRINCE GEORGE of DENMARK. &

div.head: Virgil's Aeneis.
The Firt Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Trojans, after a even Years Voyage, et ail for Italy, but are overtaken by a dreadful Storm, which Aeolus raies at Juno's Requet. The Tempet inks one, and catters the ret: Neptune drives off the Winds and calms the Sea. Aeneas with his own Ship, and ix more, arrives afe at an Affrican Port. Venus complains to Jupiter of her Son's Misfortunes. Jupiter comforts her, and ends Mercury to procure him a kind Reception among the Carthaginians. Aeneas going out to dicover the Country, meets his Mother in the Shape of an Huntres, who conveys him in a Cloud to Carthage; where he ees his Friends whom he thought lot, and receives a kind Entertainment from the Queen. Dido by a device of Venus begins to have a Paion for him, and after ome Dicoure with him, deires the Hitory of his Adventures ince the Siege of Troy, which is the Subject of the two following Books.

lg.l: ARms, and the Man I ing, who, forc'd by Fate,
And haughty Juno's unrelenting Hate;
Expell'd and exil'd, left the Trojan Shoar:
Long Labours, both by Sea and Land he bore;
And in the doubtful War, before he won
The Latian Realm, and built the detin'd Town:
His banih'd Gods retor'd to Rites Divine,
And etl'd ure Succeion in his Line:
From whence the Race of Alban Fathers come,
And the long Glories of Majetick Rome.
O Mue! the Caues and the Crimes relate,
What Goddes was provok'd, and whence her hate:
For what Offence the Queen of Heav'n began
To perecute o brave, o jut a Man!
Involv'd his anxious Life in endles Cares,
Expos'd to Wants, and hurry'd into Wars!
Can Heav'nly Minds uch high reentment how;
Or exercie their Spight in Human Woe?
Againt the Tiber's Mouth, but far away,
An ancient Town was eated on the Sea:
A Tyrian Colony; the People made
Stout for the War, and tudious of their Trade.
Carthage the Name, belov'd by Juno more
Than her own Argos, or the Samian Shoar.
Here tood her Chariot, here, if Heav'n were kind,
The Seat of awful Empire he deign'd.
Yet he had heard an ancient Rumour fly,
(Long cited by the People of the Sky;)
That times to come hou'd ee the Trojan Race
Her Carthage ruin, and her Tow'rs deface:
Nor thus confin'd, the Yoke of Sov'raign Sway,
Should on the Necks of all the Nations lay.
She ponder'd this, and fear'd it was in Fate;
Nor cou'd forget the War he wag'd of late,
For conq'ring Greece againt the Trojan State.
Beides long Caues working in her Mind,
And ecret Seeds of Envy lay behind.
Deep graven in her Heart, the Doom remain'd
Of partial Paris, and her Form didain'd:
The Grace betow'd on ravih'd Ganimed,
Electra's Glories, and her injur'd Bed.
Each was a Caue alone, and all combin'd
To kindle Vengeance in her haughty Mind.
For this, far ditant from the Latian Coat,
She drove the Remnants of the Trojan Hoat:
And ev'n long Years th' unhappy wand'ring Train,
Were tos'd by Storms, and catter'd through the Main.
Such Time, uch Toil requir'd the Roman Name,
Such length of Labour for o vat a Frame.
Now carce the Trojan Fleet with Sails and Oars,
Had left behind the Fair Sicilian Shoars:
Ent'ring with chearful Shouts the wat'ry Reign,
And ploughing frothy Furrows in the Main:
When lab'ring till, with endles dicontent,
The Queen of Heav'n did thus her Fury vent.
Then am I vanquih'd, mut I yield, aid he,
And mut the Trojans reign in Italy?
So Fate will have it, and Jove adds his Force;
Nor can my Pow'r divert their happy Coure.
Cou'd angry Pallas, with revengeful Spleen,
The Grecian Navy burn, and drown the Men?
She for the Fault of one offending Foe,
The Bolts of Jove himelf preum'd to throw:
With Whirlwinds from beneath he tos'd the Ship,
And bare expos'd the Boom of the deep:
Then, as an Eagle gripes the trembling Game,
The Wretch yet hiing with her Father's Flame,
She trongly eiz'd, and with a burning Wound,
Transfix'd and naked, on a Rock he bound.
But I, who walk in awful State above,
The Majety of Heav'n, the Siter-wife of Jove;
For length of Years, my fruitles Force employ
Againt the thin remains of ruin'd Troy.
What Nations now to Juno's Pow'r will pray,
Or Off'rings on my lighted Altars lay?
Thus rag'd the Goddes, and with Fury fraught,
The retles Regions of the Storms he ought.
Where in a pacious Cave of living Stone,
The Tyrant E'lus from his Airy Throne,
With Pow'r Imperial curbs the trugling Winds,
And ounding Tempets in dark Prions binds.
This Way, and that, th' impatient Captives tend,
And preing for Releae, the Mountains rend;
High in his Hall, th' undaunted Monarch tands,
And hakes his Scepter, and their Rage commands:
Which did he not, their unreited Sway
Wou'd weep the World before them, in their Way:
Earth, Air, and Seas through empty Space wou'd rowl,
And Heav'n would fly before the driving Soul.
In fear of this, the Father of the Gods
Confin'd their Fury to thoe dark Abodes,
And lock'd'em afe within, oppres'd with Mountain loads:
Impos'd a King, with arbritrary Sway,
To looe their Fetters, or their Force allay.
To whom the uppliant Queen her Pray'rs addret,
And thus the tenour of her Suit expres'd.
O E'lus! for to thee the King of Heav'n
The Pow'r of Tempets, and of Winds has giv'n:
Thy Force alone their Fury can retrain,
And mooth the Waves, or well the troubl'd Main.
A race of wand'ring Slaves, abhorr'd by me,
With prop'rous Paage cut the Thucan Sea:
To fruitful Italy their Coure they teer,
And for their vanquih'd Gods deign new Temples there.
Raie all thy Winds, with Night involve the Skies;
Sink, or dipere my fatal Enemies.
Twice ev'n, the charming Daughters of the Main,
Around my Peron wait, and bear my Train:
Succeed my Wih, and econd my Deign,
The fairet, Deiopeia, hall be thine;
And make thee Father of a happy Line.
To this the God—'Tis yours, O Queen! to will
The Work, which Duty binds me to fulfil.
Thee airy Kingdoms, and this wide Command,
Are all the Preents of your bounteous Hand:
Yours is my Sov'raign's Grace, and, as your Guet,
I it with Gods at their Coeletial Feat.
Raie Tempets at your Pleaure, or ubdue;
Dipoe of Empire, which I hold from you.
He aid, and hurld againt the Mountain ide,
His quiv'ring Spear, and all, the God apply'd.
The raging Winds ruh through the hollow Wound,
And dance aloft in Air, and skim along the Ground:
Then etling on the Sea, the Surges weep;
Raie liquid Mountains, and dicloe the deep.
South, Eat, and Wet, with mix'd Confuion roar,
And rowl the foaming Billows to the Shoar.
The Cables crack, the Sailors fearful Cries
Acend; and able Night involves the Skies;
And Heav'n it elf is ravih'd from their Eyes.
Loud Peals of Thunder from the Poles enue,
Then flahing Fires the tranient Light renew:
The Face of things a frightful Image bears,
And preent Death in various Forms appears.
Struck with unuual Fright, the Trojan Chief,
With lifted Hands and Eyes, invokes Relief.
And thrice, and four times happy thoe, he cry'd,
That under Ilian Walls before their Parents dy'd.
Tydides, bravet of the Grecian Train,
Why cou'd not I by that trong Arm be lain,
And lye by noble Hector on the Plain,
Or great Sarpedon, in thoe bloody Fields,
Where Simois rouls the Bodies, and the Shields
Of Heroes, whoe dimember'd Hands yet bear
The Dart aloft, and clench the pointed Spear?
Thus while the Pious Prince his Fate bewails,
Fierce Boreas drove againt his flying Sails,
And rent the Sheets: The raging Billows rie,
And mount the toing Veel to the Skies:
Nor can the hiv'ring Oars utain the Blow;
The Galley gives her ide, and turns her Prow:
While thoe atern decending down the Steep,
Thro' gaping Waves behold the boiling deep.
Three Ships were hurry'd by the Southern Blat,
And on the ecret Shelves with Fury cat.
Thoe hidden Rocks, th' Auonian Sailors knew,
They call'd them Altars, when they roe in view,
And how'd their pacious Backs above the Flood.
Three more, fierce Eurus in his angry Mood,
Dah'd on the Shallows of the moving Sand,
And in mid Ocean left them moor'd a-land.
Orontes Barque that bore the Lycian Crew,
(A horrid Sight) ev'n in the Hero's view,
From Stem to Stern, by Waves was overborn:
The trembling Pilot, from his Rudder torn,
Was headlong hurl'd; thrice round, the Ship was tot,
Then bulg'd at once, and in the deep was lot.
And here and there above the Waves were een
Arms, Pictures, precious Goods, and floating Men.
The toutet Veel to the Storm gave way,
And uck'd through looen'd Planks the ruhing Sea.
Ilioneus was her Chief: Alethes old,
Achates faithful, Abas young and bold
Endur'd not les: their Ships, with gaping Seams,
Admit the Deluge of the briny Streams.
Mean time Imperial Neptune heard the Sound
Of raging Billows breaking on the Ground:
Dipleas'd, and fearing for his Wat'ry Reign,
He reard his awful Head above the Main:
Serene in Majety, then rowl'd his Eyes
Around the Space of Earth, and Seas, and Skies.
He aw the Trojan Fleet dipers'd, ditres'd
By tormy Winds and wintry Heav'n oppres'd.
Full well the God his Siter's envy knew,
And what her Aims, and what her Arts purue:
He ummon'd Eurus and the wetern Blat,
And firt an angry glance on both he cat:
Then thus rebuk'd; Audacious Winds! from whence
This bold Attempt, this Rebel Inolence?
Is it for you to ravage Seas and Land,
Unauthoriz'd by my upream Command?
To raie uch Mountains on the troubl'd Main?
Whom I—But firt 'tis fit, the Billows to retrain,
And then you hall be taught obedience to my Reign.
Hence, to your Lord my Royal Mandate bear,
The Realms of Ocean and the Fields of Air
Are mine, not his; by fatal Lot to me
The liquid Empire fell, and Trident of the Sea.
His Pow'r to hollow Caverns is confin'd,
There let him reign, the Jailor of the Wind:
With hoare Commands his breathing Subjects call,
And boat and bluter in his empty Hall.
He poke: And while he poke, he mooth'd the Sea,
Dipell'd the Darknes, and retor'd the Day:
Cymothoe, Triton, and the Sea-green Train
Of beauteous Nymphs, the Daughters of the Main,
Clear from the Rocks the Veels with their hands;
The God himelf with ready Trident tands,
And opes the Deep, and preads the moving ands;
Then heaves them off the holes: where e're he guides
His finny Courers, and in Triumph rides,
The Waves unruffle and the Sea ubides.
As when in Tumults rie th' ignoble Crow'd,
Mad are their Motions, and their Tongues are loud;
And Stones and Brands in ratling Vollies fly,
And all the Rutick Arms that Fury can upply:
If then ome grave and Pious Man appear,
They huh their Noie, and lend a lit'ning Ear;
He ooths with ober Words their angry Mood,
And quenches their innate Deire of Blood.
So when the Father of the Flood appears,
And o're the Seas his Sov'raign Trident rears,
Their Fury falls: He skims the liquid Plains,
High on his Chariot, and with looen'd Reins,
Majetick moves along, and awful Peace maintains.
The weary Trojans ply their hatter'd Oars,
To nearet Land, and make the Lybian Shoars.
Within a long Reces there lies a Bay,
An Iland hades it from the rowling Sea,
And forms a Port ecure for Ships to ride,
Broke by the jutting Land on either ide:
In double Streams the briny Waters glide.
Betwixt two rows of Rocks, a Sylvan Scene
Appears above, and Groves for ever green:
A Grott is form'd beneath, with Moy Seats,
To ret the Nereids, and exclude the Heats.
Down thro' the Cranies of the living Walls
The Crytal Streams decend in murm'ring Falls.
No Haulers need to bind the Veels here,
Nor bearded Anchors, for no Storms they fear.
Sev'n Ships within this happy Harbour meet,
The thin Remainders of the catter'd Fleet.
The Trojans, worn with Toils, and pent with Woes,
Leap on the welcome Land, and eek their wih'd Repoe.
Firt, good Achates, with repeated troaks
Of clahing Flints, their hidden Fire provokes;
Short Flame ucceeds, a Bed of wither'd Leaves
The dying Sparkles in their Fall receives:
Caught into Life, in moaking Fumes they rie,
And, fed with tronger Food, invade the Skies.
The Trojans, dropping wet, or tand around
The chearful blaze, or lye along the Ground:
Some dry their Corn infected with the Brine,
Then grind with Marbles, and prepare to dine.
Aeneas climbs the Mountain's airy Brow,
And takes a Propect of the Seas below:
If Capys thence, or Antheus he cou'd py;
Or ee the Streamers of Caicus fly.
No Veels were in view: But, on the Plain,
Three beamy Stags command a Lordly Train
Of branching Heads; the more ignoble Throng
Attend their tately Steps, and lowly graze along.
He tood; and while ecure they fed below,
He took the Quiver, and the truty Bow
Achates us'd to bear; the Leaders firt
He laid along, and then the Vulgar pierc'd:
Nor ceas'd his Arrows, 'till the hady Plain
Sev'n mighty Bodies, with their Blood ditain.
For the ev'n Ships he made an equal Share,
And to the Port return'd, Triumphant from the War.
The Jarrs of gen'rous Wine, (Acetes Git,
When his Trinacrian Shoars the Navy left)
He et abroach, and for the Feat prepar'd;
In equal Portions, with the Ven'on har'd.
Thus while he dealt it round, the pious Chief,
With chearful Words, allay'd the common Grief.
Endure, and conquer; Jove will oon dipoe
To future Good, our pat and preent Woes.
With me, the Rocks of Scylla you have try'd;
Th' inhuman Cyclops, and his Den defy'd.
What greater Ills hereafter can you bear?
Reume your Courage, and dimis your Care.
An Hour will come, with Pleaure to relate
Your Sorrows pat, as Benefits of Fate.
Through various Hazards, and Events we move
To Latium, and the Realms foredoom'd by Jove.
Call'd to the Seat, (the Promie of the Skies,)
Where Trojan Kingdoms once again may rie.
Endure the Hardhips of your preent State,
Live, and reerve your elves for better Fate.
Thee Words he poke; but poke not from his Heart;
His outward Smiles conceal'd his inward Smart.
The jolly Crew, unmindful of the pat,
The Quarry hare, their plenteous Dinner hate:
Some trip the Skin, ome portion out the Spoil;
The Limbs yet trembling, in the Cauldrons boyl:
Some on the Fire the reeking Entrails broil.
Stretch'd on the gray Turf, at eae they dine;
Retore their Strength with Meat, and chear their Souls with Wine.
Their Hunger thus appeas'd, their Care attends,
The doubtful Fortune of their abent Friends:
Alternate Hopes and Fears, their Minds poes,
Whether to deem 'em dead, or in Ditres.
Above the ret, Aeneas mourns the Fate
Of brave Orontes, and th' uncertain State
Of Gyas, Lycus, and of Amycus:
The Day, but not their Sorrows, ended thus.
When, from aloft, Almighty Jove urveys
Earth, Air, and Shoars, and navigable Seas,
At length on Lybian Realms he fix'd his Eyes:
Whom, pond'ring thus on Human Mieries,
When Venus aw, he with a lowly Look,
Not free from Tears, her Heav'nly Sire bepoke.
O King of Gods and Men, whoe awful Hand,
Diperes Thunder on the Seas and Land;
Dipoing all with abolute Command:

figure.p: To her Royall Highnes the Princes Anne of Denmark
figure.head: AE 1. l. 295

figure.p: To her Grace Mary Dutches of Ormond

lg.l: How cou'd my Pious Son thy Pow'r incene,
Or what, alas! is vanih'd Troy's Offence?
Our hope of Italy not only lot,
On various Seas, by various Tempets tot,
But hut from ev'ry Shoar, and barr'd from ev'ry Coat.
You promis'd once, a Progeny Divine,
Of Romans, riing from the Trojan Line,
In after-times hou'd hold the World in awe,
And to the Land and Ocean give the Law.
How is your Doom revers'd, which eas'd my Care;
When Troy was ruin'd in that cruel War?
Then Fates to Fates I cou'd oppoe; but now,
When Fortune till purues her former Blow,
What can I hope? what wore can till ucceed?
What end of Labours has your Will decreed?
Antenor, from the midt of Grecian Hots,
Could pas ecure, and pierce th' Illyrian Coats:
Where rowling down the Steep, Timavus raves,
And through nine Channels diembogues his Waves.
At length he founded Padua's happy Seat,
And gave his Trojans a ecure Retreat:
There fix'd their Arms, and there renew'd their Name,
And there in Quiet rules, and crown'd with Fame.
But we, decended from your acred Line,
Entitled to your Heav'n, and Rites Divine,
Are banih'd Earth, and, for the Wrath of one,
Remov'd from Latium, and the promis'd Throne.
Are thee our Scepters? Thee our due Rewards?
And is it thus that Jove his plighted Faith regards?
To whom, the Father of th'immortal Race,
Smiling with that erene indulgent Face,
With which he drives the Clouds, and clears the Skies:
Firt gave a holy Kis, then thus replies.
Daughter, dimis thy Fears: To thy deire
The Fates of thine are fix'd, and tand entire.
Thou halt behold thy wih'd Lavinian Walls,
And, ripe for Heav'n, when Fate Aeneas calls,
Then halt thou bear him up, ublime, to me;
No Councils have revers'd my firm Decree.
And let new Fears diturb thy happy State,
Know, I have earch'd the Mytick Rolls of Fate:
Thy Son (nor is th' appointed Seaon far)
In Italy hall wage uccesful War:
Shall tame fierce Nations in the bloody Field,
And Sov'raign Laws impoe, and Cities build.
'Till, after ev'ry Foe ub du'd, the Sun
Thrice through the Signs his Annual Race hall run:
This is his time prefix'd. Acanius then,
Now called Julus, hall begin his Reign.
He thirty rowling Years the Crown hall wear:
Then from Lavinium hall the Seat transfer:
And, with hard Labour, Alba-longa build;
The Throne with his Succeion hall be fill'd,
Three hundred Circuits more: then hall be een,
Ilia the fair, a Prietes and a Queen.
Who full of Mars, in time, with kindly Throws,
Shall at a Birth two goodly Boys dicloe.
The Royal Babes a tawny Wolf hall drain,
Then Romulus his Grandire's Throne hall gain.
Of Martial Tow'rs the Founder hall become,
The People Romans call, the City Rome.
To them, no Bounds of Empire I aign;
Nor term of Years to their immortal Line.
Ev' • haughty Juno, who, with endles Broils,
Earth, Seas, and Heav'n, and Jove himelf turmoils;
At length atton'd, her friendly Pow'r hall joyn,
To cherih and advance the Trojan Line.
The ubject World hall Rome's Dominion own,
And, protrate, hall adore the Nation of the Gown.
An Age is ripening in revolving Fate,
When Troy hall overturn the Grecian State:
And weet Revenge her conqu'ring Sons hall call,
To cruh the People that conpir'd her Fall.
Then Caear from the Julian Stock hall rie,
Whoe Empire Ocean, and whoe Fame the Skies
Alone hall bound. Whom, fraught with Eatern Spoils,
Our Heav'n, the jut Reward of Human Toyls,
Securely hall reward with Rites Divine;
And Incene hall acend before his acred Shrine.
Then dire Debate, and impious War hall ceae,
And the tern Age be oftned into Peace:
Then banih'd Faith hall once again return,
And Vetal Fires in hallow'd Temples burn;
And Remus with Quirinus hall utain,
The righteous Laws, and Fraud and Force retrain.
Janus himelf before his Fane hall wait,
And keep the dreadful iues of his Gate,
With Bolts and Iron Bars: within remains
Imprion'd Fury, bound in brazen Chains:
High on a Trophie rais'd, of ueles Arms,
He its, and threats the World with vain Alarms.
He aid, and ent Cyllenius with Command
To free the Ports, and ope the Punique Land
To Trojan Guets; let ignorant of Fate,
The Queen might force them from her Town and State.
Down from the Steep of Heav'n Cyllenius flies,
And cleaves with all his Wings the yielding Skies.
Soon on the Lybian Shoar decends the God;
Performs his Meage, and diplays his Rod:
The urly Murmurs of the People ceae,
And, as the Fates requir'd, they give the Peace.
The Queen her elf upends the rigid Laws,
The Trojans pities, and protects their Caue.
Mean time, in Shades of Night Aeneas lies;
Care eiz'd his Soul, and Sleep forook his Eyes.
But when the Sun retor'd the chearful Day,
He roe, the Coat and Country to urvey,
Anxious and eager to dicover more:
It look'd a wild uncultivated Shoar:
But whether Human Kind, or Beats alone
Poes'd the new-found Region, was unknown.
Beneath a hollow Rock his Fleet he hides;
Tall Trees urround the Mountains hady ides:
The bending Brow above, a afe Retreat provides.
Arm'd with two pointed Darts, he leaves his Friends,
And true Achates on his teps attends.
Loe, in the deep Recees of the Wood,
Before his Eyes his Goddes Mother tood:
A Huntres in her Habit and her Meen;
Her dres a Maid, her Air confes'd a Queen.
Bare were her Knees, and knots her Garments bind;
Looe was her Hair, and wanton'd in the Wind;
Her Hand utain'd a Bow, her Quiver hung behind.
She eem'd a Virgin of the Spartan Blood:
With uch Array Harpalice betrode
Her Thracian Courer, and outtrip'd the rapid Flood.
Ho! Strangers! have you lately een, he aid,
One of my Siters, like my elf array'd;
Who crot the Lawn, or in the Foret tray'd?
A Painted Quiver at her Back he bore;
Vary'd with Spots, a Linx's Hide he wore:
And at full Cry puru'd the tusky Boar?
Thus Venus: Thus her Son reply'd agen;
None of your Siters have we heard or een,

figure.p: To ye Right Honble: Anne Countes of Exeter Wife to ye Right Honble: John Earle of Exeter Baron Coecill of Burleigh
figure.head: AE. 1. l. 435

lg.l: O virgin! or what other Name you bear
A bove that tile; O more than mortal fair!
Your Voice and Meen Coeletial birth betray!
If, as you eem, the Siter of the Day;
Or one at leat of Chat Diana's Train,
Let not an humble Suppliant ue in vain:
But tell a Stranger, long in Tempets tot,
What Earth we tread, and who commands the Coat?
Then on your Name hall wretched Mortals call;
And offer'd Victims at your Altars fall.
I dare not, he reply'd, aume the Name
Of Goddes, or Coeletial Honours claim:
For Tyrian Virgins Bows and Quivers bear,
And Purple Buskins o're their Ankles wear.
Know, gentle Youth, in Lybian Lands you are:
A People rude in Peace, and rough in War.
The riing City, which from far you ee,
Is Carthage; and a Tyrian Colony.
Phenician Dido rules the growing State,
Who fled from Tyre, to hun her Brother's hate:
Great were her wrongs, her Story full of Fate;
Which I will um in hort. Sicheus known
For wealth, and Brother to the Punic Throne,
Poes'd fair Dido's Bed: And either heart
At once was wounded with an equal Dart.
Her Father gave her, yet a potles Maid;
Pigmalion then the Tyrian Scepter way'd:
One who contemn'd Divine and Humane Laws:
Then Strife enu'd, and cured Gold the Caue.
The Monarch, blinded with deire of Wealth;
With Steel invades his Brother's life by tealth;
Before the acred Altar made him bleed,
And long from her conceal'd the cruel deed.
Some Tale, ome new Pretence, he daily coin'd,
To ooth his Siter, and delude her Mind.
At length, in dead of Night, the Ghot appears
Of her unhappy Lord: the Spectre tares,
And with erected Eyes his bloody Boom bares.
The cruel Altars, and his Fate he tells,
And the dire Secret of his Houe reveals.
Then warns the Widdow, with her houehold Gods,
To eek a Refuge in remote abodes.
Lat, to upport her, in o long a way,
He hows her where his hidden Treaure lay.
Admonih'd thus, and eiz'd with mortal fright,
The Queen provides Companions of her flight:
They meet; and all combine to leave the State,
Who hate the Tyrant, or who fear his hate.
They eize a Fleet, which ready rigg'd they find:
Nor is Pigmalion's Treaure left behind.
The Veels, heavy laden, put to Sea
With proprous winds; a Woman leads the way.
I know not, if by tres of Weather driv'n,
Or was their fatal Coure dipos'd by Heav'n;
At lat they landed, where from far your Eyes
May view the Turrets of new Carthage rie:
There bought a pace of Ground, which Byra call'd
From the Bulls hide, they firt inclos'd, and wall'd.
But whence are you, what Country claims your Birth?
What eek you, Strangers, on our Lybian Earth?
To whom, with orrow treaming from his Eyes,
And deeply ighing, thus her Son replyes:
Cou'd you with Patience hear, or I relate,
O Nymph! the tedious Annals of our Fate!
Thro' uch a train of Woes if I hou'd run,
The day wou'd ooner than the Tale be done!
From ancient Troy, by Force expell'd, we came,
If you by chance have heard the Trojan Name:
On various Seas by various Tempets tot,
At length we landed on your Lybian Coat.
The Good Aeneas am I call'd, a Name,
While Fortune favour'd, not unknown to Fame:
My houhold Gods, Companions of my Woes,
With pious Care I recu'd from our Foes.
To fruitful Italy my Coure was bent,
And from the King of Heav'n is my Decent.
With twice ten Sail I crot the Phrygian Sea;
Fate, and my Mother Goddes, led my Way.
Scarce ev'n, the thin Remainders of my Fleet,
From Storms preerv'd, within your Harbour meet:
My elf ditres'd, an Exile, and unknown,
Debarr'd from Europe, and from Aia thrown,
In Lybian Dearts wander thus alone.
His tender Parent could no longer bear;
But, interpoing, ought to ooth his Care.
Who e're you are, not unbelov'd by Heav'n,
Since on our friendly Shoar your Ships are driv'n:
Have Courage: To the Gods permit the ret,
And to the Queen expoe your jut Requet.
Now take this earnet of Succes, for more
Your catter'd Fleet is join'd upon the Shoar;
The Winds are chang'd, your Friends from danger free,
Or I renounce my Skill in Augury.
Twelve Swans behold, in beauteous order move,
And toop with cloing Pinions from above:
Whom late the Bird of Jove had driv'n along,
And through the Clouds puru'd the catt'ring Throng:
Now all united in a goodly Team,
They skim the Ground, and eek the quiet Stream.
As they, with Joy returning, clap their Wings,
And ride the Circuit of the Skies in Rings:
Not otherwie your Ships, and ev'ry Friend,
Already hold the Port, or with wift Sails decend.
No more Advice is needful, but purue
The Path before you, and the Town in view.
Thus having aid, he turn'd, and made appear
Her Neck refulgent, and dihevel'd Hair;
Which flowing from her Shoulders, reach'd the Ground,
And widely pread Ambroial Scents around:
In length of Train decends her weeping Gown,
And by her graceful Walk, the Queen of Love is known.
The Prince puru'd the parting Deity,
With Words like thee: Ah! whither do you fly?
Unkind and cruel, to deceive your Son
In borrow'd Shapes, and his Embrace to hun:
Never to bles my Sight, but thus unknown;
And till to peak in Accents not your own.
Againt the Goddes thee Complaints he made;
But took the Path, and her Commands obey'd.
They march obcure, for Venus kindly hrowds,
With Mits, their Perons, and involves in Clouds:
That, thus uneen, their Paage none might tay,
Or force to tell the Caues of their Way.
This part perform'd, the Goddes flies ublime,
To viit Paphos; and her native Clime:
Where Garlands ever green, and ever fair,
With Vows are offer'd, and with olemn Pray'r:
A hundred Altars in her Temple Smoke,
A thouand bleeding Hearts her Pow'r invoke.
They climb the next Acent, and, looking down,
Now at a nearer Ditance view the Town:
The Prince, with Wonder, ees the tately Tow'rs,
Which late were Huts, and Shepherd's homely Bow'rs.
The Gates and Streets; and hears, from ev'ry part,
The Noie, and buiy Concoure of the Mart.
The toiling Tyrians on each other call,
To ply their Labour: Some extend the Wall,
Some build the Citadel; the brawny Throng,
Or dig, or puh unweildy Stones along.
Some for their Dwellings chue a Spot of Ground,
Which, firt deign'd, with Ditches they urround.
Some Laws ordain, and ome attend the Choice
Of holy Senates, and elect by Voice.
Here ome deign a Mole, while others there
Lay deep Foundations for a Theatre:
From Marble Quarries mighty Columns hew,
For Ornaments of Scenes, and future view.
Such is their Toyl, and uch their buiy Pains,
As exercie the Bees in flow'ry Plains;
When Winter pat, and Summer carce begun,
Invites them forth to labour in the Sun:
Some lead their Youth abroad, while ome condene
Their liquid Store, and ome in Cells dipence.
Some at the Gate tand ready to receive
The Golden Burthen, and their Friends relieve.
All, with united Force, combine to drive
The lazy Drones from the laborious Hive;
With Envy tung they view each others Deeds;
The fragrant Work with Diligence proceeds.
Thrice happy you, whoe Walls already rie;

l.U: aid; and view'd, with lifted Eyes,

lg.l: Their lofty Tow'rs; then ent'ring at the Gate,
Conceal'd in Clouds, (prodigious to relate)
He mix'd, unmark'd, among the buiy Throng,
Born by the Tide, and pas'd uneen along.
Full in the Centre of the Town there tood,
Thick et with Trees, a venerable Wood:
The Tyrians landing near this holy Ground,
And digging here, a prop'rous Omen found:
From under Earth a Courer's Head they drew,
Their Growth and future Fortune to forehew:
This fatal Sign their Foundres Juno gave,
Of a Soil fruitful, and a People brave.
Sidonian Dido here with olemn State
Did Juno's Temple build, and conecrate:
Enrich'd with Gifts, and with a Golden Shrine;
But more the Goddes made the Place Divine.
On Brazen Steps the Marble Threhold roe,
And brazen Plates the Cedar Beams incloe:
The Rafters are with brazen Cov'rings crown'd,
The lofty Doors on brazen Hinges ound.
What firt Aeneas in this place beheld,
Reviv'd his Courage, and his Fear expel'd.
For while, expecting there the Queen, he rais'd
His wond'ring Eyes, and round the Temple gaz'd;
Admir'd the Fortune of the riing Town,
The triving Artits, and their Arts renown:
He aw in order painted on the Wall,
Whatever did unhappy Troy befall:
The Wars that Fate around the World had blown,
All to the Life, and ev'ry Leader known.
There Agamemnon, Priam here he pies,
And fierce Achilles who both Kings defies.
He top'd, and weeping aid, O Friend! ev'n here
The Monuments of Trojan Woes appear!
Our known Diaters fill ev'n foreign Lands:
See there, where old unhappy Priam tands!
Ev'n the Mute Walls relate the Warrior's Fame,
And Trojan Griefs the Tyrians Pity claim.
He aid, his Tears a ready Paage find,
Devouring what he aw o well deign'd;
And with an empty Picture fed his Mind
For there he aw the fainting Grecians yield,
And here the trembling Trojans quit the Field,
Puru'd by fierce Achilles through the Plain,
On his high Chariot driving o're the Slain.
The Tents of Rheus next, his Grief renew,
By their white Sails betray'd to nightly view.
And wakeul Diomede, whoe cruel Sword
The Centries lew; nor par'd their lumb'ring Lord.
Then took the fiery Steeds, e're yet the Food
Of Troy they tate, or drink the Xanthian Flood.
Elewhere he aw where Troilus defy'd
Achilles, and unequal Combat try'd.
Then, where the Boy diarm'd with looen'd Reins,
Was by his Hores hurry'd o're the Plains:
Hung by the Neck and Hair, and drag'd around,
The hotile Spear yet ticking in his Wound;
With tracks of Blood incrib'd the duty Ground.
Mean time the Trojan Dames oppres'd with Woe,
To Pallas Fane in long Preceion goe,
In hopes to reconcile their Heav'nly Foe:
They weep, they beat their Breats, they rend their Hair,
And rich embroider'd Vets for Preents bear:
But the tern Goddes tands unmov'd with Pray'r.
Thrice round the Trojan Walls Achilles drew
The Corps of Hector, whom in Fight he lew.
Here Priam ues, and there, for Sums of Gold,
The lifeles Body of his Son is old.
So ad an Object, and o well expres'd,
Drew Sighs and Groans from the griev'd Heroes Breat:
To ee the Figure of his lifeles Friend,
And his old Sire his helples Hand extend.
Himelf he aw amidt the Grecian Train,
Mix'd in the bloody Battel on the Plain.
And warthy Memnon in his Arms he knew
His pompous Enigns, and his Indian Crew.
Penthiilea there, with haughty Grace,
Leads to the Wars an Amazonian Race:
In their right Hands a pointed Dart they wield;
The left, for Ward, utains the Lunar Shield.
Athwart her Breat a Golden Belt he throws,
Amidt the Pres alone provokes a thouand Foes:
And dares her Maiden Arms to Manly Force oppoe.
Thus, while the Trojan Prince employs his Eyes,
Fix'd on the Walls with wonder and urprie;
The Beauteous Dido, with a num'rous Train,
And pomp of Guards, acends the acred Fane.
Such on Eurota's Banks, or Cynthus's hight,

l.U: eems; and o he charms the ight,

lg.l: When in the Dance the graceful Goddes leads
The Quire of Nymphs, and overtops their Heads.
Known by her Quiver, and her lofty Meen,
She walks Majetick, and he looks their Queen:

l.U: ees her hine above the ret,

lg.l: And feeds with ecret Joy her ilent Breat.
Such Dido was; with uch becoming State,
Amidt the Crowd, he walks erenely great.
Their Labour to her future Sway he peeds,
And paing with a gracious Glance proceeds:
Then mounts the Throne, high plac'd before the Shrine;
In Crowds around the warming People joyn.
She takes Petitions, and dipenes Laws,
Hears, and determines ev'ry Private Caue.
Their Tasks in equal Portions he divides,
And where unequal, there by Lots decides.
Another Way by chance Aeneas bends
His Eyes, and unexpected ees his Friends:
Antheus, Sergetus grave, Cloanthus trong,
And at their Backs a mighty Trojan Throng:
Whom late the Tempet on the Billows tot,
And widely catter'd on another Coat.
The Prince, uneen, urpriz'd with Wonder tands,
And longs, with joyful hate to join their Hands:
But doubtful of the wih'd Event, he tays,
And from the hollow Cloud his Friends urveys:
Impatient 'till they told their preent State,
And where they left their Ships, and what their Fate;
And why they came, and what was their Requet:
For thee were ent commiion'd by the ret,
To ue for leave to land their ickly Men,
And gain Admiion to the Gracious Queen.
Ent'ring, with Cries they fill'd the holy Fane;
Then thus, with humble Voice, Ilioneus began.
O Queen! indulg'd by Favour of the Gods,
To found an Empire in thee new Abodes;
To build a Town, with Statutes to retrain
The wild Inhabitants beneath thy Reign:
We wretched Trojans tot on ev'ry Shore,
From Sea to Sea, thy Clemency implore:
Forbid the Fires our Shipping to deface,
Receive th' unhappy Fugitives to Grace,
And pare the remnant of a Pious Race.
We come not with deign of watful Prey,
To drive the Country, force the Swains away:
Nor uch our Strength, nor uch is our Deire,
The vanquih'd dare not to uch Thoughts apire.
A Land there is, Heperia nam'd of old,
The Soil is fruitful, and the Men are bold:
Th' Oenotrians held it once, by common Fame,
Now call'd Italia, from the Leaders Name.
To that weet Region was our Voyage bent,
When Winds, and ev'ry warring Element,
Diturb'd our Coure, and far from ight of Land,
Cat our torn Veels on the moving Sand:
The Sea came on; the South with mighty Roar,
Dipers'd and dah'd the ret upon the Rocky Shoar.
Thoe few you ee ecap'd the Storm, and fear,
Unles you interpoe, a Shipwreck here:
What Men, what Monters, what inhuman Race,
What Laws, what barb'rous Cutoms of the Place,
Shut up a deart Shoar to drowning Men,
And drives us to the cruel Seas agen!
If our hard Fortune no Compaion draws,
Nor hopitable Rights, nor human Laws,
The Gods are jut, and will revenge our Caue.
Aeneas was our Prince, a juter Lord,
Or nobler Warriour, never drew a Sword:
Obervant of the Right, religious of his Word.
If yet he lives, and draws this vital Air:
Nor we his Friends of Safety hall depair;
Nor you, great Queen, thee Offices repent,
Which he will equal, and perhaps prevent.
We want not Cities, nor Sicilian Coats,
Where King Acetes Trojan Lineage boats.
Permit our Ships a Shelter on your Shoars,
Refitted from your Woods with Planks and Oars;
That if our Prince be afe, we may renew
Our detin'd Coure, and Italy purue.
But if, O bet of Men! the Fates ordain
That thou art wallow'd in the Lybian Main:
And if our young Iulus be no more,
Dimis our Navy from your friendly Shoar.
That we to good Acetes may return,
And with our Friends our common Loes mourn.
Thus poke Ilioneus; the Trojan Crew
With Cries and Clamours his Requet renew.
The modet Queen a while, with down-cat Eyes,
Ponder'd the Speech; then briefly thus replies.
Trojans dimis your Fears: my cruel Fate,
And doubts attending an unetled State,
Force me to guard my Coat, from Foreign Foes.
Who has not heard the tory of your Woes?
The Name and Fortune of your Native Place,
The Fame and Valour of the Phrygian Race?
We Tyrians are not o devoid of Sene,
Nor o remote from Phoebus influence.
Whether to Latian Shores your Coure is bent,
Or driv'n by Tempet's from your firt intent,
You eek the good Acetes Government;
Your Men hall be receiv'd, your Fleet repair'd,
And ail, with Ships of Convoy for your guard;
Or, wou'd you tay, and joyn your friendly Pow'rs,
To raie and to defend the Tyrian Tow'rs;
My Wealth, my City, and my Self are yours.
And wou'd to Heav'n the Storm, you felt, wou'd bring
On Carthaginian Coats your wand'ring King.
My People hall, by my Command, explore
The Ports and Creeks of ev'ry winding hore;
And Towns, and Wilds, and hady Woods, in quet
Of o renown'd and o deir'd a Guet.
Rais'd in his Mind the Trojan Heroe tood,
And long'd to break from out his Ambient Cloud;
Achates found it; and thus urg'd his way;
From whence, O Goddes born, this long delay?
What more can you deire, your Welcome ure,
Your Fleet in afety, and your Friends ecure?
One only wants; and him we aw in vain
Oppoe the Storm, and wallow'd in the Main.
Orontes in his Fate our Forfeit paid,
The ret agrees with what your Mother aid.
Scarce had he poken, when the Cloud gave way,
The Mits flew upward, and diolv'd in day.
The Trojan Chief appear'd in open ight,
Augut in Viage, and erenely bright.
His Mother Goddes, with her hands Divine,
Had form'd his Curling Locks, and made his Temples hine:
And giv'n his rowling Eyes a parkling grace;
And breath'd a youthful vigour on his Face:
Like polih'd Iv'ry, beauteous to behold,
Or Parian Marble, when enchas'd in Gold:
Thus radiant from the circling Cloud he broke;
And thus with manly modety he poke.
He whom you eek am I: by Tempets tot,
And av'd from Shipwreck on your Lybian Coat:
Preenting, gracious Queen, before your Throne,
A Prince that ows his Life to you alone.
Fair Majety, the Refuge and Redres
Of thoe whom Fate purues, and Wants oppres.
You, who your pious Offices employ
To ave the Reliques of abandon'd Troy;
Receive the Shipwreck'd on your friendly Shore,
With hopitable Rites relieve the Poor:
Aociate in your Town a wandring Train,
And Strangers in your Palace entertain.
What thanks can wretched Fugitives return,
Who catter'd thro' the World in exile mourn?
The Gods, (if Gods to Goodnes are inclin'd,)
If Acts of mercy touch their Heav'nly Mind;
And more than all the Gods, your gen'rous heart,
Concious of worth, requite its own deert!
In you this Age is happy, and this Earth:
And Parents more than Mortal gave you birth.

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Elizabeth Countes Dowager of Winchelsea &ct.
figure.head: AE. 1. l: 875.

lg.l: While rowling Rivers into Seas hall run,
And round the pace of Heav'n the radiant Sun;
While Trees the Mountain tops with Shades upply,
Your Honour, Name, and Praie hall never dye.
What e're abode my Fortune has aign'd,
Your Image hall be preent in my Mind.
Thus having aid; he turn'd with pious hat,
And joyful his expecting Friends embrac'd:
With his right hand Ilioneus was grac'd,
Seretus with his left; then to his breat
Cloanthus and the Noble Gyas pret;
And o by turns decended to the ret.
The Tyrian Queen tood fix'd upon his Face,
Pleas'd with his motions, ravih'd with his grace:
Admir'd his Fortunes, more admir'd the Man;
Then recollected tood; and thus began.
What Fate, O Goddes born, what angry Pow'rs
Have cat you hipwrack'd on our barren Shores?
Are you the great Aeneas, known to Fame,
Who from Coeletial Seed your Lineage claim!
The ame Aeneas whom fair Venus bore
To fam'd Anchies on th' Idaean Shore?
It calls into my mind, tho' then a Child,
When Teucer came from Salamis exil'd;
And ought my Father's aid, to be retor'd:
My Father Belus then with Fire and Sword
Invaded Cyprus, made the Region bare,
And, Conqu'ring, finih'd the uccesful War.
From him the Trojan Siege I undertood,
The Grecian Chiefs, and your Illutrious Blood.
Your Foe himelf the Dardan Valour prais'd,
And his own Ancetry from Trojans rais'd.
Enter, my Noble Guet; and you hall find,
If not a cotly welcome, yet a kind.
For I my elf, like you, have been ditres'd;
Till Heav'n afforded me this place of ret.
Like you an Alien in a Land unknown;
I learn to pity Woes, o like my own.
She aid, and to the Palace led her Guet,
Then offer'd Incene, and proclaim'd a Feat.
Nor yet les careful for her abent Friends,
Twice ten fat Oxen to the Ships he ends:
Beides a hundred Boars, a hundred Lambs,
With bleating cries, attend their Milky Dams.
And Jars of gen'rous Wine, and pacious Bowls,
She gives to chear the Sailors drooping Souls.
Now Purple Hangings cloath the Palace Walls,
And umptuous Feats are made in plendid Halls:
On Tyrian Carpets, richly wrought, they dine;
With loads of May Plate the Side-boards hine.
And Antique Vafes all of Gold Embos'd;
(The Gold it elf inferiour to the Cot:)
Of curious Work, where on the ides were een
The Fights and Figures of Illutrious Men;
From their firt Founder to the preent Queen.
The Good Aeneas, whoe Paternal Care
Iulus abence could no longer bear,
Dipatch'd Achates to the Ships in hat,
To give a glad Relation of the pat;
And, fraught with precious Gifts, to bring the Boy
Snatch'd from the Ruins of unhappy Troy:
A Robe of Tiue, tiff with golden Wire;
An upper Vet, once Hellen's rich Attire;
From Argos by the fam'd Adultres brought,
With Golden flow'rs and winding foliage wrought;
Her Mother Laeda's Preent, when he came
To ruin Troy, and et the World on flame.
The Scepter Priam's eldet Daughter bore,
Her orient Necklace, and the Crown he wore;
Of double texture, glorious to behold;
One order et with Gems, and one with Gold.
Intructed thus, the wie Achates goes:
And in his diligence his duty hows.
But Venus, anxious for her Son's Affairs,
New Councils tryes; and new Deigns prepares:
That Cupid hould aume the Shape and Face
Of weet Acanius, and the prightly grace:
Shou'd bring the Prefents, in her Nephews tead,
And in Eliza's Veins the gentle Poion hed.
For much he fear'd the Tyrians, double tongu'd,
And knew the Town to Juno's care belong'd.
Thee thoughts by Night her Golden Slumbers broke;
And thus alarm'd, to winged Love he poke.
My Son, my trength, whoe mighty Pow'r alone
Controuls the Thund'rer, on his awful Throne;
To thee thy much afflicted Mother flies,
And on thy Succour, and thy Faith relies.
Thou know't, my Son, how Jove's revengeful Wife,
By force and Fraud, attempts thy Brother's life.
And often hat thou mourn'd with me his Pains:
Him Dido now with Blandihment detains;
But I upect the Town where Juno reigns.
For this, 'tis needful to prevent her Art,
And fire with Love the proud Phoenician's heart.
A Love o violent, o fond, o ure,
That neither Age can change, nor Art can cure.
How this may be perform'd, now take my mind:
Acanius, by his Father is deign'd
To come, with Preents, laden from the Port,
To gratifie the Queen, and gain the Court.
I mean to plunge the Boy in pleaing Sleep,
And, ravih'd, in Idalian Bow'rs to keep;
Or high Cythaera: That the weet Deceipt
May pas uneen, and none prevent the Cheat,
Take thou his Form and Shape. I beg the Grace
But only for a Night's revolving Space;
Thy elf a Boy, aume a Boy's diembled Face.
That when amidt the fervour of the Feat,
The Tyrian hugs, and fonds thee on her Breat,
And with weet Kies in her Arms contrains,
Thou may't infue thy Venom in her Veins.
The God of Love obeys, and ets aide
His Bow, and Quiver, and his plumy Pride:
He walks Iulus in his Mother's Sight,
And in the weet Reemblance takes Delight.
The Goddes then to young Acanius flies,
And in a pleaing Slumber eals his Eyes;
Lull'd in her Lap, amidt a Train of Loves,
She gently bears him to her blisful Groves:
Then with a Wreath of Myrtle crowns his Head,
And oftly lays him on a flow'ry Bed.
Cupid mean time aum'd his Form and Face,
Foll'wing Achates with a horter Pace;
And brought the Gifts. The Queen, already ate
Amidt the Trojan Lords, in hining State,
High on a Golden Bed: Her Princely Guet
Was next her ide, in order ate the ret.
Then Caniters with Bread are heap'd on high;
Th' Attendants Water for their Hands upply;
And having wah'd, with ilken Towels dry.
Next fifty Handmaids in long order bore
The Ceners, and with Fumes the Gods adore.
Then Youths, and Virgins twice as many, join
To place the Dihes, and to erve the Wine.

figure.p: To the most Honble. Ursula Marchiones of Normaneby
figure.head: AE. 1. l 995

lg.l: The Tyrian Train, admitted to the Feat,
Approach, and on the painted Couches ret.
All on the Trojan Gifts, with Wonder gaze;
But view the beauteous Boy with more amaze.
His Roy-colour'd Cheeks, his radiant Eyes,
His Motions, Voice, and Shape, and all the God's diguie.
Nor pas unprais'd the Vet and Veil Divine,
Which wand'ring Foliage and rich Flow'rs entwine.
But far above the ret, the Royal Dame,
(Already doom'd to Love's diatrous Flame;)
With Eyes inatiate, and tumultuous Joy,
Beholds the Preents, and admires the Boy.
The guileful God, about his Father long,
With Children's play, and fale Embraces hung;
Then ought the Queen: She took him to her Arms,
With greedy Pleaure, and devour'd his Charms.
Unhappy Dido little thought what Guet,
How dire a God he drew o near her Breat.
But he, not mindles of his Mother's Pray'r,
Works in the pliant Boom of the Fair;
And moulds her Heart anew, and blots her former Care.
The dead is to the living Love reign'd,
And all Aeneas enters in her Mind.
Now, when the Rage of Hunger was appeas'd,
The Meat remov'd, and ev'ry Guet was pleas'd;
The Golden Bowls with parkling Wine are crown'd,
And through the Palace chearful Cries reound.
From gilded Roofs depending Lamps diplay
Nocturnal Beams, that emulate the Day.
A Golden Bowl, that hone with Gems Divine,
The Queen commanded to be crown'd with Wine;
The Bowl that Belus us'd, and all the Tyrian Line.
Then, Silence through the Hall proclaim'd, he poke:
O hopitable Jove! we thus invoke,
With olemn Rites, thy acred Name and Pow'r!
Bles to both Nations this aupicious Hour.
So may the Tojan and the Tyrian Line,
In lating Concord, from this Day combine.
Thou, Bacchus, God of Joys and friendly Cheer,
And gracious Juno, both be preent here:
And you, my Lords of Tyre, your Vows addres
To Heav'n with mine, to ratifie the Peace.
The Goblet then he took, with Nectar crown'd,
(Sprinkling the firt Libations on the Ground,)
And rais'd it to her Mouth with ober Grace,
Then ipping, offer'd to the next in place.
'Twas Bitias whom he call'd, a thirty Soul,
He took the Challenge, and embrac'd the Bowl:
With Pleaure will'd the Gold, nor ceas'd to draw,
'Till he the bottom of the Brimmer aw.
The Goblet goes around: Iopas brought
His Golden Lyre, and ung what ancient Atlas taught.
The various Labours of the wand'ring Moon,
And whence proceed th' Eclipes of the Sun.
Th' Original of Men, and Beats; and whence
The Rains arie, and Fires their Warmth dipence;
And fix'd, and erring Stars, dipoe their Influence.
What hakes the olid Earth, what Caue delays
The Summer Nights, and hortens Winter Days.
With Peals of Shouts the Tyrians praie the Song;
Thoe Peals are echo'd by the Trojan Throng.
Th' unhappy Queen with Talk prolong'd the Night,
And drank large Draughts of Love with vat Delight.
Of Priam much enquir'd, of Hector more;
Then ask'd what Arms the warthy Memnon wore;
What Troops he landed on the Trojan Shore.
The Steeds of Di'mede vary'd the Dicoure,
And fierce Achilles, with his matchles Force.
At length, as Fate and her ill Stars requir'd,
To hear the Series of the War deir'd.
Relate at large, my God-like Guet, he aid,
The Grecian Stratagems, the Town betray'd;
The fatal Iue of o long a War,
Your Flight, your Wand'rings, and your Woes declare.
For ince on ev'ry Sea, on ev'ry Coat,
Your Men have been ditres'd, your Navy tot,
Sev'n times the Sun has either Tropick view'd,
The Winter banih'd, and the Spring renew'd.

div.head: The Second Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Aeneas relates how the City of Troy was taken, after a Ten Years Siege, by the Treachery of Sinon, and the Stratagem of a wooden Hore. He declares the fixt Reolution he had taken not to urvive the Ruins of his Country, and the various Adventures he met with in the Defence of it: at lat having been before advis'd by Hector's Ghot, and now by the Appearance of his Mother Venus, he is prevail'd upon to leave the Town, and ettle his Houhold-Gods in another Country. in order to this, he carries off his Father on his Shoulders, and leads his little Son by the Hand, his Wife following him behind. When he comes to the Place appointed for the general Rendevouze, he finds a great Confluence of People, but mies his Wife, whoe Ghot afterwards appears to him, and tells him the Land which was deign'd for him.

lg.l: ALL were attentive to the God-like Man;
When from the lofty Couch he thus began.
Great Queen, what you command me to relate,
Renews the ad remembrance of our Fate.
An Empire from its old Foundations rent,
And ev'ry Woe the Trojans underwent:
A Peopl'd City made a Deart Place;
All that I aw, and part of which I was:
Not ev'n the hardet of our Foes cou'd hear,
Nor tern Ulyes tell without a Tear.
And now the latter Watch of wating Night,
And etting Stars to kindly Ret invite.
But ince you take uch Int'ret in our Woe,
And Troy's diat'rous end deire to know:
I will retrain my Tears, and briefly tell
What in our lat and fatal Night befel.
By Detiny compell'd, and in Depair,
The Greeks grew weary of the tedious War:

figure.p: To ye mot Illustrious Prince Charles Duke of Somerset, Knight of ye most Noble Order of ye Garter.
figure.head: AE. 2. l: 1.

lg.l: And by Minerva's Aid a Fabrick rear'd,
Which like a Steed of montrous height appear'd;
The Sides were planck'd with Pine, they feign'd it made
For their Return, and this the Vow they paid.
Thus they pretend, but in the hollow Side,
Selected Numbers of their Souldiers hide:
With inward Arms the dire Machine they load,
With Iron Bowels tuff the dark Abode.
In ight of Troy lies Tenedos, an Ile,
(While Fortune did on Priam's Empire mile)
Renown'd for Wealth, but ince a faithles Bay,
Where Ships expos'd to Wind and Weather lay.
There was their Fleet conceal'd: We thought for Greece
Their Sails were hoited, and our Fears releae.
The Trojans coop'd within their Walls o long,
Unbar their Gates, and iue in a Throng,
Like warming Bees, and with Delight urvey
The Camp deerted, where the Grecians lay:
The Quarters of the ev'ral Chiefs they how'd,
Here Phoenix, here Achilles made abode,
Here join'd the Battels, there the Navy rode.
Part on the Pile their wond'ring Eyes employ,
(The Pile by Pallas rais'd to ruin Troy.)
Thymaetes firt ('tis doubtful whether hir'd,
Or o the Trojan Detiny requir'd)
Mov'd that the Ramparts might be broken down,
To lodge the fatal Engine in the Town.
But Capys, and the ret of ounder Mind,
The fatal Preent to the Flames deign'd;
Or to the watry deep: At leat to bore
The hollow ides, and hidden Frauds explore:
The giddy Vulgar, as their Fancies guide,
With Noie ay nothing, and in parts divide.
Iaocoon, follow'd by a num'rous Crowd,
Ran from the Fort; and cry'd, from far, aloud;
O wretched Country-men! what Fury reigns?
What more than Madnes has poes'd your Brains?
Think you the Grecians from your Coats are gone,
And are Ulyes Arts no better known?
This hollow Fabrick either mut incloe,
Within its blind Reces, our ecret Foes;
Or 'tis an Engine rais'd above the Town,
T' o'relook the Walls, and then to batter down.
Somewhat is ure deign'd; by Fraud or Force;
Trut not their Preents, nor admit the Hore.
Thus having aid, againt the Steed he threw
His forceful Spear, which, hiing as it flew,
Pierc'd through the yielding Planks of jointed Wood,
And trembling in the hollow Belly tood.
The ides tranpierc'd, return a ratling Sound,
And Groans of Greeks inclos'd come iuing through the Wound.
And had not Heav'n the fall of Troy deign'd,
Or had not Men been fated to be blind,
Enough was aid and done, t' inpire a better Mind:
Then had our Lances pierc'd the treach'rous Wood,
And Ilian Tow'rs, and Priam's Empire tood.
Mean time, with Shouts, the Trojan Shepherds bring
A captive Greek in Bands, before the King:
Taken, to take; who made himelf their Prey,
T' impoe on their Belief, and Troy betray.
Fix'd on his Aim, and obtinately bent
To die undaunted, or to circumvent.
About the Captive, tides of Trojans flow;
All pres to ee, and ome inult the Foe.
Now hear how well the Greeks their Wiles diguis'd,
Behold a Nation in a Man compris'd.
Trembling the Micreant tood, unarm'd and bound;
He tar'd, and rowl'd his hagger'd Eyes around:
Then aid, Alas! what Earth remains, what Sea
Is open to receive unhappy me!
What Fate a wretched Fugitive attends,
Scorn'd by my Foes, abandon'd by my Friends.
He aid, and igh'd, and cat a ruful Eye:
Our Pity kindles, and our Paions dye.
We chear the Youth to make his own Defence,
And freely tell us what he was, and whence:
What News he cou'd impart, we long to know,
And what to credit from a captive Foe.
His fear at length dimis'd, he aid, what e're
My Fate ordains, my Words hall be incere:
I neither can, nor dare my Birth diclaim,
Greece is my Country, Sinon is my Name:
Though plung'd by Fortune's Pow'r in Miery,
'Tis not in Fortune's Pow'r to make me lye.
If any chance has hither brought the Name
Of Palamedes, not unknown to Fame,
Who uffer'd from the Malice of the times;
Accus'd and entenc'd for pretended Crimes:
Becaue thee fatal Wars he would prevent;
Whoe Death the wretched Greeks too late lament;
Me, then a Boy, my Father, poor and bare
Of other Means, committed to his Care:
His Kinman and Companion in the War.
While Fortune favour'd, while his Arms upport
The Caue, and rul'd the Counels of the Court,
I made ome figure there; nor was my Name
Obcure, nor I without my hare of Fame.
But when Ulyes, with fallacious Arts,
Had made Impreion in the Peoples Hearts;
And forg'd a Treaon in my Patron's Name,
(I peak of things too far divulg'd by Fame)
My Kinman fell; then I, without upport,
In private mourn'd his Los, and left the Court.
Mad as I was, I could not bear his Fate
With ilent Grief, but loudly blam'd the State:
And curs'd the direful Author of my Woes.
'Twas told again, and hence my Ruin roe.
I threatn'd, if indulgent Heav'n once more
Wou'd land me afely on my Native Shore,
His Death with double Vengeance to retore.
This mov'd the Murderer's Hate, and oon enu'd
Th' Effects of Malice from a Man o proud.
Ambiguous Rumors thro the Camp he pread,
And ought, by Treaon, my devoted Head:
New Crimes invented, left unturn'd no Stone,
To make my Guilt appear, and hide his own.
'Till Calchas was by Force and Threatning wrought:
But why—Why dwell I on that anxious Thought?
If on my Nation jut Revenge you eek,
And 'tis t' appear a Foe, t' appear a Greek;
Already you my Name and Country know,
Awage your thirt of Blood, and trike the Blow:
My Death will both the Kingly Brothers pleae,
And et inatiate Ithacus at eae.
This fair unfinih'd Tale, thee broken tarts,
Rais'd expectations in our longing Hearts;
Unknowing as we were in Grecian Arts.
His former trembling once again renew'd,
With acted Fear, the Villain thus puru'd.
Long had the Grecians (tir'd with fruitles Care,
And weary'd with an unuccesful War,)
Reolv'd to raie the Siege, and leave the Town;
And had the Gods permitted, they had gone.
But oft the Wintry Seas, and Southern Winds,
Withtood their paage home, and chang'd their Minds.
Portents and Prodigies their Souls amaz'd;
But mot, when this tupendous Pile was rais'd.
Then flaming Meteors, hung in Air, were een,
And Thunders ratled through a Skie erene:
Dimay'd, and fearful of ome dire Event,
Eurypylus, t'enquire their Fate, was ent;
He from the Gods this dreadful Anwer brought;
O Grecians, when the Trojan Shores you ought,
Your Paage with a Virgin's Blood was bought:
So mut your afe Return be bought again;
And Grecian Blood, once more attone the Main.
The preading Rumour round the People ran;
All fear'd, and each believ'd himelf the Man.
Ulyes took th'advantage of their fright;
Call'd Calchas, and produc'd in open ight:
Than bade him name the Wretch, ordain'd by Fate,
The Publick Victim, to redeem the State.
Already ome preag'd the dire Event,
And aw what Sacrifice Ulyes meant.
For twice five days the good old Seer withtood
Th' intended Treaon, and was dumb to Blood.
Till Tir'd with endles Clamours, and purute
