Of Ithacus, he tood no longer Mute:
But, as it was agreed, pronounc'd, that I
Was detin'd by the wrathful Gods to die.
All prais'd the Sentence, pleas'd the torm hould fall
On one alone, whoe Fury threatn'd all.
The dimal day was come, the Priets prepare
Their leaven'd Cakes; and Fillets for my Hair.
I follow'd Natur's Laws, and mut avow
I broke my Bonds, and fled the fatal blow.
Hid in a weedy Lake all Night I lay,
Secure of Safety when they ail'd away.
But now what further Hopes for me remain,
To ee my Friends or Native Soil again?
My tender Infants, or my careful Sire;
Whom they returning will to Death require?
Will perpetrate on them their firt Deign,
And take the forfeit of their heads for mine?
Which, O if Pity mortal Minds can move!
If there be Faith below, or Gods above!
If Innocence and Truth can claim deert,
Ye Trojans from an injur'd Wretch avert.
Fale Tears true Pity move: the King Commands
To looe his Fetters, and unbind his hands:
Then adds thee friendly words; dimis thy Fears,
Forget the Greeks, be mine as thou wert theirs.
But truly tell, was it for Force or Guile,
Or ome Religious End, you rais'd the Pile?
Thus aid the King. He full of fraudful Arts,
This well invented Tale for Truth imparts.
Ye Lamps of Heav'n! he aid, and lifted high
His hands now free, thou venerable Sky,
Inviolable Pow'rs, ador'd with dread,
Ye fatal Fillets, that once bound this head,
Ye acred Altars, from whoe flames I fled!
Be all of you adjur'd; and grant I may,
Without a Crime, th' ungrateful Greeks betray!
Reveal the Secrets of the guilty State,
And jutly punih whom I jutly hate!
But you, O King, preeve the Faith you gave,
If I to ave my elf your Empire ave.
The Grecian Hopes, and all th' Attempts they made,
Were only founded on Minerva's Aid.
But from the time when impious Diomede,
And fale Ulyes, that inventive Head,
Her fatal Image from the Temple drew,
The leeping Guardians of the Catle lew,
Her Virgin Statue with their bloody Hands
Polluted, and prophan'd her holy Bands:
From thence the Tide of Fortune left their Shore,
And ebb'd much fater than it flow'd before:
Their Courage languih'd, as their Hopes decay'd,
And Pallas, now avere, refus'd her Aid.
Nor did the Goddes doubtfully declare
Her alter'd Mind, and alienated Care:
When firt her fatal Image touch'd the Ground,
She ternly cat her glaring Eyes around;
That parkl'd as they rowl'd, and eem'd to threat:
Her Heav'nly Limbs ditill'd a briny Sweat.
Thrice from the Ground he leap'd, was een to wield
Her brandih'd Lance, and hake her horrid Shield.
Then Calchas bad our Hot for flight prepare,
And hope no Conquet from the tedious War:
'Till firt they ail'd for Greece; with Pray'rs beought
Her injur'd Pow'r, and better Omens brought.
And now their Navy ploughs the wat'ry Main,
Yet, oon expect it on your Shoars again,
With Pallas pleas'd; as Calchas did ordain.
But firt, to reconcile the blue-ey'd Maid,
For her toln Statue, and her Tow'r betray'd;
Warn'd by the Seer, to her offended Name
We rais'd, and dedicate this wond'rous Frame:
So lofty, let through your forbidden Gates
It pas, and intercept our better Fates.
For, once admitted there, our hopes are lot;
And Troy may then a new Palladium boat.
For o Religion and the Gods ordain;
That if you violate with Hands prophane
Minerva's Gift, your Town in Flames hall burn,
(Which Omen, O ye Gods, on Grecia turn!)
But if it climb, with your aiting Hands,
The Trojan Walls, and in the City tands;
Then Troy hall Argos and Mycenae burn,
And the revere of Fate on us return.
With uch Deceits he gain'd their eaie Hearts,
Too prone to credit his perfidious Arts.
What Diomede, nor Thetis greater Son,
A thouand Ships, nor ten years Siege had done:
Fale Tears and fawning Words the City won.
A greater Omen, and of wore portent,
Did our unwary Minds with fear torment:
Concurring to produce the dire Event.
Laocoon, Neptune's Priet by Lot that Year,
With olemn pomp then acrific'd a Steer.
When, dreadful to behold, from Sea we py'd
Two Serpents rank'd abreat, the Seas divide,
And moothly weep along the welling Tide.
Their flaming Crets above the Waves they how,
Their Bellies eem to burn the Seas below:
Their peckled Tails advance to teer their Coure,
And on the ounding Shoar the flying Billows force.
And now the Strand, and now the Plain they held,
Their ardent Eyes with bloody treaks were fill'd:
Their nimble Tongues they brandih'd as they came,
And lick'd their hiing Jaws, that putter'd Flame.
We fled amaz'd; their detin'd Way they take,
And to Laocoon and his Children make:

figure.p: To the Right Honble: James Earle of Salisbury &
figure.head: AE. 2. l. 290.

lg.l: And firt around the tender Boys they wind,
Then with their harpen'd Fangs their Limbs and Bodies grind.
The wretched Father, running to their Aid
With pious Hate, but vain, they next invade:
Twice round his wate their winding Volumes rowl'd,
And twice about his gaping Throat they fold.
The Priet, thus doubly choak'd, their Crets divide,
And tow'ring o're his Head, in Triumph ride.
With both his Hands he labours at the Knots,
His Holy Fillets the blue Venom blots:
His roaring fills the flitting Air around.
Thus, when an Oxe receives a glancing Wound,
He breaks his Bands, the fatal Altar flies,
And with loud Bellowings breaks the yielding Skies.
Their Tasks perform'd, the Serpents quit their prey,
And to the Tow'r of Pallas make their way:
Couch'd at her Feet, they lie protected there,
By her large Buckler, and protended Spear.
Amazement eizes all; the gen'ral Cry
Proclaims Laocoon jutly doom'd to die.
Whoe hand the Will of Pallas had withtood,
And dar'd to violate the Sacred Wood.
All vote t' admit the Steed, that Vows be paid,
And Incene offer'd to th' offended Maid.
A pacious Breach is made, the Town lies bare,
Some hoiting Leavers, ome the Wheels prepare,
And faten to the Hores Feet: the ret
With Cables haul along th' unweildy Beat.
Each on his Fellow for Aitance calls:
At length the fatal Fabrick mounts the Walls,
Big with Detruction. Boys with Chaplets crown'd,
And Quires of Virgins ing, and dance around.
Thus rais'd aloft, and then decending down,
It enters o're our Heads, and threats the Town.
O acred City! built by Hands Divine!
O valiant Heroes of the Trojan Line!
Four times he truck; as oft the clahing ound
Of Arms was heard, and inward Groans rebound.
Yet mad with Zeal, and blinded with our Fate,
We hawl along the Hore, in olemn tate;
Then place the dire Portent within the Tow'r.
Caandra cry'd, and curs'd th' unhappy Hour;
Foretold our Fate; but by the Gods decree
All heard, and none believ'd the Prophecy.
With Branches we the Fanes adorn, and wat
In jollity, the Day ordain'd to be the lat.
Mean time the rapid Heav'ns rowl'd down the Light,
And on the haded Ocean ruh'd the Night:
Our Men ecure, nor Guards nor Centries held,
But eaie Sleep their weary Limbs compell'd.
The Grecians had embark'd their Naval Pow'rs
From Tenedos, and ought our well known Shoars:
Safe under Covert of the ilent Night,
And guided by th' Imperial Galley's light.
When Sinon, favour'd by the Partial Gods,
Unlock'd the Hore, and op'd his dark abodes:
Retor'd to vital Air our hidden Foes,
Who joyful from their long Confinement roe.
Tyander bold, and Sthenelus their Guide,
And dire Ulyes down the Cable lide:
Then Thoas, Athamas, and Pyrrhus hat;
Nor was the Podalyrian Heroe lat:
Nor injur'd Menelaus, nor the fam'd
Epeus, who the fatal Engine fram'd.
A nameles Crowd ucceed; their Forces join
T' invade the Town, oppres'd with Sleep and Wine.
Thoe few they find awake, firt meet their Fate,
Then to their Fellows they unbar the Gate.
'Twas in the dead of Night, when Sleep repairs
Our Bodies worn with Toils, our Minds with Cares,
When Hector's Ghot before my ight appears:
A bloody Shrowd he eem'd, and bath'd in Tears.
Such as he was, when, by foul Treaon lain,
Thealian Courers drag'd him o're the Plain.
Swoln were his Feet, as when the Thongs were thrut
Through the bor'd holes, his Body black with dut.
Unlike that Hector, who return'd from toils
Of War Triumphant, in Aeacian Spoils:
Or him, who made the fainting Greeks retire,
And lanch'd againt their Navy Phrygian Fire.
His Hair and Beard tood tiffen'd with his gore;
And all the Wounds he for his Country bore,
Now tream'd afreh, and with new Purple ran:
I wept to ee the viionary Man:
And while my Trance continu'd, thus began.
O Light of Trojans, and Support of Troy,
Thy Father's Champion, and thy Country's Joy!
O, long expected by thy Friends! from whence
Art thou o late return'd for our Defence?
Do we behold thee, weary'd as we are,
With length of Labours, and with Toils of War?
After o many Fun'rals of thy own,
Art thou retor'd to thy declining Town?
But ay, what Wounds are thee? What new Digrace
Deforms the Manly Features of thy Face?
To this the Spectre no Reply did frame;
But anwer'd to the Caue for which he came:
And, groaning from the bottom of his Breat,
This Warning, in thee mournful Words expres'd.
O Goddes-born! ecape, by timely flight,
The Flames, and Horrors of this fatal Night.
The Foes already have poes'd the Wall,
Troy nods from high, and totters to her Fall.
Enough is paid to Priam's Royal Name,
More than enough to Duty and to Fame.
If by a Mortal Hand my Father's Throne
Cou'd be defended, 'twas by mine alone:
Now Troy to thee commends her future State,
And gives her Gods Companions of thy Fate:
From their aitance happyer Walls expect,
Which, wand'ring long, at lat thou halt erect.
He aid, and brought me, from their blet abodes,
The venerable Statues of the Gods:
With ancient Veta from the acred Quire,
The Wreaths and Relicks of th' Immortal Fire.
Now peals of Shouts come thund'ring from afar,
Cries, Threats, and loud Laments, and mingl'd War:
The Noie approaches, though our Palace tood
Aloof from Streets, encompas'd with a Wood.
Louder, and yet more loud, I hear th' Allarms
Of Human Cries ditinct, and clahing Arms:
Fear broke my Slumbers; I no longer tay,
But mount the Terras, thence the Town urvey,
And hearken what the frightful Sounds convey.
Thus when a flood of Fire by Winds is born,
Crackling it rowls, and mows the tanding Corn:
Or Deluges, decending on the Plains,
Sweep o're the yellow Year, detroy the pains
Of lab'ring Oxen, and the Peaant's gains:
Unroot the Forret Oaks, and bear away
Flocks, Folds, and Trees, an unditinguih'd Prey.
The Shepherd climbs the Cliff, and ees from far,
The watful Ravage of the wat'ry War.
Then Hector's Faith was manifetly clear'd;
The Grecian Frauds in open light appear'd.
The Palace of Deiphobus acends
In moaky Flames, and catches on his Friends.
Ucalegon burns next; the Seas are bright
With plendor, not their own; and hine with Trojan light.
New Clamours, and new Clangors now arie,
The ound of Trumpets mix'd with fighting cries.
With frenzy eiz'd, I run to meet th' Alarms,
Reolv'd on death, reolv'd to die in Arms.
But firt to gather Friends, with them t'oppoe,
If Fortune favour'd, and repel the Foes.
Spurr'd by my courage, by my Country fir'd;
With ene of Honour, and Revenge inpir'd.
Pantheus, Apollo's Priet, a acred Name,
Had cap'd the Grecian Swords, and pas'd the Flame;
With Reliques loaden, to my Doors he fled,
And by the hand his tender Grand-on led.
What hope, O Pantheus! whither can we run?
Where make a tand? and what may yet be done?
Scarce had I aid, when Pantheus, with a groan,
Troy is no more, and Ilium was a Town!
The fatal Day, th' appointed Hour is come,
When wrathful Jove's irrevocable doom
Transfers the Trojan State to Grecian hands.
The Fire conumes the Town, the Foe commands:
And armed Hots, an unexpected Force,
Break from the Bowels of the Fatal Hore.
Within the Gates, proud Sinon throws about
The flames, and Foes for entrance pres without.
With thouand others, whom I fear to name,
More than from Argos, or Mycenae came.
To ev'ral Pots their Parties they divide;
Some block the narrow Streets, ome cour the wide.
The bold they kill, th' unwary they urprie;
Who fights finds Death, and Death finds him who flies.
The Warders of the Gate but carce maintain
Th' unequal Combat, and reit in vain.
I Heard; and Heav'n, that well-born Souls inpires,
Prompts me, thro' lifted Swords, and riing Fires
To run, where clahing Arms and Clamour calls,
And ruh undaunted to defend the Walls.
Ripheus and Iph'itus by my ide engage,
For Valour one Renown'd, and one for Age.
Dymas and Hypanis by Moonlight knew
My motions, and my Meen, and to my Party drew;
With young Choroebus, who by Love was led
To win Renown, and fair Caandra's Bed;
And lately brought his Troops to Priam's aid:
Forewarn'd in vain, by the Prophetic Maid.
Whom, when I aw, reolv'd in Arms to fall,
And that one Spirit animated all;
Brave Souls, aid I, but Brave, alas! in vain:
Come, finih what our Cruel Fates ordain.
You ee the dep'rate tate of our Affairs;
And Heav'ns protecting Pow'rs are deaf to Pray'rs.
The paive Gods behold the Greeks defile
Their Temples, and abandon to the Spoil
Their own Abodes: we, feeble few, conpire
To ave a inking Town, involv'd in Fire.
Then let us fall, but fall amidt our Foes,
Depair of Life, the Means of Living hows.
So fierce a Speech incourag'd their deire
Of Death, and added fuel to their fire.
As hungry Wolves, with raging appetite,
Scour thro' the fields, nor fear the tormy Night;
Their Whelps at home expect the promis'd Food,
And long to temper their dry Chaps in Blood:
So ruh'd we forth at once, reolv'd to die,
Reolv'd in Death the lat Extreams to try.
We leave the narrow Lanes behind, and dare
Th' unequal Combat in the publick Square:
Night was our Friend, our Leader was Depair.
What Tongue can tell the Slaughter of that Night?
What Eyes can weep the Sorrows and Affright!
An ancient and imperial City falls,
The Streets are fill'd with frequent Funerals:
Houes and Holy Temples float in Blood,
And hotile Nations make a common Flood.
Not only Trojans fall, but in their turn,
The vanquih'd Triumph, and the Victors mourn.
Ours take new Courage from Depair and Night;
Confus'd the Fortune is, confus'd the Fight.
All parts reound with Tumults, Plaints, and Fears,
And grily Death in undry hapes appears.
Androgeos fell among us, with his Band,
Who thought us Grecians newly come to Land:
From whence, aid he, my Friends this long delay?
You loiter, while the Spoils are born away:
Our Ships are laden with the Trojan Store,
And you like Truants come too late ahore.
He aid, but oon corrected his Mitake,
Found, by the doubtful Anwers which we make:
Amaz'd, he wou'd have hun'd th' unequal Fight,
But we, more num'rous, intercept his flight.
As when ome Peaant in a buhy Brake,
Has with unwary Footing pres'd a Snake;
He tarts aide, atonih'd, when he pies
His riing Cret, blue Neck, and rowling Eyes;
So from our Arms, urpriz'd Androgeos flies.
In vain; for him and his we compas'd round,
Poes'd with Fear, unknowing of the Ground;
And of their Lives an eay Conquet found.
Thus Fortune on our firt Endeavour mil'd:
Choraebus then, with youthful Hopes beguil'd,
Swoln with Succes, and of a daring Mind,
This new Invention fatally deign'd.
My Friends, aid he, ince Fortune hows the way,
'Tis fit we hou'd th' aupicious Guide obey.
For what has he thee Grecian Arms betow'd,
But their Detruction, and the Trojans good?
Then change we Shields, and their Devices bear,
Let Fraud upply the want of Force in War.
They find us Arms; this aid, himelf he dres'd
In dead Androgeos's Spoils, his upper Vet,
His painted Buckler, and his plumy Cret.
Thus Ripheus, Dymas, all the Trojan Train
Lay down their own Attire, and trip the lain.
Mix'd with the Greeks, we go with ill Preage,
Flatter'd with hopes to glut our greedy Rage:
Unknown, aaulting whom we blindly meet,
And trew, with Grecian Carcaes, the Street.
Thus while their tragling Parties we defeat,
Some to the Shoar and afer Ships retreat:
And ome oppres'd with more ignoble Fear,
Remount the hollow Hore, and pant in ecret there.
But ah! what ue of Valour can be made,
When Heav'ns propitious Pow'rs refue their Aid!
Behold the royal Prophetes, the Fair
Caandra, drag'd by her dihevel'd Hair;
Whom not Minerva's Shrine, nor acred Bands,
In afety cou'd protect from acrilegious Hands:
On Heav'n he cat her Eyes, he igh'd, he cry'd,
('Twas all he cou'd) her tender Arms were ty'd.
So ad a Sight Choraebus cou'd not bear,
But fir'd with Rage, ditracted with Depair;

figure.p: To the Right Honble. William OBryen Earle of Inchiquin in the Kingdom of Ireland &ct
figure.head: AE. 2. l: 545.

lg.l: Amid the barb'rous Ravihers he flew:
Our Leader's rah Example we purue.
But torms of Stones, from the proud Temple's height,
Pour down, and on our batter'd Helms alight.
We from our Friends receiv'd this fatal Blow,
Who thought us Grecians, as we eem'd in how.
They aim at the mitaken Crets, from high,
And ours beneath the pond'rous Ruin lie.
Then, mov'd with Anger and Didain, to ee
Their Troops dipers'd, the Royal Virgin free:
The Grecians rally, and their Pow'rs unite;
With Fury charge us, and renew the Fight.
The Brother-Kings with Ajax join their force,
And the whole Squadron of Thealian Hore.
Thus, when the Rival Winds their Quarrel try,
Contending for the Kingdom of the Skie;
South, Eat, and Wet, on airy Courers born,
The Whirlwind gathers, and the Woods are torn:
Then Nereus trikes the deep, the Billows rie,
And, mix'd with Ooze and Sand, pollute the Skies.
The Troops we quander'd firt, again appear
From ev'ral Quarters, and encloe the Rear.
They firt oberve, and to the ret betray
Our diff'rent Speech; our borrow'd Arms urvey.
Oppres'd with odds, we fall; Choraebus firt,
At Pallas's Altar, by Peneleus pierc'd.
Then Ripheus follow'd, in th'unequal Fight;
Jut of his Word, obervant of the right;
Heav'n thought not o: Dymas their Fate attends,
With Hypanis, mitaken by their Friends.
Nor Pantheus, thee, thy Mitre nor the Bands
Of awful Phoebus, av'd from impious Hands.
Ye Trojan Flames your Tetimony bear,
What I perform'd, and what I uffer'd there:
No Sword avoiding in the fatal Strife,
Expos'd to Death, and prodigal of Life.
Witnes, ye Heav'ns! I live not by my Fault,
I trove to have deerv'd the Death I ought.
But when I cou'd not fight, and wou'd have dy'd,
Born off to ditance by the growing Tide,
Old Iphitus and I were hurry'd thence,
With Pelias wounded, and without Defence.
New Clamors from th' inveted Palace ring;
We run to die, or diengage the King.
So hot th' Aault, o high the Tumult roe,
While ours defend, and while the Greeks oppoe;
As all the Dardan and Argolick Race
Had been contracted in that narrow Space:
Or as all Ilium ele were void of Fear,
And Tumult, War, and Slaughter only there.
Their Targets in a Tortoie cat, the Foes
Secure advancing, to the Turrets roe:
Some mount the caling Ladders, ome more bold
Swerve upwards, and by Pots and Pillars hold:
Their left hand gripes their Bucklers, in th' acent,
While with the right they eie the Battlement.
From their demolih'd Tow'rs the Trojans throw
Huge heaps of Stones, that falling, cruh the Foe:
And heavy Beams, and Rafters from the ides,
(Such Arms their lat neceity provides:)
And gilded Roofs come tumbling from on high,
The marks of State, and ancient Royalty.
The Guards below, fix'd in the Pas, attend
The Charge undaunted, and the Gate defend.
Renew'd in Courage with recover'd Breath,
A econd time we ran to tempt our Death:
To clear the Palace from the Foe, ucceed
The weary living, and revenge the dead.
A Potern-door, yet unoberv'd and free,
Join'd by the length of a blind Gallery,
To the King's Cloet led; a way well known
To Hector's Wife, while Priam held the Throne:
Through which he brought Atyanax, uneen,
To chear his Grandire, and his Grandire's Queen.
Through this we pas, and mount the Tow'r, from whence
With unavailing Arms the Trojans make defence.
From this the trembling King had oft decry'd
The Grecian Camp, and aw their Navy ride.
Beams from its lofty height with Swords we hew;
Then wrenching with our hands, th' Aault renew.
And where the Rafters on the Columns meet,
We puh them headlong with our Arms and Feet.
The Lightning flies not wifter than the Fall;
Nor Thunder louder than the ruin'd Wall:
Down goes the top at once; the Greeks beneath
Are piecemeal torn, or pounded into Death.
Yet more ucceed, and more to death are ent;
We ceae not from above, nor they below relent.
Before the Gate tood Pyrrhus, threat'ning loud,
With glitt'ring Arms conpicuous in the Crowd.
So hines, renew'd in Youth, the creted Snake,
Who lept the Winter in a thorny Brake:
And cating off his Slough, when Spring returns,
Now looks aloft, and with new Glory burns:
Retor'd with pois'nous Herbs, his ardent ides
Reflect the Sun, and rais'd on Spires he rides:
High o're the Gras, hiing he rowls along,
And brandihes by fits his orky Tongue.
Proud Periphas, and fierce Automedon,
His Father's Charioteer, together run
To force the Gate: The Scyrian Infantry
Ruh on in Crowds, and the barr'd Paage free.
Ent'ring the Court, with Shouts the Skies they rend,
And flaming Firebrands to the Roofs acend.
Himelf, among the foremot, deals his Blows,
And with his Axe repeated Stroaks betows
On the trong Doors: then all their Shoulders ply,
'Till from the Pots the brazen Hinges fly.
He hews apace, the double Bars at length
Yield to his Ax, and unreited Strength.
A mighty Breach is made; the Rooms conceal'd
Appear, and all the Palace is reveal'd.
The Halls of Audience, and of publick State,
And where the lonely Queen in ecret ate.
Arm'd Souldiers now by trembling Maids are een,
With not a Door, and carce a Space between.
The Houe is fill'd with loud Laments and Cries,
And Shrieks of Women rend the vaulted Skies.
The fearful Matrons run from place to place,
And kis the Threholds, and the Pots embrace.
The fatal work inhuman Pyrrhus plies,
And all his Father parkles in his Eyes.
Nor Bars, nor fighting Guards his force utain;
The Bars are broken, and the Guards are lain.
In ruh the Greeks, and all the Apartments fill;
Thoe few Defendants whom they find, they kill.
Not with o fierce a Rage, the foaming Flood
Roars, when he finds his rapid Coure withtood:
Bears down the Dams with unreited way,
And weeps the Cattle and the Cots away.
Thee Eyes beheld him, when he march'd between
The Brother-Kings: I aw th' unhappy Queen,
The hundred Wives, and where old Priam tood,
To tain his hallow'd Altar with his Blood.
The fifty Nuptial Beds: (uch Hopes had he,
So large a Promie of a Progeny.)
The Pots of plated Gold, and hung with Spoils,
Fell the Reward of the proud Victor's Toils.
Where e're the raging Fire had left a pace,
The Grecians enter, and poes the Place.
Perhaps you may of Priam's Fate enquire.
He, when he aw his Regal Town on fire,
His ruin'd Palace, and his ent'ring Foes,
On ev'ry ide inevitable woes;
In Arms, dius'd, invets his Limbs decay'd
Like them, with Age; a late and ueles aid.
His feeble houlders carce the weight utain:
Loaded, not arm'd, he creeps along, with pain;
Depairing of Succes; ambitious to be lain!
Uncover'd but by Heav'n, there tood in view
An Altar; near the hearth a Lawrel grew;
Dodder'd with Age, whoe Boughs encompas round
The Houehold Gods, and hade the holy Ground.
Here Hecuba, with all her helples Train
Of Dames, for helter ought, but ought in vain.
Driv'n like a Flock of Doves along the skie,
Their Images they hugg, and to their Altars fly.
The Queen, when he beheld her trembling Lord,
And hanging by his ide a heavy Sword,
What Rage, he cry'd, has eiz'd my Husband's mind;
What Arms are thee, and to what ue deign'd?
Thee times want other aids: were Hector here,
Ev'n Hector now in vain, like Priam wou'd appear.
With us, one common helter thou halt find,
Or in one common Fate with us be join'd.
She aid, and with a lat Salute embrac'd
The poor old Man, and by the Lawrel plac'd.
Behold Polites, one of Priam's Sons,
Puru'd by Pyrrhus, there for afety runs.
Thro Swords, and Foes, amaz'd and hurt, he flies
Through empty Courts, and open Galleries:
Him Pyrrhus, urging with his Lance, purues;
And often reaches, and his thruts renews.
The Youth transfix'd, with lamentable Cries
Expires, before his wretched Parent's Eyes.
Whom, gaping at his feet, when Priam aw,
The Fear of death gave place to Nature's Law.
And haking more with Anger, than with Age,
The Gods, aid He, requite thy brutal Rage:
As ure they will, Barbarian, ure they mut,
If there be Gods in Heav'n, and Gods be jut:
Who tak't in Wrongs an inolent delight;
With a Son's death t'infect a Father's ight.
Not He, whom thou and lying Fame conpire
To call thee his; Not He, thy vaunted Sire,
Thus us'd my wretched Age: The Gods he fear'd,
The Laws of Nature and of Nations heard.
He chear'd my Sorrows, and for Sums of Gold
The bloodles Carcas of my Hector old.
Pity'd the Woes a Parent underwent,
And ent me back in afety from his Tent.
This aid, his feeble hand a Javelin threw,
Which flutt'ring, eem'd to loiter as it flew:
Jut, and but barely, to the Mark it held,
And faintly tinckl'd on the Brazen Shield.
Then Pyrrhus thus: go thou from me to Fate;
And to my Father my foul deeds relate.
Now dye: with that he dragg'd the trembling Sire,
Slidd'ring through clotter'd Blood, and holy Mire,
(The mingl'd Pate his murder'd Son had made,)
Haul'd from beneath the violated Shade;
And on the Sacred Pile, the Royal Victim laid.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble Roger Earle of Orrery Baron of Broghill &ct
figure.head: AE. 2. l: 765.

lg.l: His right Hand held his bloody Fauchion bare;
His left he twited in his hoary Hair:
Then, with a peeding Thrut, his Heart he found:
The lukewarm Blood came ruhing through the wound,
And anguine Streams ditain'd the acred Ground.
Thus Priam fell: and har'd one common Fate
With Troy in Ahes, and his ruin'd State:
He, who the Scepter of all Aia way'd,
Whom Monarchs like dometick Slaves obey'd,
On the bleak Shoar now lies th' abandon'd King,
This whole line is taken from Sir John Derhan. A headles Carcas, and a nameles thing.
Then, not before, I felt my crudled Blood
Congeal with Fear; my Hair with horror tood:
My Father's Image fill'd my pious Mind;
Let equal Years might equal Fortune find.
Again I thought on my foraken Wife;
And trembl'd for my Son's abandon'd Life.
I look'd about; but found my elf alone:
Deerted at my need, my Friends were gone.
Some pent with Toil, ome with Depair oppres'd,
Leap'd headlong from the Heights; the Flames conum'd the (ret.
Thus, wand'ring in my way, without a Guide,
The graceles Helen in the Porch I py'd
Of Veta's Temple: there he lurk'd alone;
Muffled he ate, and what he cou'd, unknown:
But, by the Flames, that cat their Blaze around,
That common Bane of Greece and Troy, I found.
For Ilium burnt, he dreads the Trojan Sword;
More dreads the Vengeance of her injur'd Lord;
Ev'n by thoe Gods, who refug'd her, abhorr'd.
Trembling with Rage, the Strumpet I regard;
Reolv'd to give her Guilt the due reward.
Shall he triumphant ail before the Wind,
And leave in Flames, unhappy Troy behind?
Shall he, her Kingdom and her Friends review,
In State attended with a Captive Crew;
While unreveng'd the good old Priam falls,
And Grecian Fires conume the Trojan Walls?
For this the Phrygian Fields, and Xanthian Flood
Were well'd with Bodies, and were drunk with Blood?
'Tis true a Souldier can mall Honour gain,
And boat no Conquet from a Woman lain:
Yet hall the Fact not pas without Applaue,
Of Vengeance taken in o jut a Caue.
The punih'd Crime hall et my Soul at eae:
And murm'ring Manes of my Friends appeae.
Thus while I rave, a gleam of pleaing Light
Spread o're the Place, and hining Heav'nly bright,
My Mother tood reveal'd before my Sight.
Never o radiant did her Eyes appear;
Not her own Star confes'd a Light o clear.
Great in her Charms, as when on Gods above
She looks, and breaths her elf into their Love.
She held my hand, the detin'd Blow to break:
Then from her roie Lips began to peak.
My Son, from whence this Madnes, this neglect
Of my Commands, and thoe whom I protect?
Why this unmanly Rage? Recall to mind
Whom you forake, what Pledges leave behind.
Look if your helples Father yet urvive;
Or if Acanius, or Creua live.
Around your Houe the greedy Grecians err;
And thee had perih'd in the nightly War,
But for my Preence and protecting Care.
Not Helen's Face, nor Paris was in fault;
But by the Gods was this Detruction brought.
Now cat your Eyes around; while I diolve
The Mits and Films that mortal Eyes involve:
Purge from your ight the Dros, and make you ee
The Shape of each avenging Deity.
Enlighten'd thus, my jut Commands fulfill;
Nor fear Obedience to your Mother's Will.
Where you diorder'd heap of Ruin lies,
Stones rent from Stones, where Clouds of dut arie,
Amid that mother, Neptune holds his place:
Below the Wall's foundation drives his Mace:
And heaves the Building from the olid Bae.
Look where, in Arms, Imperial Juno tands,
Full in the Scaean Gate, with loud Commands;
Urging on Shore the tardy Grecian Bands.
See Pallas, of her naky Buckler proud,
Betrides the Tow'r, refulgent through the Cloud:
See Jove new Courage to the Foe upplies,
And arms againt the Town, the partial Deities.
Hate hence, my Son; this fruitles Labour end:
Hate where your trembling Spoue, and Sire attend:
Hate, and a Mother's Care your Paage hall befriend.
She aid: and wiftly vanih'd from my Sight,
Obcure in Clouds, and gloomy Shades of Night.
I look'd, I liten'd; dreadful Sounds I hear;
And the dire Forms of hotile Gods appear.

l.U: unk in Flames I aw, nor could prevent;

lg.l: And Ilium from its old Foundations rent.
Rent like a Mountain Ah, which dar'd the Winds;
And tood the turdy Stroaks of lab'ring Hinds:
About the Roots the cruel Ax reounds,
The Stumps are pierc'd, with oft repeated Wounds.
The War is felt on high, the nodding Crown
Now threats a Fall, and throws the leafy Honours down.
To their united Force it yields, though late;
And mourns with mortal Groans th' approaching Fate:
The Roots no more their upper load utain;
But down he falls, and preads a ruin thro' the Plain.
Decending thence, I cape through Foes, and Fire:
Before the Goddes, Foes and Flames retire.
Arriv'd at home, he for whoe only ake,
Or mot for his, uch Toils I undertake,
The good Anchies, whom, by timely Flight,
I purpos'd to ecure on Ida's height,
Refus'd the Journey: Reolute to die,
And add his Fun'rals to the fate of Troy:
Rather than Exile and old Age utain.
Go you, whoe Blood runs warm in ev'ry Vein:
Had Heav'n decreed that I hou'd Life enjoy,
Heav'n had decreed to ave unhappy Troy.
'Tis ure enough, if not too much for one;
Twice to have een our Ilium overthrown.
Make hate to ave the poor remaining Crew;
And give this ueles Corps a long Adieu.
Thee weak old Hands uffice to top my Breath:
At leat the pitying Foes will aid my Death,
To take my Spoils: and leave my Body bare:
As for my Sepulchre let Heav'n take Care.
'Tis long ince I, for my Coeletial Wife,
Loath'd by the Gods, have drag'd a ling'ring Life:
Since ev'ry Hour and Moment I expire,
Blated from Heav'n by Jove's avenging Fire.
This oft repeated, he tood fix'd to die:
My elf, my Wife, my Son, my Family,
Intreat, pray, beg, and raie a doleful Cry.
What, will he till perit, on Death reolve,
And in his Ruin all his Houe involve!
He till perits, his reaons to maintain;
Our Pray'rs, our Tears, our loud Laments are vain.
Urg'd by Depair, again I go to try
The fate of Arms, reolv'd in Fight to die.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble, Robt: Ld. Constable Visnt. Dunbar in ye Kingdom of Scotland
figure.head: AE 2. l. 915.

lg.l: What hope remains, but what my Death mut give?
Can I without o dear a Father live?
You term it Prudence, what I Baenes call:
Cou'd uch a Word from uch a Parent fall?
If Fortune pleae, and o the Gods ordain,
That nothing hou'd of ruin'd Troy remain:
And you conpire with Fortune, to be lain;
The way to Death is wide, th' Approaches near:
For oon relentles Pyrrhus will appear,
Reeking with Priam's Blood: The wretch who lew
The Son (inhuman) in the Father's view,
And then the Sire himelf, to the dire Altar drew.
O Goddes Mother, give me back to fate;
Your Gift was undeir'd, and came too late.
Did you for this, unhappy me convey
Through Foes and Fires to ee my Houe a Prey?
Shall I, my Father, Wife, and Son, behold
Welt'ring in Blood, each others Arms infold?
Hate, gird my Sword, tho' pent, and overcome:
'Tis the lat Summons to receive our Doom.
I hear thee, Fate, and I obey thy Call:
Not unreveng'd the Foe hall ee my Fall.
Retore me to the yet unfinih'd Fight:
My Death is wanting to conclude the Night.
Arm'd once again, my glitt'ring Sword I wield,
While th' other hand utains my weighty Shield:
And forth I ruh to eek th' abandon'd Field.
I went; but ad Creua top'd my way,
And cros the Threhold in my Paage lay;
Embrac'd my Knees; and when I wou'd have gone
Shew'd me my feeble Sire, and tender Son.
If Death be your deign, at leat, aid he,
Take us along, to hare your Detiny.
If any farther hopes in Arms remain,
This Place, thee Pledges of your Love, maintain.
To whom do you expoe your Father's Life,
Your Son's, and mine, your now forgotten Wife!
While thus he fills the Houe with clam'rous Cries,
Our Hearing is diverted by our Eyes.
For while I held my Son, in the hort pace,
Betwixt our Kies and our lat Embrace;
Strange to relate, from young Iulus Head
A lambent Flame aroe, which gently pread
Around his Brows, and on his Temples fed.
Amaz'd, with running Water we prepare
To quench the acred Fire, and hake his Hair;
But old Anchies, vers'd in Omens, rear'd
His hands to Heav'n, and this requet preferr'd.
If any Vows, Almighty Jove, can bend
Thy Will, if Piety can Pray'rs commend,
Confirm the glad Preage which thou art pleas'd to end.
Scarce had he aid, when, on our left, we hear
A peal of ratling Thunder rowl in Air:
There hot a treaming Lamp along the Sky,
Which on the winged Lightning eem'd to fly;
From o're the Roof the blaze began to move;
And trailing vanih'd in th' Idean Grove.
It wept a path in Heav'n, and hone a Guide;
Then in a teaming tench of Sulphur dy'd.
The good old Man with uppliant hands implor'd
The Gods protection, and their Star ador'd.
Now, now, aid he, my Son, no more delay,
I yield, I follow where Heav'n hews the way.
Keep (O my Country Gods) our dwelling Place,
And guard this Relick of the Trojan Race:
This tender Child; thee Omens are your own;
And you can yet retore the ruin'd Town.
At leat accomplih what your Signs forehow:
I tand reign'd, and am prepar'd to go.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble: Mary Countes Dowager of Northampton
figure.head: AE. 2. l. 985.

lg.l: He aid; the crackling Flames appear on high,
And driving Sparkles dance along the Sky.
With Vulcan's rage the riing Winds conpire;
And near our Palace rowl the flood of Fire.
Hate, my dear Father, ('tis no time to wait)
And load my Shoulders with a willing Fraight.
What e're befalls, your Life hall be my care,
One Death, or one Deliv'rance we will hare.
My hand hall lead our little Son; and you
My faithful Conort, hall our Steps purfue.
Next, you my Servants, heed my trict Commands:
Without the Walls a ruin'd Temple tands,
To Ceres hollow'd once; a Cypres nigh
Shoots up her venerable Head on high;
By long Religion kept: there bend your Feet;
And in divided Parties let us meet.
Our Country Gods, the Relicks, and the Bands,
Hold you, my Father, in your guiltles Hands:
In me 'tis impious holy things to bear,
Red as I am with Slaughter, new from War:
'Till in ome living Stream I cleane the Guilt
Of dire Debate, and Blood in Battel pilt.
Thus, ord'ring all that Prudence cou'd provide,
I cloath my Shoulders with a Lion's Hide;
And yellow Spoils: Then, on my bending Back,
The welcome load of my dear Father take.
While on my better Hand Acanius hung,
And with unequal Paces tript along.
Creua kept behind: by choice we tray
Through ev'ry dark and ev'ry devious Way.
I, who o bold and dauntles jut before,
The Grecian Darts and hock of Lances bore,
At ev'ry Shadow now am eiz'd with Fear:
Not for my elf, but for the Charge I bear.
Till near the ruin'd Gate arriv'd at lat,
Secure, and deeming all the Danger pat;
A frightful noie of trampling Feet we hear;
My Father looking through the Shades, with fear,
Cry'd out, hate, hate my Son, the Foes are nigh;
Their Swords, and hining Armour I decry.
Some hotile God, for ome unknown Offence,
Had ure bereft my Mind of better Sence:
For while through winding Ways I took my Flight;
And ought the helter of the gloomy Night;
Alas! I lot Creua: hard to tell
If by her fatal Detiny he fell,
Or weary ate, or wander'd with affright;
But he was lot for ever to my ight.
I knew not, or reflected, 'till I meet
My Friends, at Ceres now deerted Seat:
We met: not one was wanting, only he
Deceiv'd her Friends, her Son, and wretched me.
What mad expeions did my Tongue refue!
Whom did I not of Gods or Men accue!
This was the fatal Blow, that pain'd me more
Than all I felt from ruin'd Troy before.
Stung with my Los, and raving with Depair,
Abandoning my now forgotten Care,
Of Counel, Comfort, and of Hope bereft,
My Sire, my Son, my Country Gods, I left.
In hining Armour once again I heath
My Limbs, not feeling Wounds, nor fearing Death.
Then headlong to the burning Walls I run,
And eek the Danger I was forc'd to hun.
I tread my former Tracks: through Night explore
Each Paage, ev'ry Street I cros'd before.
All things were full of Horrour and Affright,
And dreadful ev'n the ilence of the Night.
Then, to my Father's Houe I make repair,
With ome mall Glimps of hope to find her there:
Intead of her the cruel Greeks I met;
The houe was fill'd with Foes, with Flames beet.
Driv'n on the wings of Winds, whole heets of Fire,
Through Air tranported, to the Roofs apire.
From thence to Priam's Palace I reort;
And earch the Citadel, and deart Court.
Then, unoberv'd, I pas by Juno's Church;
A guard of Grecians had poes'd the Porch:
There Phaenix and Ulyes watch the Prey:
And thither all the Wealth of Troy convey.
The Spoils which they from ranack'd Houes brought;
And golden Bowls from burning Altars caught.
The Tables of the Gods, the Purple Vets;
The People's Treaure, and the Pomp of Priets.
A ranck of wretched Youths, with pinion'd Hands,
And captive Matrons in long Order tands.
Then, with ungovern'd Madnes, I proclaim,
Through all the ilent Streets, Creua's Name.

l.U: till I call: At length he hears;

lg.l: And uddain, through the Shades of Night appears.
Appears, no more Creua, nor my Wife:
But a pale Spectre, larger than the Life.
Aghat, atonih'd, and truk dumb with Fear,
I tood; like Britles roe my tiffen'd Hair.
Then thus the Ghot began to ooth my Grief:
Nor Tears, nor Cries can give the dead Relief;
Deit, my much lov'd Lord, t'indulge your Pain:
You bear no more than what the Gods ordain.
My Fates permit me not from hence to fly;
Nor he, the great Comptroller of the Sky.
Long wandring Ways for you the Pow'rs decree:
On Land hard Labors, and a length of Sea.
Then, after many painful Years are pat,
On Latium's happy Shore you hall be cat:
Where gentle Tiber from his Bed beholds
The flow'ry Meadows, and the feeding Folds.
There end your Toils: And there your Fates provide
A quiet Kingdom, and a Royal Bride:
There Fortune hall the Trojan Line retore;
And you for lot Creua weep no more.
Fear not that I hall watch with ervile Shame,
Th' imperious Looks of ome proud Grecian Dame:
Or, tooping to the Victor's Lut, digrace
My Goddes Mother, or my Royal Race.
And now, farewell: the Parent of the Gods
Retrains my fleeting Soul in her Abodes:
I trut our common Iue to your Care.
She aid: And gliding pas'd uneen in Air.
I trove to peak, but Horror ty'd my Tongue;
And thrice about her Neck my Arms I flung;
And thrice deceiv'd, on vain Embraces hung.
Light as an empty Dream at break of Day,
Or as a blat of Wind, he ruh'd away.
Thus, having pas'd the Night in fruitles Pain,
I, to my longing Friends, return again.
Amaz'd th' augmented Number to behold,
Of Men, and Matrons mix'd, of young and old:
A wretched Exil'd Crew together brought,
With Arms appointed, and With Treaure fraught.
Reolv'd, and willing under my Command,
To run all hazards both of Sea and Land.
The Morn began, from Ida, to diplay
Her roy Cheeks, and Phophor led the day;
Before the Gates the Grecians took their Pot:
And all pretence of late Relief was lot.
I yield to Fate, unwillingly retire;
And loaded, up the Hill convey my Sire.

div.head: The Third Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Aeneas proceeds in his Relation: He gives an Account of the Fleet with which he ail'd, and the Succes of his firt Voyage to Thrace; from thence he directs his Coure to Delos, and asks the Oracle what place the Gods had appointed for his Habitation? By a mitake of the Oracle's Anwer, he ettles in Crete; his houehold Gods give him the true ene of the Oracle, in a Dream. He follows their advice, and makes the bet of his way for Italy: He is cat on everal Shores, and meets with very urpriing Adventures, 'till at length he lands on Sicily: where his Father Anchies dies. This is the place which he was ailing from when the Tempet roe and threw him upon the Carthaginian Coat.

figure.p: To the Right Honble. William Stanley Earle of Derby &ct Ld of Man & ye Iles
figure.head: AE. e. l. 2.

lg.l: WHen Heav'n had overturn'd the Trojan State,
And Priam's Throne, by too evere a Fate:
When ruin'd Troy became the Grecians Prey,
And Ilium's lofty Tow'rs in Ahes lay:
Warn'd by Coeletial Omens, we retreat,
To eek in foreign Lands a happier Seat.
Near old Antandros, and at Ida's foot,
The Timber of the acred Groves we cut:
And build our Fleet; uncertain yet to find
What place the Gods for our Repoe aign'd.
Friends daily flock; and carce the kindly Spring
Began to cloath the Ground, and Birds to ing;
When old Anchies ummon'd all to Sea:
The Crew, my Father and the Fates obey.
With Sighs and Tears I leave my native Shore,
And empty Fields, where Ilium tood before.
My Sire, my Son, our les, and greater Gods,
All ail at once; and tempt the briny Floods.
Againt our Coat appears a pacious Land,
Which once the fierce Lycurgus did command:
Thracia the Name; the People bold in War;
Vat are their Fields, and Tillage is their Care.
A hopitable Realm while Fate was kind;
With Troy in friendhip and Religion join'd.
I land; with luckles Omens, then adore
Their Gods, and draw a Line along the Shore:
I lay the deep Foundations of a Wall;
And Enos, nam'd from me, the City call.
To Dionaean Venus Vows are paid,
And all the Pow'rs that riing Labours aid;
A Bull on Jove's Imperial Altar laid.
Not far, a riing Hillock tood in view;
Sharp Myrtles, on the ides, and Cornels grew.
There, while I went to crop the Silvan Scenes,
And hade our Altar with their leafy Greens;
I pull'd a Plant; with horror I relate
A Prodigy o trange, and full of Fate.
The rooted Fibers roe; and from the Wound,
Black bloody Drops ditill'd upon the Ground.
Mute, and amaz'd, my Hair with Horror tood;
Fear hrunk my Sinews, and congeal'd my Blood.
Man'd once again, another Plant I try;
That other guh'd with the ame anguine Dye.
Then, fearing Guilt, for ome Offence unknown,
With Pray'rs and Vows the Driads I attone:
With all the Siters of the Woods, and mot
The God of Arms, who rules the Thracian Coat:
That they, or he, thee Omens wou'd avert;
Releae our Fears, and better igns impart.
Clear'd, as I thought, and fully fix'd at length
To learn the Caue, I tug'd with all my Strength;
I bent my knees againt the Ground; once more
The violated Myrtle ran with purple Gore.
Scarce dare I tell the Sequel: From the Womb
Of wounded Earth, and Caverns of the Tomb,
A Groan, as of a troubled Ghot, renew'd
My Fright, and then thee dreadful Words enu'd.
Why dot thou thus my bury'd Body rend?
O pare the Corps of thy unhappy Friend!
Spare to pollute thy pious Hands with Blood:
The Tears ditil not from the wounded Wood;
But ev'ry drop this living Tree contains,
Is kindred Blood, and ran in Trojan Veins:
O fly from this unhopitable Shore,
Warn'd by my Fate; for I am Polydore!
Here loads of Lances, in my Blood embru'd,
Again hoot upward, by my Blood renew'd.
My faultring Tongue, and hiv'ring Limbs declare
My Horror, and in Britles roe my Hair.
When Troy with Grecian Arms was cloely pent,
Old Priam, fearful of the Wars Event,
This haples Polydore to Thracia ent.
Loaded with Gold, he ent his Darling, far
From Noie and Tumults, and detructive War:
Commited to the faithles Tyrant's Care.
Who, when he aw the Pow'r of Troy decline,
Forook the weaker, with the trong to join.
Broke ev'ry Bond of Nature, and of Truth;
And murder'd, for his Wealth, the Royal Youth.
O acred Hunger of pernicious Gold,
What bands of Faith can impious Lucre hold!
Now, when my Soul had haken off her Fears,
I call my Father, and the Trojan Peers:
Relate the Prodigies of Heav'n; require.
What he commands, and their Advice deire.
All vote to leave that execrable Shore,
Polluted with the Blood of Polydore.
But e're we ail, his Fun'ral Rites prepare;
Then, to his Ghot, a Tomb and Altars rear,
In mournful Pomp the Matrons walk the round:
With baleful Cypres, and blue Fillets crown'd;
With Eyes dejected, and with Hair unbound.
Then Bowls of tepid Milk and Blood we pour,
And thrice invoke the Soul of Polydore.
Now when the raging Storms no longer reign;
But Southern Gales invite us to the Main;
We launch our Veels, with a prop'rous Wind;
And leave the Cities and the Shores behind.
An Iland in th' Aegean Main appears:
Neptune and wat'ry Doris claim it theirs.
It floated once, till Phoebus fix'd the ides
To rooted Earth, and now it braves the Tides.
Here, born by friendly Winds, we come ahore
With needful eae our weary Limbs retore;
And the Sun's Temple, and his Town adore.
Anius the Priet, and King, with Lawrel crown'd,
His hoary Locks with purple Fillets bound,
Who aw my Sire the Delian Shore acend,
Came forth with eager hate to meet his Friend.
Invites him to his Palace; and in ign
Of ancient Love, their plighted Hands they join.
Then to the Temple of the God I went;
And thus, before the Shrine, my Vows preent.
Give, O Thymbraeus, give a reting place,
To the ad Relicks of the Trojan Race:
A Seat ecure, a Region of their own,
A lating Empire, and a happier Town.
Where hall we fix, where hall our Labours end,
Whom hall we follow, and what Fate attend?
Let not my Pray'rs a doubtful Anwer find,
But in clear Auguries unveil thy Mind.

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Nathanael Lord Bihop of Durham
figure.head: AE. 3 l: 220

lg.l: Scarce had I aid, He hook the holy Ground:
The Lawrels, and the lofty Hills around:
And from the Tripos ruh'd a bellowing ound.
Protrate we fell; confes'd the preent God,
Who gave this Anwer from his dark Abode.
Undaunted Youths, go eek that Mother Earth
From which your Ancetors derive their Birth.
The Soil that ent you forth, her Ancient Race,
In her old Boom, hall again embrace.
Through the wide World th' Eneian Houe hall reign,
And Childrens Children hall the Crown utain.
Thus Phoebus did our future Fates dicloe;
A mighty Tumult, mix'd with Joy, aroe.
All are concern'd to know what place the God
Aign'd and where determind our abode.
My Father, long revolving in His Mind,
The Race and Lineage of the Trojan Kind,
Thus anwer'd their demands: Ye Princes, hear
Your pleaing Fortune; and dipel your fear.
The fruitful Ile of Crete well known to Fame,
Sacred of old to Jove's Immortal Name.
In the mid Ocean lies, with large Command;
And on its Plains a hundred Cities tand.
Another Ida ries there; and we
From thence derive our Trojan Ancetry.
From thence, as 'tis divulg'd by certain Fame,
To the Rhaetean Shores old Teucrus came.
There fix'd, and there the Seat of Empire choe,
E're Ilium and the Trojan Tow'rs aroe.
In humble Vales they built their oft abodes:
Till Cybele, the Mother of the Gods,
With tinckling Cymbals charm'd th' Idean Woods
She, ecret Rites and Ceremonies taught,
And to the Yoke, the alvage Lions brought.
Let us the Land, which Heav'n appoints, explore;
Appeae the Winds, and eek the Gnoian Shore.
If Jove aits tht paage of our Fleet,
The third propitious dawn dicovers Creet.
Thus having aid, the Sacrifices laid
On moking Altars, to the Gods He paid.
A Bull, to Neptune an Oblation due,
Another Bull to bright Apollo lew:
A milk white Ewe the Wetern Winds to pleae;
And one cole black to calm the tormy Seas.
E're this, a flying Rumour had been pred,
That fierce Idomeneus from Crete was fled;
Expell'd and exil'd; that the Coat was free
From Foreign or Dometick Enemy:
We leave the Delian Ports, and put to Sea:
By Naxos, fam'd for Vintage, make our way:
Then green Donya pas; and Sail in ight
Of Paros Ile, with Marble Quarries white.
We pas the catter'd Iles of Cyclades;
That, carce ditinguih'd, eem to tud the Seas.
The houts of Saylors double near the hores;
They tretch their Canvas, and they ply their Oars.
All hands aloft, for Creet for Creet they cry,
And wiftly through the foamy Billows fly.
Full on the promis'd Land at length we bore,
With Joy deending on the Cretan Shore.
With eager hate a riing Town I frame,
Which from the Trojan Pergamus I name:
The Name it elf was grateful; I exhort
To found their Houes, and erect a Fort.
Our Ships are haul'd upon the yellow trand,
The Youth begin to till the labour'd Land.
And I my elf new Marriages promote,
Give Laws: and Dwellings I divide by Lot.
When riing Vapours choak the wholeom Air,
And blats of noiom Winds corrupt the Year:
The Trees, devouring Caterpillers burn:
Parch'd was the Gras, and blited was the Corn.
Nor cape the Beats: for Syrius from on high,
With petilential Heat infects the Sky:
My Men, ome fall, the ret in Feavers fry.
Again my Father bids me eek the Shore
Of acred Delos; and the God implore:
To learn what end of Woes we might expect,
And to what Clime, our weary Coure direct.
'Twas Night, when ev'ry Creature, void of Cares,
The common gift of balmy Slumber hares:
The Statues of my Gods, (for uch they eem'd)
Thoe Gods whom I from flaming Troy redeem'd,
Before me tood; Majetically bright,
Full in the Beams of Phoebe's entring light.
Then thus they poke; and eas'd my troubled Mind:
What from the Delian God thou go't to find,
He tells thee here; and ends us to relate:
Thoe Pow'rs are we, Companions of thy Fate,
Who from the burning Town by thee were brought;
Thy Fortune follow'd, and thy afety wrought.
Through Seas and Lands, as we thy Steps attend,
So hall our Care thy Glorious Race befriend.
An ample Realm for thee thy Fates ordain;
A Town, that o're the conquer'd World hall reign.
Thou, mighty Walls for mighty Nations build;
Nor let thy weary Mind to Labours yield:
But change thy Seat; for not the Delian God,
Nor we, have giv'n thee Crete for our Abode.
A Land there is, Heperia call'd of old,
The Soil is fruitful, and the Natives bold.
Th' Oenotrians held it once; by later Fame,
Now call'd Italia from the Leader's Name.
Jäius there, and Dardanus were born:
From thence we came, and thither mut return.
Rie, and thy Sire with thee glad Tidings greet;
Search Italy, for Jove denies thee Creet.
Atonih'd at their Voices, and their ight,
(Nor were they Dreams, but Viions of the Night;
I aw, I knew their Faces, and decry'd
In perfect View, their Hair with Fillets ty'd:)
I tarted from my Couch, a clammy Sweat
On all my Limbs, and hiv'ring Body ate.
To Heav'n I lift my Hands with pious hate,
And acred Incene in the Flames I cat.
Thus to the Gods their perfect Honours done,
More chearful to my good old Sire I run:
And tell the pleaing News; in little pace
He found his Error, of the double Race.
Not, as before he deem'd, deriv'd from Creet;
No more deluded by the doubtful Seat.
Then aid, O Son, turmoil'd in Trojan Fate;
Such things as thee Caandra did relate.
This Day revives within my Mind, what he
Foretold of Troy renew'd in Italy;
And Latian Lands: but who cou'd then have thought,
That Phrygian Gods to Latium hould be brought;
Or who believ'd what mad Caandra taught?
Now let us go, where Phoebus leads the way:
He aid, and we with glad Conent obey.
Forake the Seat; and leaving few behind,
We pread our ails before the willing Wind.
Now from the ight of Land, our Gallies move,
With only Seas around, and Skies above.
When o're our Heads, decends a burt of Rain;
And Night, with able Clouds involves the Main:
The ruffling Winds the foamy Billows raie:
The catter'd Fleet is forc'd to ev'ral Ways:
The face of Heav'n is ravih'd from our Eyes,
And in redoubl'd Peals the roaring Thunder flys.
Cat from our Coure, we wander in the Dark;
No Stars to guide, no point of Land to mark.
Ev'n Palinurus no ditinction found
Betwixt the Night and Day; uch Darknes reign'd around.
Three tarles Nights the doubtful Navy trays
Without Ditinction, and three Sunles Days.
The fourth renews the Light, and from our Shrowds
We view a riing Land like ditant Clouds:
The Mountain tops confirm the pleaing Sight;
And curling Smoke acending from their Height.
The Canvas falls; their Oars the Sailors ply;
From the rude trokes the whirling Waters fly.
At length I land upon the Strophades;
Safe from the danger of the tormy Seas:
Thoe Iles are compas'd by th' Ionian Main;
The dire Abode where the foul Harpies reign:
Forc'd by the winged Warriors to repair
To their old Homes, and leave their cotly Fare.
Monters more fierce, offended Heav'n ne're ent
From Hell's Abys, for Human Punihment.
With Virgin-faces, but with Wombs obcene,
Foul Paunches, and with Ordure till unclean:
With Claws for Hands, and Looks for ever lean.
We landed at the Port; and oon beheld
Fat Herds of Oxen graze the flowry Field:
And wanton Goats without a Keeper tray'd:
With Weapons we the welcome Prey invade.
Then call the Gods, for Partners of our Feat:
And Jove himelf the chief invited Guet.
We pread the Tables, on the greenword Ground:
We feed with Hunger, and the Bowls go round.
When from the Mountain tops, with hideous Cry,
And clatt'ring Wings, the hungry Harpies fly:
They natch the Meat; defiling all they find:
And parting leave a loathom Stench behind.
Cloe by a hollow Rock, again we it;
New dres the Dinner, and the Beds refit:
Secure from Sight, beneath a pleaing Shade;
Where tufted Trees a native Arbour made.
Again the Holy Fires on Altars burn:
And once again the rav'nous Birds return:
Or from the dark Recees where they ly
Or from another Quarter of the Sky.
With filthy Claws their odious Meal repeat,
And mix their loathom Ordures with their Meat.
I bid my Friends for Vengeance then prepare;
And with the Hellih Nation wage the War.
They, as commanded, for the Fight provide,
And in the Gras their glitt'ring Weapons hide:
Then, when along the crooked Shoar we hear
Their clatt'ring Wings, and aw the Foes appear;

l.U: ounds a charge: We take th' Alarm;

lg.l: And our trong hands with Swords and Bucklers arm.
In this new kind of Combat, all employ
Their utmot Force, the Monters to detroy.
In vain; the fated Skin is proof to Wounds:
And from their Plumes the hining Sword rebounds.
At length rebuff'd, they leave their mangled Prey,
And their tretch'd Pinions to the Skies diplay.
Yet one remain'd, the Meenger of Fate;
High on a craggy Cliff Celaeno ate,
And thus her dimal Errand did relate.

figure.p: To ye Right Reverend Dr: John Hartstonge Bp: of Osory in Kilkenny Son of Sr. Standih Hartstonge Bart
figure.head: AE. 3. l. 315.

lg.l: What, not contented with our Oxen lain,
Dare you with Heav'n an impious War maintain,
And drive the Harpies from their Native Reign?
Heed therefore what I ay; and keep in mind
What Jove decrees, what Phoebus has deign'd:
And I, the Fury's Queen, from both relate:
You eek th' Italian Shores, foredoom'd by Fate:
Th' Italian Shores are granted you to find:
And a afe Paage to the Port aign'd.
But know, that e're your promis'd Walls you build,
My Cures hall everely be fulfill'd.
Fierce Famine is your Lot, for this Mideed,
Reduc'd to grind the Plates on which you feed.
She aid; and to the neighb'ring Foret flew:
Our Courage fails us, and our Fears renew.
Hopeles to win by War, to Pray'rs we fall:
And on th' offended Harpies humbly call.
And whether Gods, or Birds obcene they were,
Our Vows for Pardon, and for Peace prefer.
But old Anchies, off'ring Sacrifice,
And lifting up to Heav'n his Hands, and Eyes;
Ador'd the greater Gods: Avert, aid he,
Thee Omens, render vain this Prophecy:
And from th' impending Cure, a Pious People free.
Thus having aid, he bids us put to Sea;
We looe from Shore our Haulers, and obey:
And oon with welling Sails, purue the wat'ry Way.
Amidt our coure Zacynthian Woods appear;
And next by rocky Neritos we teer:
We fly from Ithaca's deteted Shore,
And cure the Land which dire Ulyes bore.
At length Leucates cloudy top appears;
And Phoebus Temple, which the Sailor fears.
Reolv'd to breath a while from Labour pat,
Our crooked Anchors from the Prow we cat;
And joyful to the little City hate.
Here afe beyond our Hopes, our Vows we pay
To Jove, the Guide and Patron of our way.
The Cutoms of our Country we purue;
And Trojan Games on Actian Shores renew.
Our Youth, their naked Limbs bemear with Oyl;
And exercie the Wratlers noble Toil.
Pleas'd to have ail'd o long before the Wind;
And left o many Grecian Towns behind.
The Sun had now fulfill'd his Annual Coure,
And Boreas on the Seas diplay'd his Force:
I fix'd upon the Temples lofty Door,
The brazen Shield which vanquih'd Abas bore:
The Vere beneath, my Name and Action peaks,
Thee Arms, Aeneas took from Conqu'ring Greeks.
Then I command to weigh; the Seamen ply
Their weeping Oars, the mokeing Billows fly.
The ight of high Phaeacia oon we lot:
And skim'd along Epirus rocky Coat.
Then to Chaonia's Port our Coure we bend,
And landed, to Buthrotus heights acend.
Here wond'rous things were loudly blaz'd by Fame;
How Helenus reviv'd the Trojan Name;
And raign'd in Greece: That Priam's captive Son
Succeeded Pyrrhus in his Bed and Throne.
And fair Andromache, retor'd by Fate,
Once more was happy in a Trojan Mate.
I leave my Gallies riding in the Port;
And long to ee the new Dardanian Court.
By chance, the mournful Queen, before the Gate,
Then olemniz'd her former Husbands Fate.

figure.p: To The Honble. Dr: Ion: Mountague Master of Trinity College in Cambridge
figure.head: AE. 3. l: 415.

lg.l: Green Altars rais'd of Turf, with Gifts he Crown'd;
And acred Priets in order tand around;
And thrice the Name of haples Hector ound.
The Grove it elf reembles Ida's Wood;
And Simois eem'd the well diembl'd Flood.
But when, at nearer ditance, he beheld
My hining Armour, and my Trojan Shield;
Atonih'd at the ight, the vital Heat
Forakes her Limbs, her Veins no longer beat:
She faints, he falls, and carce recov'ring trength,
Thus, with a falt'ring Tongue, he peaks at length.
Are you alive, O Goddes born! he aid,
Or if a Ghot, then where is Hector's Shade?
At this, he cat a loud and frightful Cry:
With broken words, I made this brief Reply.
All of me that remains, appears in ight,
I live; if living be to loath the Light.
No Phantome; but I drag a wretched life;
My Fate reembling that of Hector's Wife.
What have you uffer'd ince you lot your Lord,
By what trange bleing are you now retor'd!
Still are you Hector's, or is Hector fled,
And his Remembrance lot in Pyrrhus Bed?
With Eyes dejected, in a lowly tone,
After a modet paue, he thus begun.
Oh only happy Maid of Priam's Race,
Whom Death deliver'd from the Foes embrace!
Commanded on Achilles Tomb to die,
Not forc'd, like us, to hard Captivity:
Or in a haughty Mater's Arms to lie.
In Grecian Ships unhappy we were born:
Endur'd the Victor's Lut, utain'd the Scorn:
Thus I ubmitted to the lawles pride
Of Pyrrhus, more a Handmaid than a Bride.
Cloy'd with Poeion, He forook my Bed,
And Helen's lovely Daughter ought to wed.
Then me, to Trojan Helenus reign'd:
And his two Slaves in equal Marriage join'd.
Till young Oretes, pierc'd with deep depair,
And longing to redeem the promis'd Fair,
Before Apollo's Altar lew the Raviher.
By Pyrrhus death the Kingdom we regain'd:
At leat one half with Helenus remain'd;
Our part, from Chaon, He Chaonia calls:
And names, from Pergamus, his riing Walls.
But you, what Fates have landed on our Coat,
What Gods have ent you, or what Storms have tot?
Does young Acanius life and health enjoy,
Sav'd from the Ruins of unhappy Troy!
O tell me how his Mothers los he bears,
What hopes are promis'd from his blooming years,
How much of Hector in his Face appears?
She poke: and mix'd her Speech with mournful Cries:
And fruitles Tears came trickling from her Eyes.
At length her Lord decends upon the Plain;
In pomp, attended with a num'rous Train:
Receives his Friends, and to the City leads;
And Tears of Joy amidt his Welcome heds.
Proceeding on, another Troy I ee;
Or, in les compas, Troy's Epitome.
A Riv'let by the name of Xanthus ran:
And I embrace the Scaean Gate again.
My Friends in Portico's were entertain'd;
And Feats and Pleaures through the City reign'd.
The Tables fill'd the pacious Hall around:
And Golden Bowls with parkling Wine were crown'd.
Two days we pas'd in mirth, till friendly Gales,
Blown from the South, upply'd our welling Sails.
Then to the Royal Seer I thus began:
O thou who know't beyond the reach of Man,
The Laws of Heav'n, and what the Stars decree,
Whom Phoebus taught unerring Prophecy,
From his own Tripod, and his holy Tree:
Skill'd in the wing'd Inhabitants of Air,
What Aupices their notes, and flights declare:
O ay; for all Religious Rites portend
A happy Voyage, and a prop'rous End:
And ev'ry Pow'r and Omen of the Sky,
Direct my Coure for detin'd Italy:
But only dire Celaeno, from the Gods,
A dimal Famine fatally fore-bodes:
O ay what Dangers I am firt to hun:
What Toils to vanquih, and what Coure to run.
The Prophet firt with Sacrifice adores
The greater Gods; their Pardon then implores:
Unbinds the Fillet from his holy Head;
To Phoebus next, my trembling Steps he led:
Full of religious Doubts, and awful dread.
Then with his God poes'd, before the Shrine,
Thee words proceeded from his Mouth Divine.
O Goddes-born, (for Heav'n's appointed Will,
With greater Aupices of good than ill,
Fore-hows thy Voyage, and thy Coure directs;
Thy Fates conpire, and Jove himelf protects:)
Of many things, ome few I hall explain,
Teach thee to hun the dangers of the Main,
And how at length the promis'd Shore to gain.
The ret the Fates from Helenus conceal;
And Juno's angry Pow'r forbids to tell.
Firt then, that happy Shore, that eems o nigh,
Will far from your deluded Wihes fly:
Long tracts of Seas divide your hopes from Italy.
For you mut cruie along Sicilian Shoars;
And tem the Currents with your truggling Oars:
Then round th' Italian Coat your Navy teer;
And after this to Circe's Iland veer.
And lat, before your new Foundations rie,
Mut pas the Stygian Lake, and view the neather Skies.
Now mark the Signs of future Eae and Ret;
And bear them afely treaur'd in thy Breat.
When in the hady Shelter of a Wood,
And near the Margin of a gentle Flood,
Thou halt behold a Sow upon the Ground,
With thirty ucking young encompas'd round;
The Dam and Off-pring white as falling Snow:
Thee on thy City hall their Name betow:
And there hall end thy Labours and thy Woe.
Nor let the threatned Famine fright thy Mind,
For Phoebus will ait; and Fate the way will find.
Let not thy Coure to that ill Coat be bent,
Which fronts from far th' Epirian Continent;
Thoe parts are all by Grecian Foes poes'd:
The alvage Locrians here the Shores infet:
There fierce Idomeneus his City builds,
And guards with Arms the Salentinian Fields.
And on the Mountains brow Petilia tands,
Which Philoctetes with his Troops commands.
Ev'n when thy Fleet is landed on the Shore,
And Priets with holy Vows the Gods adore;
Then with a Purple Veil involve your Eyes,
Let hotile Faces blat the Sacrifice.
Thee Rites and Cutoms to the Ret commend;
That to your Pious Race they may decend.
When parted hence, the Wind that ready waits
For Sicily, hall bear you to the Streights:
Where proud Pelorus opes a wider way,
Tack to the Larboord, and tand off to Sea:
Veer Star-board Sea and Land. Th' Italian Shore,
And fair Sicilia's Coat were one, before
An Earthquake caus'd the Flaw, the roaring Tides
The Paage broke, that Land from Land divides:
And where the Lands retir'd, the ruhing Ocean rides.
Ditinguih'd by the Streights, on either hand,
Now riing Cities in long order tand;
And fruitful Fields: So much can Time invade
The mouldring Work, that beauteous Nature made.
Far on the right, her Dogs foul Scylla hides:
Charibdis roaring on the left preides;
And in her greedy Whirl-pool ucks the Tides:
Then Spouts them from below; with Fury driv'n,
The Waves mount up, and wah the face of Heav'n.
But Scylla from her Den, with open Jaws,
The inking Veel in her Eddy draws;
Then dahes on the Rocks: A Human Face,
And Virgin Boom, hides her Tails digrace.
Her Parts obcene below the Waves decend,
With Dogs inclos'd; and in a Dolphin end.
'Tis afer, then, to bear aloof to Sea,
And coat Pachynus, though with more delay;
Than once to view mihapen Scylla near,
And the loud yell of watry Wolves to hear.
Beides, if Faith to Helenus be due,
And if Prophetick Phoebus tell me true;
Do not this Precept of your Friend forget;
Which therefore more than once I mut repeat.
Above the ret, great Juno's Name adore:
Pay Vows to Juno; Juno's Aid implore.
Let Gifts be to the mighty Queen deign'd;
And mollify with Pray'rs her haughty Mind.
Thus, at the length, your Paage hall be free,
And you hall afe decend on Italy.
Arriv'd at Cumae, when you view the Flood
Of black Avernus, and the ounding Wood,
The mad prophetick Sybil you hall find,
Dark in a Cave, and on a Rock reclin'd.
She ings the Fates, and in her frantick Fitts,
The Notes and Names incrib'd, to Leafs commits.
What he commits to Leafs, in order laid,
Before the Caverns Entrance are diplay'd:
Unmov'd they lie, but if a Blat of Wind
Without, or Vapours iue from behind,
The Leafs are born aloft in liquid Air,
And he reumes no more her Mueful Care:
Nor gathers from the Rocks her catter'd Vere;
Nor ets in order what the Winds dipere.
Thus, many not ucceeding, mot upbraid
The Madnes of the viionary Maid;
And with loud Cures leave the mytick Shade.
Think it not los of time a while to tay;
Though thy Companions chide thy long delay:
Tho' ummon'd to the Seas, tho' pleaing Gales
Invite thy Coure, and tretch thy welling Sails.
But beg the acred Prietes to relate
With willing Words, and not to write thy Fate.
The fierce Italian People he will how;
And all thy Wars, and all thy Future Woe;
And what thou may't avoid, and what mut undergo.
She hall direct thy Coure, intruct thy Mind;
And teach thee how the happy Shores to find.
This is what Heav'n allows me to relate:
Now part in Peace; purue thy better Fate,
And raie, by trength of Arms, the Trojan State
This, when the Priet with friendly Voice declar'd,
He gave me Licence, and rich Gifts prepar'd:
Bounteous of Treaure, he upply'd my want
With heavy Gold, and polih'd Elephant.
Then Dodonaean Caldrons put on Bord,
And ev'ry Ship with Sums of Silver tor'd.
A truty Coat of Mail to me he ent,
Thrice chain'd with Gold, for Ue and Ornament:
The Helm of Pyrrhus added to the ret,
That flourih'd with a Plume and waving Cret.
Nor was my Sire forgotten, nor my Friends:
And large Recruits he to my Navy ends;
Men, Hores, Captains, Arms, and warlick Stores:
Supplies new Pilots, and new weeping Oars.
Mean time, my Sire commands to hoit our Sails;
Let we hou'd loe the firt aupicious Gales.
The Prophet bles'd the parting Crew: and lat,
With Words like thee, his ancient Friend embrac'd.
Old happy Man, the Care of Gods above,
Whom Heav'nly Venus honour'd with her Love,
And twice preerv'd thy Life, when Troy was lot;
Behold from far the wih'd Auonian Coat:
There land; but take a larger Compas round;
For that before is all forbidden Ground.
The Shore that Phoebus has deign'd for you,
At farther ditance lies, conceal'd from view.
Go happy hence, and eek your new Abodes;
Bles'd in a Son, and favour'd by the Gods:
For I with ueles words prolong your tay;
When Southern Gales have ummon'd you away.
Nor les the Queen our parting thence deplor'd;
Nor was les bounteous than her Trojan Lord.
A noble Preent to my Son he brought,
A Robe with Flow'rs on Golden Tiue wrought;
A Phrygian Vet; and loads, with Gifts beide
Of precious Texture, and of Aian Pride.
Accept, he aid, thee Monuments of Love;
Which in my Youth with happier Hands I wove:
Regard thee Trifles for the Giver's ake;
Tis the lat Preent Hector's Wife can make.
Thou call't my lot Atyanax to mind:
In thee his Features, and his Form I find.
His Eyes o parkled with a lively Flame;
Such were his Motions, uch was all his Frame;
And ah! had Heav'n o pleas'd, his Years had been the ame.
With Tears I took my lat adieu, and aid,
Your Fortune, happy pair, already made,
Leaves you no farther Wih: My diff'rent tate,
Avoiding one, incurs another Fate.
To you a quiet Seat the Gods allow,
You have no Shores to earch, no Seas to plow,
Nor Fields of flying Italy to chae:
(Deluding Viions, and a vain Embrace!)
You ee another Simois, and enjoy
The labour of your Hands another Troy;
With better Aupice than her ancient Tow'rs:
And les obnoxious to the Grecian Pow'rs.
If e're the Gods, whom I with Vows adore,
Conduct my Steps to Tiber's happy Shore:
If ever I acend the Latian Throne,
And build a City I may call my own,
As both of us our Birth from Troy derive,
So let our Kindred Lines in Concord live:
And both in Acts of equal Friendhip trive.
Our Fortunes, good or bad, hall be the ame
The double Troy hall differ but in Name:
That what we now begin, may never end;
But long, to late Poterity decend.

figure.p: To Edward Browne Dr. in Physick.
figure.head: AE. 3. l. 625.

lg.l: Near the Ceraunean Rocks our Coure we bore:
(The hortet paage to th' Italian hore:)
Now had the Sun withdrawn his radiant Light,
And Hills were hid in dusky Shades of Night:
We land; and on the boom of the Ground
A afe Retreat, and a bare Lodging found;
Cloe by the Shore we lay; the Sailors keep
Their watches, and the ret ecurely leep.
The Night proceeding on with ilent pace,
Stood in her noon; and view'd with equal Face,
Her teepy rie, and her declining Race.
Then wakeful Palinurus roe, to pie
The face of Heav'n, and the Nocturnal Skie;
And liten'd ev'ry breath of Air to try:
Oberves the Stars, and notes their liding Coure,
The Pleiads, Hyads, and their wat'ry force;
And both the Bears is careful to behold;
And bright Orion arm'd with burnih'd Gold.
Then when he aw no threat'ning Tempet Nigh,
But a ure promie of a ettled Skie;
He gave the Sign to weigh; we break our leep;
Forake the pleaing Shore, and plow the deep.
And now the riing Morn, with roie light
Adorns the Skies, and puts the Stars to flight:
When we from far, like bluih Mits, decry
The Hills, and then the Plains of Italy.
Achates firt pronounc'd the Joyful ound;
Then Italy the chearful Crew rebound.
My Sire Anchies crown'd a Cup with Wine:
And off'ring, thus implor'd the Pow'rs Divine.
Ye Gods, preiding over Lands and Seas,
And you who raging Winds and Waves appeae,
Breath on our welling Sails a prop'rous Wind:
And mooth our Paage to the Port aign'd.
The gentle Gales their flagging force renew;
And now the happy Harbour is in view.
Minerva's Temple then alutes our ight;
Plac'd, as a Land-mark, on the Mountains height:
We furl our Sails, and turn the Prows to hore;
The curling Waters round the Galleys roar:
The Land lies open to the raging Eat,
Then, bending like a Bow, with Rocks compres'd,
Shuts out the Storms; the Winds and Waves complain,
And vent their malice on the Cliffs in vain.
The Port lies hid within; on either ide
Two Tow'ring Rocks the narrow mouth divide.
The Temple, which aloft we view'd before,
To ditance flies, and eems to hun the Shore.
Scarce landed, the firt Omens I beheld
Were four white Steeds that crop'd the flow'ry Field.
War, War is threaten'd from this Forreign Ground,
(My Father cry'd) where warlike Steeds are found.
Yet, ince reclaim'd to Chariots they ubmit,
And bend to tubborn Yokes, and champ the Bitt,
Peace may ucceed to Warr. Our way we bend
To Pallas, and the acred Hill acend.
There, protrate to the fierce Virago pray;
Whoe Temple was the Land-Mark of our way.
Each with a Phrygian Mantle veil'd his Head;
And all Commands of Helenus obey'd;
And pious Rites to Grecian Juno paid.
Thee dues perform'd, we tretch our Sails, and tand
To Sea, foraking that upected Land.
From hence Tarentum's Bay appears in view;
For Hercules renown'd, if Fame be true.
Jut oppoite, Lacinian Juno tands;
Caulonian Tow'rs and Scylacaean Strands.
For Shipwrecks fear'd: Mount Etna thence we py,
Known by the moaky Flames which Cloud the Skie.
Far off we hear the Waves, with urly ound
Invade the Rocks, the Rocks their groans rebound.
The Billows break upon the ounding Strand;
And roul the riing Tide, impure with Sand.
Then thus Anchies, in Experience old,
'Tis that Charibdis which the Seer foretold:
And thoe the promis'd Rocks; bear off to Sea:
With hate the frighted Mariners obey.
Firt Palinurus to the Larboor'd veer'd;
Then all the Fleet by his Example teer'd.
To Heav'n aloft on ridgy Waves we ride;
Then down to Hell decend, when they divide.
And thrice our Gallies knock'd the tony ground,
And thrice the hollow Rocks return'd the ound,
And thrice we aw the Stars, that tood with dews around.
The flagging Winds forook us, with the Sun;
And weary'd, on Cyclopean Shores we run.
The Port capacious, and ecure from Wind,
Is to the foot of thundring Etna joyn'd.
By turns a pitchy Cloud he rowls on high;
By turns hot Embers from her entrails fly;
And flakes of mounting Flames, that lick the Skie.
Oft from her Bowels may Rocks are thrown,
And hiver'd by the force come piece-meal down.
Oft liquid Lakes of burning Sulphur flow,
Fed from the fiery Springs that boil below.
Enceladus they ay, transfix'd by Jove,
With blated Limbs came tumbling from above:
And, where he fell, th' Avenging Father drew
This flaming Hill, and on his Body threw:
As often as he turns his weary ides,
He hakes the olid Ile, and moke the Heavens hides.
In hady Woods we pas the tedious Night,
Where bellowing Sounds and Groans our Souls affright
Of which no Caue is offer'd to the ight.
For not one Star was kindled in the Skie;
Nor cou'd the Moon her borrow'd Light upply:
For mity Clouds invovl'd the Firmament;
The Stars were muffled, and the Moon was pent.
Scarce had the riing Sun the day reveal'd;
Scarce had his heat the pearly dews dipell'd;
When from the Woods there bolts, before our ight,
Somewhat, betwixt a Mortal and a Spright.
So thin, o ghatly meagre, and o wan,
So bare of fleh, he carce reembled Man.
This thing, all tatter'd, eem'd from far t'implore
Our pious aid, and pointed to the Shore.
We look behind; then view his haggy Beard;
His Cloaths were tagg'd with Thorns, and Filth his Limbs bemear'd:
The ret, in Meen, in habit, and in Face,
Appear'd a Greek; and uch indeed he was.
He cat on us, from far, a frightful view,
Whom oon for Trojans and for Foes he knew:
Stood till, and paus'd; then all at once began
To tretch his Limbs, and trembled as he ran.
Soon as approach'd, upon his Knees he falls,
And thus with Tears and Sighs for pity calls.
Now by the Pow'rs above, and what we hare
As Nature's common Gift, this vital Air,
O Trojans take me hence: I beg no more,
But bear me far from this unhappy Shore.
'Tis true I am a Greek, and farther own,
Among your Foes beieg'd th' Imperial Town;
For uch Demerits if my death be due,
No more for this abandon'd life I ue:
This only Favour let my Tears obtain,
To throw me headlong in the rapid Main:
Since nothing more than Death my Crime demands,
I dye content, to dye by human Hands.
He aid, and on his Knees my Knees embrac'd,
I bad him boldly tell his Fortune pat;
His preent State, his Lineage and his Name;
Th' occaion of his Fears, and whence he came.
The good Anchies rais'd him with his Hand;
Who, thus encourag'd, anwer'd our Demand:
From Ithaca my native Soil I came
To Troy, and Achaemenides my Name.
Me, my poor Father, with Ulyes ent;
(Oh had I tay'd, with Poverty content!)
But fearful for themelves, my Country-men
Left me foraken in the Cyclop's Den.
The Cave, though large, was dark, the dimal Flore
Was pav'd with mangled Limbs and putrid Gore.
Our montrous Hot, of more than Human Size,
Erects his Head, and tares within the Skies.
Bellowing his Voice, and horrid is his Hue.
Ye Gods, remove this Plague from Mortal View!
The Joints of laughter'd Wretches are his Food:
And for his Wine he quaffs the treaming Blood.
Thee Eyes beheld, when with his pacious Hand
He eiz'd two Captives of our Grecian Band;
Stretch'd on his Back, he dah'd againt the Stones
Their broken Bodies, and their crackling Bones:
With pouting Blood the Purple Pavement wims,
While the dire Glutton grinds the trembling Limbs.
Not unreveng'd, Ulyes bore their Fate,
Nor thoughtles of his own unhappy State:
For, gorg'd with Fleh, and drunk with Human Wine,
While fat aleep the Gyant lay upine;
Snoaring aloud, and belching from his Maw
His indigeted Foam, and Morels raw:
We pray, we cat the Lots, and then urround
The montrous Body, tretch'd along the Ground:
Each, as he cou'd approach him, lends a hand
To bore his Eyeball with a flaming Brand.
Beneath his frowning Forehead lay his Eye,
(For onely one did the vat Frame upply;)
But that a Globe o large, his Front it fill'd,
Like the Sun's disk, or like a Grecian Shield.
The Stroke ucceeds; and down the Pupil bends;
This Vengeance follow'd for our laughter'd Friends.
But hate, unhappy Wretches, hate to fly;
Your Cables cut, and on your Oars rely.
Such, and o vat as Polypheme appears,
A hundred more this hated Iland bears:
Like him in Caves they hut their woolly Sheep,
Like him, their Herds on tops of Mountains keep;
Like him, with mighty Strides, they talk from Steep to Steep.
And now three Moons their harpen'd Horns renew
Since thus in Woods and Wilds, obcure from view,
I drag my loathom Days with mortal Fright;
And in deerted Caverns lodge by Night.
Oft from the Rocks a dreadful Propect ee,
Of the huge Cyclops, like a walking Tree:
From far I hear his thund'ring Voice reound;
And trampling Feet that hake the olid Ground.
Cornels, and alvage Berries of the Wood,
And Roots and Herbs have been my meagre Food.
While all around my longing Eyes I cat,
I aw your happy Ships appear at lat.
On thoe I fix'd my hopes, to thee I run,
'Tis all I ask this cruel Race to hun:

figure.p: To Wm. Gibbons Dr.: in Physick
figure.head: AE. 3. l. 865.

lg.l: What other Death you pleae your elves, betow.
Scarce had he aid, when on the Mountain's brow,
We aw the Gyant-Shepherd talk before
His following Flock, and leading to the Shore.
A montrous Bulk, deform'd, depriv'd of Sight,
His Staff a trunk of Pine, to guide his teps aright.
His pondrous Whitle from his Neck decends;
His woolly Care their penive Lord attends:
This onely Solace his hard Fortune ends.
Soon as he reach'd the Shore, and touch'd the Waves,
From his bor'd Eye the gutt'ring Blood he laves:
He gnah'd his Teeth and groan'd; thro' Seas he trides,
And carce the topmot Billows touch'd his ides.
Seiz'd with a udden Fear, we run to Sea,
The Cables cut, and ilent hate away:
The well deerving Stranger entertain;
Then, buckling to the Work, our Oars divide the Main.
The Gyant harken'd to the dahing Sound:
But when our Veels out of reach he found,
He trided onward; and in vain eay'd
Th' Ionian Deep, and durt no farther wade.
With that he roar'd aloud; the dreadful Cry
Shakes Earth, and Air, and Seas; the Billows fly
Before the bellowing Noie, to ditant Italy.
The neighb'ring Aetna trembled all around;
The winding Caverns echo to the ound.
His brother Cyclops hear the yelling Roar;
And, ruhing down the Mountains, crowd the Shoar:
We aw their tern ditorted looks, from far,
And one ey'd Glance, that vainly threatned War.
A dreadful Council, with their heads on high;
The mity Clouds about their Foreheads fly:
Not yielding to the tow'ring Tree of Jove;
Or tallet Cypres of Diana's Grove.
New Pangs of mortal Fear our Minds aail,
We tug at ev'ry Oar, and hoit up ev'ry Sail;
And take th' Advantage of the friendly Gale.
Forewarn'd by Helenus, we trive to hun
Charibdis Gulph, nor dare to Scylla run.
An equal Fate on either ide appears;
