We, tacking to the left, are free from Fears.
For from Pelorus Point, the North aroe,
And drove us back where wift Pantagias flows.
His Rocky Mouth we pas; and make our Way
By Thapus, and Megara's winding Bay;
This Paage Achaemenides had hown,
Tracing the Coure which he before had run.
Right o're-againt Plemmyrium's watry Strand,
There lies an Ile once call'd th' Ortygian Land:
Alphëus, as Old Fame reports, has found
From Greece a ecret Paage under-ground:
By Love to beauteous Arethua led,
And mingling here, they rowl in the ame Sacred Bed.
As Helenus enjoyn'd, we next adore
Diana's Name, Protectres of the Shore.
With prop'rous Gales we pas the quiet Sounds
Of till Elorus and his fruitul Bounds.
Then doubling Cape Pachynus, we urvey
The rocky Shore extended to the Sea.
The Town of Camarine from far we ee;
And fenny Lake undrain'd by Fates decree.
In ight of the Geloan Fields we pas,
And the large Walls, where mighty Gela was:
Then Agragas with lofty Summets crown'd;
Long for the Race of warlike Steeds renown'd:
We pas'd Selinus, and the Palmy Land,
And widely hun the Lilybaean Strand,
Unafe, for ecret Rocks, and moving Sand.
At length on Shore the weary Fleet arriv'd;
Which Drepanum's unhappy Port receiv'd.
Here, after endles Labours, often tot
By raging Storms, and driv'n on ev'ry Coat,
My dear, dear Father, pent with Age, I lot.
Eae of my Cares, and Solace of my Pain,
Sav'd through a thouand Toils, but av'd in vain:
The Prophet, who my future Woes reveal'd,
Yet this, the greatet and the wort, conceal'd.
And dire Celoeno, whoe foreboding Skill
Denounc'd all ele, was ilent of this Ill:
This my lat Labour was. Some friendly God,
From thence convey'd us to your blet Abode.
Thus to the litning Queen, the Royal Guet
His wand'ring Coure, and all his Toils expres'd;
And here concluding, he retir'd to ret.

div.head: The Fourth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Dido dicovers to her Siter her Paion for Aeneas, and her thoughts of marrying him. She prepares a Hunting-Match for his Entertainment. Juno by Venus's conent raies a Storm, which eparates the Hunters, and drives Aeneas and Dido into the ame Cave, where their Marriage is uppos'd to be compleated. Jupiter dipatches Mercury to Aeneas, to warn him from Carthage; Aeneas ecretly prepares for his Voyage: Dido finds out his Deign, and to put a top to it, makes ue of her own, and her Siter's Entreaties, and dicovers all the variety of Paions that are incident to a neglected Lover: When nothing wou'd prevail upon him, he contrives her own Death, with which this Book concludes.

lg.l: BUT anxious Cares already eiz'd the Queen:
She fed within her Veins a Flame uneen:
The Heroe's Valour, Acts, and Birth inpire
Her Soul with Love, and fann the ecret Fire.
His Words, his Looks imprinted in her Heart,
Improve the Paion, and increae the Smart.
Now, when the Purple Morn had chas'd away
The dewy Shadows, and retor'd the Day;
Her Siter firt, with early Care he ought,
And thus in mournful Accents eas'd her Thought.
My dearet Anna, what new Dreams affright
My lab'ring Soul; what Viions of the Night
Diturb my Quiet, and ditract my Breat,
With trange Ideas of our Trojan Guet?
His Worth, his Actions, and Majetick Air,
A Man decended from the Gods declare:
Fear never harbours in a Noble Mind,
But Modety, with jut Aurance join'd.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble. John Earle of Exeter Baron Coecill of Burleigh &ct
figure.head: AE. 4. l: 1.

lg.l: Then, what he uffer'd, when by Fate betray'd,
What brave Attempts for falling Troy he made!
Such were his Looks, o gracefully he poke,
That were I not reolv'd againt the Yoke
Of haples Marriage; never to be curs'd
With econd Love, o fatal was my firt;
To this one Error I might yield again:
For ince Sichaeus was untimely lain,
This onely Man, is able to ubvert
The fix'd Foundations of my tubborn Heart.
And to confes my Frailty, to my hame,
Somewhat I find within, if not the ame,
Too like the Sparkles of my former Flame.
But firt let yawning Earth a Paage rend;
And let me through the dark Abys decend;
Firt let avenging Jove, with Flames from high,
Drive down this Body, to the neather Sky,
Condemn'd with Ghots in endles Night to lye;
Before I break the plighted Faith I gave;
No; he who had my Vows, hall ever have;
For whom I lov'd on Earth, I worhip in the Grave.
She aid; the Tears ran guhing from her Eyes,
And top'd her Speech: her Siter thus replies.
O dearer than the vital Air I breath,
Will you to Grief your blooming Years bequeath?
Condem'd to wat in Woes, your lonely Life,
Without the Joys of Mother, or of Wife.
Think you thee Tears, this pompous Train of Woe,
Are known, or valu'd by the Ghots below?
I grant, that while your Sorrows yet were green,
It well became a Woman, and a Queen,
The Vows of Tyrian Princes to neglect,
To corn Hyarbas, and his Love reject;
With all the Lybian Lords of mighty Name,
But will you fight againt a pleaing Flame!
This little Spot of Land, which Heav'n betows,
On ev'ry ide is hemm'd with warlike Foes:
Getulian Cities here are pread around;
And fierce Numidians there your Frontiers bound;
Here lies a barren Wat of thirty Land,
And there the Syrtes raie the moving Sand:
Barcaean Troops befiege the narrow Shore;
And from the Sea Pigmalion threatens more.
Propitious Heav'n, and gracious Juno, lead
This wand'ring Navy to your needful Aid:
How will your Empire pread, your City rie
From uch an Union, and with uch Allies!
Implore the Favour of the Pow'rs above;
And leave the Conduct of the ret to Love.
Continue till your hopitable way,
And till invent occaions of their Stay;
'Till Storms, and winter Winds, hall ceae to threat,
And Plancks and Oars, repair their hatter'd Fleet.
Thee Words, which from a Friend, and Siter came,
With Eae reolv'd the Scruples of her Fame;
And added Fury to the kindled Flame.
Inpir'd with Hope, the Project they purue;
On ev'ry Altar Sacrifice renew;
A choen Ewe of two Years old they pay
To Ceres, Bacchus, and the God of Day:
Preferring Juno's Pow'r: For Juno ties
The Nuptial Knot, and makes the Marriage Joys.
The beauteous Queen before her Altar tands,
And holds the Golden Goblet in her Hands:
A milk-white Heifar he with Flow'rs adorns,
And pours the ruddy Wine betwixt her Horns;

figure.p: To the Lady Mary Giffard
figure.head: AE. 4. l. 80.

lg.l: And while the Priets with Pray'r the Gods invoke,
She feeds their Altars with Sabaean Smoke.
With hourly Care the Sacrifice renews,
And anxiouly the panting Entrails Views.
What Prietly Rites, alas! what Pious Art,
What Vows avail to cure a bleeding Heart!
A gentle Fire he feeds within her Veins;
Where the oft God ecure in ilence reigns.
Sick with deire, and eeking him he loves,
From Street to Street, the raving Dido roves.
So when the watchful Shepherd, from the Blind,
Wounds with a random Shaft the careles Hind;
Ditracted with her pain he flies the Woods,
Bounds o're the Lawn, and eeks the ilent Floods;
With fruitles Care; for till the fatal Dart
Sticks in her ide; and ranckles in her Heart.
And now he leads the Trojan Chief, along
The lofty Walls, amidt the buiie Throng;
Diplays her Tyrian Wealth, and riing Town,
Which Love, without his Labour, makes his own.
This Pomp he hows to tempt her wond'ring Guet;
Her falt'ring Tongue forbids to peak the ret.
When Day declines, and Feats renew the Night,
Still on his Face he feeds her famih'd ight;
She longs again to hear the Prince relate
His own Adventures, and the Trojan Fate:
He tells it o're and o're; but till in vain;
For till he begs to hear it, once again.
The Hearer on the Speaker's Mouth depends;
And thus the Tragick Story never ends.
Then, when they part, when Phoebe's paler Light
Withdraws, and falling Stars to Sleep invite,
She lat remains, when when ev'ry Guet is gone,
Sits on the Bed he pres'd, and ighs alone;
Abent, her abent Heroe ees and hears;
Or in her Boom young Acanius bears:
And eeks the Father's Image in the Child,
If Love by Likenes might be o beguil'd.
Mean time the riing Tow'rs are at a tand:
No Labours exercie the youthful Band:
Nor ue of Arts, nor Toils of Arms they know;
The Mole is left unfinih'd to the Foe.
The Mounds, the Works, the Walls, neglected lye,
And, left unbuilt, are horter of the Sky.
But when Imperial Juno, from above,
Saw Dido fetter'd in the Chains of Love;
Hot with the Venom, which her Veins inflam'd,
And by no ene of Shame to be reclaim'd:
With oothing Words to Venus he begun.
High Praies, endles Honours you have won,
And mighty Trophees with your worthy Son:
Two Gods a illy Woman have undone.
Nor am I ignorant, you both upect
This riing City, which my Hands erect:
But hall Coeletial Dicord never ceae?
'Tis better ended in a lating Peace.
You tand poes'd of all your Soul deir'd;
Poor Dido with conuming Love is fir'd:
Your Trojan with my Tyrian let us join,
So Dido hall be yours, Aeneas mine:
One common Kingdom, one united Line.

l.U: hall a Dardan Lord obey,

lg.l: And lofty Carthage for a Dow'r convey.
Then Venus, who her hidden Fraud decry'd,
(Which wou'd the Scepter of the World, miguide
To Lybian Shores,) thus artfully reply'd,
Who but a Fool, wou'd Wars with Juno chue,
And uch Alliance, and uch Gifts refue?
If Fortune with our joint Deires comply:
The Doubt is all from Jove, and Detiny.
Let he forbid, with abolute Command,
To mix the People in one common Land.
Or will the Trojan, and the Tyrian Line,
In lating Leagues, and ure Succeion join?
But you, the Partner of his Bed and Throne,
May move his Mind; my Wihes are your own.
Mine, aid Imperial Juno, be the Care;
Time urges, now, to perfect this Affair:
Attend my Counel, and the Secret hare.
When next the Sun his riing Light diplays,
And guilds the World below, with Purple Rays;
The Queen, Aeneas, and the Tyrian Court,
Shall to the hady Woods, for Silvan Game, reort.
There, while the Huntmen pitch their Toils around,
And chearful Horns, from Side to Side, reound;
A Pitchy Cloud hall cover all the Plain
With Hail, and Thunder, and tempetuous Rain:
The fearful Train hall take their peedy Flight,
Dipers'd, and all involv'd in gloomy Night:
One Cave a grateful Shelter hall afford
To the fair Princes, and the Trojan Lord.
I will my elf, the bridal Bed prepare,
If you, to bles the Nuptials, will be there:
So hall their Loves be crown'd with due Delights,
And Hymen hall be preent at the Rites.
The Queen of Love conents, and cloely miles
At her vain Project, and dicover'd Wiles.
The roy Morn was rien from the Main,
And Horns and Hounds awake the Princely Train:
They iue early through the City Gate,
Where the more wakeful Huntmen ready wait,
With Nets, and Toils, and Darts, beide the force
Of Spartan Dogs, and wift Maylian Hore.
The Tyrian Peers, and Officers of State,
For the low Queen, in Anti-Chambers wait:
Her lofty Courer, in the Court below,
(Who his Majetick Rider eems to know,)
Proud of his Purple Trappings, paws the Ground;
And champs the Golden Bitt; and preads the Foam around.
The Queen at length appears: On either Hand
The brawny Guards in Martial Order tand.
A flow'rd Cymarr, with Golden Fringe, he wore;
And at her Back a Golden Quiver bore:
Her flowing Hair, a Golden Caul retrains;
A golden Clap, the Tyrian Robe utains.
Then young Acanius, with a prightly Grace,
Leads on the Trojan Youth to view the Chace.
But far above the ret in beauty hines
The great Aeneas, when the Troop he joins:
Like fair Apollo, when he leaves the frot
Of wintry Xanthus, and the Lycian Coat;
When to his Native Delos he reorts,
Ordains the Dances, and renews the Sports:
Where painted Scythians, mix'd with Cretan Bands,
Before the joyful Altars join their Hands.
Himelf, on Cynthus walking, ees below
The merry Madnes of the acred Show.
Green Wreaths of Bays his length of Hair incloe,
A Golden Fillet binds his awful Brows:
His Quiver ounds: Not les the Prince is een
In manly Preence, or in lofty Meen.
Now had they reach'd the Hills, and torm'd the Seat
Of alvage Beats, in Dens, their lat Retreat;
The Cry purues the Mountain-Goats; they bound
From Rock to Rock, and keep the craggy Ground:

figure.p: To The Right Honble. Hugh Ld Clifford Baron of Chudleigh in ye County of Devon,
figure.head: AE. 4. l. 230.

lg.l: Quite otherwie the Stags, a trembling Train,
In Herds uningl'd, cour the duty Plain;
And a long Chace, in open view, maintain.
The glad Acanius, as his Courer guides,
Spurs through the Vale; and thee and thoe outrides.
His Hores flanks and ides are forc'd to feel
The clanking lah, and goring of the Steel.
Impatiently he views the feeble Prey,
Wihing ome Nobler Beat to cros his way.
And rather wou'd the tusky Boar attend,
Or ee the Lyon from the Hills decend.
Mean time, the gath'ring Clouds obcure the Skies;
From Pole to Pole the forky Lightning flies;
The ratling Thunders rowl; and Juno pours
A wintry Deluge down; and founding Show'rs.
The Company dipers'd, to Coverts ride,
And eek the homely Cotts, or Mountains hollow ide.
The rapid Rains, decending from the Hills,
To rowling Torrents raie the creeping Rills.
The Queen and Prince, as Love or Fortune guides,
One common Cavern in her Boom hides.
Then firt the trembling Earth the ignal gave;
And flahing Fires enlighten all the Cave:
Hell from below, and Juno from above,
And howling Nymphs, were concious to their Love.
From this ill Omend Hour, in Time aroe
Debate and Death, and all ucceeding woes.
The Queen whom ene of Honour cou'd not move
No longer made a Secret of her Love;
But call'd it Marriage, by that pecious Name,
To veil the Crime and anctifie the Shame.
The loud Report through Lybian Cities goes;
Fame, the great Ill, from fmall beginnings grows.
Swift from the firt; and ev'ry Moment brings
New Vigour to her flights, new Pinions to her wings.
Soon grows the Pygmee to Gygantic ize;
Her Feet on Earth, her Forehead in the Skies:
Inrag'd againt the Gods, revengful Earth
Produc'd her lat of the Titanian birth.
Swift is her walk, more wift her winged hat:
A montrous Fantom, horrible and vat;
As many Plumes as raie her lofty flight,
So many piercing Eyes inlarge her ight:
Millions of opening Mouths to Fame belong;
And ev'ry Mouth is furnih'd with a Tongue:
And round with litning Ears the flying Plague is hung.
She fills the peaceful Univere with Cries;
No Slumbers ever cloe her wakeful Eyes.
By Day from lofty Tow'rs her Head he hews;
And preads through trembling Crowds diatrous News.
With Court Informers haunts, and Royal Spies,
Things done relates, not done he feigns; and mingles Truth with Lyes.
Talk is her buines; and her chief delight
To tell of Prodigies, and caue affright.
She fills the Peoples Ears with Dido's Name;
Who, lot to Honour, and the ene of Shame,
Admits into her Throne and Nuptial Bed
A wandring Guet, who from his Country fled:
Whole days with him he paes in delights;
And wats in Luxury long Winter Nights.
Forgetful of her Fame, and Royal Trut;
Diolv'd in Eae, abandon'd to her Lut.
The Goddes widely preads the loud Report;
And flies at length to King Hyarba's Court.
When firt poes'd with this unwelcome News,
Whom did he not of Men and Gods accue!
This Prince, from ravih'd Garamantis born,
A hundred Temples did with Spoils adorn,
In Ammon's Honour, his Coeletial Sire;
A hundred Altars fed, with wakeful Fire:
And through his vat Dominions, Priets ordain'd,
Whoe watchful Care thee holy Rites maintain'd.
The Gates and Columns were with Garlands crown'd,
And Blood of Victim Beats enrich the Ground.
He, when he heard a Fugitive cou'd move
The Tyrian Princes, who didain'd his Love,
His Breat with Fury burn'd, his Eyes with Fire;
Mad with Depair, impatient with Deire.
Then on the Sacred Altars pouring Wine,
He thus with Pray'rs implor'd his Sire divine.
Great Jove, propitious to the Moorih Race,
Who feat on painted Beds, with Off'rings grace
Thy Temples, and adore thy Pow'r Divine
With offer'd Victims, and with parkling Wine:
Seet thou not this? or do we fear in vain
Thy boated Thunder, and thy thoughtles Reign?
Do thy broad Hands the forky Lightnings lance,
Thine are the Bolts, or the blind work of Chance?
A wandring Woman builds, within our State,
A little Town, bought at an eaie Rate;
She pays me Homage, and my Grants allow,
A narrow pace of Lybian Lands to plough.
Yet corning me, by Paion blindly led,
Admits a banih'd Trojan to her Bed:
And now this other Paris, with his Train
Of conquer'd Cowards, mut in Affrick reign!
(Whom, what they are, their Looks and Garb confes;
Their Locks with Oil perfum'd, their Lydian dres:)
He takes the Spoil, enjoys the Princely Dame;
And I, rejected I, adore an empty Name.
His Vows, in haughty Terms, he thus preferr'd,
And held his Altar's Horns; the mighty Thund'rer heard,
Then cat his Eyes on Carthage, where he found
The lutful Pair, in lawles pleaure drown'd.
Lot in their Loves, inenible of Shame;
And both forgetful of their better Fame.
He calls Cyllenius; and the God attends;
By whom his menacing Command he ends.
Go, mount the Wetern Winds, and cleave the Skie;
Then, with a wift decent, to Carthage fly:
There find the Trojan Chief, who wates his Days
In loathful Riot, and inglorious Eae.
Nor minds the future City, giv'n by Fate;
To him this Meage from my Mouth relate.
Not o, fair Venus hop'd, when twice he won
Thy Life with Pray'rs; nor promis'd uch a Son.
Hers was a Heroe, detin'd to command
A Martial Race; and rule the Latian Land.
Who hou'd his ancient Line from Teucer draw;
And, on the conquer'd World, impoe the Law.
If Glory cannot move a Mind o mean,
Nor future Praie, from fading Pleaure wean,
Yet why hou'd he defraud his Son of Fame;
And grudge the Romans their Immortal Name!
What are his vain Deigns! what hopes he more,
From his long ling'ring on a hotile Shore?
Regardles to redeem his Honour lot,
And for his Race to gain th' Auonian Coat!
Bid him with Speed the Tyrian Court forake;
With this Command the lumb'ring Warrior wake.
Hermes obeys; with Golden Pinions binds
His flying Feet, and mounts the Wetern Winds:
And whether o're the Seas or Earth he flies,
With rapid Force, they bear him down the Skies.

figure.p: To John Walkeden of ye. Inner Temple Esq:r
figure.head: AE. 4. l. 230.

lg.l: But firt he graps within his awful Hand,
The mark of Sov'raign Pow'r, his Magick Wand:
With this, he draws the Ghots from hollow Graves,
With this he drives them down the Stygian Waves;
With this he eals in Sleep, the wakeful ight;
And Eyes, though clos'd in Death retores to Light.
Thus arm'd, the God begins his Airy Race;
And drives the racking Clouds along the liquid Space.
Now ees the Tops of Atlas, as he flies;
Whoe brawny Back upports the tarry Skies:
Atlas, whoe Head with Piny Forets crown'd,
Is beaten by the Winds; with foggy Vapours bound.
Snows hide his Shoulders; from beneath his Chin
The Founts of rolling Streams their Race begin:
A beard of Yce on his large Breat depends:
Here pois'd upon his Wings, the God decends.
Then, reted thus, he from the tow'ring height
Plung'd downward, with precipitated Flight:
Lights on the Seas, and skims along the Flood:
As Water-fowl, who eek their fihy Food,
Les, and yet les, to ditant Propect how,
By turns they dance aloft, and dive below:
Like thee, the teerage of his Wings he plies;
And near the urface of the Water flies.
'Till having pas'd the Seas, and cros'd the Sands,
He clos'd his Wings, and toop'd on Lybian Lands:
Where Shepherds once were hous'd in homely Sheds,
Now Tow'rs within the Clouds, advance their Heads.
Arriving there, he found the Trojan Prince,
New Ramparts raiing for the Town's defence:
A Purple Scarf, with Gold embroider'd o're,
(Queen Dido's Gift) about his Wate he wore;
A Sword with glitt'ring Gems diverify'd,
For Ornament, not ue, hung idly by his ide.
Then thus, with winged Words, the God began;
(Reuming his own Shape) degenerate Man,
Thou Woman's Property, what mak't thou here,
Thee foreign Walls, and Tyrian Tow'rs to rear?
Forgetful of thy own? All pow'rful Jove,
Who ways the World below, and Heav'n above,
Has ent me down, with this evere Command:
What means thy ling'ring in the Lybian Land?
If Glory cannot move a Mind o mean,
Nor future Praie, from flitting Pleaure wean,
Regard the Fortunes of thy riing Heir;
The promis'd Crown let young Acanius wear.
To whom th' Auonian Scepter, and the State
Of Rome's Imperial Name, is ow'd by Fate.
So poke the God; and peaking took his flight,
Involv'd in Clouds; and vanih'd out of ight.
The Pious Prince was eiz'd with udden Fear;
Mute was his Tongue, and upright tood his Hair:
Revolving in his Mind the tern Command,
He longs to fly, and loaths the charming Land.
What hou'd he ay, or how hou'd he begin,
What Coure, alas! remains, to teer between
Th' offended Lover, and the Pow'rful Queen!
This way, and that, he turns his anxious Mind,
And all Expedients tries, and none can find:
Fix'd on the Deed, but doubtful of the Means;
After long Thought to this Advice he leans.
Three Chiefs he calls, commands them to repair
The Fleet, and hip their Men with ilent Care:
Some plauible Pretence he bids them find,
To colour what in ecret he deign'd.
Himelf, mean time, the oftet Hours wou'd chue,
Before the Love-ick Lady heard the News.
And move her tender Mind, by low degrees,
To uffer what the Sov'raign Pow'r decrees:
Jove will inpire him, when, and what to ay:
They hear with Pleaure, and with hate obey.
But oon the Queen perceives the thin Diguie;
(What Arts can blind a jealous Woman's Eyes!)
She was the firt to find the ecret Fraud,
Before the fatal News was blaz'd abroad.
Love, the firt Motions of the Lover hears,
Quick to preage, and ev'n in Safety fears.
Nor impious Fame was wanting to report
The Ships repair'd; the Trojans thick Reort,
And purpoe to forake the Tyrian Court.
Frantick with Fear, impatient of the Wound,
And impotent of Mind, he roves the City round.
Les wild the Bacchanalian Dames appear,
When, from afar, their nightly God they hear,
And houl about the Hills, and hake the wreathy Spear.
At length he finds the dear perfidious Man;
Prevents his form'd Excue, and thus began.
Bae and ungrateful, cou'd you hope to fly,
And undiover'd cape a Lover's Eye!
Nor cou'd my Kindnes your Compaion move,
Nor plighted Vows, nor dearer bands of Love!
Or is the Death of a depairing Queen
Not worth preventing, though too well foreeen?
Even when the Wint'ry Winds command your tay,
You dare the Tempets, and defie the Sea.
Fale, as you are, uppoe you were not bound
To Lands unknown, and foreign Coats to found;
Were Troy retor'd, and Priam's happy Reign,
Now durt you tempt for Troy, the raging Main?
See, whom you fly; am I the Foe you hun?
Now by thoe holy Vows, o late begun,
By this right Hand, (ince I have nothing more
To challenge, but the Faith you gave before;)
I beg you by thee Tears too truly hed,
By the new Pleaures of our Nuptial Bed;
If ever Dido, when you mot were kind,
Were pleaing in your Eyes, or touch'd your Mind;
By thee my Pray'rs, if Pray'rs may yet have Place,
Pity the Fortunes of a falling Race.
For you I have provok'd a Tyrant's Hate,
Incens'd the Lybian, and the Tyrian State;
For you alone I uffer in my Fame;
Bereft of Honour, and expos'd to Shame:
Whom have I now to trut, (ungrateful Guet,)
That only Name remains of all the ret!
What have I left, or whither can I fly;
Mut I attend Pygmalion's Cruelty!
Or till Hyarba hall in Triumph lead
A Queen, that proudly corn'd his proffer'd Bed!
Had you deferr'd, at leat, your haty Flight,
And left behind ome Pledge of our delight,
Some Babe to bles the Mother's mournful ight;
Some young Aeneas, to upply your place;
Whoe Features might expres his Father's Face;
I hould not then complain to live bereft
Of all my Husband, or be wholly left.
Here paus'd the Queen; unmov'd he holds his Eyes,
By Jove's Command; nor uffer'd Love to rie,
Tho' heaving in his Heart; and thus at length, replies.
Fair Queen, you never can enough repeat
Your boundles Favours, or I own my Debt:
Nor can my Mind forget Eliza's Name,
While vital Breath inpires this Mortal Frame.
This, only let me peak in my Defence,
I never hop'd a ecret Flight from hence:
Much les pretended to the Lawful Claim
Of Sacred Nuptials, or, a Husband's Name.
For if indulgent Heav'n would leave me free,
And not ubmit my Life to Fate's Decree,
My Choice would lead me to the Trojan Shore,
Thoe Reliques to review, their Dut adore;
And Priam's ruin'd Palace to retore.
But now the Delphian Oracle Commands,
And Fate invites me to the Latian Lands.
That is the promis'd Place to which I teer,
And all my Vows are terminated there.
If you, a Tyrian, and a Stranger born,
With Walls and Tow'rs a Lybian Town adorn;
Why may not we, like you, a Foreign Race,
Like you eek helter in a Foreign Place?
As often as the Night obcures the Skies
With humid Shades, or twinkling Stars arie,
Anchies angry Ghot in Dreams appears;
Chides my delay, and fills my Soul with fears:
And young Acanius jutly may complain,
Of his defrauded Fate, and detin'd Reign.
Ev'n now the Herald of the Gods appear'd,
Waking I aw him, and his Meage heard.
From Jove he came commiion'd, Heav'nly bright
With Radiant Beams, and manifet to Sight.
The Sender and the Sent, I both attet,
Thee Walls he enter'd, and thoe Words expres'd.
Fair Queen, oppoe not what the Gods command;
Forc'd by my Fate, I leave your happy Land.
Thus, while he poke, already She began,
With parkling Eyes, to view the guilty Man:
From Head to Foot urvey'd his Peron o're,
Nor longer thee outrageous Threats forbore.
Fale as thou art, and more than fale, forworn;
Not prung from Noble Blood, nor Goddes-born,
But hewn from hardned Entrails of a Rock;
And rough Hyrcanian Tygers gave thee uck.
Why hou'd I fawn, what have I wore to fear?
Did he once look, or lent a lit'ning Ear;
Sigh'd when I ob'd, or hed one kindly Tear?
All Symptoms of a bae Ungrateful Mind,
So foul, that which is wore, 'tis hard to find.
Of Man's Injutice, why hou'd I complain?
The Gods, and Jove himelf behold in vain
Triumphant Treaon, yet no Thunder flyes:
Nor Juno views my Wrongs with equal Eyes;
Faithles is Earth, and Faithles are the Skies!
Jutice is fled, and Truth is now no more;
I av'd the Shipwrack'd Exile on my Shore:
With needful Food his hungry Trojans fed;
I took the Traytor to my Throne and Bed:
Fool that I was—'tis little to repeat
The ret, I tor'd and Rigg'd his ruin'd Flect.
I rave, I rave: A God's Command he pleads,
And makes Heav'n acceary to his Deeds.
Now Lycian Lotts, and now the Delian God;
Now Hermes is employ'd from Jove's abode,
To warn him hence; as if the peaceful State
Of Heav'nly Pow'rs were touch'd with Humane Fate!
But go; thy flight no longer I detain;
Go eek thy promis'd Kingdom through the Main:
Yet if the Heav'ns will hear my Pious Vow,
The faithles Waves, not half o fale as thou;
Or ecret Sands, hall Sepulchers afford
To thy proud Veels, and their perjur'd Lord.
Then halt thou call on injur'd Dido's Name;

l.U: hall come, in a black Sulph'ry flame;

lg.l: When death has once diolv'd her Mortal frame.
Shall mile to ee the Traitor vainly weep,
Her angry Ghot ariing from the Deep,
Shall haunt thee waking, and diturb thy Sleep.
At leat my Shade thy Punihment hall know;
And Fame hall pread the pleaing News below.
Abruptly here he tops: Then turns away
Her loathing Eyes, and huns the ight of Day.
Amaz'd he tood, revolving in his Mind
What Speech to frame, and what Excue to find.
Her fearful Maids their fainting Mitres led;
And oftly laid her on her Iv'ry Bed.
But good Aeneas, tho' he much deir'd
To give that Pity, which her Grief requir'd,
Tho' much he mourn'd, and labour'd with his Love,
Reolv'd at length, obeys the Will of Jove:
Reviews his Forces; they with early Care
Unmoor their Veels, and for Sea prepare.
The Fleet is oon afloat, in all its Pride:
And well calk'd Gallies in the Harbour ride.
Then Oaks for Oars they fell'd; or as they tood,
Of its green Arms depoil'd the growing Wood.
Studious of Flight: The Beach is cover'd o're
With Trojan Bands that blacken all the Shore:
On ev'ry ide are een, decending down,
Thick warms of Souldiers loaden from the Town.
Thus, in Battalia, march embody'd Ants,
Fearful of Winter, and of future Wants,
T' invade the Corn, and to their Cells convey
The plunder'd Forrage of their yellow Prey.
The able Troops, along the narrow Tracks,
Scarce bear the weighty Burthen on their Backs:
Some et their Shoulders to the pond'rous Grain;
Some guard the Spoil, ome lah the lagging Train;
All ply their ev'ral Tasks, and equal Toil utain.
What Pangs the tender Breat of Dido tore,
When, from the Tow'r, he aw the cover'd Shore,
And heard the Shouts of Sailors from afar,
Mix'd with the Murmurs of the wat'ry War?
All pow'rful Love, what Changes cant thou caue
In Human Hearts, ubjected to thy Laws!
Once more her haughty Soul the Tyrant bends;
To Pray'rs and mean Submiions he decends.
No female Arts or Aids he left untry'd,
Nor Counels unexplor'd, before he dy'd.
Look, Anna, look; the Trojans crowd to Sea,
They pread their Canvas, and their Anchors weigh.
The houting Crew, their Ships with Garlands binds;
Invoke the Sea-Gods, and invite the Winds.
Cou'd I have thought this threatning Blow o near,
My tender Soul had been forewarn'd to bear.
But do not you my lat Requet deny,
With yon perfidious Man your Int'ret try;
And bring me News, if I mut live or dye.
You are his Fav'rite, you alone can find
The dark recees of his inmot Mind:
In all his truted Secrets you have part,
And know the oft Approaches to his Heart.
Hate then, and humbly eek my haughty Foe;
Tell him, I did not with the Grecians goe;
Nor did my Fleet againt his Friends employ,
Nor wore the Ruin of unhappy Troy.
Nor mov'd with Hands prophane his Father's Dut;
Why hou'd he then reject a uit o jut!
Whom does he hun, and whither would he fly;
Can he this lat, this only Pray'r deny!
Let him at leat his dang'rous Flight delay,
Wait better Winds, and hope a calmer Sea.
The Nuptials he diclaims I urge no more;
Let him purue the promis'd Latian Shore.
A hort delay is all I ask him now,
A paue of Grief; an interval from Woe:
'Till my oft Soul be temper'd to utain
Accutom'd Sorrows, and inur'd to Pain.
If you in Pity grant this one Requet,
My Death hall leave you of my Crown poes'd.
This mournful meage, Pious Anna bears,
And econds, with her own, her Siter's Tears:
But all her Arts are till employ'd in vain;
Again he comes, and is refus'd again.
His harden'd Heart nor Pray'rs nor Threatnings move;
Fate, and the God, had top'd his Ears to Love.
As when the Winds their airy Quarrel try;
Jutling from ev'ry quarter of the Sky;
This way and that, the Mountain Oak they bend,
His Boughs they hatter, and his Branches rend;
With Leaves, and falling Mat, they pread the Ground,
The hollow Vallies echo to the Sound:
Unmov'd, the Royal Plant their Fury mocks;
Or haken, clings more cloely to the Rocks:
Far as he hoots his tow'ring Head on high,
So deep in Earth his fix'd Foundations lye.
No les a Storm the Trojan Heroe bears;
Thick Meages and loud Complaints he hears;
And bandy'd Words, till beating on his Ears.
Sighs, Groans and Tears, proclaim his inward Pains,
But the firm purpoe of his Heart remains.
The wretched Queen, puru'd by cruel Fate,
Begins at length the light of Heav'n to hate:
And loaths to live: Then dire Portents he ees,
To haten on the Death her Soul decrees.
Strange to relate: for when before the Shrine
She pours, in Sacrifice, the Purple Wine,
The Purple Wine is turn'd to putrid Blood:
And the white offer'd Milk, converts to Mud.
This dire Preage, to her alone reveal'd,
From all, and ev'n her Siter, he conceal'd.
A Marble Temple tood within the Grove,
Sacred to Death, and to her murther'd Love;
That honour'd Chappel he had hung around
With nowy Fleeces, and with Garlands crown'd:
Oft, when he viited this lonely Dome,
Strange Voices iu'd from her Husband's Tomb:
She thought he heard him ummon her away;
Invite her to his Grave; and chide her tay.
Hourly 'tis heard, when with a bodeing Note
The olitary Screech-Owl trains her Throat:
And on a Chimney's top, or Turret's hight,
With Songs obcene, diturbs the Silence of the Night.
Beides, old Propheies augment her Fears;
And tern Aeneas in her Dreams appears,

l.U: dainful as by Day: She eems alone,

lg.l: To wander in her Sleep, thro ways unknown,
Guidles and dark: or, in a Deart Plain,

l.U: eek her Subjects, and to eek in vain.

lg.l: <…> k Pentheus, when ditracted with his Fear,
He aw two Suns, and double Thebes appear:
Or mad Oretes, when his Mother's Ghot
• ull in his Face, infernal Torches tot;
And hook her naky locks: He huns the ight,
Flies o're the Stage, urpris'd with mortal fright;
The Furies guard the Door; and intercept his flight.
Now, inking underneath a load of Grief,
From Death alone, he eeks her lat Relief:
The Time and Means, reolv'd within her Breat,
She to her mournful Siter, thus addres'd.
(Diembling hope, her cloudy front he clears,
And a fale Vigour in her Eyes appears.)
Rejoice he aid, intructed from above,
My Lover I hall gain, or loe my Love.
Nigh riing Atlas, next the falling Sun,
Long tracts of Ethiopian Clymates run:
There, a Maylian Prietes I have found,
Honour'd for Age; for Magick Arts renown'd:
Th' Heperian Temple was her truted Care;
'Twas he upply'd the wakeful Dragons Fare.
She Poppy-Seeds in Honey taught to teep;
Reclaim'd his Rage; and ooth'd him into leep.
She watch'd the Golden Fruit; her Charms unbind
The Chains of Love; or fix them on the Mind.
She tops the Torrents, leaves the Channel dry;
Repels the Stars; and backward bears the Sky.
The yawning Earth rebellows to her Call;
Pale Ghots acend; and Mountain Ahes fall.
Witnes, ye Gods, and thou my better part,
How loth I am to try this impious Art!
Within the ecret Court, with ilent Care,
Erect a lofty Pile, expos'd in Air:
Hang on the topmot part, the Trojan Vet;
Spoils, Arms, and Preents of my faithles Guet.
Next, under thee, the bridal Bed be plac'd,
Where I my Ruin in his Arms embrac'd:
All Relicks of the Wretch are doom'd to Fire;
For o the Prietes, and her Charms require.
Thus far he aid, and farther Speech forbears:
A Mortal Palenes in her Face appears:
Yet, the mitrutles Anna, could not find
The ecret Fun'ral, in thee Rites deign'd;
Nor thought o dire a Rage poes'd her Mind.
Unknowing of a Train conceal'd o well,
She fear'd no wore than when Sichaeus fell:
Therefore obeys. The fatal Pile they rear,
Within the ecret Court, expos'd in Air.
The cloven Holms and Pines are heap'd on high;
And Garlands on the hollow Spaces lye.
Sad Cypres, Vervain, Eugh, compoe the Wreath;
And ev'ry baleful green denoting Death.
The Queen, determin'd to the fatal Deed,
The Spoils and Sword he left, in order pread:
And the Man's Image on the Nuptial Bed.
And now (the acred Altars plac'd around)
The Prietes enters, with her Hair unbound,
And thrice invokes the Pow'rs below the Ground.
Night, Erebus, and Chaos he proclaims,
And threefold Hecat, with her hundred Names,
And three Diana's: next he prinkles round,
With feign'd Avernian Drops, the hallow'd ground;
Culls hoary Simples, found by Phoebe's Light,
With brazen Sickles reap'd at Noon of Night.
Then mixes baleful Juices in the Bowl:
And cuts the Forehead of a new-born Fole;
Robbing the Mother's love. The detin'd Queen
Oberves, aiting at the Rites obcene:
A leaven'd Cake in her devoted Hands
She holds, and next the highet Altar tands:
One tender Foot was hod, her other bare;
Girt was her gather'd Gown, and looe her Hair.
Thus dres'd, he ummon'd with her dying Breath,
The Heav'ns and Planets concious of her Death:
And ev'ry Pow'r, if any rules above,
Who minds, or who revenges injur'd Love.
'Twas dead of Night, when weary Bodies cloe
Their Eyes in balmy Sleep, and oft Repoe:

figure.p: To Henry Tasburgh Esq of Bodney in ye County of Norfolk.
figure.head: AE. 4. l. 730.

lg.l: The Winds no longer whiper through the Woods,
Nor murm'ring Tides diturb the gentle Floods.
The Stars in ilent order mov'd around,
And Peace, with downy wings, was brooding on the ground.
The Flocks and Herds, and parti-colour'd Fowl,
Which haunt the Woods, or wim the weedy Pool;
Stretch'd on the quiet Earth ecurely lay,
Forgetting the pat Labours of the day.
All ele of Nature's common Gift partake;
Unhappy Dido was alone awake.
Nor Sleep nor Eae the Furious Queen can find,
Sleep fled her Eyes, as Quiet fled her mind.
Depair, and Rage, and Love, divide her heart;
Depair and Rage had ome, but Love the greater part.
Then thus he aid within her ecret Mind:
What hall I do, what Succour can I find!
Become a Supplyant to Hyarba's Pride,
And take my turn, to Court and be deny'd!
Shall I with this ungrateful Trojan go,
Forake an Empire, and attend a Foe?
Himelf I refug'd, and his Train reliev'd;
Tis true; but am I ure to be receiv'd?
An Exile follows whom a Queen reliev'd!
Can Gratitude in Trojan Souls have place!

l.U: till lives in all his Race!

lg.l: Then, hall I eek alone the Churlih Crew,
Or with my Fleet their flying Sails purue?
What force have I but thoe, whom carce before
I drew reluctant from their Native Shore?
Will they again Embark at my deire,
Once more utain the Seas, and quit their econd Tyre?
Rather with Steel thy guilty Breat invade,
And take the Fortune thou thy elf hat made.
Your pity, Siter, firt educ'd my Mind;
Or econded too well, what I deign'd.
Thee dear-bought Pleaures had I never known,
Had I continu'd free, and till my own;
Avoiding Love; I had not found Depair:
But har'd with Salvage Beats the Common Air.
Like them a lonely life I might have led,
Not mourn'd the Living, nor diturb'd the Dead.
Thee Thoughts he brooded in her anxious Breat;
On Boord, the Trojan found more eaie ret.
Reolv'd to ail, in Sleep he pas'd the Night;
And order'd all things for his early flight.
To whom once more the winged God appears;
His former Youthful Meen and Shape he wears,
And with this new alarm invades his Ears.
Sleep't thou, O Goddes born! and can't thou drown
Thy needful Cares, o near a Hotile Town?
Beet with Foes; nor hear't the Wetern Gales
Invite thy paage, and Inpire thy ails?
She harbours in her Heart a furious hate;
And thou halt find the dire Effects too late;
Fix'd on Revenge, and Obtinate to die:
Hate wiftly hence, while thou hat pow'r to fly.
The Sea with Ships will oon be cover'd o're,
And blazing Firebrands kindle all the Shore.
Prevent her rage, while Night obcures the Skies;
And ail before the purple Morn arie.
Who knows what Hazards thy Delay may bring?
Woman's a various and a changeful Thing.
Thus Hermes in the Dream; then took his flight,
Aloft in Air uneen; and mix'd with Night.
Twice warn'd by the Coeletial Meenger,
The pious Pious aroe with haty fear:
Then rowz'd his drowie Train without delay,
Hate to your banks; your crooked Anchors weigh;
And pread your flying Sails, and tand to Sea.
A God commands; he tood before my ight;
And urg'd us once again to peedy flight.
O acred Pow'r, what Pow'r o e're thou art,
To thy bles'd Orders I reign my heart:
Lead thou the way; protect thy Trojan Bands;
And proper the Deign thy Will Commands.
He aid, and drawing forth his flaming Sword,
His thund'ring Arm divides the many twited Cord:
An emulating Zeal inpires his Train;
They run, they natch; they ruh into the main.
With headlong hate they leave the deert Shores,
And bruh the liquid Seas with lab'ring Oars.
Aurora now had left her Saffron Bed,
And beams of early Light the Heav'ns o'repread,
When from a Tow'r the Queen, with wakeful Eyes,
Saw Day point upward from the roie Skies:
She look'd to Seaward, but the Sea was void,
And carce in ken the ailing Ships decry'd:
Stung with depight, and furious with depair,
She truck her trembling Breat, and tore her Hair.
And hall th' ungrateful Traytor go, he aid,
My Land foraken, and my Love betray'd?
Shall we not Arm, not ruh from ev'ry Street,
To follow, ink, and burn his perjur'd Fleet?
Hate, haul my Gallies out, purue the Foe:
Bring flaming Brands, et ail, and wiftly row.
What have I aid? where am I? Fury turns
My Brain; and my ditemper'd Boom burns.
Then, when I gave my Peron and my Throne,
This Hate, this Rage, had been more timely hown.
See now the promis'd Faith, the vaunted Name,
The Pious Man, who, ruhing through the Flame,
Preerv'd his Gods; and to the Phrygian Shore
The Burthen of his feeble Father bore!
I hou'd have torn him piecemeal; trow'd in Floods
His catter'd Limbs, or left expos'd in Woods:
Detroy'd his Friends and Son; and from the Fire
Have et the reeking Boy before the Sire.
Events are doubtful, which on Battels wait;
Yet where's the doubt, to Souls ecure of Fate!
My Tyrians, at their injur'd Queen's Command,
Had tos'd their Fires amid the Trojan Band:
At once extinguih'd all the faithles Name;
And I my elf, in vengeance of my Shame,
Had fall'n upon the Pile to mend the Fun'ral Flame.
Thou Sun, who view't at once the World below,
Thou Juno, Guardian of the Nuptial Vow,
Thou Hecat, hearken from thy dark abodes;
Ye Furies, Fiends, and violated Gods,
All Pow'rs invok'd with Dido's dying breath,
Attend her Cures, and avenge her death.
If o the Fates ordain, and Jove commands,
Th' ungrateful Wretch hould find the Latian Lands,
Yet let a Race untam'd, and haughty Foes,
His peaceful Entrance with dire Arms oppoe;
Oppres'd with Numbers in th' unequal Field,
His Men dicourag'd, and himelf expell'd,
Let him for Succour ue from place to place,
Torn from his Subjects, and his Son's embrace:
Firt let him ee his Friends in Battel lain;
And their untimely Fate lament in vain:
And when, at length, the cruell War hall ceae;
On hard Conditions may he buy his Peace.
Nor let him then enjoy upreme Command;
But fall untimely, by ome hotile Hand:
And lye unbury'd on the barren Sand.
Thee are my Pray'rs, and this my dying Will:
And you my Tyrians ev'ry Cure fulfill.
Perpetual Hate, and mortal Wars proclaim,
Againt the Prince, the People, and the Name.
Thee grateful Off'rings on my Grave betow;
Nor League, nor Love, the jarring Nations know:
Now, and from hence in ev'ry future Age,
When Rage excites your Arms, and Strength upplies the Rage:
Rie ome Avenger of our Lybian Blood,
With Fire and Sword purue the perjur'd Brood:
Our Arms, our Seas, our Shores, oppos'd to theirs,
And the ame hate decend on all our Heirs.
This aid, within her anxious Mind he weighs
The Means of cutting hort her odious Days.
Then to Sicheus's Nure, he briefly aid,
(For when he left her Country, hers was dead)
Go Barcè, call my Siter; let her Care
The olemn Rites of Sacrifice prepare:
The Sheep, and all th' attoneing Off'rings bring;
Sprinkling her Body from the Crytal Spring
With living Drops: then let her come, and thou
With acred Fillets, bind thy hoary Brow.
Thus will I pay my Vows, to Stygian Jove;
And end the Cares of my diatrous Love.
Then cat the Trojan Image on the Fire;
And as that burns, my Paion hall expire.
The Nure moves onward, with officious Care,
And all the peed her aged Limbs can bear.
But furious Dido, with dark Thoughts involv'd,
Shook at the mighty Michief he reolv'd.
With livid Spots ditinguih'd was her Face,
Red were her rowling Eyes, and dicompos'd her Pace:
Ghatly he gaz'd, with Pain he drew her Breath,
And Nature hiver'd at approaching Death.
Then wiftly to the fatal place he pas'd;
And mounts the Fun'ral Pile, with furious hate.
Unheaths the Sword the Trojan left behind,
(Not for o dire an Enterprie deign'd,)
But when he view'd the Garments looely pred,
Which once he wore, and aw the concious Bed,
She paus'd, and, with a Sigh, the Robes embrac'd;
Then on the Couch her trembling Body cat,
Repres'd the ready Tears, and poke her lat.
Dear Pledges of my Love, while Heav'n o pleas'd,
Receive a Soul, of Mortal Anguih eas'd:
My fatal Coure is finih'd; and I go
A glorious Name, among the Ghots below.
A lofty City by my Hands is rais'd;
Pygmalion punih'd, and my Lord appeas'd.
What cou'd my Fortune have afforded more,
Had the fale Trojan never touch'd my Shore!
Then kis'd the Couch; and mut I die, he aid;
And unreveng'd; 'tis doubly to be dead!
Yet ev'n this Death with Pleaure I receive;
On any Terms, 'tis better than to live.
Thee Flames, from far, may the fale Trojan view;
Thee boding Omens his bae flight purue.
She aid, and truck: Deep enter'd in her ide
The piercing Steel, with reeking Purple dy'd:
Clog'd in the Wound the cruel Weapon tands;
The pouting Blood came treaming on her Hands.
Her ad Attendants aw the deadly Stroke,
And with loud Cries the ounding Palace hook.
Ditracted from the fatal ight they fled;
And thro the Town the dimal Rumor pread.
Firt from the frighted Court, the Yell began,
Redoubled thence from Houe to Houe it ran:
The groans of Men, with Shrieks, Laments, and Cries
Of mixing Women, mount the vaulted Skies.
Not les the Clamour, than if ancient Tyre,
Or the new Carthage, et by Foes on Fire,
The rowling Ruin, with their lov'd Abodes,
Involv'd the blazing Temples of their Gods.
Her Siter hears, and, furious with Depair,
She beats her Breat, and rends her yellow Hair:
And calling on Eliza's Name aloud,
Runs breathles to the Place, and breaks the Crowd.
Was all that Pomp of Woe for this prepar'd,
Thee Fires, this Fun'ral Pile, thee Altars rear'd;
Was all this Train of Plots contriv'd, aid he,
All only to deceive unhappy me?
Which is the wort, didt thou in Death pretend
To corn thy Siter, or delude thy Friend!
Thy ummon'd Siter, and thy Friend had come:
One Sword had erv'd us both, one common Tomb.
Was I to raie the Pile, the Pow'rs invoke,
Not to be preent at the fatal Stroke?
At once thou hat detroy'd thy elf and me;
Thy Town, thy Senate, and thy Colony!
Bring Water, bathe the Wound; while I in death
Lay cloe my Lips to hers; and catch the flying Breath.
This aid, he mounts the Pile with eager hate;
And in her Arms the gaping Queen embrac'd:
Her Temples chaf'd; and her own Garments tore
To tanch the treaming Blood, and cleane the Gore.
Thrice Dido try'd to raie her drooping Head,
And fainting thrice, fell grov'ling on the Bed.
Thrice op'd her heavy Eyes, and ought the Light,
But having found it, icken'd at the ight;
And clos'd her Lids at lat, in endles Night.
Then Juno, grieving that he hou'd utain
A Death o ling'ring, and o full of Pain;
Sent Iris down, to free her from the Strife
Of lab'ring Nature, and diolve her Life.
For ince he dy'd, not doom'd by Heav'ns Decree,
Or her own Crime; but Human Caualty;
And rage of Love, that plung'd her in Depair,
The Siters had not cut the topmot Hair;
Which Proerpine, and they can only know;
Nor made her acred to the Shades below.
Downward the various Goodes took her flight;
And drew a thouand Colours from the Light:
Then tood above the dying Lover's Head,
And aid, I thus devote thee to the dead.
This Off'ring to the Infernal Gods I bear:
Thus while he poke, he cut the fatal Hair;
The trugling Soul was loos'd; and Life diolv'd in Air.

div.head: The Fifth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Aeneas etting ail from Africk, is driven by a Storm on the Coats of Sicily: Where he is hopitably receiv'd by his friend Acetes, King of part of the Iland, and born of Trojan Parentage. He applies himelf to celebrate the Memory of his Father with Divine Honours: And accordingly intitutes Funeral Games, and appoints Prizes for thoe who hou'd conquer in them. While the Ceremonies were performing, Juno ends Iris to perwade the Trojan Women to burn the Ships, who upon her intigation et fire to them, which burnt four, and would have conum'd the ret, had not Jupiter by a miraculous Shower extinguih'd it. Upon this Aeneas by the advice of one of his Generals, and a Viion of his Father, builds a City for the Women, Old Men, and others, who were either unfit for War, or weary of the Voyage, and ails for Italy: Venus procures of Neptune a afe Voyage for him and all his Men, excepting only his Pilot Palinurus, who was unfortunately lot.

figure.p: To the most Illustrious Prince Charles Duke of St Albans Master Falconer to his Maty. and Captaine of ye Honble. Band of Gent Pensioners
figure.head: AE. 5. l. 2.

lg.l: MEan time the Trojan cuts his wat'ry way,
Fix'd on his Voyage, thro the curling Sea:
Then, cating back his Eyes, with dire Amaze,
Sees on the Punic Shore the mounting Blaze.
The Caue unknown; yet his preaging Mind,
The Fate of Dido from the Fire divin'd:
He knew the tormy Souls of Woman-kind:
What ecret Springs their eager Paions move,
How capable of Death for injur'd Love.
Dire Auguries from hence the Trojans draw;
'Till neither Fires, nor hining Shores they aw.
Now Seas and Skies, their Propect only bound;
An empty pace above, a floating Field around.
But oon the Heav'ns with hadows were o'repread;
A welling Cloud hung hov'ring o're their Head:
Livid it look'd, (the threatning of a Storm;)
Then Night and Horror Ocean's Face deform.
The Pilot, Palinurus, cry'd aloud,
What Guts of Weather from that gath'ring Cloud
My Thoughts preage; e're yet the Tempet roars,
Stand to your Tackle, Mates, and tretch your Oars;
Contract your welling Sails, and luff to Wind:
The frighted Crew perform the Task aign'd.
Then, to his fearles Chief, not Heav'n, aid he,
Tho Jove himelf hou'd promie Italy,
Can tem the Torrent of this raging Sea.
Mark how the hifting Winds from Wet arie,
And what collected Night involves the Skies!
Nor can our haken Veels live at Sea,
Much les againt the Tempet force their way;
'Tis Fate diverts our Coure; and Fate we mut obey.
Not far from hence, if I oberv'd aright
The outhing of the Stars, and Polar Light,
Sicilia lies; whoe hopitable Shores
In afety we may reach with trugling Oars.
Aeneas then reply'd, too ure I find,
We trive in vain againt the Seas, and Wind:
Now hift your Sails: What place can pleae me more
Than what you promie, the Sicilian Shore;
Whoe hallow'd Earth Anchies Bones contains,
And where a Prince of Trojan Lineage reigns?
The Coure reolv'd, before the Wetern Wind
They cud amain; and make the Port aign'd.
Mean time Acetes, from a lofty Stand,
Beheld the Fleet decending on the Land;
And not unmindful of his ancient Race,
Down from the Cliff he ran with eager Pace;
And held the Heroe in a trict Embrace.
Of a rough Lybian Bear the Spoils he wore;
And either Hand a pointed Jav'lin bore.
His Mother was a Dame of Dardan Blood;
His Sire Crinius, a Sicilian Flood;
He welcomes his returning Friends ahore
With plenteous Country Cates; and homely Store.
Now, when the following Morn had chas'd away
The flying Stars, and light retor'd the Day,
Aeneas call'd the Trojan Troops around;
And thus bepoke them from a riing Ground.
Off-pring of Heav'n, Divine Dardanian Race,
The Sun revolving thro' th' Etherial Space,
The hining Circle of the Year has fill'd,
Since firt this Ile my Father's Ahes held:
And now the riing Day renews the Year,
(A Day for ever ad, for ever dear,)
This wou'd I celebrate with Annual Games,
With Gifts on Altars pil'd, and holy Flames,
Tho banih'd to Getulia's barren Sands,
Caught on the Grecian Seas, or hotile Lands:
But ince this happy Storm our Fleet has driv'n,
(Not, as I deem, without the Will of Heav'n,)
Upon thee friendly Shores, and flow'ry Plains,
Which hide Anchies, and his blet Remains;
Let us with Joy perform his Honours due;
And pray for prop'rous Winds, our Voyage to renew.
Pray, that in Towns, and Temples of our own,
The Name of great Anchies may be known;
And yearly Games may pread the Gods renown.
Our Sports, Acetes of the Trojan Race,
With royal Gifts, ordain'd, is pleas'd to grace:
Two Steers on ev'ry Ship the King betows;
His Gods and ours, hall hare your equal Vows.
Beides, if nine days hence, the roy Morn
Shall with unclouded Light the Skies adorn,
That Day with olemn Sports I mean to grace;
Light Gallies on the Seas, hall run a wat'ry Race.
Some hall in Swiftnes for the Goal contend,
And others try the twanging Bow to bend:
The trong with Iron Gauntlets arm'd hall tand,
Oppos'd in Combat on the yellow Sand.
Let all be preent at the Games prepar'd;
And joyful Victors wait the Jut Reward.
But now ait the Rites, with Garlands crown'd;
He aid, and firt his Brows with Myrtle bound.
Then Helymus, by his Example led,
And old Acetes, each adorn'd his Head;
Thus, young Acanius, with a prightly Grace,
His Temples ty'd, and all the Trojan Race.
Aeneas then advanc'd amidt the Train,
By thouands follow'd thro' the fruitful Plain,
To great Anchies Tomb: Which when he found,
He pour'd to Bacchus, on the hallow'd Ground,
Two Bowls of parkling Wine, of Milk two more,
And two from offer'd Bulls of Purple Gore.
With Roes then the Sepulchre he trow'd;
And thus, his Father's Ghot bepoke aloud.
Hail, O ye Holy Manes; hail again
Paternal Ahes, now review'd in vain!
The Gods permitted not, that you, with me,
Shou'd reach the promis'd Shores of Italy;
Or Tiber's Flood, what Flood o e're it be.
Scarce had he finih'd, when, with peckled Pride,
A Serpent from the Tomb began to glide;
His hugy Bulk on ev'n high Volumes roll'd;
Blue was his breadth of Back, but treak'd with caly Gold:
Thus riding on his Curls, he eem'd to pas
A rowling Fire along; and inge the Gras.
More various Colours thro' his Body run,
Than Iris when her Bow imbibes the Sun;
Betwixt the riing Altars, and around,
The acred Monter hot along the Ground;
With harmles play amidt the Bowls he pas'd;
And with his lolling Tongue aay'd the Tate:
Thus fed with Holy Food, the wond'rous Guet
Within the hollow Tomb retir'd to ret.
The Pious Prince, urpri • 'd at what he view'd,
The Fun'ral Honours with more Zeal renew'd:
Doubtful if this the Place's Genius were,
Or Guardian of his Father's Sepulchre.
Five Sheep, according to the Rites, he lew;
As many Swine, and Steers of able Hue;
New gen'rous Wine he from the Goblets pour'd,
And call'd his Fathers Ghot, from Hell retor'd.
The glad Attendants in long Order come,
Off'ring their Gifts at great Anchies Tomb:
Some add more Oxen, ome divide the Spoil,
Some place the Chargers on the gray Soil;
Some blow the Fires and offer'd Entrails broil.
Now came the Day deir'd; the Skies were bright
With roy Lutre of the riing Light:
The bord'ring People, rowz'd by ounding Fame
Of Trojan Feats, and great Acetes Name;
The crowded Shore with Acclamations fill,
Part to behold, and part to prove their Skill.
And firt the Gifts in Publick view they place,
Green Lawrel Wreaths, and Palm, (the Victors grace:)
Within the Circle, Arms and Tripods lye;
Ingotts of Gold, and Silver, heap'd on high;
And Vets embroider'd of the Tyrian dye.
The Trumpet's clangor then the Feat proclaims;
And all prepare for their appointed Games.
Four Gallies firt, which equal Rowers bear,
Advancing, in the wat'ry Lits appear.
The peedy Dolphin, that out-trips the Wind,
Bore Mnetheus, Author of the Memmian kind:
Gyas, the vat Chymaera's Bulk commands,
Which riing like a tow'ring City tands:
Three Trojans tug at ev'ry lab'ring Oar;
Three Banks in three degrees the Sailors bore;
Beneath their turdy Stroaks the Billows roar.
Sergethus, who began the Sergian Race,
In the great Centaur took the leading Place:
Cloanthus on the Sea-green Scylla tood;
From whom Cluentius draws his Trojan Blood.
Far in the Sea, againt the foaming Shoar,
There tands a Rock; the raging Billows roar
Above his Head in Storms; but when 'tis clear,
Uncurl their ridgy Backs, and at his Foot appear.
In Peace below the gentle Waters run;
The Cormorants above, lye basking in the Sun.
On this the Heroe fix'd an Oak in ight,
The mark to guide the Mariners aright.
To bear with this, the Seamen tretch their Oars;
Then round the Rock they teer, and eek the former Shoars.
The Lots decide their place; above the ret,
Each Leader hining in his Tyrian Vet:
The common Crew, with Wreaths of Poplar Boughs.
Their Temples crown, and hade their weaty Brows.
Bemear'd with Oil, their naked Shoulders hine;
All take their Seats, and wait the ounding ign.
They gripe their Oars, and ev'ry panting Breat
Is rais'd by turns with Hope, by turns with Fear depres'd.

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Arthur Herbert Earle of Torrington & Baron of Torbay
figure.head: AE 5 l: 160

lg.l: The clangor of the Trumpet gives the Sign;
At once they tart, advancing in a Line:
With houts the Sailors rend the tarry Skys,
Lah'd with their Oars, the moaky Billows rie;
Sparkles the briny Main, and the vex'd Ocean fries.
Exact in time, with equal Strokes they row;
At once the bruhing Oars, and brazen prow
Dah up the andy Waves, and ope the Depths below.
Not fiery Courers, in a Chariot Race,
Invade the Field with half o wift a Pace.
Not the fierce Driver with more Fury lends
The ounding Lah; and, e're the Stroke decends,
Low to the Wheels his pliant Body bends.
The partial Crowd their Hopes and Fears divide;
And aid, with eager houts, the favour'd Side.
Cries, Murmurs, Clamours, with a mixing Sound,
From Woods to Woods, from Hills to Hills rebound.
Amidt the loud Applaues of the Shore,
Gyas outtrip'd the ret, and prung before;
Cloanthus, better mann'd, puru'd him fat;
But his o're-mated Gally check'd his Hate.
The Centaur, and the Dolphin, bruh the brine
With equal Oars, advancing in a Line:
And now the mighty Centaur eems to lead,
And now the peedy Dolphin gets a head:
Now Board to Board the rival Veels row;
The Billows lave the Skies, and Ocean groans below.
They reach'd the Mark; proud Gyas and his Train,
In Triumph rode the Victors of the Main:
But teering round, he charg'd his Pilot tand
More cloe to Shore, and skim along the Sand.
Let others bear to Sea. Menaetes heard,
But ecret helves too cautiouly he fear'd:
And fearing, ought the Deep; and till aloof he teer'd.
With louder Cries the Captain call'd again;
Bear to the rocky Shore, and hun the Main.
He poke, and peaking at his tern he aw
The bold Cloanthus near the Shelvings draw;
Betwixt the mark and him the Scylla tood,
And in a cloer Compas plow'd the Flood,
He pas'd the Mark; and wheeling got before;
Gyas blaphem'd the Gods, devoutly wore,
Cry'd out for Anger, and his Hair he tore.
Mindles of others Lives, (o high was grown
His riing Rage,) and careles of his own:
The trembling Dotard to the Deck he drew,
Then hoited up, and over-board he threw,
This done he eiz'd the Helm; his Fellows cheer'd;
Turn'd hort upon the Shelfs, and madly teer'd.
Hardly his Head, the plunging Pilot rears,
Clog'd with his Cloaths, and cumber'd with his Years:
Now dropping wet, he climbs the Cliff with Pain;
The Crowd that aw him fall, and float again,
Shout from the ditant Shore; and loudly laught,
To ee his heaving Breat digorge the briny Draught.
The following Centaur, and the Dolphin's Crew,
Their vanih'd hopes of Victory renew:
While Gyas lags, they kindle in the Race,
To reach the Mark; Sergethus takes the place:
Mnetheus purues; and while around they wind,
Comes up, not half his Gally's length behind.
Then, on the Deck amidt his Mates appear'd,
And thus their drooping Courages he cheer'd.
My Friends, and Hector's Followers heretofore;
Exert your Vigour, tug the lab'ring Oar;
Stretch to your Stroaks, my till unconquer'd Crew,
Whom from the flaming Walls of Troy I drew.
In this, our common Int'ret, let me find
That trength of Hand, that courage of the Mind,
As when you tem'd the trong Malaean Flood,
And o're the Syrtes broken Billows row'd.
I eek not now the foremot Palm to gain;
Tho yet—But ah, that haughty Wih is vain!
Let thoe enjoy it whom the Gods ordain.
But to be lat, the Lags of all the Race,
Redeem your elves and me from that Digrace.
Now one and all, they tug amain; they row
At the full tretch, and hake the Brazen Prow.
The Sea beneath 'em inks; their lab'ring ides
Are well'd, and Sweat runs gutt'ring down in Tides.
Chance aids their daring with unhop'd Succes;
Sergethus, eager with his Beak, to pres
Betwixt the Rival Gally and the Rock;
Shuts up th' unwieldy Centaur in the Lock.
The Veel truck, and with the dreadful hock
Her Oars he hiver'd, and her Head he broke.
The trembling Rowers from their Banks arie,
And anxious for themelves renounce the Prize.
With Iron Poles they heave her off the Shores;
And gather, from the Sea, their floating Oars.
The Crew of Mnetheus, with elated Minds,
Urge their Succes, and call the willing Winds:
Then ply their Oars, and cut their liquid way;
In larger Compas on the roomy Sea.
As when the Dove her Rocky Hold forakes,
Rowz'd in a Fright, her ounding Wings he hakes
The Cavern rings with clatt'ring; out he flies,
And leaves her Callow Care, and cleaves the Skies;
At firt he flutters; but at length he prings,
To moother flight, and hoots upon her Wings:
So Mnetheus in the Dolphin cuts the Sea,
And flying with a force, that force aits his Way.
Sergethus in the Centaur oon he pas'd,
Wedg'd in the Rocky Sholes, and ticking fat.
In vain the Victor he with Cries implores,
And practices to row with hatter'd Oars.
Then Mnetheus bears with Gyas, and out-flies:
The Ship without a Pilot yields the Prize.
Unvanquih'd Scylla now alone remains;
Her he purues; and all his vigour trains.
Shouts from the fav'ring Multitude arie,
Applauding Echo to the Shouts replies;
Shouts, Wihes, and Applaue run ratling through the Skies.
Thee Clamours with didain the Scylla heard;
Much grudg'd the Praie, but more the rob'd Reward:
Reolv'd to hold their own, they mend their pace;
All obtinate to dye, or gain the Race.
Rais'd with Succes, the Dolphin witly ran,
(For they can Conquer who believe they can:)
Both urge their Oars, and Fortune both upplies;
And both, perhaps had har'd an equal Prize;
When to the Seas Cloanthus holds his Hands,
And Succour from the Watry Pow'rs Demands:
Gods of the liquid Realms, on which I row,
If giv'n by you, the Lawrel bind my Brow,
Ait to make me guilty of my Vow.
A Snow-white Bull hall on your Shore be lain,
His offer'd Entrails cat into the Main;
And ruddy Wine from Golden Goblets thrown,
Your grateful Gift and my Return hall own.
The Quire of Nymphs, and Phorcus from below,
With Virgin Panopea, heard his Vow;
And old Portunus, with his breadth of Hand,
Puh'd on, and ped the Gally to the Land.
Swift as a Shaft, or winged Wind, he flies;
And darting to the Port, obtains the Prize.
The Herald ummons all, and then proclaims
Cloanthus Conqu'ror of the Naval Games.
The Prince with Lawrel crowns the Victor's Head,
And three fat Steers are to his Veel led;
The Ships Reward: with gen'rous Wine beide;
And Sums of Silver, which the Crew divide.
The Leaders are ditinguih'd from the ret;
The Victor honour'd with a nobler Vet:
Where Gold and Purple trive in equal Rows;
And Needle-work its happy Cot betows.
There, Ganymede is wrought with living Art,
Chaing thro' Ida's Groves the trembling Hart:
Breathles he eems, yet eager to purue;
When from aloft, decends in open view,
The Bird of Jove; and owing on his Prey,
With crooked Tallons bears the Boy away.
In vain, with lifted Hands, and gazing Eyes,
His Guards behold him oaring thro' the Skies;
And Dogs purue his Flight, with imitated Cries.
Mnetheus the econd Victor was declar'd;
And ummon'd there, the econd Prize he har'd.
A Coat of Mail, which brave Demoleus bore;
More brave Aeneas from his Shoulders tore;
In ingle Combat on the Trojan Shore.
This was ordain'd for Mnetheus to poes;
In War for his Defence; for Ornament in Peace.
Rich was the Gift, and glorious to behold;
But yet o pond'rous with its Plates of Gold,
That carce two Servants cou'd the Weight utain;
Yet, loaded thus, Demoleus o're the Plain
Puru'd, and lightly eiz'd the Trojan Train.
The Third ucceeding to the lat Reward,
Two goodly Bowls of May Silver har'd;
With Figures prominent, and richly wrought:
And two Bras Caldrons from Dodona brought.
Thus, all rewarded by the Heroe's hands,
Their conqu'ring Temples bound with Purple Bands.
And now Sergethus, clearing from the Rock,
Brought back his Gally hatter'd with the hock.
Forlorn he look'd, without an aiding Oar;
And howted, by the Vulgar, made to Shoar.
As when a Snake, urpris'd upon the Road,
Is cruh'd athwart her Body by the load
Of heavy Wheels; or with a Mortal Wound
Her Belly bruis'd, and trodden to the Ground:
In vain, with looen'd curls, he crawls along,
Yet fierce above, he brandihes her Tongue:
Glares with her Eyes, and britles with her Scales,
But groveling in the Dut, her parts unound he trails.
So lowly to the Port the Centaur tends,
But what he wants in Oars, with Sails amends:
Yet, for his Gally av'd, the grateful Prince,
Is pleas'd th' unhappy Chief to recompence.
Pholoe, the Cretan Slave, rewards his Care,
Beauteous her elf, with lovely Twins, as fair.
From thence his way the Trojan Heroe bent,
Into the neighb'ring Plain, with Mountains pent;
Whoe ides were haded with urrounding Wood:
Full in the midt of this fair Vally tood
A Native Theatre, which riing flow,
By jut degrees, o're-look'd the Ground below.
High on a Sylvan Throne the Leader ate;
A num'rous Train attend in Solemn State;
Here thoe, that in the rapid Coure delight,
Deire of Honour, and the Prize invite.
The Rival Runners, without Order tand,
The Trojans, mix'd with the Sicilian Band.
Firt Nius, with Euryalus, appears,
Euryalus a Boy of blooming Years;
With prightly Grace, and equal Beauty crown'd:
Nius, for Friendhip to the Youth, renown'd.
Diores, next, of Priam's Royal Race,
Then Salius, join'd with Patron took their Place:
But Patron in Arcadia had his Birth,
And Salius his, from Acarnanian Earth.
Then two Sicilian Youths, the Names of thee
Swift Helymus, and lovely Panopes:
Both jolly Huntmen, both in Forets bred,
And owning old Acetes for their Head.
With ev'ral others of Ignobler Name;
Whom Time has not deliver'd o're to Fame.
To thee the Heroe thus his Thoughts explain'd,
In Words, which gen'ral Approbation gain'd.
One common Larges is for all deign'd:
The Vanquih'd and the Victor hall be join'd.
Two Darts of polih'd Steel, and Gnoian Wood,
A Silver'd tudded Ax alike betow'd.
The foremot three have Olive Wreaths decreed;
The firt of thee obtains a tately Steed
Adorn'd with Trappings; and the next in Fame,
The Quiver of an Amazonian Dame;
With feather'd Thracian Arrows well upply'd,
A Golden Belt hall gird his Manly ide;
Which with a parkling Diamond hall be ty'd:
The third this Grecian Helmet hall content.
He aid; to their appointed Bae they went:
With beating Hearts th' expected Sign receive,
And, tarting all at once, the Barrier leave.
Spread out, as on the winged Winds, they flew,
And eiz'd the ditant Goal with greedy view.
Shot from the Crowd, wift Nius all o're-pas'd;
Nor Storms, nor Thunder, equal half his hate.
The next, but tho' the next, yet far di-join'd,
Came Salius, and Euryalus behind;
Then Helymus, whom young Diores ply'd,
Step after tep, and almot ide by ide:
His Shoulders preing, and in longer Space,
Had won, or left at leat a dubious Race.
Now pent, the Goal they almot reach at lat;
When eager Nius, haples in his hate,
Slip'd firt, and lipping, fell upon the Plain,
Soak'd with the Blood of Oxen, newly lain:
The careles Victor had not mark'd his way;
But treading where the treach'rous Puddle lay,
His Heels flew up; and on the gray Floor,
He fell, bemear'd with Filth, and Holy Gore.
Not mindles then, Euryalus, of thee,
Nor of the Sacred Bonds of Amity;
He trove th' immediate Rival's hope to cros;
And caught the Foot of Salius as he roe:
So Salius lay extended on the Plain;

l.U: prings out, the Prize to gain;

lg.l: And leaves the Crowd; applauding Peals attend
The Victor to the Goal, who vanquih'd by his Friend.
Next Helymus, and then Diores came;
By two Misfortunes made the third in Fame.
But Salius enters; and, exclaiming loud
For Jutice, deafens, and diturbs the Crowd:
Urges his Caue may in the Court be heard;
And pleads the Prize is wrongfully conferr'd.
But Favour for Euryalus appears;
His blooming Beauty, with his tender Tears,

figure.p: To Anthony Hammond of Somerham in the County of Huntingdon Eqr.
figure.head: AE 5. l: 425.

lg.l: Had brib'd the Judges to protect his Claim;
Beides Diores does as loud exclaim:
Who vainly reaches at the lat Reward,
If the firt Palm on Salius be conferr'd.
Then thus the Prince; let no Diputes arie:
Where Fortune plac'd it, I award the Prize.
But Fortune's Errors give me leave to mend,
At leat to pity my deerving Friend.
He aid, and from among the Spoils, he draws,
(Pond'rous with haggy Main, and Golden Paws)
A Lyon's Hide; to Salius this he gives:
Nius, with Envy ees the Gift, and grieves.
If uch Rewards to vanquih'd Men are due,
He aid, and Falling is to rie by you,
What Prize may Nius from your Bounty claim,
Who merited the firt Rewards and Fame?
In falling, both an equal Fortune try'd;
Wou'd Fortune for my Fall o well provide!
With this he pointed to his Face, and how'd
His Hands, and all his Habit mear'd with Blood.
Th' indulgent Father of the People mil'd;
And caus'd to be produc'd an ample Shield;
Of wond'rous Art by Didymaon wrought,
Long ince from Neptune's Bars in Triumph brought.
This giv'n to Nius; he divides the ret;
And equal Jutice, in his Gifts, expres'd.
The Race thus ended, and Rewards betow'd;
Once more the Prince bepeaks th' attentive Crowd.
If there be here, whoe dauntles Courage dare
In Gauntlet fight, with Limbs and Body bare,
His Oppoite utain in open view,
Stand forth the Champion; and the Games renew.
Two Prizes I propoe, and thus divide,
A Bull with gilded Horns, and Fillets ty'd,
Shall be the Portion of the conqu'ring Chief:
A Sword and Helm hall chear the Loer's Grief.
Then haughty Dares in the Lits appears;
Stalking he trides, his Head erected bears:
His nervous Arms the weighty Gauntlet weild;
And loud Applaues echo thro' the Field.
Dares alone, in Combat us'd to tand
The match of mighty Paris hand to hand:
The ame, at Hector's Fun'rals undertook
Gygantick Butes, of th' Amician Stock;
And by the Stroak of his reitles Hand,
Stretch'd the vat Bulk upon the yellow Sand.
Such Dares was; and uch he trod along,
And drew the Wonder of the gazing Throng.
His brawny Back, and ample Breat he hows;
His lifted Arms around his Head he throws;
And deals, in whitling Air, his empty Blows.
His Match is ought; but thro' the trembling Band,
Not one dares anwer to the proud Demand.
Preuming of his Force, with parkling Eyes,
Already he devours the promis'd Prize.
He claims the Bull with awles Inolence;
And having eiz'd his Horns, accots the Prince.
If none my matchles Valour dares oppoe,
How long hall Dares wait his datard Foes?
Permit me, Chief, permit without Delay,
To lead this uncontended Gift away.
The Crowd aents; and, with redoubled Cries,
For the proud Challenger demands the Prize.
Acetes, fir'd with jut Didain, to ee
The Palm uurp'd without a Victory;
Reproch'd Entellus thus, who ate beide,
And heard, and aw unmov'd, the Trojan's Pride:
Once, but in vain, a Champion of Renown,
So tamely can you bear the ravih'd Crown?
A Prize in triumph born before your ight,
And hun for fear the danger of the Fight?
Where is our Eryx now, the boated Name,
The God who taught your thund'ring Arm the Game;
Where now your baffled Honour, where the Spoil
That fill'd your Houe, and Fame that fill'd our Ile?
Entellus, thus: My Soul is till the ame,
Unmov'd with Fear, and mov'd with Martial Fame:
But my chill Blood is curdled in my Veins;
And carce the Shadow of a Man remains.
Oh, cou'd I turn to that fair Prime again,
That Prime, of which this Boater is o vain,
The Brave who this decrepid Age defies,
Shou'd feel my force, without the promis'd Prize.
He aid, and riing at the word, he threw
Two pond'rous Gauntlets down, in open view:
Gauntlets, which Eryx wont in Fight to wield,
And heath his hands with in the lited field.
With Fear and Wonder eiz'd, the Crowd beholds
The Gloves of Death, with ev'n ditinguih'd folds,
Of tough Bull Hides; the pace within is pread
With Iron, or with loads of heavy Lead.
Dares himelf was daunted at the ight,
Renounc'd his Challenge, and refus'd to fight.
Atonih'd at their weight the Heroe tands,
And poiz'd the pond'rous Engins in his hands.
What had your wonder, aid Entellus, been,
Had you the Gauntlets of Alcides een,
Or view'd the tern debate on this unhappy Green!
Thee which I bear, your Brother Eryx bore,
Still mark'd with batter'd Brains, and mingled Gore.
With thee he long utain'd th' Herculean Arm;
And thee I weilded while my Blood was warm:
This languih'd Frame, while better Spirits fed,
E're Age untrung my Nerves, or Time o'renow'd my Head.
But if the Challenger thee Arms refue,
And cannot wield their weight, or dare not ue;
If great Aeneas, and Acetes joyn
In his Requet, thee Gauntlets I reign:
Let us with equal Arms perform the Fight,
And let him leave to Fear, ince I reign my Right.
This aid, Entellus for the Strife prepares;
Strip'd of his quilted Coat, his Body bares:
Compos'd of mighty Bones and Brawn, he tands,
A goodly tow'ring Obj • ct on the Sands.
Then jut Aeneas equal Arms upply'd,
Which round their Shoulders to their Writs they ty'd.
Both on the tiptoe tand, at full extent,
Their Arms aloft, their Bodies inly bent;
Their Heads from aiming Blows they bear a far;
With clahing Gauntlets then provoke the War.
One on his Youth and pliant Limbs relies;
One on his Sinews, and his Gyant ize.
The lat is tiff with Age, his Motion low,
He heaves for Breath, he taggers to and fro;
And Clouds of iuing Smoak his Notrils loudly blow.
Yet equal in Succes, they ward, they trike;
Their ways are diff'rent, but their Art alike.
Before, behind, the blows are dealt; around
Their hollow ides the ratling Thumps reound.
A Storm of Strokes, well meant, with fury flies,
And errs about their Temples, Ears, and Eyes.
Nor always errs; for oft the Gauntlet draws
A weeping troke, along the crackling Jaws.

figure.p: To Henry St John of Lydiard Tregoz Esqr .
figure.head: AE 5. l: 590.

lg.l: Heavy with Age, Entellus tands his Ground,
But with his warping Body wards the Wound.
His Hand, and watchful Eye keep even pace;
While Dares traveres, and hifts his place.
And like a Captain, who beleaguers round,
Some trong built Catle, on a riing Ground,
Views all th' approaches with oberving Eyes,
This, and that other part, in vain he tries;
And more on Indutry, than Force relies.
With Hands on high, Entellus threats the Foe;
But Dares watch'd the Motion from below,
And lip'd aide, and hun'd the long decending Blow.
Entellus wats his Forces on the Wind;
And thus deluded of the Stroke deign'd,
Headlong, and heavy fell: his ample Breat,
And weighty Limbs, his ancient Mother pres'd.
So falls a hollow Pine, that long had tood
On Ida's height, or Erymanthus Wood,
Torn from the Roots: the diff'ring Nations rie,
And Shouts, and mingl'd Murmurs, rend the Skies.
Acetes runs, with eager hate, to raie
The fall'n Companion of his youthful Days:
Dauntles he roe, and to the Fight return'd:
With hame his glowing Cheeks, his Eyes with fury burn'd.
Didain, and concious Virtue fir'd his Breat;
And with redoubled Force his Foe he pres'd.
He lays on load with either Hand, amain,
And headlong drives the Trojan o're the Plain.
Nor tops, nor tays; nor ret, nor Breath allows,
But Storms of Strokes decend about his Brows;
A ratling Tempet, and a Hail of Blows.
But now the Prince, who aw the wild Increae
Of Wounds, commands the Combatants to ceae:
And bounds Entellus Wrath, and bids the Peace.
Firt to the Trojan pent with Toil he came,
And ooth'd his Sorrow for the uffer'd Shame.
What Fury eiz'd my Friend, the Gods, aid he,
To him propitious, and avere to thee,
Have giv'n his Arm uperior Force to thine;
'Tis Madnes to contend with Strength Divine.
The Gauntlet Fight thus ended, from the Shore,
His faithful Friends unhappy Dares bore:
His Mouth and Notrils, pour'd a Purple Flood;
And pounded Teeth, came ruhing with his Blood.
Faintly he tagger'd thro the hiing Throng;
And hung his Head, and trail'd his Legs along.
The Sword and Caque, are carry'd by his Train;
But with his Foe the Palm and Ox remain.
The Champion, then, before Aeneas came,
Proud of his Prize; but prouder of his Fame;
O Goddes-born, and you Dardanian Hot,
Mark with Attention, and forgive my Boat:
Learn what I was, by what remains; and know
From what impending Fate, you av'd my Foe.
Sternly he poke; and then confronts the Bull;
And, on his ample Forehead, aiming full,
The deadly Stroke decending, pierc'd the Skull.
Down drops the Beat; nor needs a econd Wound:
But prawls in pangs of Death; and purns the Ground.
Then, thus: In Dares tead I offer this;
Eryx, accept a nobler Sacrifice:
Take the lat Gift my wither'd Arms can yield,
Thy Gauntlets I reign; and here renounce the Field.
This done, Aeneas orders, for the cloe,
The trife of Archers, with contending Bows.
The Mat, Sergethus hatter'd Gally bore,
With his own Hands, he raies on the Shore.

figure.p: To Stephen Waller Dr: of Laws
figure.head: AE. 5. l. 645.

div.l: A flutt'ring Dove upon the Top they tye,
The living Mark, at which their Arrows fly.
The rival Archers in a Line advance;
Their turn of Shooting to receive from Chance.
A Helmet holds their Names: The Lots are drawn,
On the firt Scroll was read Hippocoon:
The People hout; upon the next was found
Young Mnetheus, late with Naval Honours crownd.
The third contain'd Eurytion's Noble Name,
Thy Brother, Pandarus, and next in Fame:
Whom Pallas urg'd the Treaty to confound,
And end among the Greeks a feather'd Wound.
Acetes in the bottom, lat remain'd;
Whom not his Age from Youthful Sports retrain'd.
Soon, all with Vigour bend their truty Bows,
And from the Quiver each his Arrow choe,
Hippocoon's was the firt: with forceful way
It flew, and, whizzing, cut the liquid way:
Fix'd in the Mat the feather'd Weapon tands,
The fearful Pidgeon flutters in her Bands;
And the Tree trembled: and the houting Cries
Of the pleas'd People, rend the vaulted Skies.
Then Mnetheus to the head his Arrow drove,
With lifted Eyes; and took his Aim above;
But made a glancing Shot, and mis'd the Dove.
Yet mis'd o narrow, that he cut the Cord
Which faten'd, by the Foot, the flitting Bird.
The Captive thus releas'd, away he flies,
And beats with clapping Wings, the yielding Skies.
His Bow already bent, Eurytion tood,
And having firt invok'd his Brother God,
His winged Shaft with eager hate he ped;
The fatal Meage reach'd her as he fled:
She leaves her Life aloft, he trikes the Ground;
And renders back the Weapon in the Wound.
Acetes grudging at his Lot, remains,
Without a Prize to gratifie his Pains.
Yet hooting upward, ends his Shaft, to how
An Archer's Art, and boat his twanging Bow.
The pointed Arrow gave a dire Portent;
And latter Augures judge from this Event.
Chaf'd by the peed, it fir'd; and as it flew,
A Trail of following Flames, acending drew:
Kindling they mount; and mark the hiny Way:
Acros the Skies as falling Meteors play,
And vanih into Wind; or in a Blaze decay.
The Trojans and Sicilians wildly tare:
And trembling, turn their Wonder into Pray'r.
The Dardan Prince put on a miling Face,
And train'd Acetes with a cloe Embrace:
Then hon'ring him with Gifts above the ret,
Turn'd the bad Omen, nor his Fears confes'd.
The Gods, aid he, this Miracle have wrought;
And order'd you the Prize without the Lot.
Accept this Goblet rough with figur'd Gold,
Which Thracian Cieus gave my Sire of old:
This Pledge of ancient Amity receive,
Which to my econd Sire I jutly give.
He aid, and with the Trumpets chearul ound,
Proclaim'd him Victor, and with Lawrel crown'd.
Nor good Eurytion envy'd him the Prize;
Tho' he transfix'd the Pidgeon in the Skies.
Who cut the Line, with econd Gifts was grac'd;
The third was his, whoe Arrow pierc'd the Mat.
The Chief, before the Games were wholly done,
Call'd Periphantes, Tutor to his Son;
And whiper'd thus; with peed Acanius find,
And if his Childih Troop be ready join'd;
On Hor • -back let him grace his Grandire's Day,
And lead his Equals arm'd, in jut Array.
He aid, and calling out, the Cirque he clears;
The Crowd withdrawn, an open Plain appears.
And now the Noble Youths, of Form Divine,
Advance before their Fathers, in a Line:
The Riders grace the Steeds; the Steeds with Glory hine.
Thus marching on, in Military Pride,
Shouts of Applaue reound from ide to fide.
Their Caques, adorn'd with Lawrel Wreaths, they wear.
Each brandihing aloft a Cornel Spear.
Some at their Backs their guilded Quivers bore;
Their Chains of burnih'd Gold hung down before.
Three graceful Troops they form'd upon the Green;
Three graceful Leaders at their Head were een;
Twelve follow'd ev'ry Chief, and left a Space between.
The firt young Priam led; a lovely Boy,
