Whoe Grandire was th' unhappy King of Troy:
His Race in after times was known to Fame,
New Honours adding to the Latian Name;
And well the Royal Boy his Thracian Steed became.
White were the Fetlocks of his Feet before;
And on his Front a nowy Star he bore:
Then beauteous Atys, with Iulus bred,
Of equal Age, the econd Squadron led.
The lat in Order, but the firt in place,
Firt in the lovely Features of his Face;
Rode fair Acanius on a fiery Steed,
Queen Dido's Gift, and of the Tyrian breed.
Sure Courers for the ret the King ordains;
With Golden Bitts adorn'd, and Purple Reins.

lg.l: The pleas'd Spectators peals of Shouts renew;
And all the Parents in the Children view:
Their Make, their Motions, and their prightly Grace;
And Hopes and Fears alternate in their Face.
Th' unfledg'd Commanders, and their Martial Train,
Firt make the Circuit of the andy Plain,
Around their Sires: And at th' appointed Sign,
Drawn up in beauteous Order form a Line:
The econd Signal ounds; the Troop divides,
In three ditinguih'd parts, with three ditinguih'd Guides.
Again they cloe, and once again di-join,
In Troop to Troop oppos'd, and Line to Line.
They meet, they wheel, they throw their Darts afar
With harmles Rage, and well diembled War.
Then in a round the mingl'd Bodies run;
Flying they follow, and puruing hun.
Broken they break, and rallying, they renew
In other Forms the Military hew.
At lat, in order, undicern'd they join;
And march together, in a friendly Line.
And, as the Cretan Labyrinth of old,
With wand'ring Ways, and many a winding fold,
Involv'd the weary Feet, without redres,
In a round Error, which deny'd reces;
So fought the Trojan Boys in warlike Play,
Turn'd, and return'd, and till a diff'rent way.
Thus Dolphins, in the Deep, each other chae,
In Circles, when they wim around the wat'ry Race.
This Game, thee Carouels Acanius taught;
And, building Alba, to the Latins brought.
Shew'd what he learn'd: The Latin Sires impart,
To their ucceeding Sons, the graceful Art:
From thee Imperial Rome receiv'd the Game;
Which Troy, the Youths the Trojan Troop, they name.

figure.p: To ye mot Illustrious Prince William Duke of Glocester &ct.
figure.head: AE 5. l. 7 •• .

lg.l: Thus far the acred Sports they celebrate:
But Fortune oon reum'd her ancient hate.
For while they pay the dead his Annual dues,
Thoe envy'd Rites Saturnian Juno views.
And ends the Goddes of the various bow,
To try new Methods of Revenge below:
Supplies the Winds to wing her Airy way;
Where in the Port ecure the Navy lay.
Swiftly fair Iris down her Arch decends;
And undicern'd her fatal Voyage ends.
She aw the gath'ring Crowd; and gliding thence,
The deart Shore, and Fleet without defence.
The Trojan Matrons on the Sands alone,
With Sighs and Tears, Anchies death bemoan.
Then, turning to the Sea their weeping Eyes,
Their pity to themelves, renews their Cries.
Alas! aid one, what Oceans yet remain
For us to ail; what Labours to utain!
All take the Word; and with a gen'ral groan,
Implore the Gods for Peace; and Places of their own.
The Goddes, great in Michief, views their pains;
And in a Woman's Form her heav'nly Limbs retrains.
In Face and Shape, old Beroe he became,
Doriclus Wife, a venerable Dame;
Once bles'd with Riches, and a Mother's Name.
Thus chang'd, amidt the crying Crow'd he ran,
Mix'd with the Matrons, and thee words began.
O wretched we, whom not the Grecian Pow'r,
Nor Flames detroy'd, in Troy's unhappy hour!
O wretched we, reerv'd by Cruel Fate,
Beyond the Ruins of the inking State!
Now ev'n revolving Years are wholly run,
Since this improp'rous Voyage we begun:
Since tos'd from Shores to Shores, from Lands to Lands,
Inhopitable Rocks and barren Sands;
Wand'ring in Exile, through the tormy Sea,
We earch in vain for flying Italy.
Now Cat by Fortune on this kindred Land,
What hou'd our Ret, and riing Walls withtand,
Or hinder here to fix our banih'd Band?
O, Country lot, and Gods redeem'd in vain,
If till in endles Exile we remain!
Shall we no more the Trojan Walls renew,
Or Streams of ome diembl'd Simois view!
Hate, joyn with me, th' unhappy Fleet conume:
Caandra bids, and I declare her doom.
In leep I aw her; he upply'd my hands,
(For this I more than dreamt) with flaming Brands:
With thee, aid he, thee wand'ring Ships detroy;
Thee are your fatal Seats, and this your Troy.
Time calls you now, the precious Hour employ.
Slack not the good Preage, while Heav'n inpires
Our Minds to dare, and gives the ready Fires.
See Neptune's Altars miniter their Brands;
The God is pleas'd; the God upplies our hands.
Then, from the Pile, a flaming Firr he drew,
And, tos'd in Air, amidt the Gallies threw.
Wrap'd in a maze, the Matrons wildly tare:
Then Pyrgo, reverenc'd for her hoary Hair,
Pyrgo, the Nure of Priam's num'rous Race,
No Beroe this, tho he belies her Face:
What Terrours from her frowning Front arie;
Behold a Goddes in her ardent Eyes!
What Rays around her heav'nly Face are een,
Mark her Majetick Voice, and more than mortal Meen!
Beroe but now I left; whom pin'd with pain,
Her Age and Anguih from thee Rites detain.
She aid; the Matrons, eiz'd with new Amaze,
Rowl their malignant Eyes, and on the Navy gaze.
They fear, and hope, and neither part obey:
They hope the fated Land, but fear the fatal Way.
The Goddes, having done her Task below,
Mounts up on equal Wings, and bends her painted Bow.
Struck with the ight, and feiz'd with Rage Divine;
The Matrons proecute their mad Deign:
They hriek aloud, they natch, with Impious Hands,
The food of Altars, Firs, and flaming Brands.
Green Leaves, and Saplings, mingled in their hate;
And moaking Torches on the Ships they cat.
The Flame, untop'd at firt, more Fury gains;
And Vulcan rides at large with looen'd Reins:
Triumphant to the painted Sterns he oars,
And eizes in his way, the Banks, and crackling Oars.
Eumelus was the firt, the News to bear,
While yet they crowd the Rural Theatre.
Then what they hear, is witnes'd by their Eyes;
A torm of Sparkles, and of Flames arie.
Acanius took th' Alarm, while yet he led
His early Warriors on his prancing Steed.
And purring on, his Equals oon o'repas'd,
Nor cou'd his frighted Friends reclaim his hate.
Soon as the Royal Youth appear'd in view,
He ent his Voice before him as he flew;
What Madnes moves you, Matrons, to detroy
The lat Remainders of unhappy Troy!
Not hotile Fleets, but your own hopes you burn,
And on your Friends, your fatal Fury turn.
Behold your own Acanius: while he aid,
He drew his glitt'ring Helmet from his Head;
In which the Youths to portful Arms he led.
By this, Aeneas and his Train appear;
And now the Women, eiz'd with Shame and Fear,
Dipers'd, to Woods and Caverns take their Flight;
Abhor their Actions, and avoid the Light:
Their Friends acknowledge, and their Error find;
And hake the Goddes from their alter'd Mind.
Not o the raging Fires their Fury ceae;
But lurking in the Seams, with eeming Peace,
Work on their way, amid the mouldring Tow,
Sure in Detruction, but in Motion low.
The ilent Plague, thro' the green Timber eats,
And vomits out a tardy Flame, by fits.
Down to the Keels, and upward to the Sails,
The Fire decends, or mounts; but till prevails:
Nor Buckets pour'd, nor trength of Human Hand,
Can the victorious Element withtand.
The Pious Heroe rends his Robe, and throws
To Heav'n his Hands, and with his Hands his Vows.
O Jove, he cry'd, if Pray'rs can yet have place;
If thou abhorr't not all the Dardan Race;
If any park of Pity till remain;
If Gods are Gods, and not invok'd in vain;
Yet pare the Relicks of the Trojan Train.
Yet from the Flames our burning Veels free:
Or let thy Fury fall alone on me.
At this devoted Head thy Thunder throw,
And end the willing Sacrifice below.
Scarce had he aid, when Southern Storms arie,
From Pole to Pole, the forky Lightning flies;
Loud ratling hakes the Mountains, and the Plain:
Heav'n bellies downward, and decends in Rain.
Whole Sheets of Water from the Clouds are ent,
Which hiing thro' the Planks, the Flames prevent:
And top the fiery Pet: Four Ships alone
Burn to the wat; and for the Fleet attone.
But doubtful thoughts the Hero's Heart divide;
If he hould till in Sicily reide,
Forgetful of his Fates; or tempt the Main,
In hope the promis'd Italy to gain.
Then Nautes, old, and wie, to whom alone
The Will of Heav'n, by Pallas was fore-hown;
Vers'd in Portents, experienc'd and inpir'd,
To tell Events, and what the Fates requir'd:
Thus while he tood, to neither part inclin'd,
With chearful Words reliev'd his lab'ring Mind.
O Goddes-born, reign'd in ev'ry tate,
With Patience bear, with Prudence puh your Fate.
By uff'ring well, our Fortune we ubdue;
Fly when he frowns, and when he calls purue.
Your Friend Acetes is of Trojan Kind,
To him dicloe the Secrets of your Mind:
Trut in his Hands your old and ueles Train,
Too num'rous for the Ships which yet remain:
The feeble, old, indulgent of their Eae,
The Dames who dread the Dangers of the Seas,
With all the datard Crew, who dare not tand
The hock of Battel with your Foes by Land;
Here you may build a common Town for all;
And from Acetes name, Aceta call.
The Reaons, with his Friend's Experience join'd,
Encourag'd much, but more diturb'd his Mind.
'Twas dead of Night; when to his lumb'ring Eyes,
His Father's Shade decended from the Skies;
And thus he poke: O more than vital Breath
Lov'd while I liv'd, and dear ev'n after Death;
O Son, in various Toils and Troubles tot,
The King of Heav'n employs my careful Ghot
On his Commands; the God who av'd from Fire
Your flaming Fleet, and heard your jut deire:
The Wholom Counel of your Friend receive;
And here, the Coward Train, and Women leave:
The choen Youth, and thoe who nobly dare,
Tranport; to tempt the Dangers of the War.
The tern Italians will their Courage try;
Rough are their Manners, and their Minds are high.
But firt to Pluto's Palace you hall go,
And eek my Shade among the blet below.
For not with impious Ghots my Soul remains,
Nor uffers, with the Damn'd, perpetual Pains;
But breaths the living Air of oft Elyian Plains.
The chat Sybilla hall your teps convey;
And Blood of offer'd Victims free the way.
There hall you know what Realms the Gods aign;
And learn the Fates and Fortunes of your Line.
But now, farewel; I vanih with the Night;
And feel the blat of Heav'ns approaching Light:
He aid, and mix'd with Shades, and took his airy flight.
Whether o fat, the filial Duty cry'd,
And why, ah why, the wih'd Embrace deny'd!
He aid, and roe: as holy Zeal inpires
He rakes hot Embers, and renews the Fires.
His Country Gods and Veta, then adores
With Cakes and Incene; and their Aid implores.
Next, for his Friends, and Royal Hot he ent,
Reveal'd his Viion and the Gods intent,
With his own Purpoe: All, without delay,
The Will of Jove, and his Deires obey.
They lit with Women each degenerate Name,
Who dares not hazard Life, for future Fame.
Thee they cahier; the brave remaining few,
Oars, Banks, and Cables half conum'd renew.
The Prince deigns a City with the Plough;
The Lots their ev'ral Tenements allow.
This part is nam'd from Ilium, that from Troy;
And the new King acends the Throme with Joy.
A choen Senate from the People draws;
Appoints the Judges, and ordains the Laws.
Then on the top of Eryx, they begin
To raie a Temple to the Paphian Queen:
Anchies, lat, is honour'd as a God,
A Priet is added, annual Gifts betow'd;
And Groves are planted round his blet Abode,
Nine days they pas in Feats, their Temples crown'd;
And fumes of Incene in the Fanes abound.
Then, from the South aroe a ge¯ntle Breeze,
That curl'd the moothnes of the glay Seas:
The riing Winds, a ruffling Gale afford,
And call the merry Marriners aboard.
Now loud Laments along the Shores reound,
Of parting Friends in cloe Embraces bound.
The trembling Women, the degenerate Train,
Who hun'd the frightful dangers of the Main;
Ev'n thoe deire to fail, and take their hare
Of the rough Paage, and the promis'd War.
Whom Good Aeneas chears; and recommends
To their new Mater's Care, his fearful Friends.
On Eryx Altars three at Calves he lays;
A Lamb new fall'n to the tormy Seas;
Then flips his Haulers, and his Anchors weighs.
High on the Deck, the Godlike Heroe tands;
With Olive crown'd; a Charger in his Hands;
Then cat the reeking Entrails in the brine,
And pour'd the Sacrifice of Purple Wine.
Freh Gales arie, with equal Strokes they vye,
And bruh the buxom Seas, and o're the Billows fly.
Mean time the Mother-Goddes, full of Fears,
To Neptune thus addres'd, with tender Tears.
The Pride of Jove's Imperious Queen, the Rage,
The malice which no Suff'rings can awage,
Compel me to thee Pray'rs: Since neither Fate,
Nor Time, nor Pity, can remove her hate.
Ev'n Jove is thwarted by his haughty Wife;
Still vanquih'd, yet he till renews the Strife.
As if 'twere little to conume the Town
Which aw'd the World; and wore th' Imperial Crown:
She proecutes the Ghot of Troy with Pains;
And gnaws, ev'n to the Bones, the lat Remains.
Let her the Caues of her Hatred tell;
But you can witnes its Effects too well.
You aw the Storm he rais'd on Lybian Floods,
That mix'd the mounting Billows with the Clouds.
When, bribing Eolus, he hook the Main;
And mov'd Rebellion in your wat'ry Reign.
With Fury he poes'd the Dardan Dames;
To burn their Fleet with execrable Flames.
And forc'd Aeneas, when his Ships were lot,
To leave his Foll'wers on a Foreign Coat.
For what remains, your Godhead I implore;
And trut my Son to your protecting Pow'r.
If neither Jove's, nor Fate's decree withtand,
Secure his Paage to the Latian Land.
Then thus the mighty Ruler of the Main,
What may not Venus hope, from Neptune's Reign?
My Kingdom claims your Birth: my late Defence
Of your indanger'd Fleet, may claim your Confidence.
Nor les by Land than Sea, my Deeds declare,
How much your lov'd Aeneas is my Care.
Thee Xanthus, and thee Simois I attet:
Your Trojan Troops, when proud Achilles pres'd,

figure.p: To Edmond Waller of Beacons Field in the County of Bucks Esq
figure.head: AE 5. l. 1075

lg.l: And drove before him headlong on the Plain
And dah'd againt the Walls the trembling T ••••
When Floods were fill'd with bodies of the lain.
When Crimon Xanthus, doubtful of his way,
Stood up on ridges to behold the Sea;
New heaps came tumbling in, and choak'd his way:
When your Aeneas fought, but fought with odds
Of Force unequal, and unequal Gods;
I pread a Cloud before the Victor's ight,
Sutain'd the vanquih'd, and ecur'd his flight.
Ev'n then ecur'd him, when I ought with joy
The vow'd detruction of ungrateful Troy.
My Will's the ame: Fair Goddes fear no more,
Your Fleet hall afely gain the Latian Shore:
Their lives are giv'n; one detin'd Head alone
Shall perih, and for Multitudes attone.
Thus having arm'd with Hopes her anxious Mind,
His finny Team Saturnian Neptune join'd.
Then, adds the foamy Bridle to their Jaws;
And to the looen'd Reins permits the Laws.
High on the Waves his Azure Car he guides,
Its Axles thunder, and the Sea ubides;
And the mooth Ocean rowls her ilent Tides.
The Tempets fly before their Father's face,
Trains of inferiour Gods his Triumph grace;
And Monter Whales before their Mater play,
And Quires of Tritons crowd the wat'ry way.
The Martial'd Pow'rs, in equal Troops divide,
To right and left: the Gods his better ide
Incloe, and on the wore the Nymphs and Nereids ride.
Now miling Hope, with weet Viciitude,
Within the Hero's Mind, his Joys renew'd.
He calls to raie the Mats, the Sheats diplay;
The Chearful Crew with diligence obey;
They cud before the Wind, and ail in open Sea.
A Head of all the Mater Pilot teers,
And as he leads, the following Navy veers.
The Steeds of Night had travell'd half the Sky,
The drowzy Rowers on their Benches lye;
When the oft God of Sleep, with eaie flight,
Decends, and draws behind a trail of Light.
Thou Palinurus art his detin'd Prey;
To thee alone he takes his fatal way.
Dire Dreams to thee, and Iron Sleep he bears;
And lighting on thy Prow, the Form of Phorbas wears.
Then thus the Traytor God began his Tale:
The Winds, my Friend, inpire a pleaing gale;
The Ships, without thy Care, ecurely ail.
Now teal an hour of weet Repoe; and I
Will take the Rudder, and thy room upply.
To whom the yauning Pilot, half aleep;
Me dot thou bid to trut the treach'rous Deep!
The Harlot-miles of her diembling Face,
And to her Faith commit the Trojan Race?
Shall I believe the Syren South again,
And, oft betray'd, not know the Monter Main?
He aid, his faten'd hands the Rudder keep,
And fix'd on Heav'n, his Eyes repel invading Sleep.
The God was wroth, and at his Temples threw
A Branch in Lethe dip'd, and drunk with Stygian Dew:
The Pilot, vanquih'd by the Pow'r Divine,
Soon clos'd his wimming Eyes, and lay upine.
Scarce were his Limbs extended at their length,
The God, inulting with uperiour Strength,
Fell heavy on him, plung'd him in the Sea,
And, with the Stern, the Rudder tore away.
Headlong he fell, and trugling in the Main,
Cry'd out for helping hands, but cry'd in vain:
The Victor Daemon mounts obcure in Air;
While the Ship ails without the Pilot's care.
On Neptune's Faith the floating Fleet relies;
But what the Man forook, the God upplies;
And o're the dang'rous Deep ecure the Navy flies.
Glides by the Syren's Cliffs, a helfy Coat,
Long infamous for Ships, and Sailors lot;
And white with Bones: Th' impetuous Ocean roars;
And Rocks rebellow from the ounding Shores.
The watchful Heroe felt the knocks; and found
The toing Veel ail'd on hoaly Ground.
Sure of his Pilot's los, he takes himelf
The Helm, and teers aloof, and huns the Shelf.
Inly he griev'd; and groaning from his Breat,
Deplor'd his Death; and thus his Pain expres'd:
For Faith repos'd on Seas, and on the flatt'ring Sky,
Thy naked Corps is doom'd, on Shores unknown to lye.

div.head: The Sixth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The Sibyl foretels Aeneas the Adventures he hould meet with in Italy. She attends him to Hell; decribing to him the various Scenes of that Place, and conducting him to his Father Anchies. Who intructs him in thoe ublime Myteries of the Soul of the World, and the Tranmigration: And hews him that glorious Race of Heroes, which was to decend from him, and his Poterity.

lg.l: HE aid, and wept: Then pread his Sails before
The Winds, and reach'd at length the Cuman Shore:
Their Anchors drop'd, his Crew the Veels moor.
They turn their Heads to Sea; their Sterns to Land;
And greet with greedy Joy th' Italian Strand.
Some trike from clahing Flints their fiery Seed;
Some gather Sticks, the kindled Flames to feed:
Or earch for hollow Trees, and fell the Woods,
Or trace thro Valleys the dicover'd Floods.
Thus, while their ev'ral Charges they fulfil,
The Pious Prince acends the acred Hill
Where Phoebus is ador'd; and eeks the Shade,
Which hides from ight, his venerable Maid.
Deep in a Cave the Sibyl makes abode;
Thence full of Fate returns, and of the God.
Thro Trivia's Grove they walk; and now behold,
And enter now, the Temple roof'd with Gold.
When Dedalus, to hun the Cretan Shore,
His heavy Limbs on jointed Pinions bore,
(The firt who ail'd in Air,) 'tis ung by Fame,
To the Cumaean Coat at length he came;
And, here alighting, built this cotly Frame.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble Bail Earle of Denbigh Vis-count Fielding Baron Newenham Padox & St Lis
figure.head: AE. 6. l. •

lg.l: Incrib'd to Phoebus, here he hung on high
The teerage of his Wings, that cut the Sky:
Then o're the lofty Gate his Art embos'd
Androgeos Death, and Off'rings to his Ghot.
Sev'n Youths from Athens yearly ent, to meet
The Fate appointed by revengeful Creet.
And next to thee the dreadful Urn was plac'd,
In which the detin'd Name by Lots were cat:
The mournful Parents tand around in Tears;
And riing Creet againt their Shore appears.
There too, in living Sculpture, might be een
The mad Affection of the Cretan Queen:
Then how he cheats her bellowing Lover's Eye:
The ruhing leap, the doubtful Progeny,
The lower part a Beat, a Man above,
The Monument of their polluted Love.
Nor far from thence he grav'd the wond'rous Maze;
A thouand Doors, a thouand winding Ways;
Here dwells the Monter, hid from Human View,
Not to be found, but by the faithful Clue:
'Till the kind Artit, mov'd with Pious Grief,
Lent to the loving Maid this lat Relief.
And all thoe erring Paths decrib'd o well,
That Theeus conquer'd, and the Monter fell.
Here haples Icarus had found his part;
Had not the Father's Grief retrain'd his Art.
He twice eay'd to cat his Son in Gold;
Twice from his Hands he drop'd the forming Mould.
All this with wond'ring Eyes Aeneas view'd:
Each varying Object his Delight renew'd.
Prepar'd to read the ret, Achates came,
And by his ide the mad divining Dame;
The Prietes of the God, Deiphobe her Name.
Time uffers not, he aid, to feed your Eyes
With empty Pleaures: hate the Sacrifice.
Sev'n Bullocks yet unyok'd, for Phoebus chue,
And for Diana ev'n unpotted Ewes.
This aid, the Servants urge the Sacred Rites;
While to the Temple he the Prince invites.
A pacious Cave, within its farmot part,
Was hew'd and fahion'd by laborious Art.
Thro' the Hills hollow ides: Before the place,
A hundred Doors a hundred Entries grace:
As many Voices iue; and the ound
Of Sibyl's Words as many times rebound.
Now to the Mouth they come: Aloud he cries,
This is the time, enquire your Detinies.
He comes, behold the God! Thus while he aid,
(And hiv'ring at the acred Entry taid)
Her Colour chang'd, her Face was not the ame,
And hollow Groans from her deep Spirit came.
Her Hair tood up; convulive Rage poes'd
Her trembling Limbs, and heav'd her lab'ring Breat.
Greater than Human Kind he eem'd to look:
And with an Accent, more than Mortal, poke.
Her taring Eyes with parling Fury rowl;
When all the God came ruhing on her Soul.
Swiftly he turn'd, and foaming as he poke,
Why this Delay, he cry'd; the Pow'rs invoke.
Thy Pray'rs alone can open this abode,
Ele vain are my Demands, and dumb the God.
She aid no more: The trembling Trojans hear;
O're-pread with a damp Sweat, and holy Fear.
The Prince himelf, with awful Dread poes'd,
His Vows to great Apollo thus addres'd.
Indulgent God, propitious Pow'r to Troy,
Swift to relieve, unwilling to detroy;
Directed by whoe Hand, the Dardan Dart
Pierc'd the proud Grecian's only Mortal part:
Thus far, by Fates Decrees, and thy Commands,
Through ambient Seas, and thro' devouring Sands,
Our exil'd Crew has ought th' Auonian Ground:
And now, at length, the flying Coat is found.
Thus far the Fate of Troy, from place to place,
With Fury has puru'd her wand'ring Race:
Here ceae ye Pow'rs, and let your Vengeance end,
Troy is no more, and can no more offend.
And thou, O acred Maid, inpir'd to ee
Th' Event of things in dark Futurity;
Give me, what Heav'n has promis'd to my Fate,
To conquer and command the Latian State:
To fix my wand'ring Gods; and find a place
For the long Exiles of the Trojan Race.
Then hall my grateful Hands a Temple rear
To the twin Gods, with Vows and olemn Pray'r;
And Annual Rites, and Fetivals, and Games,
Shall be perform'd to their aupicious Names.
Nor halt thou want thy Honours in my Land,
For there thy faithful Oracles hall tand,
Preerv'd in Shrines: and ev'ry Sacred Lay,
Which, by thy Mouth, Apollo hall convey.
All hall be treaur'd, by a choen Train
Of holy Priets, and ever hall remain.
But, oh! commit not thy prophetick Mind
To flitting Leaves, the port of ev'ry Wind:
Let they dipere in Air our empty Fate:
Write not, but, what the Pow'rs ordain, relate.
Strugling in vain, impatient of her Load,
And lab'ring underneath the pond'rous God,
The more he trove to hake him from her Breat,
With more, and far uperior Force he pres'd:
Commands his Entrance, and without Controul,
Uurps her Organs, and inpires her Soul.
Now, with a furious Blat, the hundred Doors
Ope of themelves; a ruhing Wirlwind roars
Within the Cave; and Sibyl's Voice retores.
Ecap'd the Dangers of the wat'ry Reign,
Yet more, and greater Ills, by Land remain.
The Coat o long deir'd, (nor doubt th' Event)
Thy Troops hall reach, but having reach'd, repent.
Wars, horrid Wars I view; a field of Blood;
And Tyber rolling with a Purple Flood.
Simois nor Xanthus hall be wanting there;
A new Achilles hall in Arms appear:
And he, too, Goddes-born: fierce Juno's Hate,
Added to hotile Force, hall urge thy Fate.
To what trange Nations halt not thou reort,
Driv'n to ollicite Aid at ev'ry Court!
The Caue the ame which Ilium once oppres'd,
A foreign Mitres, and a foreign Guet.
But thou, ecure of Soul, unbent with Woes,
The more thy Fortune frowns, the more oppoe.
The dawnings of thy Safety, hall be hown,
From whence thou leat halt hope, a Grecian Town.
Thus, from the dark Reces, the Sibyl poke,
And the reiting Air the Thunder broke;
The Cave rebellow'd; and the Temple hook.
Th' ambiguous God, who rul'd her lab'ring Breat,
In thee myterious Words his Mind expret:
Some Truths reveal'd, in Terms involv'd the ret.
At length her Fury fell; her foaming ceas'd,
And, ebbing in her Soul, the God decreas'd.
Then thus the Chief: no Terror to my view,
No frightful Face of Danger can be new.

figure.p: To Sr Fleetwood Sheppard Knight, Gent: Vher of ye Black Rod
figure.head: AE. • l. 150.

lg.l: Inur'd to uffer, and reolv'd to dare,
The Fates, without my Pow'r, hall be without my Care.
This let me crave, ince near your Grove the Road
To Hell lies open, and the dark Abode,
Which Acheron urrounds, th' innavigable Flood:
Conduct me thro' the Regions void of Light,
And lead me longing to my Father's ight.
For him, a thouand Dangers I have ought;
And, ruhing where the thicket Grecians fought,
Safe on my Back the acred Burthen brought.
He, for my ake, the raging Ocean try'd,
And Wrath of Heav'n; my till aupicious Guide,
And bore beyond the trength decrepid Age upply'd.
Oft ince he breath'd his lat, in dead of Night,
His reverend Image tood before my ight;
Enjoin'd to eek below, his holy Shade;
Conducted there, by your unerring aid.
But you, if pious Minds by Pray'rs are won,
Oblige the Father, and protect the Son.
Yours is the Pow'r; nor Proerpine in vain
Has made you Prietes of her nightly Reign.
If Orpheus, arm'd with his enchanting Lyre,
The ruthles King with Pity could inpire;
And from the Shades below redeem his Wife:
If Pollux, off'ring his alternate Life,
Cou'd free his Brother; and can daily go
By turns aloft, by turns decend below:
Why name I Theeus, or his greater Friend,
Who trod the downward Path, and upward cou'd acend!
Not les than theirs, from Jove my Lineage came:
My Mother greater, my Decent the ame.
So pray'd the Trojan Prince; and while he pray'd
His Hand upon the holy Altar laid.
Then thus reply'd the Prophetes Divine:
O Goddes born! of Great Anchies Line;
The Gates of Hell are open Night and day;
Smooth the Decent, and eaie is the Way:
But, to return, and view the chearful Skies;
In this the Task, and mighty Labour lies.
To few great Jupiter imparts this Grace:
And thoe of hining Worth, and Heav'nly Race.
Betwixt thoe Regions, and our upper Light,
Deep Forrets, and impenetrable Night
Poes the middle pace: Th' Infernal Bounds
Cocytus, with his able Waves, urrounds.
But if o dire a Love your Soul invades;
As twice below to view the trembling Shades;
If you o hard a Toil will undertake,
As twice to pas th' innavigable Lake;
Receive my Counel. In the Neighb'ring Grove
There tands a Tree; the Queen of Stygian Jove
Claims it her own; thick Woods, and gloomy Night,
Conceal the happy Plant from Humane ight.
One Bough it bears; but, wond'rous to behold;
The ductile Rind, and Leaves, of Radiant Gold:
This, from the vulgar Branches mut be torn,
And to fair Proerpine, the Preent born:
E're leave be giv'n to tempt the neather Skies:
The firt thus rent, a econd will arie;
And the ame Metal the ame room upplies.
Look round the Wood, with lifted Eyes, to ee
The lurking Gold upon the fatal Tree:
Then rend it off, as holy Rites command:
The willing Metal will obey thy hand,
Following with eae, if, favour'd by thy Fate,
Thou art foredoom'd to view the Stygian State:
If not, no labour can the Tree contrain:
And trength of tubborn Arms, and Steel are vain.
Beides, you know not, while you here attend
Th' unworthy Fate of your unhappy Friend:
Breathles he lies: And his unbury'd Ghot,
Depriv'd of Fun'ral Rites, pollutes your Hot.
Pay firt his Pious Dues: And for the dead,
Two able Sheep around his Here be led.
Then, living Turfs upon his Body lay;
This done, ecurely take the detin'd Way,
To find the Regions detitute of Day.
She aid: and held her Peace. Aeneas went
Sad from the Cave, and full of Dicontent;
Unknowing whom the acred Sibyl meant.
Achates, the Companion of his Breat,
Goes grieving by his ide; with equal Cares oppres'd.
Walking, they talk'd, and fruitlely divin'd
What Friend, the Prietes by thoe Words deign'd.
But oon they found an Object to deplore;
Mienus lay extended on the Shore.
Son to the God of Winds; none o renown'd,
The Warrior Trumpet in the Field to ound:
With breathing Bras to kindle fierce Alarms;
And rouze to dare their Fate, in honourable Arms.
He erv'd great Hector; and was ever near;
Not with his Trumpet only, but his Spear.
But, by Pelides Arms, when Hector fell,
He choe Aeneas, and he choe as well.
Swoln with Applaue, and aiming till at more,
He now provokes the Sea Gods from the Shore;
With Envy Triton heard the Martial ound,
And the bold Champion, for his Challenge, drown'd.
Then cat his mangled Carcas on the Strand
The gazing Crowd around the Body tand.
All weep, but mot Aeneas mourns his Fate;
And hatens to perform the Funeral tate.
In Altar-wie, a tately Pile they rear;
The Bais broad below, and top advanc'd in Air.
An ancient Wood, fit for the Work deign'd,
(The hady Covert of the Salvage Kind)
The Trojans found: The ounding Axe is ply'd:
Firs, Pines, and Pitch-Trees, and the tow'ring Pride
Of Foret Ahes, feel the fatal Stroke:
And piercing Wedges cleave the tubborn Oak.
Huge Trunks of Trees, fell'd from the teepy Crown
Of the bare Mountains, rowl with Ruin down.
Arm'd like the ret the Trojan Prince appears:
And, by his pious Labour, urges theirs.
Thus while he wrought, revolving in his Mind,
The ways to compas what his Wih deign'd,
He cat his Eyes upon the gloomy Grove;
And then with Vows implor'd the Queen of Love.
O may thy Pow'r, propitious till to me,
Conduct my teps to find the fatal Tree,
In this deep Foret; ince the Sibyl's Breath
Foretold, alas! too true, Mienus Death.
Scarce had he aid, when full before his ight
Two Doves, decending from their Airy Flight,
Secure upon the gray Plain alight.
He knew his Mother's Birds: and thus he pray'd:
Be you my Guides, with your aupicious Aid:
And lead my Footteps, 'till the Branch be found,
Whoe glittering Shadow guilds the acred Ground:
And thou, great Parent! with Coeletial Care,
In this Ditres, be preent to my Pray'r.
Thus having aid, he top'd: With watchful ight,
Oberving till the motions of their Flight.

figure.p: To Sr: Tho: Dyke of Horeham in ye County of Susex Bart:
figure.head: AE. 6. l. 280

figure.p: To Mrs: Anne Baynard Daughter of Dr. Ednd: Baynard of the Family of Leckham in ye County of Wilts
figure.head: AE 6. l 31 •

lg.l: What coure they took, what happy Signs they hew.
They fed, and flutt'ring by degrees, withdrew
Still farther from the Place; but till in view.
Hopping, and flying, thus they led him on
To the low Lake; whoe baleful Stench to hun,
They wing'd their Flight aloft; then, tooping low,
Perch'd on the double Tree, that bears the golden Bough.
Thro' the green Leafs the glitt'ring Shadows glow;
As on the acred Oak, the wintry Mileto:
Where the proud Mother views her precious Brood;
And happier Branches, which he never ow'd.
Such was the glitt'ring; uch the ruddy Rind,
And dancing Leaves, that wanton'd in the Wind.
He eiz'd the hining Bough with griping hold;
And rent away, with eae, the ling'ring Gold.
Then, to the Sibyl's Palace bore the Prize.
Mean time, the Trojan Troops, with weeping Eyes,
To dead Mienus pay his Obequies.
Firt, from the Ground, a lofty Pile they rear,
Of Pitch-trees, Oaks, and Pines, and unctuous Firr:
The Fabrick's Front with Cypres Twigs they trew;
And tick the ides with Boughs of baleful Yeugh.
The topmot part, his glitt'ring Arms adorn;
Warm Waters, then, in brazen Caldrons born,
Are pour'd to wah his Body, Joint by Joint:
And fragrant Oils the tiffen'd Limbs anoint.
With Groans and Cries Mienus they deplore:
Then on a Bier, with Purple cover'd o're,
The breathles Body, thus bewail'd, they lay:
And fire the Pile, their Faces turn'd away:
(Such reverend Rites their Fathers us'd to pay.)
Pure Oyl, and Incene, on the Fire they throw:
And Fat of Victims, which his Friends betow.
Thee Gifts, the greedy Flames to Dut devour;
Then, on the living Coals, red Wine they pour:
And lat, the Relicks by themelves dipoe;
Which in a brazen Urn the Priets incloe.
Old Chorineus compas'd thrice the Crew;
And dip'd an Olive Branch in holy Dew;
Which thrice he prinkl'd round; and thrice aloud
Invok'd the dead, and then dimis'd the Crowd.
But good Aeneas order'd on the Shore
A tately Tomb; whoe top a Trumpet bore:
A Souldier's Fauchion, and a Sea-man's Oar.
Thus was his Friend interr'd: And deathles Fame
Still to the lofty Cape conigns his Name.
Thee Rites perform'd, the Prince, without delay,
Hates to the neather World, his detin'd Way.
Deep was the Cave; and downward as it went
From the wide Mouth, a rocky rough Decent;
And here th' acces a gloomy Grove defends;
And there th' unnavigable Lake extends.
O're whoe unhappy Waters, void of Light,
No Bird preumes to teer his Airy Flight;
Such deadly Stenches from the depth arie,
And teaming Sulphur, that infects the Skies.
From hence the Grecian Bards their Legends make,
And give the name Avernus to the Lake.
Four able Bullocks, in the Yoke untaught,
For Sacrifice the pious Heroe brought.
The Prietes pours the Wine betwixt their Horns:
Then cuts the curling Hair; that firt Oblation burns.
Invoking Hecate hither to repair;
(A pow'rful Name in Hell, and upper Air.)
The acred Priets with ready Knives bereave
The Beats of Life; and in full Bowls receive
The treaming Blood: A Lamb to Hell and Night,
(The able Wool without a treak of white)
Aeneas offers: And, by Fates decree,
A barren Heifar, Proerpine to thee.
With Holocauts he Pluto's Altar fills:
Sev'n brawny Bulls with his own Hand he kills:
Then on the broiling Entrails Oyl he pours;
Which, ointed thus, the raging Flame devours.
Late, the Nocturnal Sacrifice begun;
Nor ended, 'till the next returning Sun.
Then Earth began to bellow, Trees to dance;
And howling Dogs in glimm'ring Light advance;
E're Hecate came: Far hence be Souls prophane,
The Sibyl cry'd, and from the Grove abtain.
Now, Trojan, take the way thy Fates afford:
Aume thy Courage, and unheath thy Sword.
She aid, and pas'd along the gloomy Space:
The Prince puru'd her Steps with equal pace.
Ye Realms, yet unreveal'd to human ight,
Ye Gods, who rule the Regions of the Night,
Ye gliding Ghots, permit me to relate
The mytick Wonders of your ilent State.
Obcure they went thro dreery Shades, that led
Along the wate Dominions of the dead:
Thus wander Travellers in Woods by Night,
By the Moon's doubtful, and malignant Light:
When Jove in dusky Clouds involves the Skies;
And the faint Crecent hoots by fits before their Eyes.
Jut in the Gate, and in the Jaws of Hell,
Revengeful Cares, and ullen Sorrows dwell;
And pale Dieaes, and repining Age;
Want, Fear, and Famine's unreited rage.
Here Toils, and Death, and Death's half-brother, Sleep,
Forms terrible to view, their Centry keep:
With anxious Pleaures of a guilty Mind,
Deep Frauds before, and open Force behind:
The Furies Iron Beds, and Strife that hakes
Her hiing Trees, and unfolds her Snakes.
Full in the midt of this infernal Road,
An Elm diplays her dusky Arms abroad;
The God of Sleep there hides his heavy Head:
And empty Dreams on ev'ry Leaf are pread.
Of various Forms unnumber'd Specters more;
Centaurs, and double Shapes, beiege the Door:
Before the Paage horrid Hydra tands,
And Briareus with all his hundred Hands:
Gorgons, Geryon with his triple Frame;
And vain Chimaera vomits empty Flame.
The Chief unheath'd his hining Steel, prepar'd,
Tho eiz'd with udden Fear, to force the Guard.
Off'ring his brandih'd Weapon at their Face;
Had not the Sibyl top'd his eager Pace,
And told him what thoe empty Fantomes were;
Forms without Bodies, and impaive Air.
Hence to deep Acheron they take their way;
Whoe troubled Eddies, thick with Ooze and Clay,
Are whirl'd aloft, and in Cocytus lot:
There Charon tands, who rules the dreary Coat:
A ordid God; down from his hoary Chin
A length of Beard decends; uncomb'd, unclean:
His Eyes, like hollow Furnaces on Fire:
A Girdle, foul with greae, binds his obcene Attire.
He preads his Canvas, with his Pole he teers;
The Freights of flitting Ghots in his thin Bottom beats.
He look'd in Years; yet in his Years were een
A youthful Vigour, and Autumnal green.
An Airy Crowd came ruhing where he tood;
Which fill'd the Margin of the fatal Flood.

figure.p: To John Lenknor Esqr: of West Deane in the County of Susex
figure.head: AE. 6. l: 390

lg.l: Husbands and Wives, Boys and unmarry'd Maids;
And mighty Heroes more Majetick Shades.
And Youths, intomb'd before their Fathers Eyes,
With hollow Groans, and Shrieks, and feeble Cries:
Thick as the Leaves in Autumn trow the Woods:
Or Fowls, by Winter forc'd, forake the Floods,
And wing their haty flight to happier Lands:
Such, and o thick, the hiv'ring Army tands:
And pres for paage with extended hands.
Now thee, now thoe, the urly Boatman bore:
The ret he drove to ditance from the Shore.
The Heroe, who beheld with wond'ring Eyes,
The Tumult mix'd with Shrieks, Laments, and Cries;
Ask'd of his Guide, what the rude Concoure meant?
Why to the Shore the thronging People bent?
What Forms of Law, among the Ghots were us'd?
Why ome were ferry'd o're, and ome refus'd?
Son of Anchies, Offspring of the Gods,
The Sibyl aid; you ee the Stygian Floods,
The Sacred Stream, which Heav'n's Imperial State
Attets in Oaths, and fears to violate.
The Ghots rejected, are th' unhappy Crew
Depriv'd of Sepulchers and Fun'ral due.
The Boatman Charon; thoe, the bury'd hot,
He Ferries over to the Farther Coat.
Nor dares his Tranport Veel cros the Waves,
With uch whoe Bones are not compos'd in Graves.
A hundred years they wander on the Shore,
At length, their Pennance done, are wafted o're.
The Trojan Chief his forward pace repres'd;
Revolving anxious Thoughts within his Breat.
He aw his Friends, who whelm'd beneath the Waves,
Their Fun'ral Honours claim'd, and ask'd their quiet Graves.
The lot Leucapis in the Crowd he knew;
And the brave Leader of the Lycian Crew:
Whom, on the Tyrrhene Seas, the Tempets met;
The Sailors mater'd, and the Ship o'reet.
Amidt the Spirits Palinurus pres'd;
Yet freh from life; a new admitted Guet.
Who, while he teering view'd the Stars, and bore
His Coure from Affrick, to the Latian Shore,
Fell headlong down. The Trojan fix'd his view;
And carcely through the gloom the ullen Shadow knew.
Then thus the Prince. What envious Pow'r, O Friend,
Brought your lov'd life to this diatrous end?
For Phoebus, ever true in all he aid,
Has, in your fate alone, my Faith betray'd?
The God foretold you hou'd not die, before
You reach'd, ecure from Seas, th' Italian Shore?
Is this th' unerring Pow'r? The Ghot reply'd,
Nor Phoebus flatter'd, nor his Anwers ly'd;
Nor envious Gods have ent me to the Deep:
But while the Stars, and coure of Heav'n I keep,
My weary'd Eyes were eiz'd with fatal leep.
I fell; and with my weight, the Helm contrain'd,
Was drawn along, which yet my gripe retain'd.
Now by the Winds, and raging Waves, I wear,
Your Safety, more than mine, was then my Care:
Let, of the Guide bereft, the Rudder lot,
Your Ship hou'd run againt the the rocky Coat.
Three blut'ring Nights, born by the Southern blat,
I floated; and dicover'd Land at lat:
High on a Mounting Wave, my head I bore:
Forcing my Strength, and gath'ring to the Shore:
Panting, but but pat the danger, now I eiz'd
The Craggy Cliffs, and my tyr'd Members eas'd:
While, cumber'd with my dropping Cloaths, I lay,
The cruel Nation, covetous of Prey,
Stain'd with my Blood th' unhopitable Coat:
And now, by Winds and Waves, my lifeles Limbs are tot.
Which O avert, by yon Etherial Light
Which I have lot, for this eternal Night:
Or if by dearer tyes you may be won,
By your dead Sire, and by your living Son,
Redeem from this Reproach, my wand'ring Ghot;
Or with your Navy eek the Velin Coat:
And in a peaceful Grave my Corps compoe:
Or, if a nearer way your Mother hows,
Without whoe Aid, you durt not undertake
This frightful Paage o're the Stygian Lake;
Lend to this Wretch your Hand, and waft him o're
To the weet Banks of yon forbidden Shore.
Scarce had he aid, the Prophetes began;
What Hopes delude thee, mierable Man?
Think't thou thus unintomb'd to cros the Floods,
To view the Furies, and Infernal Gods;
And viit, without leave, the dark abodes?
Attend the term of long revolving Years:
Fate, and the dooming Gods, are deaf to Tears.
This Comfort of thy dire Misfortune take;
The Wrath of Heav'n, inflicted for thy ake,
With Vengeance hall purue th' inhumane Coat.
Till they propitiate thy offended Ghot,
And raie a Tomb, with Vows, and olemn Pray'r;
And Palinurus name the Place hall bear.
This calm'd his Cares: ooth'd with his future Fame;
And pleas'd to hear his propagated Name.
Now nearer to the Stygian Lake they draw:
Whom from the Shore, the urly Boatman aw:
Oberv'd their Paage thro' the hady Wood;
And mark'd their near Approaches to the Flood:
Then thus he call'd aloud, inflam'd with Wrath;
Mortal, what e're, who this forbidden Path
In Arms preum't to tread, I charge thee tand,
And tell thy Name, and Buis'nes in the Land.
Know this, the Realm of Night; the Stygian Shore:
My Boat conveys no living Bodies o're:
Nor was I pleas'd great Theeus once to bear;
Who forc'd a Paage with his pointed Spear;
Nor trong Alcides, Men of mighty Fame;
And from th' immortal Gods their Lineage came.
In Fetters one the barking Porter ty'd,
And took him trembling from his Sov'raign's ide:
Two ought by Force to eize his beauteous Bride.
To whom the Sibyl thus, compoe thy Mind:
Nor Frauds are here contriv'd, nor Force deign'd.
Still may the Dog the wand'ring Troops contrain
Of Airy Ghots; and vex the guilty Train;
And with her grily Lord his lovely Queen remain.
The Trojan Chief, whoe Lineage is from Jove,
Much fam'd for Arms, and more for filial Love,
Is ent to eek his Sire, in your Eliian Grove.
If neither Piety, nor Heav'n's Command,
Can gain his Paage to the Stygian Strand,
This fatal Preent hall prevail, at leat;
Then hew'd the hining Bough, conceal'd within her Vet.
No more was needful: for the gloomy God
Stood mute with Awe, to ee the Golden Rod:
Admir'd the detin'd Off'ring to his Queen;
(A venerable Gift o rarely een)
His Fury thus appeas'd, he puts to Land:
The Ghots forake their Seats, at his Command:
He clears the Deck, receives the mighty Freight,
The leaky Veel groans beneath the weight.
Slowly he ails; and carcely tems the Tides:
The preing Water pours within her ides.
His Paengers at length are wafted o're;
Expos'd in muddy Weeds, upon the miry Shore.
No ooner landed, in his Den they found
The triple Porter of the Stygian Sound:
Grim Cerberus; who oon began to rear
His creted Snakes, and arm'd his britling Hair.
The prudent Sibyl had before prepar'd
A Sop, in Honey teep'd, to charm the Guard.
Which, mix'd with pow'rful Drugs, he cat before
His greedy grinning Jaws, jut op'd to roar:
With three enormous Mouths he gapes; and treight,
With Hunger pret, devours the pleaing Bait.
Long draughts of Sleep his montrous Limbs enlave;
He reels, and falling, fills the pacious Cave.
The Keeper charm'd, the Chief without Delay
Pas'd on, and took th' irremeable way.
Before the Gates, the Cries of Babes new born,
Whom Fate had from their tender Mothers torn,
Aault his Ears: Then thoe, whom Form of Laws
Condemn'd to die, when Traitors judg'd their Caue.
Nor want they Lots, nor Judges to review
The wrongful Sentence, and award a new.
Minos, the trict Inquiitor, appears;
And Lives and Crimes, with his Aeors, hears.
Round, in his Urn, the blended Balls he rowls;
Abolves the Jut, and dooms the Guilty Souls.
The next in Place, and Punihment, are they
Who prodigally throw their Souls away.
Fools, who repining at their wretched State,
And loathing anxious life, uborn'd their Fate.
With late Repentance, now they wou'd retrieve
The Bodies they forook, and wih to live.
Their Pains and Poverty deire to bear,
To view the Light of Heav'n, and breath the vital Air:
But Fate forbids; the Stygian Floods oppoe;
And, with nine circling Streams, the captive Souls incloe.
Not far from thence, the mournful Fields appear;
So call'd from Lovers that inhabit there.
The Souls, whom that unhappy Flame invades,
In ecret Solitude, and Myrtle Shades,
Make endles Moans, and pining with Deire,
Lament too late, their unextinguih'd Fire.
Here Procris, Eryphile here, he found
Baring her Breat, yet bleeding with the Wound
Made by her Son. He aw Paiphae there,
With Phaedra's Ghot, a foul incetuous pair;
Chat Laodamia, with Evadne, moves:
Unhappy both; but loyal in their Loves.
Caeneus, a Woman once, and once a Man;
But ending in the Sex he firt began.
Not far from thee Phoenician Dido tood;
Freh from her Wound, her Boom bath'd in Blood.
Whom, when the Trojan Heroe hardly knew,
Obcure in Shades, and with a doubtful view,
(Doubtful as he who ees thro' dusky Night,
Or thinks he ees the Moon's uncertain Light:)
With Tears he firt approach'd the ullen Shade;
And, as his Love inpir'd him, thus he aid.
Unhappy Queen! then is the common breath
Of Rumour true, in your reported Death,
And I, alas, the Caue! by Heav'n, I vow,
And all the Pow'rs that rule the Realms below,

figure.p: To John Pulteney of the Parih of St: James's Westminster Esq.
figure.head: AE. 6. l. 615

lg.l: Unwilling I forook your friendly State:
Commanded by the Gods, and forc'd by Fate.
Thoe Gods, that Fate, whoe unreited Might
Have ent me to thee Regions, void of Light,
Thro' the vat Empire of eternal Night.
Nor dar'd I to preume, that, pres'd with Grief,
My Flight hould urge you to this dire Relief.
Stay, tay your Steps, and liten to my Vows:
'Tis the lat Interview that Fate allows!
In vain he thus attempts her Mind to move,
With Tears, and Pray'rs, and late repenting Love.
Didainfully he look'd; then turning round,
But fix'd her Eyes unmov'd upon the Ground.
And, what he ays, and wears, regards no more
Than the deaf Rocks, when the loud Billows roar.
But whirl'd away, to hun his hateful ight,
Hid in the Foret, and the Shades of Night.
Then ought Sicheus, thro' the hady Grove,
Who anwer'd all her Cares, and equal'd all her Love.
Some pious Tears the pitying Heroe paid;
And follow'd with his Eyes the flitting Shade.
Then took the forward Way, by Fate ordain'd,
And, with his Guide, the farther Fields attain'd;
Where, ever'd from the ret, the Warrior Souls remain'd.
Tideus he met, with Meleager's Race;
The Pride of Armies, and the Souldier's Grace;
And pale Adratus with his ghatly Face.
Of Trojan Chiefs he view'd a num'rous Train:
All much lamented, all in Battel lain.
Glaucus and Medon, high above the ret,
Antenor's Sons, and Ceres acred Priet:
And proud Ideus, Priam's Charioteer;
Who hakes his empty Reins, and aims his Airy Spear.
The gladome Ghots, in circling Troops, attend,
And with unweary'd Eyes behold their Friend.
Delight to hover near; and long to know
What buis'nes brought him to the Realms below.
But Argive Chiefs, and Agamemnon's Train,
When his refulgent Arms flah'd thro' the hady Plain,
Fled from his well known Face, with wonted Fear,
As when his thund'ring Sword, and pointed Spear,
Drove headlong to their Ships, and glean'd the routed Reer.
They rais'd a feeble Cry, with trembling Notes:
But the weak Voice deceiv'd their gaping Throats.
Here Priam's Son, Deiphobus, he found:
Whoe Face and Limbs were one continu'd Wound.
Dihonet, with lop'd Arms, the Youth appears:
Spoil'd of his Noe, and horten'd of his Ears.
He carcely knew him, triving to diown
His blotted Form, and bluhing to be known.
And therefore firt began. O Teucer's Race,
Who durt thy faultles Figure thus deface?
What heart cou'd wih, what hand inflict this dire Digrace?
Twas fam'd, that in our lat and fatal Night,
Your ingle Prowes long utain'd the Fight:
Till tir'd, not forc'd, a glorious Fate you choe:
And fell upon a Heap of laughter'd Foes.
But in remembrance of o brave a Deed,
A Tomb, and Fun'ral Honours I decreed:
Thrice call'd your Manes, on the Trojan Plains:
The place your Armour, and your Name retains.
Your Body too I ought; and had I found,
Deign'd for Burial in your Native Ground.
The Ghot reply'd, your Piety has paid
All needful Rites, to ret my wand'ring Shade:
But cruel Fate, and my more cruel Wife,
To Grecian Swords betray'd my leeping Life.

figure.p: To Christopher Knight Esq of Chanton in Hantshire
figure.head: AE. 6. l. 675.

lg.l: Thee are the Monuments of Helen's Love:
The Shame I bear below, the Marks I bore above.
You know in what deluding Joys we pat
The Night, that was by Heav'n decreed our lat.
For when the fatal Hore, decending down,
Pregnant with Arms, o'rewhelm'd th' unhappy Town;
She feign'd Nocturnal Orgyes: left my Bed,
And, mix'd with Trojan Dames, the Dances led.
Then, waving high her Torch, the Signal made,
Which rouz'd the Grecians from their Ambucade.
With Watching overworn, with Cares oppret,
Unhappy I had laid me down to ret;
And heavy Sleep my weary Limbs poes'd.
Mean time my worthy Wife, our Arms milay'd;
And from beneath my head my Sword convey'd:
The Door unlatch'd; and with repeated calls,
Invites her former Lord within my walls.
Thus in her Crime her confidence he plac'd:
And with new Treaons wou'd redeem the pat.
What need I more, into the Room they ran;
And meanly murther'd a defenceles Man.
Ulyes, baely born, firt led the way:
Avenging Pow'rs! with Jutice if I pray,
That Fortune be their own another day.
But anwer you; and in your turn relate,
What brought you, living, to the Stygian State?
Driv'n by the Winds and Errors of the Sea,
Or did you Heav'ns Superior Doom obey?
Or tell what other Chance conducts your way?
To view, with Mortal Eyes, our dark Retreats,
Tumults and Torments of th' Infernal Seats?
While thus, in talk, the flying Hours they pas,
The Sun had finih'd more than half his Race:
And they, perhaps, in Words and Tears had pent
The little time of tay, which Heav'n had lent.
But thus the Sibyl chides their long delay;
Night ruhes down, and headlong drives the Day:
Tis here, in different Paths, the way divides:
The right, to Pluto's Golden Palace guides:
The left to that unhappy Region tends,
Which to the depth of Tartarus decends;
The Seat of Night profound, and punih'd Fiends.
Then thus Deiphobus: O Sacred Maid!
Forbear to chide; and be your Will Obey'd:
Lo to the ecret Shadows I retire,
To pay my Penance 'till my Years expire.
Proceed Aupicious Prince, with Glory Crownd,
And born to better Fates than I have found.
He aid; and while he aid, his Steps he turn'd
To Secret Shadows; and in ilence Mourn'd.
The Heroe, looking on the left, epy'd
A lofty Tow'r, and trong on ev'ry ide
With treble Walls, which Phlegethon urrounds,
Whoe fiery Flood the burning Empire bounds:
And pres'd betwixt the Rocks, the bellowing noie reounds.
Wide is the fronting Gate, and rais'd on high
With Adamantine Columns, threats the Sky.
Vain is the force of Man, and Heav'ns as van,
To cruh the Pillars which the Pile utain.
Sublime on thee a Tow'r of Steel is rear'd;
And dire Tiiphone there keeps the Ward.
Girt in her anguine Gown, by Night and Day,
Obervant of the Souls that pas the downward way:
From hence are heard the Groans of Ghots, the pains
Of ounding Lahes, and of dragging Chains.
The Trojan tood atonih'd at their Cries;
And ask'd his Guide, from whence thoe Yells arie?
And what the Crimes and what the Tortures were,
And loud Laments that rent the liquid Air?
She thus reply'd: The chat and holy Race,
Are all forbidden this polluted Place.
But Hecate, when he gave to rule the Woods,
Then led me trembling thro' thee dire Abodes:
And taught the Tortures of th' avenging Gods.
Thee are the Realms of unrelenting Fate:
And awful Rhadamanthus rules the State.
He hears and judges each committed Crime;
Enquires into the Manner, Place, and Time.
The concious Wretch mut all his Acts reveal:
Loath to confefs, unable to conceal:
From the firt Moment of his vital Breath,
To his lat Hour of unrepenting Death.
Straight, o're the guilty Ghot, the Fury hakes
The ounding Whip, and brandihes her Snakes:
And the pale Sinner, with her Siters, takes.
Then, of it elf, unfolds th' Eternal Door:
With dreadful Sounds the brazen Hinges roar.
You ee, before the Gate, what talking Ghot
Commands the Guard, what Centries keep the Pot:
More formidable Hydra tands within;
Whoe Jaws with Iron Teeth everely grin.
The gaping Gulph, low to the Centre lies;
And twice as deep as Earth is ditant from the Skies.
The Rivals of the Gods, the Titan Race,
Here ing'd with Lightning, rowl within th' unfathom'd pace.
Here lye th' Alaean Twins, (I aw them both)
Enormous Bodies, of Gigantick Growth;
Who dar'd in Fight the Thund'rer to defy;
Affect his Heav'n, and force him from the Sky.

l.U: uff'ring cruel Pains, I found,

lg.l: For emulating Jove; the ratling Sound
Of Mimick Thunder, and the glitt'ring Blaze
Of pointed Lightnings, and their forky Rays.
Through Elis, and the Grecian Towns he flew:
Th' audacious Wretch four fiery Courers drew:
He wav'd a Torch aloft, and, madly vain,
Sought Godlike Worhip from a Servile Train.
Ambitious Fool, with horny Hoofs to pas
O're hollow Arches, of reounding Bras;
To rival Thunder, in its rapid Coure:
And imitate inimitable Force.
But he, the King of Heav'n, obcure on high,
Bar'd his red Arm, and launching from the Sky
His writhen Bolt, not haking empty Smoak,
Down to the deep Abys the flaming Felon trook.
There Tityus was to ee; who took his Birth
From Heav'n, his Nuring from the foodful Earth.
Here his Gygantic Limbs, with large Embrace,
Infold nine Acres of Infernal Space.
A rav'nous Vulture in his open'd ide,
Her crooked Beak and cruel Tallons try'd:
Still for the growing Liver dig'd his Breat;
The growing Liver till upply'd the Feat.
Still are his Entrails fruitful to their Pains:
Th' immortal Hunger lats, th' immortal Food remains.
Ixion and Perithous I cou'd name;
And more Thealian Chiefs of mighty Fame.
High o're their Heads a mould'ring Rock is plac'd,
That promies a fall; and hakes at ev'ry Blat.
They lye below, on Golden Beds diplay'd,
And genial Feats, with Regal Pomp, are made.
The Queen of Furies by their ides is et;
And natches from their Mouths th' untated Meat.
Which, if they touch, her hiing Snakes he rears:
Toing her Torch, and thund'ring in their Ears.
Then they, who Brothers better Claim diown,
Expel their Parents, and uurp the Throne;
Defraud their Clients, and to Lucre old,
Sit brooding on unprofitable Gold:
Who dare not give, and ev'n refue to lend
To their poor Kindred, or a wanting Friend:
Vat is the Throng of thee; nor les the Train
Of lutful Youths, for foul Adultry lain.
Hots of Deerters, who their Honour old,
And baely broke their Faith for Bribes of Gold:
All thee within the Dungeon's depth remain:
Depairing Pardon, and expecting Pain.
Ask not what Pains; nor farther eek to know
Their Proces, or the Forms of Law below.
Some rowl a weighty Stone; ome laid along,
And bound with burning Wires, on Spokes of Wheels are hung.
Unhappy Theeus, doom'd for ever there,
Is fix'd by Fate on his Eternal Chair:
And wretched Phlegias warns the World with Cries;
(Cou'd Warning make the World more jut or wie,)
Learn Righteounes, and dread th' avenging Deities.
To Tyrants others have their Country old,
Impoing Foreign Lords, for Foreign Gold:
Some have old Laws repeal'd, new Statutes made;
Not as the People pleas'd, but as they paid.
With Incet ome their Daughters Bed prophan'd,
All dar'd the wort of Ills, and what they dar'd, attain'd.
Had I a hundred Mouths, a hundred Tongues,
And Throats of Bras, inpir'd with Iron Lungs,
I could not half thoe horrid Crimes repeat:
Nor half the Punihments thoe Crimes have met.
But let us hate our Voyage to purue;
The Walls of Pluto's Palace are in view.
The Gate, and Iron Arch above it, tands:
On Anvils labour'd by the Cyclops Hands.
Before our farther way the Fates allow,
Here mut we fix on high the Golden Bough.
She aid, and thro' the gloomy Shades they pat,
And choe the middle Path: Arriv'd at lat,
The Prince, with living Water, prinkl'd o're
His Limbs, and Body; then approach'd the Door.
Poes'd the Porch, and on the Front above
He fix'd the fatal Bough, requir'd by Pluto's Love.
Thee Holy Rites perform'd, they took their Way,
Where long extended Plains of Pleaure lay.
The verdant Fields with thoe of Heav'n may vye;
With Aether veted, and a Purple Sky:
The blisful Seats of Happy Souls below:
Stars of their own, and their own Suns they know.
Their Airy Limbs in Sports they exercie,
And, on the Green, contend the Wretler's Prize.
Some, in Heroick Vere, divinely ing;
Others in artful Meaures lead the ring.
The Thracian Bard, urrounded by the ret,
There tands conpicuous in his flowing Vet.
His flying Fingers, and harmonious Quill,
Strike ev'n ditinguih'd Notes, and ev'n at once they fill.
Here found they Teucer's old Heroick Race;
Born better times and happier Years to grace.
Aaracus and Ilus here enjoy
Perpetual Fame, with him who founded Troy.
The Chief beheld their Chariots from afar;
Their hining Arms, and Courers train'd to War:
Their Lances fix'd in Earth, their Steeds around,
Free from their Harnes, graze the flow'ry Ground.
The love of Hores which they had, alive,
And care of Chariots, after Death urvive.
Some chearful Souls, were feating on the Plain;
Some did the Song, and ome the Choir maintain.
Beneath a Laurel Shade, where mighty Po
Mounts up to Woods above, and hides his Head below.
Here Patriots live, who, for their Countries good,
In fighting Fields, were prodigal of Blood:
Priets of unblemih'd Lives here make Abode;
And Poets worthy their inpiring God:
And earching Wits, of more Mechanick parts,
Who grac'd their Age with new invented Arts.
Thoe who, to worth, their Bounty did extend;
And thoe who knew that Bounty to commend.
The Heads of thee with holy Fillets bound;
And all their Temples were with Garlands crown'd.
To thee the Sibyl thus her Speech addres'd:
And firt, to him urrounded by the ret;
Tow'ring his Height, and ample was his Breat;
Say happy Souls, Divine Muaeus ay,
Where lives Anchies, and where lies our Way
To find the Heroe, for whoe only ake
We ought the dark Abodes, and cros'd the bitter Lake?
To this the Sacred Poet thus reply'd;
In no fix'd place the Happy Souls reide.
In Groves we live; and lye on moy Beds
By Crytal Streams, that murmur through the Meads:
But pas yon eaie Hill, and thence decend,
The Path conducts you to your Journeys end.
This aid, he led them up the Mountains brow,
And hews them all the hining Fields below;
They wind the Hill, and thro' the blisful Meadows go.
But old Anchies, in a flow'ry Vale,
Review'd his muter'd Race; and took the Tale.
Thoe Happy Spirits, which ordain'd by Fate,
For future Beings, and new Bodies wait.
With tudious Thought oberv'd th' illutrious Throng;
In Nature's Order as they pas'd along.
Their Names, their Fates, their Conduct, and their Care,
In peaceful Senates, and uccesful War.
He, when Aeneas on the Plain appears,
Meets him with open Arms, and falling Tears.
Welcome, he aid, the Gods undoubted Race,
O long expected to my dear Embrace;
Once more 'tis giv'n me to behold your Face!
The Love, and Pious Duty which you pay,
Have pas'd the Perils of o hard a way.
'Tis true, computing times, I now believ'd
The happy Day approach'd; nor are my Hopes deceiv'd.
What length of Lands, what Oceans have you pas'd,
What Storms utain'd, and on what Shores been cat?
How have I fear'd your Fate! But fear'd it mot,
When Love aail'd you, on the Lybian Coat.
To this, the Filial Duty thus replies;
Your acred Ghot, before my leeping Eyes,
Appear'd; and often urg'd this painful Enterprie.
After long toing on the Tyrrhene Sea,
My Navy rides at Anchor in the Bay.
But reach your Hand, oh Parent Shade, nor hun
The dear Embraces of your longing Son!
He aid; and falling Tears his Face bedew:
Then thrice, around his Neck, his Arms he threw;
And thrice the flitting Shadow lip'd away;
Like Winds, or empty Dreams that fly the Day.
Now in a ecret Vale, the Trojan ees
A ep'rate Grove, thro' which a gentle Breeze
Plays with a paing Breath, and whipers thro' the Trees.
And jut before the Confines of the Wood,
The gliding Lethe leads her ilent Flood.
About the Boughs an Airy Nation flew,
Thick as the humming Bees, that hunt the Golden Dew;
In Summer's heat, on tops of Lillies feed,
And creep within their Bells, to uck the balmy Seed.
The winged Army roams the Fields around;
The Rivers and the Rocks remurmur to the ound.
Aeneas wond'ring tood: Then ask'd the Caue,
Which to the Stream the Crowding People draws.
Then thus the Sire. The Souls that throng the Flood
Are thoe, to Whom, by Fate, are other Bodies ow'd:
In Lethe's Lake they long Oblivion tat;
Of future Life ecure, forgetful of the Pat.
Long has my Soul deir'd this time, and place,
To et before your ight your glorious Race.
That this preaging Joy may fire your Mind,
To eek the Shores by Detiny deign'd.
O Father, can it be, that Souls ublime,
Return to viit our Terretrial Clime?
And that the Gen'rous Mind, releas'd by Death,
Can Covet lazy Limbs, and Mortal Breath?
Anchies then, in order, thus begun
To clear thoe Wonders to his Godlike Son.
Know firt, that Heav'n, and Earth's compacted Frame,
And flowing Waters, and the tarry Flame,
And both the Radiant Lights, one Common Soul
Inpires, and feeds, and animates the whole.
This Active Mind infus'd through all the Space,
Unites and mingles with the mighty Mas.
Hence Men and Beats the Breath of Life obtain;
And Birds of Air, and Monters of the Main.
Th' Etherial Vigour is in all the ame,
And every Soul is fill'd with equal Flame:
As much as Earthy Limbs, and gros allay
Of Mortal Members, ubject to decay,
Blunt not the Beams of Heav'n and edge of Day.
From this coure Mixture of Terretial parts,
Deire, and Fear, by turns poes their Hearts:
And Grief, and Joy: Nor can the groveling Mind,
In the dark Dungeon of the Limbs confin'd,
Aert the Native Skies; or own its heav'nly Kind.
Nor Death it elf can wholly wah their Stains;
But long contracted Filth, ev'n in the Soul remains.
The Reliques of inveterate Vice they wear;
And Spots of Sin obcene, in ev'ry Face appear.
For this are various Penances enjoyn'd;
And ome are hung to bleach, upon the Wind;
Some plung'd in Waters, others purg'd in Fires,
Till all the Dregs are drain'd: and all the Rut expires:
All have their Manes, and thoe Manes bear:
The few, o cleans'd to thee Abodes repair:
And breath, in ample Fields, the oft Elyian Air.
Then are they happy, when by length of time
The Scurf is worn away, of each committed Crime.
No Speck is left, of their habitual Stains;
But the pure Aether of the Soul remains.
But, when a Thouand rowling Years are pat,
(So long their Punihments and Penance lat;)
Whole Droves of Minds are, by the driving God,
Compell'd to drink the deep Lethaean Flood:
In large forgetful draughts to teep the Cares
Of their pat Labours, and their Irkom Years.
That, unrememb'ring of its former Pain,
The Soul may uffer mortal Fleh again.
Thus having aid; the Father Spirit, leads
The Prietes and his Son through Swarms of Shades.
And takes a riing Ground, from thence to ee
The long Proceion of his Progeny.
Survey (puru'd the Sire) this airy Throng;
As, offer'd to thy view, they pas along.
Thee are th' Italian Names, which Fate will join
With ours, and graff upon the Trojan Line.
Oberve the Youth who firt appears in ight;
And holds the nearet Station to the Light:
Already eems to nuff the vital Air;
And leans jut forward, on a hining Spear,
Silvius is he: thy lat begotten Race;
But firt in order ent, to fill thy place,
An Alban Name; but mix'd with Dardan Blood;
Born in the Covert of a hady Wood:
Him fair Lavinia, thy urviving Wife,
Shall breed in Groves, to lead a olitary Life.
In Alba he hall fix his Royal Seat:
And, born a King, a Race of Kings beget.
Then Procas, Honour of the Trojan Name,
Capys, and Numitor, of endles Fame.
A econd Silvius after thee appears;
Silvius Aeneas, for thy Name he bears.
For Arms and Jutice equally renown'd;
Who, late retor'd, in Alba hall be crown'd.
How great they look, how vig'rouly they wield
Their weighty Lances, and utain the Shield!
But they, who crown'd with Oaken Wreaths appear,
Shall Gabian Walls, and trong Fidena rear:
Nomentum, Bola, with Pometia, found;
And raie Colatian Tow'rs on Rocky Ground.
All thee hall then be Towns of mighty Fame;
Tho' now they lye obcure; and Lands without a Name.
See Romulus the great, born to retore
The Crown that once his injur'd Grandire wore.
This Prince, a Prietes of our Blood hall bear;
And like his Sire in Arms he hall appear.
Two riing Crets his Royal Head adorn;
Born from a God, himelf to Godhead born.
His Sire already igns him for the Skies,
And marks his Seat amidt the Deities.
Aupicious Chief! thy Race in times to come
Shall pread the Conquets of Imperial Rome.
Rome whoe acending Tow'rs hall Heav'n invade;
Involving Earth and Ocean in her Shade.
High as the Mother of the Gods in place;
And proud, like her, of an Immortal Race.
Then when in Pomp he makes the Phrygian round;
With Golden Turrets on her Temples crown'd:
A hundred Gods her weeping Train upply;
Her Offspring all, and all command the Sky.
Now fix your Sight, and tand intent, to ee
Your Roman Race, and Julian Progeny.
The mighty Caear waits his vital Hour;
Impatient for the World, and graps his promis'd Pow'r.
But next behold the Youth of Form Divine,
Caear himelf, exalted in his Line;
Augutus, promis'd oft, and long foretold,
Sent to the Realm that Saturn rul'd of old;
Born to retore a better Age of Gold.
Affrick, and India, hall his Pow'r obey,
He hall extend his propagated Sway,
Beyond the Solar Year; without the tarry Way.
Where Atlas turns the rowling Heav'ns around;
And his broad Shoulders with their Lights are crown'd.
At his fore-een Approach, already quake
The Capian Kingdoms, and Maeotian Lake.
Their Seers behold the Tempet from afar;
And threatning Oracles denounce the War.
Nile hears him knocking at his ev'nfold Gates;
And eeks his hidden Spring, and fears his Nephew's Fates
Nor Hercules more Lands or Labours knew,
Not tho' the brazen-footed Hind he lew;

figure.p: To Robert Harley of Bramton Catle in ye County of Hereford Esq
figure.head: AE. 6. l. 1085.

lg.l: Freed Erymanthus from the foaming Boar,
And dip'd his Arrows in Lernaean Gore.
Nor Bacchus, turning from his Indian War,
By Tygers drawn triumphant in his Car,
From Nius top decending on the Plains;
With curling Vines around his purple Reins.
And doubt we yet thro' Dangers to purue
The Paths of Honour, and a Crown in view?
But what's the Man, who from afar appears,
His Head with Olive crown'd, his Hand a Cener bears?
His hoary Beard, and holy Vetments bring
His lot Idea back: I know the Roman King.
He hall to peaceful Rome new Laws ordain:
Call'd from his mean abode, a Scepter to utain.
Him, Tullus next in Dignity ucceeds;
An active Prince, and prone to Martial Deeds.
For fighting Fields his Troops he hall prepare,
Dius'd to Toils, and Triumphs of the War.
By dint of Sword his Crown he hall increae;
And cour his Armour from the Rut of Peace.
Whom Ancus follows, with a fawning Air;
But vain within, and proudly popular.
Next view the Tarquin Kings: Th' avenging Sword
Of Brutus, jutly drawn, and Rome retor'd.
He firt renews the Rods, and Axe evere;
And gives the Conuls Royal Robes to wear.
His Sons, who eek the Tyrant to utain,
And long for Arbitrary Lords again,
With Ignominy courg'd, in open ight,
He dooms to Death deerv'd; aerting Publick Right.
Unhappy Man, to break the Pious Laws
Of Nature, pleading in his Children's Caue!
Howe're the doubtful Fact is undertood,
'Tis Love of Honour, and his Country's good:
The Conul, not the Father, heds the Blood.
Behold Torquatus the ame Track purue;
And next, the three devoted Decij view.
The Druian Line, Camillus loaded home
With Standards well redeem'd, and foreign Foes o'recome.
The Pair you ee in equal Armour hine;
(Now, Friends below, in cloe Embraces join:
But when they leave the hady Realms of Night,
And, cloath'd in Bodies, breath your upper Light,)
With mortal Hate each other hall purue:
What Wars, what Wounds, what Slaughter hall enue!
From Alpine Heights the Father firt decends;
His Daughter's Husband in the Plain attends:
His Daughter's Husband arms his Eatern Friends.
Embrace again, my Sons, be Foes no more:
Nor tain your Country with her Childrens Gore.
And thou, the firt, lay down thy lawles claim;
Thou, of my Blood, who bear't the Julian Name.
Another comes, who hall in Triumph ride;
And to the Capitol his Chariot guide;
From conquer'd Corinth, rich with Grecian Spoils.
And yet another, fam'd for Warlike Toils,
On Argos hall impoe the Roman Laws:
And, on the Greeks, revenge the Trojan Caue:
Shall drag in Chains their Achillaean Race;
Shall vindicate his Ancetors Digrace:
And Pallas, for her violated Place.
Great Cato there, for Gravity renown'd,
And conqu'ring Cous goes with Lawrels crown'd.
Who can omit the Gracchi, who declare
The Scipio's Worth, thoe Thunderbolts of War,
The double Bane of Carthage? Who can ee,
Without eteem for virtuous Poverty,
Severe Fabritius, or can ceae t' admire
The Ploughman Conul in his Coure Attire!
Tir'd as I am, my Praie the Fabij claim;
And thou great Heroe, greatet of thy Name;
Ordain'd in War to ave the inking State,
And, by Delays, to put a top to Fate!
Let others better mold the running Mas
Of Mettals, and inform the breathing Bras;
And often into Fleh a Marble Face:
Plead better at the Bar; decribe the Skies,
And when the Stars decend, and when they rie.
But, Rome, 'tis thine alone, with awful way,
To rule Mankind; and make the World obey;
Dipoing Peace, and War, thy own Majetick Way.
To tame the Proud, the fetter'd Slave to free;
Thee are Imperial Arts, and worthy thee.
He paus'd: And while with wond'ring Eyes they view'd
The paing Spirits, thus his Speech renew'd.
See great Marcellus! how, untir'd in Toils,
He moves with Manly grace, how rich with Regal Spoils
He, when his Country, (threaten'd with Alarms,)
Requires his Courage, and his Conqu'ring Arms,
Shall more than once the Punic Bands affright:
Shall kill the Gaulih King in ingle Fight:
Then, to the Capitol in Triumph move,
And the third Spoils hall grace Feretrian Jove.
Aeneas, here, beheld of Form Divine
A Godlike Youth, in glitt'ring Armour hine:
With great Marcellus keeping equal pace;
But gloomy were his Eyes, dejected was his Face:
He aw, and, wond'ring, ask'd his airy Guide,
What, and of whence was he, who pres'd the Hero's ide?
His Son, or one of his Illutrious Name,
How like the former, and almot the ame:
Oberve the Crowds that compas him around;
All gaze, and all admire, and raie a houting ound:
But hov'ring Mits around his Brows are pread,
And Night, with able Shades, involves his Head.
Seek not to know (the Ghot reply'd with Tears)
The Sorrows of thy Sons, in future Years.
This Youth (the blisful Viion of a day)
Shall jut be hown on Earth, and natch'd away.
The Gods too high had rais'd the Roman State;
Were but their Gifts as permanent as great.
What groans of Men hall fill the Martian Field!
How fierce a Blaze his flaming Pile hall yield!
What Fun'ral Pomp hall floating Tiber ee,
When, riing from his Bed, he views the ad Solemnity!
No Youth hall equal hopes of Glory give:
No Youth afford o great a Caue to grieve.
The Trojan Honour, and the Roman Boat;
Admir'd when living, and Ador'd when lot!
Mirror of ancient Faith in early Youth!
Undaunted Worth, Inviolable Truth!
No Foe unpunih'd in the fighting Field,
Shall dare thee Foot to Foot, with Sword and Shield.
Much les, in Arms oppoe thy matchles Force,
When thy harp Spurs hall urge thy foaming Hore.
Ah, cou'dt thou break through Fates evere Decree,
A new Marcellus hall arie in thee!
Full Caniters of fragrant Lillies bring,
Mix'd with the Purple Roes of the Spring:
Let me with Fun'ral Flow'rs his Body trow;
This Gift which Parents to their Children owe,
This unavailing Gift, at leat I may betow!
Thus having aid, He led the Heroe round
The confines of the blet Elyian Ground.
Which, when Anchies to his Son had hown,
And fir'd his Mind to mount the promis'd Throne,
He tells the future Wars, ordain'd by Fate;
The Strength and Cutoms of the Latian State:
The Prince, and People: And fore-arms his Care
With Rules, to puh his Fortune, or to bear.
Two Gates the ilent Houe of Sleep adorn;
Of polih'd Iv'ry this, that of tranparent Horn:
Of various things dicouring as he pas'd,
Anchies hither bends his Steps at lat.
Then, through the Gate of Iv'ry, he dimis'd
His valiant Offspring, and Divining Guet.
Streight to the Ships Aeneas took his way;
Embarqu'd his Men, and skim'd along the Sea:
Still Coating, till he gain'd Cajeta's Bay.
At length on Oozy ground his Gallies moor:
Their Heads are turn'd to Sea, their Sterns to Shoar.

div.head: The Seventh Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: King Latinus entertains Aeneas, and promies him his only Daughter, Lavinia, the Heires of his Crown. Turnus being in Love with her, favour'd by her Mother, and tir'd up by Juno, and Alecto, breaks the Treaty which was made, and engages in his Quarrel, Mezentius, Camilla, Meapus, and many others of the Neighbouring Princes; whoe Forces and the Names of their Commanders are here particularly related.

lg.l: AND thou, O Matron of Immortal Fame!
Here Dying, to the Shore hat left thy Name:

l.U: till the place is call'd from thee,

lg.l: The Nure of great Aeneas Infancy.
Here ret thy Bones in rich Heperia's Plains,
Thy Name ('tis all a Ghot can have) remains.
Now, when the Prince her Fun'ral Rites had paid,
He plough'd the Tyrrhene Seas with Sails diplay'd.
From Land a gentle Breeze aroe by Night,
Serenely hone the Stars, the Moon was bright,
And the Sea trembled with her Silver Light.
Now near the Shelves of Circe's Shores they run,
(Circe the rich, the Daughter of the Sun)
A dang'rous Coat: The Goddes wats her Days
In joyous Songs, the Rocks reound her Lays:
In pinning, or the Loom, he pends the Night,
And Cedar Brands upply her Father's Light.
From hence were heard, (rebellowing to the Main,)
The Roars of Lyons that refue the Chain,
The Grunts of Britled Boars, and Groans of Bears,
And Herds of Howling Wolves that tun the Sailors Ears.

figure.p: To the Right Honble Henry Earle of Romney Vicount Sydney of Shippy Baron Milton Mater Generall of the Ordinance Ld Warden of the Cinque Ports &ct
figure.head: AE. 7. l: 2.

lg.l: Thee from their Caverns, at the cloe of Night,
Fill the ad Ile with Horror and Affright.
Darkling they mourn their Fate, whom Circe's Pow'r
(That watch'd the Moon, and Planetary Hour)
With Words and wicked Herbs, from Human Kind
Had alter'd, and in Brutal Shapes confin'd.
Which Monters, let the Trojans pious Hot
Shou'd bear, or touch upon th' inchanted Coat;
Propitious Neptune teer'd their Coure by Night,
With riing Gales, that ped their happy Flight.
Supply'd with thee, they skim the ounding Shore,
And hear the welling Surges vainly roar.
Now when the roie Morn began to rie,
And wav'd her Saffron Streamer thro' the Skies;
When Thetis bluh'd in Purple, not her own,
And from her Face the breathing Winds were blown:
A udden Silence ate upon the Sea,
And weeping Oars, with Strugling, urge their Way.
The Trojan, from the Main beheld a Wood,
Which thick with Shades, and a brown Horror, tood:
Betwixt the Trees the Tyber took his Coure,
With Whirlpools dimpled; and with downward Force.
That drove the Sand along, he took his Way,
And rowl'd his yellow Billows to the Sea.
About him, and above, and round the Wood,
The Birds that haunt the Borders of his Flood;
That bath'd within, or bask'd upon his ide,
To tuneful Songs their narrow Throats apply'd.
The Captain gives Command, the joyful Train
Glide thro' the gloomy Shade, and leave the Main.
Now, Erato, thy Poet's Mind inpire,
And fill his Soul with thy Coeletial Fire.
Relate what Latium was, her ancient Kings:
Declare the pat, and preent State of things,
When firt the Trojan Fleet Auonia ought;
And how the Rivals lov'd, and how they fought.
Thee are my Theme, and how the War began,
And how concluded by the Godlike Man.
For I hall ing of Battels, Blood, and Rage,
Which Princes, and their People did engage:
And haughty Souls, that mov'd with mutual Hate,
In fighting Fields puru'd and found their Fate:
That rouz'd the Tyrrhene Realm with loud Alarms,
And peaceful Italy involv'd in Arms.
A larger Scene of Action is diplay'd,
And, riing hence, a greater Work is weigh'd.
Latinus old and mild, had long poes'd
The Latian Scepter, and his People bles'd:
His Father Faunus: a Laurentian Dame
His Mother, fair Marica was her Name.
But Faunus came from Picus, Picus drew
His Birth from Saturn, if Records be true.
Thus King Latinus, in the third Degree,
Had Saturn Author of his Family.
But this old peaceful Prince, as Heav'n decreed,
Was bles'd with no Male Iue to ucceed:
His Sons in blooming Youth were natch'd by Fate;
One only Daughter heir'd the Royal State.
Fir'd with her Love, and with Ambition led,
The neighb'ring Princes court her nuptial Bed.
Among the Crowd, but far above the ret,
Young Turnus to the Beauteous Maid addres'd.
Turnus, for great Decent, and graceful Meen,
Was firt, and favour'd by the Latian Queen:
With him he trove to join Lavinia's Hand:
But dire Portents the purpos'd Match withtand.
Deep in the Palace, of long Growth there tood
A Lawrels Trunk, a venerable Wood;
Where Rites Divine were paid; whoe holy Hair
Was kept, and cut with upertitious Care.
This Plant Latinus, when his Town he wall'd,
Then found, and from the Tree Laurentum call'd:
And lat in Honour of his new Abode,
He vow'd the Lawrel, to the Lawrel's God.
It happen'd once, (a bodeing Prodigy,)
A warm of Bees, that cut the liquid Sky,
Unknown from whence they took their airy flight,
Upon the topmot Branch in Clouds alight:
There, with their claping Feet together clung,
And a long Cluter rom the Lawrel hung.
An ancient Augur prophey'd from hence:
Behold on Latian Shores a foreign Prince!
From the ame parts of Heav'n his Navy tands,
To the ame parts on Earth: his Army lands;
The Town he conquers, and the Tow'r commands.
Yet more, when fair Lavinia fed the Fire
Before the Gods, and tood beide her Sire;
Strange to relate, the Flames, involv'd in Smoke
Of Incene, from the acred Altar broke;
Caught her dihevell'd Hair, and rich Attire;
Her Crown and Jewels crackled in the Fire:
From thence the fuming Trail began to pread,
And lambent Glories danc'd about her Head.
This new Portent the Seer with Wonder views;
Then pauing, thus his Prophecy renews.
The Nymph who catters flaming Fires around,
Shall hine with Honour, hall herelf be crown'd:
But, caus'd by her irrevocable Fate,
War hall the Country wate, and change the State.
Latinus, frighted with this dire Otent,
For Counel to his Father Faunus went:
And ought the Shades renown'd for Prophecy,
Which near Albunea's ulph'rous Fountain lye.
To thee the Latian, and the Sabine Land
Fly, when ditres'd, and thence Relief demand.
The Priet on Skins of Off'rings takes his Eae;
And nightly Viions in his Slumber ees:
A warm of thin aerial Shapes appears,
And, flutt'ring round his Temples, deafs his Ears:
Thee he conults, the future Fates to know,
From Pow'rs above, and from the Fiends below.
Here, for the Gods advice, Latinus flies,
Off'ring a hundred Sheep for Sacrifice:
Their wooly Fleeces, as the Rites requir'd,
He laid beneath him, and to Ret retir'd.
No ooner were his Eyes in Slumber bound,
When, from above, a more than Mortal Sound
Invades his Ears; and thus the Viion poke:
