Seek not, my Seed, in Latian Bands to Yoke
Our fair Lavinia, nor the Gods provoke.
A foreign Son upon thy Shore decends,
Whoe Martial Fame from Pole to Pole extends.
His Race in Arms, and Arts of Peace renown'd,
Not Latium hall contain, nor Europe bound:
'Tis theirs what e're the Sun urveys around.
Thee Anwers in the ilent Night receiv'd,
The King himelf divulg'd, the Land believ'd:
The Fame through all the Neighb'ring Nations flew,
When now the Trojan Navy was in view.
Beneath a hady Tree the Heroe pread
His Table on the Turf, with Cakes of Bread;
And, with his Chiefs, on Foret Fruits he fed.
They ate, and (not without the God's Command)
Their homely Fare dipatch'd; the hungry Band

figure.p: To Anthony Henley of ye Grange in Hanthire Esqr:
figure.head: AE. 7 l. 152

lg.l: Invade their Trenchers next, and oon devour,
To mend the canty Meal, their Cakes of Flow'r.
Acanius this oberv'd, and, miling, aid,
See, we devour the Plates on which we fed.
The Speech had Omen, that the Trojan Race
Shou'd find Repoe, and this the Time and Place.
Aeneas took the Word, and thus replies;
(Confeing Fate with Wonder in his Eyes)
All hail, O Earth! all hail my houehold Gods,
Behold the detin'd place of your Abodes!
For thus Anchies prophey'd of old,
And this our fatal place of Ret foretold.
"When on a Foreign Shore, intead of Meat,
"By Famine forc'd, your Trenchers you hall eat;
"Then Eae your weary Trojans will attend:
"And the long Labours of your Voyage end.
"Remember on that happy Coat to build:
"And with a Trench incloe the fruitful Field.
This was that Famine, this the fatal place,
Which ends the Wand'ring of our exil'd Race.
Then, on to Morrow's Dawn, your Care employ,
To earch the Land, and where the Cities lye,
And what the Men; but give this Day to Joy.
Now pour to Jove, and after Jove is blet,
Call great Anchies to the Genial Feat:
Crown high the Goblets with a chearful Draught;
Enjoy the preent Hour, adjourn the future Thought.
Thus having aid, the Heroe bound his Brows.
With leafy Branches, then perform'd his Vows:
Adoring firt the Genius of the Place;
Then Earth, the Mother of the Heav'nly Race;
The Nymphs, and native Godheads yet unknown,
And Night, and all the Stars that guild her able Throne.
And ancient Cybel, and Idaean Jove;
And lat his Sire below, and Mother Queen above.
Then Heav'ns high Monarch thundred thrice aloud,
And thrice he hook aloft, a Golden Cloud.
Soon thro' the joyful Camp a Rumor flew,
The time was come their City to renew:
Then ev'ry Brow with chearful Green is crown'd,
The Feats are doubl'd, and the Bowls go round.
When next the roie Morn diclos'd the Day,
The Scouts to ev'ral parts divide their Way,
To learn the Natives Names, their Towns, explore
The Coats, and Trendings of the crooked Shore:
Here Tyber flows, and here Numicus tands,
Here warlike Latins hold the happy Lands.
The Pious Chief, who ought by peaceful Ways,
To found his Empire, and his Town to raie;
A hundred Youths from all his Train elects;
And to the Latian Court their Coure directs:
(The pacious Palace where their Prince reides;)
And all their heads with Wreaths of Olive hides.
They go commiion'd to require a Peace;
And carry Preents to procure Acces.
Thus while they peed their Pace, the Prince deigns
His new elected Seat, and draws the Lines:
The Trojans round the place a Rampire cat,
And Paliades about the Trenches plac'd.
Mean time the Train, proceeding on their way,
From far the Town, and lofty Tow'rs urvey:
At length approach the Walls: without the Gate
They ee the Boys, and Latian Youth debate
The Martial Prizes on the duty Plain;
Some drive the Cars, and ome the Courers rein:
Some bend the tubborn Bow for Victory;
And ome with Darts their active Sinews try.
A poting Meenger dipatch'd from hence,
Of this fair Troop advis'd their aged Prince;
That foreign Men, of mighty Stature, came;
Uncouth their Habit, and unknown their Name.
The King ordains their entrance, and acends
His Regal Seat, urrounded by his Friends.
The Palace built by Picus, vat and Proud,
Supported by a hundred Pillars tood
And round incompas'd with a riing Wood.
The Pile o'relook'd the Town, and drew the ight;
Surpriz'd at once with Reverence and Delight.
There Kings receiv'd the Marks of Sov'raign Pow'r:
In State the Monarchs march'd, the Lictors bore
Their Awful Axes, and the Rods before.
Here the Tribunal tood, the Houe of Pray'r;
And here the acred Senators repair:
All at large Tables, in long order et,
A Ram their Off'ring, and a Ram their Meat.
Above the Portal, Carv'd in Cedar Wood,
Plac'd in their Ranks, their Godlike Grandires tood.
Old Saturn, with his crooked Scythe, on high;
And Italus, that led the Colony:
And ancient Janus, with his double Face,
And Bunch of Keys, the Porter of the place.
There good Sabinus, planter of the Vines,
On a hort Pruning-hook his Head reclines:
And tudiouly urveys his gen'rous Wines.
Then Warlike Kings, who for their Country fought,
And honourable Wounds from Battel brought.
Around the Pots hung Helmets, Darts, and Spears;
And Captive Chariots, Axes, Shields, and Bars,
And broken Beaks of Ships, the Trophies of their Wars.
Above the ret, as Chief of all the Band,
Was Picus plac'd, a Buckler in his hand;
His other wav'd a long divining Wand.
Girt in his Gabin Gown the Heroe ate:
Yet could not with his Art avoid his Fate.
For Circe long had lov'd the Youth in vain,
Till Love, refus'd, converted to Disdain:
Then mixing pow'rful Herbs, with Magic Art,
She chang'd his Form, who cou'd not change his heart.
Contrain'd him in a Bird, and made him fly,
With party-colour'd Plumes, a Chattring Pye.
On this high Temple, on a Chair of State,
The Seat of Audience, old Latinus ate;
Then gave admiffion to the Trojan Train,
And thus, with pleaing accents, he b • gan.
Tell me, ye Trojans, for that Name you own,
Nor is your Coure upon our Coats unknown;
Say what you eek, and whither were you bound?
Were you by tres of Weather cat a-ground?
Such dangers as on Seas are often een,
And oft befall to mierable Men?
Or come, your Shipping in our Ports to lay,
Spent and diabl'd in o long a way?
Say what you want, the Latians you hall find
Not forc'd to Goodnes, but by Will inclin'd:
For ince the time of Saturn's holy Reign,
His Hopitable Cutoms we retain.
I call to mind, but (Time the Tale has worn,)
Th' Arunci told; that Dardanus, tho' born
On Latian Plains, yet ought the Phrygian Shore,
And Samothracia, Samos call'd before:
From Tucan Coritum he claim'd his Birth,
But after, when exempt from Mortal Earth,
From thence acended to his kindred Skies,
A God, and as a God augments their Sacrifice.
He aid. Ilioneus made this Reply,
O King, of Faunus Royal Family!

figure.p: To George Stepney Esqr. His Maties. Envoy Extrary: to Severall Princes in, Germany and one of the Coincill of Trade
figure.head: AE. 7. l. 2 ••

lg.l: Nor Wint'ry Winds to Latium forc'd our way,
Nor did the Stars our wand'ring Coure betray.
Willing we ought your Shores, and hither bound,
The Port o long deir'd, at length we found.
From our weet Homes and ancient Realms expell'd;
Great as the greatet that the Sun beheld.
The God began our Line, who rules above,
And as our Race, our King decends from Jove:
And hither are we come, by his Command,
To crave Admiion in your happy Land.
How dire a Tempet, from Mycenae pour'd,
Our Plains, our Temples, and our Town devour'd;
What was the Wate of War, what fierce Alarms
Shook Aia's Crown with Europaean Arms;
Ev'n uch have heard, if any uch there be,
Whoe Earth is bounded by the frozen Sea:
And uch as born beneath the burning Sky,
And ultry Sun betwixt the Tropicks lye.
From that dire Deluge, through the wat'ry Wate,
Such length of Years, uch various Perils pat:
At lat ecap'd, to Latium we repair,
To beg what you without your Want may pare;
The common Water, and the common Air.
Sheds which our elves will build, and mean abodes,
Fit to receive and erve our banih'd Gods.
Nor our Admiion hall your Realm digrace,
Nor length of time our Gratitude efface.
Beides, what endles Honour you hall gain
To ave and helter Troy's unhappy Train.
Now, by my Sov'raign, and his Fate I wear,
Renown'd for Faith in Peace, for Force in War;
Oft our Alliance other Lands deir'd,
And what we eek of you, of us requir'd.
Depie not then, that in our Hands we bear
Thee Holy Boughs, and ue with Words of Pray'r.
Fate and the Gods, by their upreme Command,
Have doom'd our Ships to eek the Latian Land.
To thee abodes our Fleet Apollo ends;
Here Dardanus was born, and hither tends:
Where Thucan Tyber rowls with rapid Force,
And where Numicus opes his Holy Source.
Beides our Prince preents, with his Requet,
Some mall Remains of what his Sire poes'd.
This Golden Charger, natch'd from burning Troy,
Anchies did in Sacrifice employ:
This Royal Robe, and this Tiara wore
Old Priam, and this Golden Scepter bore
In full Aemblies, and in olemn Games;
Thee Purple Vets were weav'd by Dardan Dames.
Thus while he poke, Latinus rowld around
His Eyes, and fix'd a while upon the Ground.
Intent he eem'd, and anxious in his Breat;
Not by the Scepter mov'd, or Kingly Vet:
But pond'ring future Things of wond'rous Weight;
Succeion, Empire, and his Daughter's Fate:
On thee he mus'd within his thoughtful Mind;
And then revolv'd what Faunus had divin'd.
This was the Foreign Prince, by Fate decreed
To hare his Scepter, and Lavinia's Bed:
This was the Race, that ure Portents forehew
To way the World, and Land and Sea ubdue.
At length he rais'd his chearful Head, and poke
The Pow'rs, aid he, the Pow'rs we both invoke,
To you, and yours, and mine, propitious be,
And firm our Purpoe with their Augury.
Have what you ask; your Preents I receive,
Land where, and when you pleae, with ample Leave:
Partake and ue my Kingdom as your own;
All hall be yours, while I command the Crown.
And if my wih'd Alliance pleae your King,
Tell him he hou'd not end the Peace, but bring:
Then let him not a Friend's Embraces fear;
The Peace is made when I behold him here.
Beides this Anwer, tell my Royal Guet,
I add to his Commands, my own Requet:
One only Daughter heirs my Crown and State,
Whom, not our Oracles, nor Heav'n, nor Fate,
Nor frequent Prodigies permit to join
With any Native of th' Auonian Line.
A foreign Son-in-Law hall come from far,
(Such is our Doom) a Chief renown'd in War:
Whoe Race hall bear alot the Latian Name,
And through the conquer'd World diffue our Fame.
Himelf to be the Man the Fates require,
I firmly judge, and what I judge, deire.
He aid, and then on each betow'd a Steed;
Three hundred Hores, in high Stables f • d,
Stood ready, hining all, and moothly dres'd;
Of thee he choe the fairet and the bet,
To mount the Trojan Troop; at his Command,
The Steeds caparion'd with Purple tand;
With Golden Trappings, glorious to behold,
And champ betwixt their Teeth the foaming Gold.
Then to his abent Guet the King decreed
A pair of Courers born of Heav'nly Breed:
Who from their Notrils breath'd Etherial Fire;
Whom Circe tole from her Coeletial Sire:
By ubtituting Mares, produc'd on Earth,
Whoe Wombs conceiv'd a more than Mortal Birth.
Thee draw the Chariot which Latinus ends;
And the rich Preent to the Prince commends.
Sublime on tately Steeds the Trojans born;
To their expecting Lord with Peace return.
But jealous Juno, from Pachynus height,
As he from Argos took her airy Flight,
Beheld, with envious Eyes, this hateful Sight.
She aw the Trojan, and his joyful Train
Decend upon the Shore, deert the Main;
Deign a Town, and with unhop'd Succes
Th' Embaadors return with promis'd Peace.
Then pierc'd with Pain, he hook her haughty Head;
Sigh'd from her inward Soul; and thus he aid.
O hated Off-pring of my Phrygian Foes!
O Fates of Troy, which Juno's Fates oppoe!
Cou'd they not fall unpity'd, on the Plain,
But lain revive, and taken, cape again?
When execrable Troy in Ahes lay,
Thro' Fires, and Swords, and Seas, they forc'd their Way.
Then vanquih'd Juno mut in vain contend,
Her Rage diarm'd, her Empire at an end.
Breathles and tir'd, is all my Fury pent,
Or does my glutted Spleen at length relent?
As if 'twere little from their Town to chae,
I thro' the Seas puru'd their exil'd Race:
Ingag'd the Heavn's, oppos'd the Stormy Main;
But Billows roar'd, and Tempets rag'd in vain.
What have my Scylla's and my Sirtes done,
When thee they overpas, and thoe they hun?
On Tyber's Shores they land, ecure of Fate,
Triumphant o're the Storms and Juno's Hate.
Mars cou'd in mutual Blood the Centaurs bath,
And Jove himelf gave way to Cynthia's Wrath;
Who ent the tusky Boar to Calydon:
What great Offence had either People done?
But I, the Confort of the Thunderer,
Have wag'd a long and unuccesful War:
With various Arts and Arms in vain have toil'd,
And by a Mortal Man at length am foil'd.
If native Pow'r prevail not, hall I doubt
To eek for needful Succour from without:
If Jove and Heav'n my jut Deires deny,
Hell hall the Pow'r of Heav'n and Jove upply.
Grant that the Fates have firm'd, by their Decree,
The Trojan Race to reign in Italy;
At leat I can defer the Nuptial Day,
And with protracted Wars the Peace delay:
With Blood the dear Alliance hall be bought;
And both the People to Detruction brought.
So hall the Son-in-Law, and Father join,
With Ruin, War, and Wate of either Line.
O fatal Maid! thy Marriage is endow'd
With Phrygian, Latian, and Rutulian Blood!
Bellona leads thee to thy Lover's Hand,
Another Queen brings forth another Brand;
To burn with foreign Fires her native Land!
A econd Paris, diff'ring but in Name,
Shall fire his Country with a econd Flame.
Thus having aid, he inks beneath the Ground,
With furious hate, and hoots the Stygian Sound;
To rowze Alecto from th' Infernal Seat
Of her dire Siters, and their dark Retreat.
This Fury, fit for her Intent, he choe;
One who delights in Wars, and Human Woes.
Ev'n Pluto hates his own mihapen Race:
Her Siter-Furies fly her hideous Face:
So frightful are the Forms the Monter takes,
So fierce the Hiings of her peckled Snakes.
Her Juno finds, and thus inflames her Spight:
O Virgin Daughter of Eternal Night,
Give me this once thy Labour, to utain
My Right, and execute my jut didain.
Let not the Trojans, with a feign'd Pretence
Of proffer'd Peace, delude the Latian Prince:
Expel from Italy that odious Name,
And let not Juno uffer in her Fame.
'Tis thine to ruin Realms, o'return a State,
Betwixt the dearet Friends to raie Debate;
And kindle kindred Blood to mutual Hate.
Thy Hand o're Towns the fun'ral Torch diplays,
And forms a thouand Ills ten thouand Ways.
Now hake from out thy fruitful Breat, the Seeds
Of Envy, Dicord, and of Cruel Deeds:
Confound the Peace etablih'd, and prepare
Their Souls to Hatred, and their Hands to War.
Smear'd as he was with black Gorgonean Blood,
The Fury prang above the Stygian Flood:
And on her wicker Wings, ublime through Night,
She to the Latian Palace took her Flight.
There ought the Queen's Apartment, tood before
The peaceful Threhold, and beieg'd the Door.
Retles Amata lay, her welling Breat
Fir'd with Didain for Turnus dipoet,
And the new Nuptials of the Trojan Guet.
From her black bloody Locks the Fury hakes
Her darling Plague, the Fav'rite of her Snakes:
With her full Force he threw the pois'nous Dart,
And fix'd it deep within Amata's Heart.
That thus envenom'd he might kindle Rage,
And acrifice to Strife her Houe and Husbands Age.
Uneen, unfelt, the fiery Serpent skims
Betwixt her Linnen, and her naked Limbs.
His baleful Breath inpiring, as he glides,
Now like a Chain around her Neck he rides;
Now like a Fillet to her Head repairs,
And with his Circling Volumes folds her Hairs:
At firt the ilent Venom lid with eae,
And eiz'd her cooler Senes by degrees;
Then e're th' infected Mas was fir'd too far,
In Plaintive Accents he began the War:
And thus bepoke her Husband; Shall, he aid,
A wandring Prince enjoy Lavinia's Bed?
If Nature plead not in a Parent's Heart,
Pity my Tears, and pity her Deert:
I know, my dearet Lord, the time will come,
You wou'd, in vain, revere your Cruel doom:
The faithles Pirate oon will et to Sea,
And bear the Royal Virgin far away!
A Guet like him, a Trojan Guet before,
In hew of friendhip, ought the Spartan Shore;
And ravih'd Helen from her Husband bore.
Think on a King's inviolable Word;
And think on Turnus, her once plighted Lord:
To this fale Foreigner you give your Throne,
And wrong a Friend, a Kinman, and a Son.
Reume your ancient Care; and if the God
Your Sire, and you, reolve on Foreign Blood:
Know all are Foreign, in a larger Sene,
Not born your Subjects, or deriv'd from hence.
Then if the Line of Turnus you retrace;
He prings from Inachus of Argive Race.
But when he aw her Reaons idly pent,
And cou'd not move him from his fix'd Intent;
She flew to rage; for now the Snake poes'd
Her vital parts, and poion'd all her Breat;
She raves, he runs with a ditracted pace,
And fills, with horrid howls, the public Place.
And, as young Striplings whip the Top for port,
On the mooth Pavement of an empty Court;
The wooden Engine flies and whirls about,
Admir'd, with Clamours, of the Beardles rout;
They lah aloud, each other they provoke,
And lend their little Souls at ev'ry troke:
Thus fares the Queen, and thus her fury blows
Amidt the Crowd, and kindles as he goes.
Nor yet content, he trains her Malice more,
And adds new Ills to thoe contriv'd before:
She flies the Town, and, mixing with a throng
Of madding Matrons, bears the Bride along:
Wand'ring through Woods and Wilds, and devious ways,
And with thee Arts the Trojan Match delays.
She feign'd the Rites of Bacchus! cry'd aloud,
And to the Buxom God the Virgin vow'd.
Evoe, O Bacchus thus began the Song,
And Evoe! anwer'd all the Female Throng:
O Virgin! worthy thee alone, he cry'd;
O worthy thee alone, the Crew reply'd.
For thee he feeds her Hair, he leads thy Dance,
And with thy winding Ivy crowns her Lance.
Like fury eiz'd the ret; the progres known,
All eek the Mountains, and forake the Town:
All Clad in Skins of Beats the Jav'lin bear,
Give to the wanton Winds their flowing Hair:
And hrieks and howtings rend the paive Air.
The Queen, her elf, inpir'd with Rage Divine,
Shook high above her head a flaming Pine:
Then rowl'd her haggar'd Eyes around the throng,
And ung, in Turnus Name, the Nuptial Song:

figure.p: To Colll: Thomas Farrington of the Parih of St: James's Westminster
figure.head: AE 7. l. 559

lg.l: Io ye Latian Dames, if any here
Hold, your unhappy Queen, Amata, dear;
If there be here, he aid, who dare maintain
My Right, nor think the Name of Mother vain:
Unbind your Fillets, looe your flowing Hair,
And Orgies, and Nocturnal Rites prepare.
Amata's Breat the Fury thus invades,
And fires with Rage, amid the Silvan Shades.
Then when he found her Venom pread o far,
The Royal Houe embroil'd in Civil War:
Rais'd on her dusky Wings he cleaves the Skies,
And eeks the Palace where young Turnus lies
His Town, as Fame reports, was built of old
By Danae, pregnant with Almighty Gold:
Who fled her Father's Rage, and with a Train
Of following Argives, thro' the tormy Main,
Driv'n by the Southern Blats, was fated here to reign.
'Twas Ardua once, now Ardea's Name it bears:
Once a fair City, now conum'd with Years.
Here in his lofty Palace Turnus lay,
Betwixt the Confines of the Night and Day,
Secure in Sleep: The Fury laid aide
Her Looks and Limbs, and with new methods try'd,
The foulnes of th' inernal Form to hide.
Prop'd on a Staff, he takes a trembling Meen,
Her Face is furrow'd, and her Front obcene:
Deep dinted Wrinckles on her Cheek he draws,
Sunk are her Eyes, and toothles are her Jaws:
Her hoary Hair with holy Fillets bound,
Her Temples with an Olive Wreath are crown'd.
Old Chalibe, who kept the acred Fane
Of Juno, now he eem'd, and thus began,
Appearng in a Dream, to rouze the careles Man.
Shall Turnus then uch endles Toil utain,
In fighting Fields, and conquer Towns in vain:
Win, for a Trojan Head to wear the Prize,
Uurp thy Crown, enjoy thy Victories?
The Bride and Scepter which thy Blood has bought,
The King transfers, and Foreign Heirs are ought:
Go now, deluded Man, and eek again
New Toils, new Dangers on the duty Plain.
Repel the Tucan Foes, their City eize,
Protect the Latians in luxurious Eae.
This Dream all-pow'rful Juno ends, I bear
Her mighty Mandates, and her Words you hear.
Hate, arm your Ardeans, iue to the Plain,
With Fate to friend, aault the Trojan Train:
Their thoughtles Chiefs, their painted Ships that lye
In Tyber's Mouth, with Fire and Sword detroy.
The Latian King, unles he hall ubmit,
Own his old Promie, and his new forget;
Let him, in Arms, the Pow'r of Turnus prove,
And learn to fear whom he didains to Love.
For uch is Heav'ns Command. The youthful Prince
With Scorn reply'd, and made this bold Defence.
You tell me, Mother, what I knew before,
The Phrygian Fleet is landed on the Shore:
I neither fear, nor will provoke the War;
My Fate is Juno's mot peculiar Care.
But Time has made you dote, and vainly tell
Of Arms imagin'd, in your lonely Cell:
Go, be the Temple and the Gods your Care,
Permit to Men the Thought of Peace and War.
Thee haughty Words Alecto's Rage provoke,
And frighted Turnus trembled as he poke.
Her Eyes grow tiffen'd, and with Sulphur burn,
Her hideous Looks, and hellih Form return:
Her curling Snakes, with Hiings fill the Place,
And open all the Furies of her Face:
Then, darting Fire from her malignant Eyes,
She cat him backward as he trove to rie,
And, ling'ring, ought to frame ome new Replies.
High on her Head he rears two twited Snakes,
Her Chains he rattles, and her Whip he hakes;
And churning bloody Foam, thus loudly peaks.
Behold whom Time has made to dote, and tell
Of Arms, imagin'd in her lonely Cell:
Behold the Fates Infernal Miniter;
War, Death, Detruction, in my Hand I bear.
Thus having aid, her mould'ring Torch impres'd,
With her full Force, he plung'd into his Breat.
Aghat he wak'd, and, tarting from his Bed,
Cold Sweat, in clammy Drops, his Limbs o'repread.
Arms, Arms, he cries, my Sword and Shield prepare;
He breaths Defiance, Blood, and Mortal War.
So when with crackling Flames a Cauldron fries,
The bubling Waters from the Bottom rie:
Above the Brims they force their fiery way;
Black Vapours climb aloft, and cloud the Day.
The Peace polluted thus, a choen Band
He firt commiions to the Latian Land;
In threatning Embay: Then rais'd the ret,
To meet in Arms th' intruding Trojan Guet:
To force the Foes from the Lavinian Shore,
And Italy's indanger'd Peace retore.
Himelf alone, an equal Match he boats,
To fight the Phrygian and Auonian Hoats.
The Gods invok'd, the Rutuli prepare
Their Arms, and warm each other to the War.
His Beauty thee, and thoe his blooming Age,
The ret his Houe, and his own Fame ingage.
While Turnus urges thus his Enterprie;
The Stygian Fury to the Trojans flies:
New Frauds invents, and takes a teepy Stand,
Which overlooks the Vale with wide Command;
Where fair Acanius, and his youthful Train,
With Horns and Hounds a hunting Match ordain,
And pitch their Toils around the hady Plain.
The Fury fires the Pack; they nuff, they vent,
And fill their hungry Notrils with the Scent.
'Twas of a well grown Stag, whoe Antlers rie
High o're his Front, his Beams invade the Skies:
From this light Caue, th' Infernal Maid prepares
The Country Churls to Michief, Hate, and Wars.
The tately Beat, the Two Tyrrheidae bred,
Snatch'd from his Dam, and the tame Youngling fed.
Their Father Tyrrheus did his Fodder bring,
Tyrrheus, chief Ranger to the Latian King:
Their Siter Silvia cherih'd with her Care
The little Wanton, and did Wreaths prepare
To hang his budding Horns: with Ribbons ty'd
His tender Neck, and comb'd his ilken Hide;
And bath'd his Body. Patient of Command,
In time he grew, and growing us'd to Hand.
He waited at his Mater's Board for Food;
Then ought his alvage Kindred in the Wood:
Where grazing all the Day, at Night he came
To his known Lodgings, and his Country Dame.
This houehold Beat, that us'd the Woodland Grounds,
Was view'd at firt by the young Hero's Hounds;
As down the Stream he wam, to eek Retreat
In the cool Waters, and to quench his Heat.
Acanius young, and eager of his Game,
Soon bent his Bow, uncertain in his Aim:

figure.p: To ye Right Honble: ye Lady Mary Sackvile daughter to Charles Earle of Doret & Middlesex
figure.head: AE. 7. l. 675.

lg.l: But the dire Fiend the fatal Arrow guides,
Which pierc'd his Bowels thro' his panting ides.
The bleeding Creature iues from the Floods,
Poes'd with Fear, and eeks his known abodes;
His old familiar Hearth, and houehold Gods.
He falls, he fills the Houe with heavy Groans,
Implores their Pity, and his Pain bemoans.
Young Silvia beats her Breat, and cries aloud
For Succour, from the clownih Neighbourhood:
The Churls aemble; for the Fiend, who lay
In the cloe Woody Covert, urg'd their way.
One with a Brand, yet burning from the Flame;
Arm'd with a knotty Club, another came:
What e're they catch or find, without their Care,
Their Fury makes an Intrument of War.
Tyrrheus, the Foter-Father of the Beat,
Then clench'd a Hatchet in his horny Fit:
But held his Hand from the decending Stroke,
And left his Wedge within the cloven Oak,
To whet their Courage, and their Rage provoke.
And now the Goddes, exercis'd in Ill,
Who watch'd an Hour to work her impious Will,
Acends the Roof, and to her crooked Horn,
Such as was then by Latian Shepherds born,
Adds all her Breath, the Rocks and Woods around,
And Mountains, tremble at th' infernal Sound.
The Sacred Lake of Trivia from afar,
The Veline Fountains, and ulphureous Nar,
Shake at the baleful Blat, the Signal of the War.
Young Mothers wildly tare, with Fear poes'd,
And train their helples Infants to their Breat.
The Clowns, a boit'rous, rude, ungovern'd Crew,
With furious hate to the loud Summons flew.
The Pow'rs of Troy then iuing on the Plain,
With freh Recruits their youthful Chief utain:
Not theirs a raw and unexperienc'd Train,
But a firm Body of embattel'd Men.
At firt, while Fortune favour'd neither ide,
The Fight with Clubs and burning Brands was try'd:
But now, both Parties reinfor'd, the Fields
Are bright with flaming Swords and brazen Shields.
A hining Harvet either Hot diplays,
And hoots againt the Sun with equal Rays.
Thus when a black-brow'd Gut begins to rie,
White Foam at firt on the curl'd Ocean fries;
Then roars the Main, the Billows mount the Skies:
'Till by the Fury of the Storm full blown,
The muddy Bottom o're the Clouds is thrown.
Firt Almon falls, old Tyrrheus eldet Care,
Pierc'd with an Arrow from the ditant War:
Fix'd in his Throat the flying Weapon tood,
And top'd his Breath, and drank his vital Blood.
Huge Heaps of lain above the Body rie;
Among the ret, the rich Galeus lyes:
A good old Man, while Peace he preach'd in vain,
Amidt the Madnes of th' unruly Train.
Five Heards, five bleating Flocks his Patures fill'd,
His Lands a hundred Yoke of Oxen till'd.
Thus, while in equal Scales their Fortune tood,
The Fury bath'd them in each others Blood.
Then having fix'd the Fight, exulting flies,
And bears fulfill'd her Promie to the Skies.
To Juno thus he peaks; Behold, 'tis done,
The Blood already drawn, the War begun;
The Dicord is compleat, nor can they ceae
The dire Debate, nor you command the Peace.
Now ince the Latian and the Trojan Brood
Have tated Vengeance, and the Sweets of Blood;
Speak, and my Pow'r hall add this Office more:
The Neighb'ring Nations of th' Auonian Shore
Shall hear the dreadful Rumour, from afar,
Of arm'd Invaion, and embrace the War.
Then Juno thus; The grateful Work is done,
The Seeds of Dicord ow'd, the War begun:
Frauds, Fears, and Fury have poes'd the State,
And fix'd the Caues of a lating Hate:
A bloody Hymen hall th' Alliance join
Betwixt the Trojan and Auonian Line:
But thou with Speed to Night and Hell repair,
For not the Gods, nor angry Jove will bear
Thy lawles wand'ring walks, in upper Air.
Leave what remains to me. Saturnia aid:
The ullen Fiend her ounding Wings diplay'd;
Unwilling left the Light, and ought the neather Shade.
In midt of Italy, well known to Fame,
There lies a Lake, Amanctus is the Name,
Below the lofty Mounts: On either ide
Thick Forrets, the forbidden Entrance hide:
Full in the Centre of the acred Wood
An Arm aries of the Stygian Flood;
Which, breaking from beneath with bellowing ound,
Whirls the black Waves and rattling Stones around.
Here Pluto pants for Breath from out his Cell,
And opens wide the grinning Jaws of Hell.
To this Infernal Lake the Fury flies;
Here hides her hated Head, and frees the lab'ring Skies.
Saturnian Juna now, with double Care,
Attends the fatal Proces of the War.
The Clowns return'd, from Battel bear the lain,
Implore the Gods, and to their King complain.
The Corps of Almon and the ret are hown,
Shrieks, Clamours, Murmurs fill the frighted Town.
Ambitious Turnus in the Pres appears,
And, aggravating Crimes, augments their Fears:
Proclaims his Private Injuries aloud,
A Solemn Promie made, and diavow'd;
A foreign Son is ought, and a mix'd Mungril Brood.
Then they, whoe Mothers, frantick with their Fear,
In Woods and Wilds the Flags of Bacchus bear,
And lead his Dances with dihevell'd hair,
Increae the Clamour, and the War demand,
(Such was Amata's Interet in the Land)
Againt the Public Sanctions of the Peace,
Againt all Omens of their ill Succes;
With Fates avere, the Rout in Arms reort,
To Force their Monarch, and inult the Court.
But like a Rock unmov'd, a Rock that braves
The rageing Tempet and the riing Waves,
Prop'd on himelf he tands: His olid ides
Wah off the Sea-weeds, and the ounding Tides:
So tood the Pious Prince unmov'd: and long
Sutain'd the madnes of the noiie Throng.
But when he found that Juno's Pow'r prevail'd,
And all the Methods of cool Counel ail'd,
He calls the Gods to witnes their offence,
Diclaims the War, aerts his Innocence.
Hurry'd by Fate, he cries, and born before
A furious Wind, we leave the faithful Shore:
O more than Madmen! you your elves hall bear
The guilt of Blood and Sacrilegious War:
Thou, Turnus, halt attone it by thy Fate,
And pray to Heav'n for Peace, but pray too late.
For me, my tormy Voyage at an end,
I to the Port of Death ecurely tend.
The Fun'ral Pomp which to your Kings you pay,
Is all I want, and all you take away.
He aid no more, but in his Walls confin'd,
Shut out the Woes which he too well divin'd:
Nor with the riing Storm wou'd vainly trive,
But left the Helm, and let the Veel drive.
A olemn Cutom was oberv'd of old,
Which Latium held, and now the Romans hold;
Their Standard, when in fighting Fields they rear
Againt the fierce Hircanians, or declare
The Scythian, Indian, or Arabian War:
Or from the boating Parthians wou'd regain
Their Eagles lot in Carrhae's bloody Plain:
Two Gates of Steel (the Name of Mars they bear)
And till are worhip'd with religious Fear;
Before his Temple tand: The dire abode,
And the fear'd Iues of the furious God,
Are fenc'd with Brazen Bolts; without the Gates,
The wary Guardian Janus doubly waits.
Then, when the acred Senate votes the Wars,
The Roman Conul their Decree declares,
And in his Robes the ounding Gates unbars.
The Youth in Military Shouts arie,
And the loud Trumpets break the yielding Skies.
Thee Rites of old by Sov'raign Princes us'd,
Were the King's Office, but the King refus'd.
Deaf to their Cries, nor wou'd the Gates unbar
Of acred Peace, or looe th' imprion'd War:
But hid his Head, and, afe from loud Alarms,
Abhor'd the wicked Minitry of Arms.
Then Heav'ns Imperious Queen came down from high;
At her Approach the Brazen Hinges fly,
The Gates are forc'd, and ev'ry falling Bar,
And like a Tempet iues out the War.
The peaceful Cities of th' Auonian Shore,
Lull'd in their Eae, and unditurb'd before;
Are all on Fire, and ome with tudious Care,
Their retiff Steeds in andy Plains prepare:
Some their oft Limbs in painful Marches try,
And War is all their Wih, and Arms the gen'ral Cry.
Part cour the ruty Shields with Seam, and part
New grind the blunted Ax, and point the Dart:
With Joy they view the waving Enigns fly,
And hear the Trumpet's Clangor pierce the Sky.
Five Cities forge their Arms; th' Atinian Pow'rs,
Antemnae, Tybur with her lofty Tow'rs,
Ardea the proud, the Crutumerian Town:
All thee of old were places of Renown.
Some hammer Helmets for the fighting Field,
Some twine young Sallows to upport the Shield;
The Crolet ome, and ome the Cuihes mould,
With Silver plated, and with ductile Gold.
The rutick Honours of the Scythe and Share,
Give place to Swords and Plumes, the Pride of War.
Old Fauchions are new temper'd in the Fires:
The ounding Trumpet ev'ry Soul inpires.
The Word is giv'n, with eager Speed they lace
The hining Head-piece, and the Shield embrace.
The neighing Steeds are to the Chariot ty'd,
The truty Weapon its on ev'ry ide.
And now the mighty Labour is begun,
Ye Mues open all your Helicon.
Sing you the Chiefs that way'd th' Auonian Land,
Their Arms, and Armies under their Command:
What Warriours in our ancient Clime were bred,
What Souldiers follow'd, and what Heroes led.
For well you know, and can record alone,
What Fame to future times conveys but darkly down.
Mezentius firt appear'd upon the Plain,
Scorn fate upon his Brows, and our Didain;
Defying Earth and Heav'n: Etruria lot,
He brings to Turnus's Aid his baffled Hot.
The charming Lauus, full of youthful Fire,
Rode in the Rank, and next his ullen Sire:
To Turnus only econd in the Grace
Of Manly Meen, and features of the Face.
A skilful Horeman, and a Huntman bred,
With Fates avere a thouand Men he led:
His Sire unworthy of o brave a Son;
Himelf well worthy of a happier Throne.
Next Aventinus drives his Chariot round
The Latian Plains, with Palms and Lawrels crown'd.
Proud of his Steeds he moaks along the Field,
His Father's Hydra fills his ample Shield.
A hundred Serpents his about the Brims;
The Son of Hercules he jutly eems,
By his broad Shoulders and Gigantick Limbs.
Of Heav'nly part, and part of Earthly Blood,
A mortal Woman mixing with a God.
For trong Alcides, after he had lain
The triple Geryon, drove from conquer'd Spain
His captive Herds, and thence in Triumph led;
On Tucan Tyber's flow'ry Banks they fed.
Then on Mount Aventine, the Son of Jove
The Prietes Rhea found, and forc'd to Love.
For Arms his Men long Piles and Jav'lins bore,
And Poles with pointed Steel their Foes in Battel gore.
Like Hercules himelf, his Son appears,
In Salvage Pomp a Lyon's Hide he wears;
About his Shoulders hangs the haggy Skin,
The Teeth, and gaping Jaws everely grin.
Thus like the God his Father, homely dret,
He trides into the Hall, a horrid Guet.
Then two Twin-Brothers from fair Tybur came,
(Which from their Brother Tyburs took the Name,)
Fierce Coras, and Catillus, void of Fear,
Arm'd Argive Hore they led, and in the Front appear.
Like Cloud-born Centaurs, from the Mountain's height,
With rapid Coure decending to the Fight;
They ruh along, the ratling Woods give way,
The Branches bend before their weepy Sway.
Nor was Praenete's Founder wanting there,
Whom Fame reports the Son of Mulciber:
Found in the Fire, and foter'd in the Plains;
A Shepherd and a King at once he reigns,
And leads to Turnus Aid his Country Swains.
His own Praenete ends a choen Band,
With thoe who plough Saturnia's Gabine Land:
Beides the Succour which cold Anien yields,
The Rocks of Hernicus, and roie Fields;
Anagnia fat, and Father Amaene,
A num'rous Rout, but all of naked Men:
Nor Arms they wear, nor Swords and Bucklers wield,
Nor drive the Chariot thro' the duty Field:
But whirle from Leathern Slings huge Balls of Lead;
And Spoils of yellow Wolves adorn their Head:
The Left Foot naked, when they march to fight,
But in a Bull's raw Hide they heath the Right.
Meapus next, (great Neptune was his Sire)
Secure of Steel, and fated from the Fire;
In Pomp appears: And with his Ardour warms
A heartles Train, unexercis'd in Arms:
The jut Falicans he to Battel brings,
And thoe who live where Lake Ciminia prings;
And where Feronia's Grove and Temple tands,
Who till Fecennian or Flavinian Lands:
All thee in order march, and marching ing
The warlike Actions of their Sea-born King.
Like a long Team of Snowy Swans on high,
Which clap their Wings, and cleave the liquid Sky,
When homeward from their wat'ry Patures born,
They ing, and Aia's Lakes their Notes return.
Not one who heard their Muick from afar,
Wou'd think thee Troops an Army train'd to War:
But Flocks of Fowl, that when the Tempets roar,
With their hoare gabling eek the ilent Shoar.
Then Clauus came, who led a num'rous Band
Of Troops embody'd, from the Sabine Land:
And in himelf alone, an Army brought,
'Twas he the noble Claudian Race begot:
The Claudian Race, ordain'd, in times to come,
To hare the Greatnes of Imperial Rome.
He led the Cures forth of old Renown,
Mutucans from their Olive-bearing Town;
And all th' Eretian Pow'rs: Beides a Band
That follow'd from Velinum's dewy Land:
And Amiternian Troops, of mighty Fame,
And Mountaineers, that from Severus came.
And from the craggy Cliffs of Tetrica,
And thoe where yellow Tyber takes his way,
And where Himella's wanton Waters play.

l.U: ends her Arms, with thoe that lye

lg.l: By Fabaris, and fruitful Foruli:
The warlike Aids of Horta next appear,
And the cold Nurians come to cloe the Reer:
Mix'd with the Natives born of Latine Blood,
Whom Allia wahes with her fatal Flood.
Not thicker Billows beat the Lybian Main,
When pale Orion ets in wint'ry Rain;
Not thicker Harvets on rich Hermus rie,
Or Lycian Fields, when Phoebus burns the Skies;
Than tand thee Troops: Their Bucklers ring around,
Their Trampling turns the Turf, and hakes the olid Ground.
High in his Chariot then Haleus came,
A Foe by Birth to Troy's unhappy Name:
From Agamemnon born; to Turnus Aid,
A thouand Men the youthful Heroe led;
Who till the Maick Soil, for Wine renown'd,
And fierce Auruncans from their Hilly Ground:
And thoe who live by Sidicinian Shores,
And where, with hoaly Foords Vulturnus roars;
Cales and Oca's old Inhabitants,
And rough Saticulans inur'd to Wants:
Light demi-Launces from afar they throw,
Faten'd with Leathern Thongs to gaul the Foe.
Short crooked Swords in cloer Fight they wear,
And on their warding Arm light Bucklers bear.
Nor Oebalus, halt thou be left unung,
From Nymph Semethis and old Telon prung:
Who then in Teleboan Capri reign'd,
But that hort Ile th' ambitious Youth didain'd;
And o're Campagnia tretch'd his ample Sway;
Where welling Sarnus eeks the Tyrrhene Sea:
O're Batulum, and where Abella ees,
From her high Tow'rs, the Harvet of her Trees.
All thee (as was the Teuton ue of old)
Wield Brazen Swords, and Brazen Bucklers hold:
Sling weighty Stones when from afar they fight;
Their Caques are Cork, a Covering thick and light.
Next thee in Rank, the warlike Ufens went,
And led the Mountain Troops that Nuria ent.
The rude Equicolae his Rule obey'd,
Hunting their Sport, and Plund'ring was their Trade.
In Arms they plough'd, to Battel till prepar'd;
Their Soil was barren, and their Hearts were hard.
Umbro the Priet the proud Marrubians led,
By King Archippus ent to Turnus aid;
And peaceful Olives crown'd his hoary head.
His Wand and holy Words, the Viper's rage,
And venom'd wounds of Serpents, cou'd awage.
He, when he pleas'd with powerful Juice to teep
Their Temples, hut their Eyes in pleaing Sleep.
But vain were Marian Herbs, and Magick Art,
To cure the Wound giv'n by the Dardan Dart.
Yet his untimely Fate, th' Angitian Woods
In ighs remurmur'd, to the Fucine Floods.
The Son of fam'd Hippolitus was there;
Fam'd as his Sire, and as his Mother fair.
Whom in Egerian Groves Aricia bore,
And nurs'd his Youth along the Marhy Shore:
Where great Diana's peaceful Altars flame,
In fruitful Fields, and Virbius was his Name.
Hippolitus, as old Records have aid,
Was by his Stepdam ought to hare her Bed:
But when no Female Arts his Mind cou'd move,
She turn'd to furious Hate her impious Love.
Torn by Wild Hores on the andy Shore,
Another's Crimes th' unhappy Hunter bore;
Glutting his Father's Eyes with guiltles gore.
But chat Diana, who his death deplor'd,
With Aeculapian Herbs his life retor'd.
Then Jove, who aw from high, with jut didain,
The dead inpir'd with Vital Breath again,
Struck to the Center with his flaming Dart
Th' unhappy Founder of the Godlike Art.
But Trivia kept in ecret Shades alone,
Her care, Hippolitus, to Fate unknown;
And call'd him Virbius in th' Egerian Grove:
Where then he liv'd obcure, but afe from Jove.
For this, from Trivia's Temple and her Wood,
Are Courers driv'n, who hed their Mater's Blood;
Affrighted by the Monters of the Flood.
His Son, the Second Virbius, yet retain'd
His Fathers Art, and Warrior Steeds he rein'd.
Amid the Troops, and like the leading God,
High o're the ret in Arms the Graceful Turnus rode:
A triple Pile of Plumes his Cret adorn'd,
On which with belching Flames Chimaera burn'd:
The more the Winds his kindled Coure inpire,
The more with fury burn'd the blazing Fire.
Fair Io grac'd his Shield, but Io now
With Horns exalted tands, and eems to lowe:
(A noble charge) her Keeper by her ide,
To watch her Walks his hundred Eyes apply'd.
And on the Brims her Sire, the wat'ry God,
Rowl'd from a Silver Urn his Crytal Flood.
A Cloud of Foot ucceeds, and fills the Fields
With Swords and pointed Spears, and clatt'ring Shields;
Of Argives, and of old Sicanian Bands,
And thoe who Plow the rich Sutulian Lands;
Auruncan Youth and thoe Sacrana yieids,
And the proud Labicans with painted Shields.
And thoe who near Numician Streams reide,
And thoe whom Tyber's holy Forets hide;
Or Circes Hills from the main Land divide.
Where Ufens glides along the lowly Lands,
Or the black Water of Pomptina tands.
Lat from the Volcians fair Camilla came;
And led her warlike Troops, a Warriour Dame:

figure.p: To Charles Fox of ye Parish of St: Martins in ye Fields Esqr.
figure.head: AE. 7. l. 1075.

lg.l: Unbred to Spinning, in the Loom unskill'd,
She choe the nobler Pallas of the Field.
Mix'd with the firt, the fierce Virago fought,
Sutain'd the Toils of Arms, the Danger ought:
Outtrip'd the Winds in peed upon the Plain,
Flew o're the Fields, nor hurt the bearded Grain:
She wept the Seas, and as he skim'd along,
Her flying Feet unbath'd on Billows hung.
Men, Boys, and Women tupid with Surprie,
Where e're he paes, fix their wond'ring Eyes:
Longing they look, and gaping at the Sight,
Devour her o're and o're with vat Delight.
Her Purple Habit its with uch a Grace
On her mooth Shoulders, and o uits her Face:
Her Head with Ringlets of her Hair is crown'd,
And in a Golden Caul the Curls are bound.
She hakes her Myrtle Jav'lin: And, behind,
Her Lycian Quiver dances in the Wind.

div.head: The Eighth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: The War being now begun, both the Generals make all poible Preparations. Tumus ends to Diomedes. Aeneas goes in Peron to beg Succours from Evander and the Tucans. Evander receives him kindly, furnihes him with Men, and ends his Son Pallas with him. Vulcan, at the Requet of Venus, makes Arms for her Son Aeneas, and draws on his Shield the mot memorable Actions of his Poterity.

lg.l: WHen Turnus had aembled all his Pow'rs;
His Standard planted on Laurentum's Tow'rs;
When now the prightly Trumpet, from afar,
Had giv'n the Signal of approaching War,
Had rouz'd the neighing Steeds to cour the Fields,
While the fierce Riders clatter'd on their Shields,
Trembling with Rage, the Latian Youth prepare
To join th' Allies, and headlong ruh to War.
Fierce Ufens, and Meapus, led the Crowd;
With bold Mezentius, who blaphem'd aloud.
Thee, thro the Country took their watful Coure;
The Fields to forage, and to gather Force.
Then Venulus to Diomede they end,
To beg his Aid Auonia to defend:
Declare the common Danger; and inform
The Grecian Leader of the growing Storm:
Aeneas landed on the Latian Coat,
With banih'd Gods, and with a baffled Hoat;
Yet now apir'd to Conquet of the State;
And claim'd a Title from the Gods and Fate.
What num'rous Nations in his Quarrel came,
And how they pread his formidable Name:

figure.p: To ye Right Honble. Tho Earle of Ailesbury & Elgin Viscount Bruce of Ampthill Baron Bruce of Whorleton Shelton and Kinlos &ct.
figure.head: AE. 8. l. 2.

lg.l: What he deign'd, what Michiefs might arie,
If Fortune favour'd his firt Enterprie,
Was left for him to weigh: whoe equal Fears,
And common Interet was involv'd in theirs.
While Turnus and th' Allies thus urge the War,
The Trojan floating in a Flood of Care,
Beholds the Tempet which his Foes prepare.
This way and that he turns his anxious Mind;
Thinks, and rejects the Counels he deign'd.
Explores himelf in vain, in ev'ry part,
And gives no ret to his ditracted Heart.
So when the Sun by Day, or Moon by Night,
Strike, on the polih'd Bras, their trembling Light,
The glitt'ring Species here and there divide;
And cat their dubious Beams from ide to ide:
Now on the Walls, now on the Pavement play,
And to the Cieling flah the glaring Day.
'Twas Night: And weary Nature lul'd aleep
The Birds of Air, and Fihes of the Deep;
And Beats, and Mortal Men: The Trojan Chief
Was laid on Tyber's Banks, oppres'd with Grief,
And found in ilent Slumber late Relief.
Then, thro' the Shadows of the Poplar Wood,
Aroe the Father of the Roman Flood;
An Azure Robe was o're his Body pread,
A Wreath of hady Reeds adorn'd his Head:
Thus, manifet to Sight, the God appear'd
And with thee pleaing Words his Sorrow chear'd.
Undoubted Off-pring of Etherial Race,
O long expected in this promis'd Place,
Who, thro the Foes, hat born thy banih'd Gods,
Retor'd them to their Hearths, and old Abodes;
This is thy happy Home! The Clime where Fate
Ordains thee to retore the Trojan State.
Fear not, the War hall end in lating Peace;
And all the Rage of haughty Juno ceae.
And that this nightly Viion may not eem
Th' Effect of Fancy, or an idle Dream,
A Sow beneath an Oak hall lye along;
All white her elf, and white her thirty Young.
When thirty rowling Years have run their Race,
Thy Son, Acanius, on this empty Space,
Shall build a Royal Town, of lating Fame;
Which from this Omen hall receive the Name.
Time hall approve the Truth: For what remains,
And how with ure Succes to crown thy Pains,
With Patience next attend. A banih'd Band,
Driv'n with Evander from th' Arcadian Land,
Have planted here: and plac'd on high their Walls;
Their Town the Founder, Palanteum calls:
Deriv'd from Pallas, his great Grandire's Name:
But the fierce Latians old Poeion claim:
With War infeting the new Colony;
Thee make thy Friends, and on their Aid rely.
To thy free Paage I ubmit my Streams:
Wake Son of Venus from thy pleaing Dreams;
And, when the etting Stars are lot in Day,
To Juno's Pow'r thy jut Devotion pay.
With Sacrifice the wrathful Queen appeae;
Her Pride at length hall fall, her Fury ceae.
When thou return't victorious from the War,
Perform thy Vows to me with grateful Care.
The God am I, whoe yellow Water flows
Around thee Fields, and fattens as it goes:
Tyber my Name: among the rowling Floods,
Renown'd on Earth, eteem'd among the Gods.
This is my certain Seat: In Times to come,
My Waves hall wah the Walls of mighty Rome.
He aid; and plung'd below, while yet he poke:
His Dream Aeneas and his Sleep forook.
He roe, and looking up, beheld the Skies
With Purple bluhing, and the Day arie.
Then, Water in his hollow Palm he took,
From Tyber's Flood; and thus the Pow'rs bepoke.
Laurentian Nymphs, by whom the Streams are fed,
And Father Tyber, in thy acred Bed
Receive Aeneas; and from Danger keep.
Whatever Fount, whatever holy deep,
Conceals thy wat'ry Stores; where e're they rie,
And, bubling from below, alute the Skies:
Thou King of horned Floods, whoe plenteous Urn
Suffices Fatnes to the fruitful Corn,
For this thy kind Compaion of our Woes,
Shalt hare my Morning Song, and Ev'ning Vows.
But, oh! be preent to thy Peoples Aid;
And firm the gracious Promie thou hat made.
Thus having aid, two Gallies, from his Stores,
With Care he chues; Mans, and fits with Oars.
Now on the Shore the fatal Swine is found:
Wond'rous to tell; he lay along the Ground:
Her well fed Offspring at her Udders hung;
She white her elf, and white her thirty young.
Aeneas takes the Mother, and her Brood,
And all on Juno's Altar are betow'd.
The foll'wing Night, and the ucceeding Day,
Propitious Tyber mooth'd his wat'ry Way:
He rowld his River back; and pois'd he tood;
A gentle Swelling, and a peaceful Flood.
The Trojans mount their Ships; they put from Shore,
Born on the Waves, and carcely dip an Oar.
Shouts from the Land give Omen to their Coure;
And the pitch'd Veels glide with eaie Force.
The Woods and Waters, wonder at the Gleam
Of Shields, and painted Ships, that tem the Stream.
One Summer's Night, and one whole Day they pas,
Betwixt the green-wood Shades; and cut the liquid Glas.
The fiery Sun had finih'd half his Race;
Look'd back, and doubted in the middle Space:
When they from far beheld the riing Tow'rs,
The Tops of Sheds, and Shepherds lowly Bow'rs:
Thin as they tood, which, then of homely Clay,
Now rie in Marble, from the Roman Sway.
Thee Cots, (Evander's Kingdom, mean and poor)
The Trojan aw; and turn'd his Ships to Shore.
'Twas on a olemn Day: Th' Arcadian States,
The King and Prince without the City Gates,
Then paid their Off'rings in a acred Grove,
To Hercules, the Warrior Son of Jove.
Thick Clouds of rowling Smoke involve the Sky:
And Fat of Entrails on his Altar fry.
But when they aw the Ships that temm'd the Flood,
And glitter'd thro' the Covert of the Wood,
They roe with Fear; and left th' unfinih'd Feat:
'Till dauntles Pallas reaur'd the ret,
To pay the Rites. Himelf without delay
A Jav'lin eiz'd, and ingly took his Way.
Then gain'd a riing Ground; and call'd from far.
Reolve me, Strangers, whence, and what you are;
Your Buis'nes here; and bring you Peace or War?
High on the Stern, Aeneas took his Stand,
And held a Branch of Olive in his Hand;
While thus he poke. The Phrygians Arms you ee;
Expell'd from Troy, provok'd in Italy
By Latian Foes, with War unjutly made:
At firt affianc'd, and at lat betray'd.
This Meage bear: The Trojans and their Chief
Bring holy Peace; and beg the King's Relief.
Struck with o great a Name, and all on fire,
The Youth Replies, Whatever you require,
Your Fame exacts: Upon our Shores decend,
A welcome Guet, and what you wih, a Friend.
He aid; and downward hating to the Strand,
Embrac'd the Stranger Prince, and join'd his Hand.
Conducted to the Grove, Aeneas broke
The ilence firt, and thus the King bepoke.
Bet of the Greeks, to whom, by Fates Command,
I bear thee peaceful Branches in my hand;
Undaunted I approach you; though I know
Your Birth is Grecian, and your Land my Foe:
From Atreus tho' your ancient Lineage came;
And both the Brother Kings your Kindred claim:
Yet, my elf-concious Worth, your high Renown,
Your Vertue, through the Neighb'ring Nations blown,
Our Fathers mingl'd Blood, Apollo's Voice,
Have led me hether, les by Need than Choice.
Our Founder Dardanus, as Fame has ung,
And Greeks acknowledge, from Electra prung:
Electra from the Loins of Atlas came;
Atlas whoe Head utains the Starry Frame.
Your Sire is Mercury; whom long before
On cold Cyllene's top fair Maja bore.
Maja the fair, on Fame if we rely,
Was Atlas Daughter, who utains the Sky.
Thus from one common Source our Streams divide:
Ours is the Trojan, yours th' Arcadian ide.
Rais'd by thee Hopes, I ent no News before:
Nor ask'd your leave, nor did your Faith implore;
But come, without a Pledg, my own Ambaador.
The ame Rutulians, who with Arms purue
The Trojan Race, are equal Foes to you.
Our Hot expell'd, what farther Force can tay
The Victor Troops from Univeral Sway?
Then will they tretch their Pow'r athwart the Land;
And either Sea from ide to ide command.
Receive our offer'd Faith: and give us thine;
Ours is a gen'rous, and experienc'd Line:
We want not Hearts, nor Bodies for the War;
In Council cautious, and in Fields we dare.
He aid; and while he poke, with piercing Eyes,
Evander view'd the Man with vat urprize.
Pleas'd with his Action, ravih'd with his Face,
Then anwer'd briefly, with a Royal grace.
O Valiant Leader of the Trojan Line,
In whom the Features of thy Father hine;
How I recall Anchies, how I ee
His Motions, Meen, and all my Friend in thee!
Long tho it be, 'tis freh within my Mind,
When Priam, to his Siter's Court deign'd
A welcome Viit, with a friendly tay;
And, through th' Arcadian Kingdom took his way.
Then, pat a Boy, the callow Down began
To hade my Chin, and call me firt a Man.
I aw the hining Train, with vat delight,
And Priam's goodly Peron pleas'd my ight:
But great Anchies, far above the ret,
With awful Wonder fir'd my Youthful Breat.
I long'd to join, in Friendhip's holy Bands,
Our mutual Hearts, and plight our mutual Hands.
I firt accoted him: I u'd, I ought,
And, with a loving force, to Pheneus brought.
He gave me, when at length contrain'd to go,
A Lycian Quiver, and a Gnoian Bow:
A Vet embroyder'd, glorious to behold,
And two rich Bridles, with their Bits of Gold,
Which my Son's Courers in obedience hold.
The League you ask I offer, as your Right:
And when to Morrow's Sun reveals the Light,
With wift Supplies you hall be ent away:
Now celebrate, with us, this olemn Day;
Whoe Holy Rites admit no long Delay.
Honour our Annual Feat; and take your Seat
With friendly Welcome, at a homely Treat.
Thus having aid, the Bowls (remov'd for Fear)
The Youths replac'd; and oon retor'd the Chear.
On ods of Turf he et the Souldiers round;
A Maple Throne, rais'd higher from the Ground,
Receiv'd the Trojan Chief: And o're the Bed,
A Lyon's haggy Hide for Ornament they pread.
The Loaves were erv'd in Caniters; the Wine
In Bowls, the Priet renew'd the Rites Divine:
Broil'd Entrails are their Food; and Beefs continu'd Chine.
But, when the Rage of Hunger was repres'd,
Thus poke Evander to his Royal Guet.
Thee Rites, thee Altars, and this Feat, O King,
From no vain Fears, or Supertition pring:
Or blind Devotion, or from blinder Chance;
Or heady Zeal, or brutal Ignorance:
But, av'd from Danger, with a grateful Sence,
The Labours of a God we recompence.
See, from afar, yon Rock that mates the Sky;
About whoe Feet uch Heaps of Rubbih lye:
Such indigeted Ruin; bleak and bare,
How deart now it tands, expos'd in Air!
'Twas once a Robber's Den; inclos'd around
With living Stone, and deep beneath the Ground.
The Monter Cacus, more than half a Beat,
This Hold, impervious to the Sun, poes'd.
The Pavement ever foul with Human Gore;
Heads, and their mangled Members, hung the Door.
Vulcan this Plague begot: And, like his Sire,
Black Clouds he belch'd, and flakes of livid Fire.
Time, long expected, eas'd us of our Load:
And brought the needful Preence of a God.
Th' avenging Force of Hercules, from Spain,
Arriv'd in Triumph, from Geryon lain;
Thrice liv'd the Gyant, and thrice liv'd in vain.
His Prize, the lowing Herds, Alcides drove
Near Tyber's Bank, to graze the hady Grove.
Allur'd with Hope of Plunder, and intent
By Force to rob, by Fraud to circumvent;
The brutal Cacus, as by Chance they tray'd,
Four Oxen thence, and four fair Kine convey'd.
And, let the printed Footteps might be een,
He drag'd 'em backwards to his rocky Den.
The Tracks avere, a lying Notice gave;
And led the Searcher backward from the Cave.
Mean time the Herdman Heroe hifts his place:
To find freh Pature, and untrodden Gras.
The Beats, who mis'd their Mates, fill'd all around
With Bellowings, and the Rocks retor'd the Sound.
One Heifar who had heard her Love complain,
Roar'd from the Cave; and made the Project vain.
Alcides found the Fraud: With Rage he hook,
And tos'd about his Head his knotted Oak.
Swift as the Winds, or Scythian Arrows flight,
He clomb, with eager hate, th' Aerial height.
Then firt we aw the Monter mend his Pace:
Fear in his Eyes, and Palenes in his Face,
Confes'd the Gods approach: Trembling he prings,
As Terror had increas'd his Feet with Wings:
Nor tay'd for Stairs; but down the Depth he threw
His Body; on his Back the Door he drew.
The Door, a Rib of living Rock; with Pains
His Father hew'd it out, and bound with Iron Chains.
He broke the heavy Lincks; the Mountain clos'd;
And Bars and Leavers to his Foe oppos'd.
The Wretch had hardly made his Dungeon fat;
The fierce Avenger came with bounding hate:
Survey'd the Mouth of the forbidden hold;
And here and there his raging Eyes he rowl'd.
He gnah'd his Teeth; and thrice he compas'd round
With winged peed the Circuit of the Ground.
Thrice at the Cavern's Mouth he pull'd in vain,
And, panting, thrice deited from his Pain.
A pointed flinty Rock, all bare, and black,
Grew gibbous from behind the Mountains Back:
Owls, Ravens, all ill Omens of the Night,
Here built their Nets, and hether wing'd their Flight.
The leaning Head hung threat'ning o're the Flood:
And nodded to the left: The Heroe tood
Advere, with planted Feet, and from the right,
Tugg'd at the olid Stone with all his might.
Thus heav'd, the fix'd Foundations of the Rock
Gave way: Heav'n echo'd at the ratling Shock.
Tumbling it choak'd the Flood: On either ide
The Banks leap backward; and the Streams divide.
The Sky hrunk upward with unuual Dread:
And trembling Tyber div'd beneath his Bed.
The Court of Cacus tands reveal'd to ight;
The Cavern glares with new admitted Light.
So the pent Vapours with a rumbling Sound
Heave from below; and rend the hollow Ground:
A ounding Flaw ucceeds: And from on high,
The Gods, with Hate beheld the neather Sky:
The Ghots repine at violated Night;
And cure th' invading Sun; and icken at the ight.
The graceles Monter caught in open Day,
Inclos'd, and in Depair to fly away;
Howls horrible from underneath, and fills
His hollow Palace, with unmanly Yells.
The Heroe tands above; and from afar
Plies him with Darts, and Stones, and ditant War.
He, from his Notrils, and huge Mouth, expires
Black Clouds of Smoke, amidt his Father's Fires.
Gath'ring, with each repeated Blat, the Night:
To make uncertain Aim, and erring Sight.
The wrathful God, then plunges from above,
And where in thicket Waves the Sparkles drove,
There lights; and wades thro Fumes, and gropes his Way;
Half ing'd, half tifled, 'till he graps his Prey.
The Monter, pewing fruitles Flames, he found;
He queez'd his Throat, he writh'd his Neck around,
And in a Knot his cripled Members bound.
Then, from their Sockets, tore his burning Eyes;
Rowld on a heap the breathles Robber lyes.
The Doors, unbarr'd, receive the ruhing Day;
And thorough Lights dicloe the ravih'd Prey.
The Bulls redeem'd, breathe open Air agen;
Next, by the Feet, they drag him from his Den.
The wond'ring Neighbourhood, with glad urprize,
Behold his hagged Breat, his Gyant Size,
His Mouth that flames no more, and his extinguih'd Eyes.
From that aupicious Day, with Rites Divine,
We worhip at the Hero's Holy Shrine.
Potitius firt ordain'd thee annual Vows,
As Priets, were added the Pinarian Houe:
Who rais'd this Altar in the Sacred Shade;
Where Honours, ever due, for ever hall be paid.
For thee Deerts, and this high Virtue hown,
Ye warlike Youths, your Heads with Garlands crown.
Fill high the Goblets with a parkling Flood:
And with deep Draughts invoke our common God.
This aid, a double Wreath Evander twin'd:
And Poplars black and white his Temples bind.
Then Brims his ample Bowl: With like Deign
The ret invoke the Gods, with prinkled Wine.
Mean time the Sun decended from the Skies;
And the bright Evening-Star began to rie.
And now the Priets, Potitius at their Head,
In Skins of Beats involv'd, the long Proceion led:
Held high the flaming Tapers in their Hands;
As Cutom had precrib'd their holy Bands:
Then with a econd Coure the Tables load:
And with full Chargers offer to the God.
The Salij ing; and cene his Altars round
With Saban Smoke, their Heads with Poplar bound.
One Choire of old, another of the young;
To dance, and bear the Burthen of the Song.
The Lay records the Labours, and the Praie,
And all th' Immortal Acts of Hercules.
Firt, how the mighty Babe, when wath'd in Bands,
The Serpents trangled, with his Infant Hands:
Then, as in Years, and matchles Force he grew,
Th' Oechalian Walls, and Trojan overthrew.
Beides a thouand Hazards they relate,
Procur'd by Juno's, and Euritheus's Hate.
Thy Hands, unconquer'd Heroe, cou'd ubdue
The Cloud-born Centaurs, and the Monter Crew.
Nor thy reitles Arm the Bull withtood:
Nor He the roaring Terror of the Wood.
The triple Porter of the Stygian Seat,
With lolling Tongue, lay fawning at thy Feet:
And, eiz'd with Fear, forgot his mangled Meat.
Th' Infernal Waters trembled at thy Sight;
Thee, God, no face of Danger cou'd Affright.
Not huge Typhoeus, nor th' unnumber'd Snake,
Increas'd with hiing Heads, in Lerna's Lake.
Hail Jove's undoubted Son! An added Grace
To Heav'n, and the great Author of thy Race.
Receive the gratful Off'rings, which we pay,
And mile propitious on thy olemn Day.
In Numbers, thus, they ung: Above the ret,
The Den, and Death of Cacus crown the Feat.
The Woods to hollow Vales convey the Sound;
The Vales to Hills, and Hills the Notes rebound.
The Rites perform'd, the chearful Train retire.
Betwixt young Pallas, and his aged Sire
The Trojan pas'd, the City to urvey;
And pleafing Talk beguil'd the tedious Way.
The Stranger cat around his curious Eyes;
New Objects viewing till, with new Surprie.
With greedy Joy enquires of various Things;
And Acts and Monuments of Ancient Kings.
Then thus the Founder of the Roman Tow'rs:
Thee Woods were firt the Seat of Silvan Pow'rs,
Of Nymphs, and Fauns, and alvage Men, who took
Their Birth from Trunks of Trees, and tubborn Oak.
Nor Laws they knew, nor Manners, nor the Care
Of lab'ring Oxen, or the hining Share:
Nor Arts of Gain, nor what they gain'd to pare.
Their Exercie the Chae: the running Flood
Supply'd their Thirt; the Trees upply'd their Food.
Then Saturn came, who fled the Pow'r of Jove,
Robb'd of his Realms, and banih'd from above.

figure.p: To the Honble. Robert Bruce Second son to Robert late Earle of Ailesbury

lg.l: The Men, dipers'd on Hills, to Towns he brought;
And Laws ordain'd, and Civil Cutoms taught:
And Latium call'd the Land where afe he lay,
From his Unduteous Son, and his Uurping Sway.
With his mild Empire, Peace and Plenty came:
And hence the Golden Times deriv'd their name.
A more degenerate, and dicolour'd Age,
Succeeded this, with Avarice and Rage.
Th' Auonians, then, and bold Sicanians came;
And Saturn's Empire often chang'd the name.
Then Kings, Gygantick Tybris, and the ret,
With Arbitrary Sway the Land oppres'd.
For Tybers flood was Albula before:
Till, from the Tyrants Fate, his name it bore.
I lat arriv'd, driv'n from my native home,
By Fortune's Pow'r, and Fate's reitles Doom.
Long tos'd on Seas I ought this happy Land:
Warn'd by my Mother Nymph, and call'd by Heav'ns Command.
Thus, walking on, he poke: and hew'd the Gate,
Since call'd Carmental by the Roman State;
Where tood an Altar, Sacred to the Name
Of old Carmenta, the Prophetick Dame:
Who to her Son foretold th' Aenean Race,
Sublime in Fame, and Rome's Imperial Place.
Then hews the Foret, which in after times,
Fierce Romulus, for perpetrated Crimes,
A Sacred Refuge made: with this, the Shrine
Where Pan below the Rock had Rites Divine.
Then tells of Argus death, his murder'd Guet,
Whoe Grave, and Tomb, his Innocence attet.
Thence, to the teep Tarpeian Rock he leads;
Now Roof'd with Gold; then thatch'd with homely Reeds.
A Reverent fear (uch Supertition reigns
Among the rude) ev'n then poes'd the Swains.
Some God they knew, what God they cou'd not tell,
Did there amidt the acred horrour dwell.
Th' Arcadians thought him Jove; and aid they aw
The mighty Thund'rer with Majetick awe;
Who hook his Shield, and dealt his Bolts around;
And catter'd Tempets on the teeming Ground.
Then aw two heaps of Ruins; once they tood
Two tately Towns, on either ide the Flood.
Saturnia's and Janicula's Remains:
And, either place, the Founder's Name retains.
Dicouring thus together, they reort
Where poor Evander kept his Country Court.
They view'd the ground of Rome's litigious Hall;
Once Oxen low'd, where now the Lawyers bawl.
Then, tooping, through the Narrow Gate they pres'd,
When thus the King bepoke his Trojan Guet.
Mean as it is, this Palace, and this Door,
Receiv'd Alcides, then a Conquerour.
Dare to be poor: accept our homely Food
Which feated him; and emulate a God.
Then, underneath a lowly Roof, he led
The weary Prince; and laid him on a Bed:
The tuffing Leaves, which Hides of Bears o'repread.
Now Night had hed her ilver Dews around,
And with her able Wings embrac'd the Ground,
When Love's fair Goddes, anxious for her Son;
(New Tumults riing, and new Wars begun)
Couch'd with her Husband, in his Golden Bed,
With thee alluring Words invokes his aid.
And, that her pleaing Speech his Mind may move,
Inpires each accent with the Charms of Love.
While Cruel Fate conpir'd with Grecian Pow'rs,
To level with the Ground the Trojan Tow'rs;
I ask'd not Aid th' unhappy to retore:
Nor did the Succour of thy Skill implore.
Nor urg'd the Labours of my Lord in vain;
A inking Empire longer to utain.
Tho' much I ow'd to Priam's Houe; and more
The Dangers of Aeneas did deplore.
But now by Jove's Command, and Fates Decree,
His Race is doom'd to reign in Italy;
With humble Suit I beg thy needful Art,
O till propitious Pow'r, that rules my Heart!
A Mother kneels a uppliant for her Son.
By Thetis and Aurora thou wert won
To forge impenetrable Shields; and grace,
With fated Arms, a les illutrious Race.
Behold, what haughty Nations are combin'd
Againt the Relicks of the Phrygian Kind;
With Fire and Sword my People to detroy;
And conquer Venus twice, in conqu'ring Troy.
She aid; and trait her Arms, of nowy hue,
About her unreolving Husband threw.
Her oft Embraces oon infue Deire:
His Bones and Marrow udden Warmth inpire;
And all the Godhead feels the wonted Fire.
Not half o wift the ratling Thunder flies,
Or forky Lightnings flah along the Skies.
The Goddes, proud of her uccesful Wiles,
And concious of her Form, in ecret Smiles.
Then thus, the Pow'r, obnoxious to her Charms,
Panting, and half diolving in her Arms:
Why eek you Reaons for a Caue o jut;
Or your own Beauties, or my Love ditrut?
Long ince, had you requir'd my helpful Hand,
Th' Artificer, and Art you might command,
To labour Arms for Troy: Nor Jove, nor Fate,
Confin'd their Empire to o hort a Date.
And, if you now deire new Wars to wage,
My Skill I promie; and my Pains engage.
Whatever melting Metals can conpire,
Or breathing Bellows, or the forming Fire,
Is freely yours: Your anxious Fears remove:
And think no Task is difficult to Love.
Trembling he poke; and eager of her Charms,
He natch'd the willing Goddes to his Arms;
'Till in her Lap infus'd, he lay poes'd
Of full Deire, and unk to pleaing Ret.
Now when the Night her middle race had rode;
And his firt Slumber had refreh'd the God;
The time when early Houewifes leave the Bed;
And living Embers on the Hearth they pred;
Supply the Lamp, and call the Maids to rie,
With yawning Mouths, and with half open'd Eyes;
They ply the Ditaff by the winking Light;
And to their daily Labour add the Night.
Thus frugally they earn their Childrens Bread:
And uncorrupted keep the Nuptial Bed.
Not les concern'd, nor at a later Hour,
Roe from his downy Couch the forging Pow'r.
Sacred to Vulcan's Name an Ile there lay,
Betwixt Sicilia's Coats and Lipare;
Rais'd high on moaking Rocks, and deep below,
In hollow Caves the Fires of Aetna glow.
The Cyclops here their heavy Hammers deal;
Loud Strokes, and hiings of tormented Steel
Are heard around: The boyling Waters roar;
And moaky Flames thro' fuming Tunnels oar.
Hether, the Father of the Fire, by Night,
Through the brown Air precipitates his Flight.

figure.p: To Chritopher Rich of Grays Inn Esq
figure.head: AE. 8. l: 560

lg.l: On their Eternal Anvils here he found
The Brethren beating, and the Blows go round:
A load of pointles Thunder now there lies
Before their Hands, to ripen for the Skies:
Thee Darts, for angry Jove, they dayly cat:
Conum'd on Mortals with prodigious wate.
Three Rays of writhen Rain, of Fire three more,
Of winged Southern Winds, and cloudy Store
As many parts, the dreadful Mixture frame:
And Fears are added, and avenging Flame.
Inferior Miniters, for Mars repair
His broken Axeltrees, and blunted War:
And end him forth agen, with furbih'd Arms,
To wake the lazy War, with Trumpets loud Alarms.
The ret refreh the caly Snakes, that fold
The Shield of Pallas; and renew their Gold.
Full on the Cret the Gorgon's Head they place,
With Eyes that rowl in Death, and with ditorted Face.
My Sons, aid Vulcan, et your Tasks aide,
Your Strength, and Mater Skill, mut now be try'd.
Arms, for a Heroe forge: Arms that require
Your Force, your Speed, and all your forming Fire.
He aid: They et their former Work aide:
And their new Toils with eager hate divide.
A Flood of molten Silver, Bras, and Gold,
And deadly Steel, in the large Furnace rowl'd;
Of this, their artful Hands a Shield prepare;
Alone ufficient to utain the War.
Sev'n Orbs within a pacious round they cloe;
One tirs the Fire, and one the Bellows blows.
The hiing Steel is in the Smithy drown'd;
The Grot with beaten Anvils groans around.
By turns their Arms advance, in equal time:
By turns their Hands decend, and Hammers chime.
They turn the glowing Mas, with crooked Tongs:
The fiery Work proceeds, with Rutick Songs.
While, at the Lemnian God's Command, they urge
Their Labours thus, and ply th' Eolian Forge:
The chearful Morn alutes Evander's Eyes;
And Songs of chirping Birds invite to rie.
He leaves his lowly Bed; his Buskins meet
Above his Ankles; Sandals heath his Feet:
He ets his truty Sword upon his ide;
And o're his Shoulder throws a Panther's Hide.
Two Menial Dogs before their Mater pres'd:
Thus clad, and guarded thus, he eeks his Kingly Guet.
Mindful of promis'd Aid, he mends his Pace:
But meets Aeneas in the middle Space.
Young Pallas did his Father's Steps attend;
And true Achates waited on his Friend.
They join their Hands; a ecret Seat they chufe;
Th' Arcadian firt, their former Talk renews.
Undaunted Prince, I never can believe
The Trojan Empire lot, while you urvive.
Command th' Aitance of a faithful Friend:
But feeble are the Succours I can end.
Our narrow Kingdom, here the Tyber bounds;
That other ide the Latian State urrounds;
Inults our Walls, and wates our fruitful Grounds.
But mighty Nations I prepare, to join
Their Arms with yours, and aid your jut Deign.
You come, as by your better Genius ent:
And Fortune eems to favour your intent.
Not far from hence there tands a Hilly Town,
Of ancient Building, and of high Renown;
Torn from the Tucans, by the Lydian Race;
Who gave the Name of Caere, to the Place
Once Agyllina call'd: It flourih'd long
In Pride of Wealth; and warlike People trong.
'Till curs'd Mezentius, in a fatal Hour,
Aum'd the Crown, with Arbitrary Pow'r.
What Words can paint thoe execrable Times;
The Subjects Suff'rings, and the Tyrant's Crimes!
That Blood, thoe Murthers, O ye Gods replace
On his own Head, and on his impious Race!
The living, and the Dead, at his Command
Were coupled, Face to Face, and Hand to Hand:
'Till choak'd with Stench, in loath'd Embraces ty'd,
The ling'ring Wretches pin'd away, and dy'd.
Thus plung'd in Ills, and meditating more,
The People's Patience tyr'd, no longer bore
The raging Monter: But with Arms beet
His Houe, and Vengeance and Detruction threat.
They fire his Palace: While the Flame acends,
They force his Guards; and execute his Friends.
He cleaves the Crowd; and favour'd by the Night,
To Turnus's friendly Court directs his flight.
By jut Revenge the Tucans et on Fire,
With Arms, their King to Punihment require:
Their num'rous Troops, now muter'd on the Strand,
My Counel hall ubmit to your Command.
Their Navy warms upon the Coats: They cry
To hoit their Anchors; but the Gods deny.
An ancient Augur, skill'd in future Fate,
With thee foreboding Words retrains their Hate.
Ye brave in Arms, ye Lydian Blood, the Flow'r
Of Tucan Youth, and choice of all their Pow'r,
Whom jut Revenge againt Mezentius arms,
To eek your Tyrant's Death, by lawful Arms:
Know this; no Native of our Land may lead
This pow'rful People: Seek a Foreign Head.
Aw'd with thee Words, in Camps they till abide;
And wait with longing Looks their promis'd Guide.
Tarchon, the Tucan Chief, to me has ent
Their Crown, and ev'ry Regal Ornament:
The People join their own with his Deire;
And All, my Conduct, as their King, require.
But the chill Blood that creeps within my Veins,
And Age, and lifeles Limbs unfit for Pains,
And a Soul concious of its own Decay,
Have forc'd me to refue Imperial Sway.
My Pallas were more fit to mount the Throne;
And hou'd, but he's a Sabine Mother's Son;
And half a Native: But in you combine
A Manly Vigour, and a Foreign Line.
Where Fate and miling Fortune hew the Way,
Purue the ready Path to Sov'raign Sway.
The Staff of my declining Days, my Son,
Shall make your good or ill Succes his own.
In fighting Fields from you hall learn to dare:
And erve the hard Apprentihip of War.
Your matchles Courage, and your Conduct view;
And early hall begin t' admire and copy you.
Beides, two hundred Hore he hall command:
Tho' few, a warlike and well choen Band.
Thee in my Name are lited: And my Son
As many more has added in his own.
Scarce had he aid; Achates and his Guet,
With downcat Eyes their ilent Grief expret:
Who hort of Succours; and in deep Depair,
Shook at the dimal Propect of the War.
But his bright Mother, from a breaking Cloud,
To chear her Iue, thunder'd thrice aloud.
Thrice, forky Lightning flah'd along the Sky;
And Tyrrhene Trumpets thrice were heard on high.
Then, gazing up, repeated Peals they hear:
And, in a Heav'n erene, refulgent Arms appear;
Red'ning the Skies, and glitt'ring all around,
The temper'd Metals clah; and yield a Silver ound.
The ret tood trembling, truck with awe divine,
Aeneas onely concious to the Sign:
Preag'd th' Event; and joyful view'd, above,
Th' accomplih'd Promie of the Queen of Love.
Then, to th' Arcadian King: This Prodigy
(Dimis your Fear) belongs alone to me.
Heav'n calls me to the War: Th' expected Sign
Is giv'n of promis'd Aid, and Arms Divine.
My Goddes-Mother; whoe Indulgent Care,
Foreaw the Dangers of the growing War;
This Omen gave; when Bright Vulcanian Arms,
Fated from force of Steel by Stygian Charms,
Supended, hone on high: She then forehow'd
Approaching Fights, and Fields to float in Blood.

l.U: hall dearly pay for Faith forworn;

lg.l: And Corps, and Swords, and Shields, on Tyber born,
Shall choak his Flood: Now ound the loud Alarms;
And Latian Troops prepare your perjur'd Arms.
He aid; and riing from his homely Throne,
The Solemn Rites of Hercules begun:
And on his Altars wak'd the leeping Fires:
Then chearful to his Houehold-Gods retires.
There offers choen Sheep: Th' Arcadian King
And Trojan Youth the ame Oblations bring.
Next of his Men, and Ships, he makes review,
Draws out the bet, and ablet of the Crew.
Down with the falling Stream the Refue run:
To raie with joyful News his drooping Son.
Steeds are prepar'd to mount the Trojan Band;
Who wait their Leader to the Tyrrhene Land.
A prightly Courer, fairer than the ret,
The King himelf preents his Royal Guet.
A Lyons Hide his Back and Limbs infold;
Precious with tudded work, and Paws of Gold.
Fame through the little City preads aloud
Th' intended March, amid the fearful Crowd:
The Matrons beat their Breats; diolve in Tears;
And double their Devotion in their Fears.
The War at hand appears with more affright:
And ries ev'ry Moment to the ight.
Then, old Evander, with a cloe embrace,
Strain'd his departing Friend; and Tears o're-flow his Face:
Wou'd Heav'n, aid he, my trength and youth recall,
Such as I was beneath Prenete's Wall;
Then when I made the foremot Foes retire,
And et whole heaps of conquer'd Shields on Fire.
When Herilus in ingle Fight I lew;
Whom with three lives Feronia did endue:
And thrice I ent him to the Stygian Shore;
Till the lat Ebbing Soul return'd no more:
Such, if I tood renew'd, not thee Alarms,
Nor Death, hou'd rend me from my Pallas arms:
Nor proud Mezentius, thus unpunih'd, boat
His Rapes and Murthers on the Tucan Coat.
Ye Gods! and mighty Jove, in pity bring
Relief, and hear a Father, and a King.
If Fate and you, reerve thee Eyes, to ee
My Son return with peace and Victory;
If the lov'd Boy hall bles his Father's ight;
If we hall meet again with more delight;
Then draw my Life in length, let me utain,
In hopes of his Embrace, the wort of Pain.
But if your hard Decrees, which O I dread,
Have doom'd to death his undeerving head;
This, O this very Moment, let me die;
While Hopes and Fears in equal ballance lye.
While yet Poet of all his Youthful Charms,
I train him cloe within thee Aged Arms:
Before that fatal news my Soul hall wound!
He aid, and, wooning, unk upon the ground;
His Servants bore him off: And oftly laid
His languih'd Limbs upon his homely Bed.
The Horemen march; the Gates are open'd wide;
Aeneas at their head, Achates by his ide.
Next thee the Trojan Leaders rode along:
Lat, follows in the Reer, th' Arcadian Throng.
Young Pallas hone conpicuous o're the ret;
Guilded his Arms, Embroider'd was his Vet.
So, from the Seas, exerts his radiant head
The Star, by whom the Lights of Heav'n are led:
Shakes from his roie Locks the perly Dews;
Dipels the darknes, and the Day renews.
The trembling Wives, the Walls and Turrets crowd;
And follow, with their Eyes, the duty Cloud:
Which Winds dipere by fits; and hew from far
The blaze of Arms, and Shields, and hining War.
The Troops, drawn up in beautiful Array,
O're heathy Plains purue the ready way.
Repeated peals of howts are heard around:
The Neighing Courers anwer to the ound:
And hake with horny Hoofs the olid ground.
A greenwood Shade, for long Religion known,
Stands by the Streams that wah the Tucan Town:
Incompas'd round with gloomy Hills above,
Which add a holy horrour to the Grove.
The firt Inhabitants, of Grecian Blood,
That acred Foret to Sylvanus vow'd:
The Guardian of their Flocks, and Fields; and pay
Their due Devotions on his annual day.
Not far from hence, along the River's ide,
In Tents ecure, the Tucan Troops abide;
By Tarchon led. Now, from a riing ground,
Aeneas cat his wond'ring Eyes around;
And all the Tyrrhene Army had in ight,
Stretch'd on the pacious Plain from left to right.
Thether his warlike Train the Trojan led;
Refreh'd his Men, and weary'd Hores fed.
Mean time the Mother Goddes, crown'd with Charms,
Breaks through the Clouds, and brings the fated Arms.
Within a winding Vale he finds her Son,
On the cool Rivers' Banks, retir'd alone.
She hews her heav'nly Form, without diguie,
And gives her elf to his deiring Eyes.
Behold, he aid, perform'd, in ev'ry part
My promie made; and Vulcan's labour'd Art.
Now eek, ecure, the Latian Enemy;
And haughty Turnus to the Field defy.
She aid: And having firt her Son embrac'd;
The radiant Arms beneath an Oak he plac'd.
Proud of the Gift, he rowl'd his greedy ight
Around the Work, and gaz'd with vat delight.
He lifts, he turns, he poizes, and admires
The Creted Helm, that vomits radiant Fires:
His hands the fatal Sword, and Corlet hold:
One keen with temper'd Steel, one tiff with Gold.
Both ample, flaming both, and beamy bright:
So hines a Cloud, when edg'd with advere Light.
He hakes the pointed Spear; and longs to try
The plated Cuihes, on his manly thigh,
But mot admires the Shields Myterious mould,
And Roman Triumphs riing on the Gold.

figure.p: To Sr. Godfry Kneller Knight Principall Painter to his Majesty
figure.head: AE. 8. l. 805

lg.l: For thoe, embos'd, the Heav'nly Smith had wrought,
(Not in the Rolls of future Fate untaught,)
The Wars in Order, and the Race Divine
Of Warriors, iuing from the Julian Line.
The Cave of Mars was dres'd with moy Greens:
There, by the Wolf, were laid the Martial Twins.
Intrepid on her welling Dugs they hung;
The foter Dam loll'd out her fawning Tongue:
They uck'd ecure, while bending Back her Head,
She lick'd their tender Limbs; and form'd them as they fed.
Not far from thence new Rome appears, with Games
Projected for the Rape of Sabine Dames.
The Pit reounds with Shrieks: A War ucceeds,
