For breach of Publick Faith, and unexampl'd Deeds.
Here for Revenge the Sabine Troops contend:
The Romans there with Arms the Prey defend.
Weary'd with tedious War, at length they ceae;
And both the Kings and Kingdoms plight the Peace.
The friendly Chiefs, before Jove's Altar tand;
Both arm'd, with each a Charger in his Hand:
A fatted Sow, for Sacrifice is led;
With Imprecations on the perjur'd Head.
Near this, the Traytor Metius, tretch'd between
Four fiery Steeds, is dragg'd along the Green;
By Tullus doom: The Brambles drink his Blood;
And his torn Limbs are left, the Vulture's Food.
There, Porena to Rome proud Tarquin brings;
And wou'd by Force retore the banih'd Kings.
One Tyrant, for his fellow Tyrant fights:
The Roman Youth aert their Native Rights.
Before the Town the Tucan Army lies:
To win by Famine, or by Fraud urprie.
Their King, half threat'ning, half didaining tood:
While Cocles broke the Bridge; and tem'd the Flood.
The Captive Maids there tempt the raging Tide:
Scap'd from their Chains, with Clelia for their Guide.
High on a Rock Heroick Manlius tood;
To guard the Temple, and the Temple's God:
Then Rome was poor; and there you might behold
The Palace, thatch'd with Straw, now roof'd with Gold.
The Silver Goofe before the hining Gate
There flew; and by her Cackle, av'd the State.
She told the Gauls approach: Th' approaching Gauls,
Obcure in Night, acend, and eize the Walls.
The Gold, diembl'd well their yellow Hair:
And Golden Chains on their white Necks they wear.
Gold are their Vets: Long Alpine Spears they wield:
And their left Arm utains a length of Shield.
Hard by, the leaping Salian Priets advance:
And naked thro' the Streets the mad Luperci dance:
In Caps of Wool. The Targets dropt from Heav'n:
Here modet Matrons in oft Litters driv'n,
To pay their Vows in olemn Pomp appear:
And odorous Gums in their chat Hands they bear.
Far hence remov'd, the Stygian Seats are een:
Pains of the damn'd, and punih'd Catiline:
Hung on a Rock the Traytor; and around,
The Furies hiing from the neather Ground.
Apart from thee, the happy Souls, he draws:
And Cato's holy Ghot, dipening Laws.
Betwixt the Quarters, flows a Golden Sea:
But foaming Surges, there, in Silver play.
The dancing Dolphins, with their Tails, divide
The glitt'ring Waves; and cut the precious Tide.
Amid the Main, two mighty Fleets engage
Their Brazen Beaks; oppos'd with equal Rage.

l.U: urveys the well diputed Prize:

lg.l: Leucate's wat'ry Plain, with foamy Billows fries.
Young Caear, on the Stern, in Armour bright;
Here leads the Romans and their Gods to fight:
His beamy Temples hoot their Flames afar;
And o're his Head is hung the Julian Star.

l.U: econds him, with prop'rous Gales:

lg.l: And, with propitious Gods, his Foes aails.
A Naval Crown, that binds his Manly Brows,
The happy Fortune of the Fight forehows.
Rang'd on the Line oppos'd, Antonius brings
Barbarian Aids, and Troops of Eatern Kings.
Th' Arabians near, and Bactrians from afar,
Of Tongues dicordant, and a mingled War.
And, rich in gaudy Robes, amidt the Strife,
His ill Fate follows him; th' Egyptian Wife.
Moving they fight: With Oars, and forky Prows,
The Froth is gather'd; and the Water glows.
It eems, as if the Cyclades again
Were rooted up, and jutled in the Main:
Or floating Mountains, floating Mountains meet:
Such is the fierce Encounter of the Fleet.
Fire-balls are thrown; and pointed Jav'lins fly:
The Fields of Neptune take a Purple Dye.
The Queen her elf, amidt the loud Alarms,
With Cymbals tos'd her fainting Souldiers warms.
Fool as he was; who had not yet divin'd
Her cruel Fate; nor aw the Snakes behind.
Her Country Gods, the Monters of the Sky,
Great Neptune, Pallas, and Love's Queen, defy.
The Dog Anubis barks, but barks in vain;
Nor longer dares oppoe th' Aetherial Train.
Mars, in the middle of the hining Shield
Is grav'd, and trides along the liquid Field.
The Dirae owe from Heav'n, with wift Decent:
And Dicord, dy'd in Blood, with Garments rent,
Divides the Preace: Her Steps, Bellona treads,
And hakes her Iron Rod above their Heads.
This een, Apollo, from his Actian height,
Pours down his Arrows: At whoe winged flight
The trembling Indians, and Egyptians yield:
And oft Sabaeans quit the wat'ry Field.
The fatal Mitres hoits her ilken Sails;
And, hrinking from the Fight, invokes the Gales.
Aghat he looks; and heaves her Breat, for Breath:
Panting, and pale with fear of future Death.
The God had figur'd her, as driv'n along,
By Winds and Waves; and cudding thro' the Throng.
Jut oppoite, ad Nilus, opens wide
His Arms, and ample Boom, to the Tide.
And preads his Mantle o're the winding Coat:
In which he wraps his Queen, and hides the flying Ho •••
The Victor, to the Gods his Thanks expres'd
And Rome triumphant, with his Preence bles'd.
Three hundred Temples in the Town he plac'd:
With Spoils and Altars ev'ry Temple grac'd.
Three hining Nights, and three ucceeding Days,
The Fields reound with Shouts; the Streets with Praie
The Domes with Songs, the Theatres with Plays.
All Altars flame: Before each Altar lies,
Drench'd in his Gore, the detin'd Sacrifice.
Great Caear its ublime upon his Throne;
Before Apollo's Porch of Parian Stone:
Accepts the Preents vow'd for Victory;
And hangs the monumental Crowns on high.
Vat Crowds of vanquih'd Nations march along:
Various in Arms, in Habit, and in Tongue.
Here, Mulciber aigns the proper Place
For Carians, and th' ungirt Numidian Race;
Then ranks the Thracians in the econd Row;
With Scythians, expert in the Dart and Bow.
And here the tam'd Euphrates humbly glides;
And there the Rhine ubmits her welling Tides.
And proud Araxes, whom no Bridge cou'd bind:
The Danes unconquer'd Offspring, march behind;
And Morini, the lat of Human Kind.
Thee Figures, on the Shield divinely wrought,
By Vulcan labour'd, and by Venus brought,
With Joy and Wonder fill the Hero's thought.
Unknown the Names, he yet admires the Grace;
And bears aloft the Fame, and Fortune of his Race.

div.head: The Ninth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Turnus takes Advantage of Aeneas's Abence, fires ome of his Ships, (which are transform'd into Sea-Nymphs) and aaults his Camp. The Trojans reduc'd to the lat Extremities, end Nius and Euryalus to recall Aeneas; which furnihes the Poet with that admirable Epiode of their Friendhip, Generoity; and the concluion of their Adventures.

lg.l: WHile thee Affairs in ditant Places pas'd,
The various Iris Juno ends with hate,
To find bold Turnus, who, with anxious Thought,
The ecret Shade of his great Grandire ought.
Retir'd alone he found the daring Man;
And op'd her roie Lips, and thus began.
What none of all the Gods cou'd grant thy Vows;
That, Turnus, this aupicious Day betows.
Aeneas, gone to eek th' Arcadian Prince,
Has left the Trojan Camp without defence;
And, hort of Succours there; employs his Pains
In Parts remote to raie the Tucan Swains:
Now natch an Hour that favours thy Deigns,
Unite thy Forces, and attack their Lines.
This aid, on equal Wings he pois'd her Weight,
And form'd a radiant Rainbow in her flight.
The Daunian Heroe lifts his Hands and Eyes;
And thus invokes the Goddes as he flies.
Iris, the Grace of Heav'n, what Pow'r Divine
Has ent thee down, thro' dusky Clouds to hine?
See they divide; immortal Day appears;
And glitt'ring Planets dancing in their Spheres!

figure.p: To the Right Honble. Robert Earle of Sunderland Ld. Chamberlaine of his Majesties Household &
figure.head: AE. 9. l. 2.

lg.l: With Joy, thee happy Omens I obey;
And follow to the War, the God that leads the Way.
Thus having aid, as by the Brook he tood,
He coop'd the Water from the Crytal Flood;
Then with his Hands the drops to Heav'n he throws,
And loads the Pow'rs above with offer'd Vows.
Now march the bold Confed'rates thro' the Plain;
Well hors'd, well clad, a rich and hining Train:
Meapus leads the Van; and in the Reer,
The Sons of Tyrrheus in bright Arms appear.
In the Main Battel, with his flaming Cret,
The mighty Turnus tow'rs above the ret:
Silent they move; majetically low,
Like ebbing Nile, or Ganges in his flow.
The Trojans view the duty Cloud from far;
And the dark Menace of the ditant War.
Caicus from the Rampire aw it rie,
Blackning the Fields, and thickning thro' the Skies.
Then to his Fellows thus aloud he calls,
What rowling Clouds, my Friends, approach the Walls?
Arm, arm, and man the Works; prepare your Spears,
And pointed Darts; the Latian Hoat appears.
Thus warn'd, they hut their Gates; with Shouts acend
The Bulwarks, and ecure their Foes attend.
For their wie Gen'ral with foreeeing Care,
Had charg'd them not to tempt the doubtful War:
Nor, tho' provok'd, in open Fields advance;
But cloe within their Lines attend their chance.
Unwilling, yet they keep the trict Command;
And ourly wait in Arms the Hotile Band.
The fiery Turnus flew before the ret,
A Pye-ball'd Steed of Thracian Strain he pres'd;
His Helm of may Gold; and Crimon was his Cret.
With twenty Hore to fecond his Deigns,
An unexpected Foe, he fac'd the Lines.
Is there, he aid, in Arms who bravely dare,
His Leader's Honour, and his Danger hare?
Then, purring on, his brandih'd Dart he threw,
In ign of War, applauding Shouts enue.
Amaz'd to find a datard Race that run
Behind the Rampires, and the Battel hun,
He rides around the Camp, with rowling Eyes,
And tops at ev'ry Pot; and ev'ry Paage tries.
So roams the nightly Wolf about the Fold,
Wet with decending Show'rs, and tiff with cold;
He howls for Hunger, and he grins for Pain;
His gnahing Teeth are exercis'd in vain:
And impotent of Anger, finds no way
In his ditended Paws to grap the Prey.
The Mothers liten; but the bleating Lambs
Securely wig the Dug, beneath the Dams.
Thus ranges eager Turnus o're the Plain,
Sharp with Deire, and furious with Didain:
Surveys each Paage with a piercing Sight;
To force his Foes in equal Field to fight.
Thus, while he gazes round, at length he pies
Where, fenc'd with trong Redoubts, their Navy lies;
Cloe underneath the Walls: The wahing Tyde
Secures from all approach this weaker ide.
He takes the wih'd Occaion; fills his Hand
With ready Fires, and hakes a flaming Brand:
Urg'd by his Preence, ev'ry Soul is warm'd,
And ev'ry Hand with kindled Firrs is arm'd.
From the fir'd Pines the catt'ring Sparkles fly;
Fat Vapours mix'd with Flames involve the Sky.
What Pow'r, O Mues, cou'd avert the Flame
Which threaten'd, in the Fleet, the Trojan Name!
Tell: For the Fact thro' length of Time obcure,
Is hard to Faith; yet hall the Fame endure.
'Tis aid, that when the Chief prepar'd his flight,
And fell'd his Timber from Mount Ida's height,
The Grandam Goddes then approach'd her Son,
And with a Mother's Majety begun.
Grant me, he aid, the ole Requet I bring.
Since conquer'd Heav'n has own'd you for its King:
On Ida's Brows, for Ages pat, there tood,
With Firrs and Maples fill'd, a hady Wood:
And on the Summit roe a Sacred Grove,
Where I was worhipp'd with Religious Love;
Thoe Woods, that Holy Grove, my long delight,
I gave the Trojan Prince, to peed his flight.
Now fill'd with Fear, on their behalf I come;
Let neither Winds o'reet, nor Waves intomb
The floating Forets of the Sacred Pine;
But let it be their Safety to be mine.
Then thus reply'd her awful Son; who rowls
The radiant Stars, and Heav'n and Earth controuls;
How dare you, Mother, endles Date demand,
For Veels moulded by a Mortal Hand?
What then is Fate? Shall bold Aeneas ride
Of Safety certain, on th' uncertain Tide?
Yet what I can, I grant: When, wafted o're,
The Chief is landed on the Latian Shore,
Whatever Ships ecape the raging Storms,
At my Command hall change their fading Forms
To Nymphs Divine: and plow the wat'ry Way,
Like Dotis, and the Daughters of the Sea.
To eal his acred Vow, by Styx he wore,
The Lake of liquid Pitch, the dreery Shore;
And Phlegethon's innavigable Flood,
And the black Regions of his Brother God:
He aid; and hook the Skies with his Imperial Nod.
And now at length the number'd Hours were come,
Prefix'd by Fate's irrevocable Doom,
When the great Mother of the Gods was free
To ave her Ships, and finih Jove's Decree.
Firt, from the Quarter of the Morn, there prung
A Light that ign'd the Heav'ns, and hot along:
Then from a Cloud, fring'd round with Golden Fires,
Were Timbrels heard, and Berecynthian Quires:
And lat a Voice, with more than Mortal Sounds,
Both Hots in Arms oppos'd, with equal Horrour wounds.
O Trojan Race, your needles Aid forbear;
And know my Ships are my peculiar Care.
With greater eae the bold Rutulian may,
With hiing Brands, attempt to burn the Sea,
Than indge my acred Pines. But you my Charge,
Loos'd from your crooked Anchors lanch at large,
Exalted each a Nymph: Forake the Sand,
And wim the Seas, at Cybele's Command.
No ooner had the Goddes ceas'd to peak,
When lo, th' obedient Ships, their Haulers break;
And, trange to tell, like Dolphins in the Main,
They plunge their Prows, and dive, and pring again:
As many beauteous Maids the Billows weep,
As rode before tall Veels on the Deep.
The Foes, urpriz'd with Wonder, tood aghat,
Meapus curb'd his fiery Courer's hate;
Old Tyber roar'd; and raiing up his Head,
Call'd back his Waters to their Oozy Bed.
Turnus alone, undaunted, bore the Shock;
And with thee Words his trembling Troops bepoke
Thee Monters for the Trojans Fate are meant,
And are by Jove for black Preages ent.
He takes the Cowards lat Relief away;
For fly they cannot; and, contrain'd to tay,
Mut yield unfought, a bae inglorious Prey.

figure.p: To Thomas Foley Junr: of Great Witley Court in the County of Worcester Esq.
figure.head: AE. 9. l. 130.

lg.l: The liquid half of all the Globe, is lot;
Heav'n huts the Seas, and we ecure the Coat.
Theirs is no more, than that mall pot of Ground,
Which Millions of our Martial Troops urround.
Their Fates I fear not; or vain Oracles;
'Twas giv'n to Venus, they hou'd cros the Seas:
And land ecure upon the Latian Plains,
Their promis'd Hour is pas'd, and mine remains.
'Tis in the Fate of Turnus, to detroy
With Sword and Fire the faithles Race of Troy.
Shall uch Affronts as thee, alone inflame
The Grecian Brothers, and the Grecian Name?
My Caue and theirs is one; a fatal Strife,
And final Ruin, for a ravih'd Wife.
Was't not enough, that, punih'd for the Crime,
They fell; but will they fall a econd Time?
One wou'd have thought they paid enough before,
To cure the cotly Sex; and durt offend no more.
Can they ecurely trut their feeble Wall,
A light Partition, a thin Interval,
Betwixt their Fate and them; when Troy, tho' built
By Hands Divine, yet perih'd by their Guilt?
Lend me, for once, my Friends, your valiant Hands,
To force from out their Lines thee datard Bands.
Les than a thouand Ships will end this War;
Nor Vulcan needs his fated Arms prepare.
Let all the Tucans, all th' Arcadians join,
Nor thee, nor thoe hall frutrate my Deign.
Let them not fear the Treaons of the Night;
The robb'd Palladium, the pretended flight:
Our Onet hall be made in open Light.
No wooden Engine hall their Town betray,
Fires they hall have around, but Fires by Day.
No Grecian Babes before their Camp appear,
Whom Hector's Arms detain'd, to the tenth tardy Year.
Now, ince the Sun is rowling to the Wet,
Give we the ilent Night to neeedful Ret:
Refreh your Bodies, and your Arms prepare,
The Morn hall end the mall Remains of War.
The Pot of Honour to Meapus falls,
To keep the Nightly Guard; to watch the Walls;
To pitch the Fires at Ditances around,
And cloe the Trojans in their canty Ground.
Twice even Rutulian Captains ready tand;
And twice even hundred Hore thee Chiefs command:
All clad in hining Arms the Works invet;
Each with a radiant Helm, and waving Cret.
Stretch'd at their length, they pres the gray Ground;
They laugh, they ing, the jolly Bowls go round:
With Lights, and chearful Fires renew the Day;
And pas the wakeful Night in Feats and Play.
The Trojans, from above, their Foes beheld;
And with arm'd Legions all the Rampires fill'd:
Seiz'd with Affright, their Gates they firt explore,
Join Works to Works with Bridges; Tow'r to Tow'r:
Thus all things needful for Defence, abound;
Mnetheus, and brave Serethus walk the round:
Commiion'd by their Abent Prince, to hare
The common Danger, and divide the Care.
The Souldiers draw their Lots; and as they fall,
By turns relieve each other on the Wall.
Nigh where the Foes their utmot Guards advance,
To watch the Gate, was warlike Nius chance.
His Father Hyrtacus of Noble Blood;
His Mother was a Hunt'res of the Wood:
And ent him to the Wars; well cou'd he bear
His Lance in fight, and dart the flying Spear:
But better skill'd unerring Shafts to end:
Beide him tood Euryalus his Friend.
Euryalus, than whom the Trojan Hoat
No fairer Face, or fweeter Air could boat.
Scarce had the Down to hade his Cheeks begun;
One was their Care, and their Delight was one.
One Common hazard in the War they har'd;
And now were both by choice upon the Guard.
Then Nius, thus: Or do the Gods inpire
This warmth, or make we Gods of our Deire?
A gen'rous ardour boils within my Breat,
Eager of Action, Enemy to Ret:
This urges me to fight, and fires my Mind,
To leave a memorable Name behind.
Thou ee't the Foe ecure: how faintly hine
Their catter'd Fires! the mot in Sleep upine;
Along the ground, an eaie Conquet lye;
The wakeful few, the fuming Flaggon ply:
All huh'd around. Now hear what I revolve;
A Thought unripe; and carcely yet reolve.
Our abent Prince both Camp and Council mourn;
By Meage both wou'd haten his return:
If they confer what I demand, on thee,
(For Fame is Recompence enough for me)
Methinks, beneath yon Hill, I have epy'd
A way that afely will my paage guide.

l.U: tood lit'ning while he poke;

lg.l: With love of Praie, and noble Envy truck;
Then to his ardent Friend expos'd his Mind:
All this alone, and leaving me behind,
Am I unworthy, Nius, to be join'd?
Think't thou I can my hare of Glory yield,
Or end thee unaited to the Field?
Not o my Father taught my Childhood Arms;
Born in a Siege, and bred among Alarms!
Nor is my Youth unworthy of my Friend,
Nor of the Heav'n-born Heroe I attend.
The thing call'd Life, with eae I can diclaim;
And think it over old to purchae Fame.
Then Nius, thus; alas! thy tender years
Wou'd miniter new matter to my Fears:
So may the Gods, who view this friendly Strife,
Retore me to thy lov'd Embrace with life,
Condemn'd to pay my Vows (as ure I trut,)
This thy Requet is Cruel and Unjut.
But if ome Chance, as many Chances are,
And doubtful Hazards in the deeds of War;
If one hou'd reach my Head, there let it fall,
And pare thy Life; I wou'd not perih all.
Thy bloomy Youth deerves a longer date;
Live thou to mourn thy Love's unhappy Fate:
To bear my mangled Body from the Foe;
Or buy it back, and Fun'ral Rites betow.
Or if hard Fortune hall thoe Dues deny,
Thou cant at leat an empty Tomb upply.
O let not me the Widows Tears renew;
Nor let a Mother's Cure my Name purue;
Thy Pious Parent, who, for love of thee,
Forook the Coats of friendly Sicily,
Her Age, committing to the Seas and Wind,
When ev'ry weary Matron taid behind.
To this, Euryalus, you plead in vain,
And but protract the Caue you cannot gain:
No more delays, but hate. With that he wakes
The nodding Watch; each to his Office takes.
The Guard reliev'd, the gen'rous Couple went
To find the Council at the Royal Tent.
All Creatures ele forgot their daily Care;
And Sleep, the common Gift of Nature, hare:
Except the Trojan Peers, who wakeful ate
In nightly Council for th' indanger'd State.
They vote a Meage to their abent Chief;
Shew their Ditres; and beg a wift Relief.
Amid the Camp a ilent Seat they choe,
Remote from Clamour, and ecure from Foes.
On their left Arms their ample Shields they bear,
The right reclin'd upon the bending Spear.
Now Nius and his Friend approach the Guard,
And beg Admiion, eager to be heard:
Th' Affair important, not to be deferr'd.
Acanius bids 'em be conducted in;
Ord'ring the more experienc'd to begin.
Then Nius thus. Ye Fathers lend your Ears;
Nor judge our bold Attempt beyond our Years.
The Foe ecurely drench'd in Sleep and Wine,
Neglect their Watch; the Fires but thinly hine:
And where the Smoke, in cloudy Vapours flies,
Cov'ring the Plain, and curling to the Skies,
Betwixt two Paths, which at the Gate divide,
Cloe by the Sea, a Paage we have py'd,
Which will our way to great Aeneas guide.
Expect each Hour to ee him afe again,
Loaded with Spoils of Foes in Battel lain.
Snatch we the lucky Minute while we may:
Nor can we be mitaken in the way;
For hunting in the Vale, we both have een
The riing Turrets, and the Stream between;
And know the winding Coure, with ev'ry Ford.
He ceas'd: And old Alethes took the Word.
Our Country Gods, in whom our Trut we place,
Will yet from Ruin ave the Trojan Race:
While we behold uch dauntles Worth appear
In dawning Youth; and Souls o void of Fear.
Then, into Tears of Joy the Father broke;
Each in his longing Arms by Turns he took:
Panted and paus'd; and thus again he poke.
Ye brave young Men, what equal Gifts can we,
In recompencc of uch Deert, decree?
The greatet, ure, and bet you can receive,
The Gods, and your own concious Worth will give.
The ret our grateful Gen'ral will betow;
And young Acanius 'till his Manhood owe.
And I, whoe Welfare in my Father lies,
Acanius adds, by the great Deities,
By my dear Country, by my houehold Gods,
By hoary Veta's Rites, and dark Abodes,
Adjure you both; (on you my Fortune tands,
That and my Faith I plight into your Hands:)
Make me but happy in his afe Return,
Whoe wanted Preence I can only mourn;
Your common Gift hall two large Goblets be,
Of Silver, wrought with curious Imagery;
And high embos'd, which, when old Priam reign'd,
My conqu'ring Sire at ack'd Arisba gain'd.
And more, two Tripods cat in antick Mould,
With two great Talents of the finet Gold:
Beide a cotly Bowl, ingrav'd with Art,
Which Dido gave, when firt he gave her Heart.
But if in conquer'd Italy we reign,
When Spoils by Lot the Victor hall obtain;
Thou aw't the Courer by proud Turnus pres'd,
That, Nius, and his Arms, and nodding Cret,
And Shield, from Chance exempt, hall be thy Share;
Twelve lab'ring Slaves, twelve Handmaids young and fair,
All clad in rich Attire, and train'd with Care.
And lat, a Latian Field with fruitful Plains;
And a large Portion of the King's Domains.
But thou, whoe Years are more to mine ally'd,
No Fate my vow'd Affection hall divide
From thee, Heroick Youth; be wholly mine:
Take full Poeion; all my Soul is thine.
One Faith, one Fame, one Fate hall both attend;
My Life's Companion, and my Boom Friend.
My Peace hall be committed to thy Care,
And to thy Conduct, my Concerns in War.
Then thus the young Euryalus reply'd;
Whatever Fortune, good or bad betide,
The ame hall be my Age, as now my Youth;
No time hall find me wanting to my Truth.
This only from your Goodnes let me gain;
(And this ungranted, all Rewards are vain)
Of Priam's Royal Race my Mother came;
And ure the bet that ever bore the Name:
Whom neither Troy, nor Sicily cou'd hold
From me departing, but o'repent, and old,
My Fate he follow'd; ignorant of this,
Whatever Danger, neither parting Kis,
Nor pious Bleing taken, her I leave;
And, in this only Act of all my Life deceive.
By this right Hand, and concious Night I wear,
My Soul o ad a farewel could not bear.
Be you her Comfort; fill my vacant place,
(Permit me to preume o great a Grace)
Support her Age, foraken and ditres'd,
That hope alone will fortifie my Breat
Againt the wort of Fortunes, and of Fears.
He aid: The mov'd Aitants melt in Tears.
Then thus Acanius, (wonder-truck to ee
That Image of his filial Piety;)
So great Beginnings, in o green an Age,
Exact the Faith, which I again ingage.
Thy Mother all the Dues hall jutly claim
Creua had; and only want the Name.
Whate're Event thy bold Attempt hall have,
'Tis Merit to have born a Son o brave.
Now by my Head, a acred Oath, I wear,
(My Father us'd it) what returning here
Crown'd with Succes, I for thy elf prepare,
That, if thou fail, hall thy lov'd Mother hare.
He aid; and weeping while he poke the Word,
From his broad Belt he drew a hining Sword,
Magnificent with Gold. Lycaon made,
And in an Iv'ry Scabbard heath'd the Blade:
This was his Gift: Great Mnetheus gave his Friend
A Lyon's Hide, his Body to defend:
And good Alethes furnih'd him beide,
With his own truty Helm, of Temper try'd.
Thus arm'd they went. The Noble Trojans wait
Their iuing forth, and follow to the Gate.
With Prayers and Vows, above the ret appears
Acanius, manly far beyond his Years.
And Meages committed to their Care,
Which all in Winds were lot, and flitting Air.
The Trenches firt they pas'd: Then took their Way
Where their proud Foes in pitch'd Pavilions lay;
To many fatal, e're themelves were lain:
They found the careles Hoat dipers'd upon the Plain.
Who gorg'd, and drunk with Wine, upinely nore;
Unharnas'd Chariots tand along the Shore:
Amidt the Wheels and Reins, the Goblet by,
A Medly of Debauch and War they lye.
Oberving Nius hew'd his Friend the ight;
Behold a Conquet gain'd without a Fight.

figure.p: To ye Honble: Colonel George Cholmondeley Colonel of his Majestys Troop of Granadier Guards & Groome of his Majties: Bedchamber
figure.head: AE. 9. l. 435.

lg.l: Occaion offers, and I tand prepar'd;
There lies our Way; be thou upon the Guard,
And look around; while I ecurely go,
And a hew Paage, thro the leeping Foe.
Softly he poke; then triding, took his way,
With his drawn Sword, where haughty Rhamnes lay:
His Head rais'd high, on Tapetry beneath,
And heaving from his Breat, he drew his Breath:
A King and Prophet by King Turnus lov'd;
But Fate by Precience cannot be remov'd.
Him, and his leeping Slaves he lew. Then pies
Where Rhemus, with his rich Retinue lies:
His Armor-bearer firt, and next he kills
His Charioteer, intrench'd betwixt the Wheels
And his lov'd Hores: Lat invades their Lord;
Full on his Neck he drives the fatal Sword:
The gaping Head flies off; a Purple flood
Flows from the Trunk, that welters in the Blood:
Which by the purning Heels, dipers'd around,
The Bed beprinkles, and bedews the Ground.
Lamus the bold, and Lamyrus the trong,
He lew; and then Serranus fair and young:
From Dice and Wine the Youth retir'd to Ret,
And puff'd the fumy God from out his Breat:
Ev'n then he dreamt of Drink and lucky Play;
More lucky had it lated 'till the Day.
The famih'd Lyon thus, with Hunger bold;
O'releaps the Fences of the Nightly Fold;
And tears the peaceful Flocks: With ilent Awe
Trembling they lye, and pant beneath his Paw.
Nor with les Rage Euryalus employs
The wrathful Sword, or fewer Foes detroys:
But on th' ignoble Crowd his Fury flew:
He Fadus, Hebeus, and Rhaetus lew.
Oppres'd with heavy Sleep the former fall,
But Rhoetus wakeful, and oberving all:
Behind a pacious Jarr he link'd for fear;
The fatal Iron found, and reach'd him there.
For as he roe, it pierc'd his naked ide;
And reeking, thence return'd in Crimon dy'd.
The Wound pours out a Stream of Wine and Blood,
The Purple Soul comes floating in the flood.
Now where Meapus Quarter'd they arrive;
The Fires were fainting there, and jut alive.
The Warriour-Hores ty'd in order fed;
Nius oberv'd the Dicipline, and aid,
Our eager thirt of Blood may both betray;
And ee the catter'd Streaks of dawning day,
Foe to Nocturnal Thefts: No more, my Friend,
Here let our glutted Execution end:
A Lane through laughter'd Bodies we have made:
The bold Euryalus, tho' loath, obey'd.
Of Arms, and Arras, and of Plate they find
A precious load; but thee they leave behind.
Yet fond of gaudy Spoils the Boy wou'd tay
To make the rich Caparion his prey,
Which on the teed of conquer'd Rhamnes lay.
Nor did his Eyes les longingly behold
The Girdle-Belt, with Nails of burnih'd Gold.
This Preent Cedicus the Rich, betow'd
On Remulus, when Friendhip firt they vow'd:
And abent, join'd in hopitable tyes;
He dying, to his Heir bequeath'd the Prize:
Till by the Conqu'ring Ardean Troops oppres'd
He fell; and they the Glorious Gift poes'd.
Thee Glitt'ring Spoils (now made the Victor's gain)
He to his body uits; but uits in vain.
Meapus Helm he finds among the ret,
And laces on, and wears the waving Cret.
Proud of their Conquet, prouder of their Prey,
They leave the Camp; and take the ready way.
But far they had not pas'd, before they py'd
Three hundred Hore with Volcens for their Guide.
The Queen a Legion to King Turnus ent,
But the wift Hore the lower Foot outwent;
And now advancing, ought the Leader's Tent.
They aw the Pair; for thro' the doubtful hade
His hineing Helm Euryalus betray'd,
On which the Moon with full reflexion play'd.
'Tis not for nought, cry'd Volcens, from the Crow'd,
Thee Men go there; then rais'd his Voice aloud:
Stand, tand: why thus in Arms, and whither bent;
From whence, to whom, and on what Errand ent?
Silent they cud away, and hate their flight,
To Neighb'ring Woods, and trut themelves to night.
The peedy Hore all paages belay,
And pur their moaking Steeds to Cros their way;
And watch each Entrance of the winding Wood;
Black was the Foret, thick with Beech it tood:
Horrid with Fern, and intricate with Thorn,
Few Paths of Humane Feet or Tracks of Beats were worn
The darknes of the Shades, his heavy Prey,
And Fear, mi-led the Younger from his way.
But Nius hit the Turns with happier hate,
And thoughtles of his Friend, the Foret pas'd:
And Alban Plains, from Alba's Name o call'd,
Where King Latinus then his Oxen tall'd.
Till turning at the length, he tood his ground,
And mis'd his Friend, and cat his Eyes around;
Ah Wretch, he cry'd, where have I left behind
Th' unhappy Youth, where hall I hope to find?
Or what way take! again He ventures back:
And treads the Mazes of his former track.
He winds the Wood, and lit'ning hears the noie
Of trampling Courers, and the Riders voice.
The ound approach'd, and uddenly he view'd
The Foes incloing, and his Friend puru'd:
Forelay'd and taken, while he trove in vain,
The helter of the friendly Shades to gain.
What hou'd he next attempt! what Arms employ,
What fruitles Force to free the Captive Boy?
Or deperate hou'd he ruh and loe his Life,
With odds oppres'd, in uch unequal trife?
Reolv'd at length, his pointed Spear he hook;
And cating on the Moon a mournful look,
Guardian of Groves, and Goddes of the Night;
Fair, Queen, he aid, direct my Dart aright:
If e're my Pious Father for my ake
Did grateful Off'rings on thy Altars make;
Or I increas'd them with my Silvan toils,
And hung thy Holy Roofs, with Salvage Spoils;
Give me to catter thee. Then from his Ear
He poiz'd, and aim'd, and lanch'd the trembling Spear.
The deadly Weapon, hiffing from the Grove,
Impetuous on the back of Sulmo drove:
Pierc'd his thin Armour, drank his Vital Blood,
And in his Body left the broken Wood.
He taggers round, his Eyeballs rowl in Death,
And with hort obs he gaps away his Breath.
All tand amaz'd; a econd Jav'lin flies,
With equal trength, and quivers through the Skies;
This through thy Temples, Tagus, forc'd the way,
And in the Brain-pan warmly bury'd lay.
Fierce Volcens foams with Rage, and gazing round,
Decry'd not him who gave the Fatal Wound:

figure.p: To Sr: Ion Percivalé Bart. of Barton in the County of Corke in Ireland
figure.head: AE. 9. l. 590

lg.l: Nor knew to fix Revenge: but thou, he cries,
Shalt pay for both, and at the Pris'ner flies,
With his drawn Sword. Then truck with deep Depair,
That cruel ight the Lover cou'd not bear:
But from his Covert ruh'd in open view,
And ent his Voice before him as he flew.
Me, me, he cry'd, turn all your Swords alone
On me; the Fact confes'd, the Fault my own.
He neither cou'd nor durt, the guiltles Youth;
Ye Moon and Stars bear Witnes to the Truth!
His only Crime, (if Friendhip can offend,)
Is too much Love; to his unhappy Friend.
Too late he peaks; the Sword, which Fury guides,
Driv'n with full Force, had pierc'd his tender Sides.
Down fell the beauteous Youth; the yawning Wound
Guh'd out a Purple Stream, and tain'd the Ground.
His nowy Neck reclines upon his Breat,
Like a fair Flow'r by the keen Share oppres'd:
Like a white Poppy inking on the Plain,
Whoe heavy Head is overcharg'd with Rain.
Depair, and Rage, and Vengeance jutly vow'd,
Drove Nius headlong on the hotile Crowd:
Volcens he eeks; on him alone he bends;
Born back, and bor'd, by his urrounding Friends,
Onward he pres'd: and kept him till in ight;
Then whirl'd aloft his Sword, with all his might:
Th' unnerring Steel decended while he poke;
Pierc'd his wide Mouth, and thro' his Weazon broke:
Dying, he flew; and tagg'ring on the Plain,
With mimming Eyes he ought his Lover lain:
Then quiet on his bleeding Boom fell;
Content in Death, to be reveng'd o well.
O happy Friends! for if my Vere can give
Immortal Life, your Fame hall ever live:
Fix'd as the Capitol's Foundation lies;
And pread, where e're the Roman Eagle flies!
The conqu'ring Party, firt divide the Prey,
Then their lain General to the Camp convey.
With Wonder, as they went, the Troops were fill'd,
To ee uch Numbers whom o few had kill'd.
Serranus, Rhamnes, and the ret they found;
Vat Crowds the dying and the dead urround:
And the yet reeking Blood o'reflows the Ground.
All knew the Helmet which Meapus lot;
But mourn'd a Purchae, that o dear had cot.
Now roe the ruddy Morn from Tithon's Bed;
And with the Dawns of Day the Skies o'repread.
Nor long the Sun his daily Coure withheld,
But added Colours to the World reveal'd.
When early Turnus wak'ning with the Light,
All clad in Armour calls his Troops to fight.
His Martial Men with fierce Harangues he fir'd;
And his own Ardor, in their Souls inpir'd.
This done, to give new Terror to his Foes,
The Heads of Nius, and his Friend he hows,
Rais'd high on pointed Spears: A ghatly Sight;
Loud peals of Shouts enue, and barbarous Delight.
Mean time the Trojans run, where Danger calls,
They line their Trenches, and they man their Walls:
In Front extended to the left they tood:
Safe was the right urrounded by the Flood.
But cating from their Tow'rs a frightful view,
They aw the Faces, which too well they knew;
Tho' then diguis'd in Death, and mear'd all o're
With Filth obcene, and dropping putrid Gore.
Soon haty Fame, thro' the ad City bears
The mournful Meage to the Mother's Ears:
An icy Cold benums her Limbs: She hakes:
Her Cheeks the Blood, her Hand the Web forakes.
She runs the Rampires round amidt the War,
Nor fears the flying Darts: She rends her Hair,
And fills with loud Laments the liquid Air.
Thus then, my lov'd Euryalus appears;
Thus looks the Prop of my declining Years!
Was't on this Face, my famih'd Eyes I fed,
Ah how unlike the living, is the dead!
And cou'dt thou leave me, cruel, thus alone,
Not one kind Kis from a departing Son!
No Look, no lat adieu before he went,
In an ill-boding Hour to Slaughter ent!
Cold on the Ground, and preing foreign Clay,
To Latian Dogs, and Fowls he lies a Prey!
Nor was I near to cloe his dying Eyes,
To wah his Wounds, to weep his Obequies:
To call about his Corps his crying Friends,
Or pread the Mantle, (made for other ends,)
On his dear Body, which I wove with Care,
Nor did my daily Pains, or nightly labour pare.
Where hall I find his Corps, what Earth utains
His Trunk dimember'd, and his cold Remains?
For this, alas, I left my needful Eae,
Expos'd my Life to Winds, and winter Seas!
If any pity touch Rutulian Hearts,
Here empty all your Quivers, all your Darts:
Or if they fail, thou Jove conclude my Woe,
And end me Thunder-truck to Shades below!
Her Shrieks and Clamours, pierce the Trojans Ears,
Unman their Courage, and augment their Fears:
Nor young Acanius cou'd the ight utain,
Nor old Ilioneus his Tears retrain:
But Actor and Idoeus, jointly ent,
To bear the madding Mother to her Tent.
And now the Trumpets terribly from far,
With rattling Clangor, rouze the leepy War.
The Souldiers Shouts ucceed the Brazen Sounds;
And Heav'n, from Pole to Pole, the Noie rebounds.
The Volcians bear their Shields upon their Head,
And ruhing forward, from a moving Shed;
Thee fill the Ditch, thoe pull the Bulwarks down:
Some raie the Ladders, others cale the Town.
But where void Spaces on the Walls appear,
Or thin Defence, they pour their Forces there.
With Poles and miive Weapons from afar,
The Trojans keep aloof the riing War.
Taught by their ten Years Siege defenive fight;
They rowl down Ribs of Rocks, an unreited Weight:
To break the Penthoue with the pond'rous Blow;
Which yet the patient Volcians undergo.
But cou'd not bear th' unequal Combat long;
For where the Trojans find the thicket Throng,
The Ruin falls: Their hatter'd Shields give way,
And their cruh'd Heads become an eaie Prey.
They hrink for Fear, abated of their Rage,
Nor longer dare in a blind Fight engage.
Contented now to gaul them from below
With Darts and Slings, and with the ditant Bow.
Elewhere Mezentius, terrible to view,
A blazing Pine within the Trenches threw.
But brave Meapus, Neptune's warlike Son,
Broke down the Paliades, the Trenches Won,
And loud for Ladders calls, to cale the Town.
Calliope begin: Ye acred Nine,
Inpire your Poet in his high Deign;
To ing what Slaughter manly Turnus made:
What Souls he ent below the Stygian Shade.
What Fame the Souldiers with their Captain hare,
And the vat Circuit of the fatal War.
For you in inging Martial Facts excel;
You bet remember; and alone can tell.
There tood a Tow'r, amazing to the ight,
Built up of Beams; and of tupendous height;
Art, and the nature of the Place conpir'd,
To furnih all the Strength, that War requir'd.
To level this, the bold Italians join;
The wary Trojans obviate their deign:
With weighty Stones o'rewhelm their Troops below,
Shoot through the Loopholes, and harp Jav'lins throw.
Turnus, the Chief, tos'd from his thund'ring Hand,
Againt the wooden Walls, a flaming Brand:
It tuck, the fiery Plague: The Winds were high;
The Planks were eaon'd, and the Timber dry.
Contagion caught the Pots: It pread along,
Scorch'd, and to ditance drove the catter'd Throng.
The Trojans fled; the Fire puru'd amain,
Still gath'ring fat upon the trembling Train;
Till crowding to the Corners of the Wall,
Down the Defence, and the Defenders fall.
The mighty flaw makes Heav'n it elf reound,
The Dead, and dying Trojans trew the Ground.
The Tow'r that follow'd on the fallen Crew,
Whelm'd o're their Heads, and bury'd whom it lew:
Some tuck upon the Darts themelves had ent;
All, the ame equal Ruin underwent.
Young Lycus and Helenor only cape;
Sav'd, how they know not, from the teepy Leap.
Helenor, elder of the two; by Birth,
On one ide Royal, one a Son of Earth,
Whom to the Lydian King, Lycimnia bare,
And ent her boated Batard to the War:
(A Priviledge which none but Free-men hare.)
Slight were his Arms, a Sword and Silver Shield,
No Marks of Honour charg'd its empty Field.
Light as he fell, o light the Youth aroe,
And riing found himelf amidt his Foes.
Nor flight was left, nor hopes to force his Way;
Embolden'd by Depair, he tood at Bay:
And like a Stag, whom all the Troop urrounds
Of eager Huntmen, and invading Hounds;
Reolv'd on Death, he diipates his Fears,
And bounds aloft, againt the pointed Spears:
So dares the Youth, ecure of Death; and throws
His dying Body, on his thicket Foes.
But Lycus, wifter of his Feet, by far,
Runs, doubles, winds and turns, amidt the War:
Springs to the Walls, and leaves his Foes behind,
And natches at the Beam he firt can find.
Looks up, and leaps aloft at all the tretch,
In hopes the helping Hand of ome kind Friend to reach.
But Turnus follow'd hard his hunted Prey,
(His Spear had almot reach'd him in the way,
Short of his Reins, and carce a Span behind,)
Fool, aid the Chief, tho' fleeter than the Wind,
Coud't thou preume to cape, when I purue?
He aid, and downward by the Feet he drew
The trembling Datard: at the Tug he falls,
Vat Ruins come along, rent from the moking Walls.
Thus on ome ilver Swan, or tim'rous Hare,
Jove's Bird comes owing down, from upper Air;
Her crooked Tallons trus the fearful Prey:
Then out of ight he oars, and wings her way.
So eizes the grim Wolf the tender Lamb,
In vain lamented by the bleating Dam.
Then ruhing onward, with a barbr'ous cry,
The Troops of Turnus to the Combat fly.
The Ditch with Faggots fill'd, the daring Foe
Tos'd Firebrands to the teepy Turrets throw.
Ilioneus, as bold Lucetius came
To force the Gate, and feed the kindling Flame,
Rowl'd down the Fragment of a Rock o right,
It cruh'd him double underneath the weight.
Two more young Liger and Aylas lew;
To bend the Bow young Liger better knew;
Aylas bet the pointed Jav'lin threw.
Brave Caeneus laid Ortygius on the Plain,
The Victor Caeneus was by Turnus lain.
By the ame Hand, Clonius and Itys fall,
Sagar, and Ida, tanding on the Wall.
From Capys Arms his Fate Privernus found;
Hurt by Themilla firt; but light the Wound;
His Shield thrown by, to mitigate the mart,
He clap'd his Hand upon the wounded part:
The econd Shaft came wift and unepy'd,
And pierc'd his Hand, and nail'd it to his ide:
Transfix'd his breathing Lungs, and beating heart;
The Soul came iuing out, and his'd againt the Dart.
The Son of Arcens hone amid the ret,
In glitt'ring Armour, and a Purple Vet.
Fair was his Face, his Eyes inpiring Love,
Bred by his Father in the Martian Grove;
Where the fat Altars of Palicus flame,
And ent in Arms to purchae early Fame.
Him, when he py'd from far the Thucan King,
Laid by the Lance, and took him to the Sling:
Thrice whirl'd the Thong around his head, and threw:
The heated Lead half melted as it flew:
It pierc'd his hollow Temples and his Brain;
The Youth came tumbling down, and purn'd the Plain.
Then Young Acanius, who before this day
Was wont in Woods to hoot the alvage Prey,
Firt bent in Martial Strife, the twanging Bow;
And exercis'd againt a Humane Foe.
With this bereft Numanus of his life,
Who Turnus younger Siter took to Wife.
Proud of his Realm, and of his Royal Bride,
Vaunting before his Troops, and lengthen'd with a Stride,
In thee Inulting terms, the Trojans he defy'd.
Twice Conquer'd Cowards, now your hame is hown,
Coop'd up a econd time within your Town!
Who dare not iue forth in open Field,
But hold your Walls before you for a Shield:
Thus threat you War, thus our Alliance force!
What Gods what madnes hether teer'd your Coure!
You hall not find the Sons of Atreus here,
Nor need the Frauds of ly Ulyes fear.
Strong from the Cradle, of a turdy Brood,
We bear our new-born Infants to the Flood;
There bath'd amid the Stream, our Boys we hold,
With Winter harden'd, and inur'd to Cold.
They wake before the Day to range the Wood,
Kill e're they eat, nor tat unconquer'd Food.
No Sports, but what belong to War they know,
To break the tubborn Colt, to bend the Bow.
Our youth, of Labour patient, earn their Bread;
Hardly they work, with frugal Diet fed.
From Ploughs and Harrows ent to eek Renown,
They fight in Fields, and torm the haken Town.
No part of Life from Toils of War is free;
No change in Age, or diff'rence in Degree.
We plow, and till in Arms; our Oxen feel,
Intead of Goads, the Spur, and pointed Steel:
Th' inverted Lance makes Furrows in the Plain;
Ev'n time that changes all, yet changes us in vain:
The Body, not the Mind: Nor can controul
Th' immortal Vigour, or abate the Soul.
Our Helms defend the Young, diguie the Grey:
We live by Plunder, and delight in Prey.
Your Vets embroyder'd with rich Purple hine;
In Sloth you Glory, and in Dances join.
Your Vets have weeping Sleeves: With female Pride,
Your Turbants underneath your Chins are ty'd.
Go, Phrygians, to your Dindymus agen;
Go, les than Women, in the Shapes of Men.
Go, mix'd with Eunuchs, in the Mother's Rites,
Where with unequal Sound the Flute invites.
Sing, dance, and howl by turns in Ida's Shade;
Reign the War to Men, who know the Martial Trade.
This foul Reproach, Acanius cou'd not hear
With Patience, or a vow'd Revenge forbear.
At the full tretch of both his Hands, he drew,
And almot join'd the Horns of the tough Eugh.
But firt, before the Throne of Jove he tood;
And thus with lifted Hands invok'd the God.
My firt Attempt, great Jupiter ucceed;
An annual Off'ring in thy Grove hall bleed:
A now-white Steer, before thy Altar led,
Who like his Mother bears aloft his Head,
Buts with his threatning Brows, and bellowing tands,
And dares the Fight, and purns the yellow Sands.
Jove bow'd the Heav'ns, and lent a gracious Ear,
And thunder'd on the left, amidt the clear.
Sounded at once the Bow; and wiftly flies
The feather'd Death, and hifes thro' the Skies.
The Steel thro' both his Temples forc'd the way:
Extended on the Ground, Numanus lay.
Go now, vain Boater, and true Valour corn;
The Phrygians twice ubdu'd, yet make this third Return.

l.U: aid no more: The Trojans hake

lg.l: The Heav'ns with Shouting, and new Vigour take.
Apollo then betrode a Golden Cloud,
To view the feats of Arms, and fighting Crowd;
And thus the beardles Victor, he bepoke aloud.
Advance Illutrious Youth, increae in Fame,
And wide from Eat to Wet extend thy Name.
Offspring of Gods thy elf; and Rome hall owe
To thee, a Race of Demigods below.
This is the Way to Heav'n: The Pow'rs Divine
From this beginning date the Julian Line.
To thee, to them, and their victorious Heirs,
The conquer'd War is due; and the vat World is theirs.
Troy is too narrow for thy Name. He aid,
And plunging downward hot his radiant Head;
Dipell'd the breathing Air, that broke his Flight,
Shorn of his Beams, a Man to Mortal ight.
Old Butes Form he took, Anchies Squire,
Now left to rule Acanius, by his Sire:
His wrinkled Viage, and his hoary Hairs,
His Meen, his Habit, and his Arms he wears;
And thus alutes the Boy, too forward for his Years.
Suffice it thee, thy Father's worthy Son,
The warlike Prize thou hat already won:
The God of Archers gives thy Youth a part
Of his own Praie; nor envies equal Art.
Now tempt the War no more. He aid, and flew
Obcure in Air, and vanih'd from their view.
The Trojans, by his Arms, their Patron know;
And hear the twanging of his Heav'nly Bow.
Then duteous Force they ue; and Phoebus Name,
To keep from Fight, the Youth too fond of Fame.
Undaunted they themelves no Danger hun:
From Wall to Wall, the Shouts and Clamours run.
They bend their Bows; they whirl their Slings around:
Heaps of pent Arrows fall; and trew the Ground;
And Helms, and Shields, and ratling Arms reound.
The Combate thickens, like the Storm that flies
From Wetward, when the Show'ry Kids arie:
Or patt'ring Hail comes pouring on the Main,
When Jupiter decends in harden'd Rain.
Or bellowing Clouds burt with a tormy Sound,
And with an armed Winter trew the Ground.
Pand'rus and Bitias, Thunder-bolts of War,
Whom Hiera, to bold Alcanor bare
On Ida's Top, two Youths of Height and Size,
Like Firrs that on their Mother Mountain rie;
Preuming on their Force, the Gates unbar,
And of their own Accord invite the War.
With Fates avere, againt their King's Command,
Arm'd on the right, and on the left they tand;
And flank the Paage: Shining Steel they wear,
And waving Crets, above their Heads appear.
Thus two tall Oaks, that Padus Banks adorn,
Lift up to Heav'n their leafy Heads unhorn;
And overpres'd with Nature's heavy load,
Dance to the whitling Winds, and at each other nod.
In flows a Tyde of Latians, when they ee
The Gate et open, and the Paage free.
Bold Quercens, with rah Tmarus ruhing on,
Equicolus, that in bright Armour hone,
And Haemon firt, but oon repuls'd they fly,
Or in the well-defended Pas they dye.
Thee with Succes are fir'd, and thoe with Rage;
And each on equal Terms at length ingage.
Drawn from their Lines, and iuing on the Plain,
The Trojans hand to hand the Fight maintain.
Fierce Turnus in another Quarter fought,
When uddenly th' unhop'd for News was brought;
The Foes had left the fatnes of their Place,
Prevail'd in Fight, and had his Men in Chace.
He quits th' Attack, and, to prevent their Fate,
Runs, where the Gyant Brothers guard the Gate.
The firt he met, Antiphates the brave,
But bae begotten on a Theban Slave;
Sarpedon's Son he lew: The deadly Dart
Found Paage thro' his Breat, and pierc'd his Heart.
Fix'd in the Wound th' Italian Cornel tood;
Warm'd in his Lungs, and in his vital Blood.
Aphidnus next, and Erymanthus dies,
And Meropes, and the Gygantick Size
Of Bitias, threat'ning with his ardent Eyes.
Not by the feeble Dart he fell oppres'd,
A Dart were lot, within that roomy Breat;
But from a knotted Lance, large, heavy, trong;
Which roar'd like Thunder as it whirl'd along:
Not two Bull-hides th' impetuous Force withhold;
Nor Coat of double Male, with Scales of Gold.
Down unk the Monter-Bulk, and pres'd the Ground;
His Arms and clatt'ring Shield, on the vat Body ound.
Not with les Ruin, than the Bajan Mole,
(Rais'd on the Seas the Surges to controul,)
At once comes tumbling down the rocky Wall,
Prone to the Deep the Stones disjointed fall,
Of the vat Pile; the catter'd Ocean flies;
Black Sands, dicolour'd Froth, and mingled Mud arie.
The frighted Billows rowl, and eek the Shores:
Then trembles Prochyta, then Ichia roars:
Typhoeus thrown beneath, by Jove's Command,
Atonih'd at the Flaw, that hakes the Land,
Soon hifts his weary Side, and carce awake,
With Wonder feels the weight pres lighter on his Back.
The Warrior God the Latian Troops inpir'd;
New trung their Sinews, and their Courage fir'd:
But chills the Trojan Hearts with cold Affright;
Then black Depair precipitates their Flight.
When Pandarus beheld his Brother kill'd,
The Town with Fear, and wild Confuion fill'd,
He turns the Hindges of the heavy Gate
With both his Hands; and adds his Shoulders to the weight.
Some happier Friends, within the Walls inclos'd;
The ret hut out, to certain Death expos'd.
Fool as he was, and frantick in his Care,
T' admit young Turnus, and include the War.
He thrut amid the Crowd, ecurely bold;
Like a fierce Tyger pent amid the Fold.
Too late his blazing Buckler they decry;
And parkling Fires that hot from either Eye:
His mighty Members, and his ample Breat,
His ratt'ling Armour, and his Crimon Cret.
Far from that hated Face the Trojans fly;
All but the Fool who ought his Detiny.
Mad Pandarus teps forth, with Vengeance vow'd
For Bitias's Death, and threatens thus aloud.
Thee are not Ardea's Walls, nor this the Town
Amata proffers with Lavinia's Crown:
'Tis hotile Earth you tread; of hope bereft,
No means of afe Return by flight are left.
To whom with Count'nance calm, and Soul edate,
Thus Turnus: Then begin; and try thy Fate:
My Meage to the Ghot of Priam bear,
Tell him a new Achilles ent thee there.
A Lance of tough ground-Ah the Trojan threw,
Rough in the Rind, and knotted as it grew,
With his full force he whirl'd it firt around;
But the oft yielding Air receiv'd the wound:
Imperial Juno turn'd the Coure before;
And fix'd the wand'ring Weapon in the door.
But hope not thou, aid Turnus, when I trike,
To hun thy Fate, our Force is not alike:
Nor thy Steel temper'd by the Lemnian God:
Then riing, on is utmot tretch he tood:
And aim'd from high, the full decending blow
Cleaves the broad Front, and beardles Cheeks in two:
Down inks the Giant with a thund'ring ound,
His pond'rous Limbs oppres the trembling ground;
Blood, Brains, and Foam, guh from the gaping Wound.
Scalp, Face, and Shoulders, the keen Steel divides;
And the har'd Viage hangs on equal ides.
The Trojans fly from their approaching Fate:
And had the Victor then ecur'd the Gate,
And, to his Troops without, unclos'd the Barrs;
One lucky Day had ended all his Wars.
But boiling Youth, and blind Deire of Blood,
Puh'd on his Fury, to purue the Crowd:
Hamtring'd behind unhappy Gyges dy'd;
Then Phalaris is added to his ide:
The pointed Jav'lins from the dead he drew,
And their Friends Arms againt their Fellows threw.
Strong Halys tands in vain; weak Phlegys flies;

l.U: till at hand, new Force and Fire upplies.

figure.p: To Mr John Clos Jerman
figure.head: AE. 9. l. 1010.

lg.l: Then Halius, Prytanis, Alcander fall;
(Ingag'd againt the Foes who cal'd the Wall:)
But whom they fear'd without, they found within:
At lat, tho' late, by Linceus he was een.
He calls new Succours, and aaults the Prince,
But weak his Force, and vain is their Defence.
Turn'd to the right, his Sword the Heroe drew;
And at one blow the bold Aggreor lew.
He joints the Neck: And with a troke o trong
The Helm flies off; and bears the Head along.
Next him, the Huntman Amycus he kill'd,
In Darts, invenom'd, and in Poyon skill'd.
Then Clytius fell beneath his fatal Spear,
And Creteus, whom the Mues held o dear:
He fought with Courage, and he ung the fight:
Arms were his buis'nes, Veres his delight.
The Trojan Chiefs behold, with Rage and Grief,
Their laughter'd Friends, and haten their Relief.
Bold Mnetheus rallies firt the broken Train,
Whom brave Serethus, and his Troop utain.
To ave the living, and revenge the dead;
Agint one Warriour's Arms all Troy they led.
O, void of Sene and Courage, Mnetheus cry'd,
Where can you hope your Coward Heads to hide?
Ah, where beyond thee Rampires can you run!
One Man, and in your Camp inclos'd, you hun!
Shall then a ingle Sword uch Slaughter boat,
And pas unpunih'd from a Num'rous Hoat?
Foraking Honour, and renouncing Fame,
Your Gods, your Country, and your King you hame.
This jut Reproach their Vertue does excite,
They tand, they joyn, they thicken to the Fight.
Now Turnus doubts, and yet didains to yield;
But with low paces meaures back the Field.
And Inches to the Walls, where Tyber's Tide,
Wahing the Camp, defends the weaker ide.
The more he loes, they advance the more;
And tread in ev'ry Step he trod before.
They howt, they bear him back, and whom by Might
They cannot Conquer, they oppres with Weight.
As compas'd with a Wood of Spears around,
The Lordly Lyon, till maintains his Ground.
Grins horrible, retires, and turns again;
Threats his ditended Paws, and hakes his Mane;
He loes while in vain he prees on,
Nor will his Courage let him dare to run:
So Turnus fares; and unreolv'd of flight,
Moves tardy back, and jut recedes from fight.
Yet twice, inrag'd, the Combat he renews;
Twice breaks, and twice his broken Foes purues:
But now they warm; and with freh Troops upply'd,
Come rowling on, and ruh from ev'ry ide.
Nor Juno, who utain'd his Arms before,
Dares with new trength uffice th' exhauted tore.
For Jove, with our Commands, ent Iris down,
To force th' Invader from the frighted Town.
With Labour pent, no Longer can he wield
The heavy Fauchion, or utain the Shield:
O'rewhelm'd with Darts, which from afar they fling,
The Weapons round his hollow Temples ring:
His golden Helm gives way: with tony blows
Batter'd, and flat, and beaten to his Brows.
His Cret is rah'd away; his ample Shield
Is falify'd, and round with Jav'lins fill'd.
The Foe now faint, the Trojans overwhelm:
And Mnetheus lays hard load upon his Helm.
Sick weat ucceeds, he drops at ev'ry pore,
With driving Dut his Cheeks are pated o're.
Shorter and horter ev'ry Gap he takes,
And vain Efforts, and hurtles Blows he makes.
Arm'd as he was, at length, he leap'd from high;
Plung'd in the Flood, and made the Waters fly.
The yellow God, the welcome Burthen bore,
And wip'd the Sweat, and wah'd away the Gore:
Then gently wafts him to the farther Coat;
And ends him afe to chear his anxious Hoat.

div.head: The Tenth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.p: Jupiter calling a Council of the Gods, forbids them to engage in either Party. At Aeneas's return there is a bloody Battel: Turnus killing Pallas; Aeneas, Lauus and Mezentius. Mezentius is decrib'd as an Atheit; Lauus as a pious and virtuous Youth: The different Actions and Death of thee two, are the Subject of a Noble Epiode.

lg.l: THE Gates of Heav'n unfold; Jove ummons all
The Gods to Council, in the Common Hall.
Sublimely eated, he urveys from far
The Fields, the Camp, the Fortune of the War;
And all th' inferior World: From firt to lat
The Sov'raign Senate in Degrees are plac'd.
Then thus th' Almighty Sire began. Ye Gods,
Natives, or Denizons, of blet Abodes;
From whence thee Murmurs, and this change of Mind,
This backward Fate from what was firt deign'd?
Why this protracted War? When my Commands
Pronounc'd a Peace, and gave the Latian Lands.
What Fear or Hope on either part divides
Our Heav'ns, and arms our Pow'rs on diff'rent ides?
A lawful Time of War at length will come,
(Nor need your hate anticipate the Doom,)
When Carthage hall contet the World with Rome:
Shall force the rigid Rocks, and Alpine Chains;
And like a Flood come pouring on the Plains.
Then is your time for Faction and Debate,
For partial Favour, and permitted Hate.
Let now your immature Diention ceae;
Sit quiet, and compoe your Souls to Peace.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble: Iohn Ld. Viscount Fitzharding of Beare-haven and Bawn Berkley of Rathdowne in ye Kingdom of Ireland & Master of ye Horse to Her Royall Highnes the Princes Anne of Denmark
figure.head: AE. 10. l. 1.

lg.l: Thus Jupiter in few unfolds the Charge:
But lovely Venus thus replies at large.
O Pow'r immene, Eternal Energy!
(For to what ele Protection can we fly,)
Seet thou the proud Rutulians, how they dare
In Fields, unpunih'd, and inult my Care?
How lofty Turnus vaunts amidt his Train,
In hining Arms, triumphant on the Plain?
Ev'n in their Lines and Trenches they contend;
And carce their Walls the Trojan Troops defend:
The Town is fill'd with Slaughter, and o'refloats,
With a red Deluge, their increaing Moats.
Aeneas ignorant, and far from thence,
Has left a Camp expos'd, without Defence.
This endles outrage hall they till utain?
Shall Troy renew'd be forc'd, and fir'd again?
A econd Siege my banih'd Iue fears,
And a new Diomede in Arms appears.
One more audacious Mortal will be found;
And I thy Daughter wait another Wound.
Yet, if with Fates avere, without thy Leave,
The Latian Lands my Progeny receive;
Bear they the Pains of violated Law,
And thy Protection from their Aid withdraw.
But if the Gods their ure Succes foretel,
If thoe of Heav'n conent with thoe of Hell,
To promie Italy; who dare debate
The Pow'r of Jove, or fix another Fate?
What hou'd I tell of Tempets on the Main,
Of Eolus uurping Neptune's Reign?
Of Iris ent; with Bachanalian Heat,
T' inpire the Matrons, and detroy the Fleet.
Now Juno to the Stygian Sky decends,
Sollicites Hell for Aid, and arms the Fiends.
That new Example wanted yet above:
An Act that well became the Wife of Jove.
Alecto, rais'd by her, with Rage inflames
The peaceful Booms of the Latian Dames.
Imperial Sway no more exalts my Mind:
(Such hopes I had indeed, while Heav'n was kind)
Now let my happier Foes poes my place,
Whom Jove prefers before the Trojan Race;
And conquer they, whom you with Conquet grace.
Since you can pare, from all your wide Command,
No pot of Earth, no hopitable Land,
Which may my wand'ring Fugitives receive;
(Since haughty Juno will not give you leave)
Then, Father, (if I till may ue that Name)
By ruin'd Troy, yet moking from the Flame,
I beg you let Acanius, by my Care,
Be freed from Danger, and dimis'd the War:
Inglorious let him live, without a Crown;
The Father may be cat on Coats unknown,
Strugling with Fate; but let me ave the Son.
Mine is Cythera, mine the Cyprian Tow'rs;
In thoe Recees, and thoe acred Bow'rs,
Obcurely let him ret; his Right reign
To promis'd Empire, and his Julian Line.
Then Carthage may th' Auonian Towns detroy,
Nor fear the Race of a rejected Boy.
What profits it my Son, to cape the Fire,
Arm'd with his Gods, and loaded with his Sire;
To pas the Perils of the Seas and Wind,
Evade the Greeks, and leave the War behind;
To reach th' Italian Shores: If after all,
Our econd Pergamus is doom'd to fall?
Much better had he curb'd his high Deires,
And hover'd o're his ill extinguih'd Fires.
To Simois Banks the Fugitives retore,
And give them back to War, and all the Woes before.
Deep indignation well'd Saturnia's Heart:
And mut I own, he aid, my ecret Smart?
What with more decence were in ilence kept,
And but for this unjut Reproach had lept?
Did God, or Man, your Fav'rite Son advie,
With War unhop'd the Latians to urprie?
By Fate you boat, and by the Gods Decree,
He left his Native Land for Italy:
Confes the Truth; by mad Caandra, more
Than Heav'n, inpir'd, he ought a foreign Shore!
Did I perwade to trut his econd Troy,
To the raw Conduct of a beardles Boy?
With Walls unfinih'd, which himelf forakes,
And thro' the Waves a wand'ring Voyage makes?
When have I urg'd him meanly to demand
The Tucan Aid, and arm a quiet Land?
Did I or Iris give this mad Advice,
Or made the Fool himelf the fatal Choice?
You think it hard, the Latians hou'd detroy
With Swords your Trojans, and with Fires your Troy:
Hard and unjut indeed, for Men to draw
Their Native Air, nor take a foreign Law:
That Turnus is permitted till to live,
To whom his Birth a God and Goddes give:
But yet 'tis jut and lawful for your Line,
To drive their Fields, and Force with Fraud to join.
Realms, not your own, among your Clans divide,
And from the Bridegroom tear the promis'd Bride:
Petition, while you publick Arms prepare;
Pretend a Peace, and yet provoke a War.
'Twas giv'n to you, your darling Son to hrowd,
To draw the Datard from the fighting Crowd;
And for a Man obtend an empty Cloud.
From flaming Fleets you turn'd the Fire away,
And chang'd the Ships to Daughters of the Sea.
But 'tis my Crime, the Queen of Heav'n offends,
If he preume to ave her uff'ring Friends.
Your Son, not knowing what his Foes decree,
You ay is abent: Abent let him be.
Yours is Cythera, yours the Cyprian Tow'rs,
The oft Recees, and the Sacred Bow'rs.
Why do you then thee needles Arms prepare,
And thus provoke a People prone to War?
Did I with Fire the Trojan Town deface,
Or hinder from return your exil'd Race?
Was I the Caue of Michief, or the Man,
Whoe lawles Lut the bloody War began?
Think on whoe Faith th' Adult'rous Youth rely'd;
Who promis'd, who procur'd the Spartan Bride?
When all th' united States of Greece combin'd,
To purge the World of the perfidious Kind;
Then was your time to fear the Trojan Fate:
Your Quarrels and Complaints are now too late.
Thus Juno. Murmurs rie, with mix'd Applaue;
Jut as they favour, or dilike the Caue:
So Winds, when yet unfledg'd in Woods they lie,
In whipers firt their tender Voices try:
Then iue on the Main with bellowing rage,
And Storms to trembling Mariners preage.
Then thus to both reply'd th' Imperial God,
Who hakes Heav'ns Axels with his awful Nod.
(When he begins, the ilent Senate tand
With Rev'rence, lit'ning to the dread Command:
The Clouds dipel; the Winds their Breath retrain;
And the huh'd Waves lie flatted on the Main.)
Coeletials! Your attentive Ears incline;
Since, aid the God, the Trojans mut not join
In wih'd Alliance with the Latian Line;
Since endles jarrings, and immortal Hate,
Tend but to dicompoe our happy State;
The War henceforward be reign'd to Fate.
Each to his proper Fortune tand or fall,
Equal and unconcern'd I look on all.
Rutulians, Trojans, are the ame to me;
And both hall draw the Lots their Fates decree.
Let thee aault; if Fortune be their Friend;
And if he favours thoe, let thoe defend:
The Fates will find their way. The Thund'rer aid;
And hook the acred Honours of his Head;
Atteting Styx, th' Inviolable Flood,
And the black Regions of his Brother God
Trembled the Poles of Heav'n; and Earth confes'd the Nod.
This end the Seions had: The Senate rie,
And to his Palace wait their Sov'raign thro' the Skies.
Mean time, intent upon their Siege, the Foes
Within their Walls the Trojan Hoat incloe:
They wound, they kill, they watch at ev'ry Gate:
Renew the Fires, and urge their happy Fate.
Th' Aeneans wih in vain their wanted Chief,
Hopeles of flight, more hopeles of Relief:
Thin on the Tow'rs they tand; and ev'n thofe few,
A feeble, fainting, and dejected Crew:
Yet in the face of Danger ome there tood:
The two bold Brothers of Sarpedon's Blood,
Aius, and Acmon: both th' Aaraci;
Young Haemon, and tho' young, reolv'd to dye.
With thee were Clarus and Thymaetes join'd;
Tibris and Cator, both of Lycian Kind.
From Acmon's Hands a rowling Stone there came,
So large, if half deerv'd a Mountain's Name:
Strong inew'd was the Youth, and big of Bone,
His Brother Mnetheus cou'd not more have done:
Or the great Father of th' intrepid Son.
Some Firebrands throw, ome flights of Arrows end;
And ome with Darts, and ome with Stones defend.
Amid the Pres appears the beauteous Boy,
The Care of Venus, and the Hope of Troy.
His lovely Face unarm'd, his Head was bare,
In ringlets o're his Shoulders hung his Hair.
His Forehead circled with a Diadem;
Ditinguih'd from the Crowd, he hines a Gem,
Enchas'd in Gold, or Polih'd Iv'ry et,
Amidt the meaner foil of able Jett.
Nor Imarus was wanting to the War,
Directing Ointed Arrows from afar;
And Death with Poyon arm'd: In Lydia born,
Where plenteous Harvets the fat Fields adorn:
Where proud Pactolus floats the fruitful Lands,
And leaves a rich manure of Golden Sands.
There Capys, Author of the Capuan Name:
And there was Mnetheus too increas'd in Fame:
Since Turnus from the Camp He cat with hame.
Thus Mortal War was wag'd on either ide,
Mean time the Heroe cuts the Nightly Tyde.
For, anxious, from Evander when he went,
He ought the Tyrrhene Camp, and Tarchon's Tent;
Expos'd the Caue of coming to the Chief;
His Name, and Country told, and ask'd Relief:
Propos'd the Terms; his own mall trength declar'd,
What Vengeance proud Mezentius had prepar'd:
What Turnus, bold and violent, deign'd;
Then hew'd the lippry tate of Humane-kind,
And fickle Fortune; warn'd him to beware:
And to his wholom Counel added Pray'r.
Tarchon, without delay, the Treaty igns;
And to the Trojan Troops the Tucan joins.
They oon et ail; nor now the Fates withtand;
Their Forces truted with a Foreign Hand.
Aeneas leads; upon his Stern appear,
Two Lyons carv'd, which riing Ida bear:
Ida, to wand'ring Trojans ever dear.
Under their grateful Shade Aeneas ate,
Revolving Wars Events, and various Fate.
His left young Pallas kept, fix'd to his ide,
And oft of Winds enquir'd, and of the Tyde:
Oft of the Stars, and of their wat'ry Way;
And what he uffer'd both by Land and Sea.
Now acred Siters open all your Spring,
The Tucan Leaders, and their Army ing;
Which follow'd great Aeneas to the War:
Their Arms, their Numbers, and their Names declare.
A thouand Youths brave Maicus obey,
Born in the Tyger, thro' the foaming Sea;
From Aium brought, and Coa, by his Care;
For Arms, light Quivers, Bows, and Shafts they bear.
Fierce Abas next, his Men bright Armour wore;
His Stern, Apollo's Golden Statue bore.
Six hundred Populonea ent along,
All skill'd in Martial Exercie, and trong.
Three hundred more for Battel Ilva joins,
An Ile renown'd for Steel, and unexhauted Mines.
Aylas on his Prow the third appears,
Who Heav'n interprets, and the wand'ring Stars:
From offer'd Entrails Prodigies expounds,
And Peals of Thunder, with preaging Sounds.
A thouand Spears in warlike Order tand,
Sent by the Pians under his Command.
Fair Atur follows in the wat'ry Field,
Proud of his manag'd Hore, and painted Shield.
Gravica, noiom from the neighb'ring Fen,
And his own Coere ent three hundred Men:
With thoe which Minio's Fields, and Pyrgi gave;
All bred in Arms, unanimous and brave.
Thou Mue the Name of Cyniras renew,
And brave Cupavo follow'd but by few:
Whoe Helm confes'd the Lineage of the Man,
And bore, with Wings diplay'd, a ilver Swan.
Love was the fault of his fam'd Ancetry,
Whoe Forms, and Fortunes in his Enigns fly.
For Cycnus lov'd unhappy Phaeton,
And ung his Los in Poplar Groves, alone;
Beneath the Siter hades to ooth his Grief;
Heav'n heard his Song, and haten'd his Relief:
And chang'd to nowy Plumes his hoary Hair,
And wing'd his Flight, to chant aloft in Air.
His Son Cupavo bruh'd the briny Flood;
Upon his Stern a brawny Centaur tood,
Who heav'd a Rock, and threat'ning till to throw,
With lifted Hands, alarm'd the Seas below:
They eem'd to fear the formidable Sight,
And rowl'd their Billows on, to peed his Flight.
Ocnus was next, who led his Native Train,
Of hardy Warriors, thro' the wat'ry Plain.
The Son of Manto, by the Tucan Stream,
From whence the Mantuan Town derives the Name.
An ancient City, but of mix'd Decent,
Three ev'ral Tribes compoe the Government:
Four Towns are under each; but all obey
The Mantuan Laws, and own the Tucan Sway.
Hate to Mezentius, arm'd five hundred more,
Whom Mincius from his Sire Benacus bore;
(Mincius with Wreaths of Reeds his forehead cover'd o're.)
Thee grave Auletes leads. A hundred weep,
With tretching Oars at once the glay deep:
Him, and his Martial Train, the Triton bears,
High on his Poop the Sea-green God appears:
Frowning he eems his crooked Shell to ound,
And at the Blat the Billows dance around.
A hairy Man above the Wate he hows,
A Porpoie Tail beneath his Belly grows;
And ends a Fih: His Breat the Waves divides,
And Froth and Foam augment the murm'ring Tides.
Full thirty Ships tranport the choen Train,
For Troy's Relief, and cour the briny Main.
Now was the World oraken by the Sun,
And Phoebe half her nightly Race had run.
The careful Chief, who never clos'd his Eyes,
Himelf the Rudder holds, the Sails upplies.
A Choir of Nereids meet him on the Flood,
Once his own Gallies, hewn from Ida's Wood:
But now as many Nymphs the Sea they weep,
As rode before tall Veels on the Deep.
They know him from afar; and, in a Ring,
Incloe the Ship that bore the Trojan King.
Cymodoce, whoe Voice excell'd the ret,
Above the Waves advanc'd her nowy Breat,
Her right Hand tops the Stern, her left divides
The curling Ocean, and corrects the Tides:
She poke for all the Choir; and thus began,
With pleaing Words to warn th' unknowing Man.
Sleeps our lov'd Lord? O Goddes-born! awake,
Spread ev'ry Sail, purue your wat'ry Track;
And hate your Coure. Your Navy once were we,
From Ida's Height decending to the Sea:
'Till Turnus, as at Anchor fix'd we tood,
Preum'd to violate our holy Wood.
Then loos'd from Shore we fled his Fires prophane;
(Unwillingly we broke our Mater's Chain)
And ince have ought you thro' the Tucan Main.
The mighty Mother chang'd our Forms to thee,
And gave us Life Immortal in the Seas.
But young Acanius, in his Camp ditres'd,
By your inulting Foes is hardly pres'd.
Th' Arcadian Horemen, and Etrurian Hoat
Advance in order on the Latian Coat:
To cut their way the Daunian Chief deigns,
Before their Troops can reach the Trojan Lines.
Thou, when the roie Morn retores the Light,
Firt arm thy Souldiers for th' enuing Fight:
Thy elf the fated Sword of Vulcan wield,
And bear aloft th' impenetrable Shield.
To Morrow's Sun, unles my Skill be vain,
Shall ee huge heaps of Foes in Battel lain.
Parting, he poke; and with Immortal Force,
Puh'd on the Veel in her wat'ry Coure:
(For well he knew the Way) impell'd behind,
The Ship flew forward, and outtrip'd the Wind.
The ret make up: Unknowing of the caue
The Chief admires their Speed, and happy Omens draws.
Then thus he pray'd, and fix'd on Heav'n his Eyes;
Hear thou, great Mother of the Deities!
With Turrets crown'd, (on Ida's holy Hill,
Fierce Tygers, rein'd and curb'd, obey thy Will.)
Firm thy own Omens, lead us on to fight,
And let thy Phrygians conquer in thy right.
He aid no more. And now renewing Day
Had chas'd the Shadows of the Night away.
He charg'd the Souldiers with preventing Care,
Their Flags to follow, and their Arms prepare;
Warn'd of th' enuing Fight, and bad'em hope the War.
Now, from his lofty Poop, he view'd below
His Camp incompas'd, and th' incloing Foe.
His blazing Shield imbrac'd, he held on high;
The Camp receive the ign, and with loud Shouts reply.
Hope arms their Anger: From their Tow'rs they throw
Their Darts with double Force, and drive the Foe.
Thus, at the ignal giv'n, the Cranes arie
Before the tormy South, and blacken all the Skies.
King Turnus wonder'd at the Fight renew'd;
'Till, looking back, the Trojan Fleet he view'd:
The Seas with welling Canvas cover'd o're;
And the wift Ships decending on the Shore.
The Latians aw from far, with dazl'd Eyes,
The radiant Cret that eem'd in Flames to rie,
And dart diffuive Fires around the Field;
And the keen glitt'ring of the Golden Shield.
Thus threatning Comets, when by Night they rie,
Shoot anguine Streams, and adden all the Skies:
So Sirius, flahing forth initer Lights,
Pale humane kind with Plagues, and with dry Famine frights.
Yet Turnus, with undaunted Mind is bent
To man the Shores, and hinder their Decent:
And thus awakes the Courage of his Friends.
What you o long have wih'd, kind Fortune ends:
In equal Arms to meet th' invading Foe:
You find, and find him at Advantage now.
Yours is the Day, you need but only dare:
Your Swords will make you Maters of the War.
Your Sires, your Sons, your Houes, and your Lands,
And dearet Wifes, are all within your Hands.
Be mindful of the Race from whence you came;
And emulate in Arms your Fathers Fame.
Now take the Time, while tagg'ring yet they tand
With Feet unfirm; and prepoes the Strand:
Fortune befriends the bold. Nor more he aid,
But ballanc'd whom to leave, and whom to lead:
Then thee elects, the Landing to prevent;
And thoe he leaves to keep the City pent.
Mean time the Trojan ends his Troops ahore:
Some are by Boats expos'd, by Bridges more.
With lab'ring Oars they bear along the Strand,
Where the Tide languihes, and leap a-land.
Tarchon oberves the Coat with careful Eyes,
And where no Foord he finds, no Water fryes,
Nor Billows with unequal Murmurs roar;
But moothly lide along, and well the Shoar;
That Coure he teer'd, and thus he gave command,
Here ply your Oars, and at all hazard land:
Force on the Veel that her Keel may wound
This hated Soil, and furrow hotile Ground.
Let me ecurely land, I ask no more,
Then ink my Ships, or hatter on the Shore.
This fiery Speech inflames his fearful Friends,
They tug at ev'ry Oar; and ev'ry Stretcher bends:
They run their Ships aground, the Veels knock,
(Thus forc'd ahore) and tremble with the hock.
Tarchon's alone was lot, that tranded tood,
Stuck on a Bank, and beaten by the Flood.
She breaks her Back, the looen'd Sides give way,
And plunge the Tucan Souldiers in the Sea.
Their broken Oars, and floating Planks withtand
Their Paage, while they labour to the Land;
And ebbing Tides bear back upon th' uncertain Sand.
Now Turnus leads his Troops, without delay,
Advancing to the Margin of the Sea.
The Trumpets ound: Aeneas firt aail'd
The Clowns new rais'd and raw; and oon prevail'd.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble: Sr: Robert Howard Auditor of his Maties. Exchequer, and one of ye Lords of his Majties. most Honble: Prioy Councill
figure.head: AE. 10. l. 450.

lg.l: Great Theron fell, an Omen of the Fight:
Great Theron large of Limbs, of Gyant height.
He firt in open Field defy'd the Prince,
But Armour cal'd with Gold was no Defence
Againt the fated Sword, which open'd wide
His plated Shield, and pierc'd his naked ide.
Next, Lycas fell; who, not like others born,
Was from his wretched Mother rip'd and torn:
Sacred, O Phoebus! from his Birth to thee,
For his beginning Life from biting Steel was free.
Not far from him was Gyas laid along,
Of mont'rous Bulk; with Cieus fierce and trong:
Vain Bulk and Strength; for when the Chief aail'd,
Nor Valour, nor Herculean Arms avail'd;
Nor their fam'd Father, wont in War to go
With great Alcides, while he toil'd below.
The noiie Pharos next receiv'd his Death,
Aeneas writh'd his Dart, and topp'd his bawling Breath.
Then wretched Cydon had receiv'd his Doom,
Who courted Clytius in his beardles Bloom,
And ought with lut obcene polluted Joys:
The Trojan Sword had cur'd his love of Boys,
Had not his ev'n bold Brethren top'd the Coure
Of the fierce Champion, with united Force.
Sev'n Darts were thrown at once, and ome rebound
From his bright Shield, ome on his Helmet ound:
The ret had reach'd him, but his Mother's Care
Prevented thoe, and turn'd aide in Air.
The Prince then call'd Achates, to upply
The Spears, that knew the way to Victory.
Thoe fatal Weapons, which inur'd to Blood,
In Grecian Bodies under Ilium tood:
Not one of thoe my Hand hall tos in vain
Againt our Foes, on this contended Plain.
He aid: Then eiz'd a mighty Spear, and threw;
Which, wing'd with Fate, thro' Maeon's Buckler flew:
Pierc'd all the brazen Plates, and reach'd his Heart:
He tagger'd with intolerable Smart.

l.U: aw; and reach'd, but reach'd in vain,

lg.l: His helping Hand, his Brother to utain.
A econd Spear, which kept the former Coure,
From the ame Hand, and ent with equal Force,
His right Arm pierc'd, and holding on, bereft
His ue of both, and pinion'd down his left.
Then Numitor, from his dead Brother drew
Th' ill-omend Spear, and at the Trojan threw:
Preventing Fate directs the Lance awry,
Which glancing, only mark'd Achates Thigh.
In Pride of Youth the Sabine Clauus came,
And from afar, at Driops took his Aim.
The Spear flew hiing thro' the middle Space,
And pierc'd his Throat, directed at his Face:
It top'd at once the Paage of his Wind,
And the free Soul to flitting Air reign'd:
His Forehead was the firt that truck the Ground;
Life-blood, and Life ruh'd mingl'd thro' the Wound.
He lew three Brothers of the Borean Race,
And three, whom Imarus, their Native Place,
Had ent to War, but all the Sons of Thrace.
Haleus next, the bold Aurunci leads;
The Son of Neptune to his Aid ucceeds,
Conpicuous on his Hore: On either Hand
Thee fight to keep, and thoe to win the Land.
With mutual Blood th' Auonian Soil is dy'd,
While on its Borders each their Claim decide.
As wint'ry Winds contending in the Sky,
With equal force of Lungs their Titles try.
They rage, they roar; the doubtful rack of Heav'n
Stands without Motion, and the Tyde undriv'n:
Each bent to conquer, neither ide to yield;
They long upend the Fortune of the Field.
Both Armies thus perform what Courage can:
Foot et to Foot, and crowded Man to Man.
But in another part, th' Arcadian Hore,
With ill Succes ingage the Latin Force.
For where th' impetuous Torrent ruhing down,
Huge craggy Stones, and rooted Trees had thrown:
They left their Courers, and unus'd to Fight
On Foot, were catter'd in a hameful flight.
Pallas, who with Didain and Grief, had view'd
His Foes puruing, and his Friends puru'd;
Us'd Threatnings mix'd with Pray'rs, his lat Reource;
With thee to move their Minds, with thoe to fire their Force.
Which way, Companions! Whether wou'd you run?
By you your elves, and mighty Battels won;
By my great Sire, by his etablih'd Name,
And early promie of my Future Fame;
By my Youth emulous of equal Right,
To hare his Honours, hun ignoble Flight.
Trut not your Feet, your Hands mut hew your way
Thro' yon black Body, and that thick Array:
'Tis thro' that forward Path that we mut come:
There lies our Way, and that our Paage home.
Nor Pow'rs above, nor Detinies below,
Oppres our Arms; with equal Strength we go;
With Mortal Hands to meet a Mortal Foe.
See on what Foot we tand: A canty Shore;
The Sea behind, our Enemies before:
No Paage left, unles we wim the Main;
Or forcing thee, the Trojan Trenches gain.
This aid, he trode with eager hate along,
And bore amidt the thicket of the Throng.
Lagus, the firt he met, with Fate to Foe,
Had heav'd a Stone of mighty Weight to throw:
Stooping, the Spear decended on his Chine,
Jut where the Bone ditinguih'd either Loin:
It tuck o fat, o deeply bury'd lay,
That carce the Victor forc'd the Steel away.
Hisbon came on, but while he mov'd too low
To wih'd Revenge, the Prince prevents his Blow:
For warding his at once, at once he pres'd;
And plung'd the fatal Weapon in his Breat.
Then leud Anchemolus he laid in Dut,
Who tain'd his Stepdam's Bed with impious Lut.
And after him the Daucian Twins were lain,
Laris and Thimbrus, on the Latian Plain:
So wond'rous like in Feature, Shape, and Size,
As caus'd an Error in their Parents Eyes.
Grateful Mitake! but oon the Sword decides
The nice Ditinction, and their Fate divides.
For Thimbrus Head was lop'd: and Laris Hand
Dimember'd, ought its Owner on the Strand:
The trembling Fingers yet the Fauchion train,
And threaten till th' intended Stroke in vain.
Now, to renew the Charge, th' Arcadians came:
Sight of uch Acts, and ene of honet Shame,
And Grief, with Anger mix'd, their Minds inflame.
Then, with a caual Blow was Rhaeteus lain,
Who chanc'd, as Pallas threw, to cros the Plain:
