The flying Spear was after Ilus ent,
But Rhaeteus hapen'd on a Death unmeant:
From Teuthras, and from Tyres while he fled,
The Lance, athwart his Body, laid him dead:
Rowl'd from his Chariot with a Mortal Wound,
And intercepted Fate, he purn'd the Ground.
As, when in Summer, welcome Winds arie,
The watchful Shepherd to the Foret flies,
And fires the midmot Plants; Contagion preads,
And catching Flames infect the neighb'ring Heads;
Around the Foret flies the furious Blat,
And all the leafie Nation inks at lat;
And Vulcan rides in Triumph o're the Wat;
The Pator pleas'd with his dire Victory,
Beholds the atiate Flames in Sheets acend the Sky:
So Pallas's Troops their catter'd Strength unite;
And pouring on their Foes, their Prince delight.
Haleus came, fierce with deire of Blood,
(But firt collected in his Arms he tood)
Advancing then, he ply'd the Spear o well,
Ladon, Demodocus, and Pheres fell:
Around his Head he tos'd his glitt'ring Brand,
And from Strimonius hew'd his better Hand,
Held up to guard his Throat: Then hurl'd a Stone
At Thoas ample Front, and pierc'd the Bone:
It truck beneath the pace of either Eye,
And Blood, and mingled Brains, together fly.
Deep skill'd in future Fates, Haleus Sire,
Did with the Youth to lonely Groves retire:
But when the Father's Mortal Race was run,
Dire Detiny laid hold upon the Son,
And haul'd him to the War: to find beneath
Th' Evandrian Spear, a memorable Death.
Pallas th' Encounter eeks, but e're he throws,
To Tucan Tyber thus addres'd his Vows:
O acred Stream direct my flying Dart;
And give to pas the proud Haleus Heart:
His Arms and Spoils thy holy Oak hall bear:
Pleas'd with the Bribe, the God receiv'd his Pray'r.
For while his Shield protects a Friend ditres'd,
The Dart came driving on, and pierc'd his Breat.
But Lauus, no mall portion of the War,
Permits not Panick Fear to reign too far,
Caus'd by the Death of o renown'd a Knight;
But by his own Example chears the Fight.
Fierce Abas firt he lew, Abas, the tay
Of Trojan Hopes, and hind'rance of the Day.
The Phrygian Troops ecap'd the Greeks in vain,
They, and their mix'd Allies, now load the Plain.
To the rude hock of War both Armies came,
Their Leaders equal, and their Strength the ame.
The Rear o pres'd the Front, they cou'd not wield
Their angry Weapons, to dipute the Field.
Here Pallas urges on, and Lauus there,
Of equal Youth and Beauty both appear,
But both by Fate forbid to breath their Native Air.
Their Congres in the Field great Jove withtands,
Both doom'd to fall, but fall by greater Hands.
Mean time Juturna warns the Daunian Chief
Of Lauus Danger, urging wift Relief.
With his driv'n Chariot he divides the Crowd,
And making to his Friends, thus calls aloud:
Let none preume his needles Aid to join;
Retire, and clear the Field, the Fight is mine:
To this right Hand is Pallas only due:
Oh were his Father here my jut Revenge to view!
From the forbidden Space his Men retir'd;
Pallas, their Awe, and his tern Words admir'd:
Survey'd him o're and o're with wond'ring ight,
Struck with his haughty Meen, and tow'ring Height.
Then to the King; your empty Vaunts forbear:
Succes I hope, and Fate I cannot fear.
Alive or dead, I hall deerve a Name:
Jove is impartial, and to both the ame.
He aid, and to the void advanc'd his Pace;
Pale Horror ate on each Arcadian Face.
Then Turnus, from his Chariot leaping light,
Addres'd himelf on Foot to ingle Fight.
And, as a Lyon, when he pies from far
A Bull, that eems to meditate the War;
Bending his Neck, and purning back the Sand,
Runs roaring downward from his hilly Stand:
Imagine eager Turnus not more low,
To ruh from high on his unequal Foe.
Young Pallas, when he aw the Chief advance
Within due ditance of his flying Lance;
Prepares to charge him firt: Reolv'd to try
If Fortune wou'd his want of Force upply.
And thus to Heav'n and Hercules addres'd.
Alcides, once on Earth Evander's Guet,
His Son adjures you by thoe Holy Rites,
That hopitable Board, thoe Genial Nights;
Ait my great Attempt to gain this Prize,
And let proud Turnus view, with dying Eyes,
His ravih'd Spoils. 'Twas heard, the vain Requet;
Alcides mourn'd: And tifled Sighs within his Breat.
Then Jove, to ooth his Sorrow, thus began:
Short bounds of Life are et to Mortal Man,
'Tis Vertues work alone to tretch the narrow Span.
So many Sons of Gods in bloody Fight,
Around the Walls of Troy, have lot the Light:
My own Sarpedon fell beneath his Foe,
Nor I, his mighty Sire, cou'd ward the Blow.
Ev'n Turnus hortly hall reign his Breath;
And tands already on the Verge of Death.
This aid, the God permits the fatal Fight,
But from the Latian Fields averts his ight.
Now with full Force his Spear young Pallas threw;
And having thrown, his hining Fauchion drew:
The Steel jut graz'd along the Shoulder Joint,
And mark'd it lightly with the glancing Point.
Fierce Turnus firt to nearer ditance drew,
And poiz'd his pointed Spear before he threw:
Then, as the winged Weapon whiz'd along;
See now, aid he, whoe Arm is better trung.
The Spear kept on the fatal Coure, untay'd
By Plates of Ir'n, which o're the Shield were laid:
Thro' folded Bras, and tough Bull-hides it pas'd,
His Corlet pierc'd, and reach'd his Heart at lat.
In vain the Youth tugs at the broken Wood,
The Soul comes iuing with the vital Blood:
He falls; his Arms upon his Body ound;
And with his bloody Teeth he bites the Ground.
Turnus betrode the Corps: Arcadians hear,
Said he; my Meage to your Mater bear:
Such as the Sire deerv'd, the Son I end:
It cots him dear to be the Phrygians Friend.
The lifeles Body, tell him, I betow
Unask'd, to pleae his wand'ring Ghot below.
He aid, and trampled down with all the Force
Of his left Foot, and purn'd the wretched Core:
Then natch'd the hining Belt, with Gold inlaid;
The Belt Eurytion's artful Hands had made:
Where fifty fatal Brides, expres'd to ight,
All, in the compas of one mournful Night,
Depriv'd their Bridegrooms of returning Light.

figure.p: To Sr: Iohn Leveson Gower of Trentham in, Staffordshire Baronet
figure.head: AE. 10. l. 690.

lg.l: In an ill Hour inulting Turnus tore
Thoe Golden Spoils, and in a wore he wore.
O Mortals! blind in Fate, who never know
To bear high Fortune, or endure the low!
The Time hall come, when Turnus, but in vain,
Shall wih untouch'd the Trophies of the lain:
Shall wih the fatal Belt were far away;
And cure the dire Remembrance of the Day.
The ad Arcadians from th' unhappy Field,
Bear back the breathles Body on a Shield.
O Grace and Grief of War! at once retor'd
With Praies to thy Sire, at once deplor'd.
One Day firt ent thee to the fighting Field,
Beheld whole heaps of Foes in Battel kill'd;
One Day beheld thee dead, and born upon thy Shield.
This dimal News, not from uncertain Fame,
But ad Spectators, to the Heroe came:
His Friends upon the brink of Ruin tand,
Unles reliev'd by his victorious Hand.
He whirls his Sword around, without delay,
And hews through advere Foes an ample Way;
To find fierce Turnus, of his Conquet proud:
Evander, Pallas, all that Friendhip ow'd
To large Deerts, are preent to his Eyes;
His plighted Hand, and hopitable Ties.
Four Sons of Sulmo, four whom Ufens bred,
He took in fight, and living Victims led,
To pleae the Ghot of Pallas; and expire
In Sacrifice, before his Fun'ral Fire.
At Magus next he threw: He toop'd below
The flying Spear, and hun'd the promis'd Blow.
Then creeping, clap'd the Hero's Knees, and pray'd
By young Iulus, by thy Father's Shade,
O pare my Life, and end me back to ee
My longing Sire, and tender Progeny.
A lofty Houe I have, and Wealth untold,
In Silver Ingots, and in Bars of Gold:
All thee, and Sums beides, which ee no Day,
The Ranom of this one poor Life hall pay.
If I urvive, hall Troy the les prevail?
A ingle Soul's too light to turn the Scale.
He aid. The Heroe ternly thus reply'd:
Thy Barrs, and Ingots, and the Sums beide,
Leave for thy Childrens Lot. Thy Turnus broke
All Rules of War, by one relentles Stroke
When Pallas fell: So deems, nor deems alone,
My Father's Shadow, but my living Son.
Thus having aid, of kind Remore bereft,
He eiz'd his Helm, and drag'd him with his left:
Then with his right Hand, while his Neck he wreath'd,
Up to the hilts his hining Fauchion heath'd.
Apollo's Priet, Emonides, was near,
His holy Fillets on his Front appear;
Glitt'ring in Arms he hone amidt the Crowd;
Much of his God, more of his Purple proud:
Him the fierce Trojan follow'd thro' the Field;
The holy Coward fell: And forc'd to yield,
The Prince tood o're the Priet; and at one Blow,
Sent him an Off'ring to the Shades below.
His Arms Serethus on his Shoulders bears,
Deign'd a Trophee to the God of Wars.
Vulcanian Caeculus renews the Fight;
And Umbro born upon the Mountains Height:
The Champion chears his Troops t' encounter thoe:
And eeks Revenge himelf on other Foes.
At Anxur's Shield he drove, and at the Blow,
Both Shield and Arm to Ground together go.
Anxur had boated much of magick Charms,
And thought he wore impenetrable Arms;
So made by mutter'd Spells: And from the Spheres,
Had Life ecur'd, in vain, for length of Years.
Then Tarquitus the Field in Triumph trod;
A Nymph his Mother, and his Sire a God.
Exulting in bright Arms he braves the Prince;
With his protended Lance He makes defence:
Bears back his feeble Foe; then preing on,
Arrets his better Hand, and drags him down.
Stands o're the protrate Wretch, and as he lay,
Vain Tales inventing, and prepar'd to pray:
Mows off his Head, the Trunk a Moment tood,
Then unk, and rowl'd along the Sand in Blood.
The vengeful Victor thus upbraids the lain;
Lye there, proud Man unpity'd, on the Plain:
Lye there, inglorious, and without a Tomb,
Far from thy Mother, and thy Native Home:
Expos'd to alvage Beats, and Birds of Prey;
Or thrown for Food to Monters of the Sea.
On Lycas and Antaeus next he ran,
Two Chiefs of Turnus, and who led his Van.
They fled for Fear; with thee he chas'd along,
Camers the yellow Lock'd, and Numa trong,
Both great in Arms, and both were fair, and young:
Camers, was Son to Volcens lately lain;
In Wealth urpaing all the Latian Train,
And in Amycla fix'd his ilent, eay Reign.
And as Aegeon, when with Heav'n he trove,
Stood oppoite in Arms to mighty Jove;
Mov'd all his hundred Hands, provok'd the War,
Defy'd the forky Lightning from afar:
At fifty Mouths his flaming Breath expires,
And Flah for Flah returns, and Fires for Fires:
In his right Hand as many Swords he wields,
And takes the Thunder on as many Shields:
With Strength like his the Trojan Heroe tood,
And oon the Fields with falling Corps were trowd,
When once his Fauchion found the Tate of Blood.
With Fury carce to be conceiv'd, he flew
Againt Niphaeus, whom four Courers drew.
They, when they ee the fiery Chief advance,
And puhing at their Chets his pointed Lance;
Wheel'd with o wift a Motion, mad with Fear,
They threw their Mater headlong from the Chair:
They tare, they tart, nor top their Coure before
They bear the bounding Chariot to the Shore.
Now Lucagus, and Liger cour the Plains,
With two white Steeds, but Liger holds the Reins,
And Lucagus the lofty Seat maintains.
Bold Brethren both, the former wav'd in Air
His flaming Sword; Aeneas couch'd his Spear,
Unus'd to Threats, and more unus'd to Fear.
Then Liger thus. Thy Confidence is vain
To cape from hence, as from the Trojan Plain:
Nor thee the Steeds which Diomede betrode,
Nor this the Chariot where Achilles rode:
Nor Venus's Veil is here, nor Neptune's Shield:
Thy fatal Hour is come; and this the Field.
Thus Liger vainly vaunts: The Trojan Peer
Return'd his anwer with his flying Spear.
As Lucagus to lah his Hores bends,
Prone to the Wheels, and his left Foot protends:
Prepar'd for Fight, the fatal Dart arrives,
And thro' the borders of his Buckler drives.
Pas'd through; and pierc'd his Groin, the deadly Wound,
Cat from his Chariot, rowl'd him on the Ground.
Whom thus the Chief upbraids with cornful pight:
Blame not the lownes of your Steeds in flight;
Vain Shadows did not force their wift Retreat:
But you your elf forake your empty Seat.
He aid, and eiz'd at once the looen'd Rein,
(For Liger lay already on the Plain,
By the ame Shock) then, tretching out his Hands,
The Recreant thus his wretched Life demands.
Now by thy elf, O more than Mortal Man!
By her and him from whom thy Breath began,
Who form'd thee thus Divine, I beg thee pare
This forfeit Life, and hear thy Suppliant's Pray'r.
Thus much he poke, and more he wou'd have aid,
But the tern Heroe turn'd aide his Head,
And cut him hort. I hear another Man,
You talk'd not thus before the Fight began;
Now take your turn: And, as a Brother hou'd,
Attend your Brother to the Stygian Flood:
Then thro' his Breat his fatal Sword he ent,
And the Soul iu'd at the bloody Vent.
As Storms the Skies, and Torrents tear the Ground,
Thus rag'd the Prince, and catter'd Deaths around:
At length Acanius, and the Trojan Train,
Broke from the Camp, o long beieg'd in vain.
Mean time the King of Gods and Mortal Man,
Held Conference with his Queen, and thus began:
My Siter Goddes, and well pleaing Wife,
Still think you Venus's Aid upports the Strife;
Sutains her Trojans: Or themelves alone,
With inborn Valour force their Fortune on?
How fierce in Fight, with Courage undecay'd;
Judge if uch Warriors want immortal Aid.
To whom the Goddes, with the charming Eyes,
Soft in her Tone ubmiively replies.
Why, O my loving Lord, whoe Frown I fear,
And cannot, unconcern'd, your Anger bear;
Why urge you thus my Grief? When if I till,
(As once I was) were Mitres of your Will:
From your Almighty Pow'r, your pleaing Wife
Might gain the Grace of lengthning Turnus's Life:
Securely natch him from the fatal Fight,
And give him to his aged Father's ight.
Now let him perih, ince you hold it good,
And glut the Trojans with his pious Blood.
Yet from our Lineage he derives his Name,
And in the fourth degree, from God Pilumnus came:
Yet he devoutly pays you Rites Divine,
And offers daily Incene at your Shrine.
Then hortly thus the Sov'raign God reply'd;
Since in my Pow'r and Goodnes you confide;
If for a little Space, a lengthen'd Span,
You beg Reprieve for this expiring Man:
I grant you leave to take your Turnus hence,
From Intant Fate, and can o far dipene.
But if ome ecret Meaning lies beneath,
To ave the hort-liv'd Youth from detin'd Death:
Or if a farther Thought you entertain,
To change the Fates; you feed your hopes in vain.
To whom the Goddes thus, with weeping Eyes,
And what if that Requet your Tongue denies,
Your Heart hou'd grant; and not a hort Reprieve,
But length of certain Life to Turnus give.
Now peedy Death attends the guiltles Youth,
If my preaging Soul divines with Truth.
Which, O! I wih might err thro' caueles Fears,
And you, (for you have Pow'r) prolong his Years.
Thus having aid, involv'd in Clouds, he flies,
And drives a Storm before her thro' the Skies.
Swift he decends, alighting on the Plain,
Where the fierce Foes a dubious Fight maintain.
Of Air condens'd, a Spectre oon he made,
And what Aeneas was, uch eem'd the Shade.
Adorn'd with Dardan Arms, the Phantom bore
His Head aloft, a Plumy Cret he wore:
This Hand appear'd a hining Sword to wield,
And that utain'd an imitated Shield:
With manly Meen He talk'd along the Ground;
Nor wanted Voice bely'd, nor vaunting Sound.
(Thus haunting Ghots appear to waking Sight,
Or dreadful Viions in our Dreams by Night.)
The Spectre eems the Daunian Chief to dare,
And flourihes his empty Sword in Air:
At this advancing Turnus hurl'd his Spear;
The Phantom wheel'd, and eem'd to fly for Fear.
Deluded Turnus thought the Trojan fled,
And with vain hopes his haughty Fancy fed.
Whether, O Coward, (thus he calls aloud,
Nor found he poke to Wind, and chas'd a Cloud;)
Why thus forake your Bride? Receive from me
The fated Land you ought o long by Sea.
He aid, and brandihing at once his Blade,
With eager Pace puru'd the flying Shade.
By chance a Ship was faten'd to the Shore,
Which from old Cluium King Oinius bore:
The Planks were ready laid for afe acent;
For helter there the trembling Shadow bent:
And skip'd, and culk'd, and under Hatches went.
Exulting Turnus, with regardles hate,
Acends the Plank, and to the Gally pas'd:
Scarce had he reach'd the Prow, Saturnia's Hand
The Haulers cuts, and hoots the Ship from Land.
With Wind in Poop, the Veel plows the Sea,
And meaures back with peed her former Way.
Mean time Aeneas eeks his abent Foe,
And ends his laughter'd Troops to Shades below.
The guileful Phantom now forook the hrowd,
And flew ublime, and vanih'd in a Cloud.
Too late young Turnus the Deluion found,
Far on the Sea, till making from the Ground.
Then thankles for a Life redeem'd by Shame;
With ene of Honour tung, and forfeit Fame:
Fearful beides of what in Fight had pas'd,
His Hands, and hagger'd Eyes to Heav'n he cat.
O Jove! he cry'd, for what Offence have I
Deerv'd to bear this endles Infamy:
Whence am I forc'd, and whether am I born,
How, and with what Reproach hall I return?
Shall ever I behold the Latian Plain,
Or ee Laurentum's lofty Tow'rs again?
What will they ay of their deerting Chief?
The War was mine, I fly from their Relief:
I led to Slaughter, and in Slaughter leave;
And ev'n from hence their dying Groans receive.
Here over-match'd in Fight, in heaps they lye,
There catter'd o're the Fields ignobly fly.
Gape wide, O Earth! and draw me down alive,
Or, oh ye pitying Winds, a Wretch relieve;
On Sands or Shelves the plitting Veel drive:
Or et me Shipwrack'd on ome deart Shore,
Where no Rutulian Eyes may ee me more:
Unknown to Friends, or Foes, or concious Fame,
Let he hould follow, and my flight proclaim.
Thus Turnus rav'd, and various Fates revolv'd,
The Choice was doubtful, but the Death reolv'd.
And now the Sword, and now the Sea took place:
That to revenge, and this to purge Digrace.
Sometimes he thought to wim the tormy Main,
By tretch of Arms the ditant Shore to gain:
Thrice he the Sword aay'd, and thrice the Flood;
But Juno mov'd with Pity both withtood:
And thrice repres'd his Rage: trong Gales upply'd,
And puh'd the Veel o're the welling Tide.
At length he lands him on his Native Shores,
And to his Father's longing Arms retores.
Mean time, by Jove's Impule, Mezentius arm'd:
Succeeding Turnus; with his ardour warm'd
His fainting Friends, reproach'd their hameful flight,
Repell'd the Victors, and renew'd the Fight.
Againt their King the Tucan Troops conpire,
Such is their Hate, and uch their fierce deire
Of wih'd Revenge: On him, and him alone,
All Hands employ'd, and all their Darts are thrown.
He, like a olid Rock by Seas inclos'd,
To raging Winds and roaring Waves oppos'd;
From his proud Summit looking down, didains
Their empty Menace, and unmov'd remains.
Beneath his Feet fell haughty Hebrus dead,
Then Latagus; and Palmus as he fled:
At Latagus a weighty Stone he flung,
His Face was flatted, and his Helmet rung.
But Palmus from behind receives his Wound,
Hamtring'd he falls, and grovels on the Ground:
His Cret and Armor from his Body torn,
Thy Shoulders, Lauus, and thy Head adorn.
Evas and Mymas, both of Troy, he lew,
Mymas his Birth from fair Theano drew:
Born on that fatal Night, when, big with Fire,
The Queen produc'd young Paris to his Sire.
But Paris in the Phrygian Fields was lain,
Unthinking Mymas on the Latian Plain.
And as a alvage Boar on Mountains bred,
With foret Mat, and fatning Marhes fed;
When once he ees himelf in Toils inclos'd,
By Huntmen and their eager Hounds oppos'd:
He whets his Tusks, and turns, and dares the War:
Th' Invaders dart their Jav'lins from afar;
All keep aloof, and afely hout around,
But none preumes to give a nearer Wound.
He frets and froaths, erects his britled Hide,
And hakes a Grove of Lances from his Side:
Not otherwie the Troops, with Hate inpir'd,
And jut Revenge, againt the Tyrant fir'd;
Their Darts with Clamour at a ditance drive:
And only keep the languih'd War alive.
From Coritus came Acron to the Fight,
Who left his Spoue betroath'd, and unconummate Night.

l.U: ees him thro' the Squadrons ride,

lg.l: Proud of the Purple Favours of his Bride.
Then, as a hungry Lyon, who beholds
A Gameom Goat, who frisks about the Folds;
Or beamy tag that grazes on the Plain:
He runs, he roars, he hakes his riing Mane;
He grins, and opens wide his greedy Jaws,
The Prey lyes panting underneath his Paws:
He fills his famih'd Maw, his Mouth runs o're
With unchew'd Morels, while he churns the Gore:
So proud Mezentius ruhes on his Foes,
And firt unhappy Acron overthrows:
Stretch'd at his length, he purns the warthy Ground,
The Lance bemear'd with Blood, lies broken in the wound.
Then with Didain the haughty Victor view'd
Orodes flying, nor the Wretch puru'd:
Nor thought the Datard's Back deerv'd a Wound,
But running gain'd th' Advantage of the Ground.
Then turning hort, he met him Face to Face,
To give his Victory the better grace.
Orodes falls, in equal Fight oppres'd:
Mezentius fix'd his Foot upon his Breat,
And reted Lance: And thus aloud he cries,
Lo here the Champion of my Rebels lies.
The Fields around with Io Paean ring,
And peals of Shouts applaud the conqu'ring King.
At this the vanquih'd, with his dying Breath,
Thus faintly poke, and prophey'd in Death:
Nor thou, proud Man, unpunih'd halt remain;
Like Death attends thee on this fatal Plain.
Then, ourly miling, thus the King reply'd,
For what belongs to me let Jove provide:
But dye thou firt, whatever Chance enue:
He aid, and from the Wound the Weapon drew:
A hov'ring Mit came wimming o're his ight,
And eal'd his Eyes in everlating Night.
By Caedicus, Alcathous was lain,
Sacrator laid Hydapes on the Plain:
Ores the trong to greater Strength mut yield;
He, with Parthenius, were by Rapo kill'd.
Then brave Meapus Ericetes lew,
Who from Lycaon's Blood his Lineage drew.
But from his headtrong Hore his Fate he found,
Who threw his Mater as he made a bound,
The Chief alighting, tuck him to the Ground.
Then Clonius hand to hand, on Foot aails,
The Trojan inks, and Neptune's Son prevails.
Agis the Lycian tepping forth with Pride,
To ingle Fight the boldet Foe defy'd.
Whom Tucan Valerus by Force o'recame,
And not bely'd his mighty Father's Fame.
Salius to Death the great Antronius fent,
But the ame Fate the Victor underwent:
Slain by Nealces Hand, well skill'd to throw
The flying Dart, and draw the far-deceiving Bow.
Thus equal Deaths are dealt with equal Chance;
By turns they quit their Ground, by turns advance:
Victors, and vanquih'd, in the various Field,
Nor wholly overcome, nor wholly yield.
The Gods from Heav'n urvey the fatal Strife,
And mourn the Mieries of Human Life.
Above the ret two Goddees appear
Concern'd for each: Here Venus, Juno there:
Amidt the Crowd Infernal Atè hakes
Her Scourge aloft, and Cret of hiing Snakes.
Once more the proud Mezentius, with Didain,
Brandih'd his Spear, and ruh'd into the Plain:
Where tow'ring in the midmot Ranks he tood,
Like tall Orion talking o're the Flood:
When with his brawny Breat he cuts the Waves,
His Shoulders carce the topmot Billow laves.
Or like a Mountain Ah, whoe Roots are pread,
Deep fix'd in Earth, in Clouds he hides his Head.
The Trojan Prince beheld him from afar,
And dauntles undertook the doubtful War.
Collected in his Strength, and like a Rock,
Poiz'd on his Bae, Mezentius tood the Shock.
He tood, and meauring firt with careful Eyes,
The pace his Spear cou'd reach, aloud he cries:
My trong right Hand, and Sword, ait my Stroke;
(Thoe only Gods Mezentius will invoke)
His Armour from the Trojan Pyrate torn,
By my triumphant Lauus hall be worn.

figure.p: To Sr: Charles Orby Baronet of Burton Pednarden in ye County of Lincolne
figure.head: AE. 10. l. 1125.

lg.l: He aid, and with his utmot force he threw
The may Spear, which, hiing as it flew,
Reach'd the Coeletial Shield that top'd the coure;
But glancing thence, the yet unbroken Force
Took a new bent obliquely, and betwixt
The Side and Bowels fam'd Anthores fix'd.
Anthores had from Argos travell'd far,
Alcides Friend, and Brother of the War:
'Till tir'd with Toils, fair Italy he choe,
And in Evander's Palace ought Repoe:
Now falling by another's Wound, his Eyes
He cats to Heav'n, on Argos thinks, and dyes.
The pious Trojan then his Jav'lin ent,
The Shield gave way: Thro' treble Plates it went
Of olid Bras, of Linnen trebly rowl'd,
And three Bull-hides which round the Buckler rowl'd.
All thee it pas'd, reitles in the Coure,
Tranpierc'd his Thigh, and pent its dying Force.
The gaping Wound guh'd out a Crimon Flood;
The Trojan, glad with ight of hotile Blood,
His Fauchion drew, to cloer Fight addres'd,
And with new Force his fainting Foe oppres'd.
His Father's Peril Lauus view'd with Grief,
He igh'd, he wept, he ran to his Relief.
And here, Heroick Youth, 'tis here I mut
To thy immortal Memory be jut;
And ing an Act o noble and o new,
Poterity will carce believe 'tis true.
Pain'd with his Wound, and ueles for the Fight,
The Father ought to ave himelf by Flight:
Incumber'd, low he drag'd the Spear along,
Which pierc'd his thigh, and in his Buckler hung.
The pious Youth, reolv'd on Death, below
The lifted Sword, prings forth to face the Foe;
Protects his Parent, and prevents the Blow.
Shouts of Applaue ran ringing thro' the Field,
To ee the Son the vanquih'd Father hield:
All fir'd with gen'rous Indignation trive;
And with a torm of Darts, to ditance drive
The Trojan Chief; who held at Bay from far,
On his Vulcanian Orb utain'd the War.
As when thick Hail comes ratling in the Wind,
The Plowman, Paenger, and lab'ring Hind,
For helter to the neighb'ring Covert fly;
Or hous'd, or afe in hollow Caverns lye:
But that o'reblown, when Heav'n above 'em miles,
Return to Travel, and renew their Toils:
Aeneas thus o'rewhelm'd on ev'ry ide,
The torm of Darts, undaunted, did abide;
And thus to Lauus loud with friendly threat'ning cry'd.
Why wilt thou ruh to certain Death, and Rage
In rah Attempts, beyond thy tender Age:
Betray'd by pious Love? Nor thus forborn
The Youth deits, but with inulting Scorn
Provokes the ling'ring Prince: Whoe Patience tyr'd,
Gave Place, and all his Breat with Fury fir'd.
For now the Fates prepar'd their cruel Sheers;
And lifted high the flaming Sword appears:
Which full decending, with a frightful way,
Thro Shield and Corlet forc'd th'impetuous Way,
And bury'd deep in his fair Boom lay.
The purple Streams thro' the thin Armour trove,
And drench'd th' imbroider'd Coat his Mother wove:
And Life at length forook his heaving Heart,
Loath from o weet a Manion to depart.
But when, with Blood, and Palenes all o'repread,
The pious Prince beheld young Lauus dead;
He griev'd, he wept, the ight an Image brought
Of his own filial Love; a adly pleaing Thought.
Then tretch'd his Hand to hold him up, and aid,
Poor haples Youth! what Praies can be paid
To Love o great, to uch trancendent Store
Of early Worth, and ure Preage of more?
Accept what e're Aeneas can afford,
Untouch'd thy Arms, untaken be thy Sword:
And all that pleas'd thee living till remain
Inviolate, and acred to the lain.
Thy Body on thy Parents I betow,
To ret thy Soul, at leat if Shadows know,
Or have a ene of human Things below.
There to thy fellow Ghots with Glory tell,
'Twas by the great Aeneas hand I fell.
With this his ditant Friends he beckons near,
Provokes their Duty, and prevents their Fear:
Himelf aits to lift him from the Ground,
With clotted Locks, and Blood that well'd from out the Wound.
Mean time his Father, now no Father, tood,
And wah'd his Wounds by Tyber's yellow Flood:
Oppres'd with Anguih, panting, and o'repent,
His fainting Limbs againt an Oak he leant.
A Bough his Brazen Helmet did utain,
His heavier Arms lay catter'd on the Plain.
A choen Train of Youth around him tand,
His drooping Head was reted on his hand:
His grily Beard his penive Boom ought,
And all on Lauus ran his retles thought.
Careful, concern'd his Danger to prevent,
He much enquir'd, and many a Meage ent
To warn him from the Field: Alas! in vain,
Behold his mournful Followers bear him lain:
O're his broad Shield till guh'd the yawning Wound,
And drew a bloody Trail along the Ground.
Far off he heard their Cries, far off divin'd
The dire Event, with a foreboding Mind.
With Dut he prinkled firt his hoary Head,
Then both his lifted hands to Heav'n he pread;
Lat, the dear Corps embracing, thus he aid.
What Joys, alas! cou'd this frail Being give,
That I have been o covetous to live?
To ee my Son, and uch a Son, reign
His Life a Ranom for preerving mine?
And am I then preerv'd, and art thou lot?
How much too dear has that Redemption cot!
'Tis now my bitter Banihment I feel;
This is a Wound too deep for time to heal.
My Guilt thy growing Virtues did defame;
My Blacknes blotted thy unblemih'd Name.
Chas'd from a Throne, abandon'd, and exil'd
For foul Mideeds, were Punihments too mild:
I ow'd my People thee, and from their hate,
With les Reentment cou'd have born my Fate.
And yet I live, and yet utain the ight
Of hated Men, and of more hated Light:
But will not long. With that he rais'd from Ground
His fainting Limbs, that tagger'd with his Wound.
Yet with a Mind reolv'd, and unappal'd
With Pains or Perils, for his Courer call'd:
Well mouth'd, well manag'd, whom himelf did dres,
With daily Care, and mounted with Succes;
His Aid in Arms, his Ornament in Peace.
Soothing his Courage with a gentle Stroke,
The Steed eem'd enible, while thus he poke.
O Rhaebus we have liv'd too long for me,
(If Life and long were Terms that cou'd agree)
This Day thou either halt bring back the Head,
And bloody Trophees of the Trojan dead:
This Day thou either halt revenge my Woe
For murther'd Lauus, on his cruel Foe;
Or if inexorable Fate deny
Our Conquet, with thy conquer'd Mater dye:
For after uch a Lord, I ret ecure,
Thou wilt no foreign Reins, or Trojan Load endure.
He aid: And traight th' officious Courer kneels
To take his wonted Weight. His Hands he fills
With pointed Jav'lins: On his Head he lac'd
His glitt'ring Helm, which terribly was grac'd
With waving Hore-hair, nodding from afar;
Then purr'd his thund'ring Steed amidt the War.
Love, Anguih, Wrath, and Grief, to Madnes wrought,
Depair, and ecret Shame, and concious thought
Of inborn Worth, his lab'ring Soul oppres'd,
Rowl'd in his Eyes, and rag'd within his Breat.
Then loud he call'd Aeneas thrice by Name,
The loud repeated Voice to glad Aeneas came.
Great Jove, he aid, and the far-hooting God,
Inpire thy Mind to make thy Challenge good.
He poke no more, but haten'd, void of Fear,
And threaten'd with his long protended Spear.
To whom Mezentius thus. Thy Vaunts are vain,
My Lauus lies extended on the Plain:
He's lot! thy Conquet is already won,
The wretched Sire is murther'd in the Son.
Nor Fate I fear, but all the Gods defy,
Forbear thy Threats, my Bus'nes is to dye;
But firt receive this parting Legacy.
He aid: And traight a whirling Dart he ent:
Another after, and another went.
Round in a pacious Ring he rides the Field,
And vainly plies th' impenetrable Shield:
Thrice rode he round, and thrice Aeneas wheel'd.
Turn'd as he turn'd; the Golden Orb withtood
The Strokes, and bore about an Iron Wood.
Impatient of Delay, and weary grown,
Still to defend, and to defend alone:
To wrench the Darts which in his Buckler light,
Urg'd, and o're-labour'd in unequal Fight:
At length reolv'd, he throws with all his Force,
Full at the Temples of the Warrior Hore.
Jut where the Stroke was aim'd, th' unerring Spear
Made way, and tood transfix'd thro' either Ear.
Seiz'd with unwonted Pain, urpriz'd with Fright,
The wounded Steed curvets; and, rais'd upright,
Lights on his Feet before: His Hoofs behind
Spring up in Air aloft, and lah the Wind.
Down comes the Rider headlong from his height,
His Hore came after with unweildy weight:
And flound'ring forward, pitching on his Head,
His Lord's incumber'd Sholuder overlaid.
From either Hoat the mingl'd Shouts, and Cries,
Of Trojans and Rutulians rend the Skies.
Aeneas hat'ning, wav'd his fatal Sword
High o're his head, with this reproachful Word.
Now, where are now thy Vaunts, the fierce Didain
Of proud Mezentius, and the lofty Strain?
Strugling, and wildly taring on the Skies,
With carce recover'd Sight, he thus replies.
Why thee inulting Words, this wate of Breath,
To Souls undaunted, and ecure of Death?
'Tis no Dihonour for the Brave to dye,
Nor came I here with hope of Victory:
Nor ask I Life, nor fought with that deign,
As I had us'd my Fortune, ue thou thine.
My dying Son contracted no uch Band;
The Gift is hateful from his Murd'rer's hand.

figure.p: To Tho: Hopkins of ye Middle Temple Esq.

lg.l: For this, this only Favour let me ue,
(If Pity can to conquer'd Foes be due)
Refue it not: But let my Body have,
The lat Retreat of Human Kind, a Grave.
Too well I know th' inulting People's Hate;
Protect me from their Vengeance after Fate:
This Refuge for my poor Remains provide,
And lay my much lov'd Lauus by my ide:
He aid, and to his Throat the Sword apply'd.
The Crimon Stream ditain'd his Arms around,
And the didainful Soul came ruhing thro' the Wound.

div.head: The Eleventh Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Aeneas erects a Trophy of the Spoils of Mezentius; grants a Truce for burying the dead; and ends home the Body of Pallas with great Solemnity. Latinus calls a Council to propoe offers of Peace to Aeneas, which occaions great Animoity betwixt Turnus and Drances: In the mean time there is a harp Engagement of the Hore; wherein Camilla ignalizes her elf; is kill'd: And the Latine Troops are entirely defeated.

lg.l: SCarce had the roie Morning rais'd her Head
Above the Waves, and left her wat'ry Bed;
The Pious Chief, whom double Cares attend
For his unbury'd Souldiers, and his Friend:
Yet firt to Heav'n perform'd a Victor's Vows;
He bar'd an ancient Oak of all her Boughs:
Then on a riing Ground the Trunk he plac'd;
Which with the Spoils of his dead Foe he grac'd.
The Coat of Arms by proud Mezentius worn,
Now on a naked Snag in Triumph born,
Was hung on high; and glitter'd from afar:
A Trophy acred to the God of War.
Above his Arms, fix'd on the leafles Wood,
Appear'd his Plumy Cret, ditilling Blood;
His brazen Buckler on the left was een;
Trunchions of hiver'd Lances hung between:
And on the right was plac'd his Corlet, bor'd;
And to the Neck was ty'd his unavailing Sword.
A Crowd of Chiefs incloe the Godlike Man:
Who thus, conpicuous in the midt, began.
Our Toils, my Friends, are crown'd with ure Succes:
The greater Part perform'd, atchieve the les.

figure.p: To ye Right Noble Charles Duke of Shrensbury Marquis of Alton Earle of Shrensbury Wexford & Water-ford, Baron Talbot Strange of Blackmere Gifford of Brimsfield &ct One of the Lords of his Ma.ties most Hon.ble Privy Councill Principall Secretary of State, and Knight of ye most Noble Order of the Garter.
figure.head: AE. 11. l. 1.

lg.l: Now follow chearful to the trembling Town;
Pres but an Entrance, and preume it won.
Fear is no more: For fierce Mezentius lies,
As the firt Fruits of War, a Sacrifice.

l.U: hall fall extended on the Plain;

lg.l: And in this Omen is already lain.
Prepar'd in Arms purue your happy Chance;
That none unwarn'd may plead his Ignorance:
And I, at Heav'n's appointed Hour, may find
Your warlike Enigns waving in the Wind.
Mean time the Rites and Fun'ral Pomps prepare,
Due to your dead Companions of the War:
The lat Repect the living can betow,
To hield their Shadows from Contempt below.
That conquer'd Earth be theirs for which they fought;
And which for us with their own blood they bought.
But firt the Corps of our unhappy Friend,
To the ad City of Evander end:
Who not inglorious in his Ages bloom
Was hurry'd hence by too evere a Doom.
Thus, weeping while he poke, he took his Way,
Where, new in Death, lamented Pallas lay:
Acaetes watch'd the Corps; whoe Youth deerv'd
The Father's Trut, and now the Son he erv'd
With equal Faith, but les aupicious Care:
Th' Attendants of the lain, his Sorrow hare.
A Troop of Trojans mix'd with thee appear,
And mourning Matrons with dihevell'd Hair.
Soon as the Prince appears, they raie a Cry;
All beat their Breats, and Echoes rend the Sky.
They rear his drooping Forehead from the Ground;
But when Aeneas view'd the grily Wound
Which Pallas in his Manly Boom bore,
And the fair Fleh ditain'd with Purple Gore:
Firt, melting into Tears, the pious Man
Deplor'd o ad a ight, then thus began.
Unhappy Youth! When Fortune gave the ret
Of my full Wihes, he refus'd the bet!
She came; but brought not thee along; to bles
My longing Eyes, and hare in my Succes:
She grudg'd thy afe Return the Triumphs due
To prop'rous Valour, in the publick View.
Not thus I promis'd, when thy Father lent
Thy needful Succour with a ad Conent;
Embrac'd me parting for th' Etrurian Land,
And ent me to poes a large Command.
He warn'd, and from his own Experience told,
Our Foes were warlike, diciplin'd, and bold:
And now perhaps, in hopes of thy return,
Rich Odours on his loaded Altars burn;
While we, with vain officious Pomp, prepare
To end him back his Portion of the War;
A bloody breathles Body: which can owe
No farther Debt, but to the Pow'rs below.
The wretched Father, e're his Race is run,
Shall view the Fun'ral Honours of his Son.
Thee are my Triumphs of the Latian War;
Fruits of my plighted Faith, and boated Care.
And yet, unhappy Sire, thou halt not ee
A Son, whoe Death digrac'd his Ancetry:
Thou halt not bluh, old Man, however griev'd:
Thy Pallas no dihonet Wound receiv'd.
He dy'd no Death to make thee wih, too late,
Thou hadt not liv'd to ee his hameful Fate:
But what a Champion has th' Auonian Coat,
And what a Friend hat thou, Acanius, lot!
Thus having mourn'd, he gave the Word around,
To raie the lifeles Body from the Ground;
And choe a thouand Hore, the flow'r of all
His warlike Troops, to wait the Funeral:
To bear him back, and hare Evander's Grief;
(A well becoming, but a weak Relief.)
Of Oaken Twigs they twit an eaie Bier;
Then on their Shoulders the ad Burden rear.
The Body on this Rural Here is born,
Strewd Leaves and Funeral Greens the Bier adorn.
All pale he lies, and looks a lovely Flow'r,
New cropt by Virgin Hands, to dres the Bow'r;
Unfaded yet, but yet unfed below,
No more to Mother Earth or the green Stem hall owe.
Then two fair Vets, of wond'rous Work and Cot,
Of Purple woven, and with Gold embos'd,
For Ornament the Trojan Heroe brought,
Which with her Hands Sidonian Dido wrought.
One Vet array'd the Corps, and one they pread
O're his clos'd Eyes, and wrap'd around his Head:
That when the yellow Hair in Flame hou'd fall,
The catching Fire might burn the Golden Caul.
Beides, the Spoils of Foes in Battel lain,
When he decended on the Latian Plain:
Arms, Trappings, Hores, by the Here are led
In long Array, (th' Atchievments of the Dead.)
Then, pinion'd with their hands behind, appear
Th' unhappy Captives, marching in the Rear:
Appointed Off'rings in the Victor's Name,
To prinkle with their Blood, the Fun'ral Flame.
Inferior Trophees by the Chiefs are born;
Gantlets and Helms, their heads and hands adorn:
And fair Incriptions fix'd, and Titles read,
Of Latian Leaders conquer'd by the Dead.
Acaetes on his Pupil's Corps attends,
With feeble Steps; upported by his Friends:
Pauing at ev'ry Pace; in Sorrow drown'd,
Betwixt their Arms he inks upon the Ground.
Where grov'ling, while he lies in deep Depair,
He beats his Breat, and rends his hoary Hair.
The Champion's Chariot next is een to rowl,
Bemear'd with hotile blood, and honourably foul.
To cloe the Pomp, Aethon, the Steed of State,
Is led, the Fun'rals of his Lord to wait.
Stripp'd of his Trappings, with a ullen Pace
He walks, and the big Tears run rolling down his Face.
The Lance of Pallas, and the Crimon Cret,
Are born behind; the Victor eiz'd the ret.
The March begins: The Trumpets hoarly ound,
The Pikes and Lances trail along the Ground.
Thus while the Trojan and Arcadian Hore,
To Pallantean Tow'rs direct their Coure,
In long Proceion rank'd; the pious Chief
Stop'd in the Rear, and gave a vent to Grief.
The publick Care, he aid, which War attends
Diverts our preent Woes, at leat upends:
Peace with the Manes of great Pallas dwell;
Hail holy Relicks, and a lat farewel!
He aid no more, but inly though he mourn'd,
Retrain'd his Tears, and to the Camp return'd.
Now Suppliants, from Laurentum ent, demand
A Truce, with Olive Branches in their hand.
Obtet his Clemency, and from the Plain
Beg leave to draw the Bodies of their lain.
They plead, that none thoe common Rites deny
To conquer'd Foes, that in fair Battel dye.
All caue of Hate was ended in their Death;
Nor cou'd he War with Bodies void of Breath.
A King, they hop'd, wou'd hear a King's Requet:
Whoe Son he once was call'd, and once his Guet.
Their Suit, which was too jut to be deny'd,
The Heroe grants, and farther thus reply'd:
O Latian Princes, how evere a Fate
In caueles Quarrels has involv'd your State!
And arm'd againt an unoffending Man,
Who ought your Friendhip e're the War began!
You beg a Truce, which I wou'd gladly give,
Not only for the lain, but thoe who live.
I came not hether but by Heav'n's Command,
And ent by Fate to hare the Latian Land.
Nor wage I Wars unjut; your King deny'd
My proffer'd Friendhip, and my promis'd Bride.
Left me for Turnus; Turnus then hould try
His Caue in Arms, to Conquer or to dye.
My Right and his are in dipute: The lain
Fell without fault, our Quarrel to maintain.
In equal Arms let us alone contend;
And let him vanquih, whom his Fates befriend.
This is the way, o tell him, to poes
The Royal Virgin, and retore the Peace.
Bear this my Meage back; with ample leave
That your lain Friends may Fun'ral Rites receive.
Thus having aid, th' Embaadors amaz'd,
Stood mute a while, and on each other gaz'd:
Drances, their Chief, who harbour'd in his Breat
Long hate to Turnus, as his Foe profes'd,
Broke ilence firt, and to the Godlike Man,
With graceful action bowing, thus began.
Aupicious Prince, in Arms a mighty Name,
But yet whoe Actions far trancend your Fame;
Wou'd I your Jutice or your Force expres,
Thought can but equal; and all Words are les:
Your Anwer we hall thankfully relate,
And Favours granted to the Latian State:
If wih'd Succes our Labour hall attend,
Think Peace concluded, and the King your Friend:
Let Turnus leave the Realm to your Command;
And eek Alliance in ome other Land:
Build you the City which your Fates aign;
We hall be proud in the great Work to join.
Thus Drances; and his Words o well perwade
The ret impower'd, that oon a Truce is made.
Twelve days the term allow'd: And during thoe,
Latians and Trojans, now no longer Foes,
Mix'd in the Woods, for Fun'ral Piles prepare,
To fell the Timber, and forget the War.
Loud Axes thro' the groaning Groves reound:
Oak, Mountain Ah, and Poplar, pread the Ground:
Firrs fall from high: And ome the Trunks receive,
In Loaden Wains, with Wedges ome they cleave.
And now the Fatal News, by Fame is blown
Thro' the hort Circuit of th' Arcadian Town,
Of Pallas lain: By Fame, which jut before
His Triumphs on ditended Pinions bore.
Ruhing from out the Gate, the People tand,
Each with a Fun'ral Flambeau in his hand:
Wildly they tare, ditracted with amaze:
The Fields are lighten'd with a fiery blaze,
That cat a ullen Splendor on their Friends,
(The marching Troop which their dead Prince attends.)
Both Parties meet: They raie a doleful Cry:
The Matrons from the Walls with hrieks reply;
And their mix'd mourning rends the vaulted Sky.
The Town is fill'd with Tumult and with Tears;
Till the loud Clamours reach Evander's Ears:
Forgetful of his State, he runs along,
With a diorder'd pace, and cleaves the Throng:

figure.p: To Sr. Walter Kirkham Blount of Sodington in the County of Worcester Bart.
figure.head: AE 11. l. 215

lg.l: Falls on the Corps, and groaning there he lies,
With ilent Grief that peaks but at his Eyes:
Short Sighs and Sobs ucceed; 'till Sorrow breaks
A Paage, and at once he weeps and peaks.
O Pallas! thou hat fail'd thy plighted Word!
To fight with Caution, not to tempt the Sword:
I warn'd thee, but in vain; for well I knew
What Perils youthful Ardour wou'd purue:
That boiling Blood wou'd carry thee too far;
Young as thou wert in Dangers, raw to War!
O curt Eay of Arms, diat'rous Doom,
Prelude of bloody Fields, and Fights to come!
Hard Elements of unaupicious War,
Vain Vows to Heav'n, and unavailing Care!
Thrice happy thou, dear Partner of my Bed,
Whoe holy Soul the Stroke of Fortune fled:
Praecious of Ills, and leaving me behind,
To drink the Dregs of Life by Fate aign'd.
Beyond the Goal of Nature I have gon;
My Pallas late et out, but reach'd too oon.
If, for my League againt th' Auonian State,
Amidt their Weapons I had found my Fate,
(Deerv'd from them,) then I had been return'd
A breathles Victor, and my Son had mourn'd.
Yet will I not my Trojan Friend upbraid,
Nor grudge th' Alliance I o gladly made.
'Twas not his Fault my Pallas fell o young,
But my own Crime for having liv'd too long.
Yet, ince the Gods had detin'd him to dye,
At leat he led the way to Victory:
Firt for his Friends he won the fatal Shore,
And ent whole Herds of laughter'd Foes before:
A Death too great, too glorious to deplore.
Nor will I add new Honours to thy Grave;
Content with thoe the Trojan Heroe gave.
That Funeral Pomp thy Phrygian Friends deign'd;
In which the Tucan Chiefs, and Army join'd:
Great Spoils, and Trophees gain'd by thee, they bear:
Then let thy own Atchievments be thy hare.
Even thou, O Turnus, hadt a Trophy tood,
Whoe mighty Trunk had better grac'd the Wood,
If Pallas had arriv'd, with equal length
Of Years, to match thy Bulk with equal Strength.
But why, unhappy Man, dot thou detain
Thee Troops, to view the Tears thou hedt in vain!
Go, Friends, this Meage to your Lord relate;
Tell him, that if I bear my bitter Fate,
And after Pallas Death, live ling'ring on,
'Tis to behold his Vengeance for my Son.
I tay for Turnus; whoe devoted Head
Is owing to the living and the dead:
My Son and I expect it from his Hand;
'Tis all that he can give, or we demand.
Joy is no more: But I would gladly go,
To greet my Pallas with uch News below.
The Morn had now dipell'd the Shades of Night;
Retoring Toils, when he retor'd the Light:
The Trojan King, and Tucan Chief, command
To raie the Piles, along the winding Strand:
Their Friends convey the dead to Fun'ral Fires;
Black mould'ring Smoke from the green Wood expires;
The Light of Heav'n is choak'd, and the new Day retires.
Then thrice around the kindled Piles they go:
(For ancient Cutom had ordain'd it o)
Thrice Hore and Foot about the Fires are led,
And thrice with loud Laments they hail the dead.

figure.p: To ye Honble John Noel Esq 2d Son to ye Rt Honble: Baptist late Ld Viscount Campden Baron of Ridlington & Ilmington
figure.head: AE. 11. l. 290.

lg.l: Tears trickling down their Breats bedew the Ground;
And Drums and Trumpets mix their mournful Sound.
Amid the Blaze, their pious Brethren throw
The Spoils, in Battel taken from the Foe:
Helms, Bitts embos'd, and Swords of hining Steel;
One cats a Target, one a Chariot Wheel:
Some to their Fellows their own Arms retore;
The Fauchions which in luckles Fight they bore:
Their Bucklers pierc'd, their Darts betow'd in vain,
And hiver'd Lances gather'd from the Plain.
Whole Herds of offer'd Bulls about the Fire,
And britled Boars, and wooly Sheep expire.
Around the Piles a careful Troop attends,
To watch the wating Flames, and weep their burning Friends.
Ling'ring along the Shore, 'till dewy Night,
New decks the Face of Heav'n with tarry Light.
The conquer'd Latians, with like Pious Care,
Piles without number for their Dead prepare;
Part, in the Places where they fell, are laid;
And part are to the neighb'ring Fields convey'd.
The Corps of Kings, and Captains of Renown,
Born off in State, are bury'd in the Town:
The ret, unhonour'd, and without a Name,
Are cat a common heap to feed the Flame.
Trojans and Latians vie with like deires:
To make the Field of Battel hine with Fires:
And the promicuous Blaze to Heav'n apires.
Now had the Morning thrice renew'd the Light,
And thrice dipell'd the Shadows of the Night;
When thoe who round the wated Fires remain,
Perform the lat ad Office to the lain:
They rake the yet warm Ahes, from below;
Thee, and the Bones unburn'd, in Earth betow:
Thee Relicks with their Country Rites they grace;
And raie a mount of Turf to mark the place.
But in the Palace of the King, appears
A Scene more olemn, and a Pomp of Tears.
Maids, Matrons, Widows, mix their common Moans:
Orphans their Sires, and Sires lament their Sons.
All in that univeral Sorrow hare,
And cure the Caue of this unhappy War.
A broken League, a Bride unjutly ought,
A Crown uurp'd, which with their Blood is bought!
Thee are the Crimes, with which they load the Name
Of Turnus, and on him alone exclaim.
Let him, who lords it o're th' Auonian Land,
Engage the Trojan Heroe hand to hand:
His is the Gain, our Lot is but to erve:
'Tis jut, the way he eeks, he houd deerve.
This Drances aggravates; and adds, with pight,
His Foe expects, and dares him to the Fight.
Nor Turnus wants a Party to upport
His Caue and Credit, in the Latian Court.
His former Acts ecure his preent Fame;
And the Queen hades him with her mighty Name.
While thus their factious Minds with Fury burn;
The Legats from th' Aetolian Prince return:
Sad News they bring, that after all the Cot,
And Care employ'd, their Embay is lot:
That Diomede refus'd his Aid in War;
Unmov'd with Preents, and as deaf to Pray'r.
Some new Alliance mut elwhere be ought;
Or Peace with Troy on hard Conditions bought.

l.U: unk in Sorrow, finds too late,

lg.l: A Foreign Son is pointed out by Fate:
And till Aeneas hall Lavinia wed,
The wrath of Heav'n is hov'ring o're his Head.

q.l: Rem nulli obcuram notrae nec vocis egentem
Conulis Ô bone Rex Cuncti e cire fatentur
Quid fortuna ferat populi ed dicere musant
Det libertatem fande flatusque remittat
Cujus ob aupicum infautum moreque initros
Dicam equidem licet arma mihi mortemque minetur
Lumina tot cecidise ducum totamque videmus
Conedise urbem luctu

figure.p: To ye most Honble. Johns Marquis of Normanby Earle of Mulgrave & Kt. of ye mot noble Order of ye Garter
figure.head: AE. 11. l. 365

lg.l: The Gods, he aw, epous'd the juter ide,
When late their Titles in the Field were try'd:
Witnes the freh Laments, and Fun'ral Tears undry'd.
Thus, full of anxious Thought, he ummons all
The Latian Senate to the Council Hall:
The Princes come, commanded by their Head,
And crowd the Paths that to the Palace lead.
Supream in Pow'r, and reverenc'd for his Years,
He takes the Throne, and in the midt appears:
Majetically ad, he its in State,
And bids his Envoys their Succes relate.
When Venulus began, the murmuring Sound
Was huh'd, and acred Silence reign'd around.
We have, aid he, perform'd your high Command;
And pas'd with Peril a long Tract of Land:
We reach'd the Place deir'd, with Wonder fill'd,
The Grecian Tents, and riing Tow'rs beheld.
Great Diomede has compas'd round with Walls
The City, which Argyripa he calls;
From his own Argos nam'd: We touch'd, with Joy,
The Royal Hand that raz'd unhappy Troy.
When introduc'd, our Preents firt we bring,
Then crave an intant Audience from the King:
His Leave obtain'd, our Native Soil we name;
And tell th' important Caue for which we came.
Attentively he heard us, while we poke;
Then, with oft Accents, and a pleaing Look,
Made this return. Auonian Race, of old
Renown'd for Peace, and for an Age of Gold,
What Madnes has your alter'd Minds poes'd,
To change for War hereditary Ret?
Sollicite Arms unknown, and tempt the Sword,
(A needles Ill your Ancetors abhorr'd?)
We; (for my elf I peak, and all the Name
Of Grecians, who to Troy's Detruction came;)
Omitting thoe who were in Battel lain,
Or born by rowling Simois to the Main:
Not one but uffer'd, and too dearly bought
The Prize of Honour which in Arms he ought.
Some doom'd to Death, and ome in Exile driv'n,
Out-cats, abandon'd by the Care of Heav'n:
So worn, o wretched, o depis'd a Crew,
As ev'n old Priam might with Pity view.
Witnes the Veels by Minerva tos'd
In Storms, the vengeful Capharaean Coat;
Th' Eubaean Rocks! The Prince, whoe Brother led
Our Armies to revenge his injur'd Bed,
In Egypt lot; Ulyes, with his Men,
Have een Charybdis, and the Cyclops Den:
Why hou'd I name Idomeneus, in vain
Retor'd to Scepters, and expell'd again?
Or young Achilles by his Rival lain?
Ev'n he, the King of Men, the foremot Name
Of all the Greeks, and mot renown'd by Fame,
The proud Revenger of another's Wife,
Yet by his own Adult'res lot his Life:
Fell at his Threhold, and the Spoils of Troy,
The foul Polluters of his Bed enjoy.
The Gods have envy'd me the weets of Life,
My much lov'd Country, and my more lov'd Wife:
Banih'd from both, I mourn; while in the Sky
Transform'd to Birds, my lot Companions fly:
Hov'ring about the Coats they make their Moan;
And cuff the Cliffs with Pinions not their own.
What qualid Spectres, in the dead of Night,
Break my hort Sleep, and skim before my ight!
I might have promis'd to my elf thoe Harms,
Mad as I was, when I with Mortal Arms
Preum'd againt Immortal Pow'rs to move;
And violate with Wounds the Queen of Love.
Such Arms, this Hand hall never more employ;
No Hate remains with me to ruin'd Troy.
I war not with its Dut; nor am I glad
To think of pat Events, or good or bad.
Your Preents I return: What e're you bring
To buy my Friendhip, end the Trojan King.
We met in fight, I know him to my Cot;
With what a whirling force his Lance he tos'd:
Heav'ns what a pring was in his Arm, to throw:
How high he held his Shield, and roe at ev'ry blow!
Had Troy produc'd two more, his Match in Might,
They would have chang'd the Fortune of the Fight:
Th' Invaion of the Greeks had been return'd:
Our Empire wated, and our Cities burn'd.
The long Defence the Trojan People made,
The War protracted, and the Siege delay'd,
Were due to Hector's and this Heroe's hand:
Both brave alike, and equal in Command;
Aeneas, not inferior in the Field,
In pious reverence to the Gods, excell'd.
Make peace, ye Latians, and avoid with Care
Th' impending Dangers of a fatal War.
He aid no more; but with this cold Excue,
Refus'd th' Alliance, and advis'd a Truce.
Thus Venulus concluded his Report.
A Jarring Murmur fill'd the factious Court:
As when a Torrent rowls with rapid force,
And dahes o're the Stones that top the Coure;
The Flood, contrain'd within a canty pace,
Roars horrible along th' uneaie race:
White foam in gath'ring Eddies floats around:
The rocky Shores rebellow to the ound.
The Murmur ceas'd: Then from his lofty Throne
The King invok'd the Gods, and thus begun.
I wih, ye Latins, what we now debate
Had been reolv'd before it was too late:
Much better had it been for you and me,
Unforc'd by this our lat Neceity,
To have been earlier wie; than now to call
A Council, when the Foe urrounds the Wall.
O Citizens! we wage unequal War,
With men, not only Heav'n's peculiar Care,
But Heav'n's own Race: Unconquer'd in the Field,
Or Conquer'd, yet unknowing how to yield.
What Hopes you had in Diomede, lay down:
Our Hopes mut center on our elves alone.
Yet thoe how feeble, and, indeed, how vain,
You ee too well; nor need my Words explain.
Vanquih'd without reource; laid flat by Fate,
Factions within, a Foe without the Gate;
Not but I grant, that all perform'd their parts,
With manly Force, and with undaunted Hearts:
With our united Strength the War we wag'd;
With equal Numbers, equal Arms engag'd:
You ee th' Event.—Now hear what I propoe,
To ave our Friends, and atisfie our Foes:
A Tract of Land the Latins have poes'd
Along the Tyber, tretching to the Wet,
Which now Rutulians and Auruncans till:
And their mix'd Cattle graze the fruitful Hill;
Thoe Mountains fill'd with Firs, that lower Land,
If you conent, the Trojan hall Command.
Call'd into part of what is ours; and there,
On terms agreed, the common Country hare.
There let 'em build, and ettle if they pleae;
Unles they chue once more to cros the Seas,
In earch of Seats remote from Italy;
And from unwelcome Inmates et us free.
Then twice ten Gallies let us build with Speed,
Or twice as many more, if more they need;
Materials are at hand: A well-grown Wood
Runs equal with the Margin of the Flood:
Let them the Number, and the Form aign;
The Care and Cot of all the Stores be mine.
To treat the Peace, a hundred Senators
Shall be commiion'd hence with ample Pow'rs;
With Olive crown'd: The Preents they hall bear,
A Purple Robe, a Royal Iv'ry Chair;
And all the marks of Sway that Latian Monarchs wear;
And Sums of Gold. Among your elves debate
This great Affair, and ave the inking State.
Then Drances took the word; who grudg'd, long ince,
The riing Glories of the Daunian Prince.
Factious and rich, bold at the Council Board,
But cautious in the Field, he hun'd the Sword;
A clos Caballer, and Tongue-valiant Lord.
Noble his Mother was, and near the Throne,
But what his Father's Parentage, unknown.
He roe, and took th' Advantage of the Times,
To load young Turnus with invidious Crimes.
Such Truths, O King, aid he, your Words contain,
As trike the Sence, and all Replies are vain.
Nor are your Loyal Subjects now to eek
What common Needs require; but fear to peak.
Let him give leave of Speech, that haughty Man,
Whoe Pride this unaupicious War began:
For whoe Ambition (let me dare to ay,
Fear et apart, tho' Death is in my Way)
The Plains of Latium run with Blood arround;
So many Valiant Heros bite the Ground:
Dejected Grief in ev'ry Face appears;
A Town in Mourning, and a Land in Tears.
While he th' undoubted Author of our Harms,
The Man who menaces the Gods with Arms,
Yet, after all his Boats, forook the Fight,
And ought his afety in ignoble Flight.
Now, bet of Kings, ince you propoe to end
Such bounteous Preents to your Trojan Friend;
Add yet a greater at our joint Requet,
One which he values more than all the ret;
Give him the fair Lavinia for his Bride:
With that Alliance let the League be ty'd:
And for the bleeding Land a lating Peace provide.
Let Inolence no longer awe the Throne,
But with a Father's Right betow your own.
For this Maligner of the general Good,
If till we fear his Force, he mut be woo'd:
His haughty Godhead we with Pray'rs implore,
Your Scepter to releae, and our jut Rights retore.
O cured Caue of all our Ills, mut we
Wage Wars unjut, and fall in Fight for thee!
What right hat thou to rule the Latian State,
And end us out to meet our certain Fate?
'Tis a detructive War; from Turnus Hand
Our Peace and publick afety we demand.
Let the fair Bride to the brave Chief remain;
If not, the Peace without the Pledge is vain.
Turnus, I know you think me not your Friend,
Nor will I much with your Belief contend:
I beg your Greatnes not to give the Law
In others Realms, but, beaten, to withdraw.
Pity your own, or pity our Etate;
Nor twit our Fortunes with your inking Fate.
Your Interet is the War hou'd never ceae;
But we have felt enough, to wih the Peace:
A Land exhauted to the lat remains,
Depopulated Towns, and driven Plains.
Yet, if deire of Fame, and thirt of Pow'r,
A Beauteous Princes, with a Crown in Dow'r,
So fire your Mind, in Arms aert your Right;
And meet your Foe, who dares you to the Fight.
Mankind, it eems, is made for you alone;
We, but the Slaves who mount you to the Throne:
A bae ignoble Crowd, without a Name,
Unwept, unworthy of the Fun'ral Flame:
By Duty bound to forfeit each his Life,
That Turnus may poes a Royal Wife.
Permit not, Mighty Man, o mean a Crew
Shou'd hare uch Triumphs; and detain from you
The Pot of Honour, your unquetion'd Due:
Rather alone your matchles Force employ;
To merit, what alone you mut enjoy.
Thee Words, o full of Malice, mix'd with Art,
Inflam'd with Rage the youthful Hero's Heart.
Then groaning from the bottom of his Breat,
He heav'd for Wind, and thus his Wrath expres'd.
You, Drances, never want a Stream of Words,
Then, when the Publick Need requires our Swords.
Firt in the Council-hall to teer the State;
And ever foremot at a Tongue debate.
While our trong Walls ecure us from the Foe,
E're yet with Blood our Ditches overflow:
But let the potent Orator declaim,
And with the brand of Coward blot my Name;
Free Leave is giv'n him, when his fatal Hand
Has cover'd with more Corps the anguine Strand;
And high as mine his tow'ring Trophees tand.
If any Doubt remains who dares the mot,
Let us decide it at the Trojans cot:
And iue both abret, where Honour calls;
Foes are not far to eek without the Walls.
Unles his noiie Tongue can only fight;
And Feet were giv'n him but to peed his Flight.
I beaten from the Field? I forc'd away?
Who, but o known a Datard, dares to ay?
Had he but ev'n beheld the Fight, his Eyes
Had witnes'd for me what his Tongue denies:
What heaps of Trojans by this Hand were lain,
And how the bloody Tyber well'd the Main.
All aw, but he, th' Arcadian Troops retire,
In catter'd Squadrons, and their Prince expire.
The Gyant Brothers, in their Camp, have found
I was not forc'd with eae to quit my Ground.
Not uch the Trojans try'd me, when inclos'd,
I ingly their united Arms oppos'd:
Firt forc'd an Entrance thro' their thick Array;
Then, glutted with their Slaughter, freed my Way.
'Tis a detructive War? So let it be,
But to the Phrygian Pirate, and to thee.
Mean time proceed to fill the People's Ears
With fale Reports, their Minds with panick Fears:
Extol the Strength of a twice conquer'd Race,
Our Foes encourage, and our Friends debae.
Believe thy Fables, and the Trojan Town
Triumphant tands, the Grecians are o'rethrown:
Suppliant at Hector's Feet Achilles lyes;
And Diomede from fierce Aeneas flies.
Say rapid Aufidus with awful Dread
Runs backward from the Sea, and hides his Head,
When the great Trojan on his Bank appears:
For that's as true as thy diembl'd Fears
Of my Revenge: Dimis that Vanity,
Thou, Drances, art below a Death from me.
Let that vile Soul in that vile Body ret;
The Lodging is well worthy of the Guet.
Now, Royal Father, to the preent tate
Of our Affairs, and of this high Debate;
If in your Arms thus early you diffide,
And think your Fortune is already try'd;
If one Defeat has brought us down o low;
As never more in Fields to meet the Foe;
Then I conclude for Peace: 'Tis time to treat,
And lye like Vaals at the Victor's Feet.
But oh, if any ancient Blood remains,
One drop of all our Father's in our Veins;
That Man would I prefer before the ret,
Who dar'd his Death with an undaunted Breat;
Who comely fell, by no dihonet Wound,
To hun that Sight; and dying gnaw'd the Ground.
But if we till have freh Recruits in tore,
If our Confederates can afford us more;
If the contended Field we bravely fought;
And not a bloodles Victory was bought:
Their Loes equall'd ours, and for their lain,
With equal Fires they fill'd the hining Plain;
Why thus unforc'd hou'd we o tamely yield;
And e're the Trumpet ounds, reign the Field?
Good unexpected, Evils unforeeen,
Appear by Turns, as Fortune hifts the Scene:
Some, rais'd aloft, come tumbling down amain;
Then fall o hard, they bound and rie again.
If Diomede refue his Aid to lend,
The great Meapus yet remains our Friend:
Tolumnius, who foretels Events, is ours;
Th' Italian Chiefs, and Princes, joyn their Pow'rs:
Nor leat in Number, nor in Name the lat,
Your own brave Subjects have your Caue embrac'd.
Above the ret, the Volcian Amazon
Contains an Army in her elf alone:
And heads a Squadron, terrible to ight,
With glitt'ring Shields, in Brazen Armour bright.
Yet if the Foe a ingle Fight demand,
And I alone the Publick Peace withtand;
If you conent, he hall not be refus'd,
Nor find a Hand to Victory unus'd.
This new Achilles, let him take the Field,
With fated Armour, and Vulcanian Shield;
For you, my Royal Father, and my Fame,
I, Turnus, not the leat of all my Name,
Devote my Soul. He calls me hand to hand,
And I alone will anwer his Demand.

l.U: hall ret ecure, and neither hare

lg.l: The Danger, nor divide the Prize of War.
While they debate; nor thee nor thoe will yield;
Aeneas draws his Forces to the Field:
And moves his Camp. The Scouts, with flying Speed
Return, and thro' the frighted City pread
Th' unpleaing News, the Trojans are decry'd,
In Battel marching by the River ide;
And bending to the Town. They take th' Allarm,
Some tremble, ome are bold, all in Confuion arm.
Th' impetuous Youth pres forward to the Field;
They clah the Sword, and clatter on the Shield:
The fearful Matrons raie a creaming Cry;
Old feeble Men with fainter Groans reply:
A jarring Sound reults, and mingles in the Sky.
Like that of Swans remurm'ring to the Floods;
Or Birds of diff'ring kinds in hollow Woods.
Turnus th' occaion takes, and cries aloud,
Talk on, ye quaint Haranguers of the Crowd:
Declaim in praie of Peace, when Danger calls;
And the fierce Foes in Arms approach the Walls.
He aid, and turning hort, with peedy Pace,
Cats back a cornful Glance, and quits the Place.
Thou, Voluus, the Volcian Troops command
To mount; and lead thy elf our Ardean Band.
Meapus, and Catillus, pot your Force
Along the Fields, to charge the Trojan Hore.
Some guard the Paes, others man the Wall;
Drawn up in Arms, the ret attend my Call.
They warm from ev'ry Quarter of the Town;
And with diorder'd hate the Rampires crown.
Good old Latinus, when he aw, too late,
The gath'ring Storm, jut breaking on the State,
Dimis'd the Council, 'till a fitter time.
And own'd his eaie Temper as his Crime:
Who, forc'd againt his reaon, had comply'd
To break the Treaty for the promis'd Bride.
Some help to ink new Trenches, others aid
To ram the Stones, or raie the Paliade.
Hoare Trumpets ound th' Alarm: Around the Walls
Runs a ditracted Crew, whom their lat Labour calls.
A ad Proceion in the Streets is een,
Of Matrons that attend the Mother Queen:
High in her Chair he its, and at her ide,
With downcat Eyes appears the fatal Bride.
They mount the Cliff, where Pallas's Temple tands;
Pray'rs in their Mouths, and Preents in their Hands:
With Ceners, firt they fume the acred Shrine;
Then in this common Supplication joyn.
O Patrones of Arms, unpotted Maid,
Propitious hear, and lend thy Latins Aid:
Break hort the Pirat's Lance; pronounce his Fate,
And lay the Phrygian low before the Gate.
Now Turnus arms for Fight: His Back and Breat,
Well temper'd Steel, and caly Bras invet:
The Cuihes, which his brawny Thighs infold,
Are mingled Metal damask'd o're with Gold.
His faithful Fauchion its upon his ide;
Nor Caque, nor Cret, his manly Features hide:
But bare to view, amid urrounding Friends,
With Godlike Grace, he from the Tow'r decends.
Exulting in his Strength, he eems to dare
His abent Rival, and to promie War.
Freed from his Keepers, thus with broken Reins,
The wanton Courer prances o're the Plains:
Or in the Pride of Youth o'releaps the Mounds;
And nuffs the Females in forbidden Grounds.
Or eeks his wat'ring in the well known Flood,
To quench his Thirt, and cool his fiery Blood:
He wims luxuriant, in the liquid Plain,
And o're his Shoulder flows his waving Mane:
He neighs, he norts, he bears his Head on high;
Before his ample Chet the frothy Waters fly.
Soon as the Prince appears without the Gate,
The Volcians, with their Virgin Leader, wait
His lat Commands. Then with a graceful Meen,
Lights from her lofty Steed, the Warrior Queen:
Her Squadron imitates, and each decends;
Whoe common Sute Camilla thus commends.
If Sence of Honour, if a Soul ecure
Of inborn Worth, that can all Tets endure,
Can promie ought; or on it elf rely,
Greatly to dare, to conquer or to dye:
Then, I alone, utain'd by thee, will meet
The Tyrrhene Troops, and promie their Defeat.
Ours be the Danger, ours the ole Renown;
You, Gen'ral, tay behind, and guard the Town.
Turnus a while tood mute, with glad Surprize,
And on the fierce Virago fix'd his Eyes:
Then thus return'd: O Grace of Italy,
With what becoming Thanks can I reply!
Not only Words lye lab'ring in my Breat;
But Thought it elf is by thy Praie oppret.
Yet rob me not of all, but let me join
My Toils, my Hazard, and my Fame, with thine.
The Trojan, (not in Stratagem unskill'd,)
Sends his light Foot before to cour the Field:
Himelf, thro' teep Acents, and thorny Brakes,
A larger Compas to the City takes.
This news my Scouts confirm: And I prepare
To foil his Cunning, and his Force to dare.
With choen Foot his Paage to forelay;
And place an Ambuh in the winding way.
Thou, with thy Volcians, face the Tucan Hore:
The brave Meapus hall thy Troops inforce;
With thoe of Tibur; and the Latian Band:
Subjected all to thy Supream Command.
This aid, he warns Meapus to the War:
Then ev'ry Chief exhorts, with equal Care.
All thus encourag'd, his own Troops he joins,
And hates to proecute his deep Deigns.
Inclos'd with Hills, a winding Valley lies,
By Nature form'd for Fraud, and fitted for Surprize:
A narrow Track, by Human Steps untrode,
Leads, thro' perplexing Thorns, to this obcure abode.
High o're the Vale a teepy Mountain tands;
Whence the urveying Sight the neather Ground commands.
The top is level: an offenive Seat
Of War; and from the War a afe Retreat.
For, on the right, and left, is room to pres
The Foes at hand, or from afar ditres:
To drive 'em headlong downward; and to pour
On their decending backs, a tony how'r.
Thither young Turnus took the well known way;
Poes'd the Pas, and in blind Ambuh lay.
Mean time, Latonian Phoebe from the Skies,
Beheld th' approaching War with hateful Eies.
And call'd the light-foot Opis, to her aid,
Her mot belov'd, and ever truty Maid.
Then with a igh began: Camilla goes
To meet her Death, amidt her Fatal Foes.
The Nymph I lov'd of all my Mortal Train;
Inveted with Diana's Arms, in vain.
Nor is my kindnes for the Virgin, new,
'Twas born with Her, and with her Years it grew:
Her Father Metabus, when forc'd away
From old Privernum, for Tyrannick way;
Snatch'd up, and av'd from his prevailing Foes,
This tender Babe, Companion of his Woes.
Camilla was her Mother; but he drown'd,
One hiing Letter in a ofter ound,
And call'd Camilla. Thro the Woods, he flies;
Wrap'd in his Robe the Royal Infant lies.
His Foes in ight, he mends his weary pace;
With houts and clamours they purue the Chace.
The Banks of Amaene at length he gains;
The raging Flood his farther flight retrains:
Rais'd o're the Borders with unuual Rains.
Prepar'd to Plunge into the Stream, He fears:
Not for himelf, but for the Charge he bears.
Anxious he tops a while; and thinks in hate;
Then, dep'rate in Ditres, reolves at lat.
A knotty Lance of well-boil'd Oak he bore;
The middle part with Cork he cover'd o're:
He clos'd the Child within the hollow Space;
With Twigs of bending Oier bound the Cae.
Then pois'd the Spear, heavy with Human Weight;
And thus invok'd my Favour for the Freight.
Accept, great Goddes of the Woods, he aid,
Sent by her Sire, this dedicated Maid:
Thro' Air he flies a Suppliant to thy Shrine;
And the firt Weapons that he knows, are thine.
He aid; and with full Force the Spear he threw:
Above the ounding Waves Camilla flew.
Then, pres'd by Foes, he temm'd the tormy Tyde;
And gain'd, by tres of Arms, the farther Side.
His faten'd Spear he pull'd from out the Ground;
And, Victor of his Vows, his Infant Nymph unbound.
Nor after that, in Towns which Walls incloe,
Wou'd trut his hunted Life amidt his Foes.
But rough, in open Air he choe to lye:
Earth was his Couch, his Cov'ring was the Sky.
On Hills unhorn, or in a deart Den,
He hunn'd the dire Society of Men.
A Shepherd's olitary Life he led:
His Daughter with the Milk of Mares he fed;
The Dugs of Bears, and ev'ry Salvage Beat,
He drew, and thro' her Lips the Liquor pres'd.
The little Amazon cou'd carcely go,
He loads her with a Quiver and a Bow:
And, that he might her tagg'ring Steps command,
He with a lender Jav'lin fills her Hand:
Her flowing Hair no golden Fillet bound;
Nor wept her trayling Robe the duty Ground.
Intead of thee, a Tyger's Hide o'repread
Her Back and Shoulders, faten'd to her Head.
The flying Dart he firt attempts to fling;
And round her tender Temples tos'd the Sling:
Then, as her Strength with Years increas'd, began
To pierce aloft in Air the oaring Swan:
And from the Clouds to fetch the Heron and the Crane.
The TucanMatrons with each other vy'd,
To bles their Rival Sons with uch a Bride:
But he didains their Love; to hare with me
The Silvan Shades, and vow'd Virginity.
And, oh! I wih, contented with my Cares
Of Salvage Spoils, he had not ought the Wars:
Then had he been of my Coeletial Train;
And hun'd the Fate that dooms her to be lain.
But, ince oppoing Heav'n's Decree, he goes
To find her Death among forbidden Foes;
Hate with thee Arms, and take thy teepy flight,
Where, with the Gods avere, the Latins fight:
This Bow to thee, this Quiver, I bequeath,
This choen Arrow to revenge her Death.
By what e're Hand Camilla hall be lain,
Or of the Trojan, or Italian Train,
Let him not pas unpunih'd from the Plain.
Then, in a hollow Cloud, my elf will Aid,
To bear the breathles Body of my Maid:
Unpoil'd hall be her Arms, and unprofan'd
Her holy Limbs with any Human Hand:
And in a Marble Tomb laid in her Native Land.
She aid: The faithful Nymph decends from high
With rapid flight, and cuts the ounding Sky;
Black Clouds and tormy Winds around her Body fly.
By this, the Trojan and the Tucan Hore,
Drawn up in Squadrons, with united Force,
Approach the Walls; the prightly Courers bound;
Pres forward on their Bitts, and hift their Ground:
Shields, Arms, and Spears, flah horrible from far;
And the Fields glitter with a waving War.
Oppos'd to thee, come on with furious Force,
Meapus, Coras, and the Latian Hore;
Thee in the Body plac'd; on either hand
Sutain'd, and clos'd by fair Camilla's Band.
Advancing in a Line, they couch their Spears;
And les and les the middle Space appears.
Thick Smoak obcures the Field: And carce are een
The neighing Courers, and the houting Men.
In ditance of their Darts they top their Coure;
Then Man to Man they ruh, and Hore to Hore.
The face of Heav'n their flying Jav'lins hide;
And Deaths uneen are dealt on either ide.
Tyrrhenus, and Aconteus, void of Fear,
By metled Courers born in full Carreer,
Meet firt oppos'd: and, with a mighty Shock,
Their Hores Heads againt each other knock.
Far from his Steed is fierce Aconteus cat;
As with an Engin's force, or Lightning's blat:
He rowls along in Blood, and breathes his lat.
The Latin Squadrons take a udden fright;
And ling their Shields behind, to ave their Backs in flight.
Spurring at peed to their own Walls they drew;
Cloe in the rear the Tucan Troops purue:
And urge their flight. Aylas leads the Chae;
'Till eiz'd with Shame they wheel about and face:
Receive their Foes, and raie a threat'ning Cry:
The Tucans take their turn to fear and fly.
So welling Surges, with a thund'ring Roar,
Driv'n on each others Backs, inult the Shoar;
Bound o're the Rocks, incroach upon the Land;
And far upon the Beach eject the Sand.
Then backward with a Swing, they take their Way;
Repuls'd from upper Ground, and eek their Mother Sea:
With equal hurry quit th' invaded Shore;
And wallow back the Sand, and Stones they pew'd before.
Twice were the Tucans Maters of the Field,
Twice by the Latins, in their turn repell'd.
Aham'd at length, to the third Charge they ran
Both Hoats reolv'd, and mingled Man to Man:
Now dying Groans are heard, the Fields are trow'd
With falling Bodies, and are drunk with Blood:
Arms, Hores, Men, on heaps together lye:
Confus'd the Fight, and more confus'd the Cry.
Orilochus, who durt not pres too near
Strong Remulus, at ditance drove his Spear;
And tuck the Steel beneath his Hores Ear:
The fiery Steed, impatient of the Wound,
Curvets, and pringing upward with a Bound,
His helples Lord cat backward on the Ground.
Catillus pierc'd Iolas firt; then drew
His reeking Lance, and at Herminius threw:
The mighty Champion of the Tucan Crew.
His Neck and Throat unarm'd, his Head was bare,
But haded with a length of yellow Hair:
Secure, he fought, expos'd on ev'ry part,
A pacious mark for Swords, and for the Dart:
Acros the Shoulders came the flying Wound;
Transfix'd, he fell, and doubled to the Ground.
The Sands with treaming Blood are anguine dy'd;
And Death with Honour, ought on either ide.
Reitles through the War, Camilla rode;
In Danger unappall'd, and pleas'd with Blood.
One ide was bare for her exerted Bret;
One Shoulder with her painted Quiver pres'd.
Now from afar her Fatal Jav'lins play;
Now with her Axe's edge he hews her Way:
Diana's Arms upon her Shoulder found;
And when, too cloely pres'd, he quits the Ground;
From her bent Bow he ends a backward Wound.
Her Maids, in Martial Pomp, on either ide,
Larina, Tulla, fierce Tarpeia ride;
Italians all: in Peace, their Queen's delight:
In War the bold Companions of the Fight.
So march'd the Thracian Amazons of old,
When Thermodon with bloody Billows rowl'd:
Such Troops as thee in hining Arms were een;
When Theeus met in Fight their Maiden Queen.
Such to the Field Penthiilea led,
From the fierce Virgin when the Grecians fled:
With uch, return'd Triumphant from the War;
Her Maids with Cries attend the lofty Carr:
They clah with manly force their Moony Shields;
With Female Showts refound the Phrygian Fields.
Who formot, and who lat, Heroick Maid,
On the cold Earth were by thy Courage laid?
Thy Spear, of Mountain Ah, Eumenius firt,
With fury driv'n, from ide to ide tranpierc'd:
A purple Stream came powting from the Wound;
Bath'd in his Blood he lies, and bites the Ground.
Lyris and Pagaus at once he lew;
The former, as the lacken'd Reins he drew,
Of his faint teed: the latter, as he tretch'd
His Arm to prop his Friend, the Jav'lin reach'd.
By the ame Weapon, ent from the ame Hand,
Both fall together, and both purn the Sand.
Amatrus next is added to the lain:
The ret in Rout he follows o're the Plain.
And Chromys, at full Speed her Fury hun.
Of all her deadly Darts, not one he lot;
Each was attended with a Trojan Ghot.
Young Ornithus betrode a Hunter Steed,
Swift for the Chae, and of Apulian Breed:
Him, from afar, he py'd in Arms unknown;
O're his broad Back an Oxes hide was thrown:
His Helm a Wolf, whoe gaping Jaws were pread,
A cov'ring for his Cheeks, and grinn'd around his Head.
He clench'd within his Hand an Iron Prong;
And tow'rd above the ret, conpicuous in the Throng.
Him oon he ingled from the flying Train,
And lew with eae: Then thus inults the lain.
Vain Hunter didt thou think thro' Woods to chae
The Salvage Herd, a vile and trembling Race:
Here ceae thy Vaunts, and own my Victory;
A Woman-Warrior was too trong for thee.
Yet if the Ghots demand the Conqu'ror's Name,
Confeing great Camilla, ave thy Shame.
Then Butes, and Orilochus, he lew:
The bulkiet Bodies of the Trojan Crew.
But Butes Breat to Breat: the Spear decends
Above the Gorget, where his Helmet ends;
And o're the Shield which his left Side defends.
Orilochus and he, their Courers ply;
He eems to follow, and he eems to fly.
But in a narrower Ring he makes the Race;
And then he flies, and he purues the Chae.
Gath'ring at length on her deluded Foe,
She wings her Axe, and ries to the Blow:

figure.p: To the Right Honble William Berkley Baron Berkley of Stratton &ct.
figure.head: AE. 11. l. 1035.

lg.l: Full on the Helm behind, with uch a way
The Weapon falls, the riven Steel gives way:
He groans, he roars, he ues in vain for Grace;
Brains, mingled with his Blood, bemear his Face.
Atonih'd Aunus jut arrives by Chance,
To ee his Fall, nor farther dares advance:
But fixing on the horrid Maid his Eye,
He tares, and hakes, and finds it vain to fly.
Yet like a true Ligurian, born to cheat,
(At leat while Fortune favour'd his Deceit)
Cries out aloud, what Courage have you hown,
Who trut your Courers Strength, and not your own?
Forego the vantage of your Hore, alight,
And then on equal Terms begin the Fight:
It hall be een, weak Woman, what you can,
When Foot to Foot, you combat with a Man.
He aid: She glows with Anger and Didain,
Dimounts with peed to dare him on the Plain;
And leaves her Hore at large among her Train.
With her drawn Sword defies him to the Field;
And marching, lifts aloft her maiden Shield:
The Youth, who thought his Cunning did ucceed,
Reins round his Hore, and urges all his Speed.
Adds the remembrance of the Spur, and hides
