The goring Rowels in his bleeding Sides.
Vain Fool, and Coward, cries the lofty Maid,
Caught in the Train, which thou thy elf hat laid!
On others practie thy Ligurian Arts;
Thin Stratagems, and Tricks of little Hearts
Are lot on me. Nor halt thou afe retire,
With vaunting Lyes to thy fallacious Sire.
At this, o fat her flying Feet he ped,
That oon he train'd beyond his Hore's Head:
Then turning hort, at once he eiz'd the Rein,
And laid the Boater grov'ling on the Plain.
Not with more eae the Falcon from above,
Trues, in middle Air, the trembling Drove:
Then Plumes the Prey, in her trong Pounces bound:
The Feathers foul with Blood come tumbling to the ground.
Now mighty Jove, from his uperior height,
With his broad Eye urveys th' unequal Fight.
He fires the Breat of Tarchon with Didain;
And ends him to redeem th' abandon'd Plain.
Betwixt the broken Ranks the Tucan rides,
And thee encourages, and thoe he chides:
Recalls each Leader, by his Name, from flight;
Renews their Ardour; and retores the Fight.
What Panick Fear has eiz'd your Souls, O hame,
O Brand perpetual of th' Etrurian Name;
Cowards incurable, a Woman's Hand
Drives, breaks, and catters your ignoble Band!
Now cat away the Sword, and quit the Shield:
What ue of Weapons which you dare not wield?
Not thus you fly your Female Foes, by Night,
Nor hun the Feat, when the full Bowls invite:
When to fat Off'rings the glad Augur calls;
And the hrill Horn-pipe ounds to Bacchanals.
Thee are your tudy'd Cares; your lewd Delight;
Swift to debauch; but low to Manly Fight.
Thus having aid, he purs amid the Foes;
Not managing the Life he meant to loe.
The firt he found he eiz'd, with headlong hate,
In his trong Gripe; and clap'd around the Wate:
'Twas Venulus; whom from his Hore he tore,
And, (laid athwart his own,) in Triumph bore.
Loud Shouts enue: The Latins turn their Eyes,
And view th' unuual ight with vat Surprize.
The fiery Tarchon, flying o're the Plains,
Pres'd in his Arms the pond'rous Prey utains:
Then, with his horten'd Spear, explores around
His jointed Arms, to fix a deadly Wound.
Nor les the Captive truggles for his Life;
He writhes his Body to prolong the Strife:
And, fencing for his naked Throat, exerts
His utmot Vigour, and the point averts.
So toops the yellow Eagle from on high,
And bears a peckled Serpent thro' the Sky;
Fat'ning his crooked Tallons on the Prey:
The Pris'ner hies thro' the liquid Way,
Reits the Royal Hawk, and tho' oppret,
She fights in Volumes, and erects her Cret:
Turn'd to her Foe, he tiffens ev'ry Scale;
And hoots her forky Tongue, and whisks her threat'ning Tail.
Againt the Victour all Defence is weak;
Th' imperial Bird till plies her with his Beak:
He tears her Bowels, and her Breat he gores;
Then claps his Pinions, and ecurely oars.
Thus, thro' the midt of circling Enemies,
Strong Tarchon natch'd and bore away his Prize:
The Tyrrhene Troops, that hrunk before, now pres
The Latins, and preume the like Succes.
Then, Aruns doom'd to Death, his Arts aay'd
To murther, unepy'd, the Volcian Maid,
This way, and that his winding Coure he bends;
And whereoe're he turns, her Steps attends.
When he retires victorious from the Chae,
He wheels about with Care, and hifts his place:
When ruhing on, he eeks her Foes in Fight,
He keeps aloof, but keeps her till in ight:
He threats, and trembles, trying ev'ry Way
Uneen to kill, and afely to betray.
Chloreus, the Priet of Cybele, from far,
Glitt'ring in Phrygian Arms amidt the War,
Was by the Virgin view'd: The Steed he pres'd
Was proud with Trappings; and his brawny Chet
With Scales of guilded Bras was cover'd o're:
A Robe of Tyrian Dye the Rider wore.
With deadly Wounds he gaul'd the ditant Eoe;
Gnoian his Shafts, and Lycian was his Bow:
A Golden Helm his Front, and head urrounds;
A guilded Quiver from his Shoulder ounds.
Gold, weav'd with Linen, on his Thighs he wore:
With Flowers of Needlework ditinguih'd o're:
With Golden Buckles bound, and gather'd up before.
Him, the fierce Maid beheld with ardent Eyes;
Fond and Ambitious of o Rich a Prize:
Or that the Temple might his Trophees hold,
Or ele to hine her elf in Trojan Gold:
Blind in her hate, he chaes him alone,
And eeks his Life, regardles of her own.
This lucky Moment the lye Traytor choe:
Then, tarting from his Ambuh up he roe,
And threw, but firt to Heav'n addres'd his Vows.
O Patron of Soractes high Abodes,
Phoebus the Ruling Pow'r among the Gods;
Whom firt we erve, whole Woods of unctuous Pine
Are fell'd for thee, and to thy Glory hine;
By thee protected, with our naked Soles,
Thro' Flames uning'd we march, and tread the kindled Coals:
Give me, propitious Pow'r, to wah away
The Stains of this dihonourable Day:
Nor Spoils, nor Triumph, from the Fact I claim;
But with my future Actions trut my Fame.
Let me, by tealth; this Female Plague o'recome;
And from the Field, return inglorious home.

figure.p: To Arthur Manwaringe of Ightfield in the County of Salop Esqr:
figure.head: AE. 11. l. 1150.

lg.l: Apollo heard, and granting half his Pray'r,
Shuffled in Winds the ret, and tos'd in empty Air.
He gives the Death deir'd; his afe return,
By Southern Tempets to the Seas is born.
Now, when the Jav'lin whizz'd along the Skies,
Both Armies on Camilla turn'd their Eyes,
Directed by the Sound: Of either Hot,
Th' unhappy Virgin, tho' concern'd the mot,
Was only deaf; o greedy was he bent
On Golden Spoils, and on her Prey intent:
Till in her Pap the winged Weapon tood
Infix'd; and deeply drunk the purple Blood.
Her ad Attendants haten to utain
Their dying Lady drooping on the Plain.
Far from their ight the trembling Aruns flies,
With beating Heart, and Fear confus'd with Joys;
Nor dares he farther to purue his Blow;
Or ev'n to bear the ight of his expiring Foe.
As when the Wolf has torn a Bullocks Hide,
At unawares, or ranch'd the Shepherd's Side:
Concious of his audacious deed, he flies,
And claps his quiv'ring Tail between his Thighs:
So, peeding once, the Wretch no more attends;
But purring forward herds among his Friends.
She wrench'd the Jav'lin with her dying Hands;
But wedg'd within her Breat the Weapon tands:
The Wood he draws, the teely Point remains,
She taggers in her Seat, with agonizing Pains:
A gath'ring Mit o'reclouds her chearful Eyes;
And from her Cheeks the roie Colour flies.
Then, turns to her, whom, of her Female Train,
She truted mot, and thus he peaks with Pain.
Acca, 'tis pat! He wims before my ight,
Inexorable Death; and claims his right.
Bear my lat Words to Turnus, fly with peed,
And bid him timely to my Charge ucceed:
Repel the Trojans, and the Town relieve:
Farewel; and in this Kis my parting Breath receive.
She aid; and liding, unk upon the Plain;
Dying, her open'd Hand forakes the Rein;
Short, and more hort, he pants: By low degrees
Her Mind the Paage from her Body frees.
She drops her Sword, he nods her plumy Cret;
Her drooping Head declining on her Breat:
In the lat Sigh her trugling Soul expires;
And murm'ring with Didain, to Stygian Sounds retires.
A Shout, that truck the Golden Stars, enu'd:
Depair and Rage, the languih'd Fight renew'd.
The Trojan Troops, and Tucans in a Line,
Advance to charge; the mix'd Arcadians join.
But Cynthia's Maid, high eated, from afar
Surveys the Field, and fortune of the War:
Unmov'd a while, 'till protrate on the Plain,
Welt'ring in Blood, he ees Camilla lain;
And round her Corps, of Friends and Foes a fighting Train.
Then, from the bottom of her Breat, he drew
A mournful Sigh, and thee ad Words enue:
Too dear a Fine, ah much lamented Maid,
For warring with the Trojans, thou hat paid!
Nor ought avail'd, in this unhappy Strife,
Diana's acred Arms, to ave thy Life.
Yet unreveng'd thy Goddes will not leave
Her Vot'rys Death, nor with vain Sorrow grieve.
Branded the Wretch, and be his Name abhorr'd;
But after Ages hall thy Praie record.
Th' inglorious Coward oon hall pres the Plain;
Thus vows thy Queen, and thus the Fates ordain.
High o're the Field, there tood a hilly Mound;
Sacred the Place, and pread with Oaks around;
Where, in a Marble Tomb, Dercennus lay,
A King that once in Latium bore the Sway.
The beauteous Opis thither bent her flight,
To mark the Traytor Aruns, from the height.
Him, in refulgent Arms he oon epy'd,
Swoln with ucces, and loudly thus he cry'd.
Thy backward teps, vain boater, are too late;
Turn, like a Man at length, and meet thy Fate.
Charg'd with my Meage to Camilla go;
And ay I ent thee to the Shades below;
An Honour undeerv'd from Cynthia's Bow.
She aid: and from her Quiver choe with peed
The winged Shaft, predetin'd for the Deed:
Then, to the tubborn Eugh her trength apply'd;
Till the far ditant Horns approach'd on either ide.
The Bow-tring touch'd her Breat, o trong he drew;
Whizzing in Air the fatal Arrow flew.
At once the twanging Bow, and ounding Dart
The Traytor heard, and felt the point within his heart.
Him, beating with his heels, in pangs of death,
His flying Friends to foreign Fields bequeath.
The Conqu'ring Damel, with expanded Wings,
The welcome Meage to her Mitres brings.
Their Leader lot, the Volcians quit the Field;
And, unutain'd, the Chiefs of Turnus yield.
The frighted Souldiers, when their Captains fly,
More on their peed than on their Strength rely.
Confus'd in flight, they bear each other down:
And pur their Hores headlong to the Town.
Driv'n by their Foes, and to their Fears reign'd,
Not once they turn; but take their Wounds behind.
Thee drop the Shield, and thoe the Lance forego;
Or on their Shoulders bear the lacken'd Bow.
The Hoofs of Hores with a ratling ound,
Beat hort, and thick, and hake the rotten ground.
Black clouds of dut, come rowling in the Sky,
And o're the darken'd Walls, and Rampires fly.
The trembling Matrons, from their lofty Stands,
Rend Heav'n with Female Shrieks; and wring their Hands
All preing on, Puruers and puru'd,
Are cruh'd in Crowds, a Mingled multitude.
Some happy few ecape: the Throng too late
Ruh on for Entrance, till they choak the Gate.
Ev'n in the ight of home, the wretched Sire
Looks on, and ees his helples Son expire.
Then, in a fright, the folding Gates they cloe:
But leave their Friends excluded with their Foes.
The vanquih'd cry; the Victors loudly hout;
Tis Terror all within; and Slaughter all without.
Blind in their Fear, they bounce againt the wall,
Or to their Moats puru'd, precipitate their fall.
The Latian Virgins, valiant with depair,
Arm'd on the Towr's the Common Danger hare:
So much of Zeal their Country's Caue inpir'd;
So much Camilla's great Example fir'd.
Poles, harpen'd in the flames, from high they throw;
With imitated Darts to gaul the Foe.
Their Lives, for Godlike freedom they bequeath;
And crowd each other to be firt in death.
Mean time, to Turnus, ambuh'd in the hade,
With heavy tydings, came th' Unhappy Maid.
The Volcians overthrown, Camilla kill'd,
The Foes entirely Maters of the Field,
Like a reitles Flood, come rowling on:
The cry goes off the Plain, and thickens to the Town.
Inflam'd with Rage, (for o the Furies fire
The Daunian's Breat, and o the Fates require,)
He leaves the hilly Pas, the Woods in vain
Poes'd, and downward iues on the Plain:
Scarce was he gone, when to the Streights, now freed
From ecret Foes, the Trojan Troops ucceed.
Thro' the black Foret, and the ferny Brake,
Unknowingly ecure, their Way they take.
From the rough Mountains to the Plain decend;
And there, in Order drawn, their Line extend.
Both Armies, now, in open Fields are een:
Nor far the ditance of the Space between.
Both to the City bend: Aeneas ees,
Thro' moaking Fields, his hat'ning Enemies.
And Turnus views the Trojans in Array,
And hears th' approaching Hores proudly neigh.
Soon had their Hoats in bloody Battel join'd;
But wetward to the Sea the Sun declin'd.
Intrench'd before the Town, both Armies lye:
While Night with able Wings o'repreads the Sky.

div.head: The Twelfth Book of the Aeneis.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Turnus challenges Aeneas to a ingle Combat: Articles are agreed on, but broken by the Rutili, who wound Aeneas: He is miraculouly cur'd by Venus, forces Turnus to a Duel, and concludes the Poem with his Death.

lg.l: WHen Turnus aw the Latins leave the Field;
Their Armies broken, and their Courage quell'd;
Himelf become the Mark of publick Spight,
His Honour quetion'd for the promis'd Fight:
The more he was with Vulgar hate oppres'd;
The more his Fury boil'd within his Breat:
He rowz'd his Vigour for the lat Debate;
And rais'd his haughty Soul, to meet his Fate.
As when the Swains the Lybian Lion chae,
He makes a our Retreat, nor mends his Pace;
But if the pointed Jav'lin pierce his Side,
The lordly Beat returns with double Pride:
He wrenches out the Steel, he roars for Pain;
His ides he lahes, and erects his Mane.
So Turnus fares; his Eye-balls flah with Fire,
And his wide Notrils Clouds of Smoke expire.
Trembling with Rage, around the Court he ran;
At length approach'd the King, and thus began.
No more excues or Delays: I tand
In Arms prepar'd to Combat, hand to hand,
This bae Deerter of his Native Land.
The Trojan, by his Word, is bound to take
The ame Conditions which himelf did make.

figure.p: To ye Right Honble: Phillip Lord Stanhope Earle of Chesterfield Baron of Shelford in the Kingdom of England
figure.head: AE. 12. l. 1.

lg.l: Renew the Truce, the olemn Rites prepare;
And to my ingle Virtue trut the War.
The Latians unconcern'd hall ee the Fight;
This Arm unaided hall aert your Right:
Then, if my protrate Body pres the Plain,
To him the Crown, and beauteous Bride remain.
To whom the King edately thus reply'd;
Brave Youth, the more your Valour has been try'd,
The more becomes it us, with due Repect
To weigh the chance of War, which you neglect.
You want not Wealth, or a ucceive Throne,
Or Cities, which your Arms have made your own;
My Towns and Treaures are at your Command;
And tor'd with blooming Beauties is my Land:
Laurentum more than one Lavinia ees,
Unmarry'd, fair, of Noble Families.
Now let me peak; and you with Patience hear,
Things which perhaps may grate a Lover's Ear:
But ound Advice, proceeding from a heart,
Sincerely yours, and free from fraudful Art.
The Gods, by Signs, have manifetly hown,
No Prince, Italian born, hou'd heir my Throne:
Oft have our Augurs, in Prediction skill'd,
And oft our Priets, a Foreign Son reveal'd.
Yet, won by Worth, that cannot be withtood,
Brib'd by my Kindnes to my kindred Blood,
Urg'd by my Wife, who wou'd not be deny'd;
I promis'd my Lavinia for your Bride:
Her from her plighted Lord by force I took;
All tyes of Treaties, and of Honour broke:
On your Account I wag'd an impious War,
With what Succes 'tis needles to declare;
I, and my Subjects feel; and you have had your Share.
Twice vanquih'd, while in bloody Fields we trive,
Scarce in our Walls, we keep our Hopes alive:
The rowling Flood runs warm with human Gore;
The Bones of Latians, blanch the neighb'ring Shore:
Why put I not an end to this Debate,
Still unreolv'd, and till a Slave to Fate?
If Turnus's Death a lating Peace can give,
Why hou'd I not procure it, while you live.
Shou'd I to doubtful Arms your Youth betray,
What wou'd my Kinmen, the Rutulians, ay?
And hou'd you fall in Fight, (which Heav'n defend)
How cure the Caue, which haten'd to his end,
The Daughter's Lover, and the Father's Friend?
Weigh in your Mind, the various Chance of War,
Pity your Parent's Age; and eae his Care.
Such balmy Words he pour'd, but all in vain;
The proffer'd Med'cine but provok'd the Pain.
The wrathful Youth didaining the Relief,
With intermitting Sobs, thus vents his Grief.
The care, O bet of Fathers, which you take
For my Concerns, at my Deire, forake.
Permit me not to languih out my Days;
But make the bet exchange of Life for Praie.
This Arm, this Lance, can well dipute the Prize;
And the Blood follows, where the Weapon flies:
His Goddes Mother is not near, to hrowd
The flying Coward, with an empty Cloud.
But now the Queen, who fear'd for Turnus Life,
And loath'd the hard Conditions of the Strife,
Held him by Force; and, dying in his Death,
In thee ad Accents gave her Sorrow breath.
O Turnus I adjure thee by thee Tears;
And what e're price Amata's Honour bears
Within thy Breat, ince thou art all my hope,
My ickly Mind's repoe, my inking Age's Prop;
Since on the afety of thy Life alone,
Depends Latinus, and the Latian Throne:
Refue me not this one, this only Pray'r;
To wave the Combat, and purue the War.
Whatever chance attends this fatal Strife,
Think it includes in thine Amata's Life.
I cannot live a Slave; or ee my Throne
Uurp'd by Strangers, or a Trojan Son.
At this, a Flood of Tears Lavinia hed;
A crimon Bluh her beauteous Face o'repread;
Varying her Cheeks by Turns, with white and red.
The driving Colours, never at a tay,
Run here and there; and fluh, and fade away.
Delightful change! Thus Indian Iv'ry hows,
Which with the bord'ring Paint of Purple glows;
Or Lillies damask'd by the neighb'ring Roe.
The Lover gaz'd, and burning with deire,
The more he look'd, the more he fed the Fire:
Revenge, and jealous Rage, and ecret Spight;
Rowl in his Breat, and rowze him to the Fight.
Then fixing on the Queen his ardent Eyes,
Firm to his firt intent, he thus replies.
O Mother, do not by your Tears prepare
Such boding Omens, and prejudge the War.
Reolv'd on Fight, I am no longer free
To hun my Death, if Heav'n my Death decree.
Then turning to the Herald, thus purues;
Go, greet the Trojan with ungrateful News,
Denounce from me, that when to Morrow's Light
Shall guild the Heav'ns, he need not urge the Fight:
The Trojan and Rutulian Troops, no more
Shall dye, with mutual Blood, the Latian Shore:
Our ingle Swords the Quarrel hall decide,
And to the Victor be the beauteous Bride.
He aid, and triding on, with peedy Pace,
He ought his Courers of the Thracian Race.
At his Approach, they tos their Heads on high;
And proudly neighing, promie Victory.
The Sires of thee Orythia ent from far,
To grace Pilumnus, when he went to War.
The drifts of Thracian Snows were carce o white
Nor Northern Winds in fleetnes match'd their Flight.
Officious Grooms tand ready by his Side;
And ome with Combs their flowing Manes divide,
And others troke their Chets, and gently ooth their Pride.
He heath'd his Limbs in Arms; a temper'd Mas
Of golden Metal thoe, and Mountain Bras.
Then to his Head his glitt'ring Helm he ty'd;
And girt his faithful Fauchion to his ide.
In his Aetnean Forge, the God of Fire
That Fauchion labour'd or the Hero's Sire:
Immortal Keennes on the Blade betow'd,
And plung'd it hiing in the Stygian Flood.
Prop'd on a Pillar, which the Ceiling bore,
Was plac'd the Lance Auruncan Actor wore;
Which with uch Force he brandih'd in his Hand,
The tough Ah trembled like an Oyer Wand.
Then cry'd, O pond'rous Spoil of Actor lain,
And never yet by Turnus tos'd in vain,
Fail not this Day thy wonted Force: But go,
Sent by this Hand, to pierce the Trojan Foe:
Give me to tear his Corlet from his Breat,
And from that Eunuch Head, to rend the Cret:
Drag'd in the Dut, his frizled Hair to oil;
Hot from the vexing Ir'n, and mear'd with fragrant Oyl.
Thus while he raves, from his wide Notrils flies
A fiery Steam, and Sparkles from his Eyes.
So fares the Bull in his lov'd Female's ight;
Proudly he bellows, and preludes the fight:
He tries his goring Horns againt a Tree;
And meditates his abent Enemy:
He puhes at the Winds, he digs the Strand
With his black Hoofs, and purns the yellow Sand.
Nor les the Trojan, in his Lemnian Arms,
To future Fight his Manly Courage warms:
He whets his Fury, and with Joy prepares,
To terminate at once the ling'ring Wars.
To chear his Cheifs, and tender Son, relates
What Heav'n had promis'd, and expounds the Fates.
Then to the Latian King he ends, to ceae
The Rage of Arms, and ratifies the Peace.
The Morn enuing from the Mountain's height,
Had carcely pread the Skies with roie Light;
Th' Etherial Courers bounding from the Sea,
From out their flaming Notrils breath'd the Day:
When now the Trojan and Rutulian Guard,
In friendly Labour join'd, the Lit prepar'd.
Beneath the Walls, they meaure out the Space;
Then acred Altars rear, on ods of Gras;
Where, with Religious Rites, their common Gods they place.
In puret white, the Priets their Heads attire,
And living Waters bear, and holy Fire:
And o're their Linnen Hoods, and haded Hair,
Long twited Wreaths of acred Vervain wear.
In Order iuing from the Town, appears
The Latin Legion, arm'd with pointed Spears;
And from the Fields, advancing on a Line,
The Trojan and the Tucan Forces join:
Their various Arms afford a pleaing Sight;
A peaceful Train they eem, in Peace prepar'd for Fight.
Betwixt the Ranks the proud Commanders ride,
Glitt'ring with Gold, and Vets in Purple dy'd.
Here Mnetheus Author of the Memmian Line,
And there Meapus born of Seed Divine.
The Sign is giv'n, and round the lited Space,
Each Man in order fills his proper Place.
Reclining on their ample Shields, they tand;
And fix their pointed Lances in the Sand.
Now, tudious of the ight, a num'rous Throng
Of either Sex promicuous, old and young,
Swarm from the Town: By thoe who ret behind,
The Gates and Walls, and Houes tops are lin'd.
Mean time the Queen of Heav'n beheld the ight,
With Eyes unpleas'd, from Mount Albano's height:
(Since call'd Albano, by ucceeding Fame,
But then an empty Hill, without a Name.)
She thence urvey'd the Field, the Trojan Pow'rs,
The Latian Squadrons, and Laurentine Tow'rs.
Then thus the Goddes of the Skies bepake,
With Sighs and Tears, the Goddes of the Lake;
King Turnus Siter, once a lovely Maid,
E're to the Lut of lawles Jove betray'd:
Compres'd by Force, but by the grateful God,
Now made the Nais of the neighb'ring Flood.
O Nymph, the Pride of living Lakes, aid he,
O mot renown'd, and mot belov'd by me,
Long hat thou known, nor need I to record
The wanton allies of my wand'ring Lord:
Of ev'ry Latian fair, whom Jove mi-led,
To mount by Stealth my violated Bed,
To thee alone I grudg'd not his Embrace;
But gave a part of Heav'n, and an unenvy'd Place.

figure.p: To ye Honble. Brigadier Edward Fitzpatrick

lg.l: Now learn from me, thy near approaching Grief,
Nor think my Wihes want to thy Relief.
While fortune favour'd, nor Heav'n's King deny'd,
To lend my Succour to the Latian ide,
I av'd thy Brother, and the inking State:
But now he truggles with unequal Fate;
And goes with Gods avere, o'rematch'd in Might,
To meet inevitable Death in Fight:
Nor mut I break the Truce, nor can utain the ight.
Thou, if thou dar't, thy preent Aid upply;
It well becomes a Siter's Care to try.
At this the lovely Nymph, with Grief oppres'd,
Thrice tore her Hair, and beat her comely Breat.
To whom Saturnia thus; thy Tears are late;
Hate, natch him, if he can be natch'd from Fate:
New Tumults kindle, violate the Truce;
Who knows what changeful Fortune may produce?
'Tis not a Crime t' attempt what I decree,
Or if it were, dicharge the Crime on me.
She aid, and, ailing on the winged Wind,
Left the ad Nymph upended in her Mind.
And now in Pomp the peaceful Kings appear:
Four Steeds the Chariot of Latinus bear:
Twelve golden Beams around his Temples play,
To mark his Lineage from the God of Day.
Two nowy Courers Turnus's Chariot yoke,
And in his Hand two May Spears he hook:
Then iu'd from the Camp, in Arms Divine,
Aeneas, Author of the Roman Line:
And by his ide Acanius took his Place,
The econd Hope of Rome's Immortal Race.
Adorn'd in white, a rev'rend Priet appears;
And Off'rings to the flaming Altars bears;
A Porket, and a Lamb, that never uffer'd Shears.
Then, to the riing Sun he turns his Eyes,
And trews the Beats, deign'd for Sacrifice,
With Salt, and Meal: With like officious Care
He marks their Foreheads, and he clips their Hair.
Betwixt their Horns the Purple Wine he heds,
With the ame gen'rous Juice the Flame he feeds.
Aeneas then unheath'd his hining Sword,
And thus with pious Pray'rs the Gods ador'd.
All-eeing Sun, and thou Auonian Soil,
For which I have utain'd o long a Toil,
Thou King of Heav'n, and thou the Queen of Air,
(Propitious now, and reconcil'd by Pray'r,)
Thou God of War, whoe unreited Sway
The Labours and Events of Arms obey;
Ye living Fountains, and ye running Floods,
All Pow'rs of Ocean, all Etherial Gods,
Hear, and bear Record: if I fall in Field,
Or Recreant in the Fight, to Turnus yield,
My Trojans hall encreae Evander's Town;

l.U: hall renounce th' Auonian Crown:

lg.l: All Claims, all Quetions of Debate hall ceae;
Nor he, nor they, with Force infringe the Peace.
But if my juter Arms prevail in Fight,
As ure they hall, if I divine aright,
My Trojans hall not o're th' Italians Reign;
Both equal, both unconquer'd hall remain:
Join'd in their Laws, their Lands, and their Abodes;
I ask but Altars for my weary Gods:
The Care of thoe Religious Rites be mine;
The Crown to King Latinus I reign:
His be the Sov'raign Sway. Nor will I hare
His Pow'r in Peace, or his Command in War.
For me, my Friends another Town hall frame,
And bles the riing Tow'rs, with fair Lavinia's Name.
Thus he. Then with erected Eyes and Hands,
The Latian King before his Altar tands.
By the ame Heav'n, aid he, and Earth, and Main,
And all the Pow'rs, that all the three contain;
By Hell below, and by that upper God,
Whoe Thunder igns the Peace, who eals it with his Nod;
So let Latona's double Offspring hear,
And double fronted Janus, what I wear;
I touch the acred Altars, touch the Flames,
And all thoe Pow'rs attet, and all their Names:
Whatever Chance befall on either Side,
No term of time this Union hall divide:
No Force, no Fortune, hall my Vows unbind,
Or hake the tedfat Tenour of my Mind:
Not tho' the circling Seas hou'd break their Bound,
O'reflow the Shores, or ap the olid Ground;
Not tho' the Lamps of Heav'n their Spheres forake,
Hurl'd down, and hiing in the neather Lake:
Ev'n as this Royal Scepter, (for he bore
A Scepter in his Hand) hall never more
Shoot out in Branches, or renew the Birth;
(An Orphan now, cut from the Mother Earth
By the keen Axe, dihonour'd of its Hair,
And cas'd in Bras, for Latian Kings to bear.)
When thus in publick view the Peace was ty'd,
With olemn Vows, and worn on either ide,
All dues perform'd which holy Rites require;
The Victim Beats are lain before the Fire:
The trembling Entrails from their Bodies torn,
And to the fatten'd Flames in Chargers born.
Already the Rutulians deem'd their Man
O'rematch'd in Arms, before the Fight began.
Firt riing Fears are whiper'd thro' the Crowd;
Then, gath'ring ound, they murmur more aloud.
Now ide to ide, they meaure with their Eyes
The Champions bulk, their Sinews, and their Sie:
The nearer they approach, the more is known
Th' apparent Diadvantage of their own.
Turnus himelf, appears in publick ight,
Concious of Fate, deponding of the Fight.
Slowly he moves; and at his Altar tands
With eyes dejected, and with trembling hands:
And while he mutters unditinguih'd Pray'rs,
A livid deadnes in his Cheeks appears.
With anxious Pleaure when Juturna view'd
Th' increaing Fright of the mad Multitude,
When their hort Sighs, and thickning Sobs he heard,
And found their ready Minds for Change prepar'd;
Diembling her immortal Form, he took
Camertus Meen, his Habit, and his Look;
A Chief of ancient Blood: in Arms well known
Was his great Sire, and he, his greater Son.
His Shape aum'd, amid the Ranks he ran,
And humouring their firt Motions, thus began.
For hame, Rutulians, can you bear the ight,
Of one expos'd for all, in ingle Fight?
Can we, before the Face of Heav'n, confes
Our Courage colder, or our Numbers les?
View all the Trojan Hoat, th' Arcadian Band,
And Tucan Army; count 'em as they tand,
Undaunted to the Battel, if we goe,
Scarce ev'ry econd Man will hare a Foe.
Turnus, 'tis true, in this unequal Strife
Shall loe, with Honour, his devoted Life:
Or change it rather for immortal Fame,
Succeeding to the Gods, from whence he came:
But you, a ervile, and inglorious Band,
For Foreign Lords hall ow your Native Land:
Thoe fruitful Fields, your fighting Fathers gain'd,
Which have o long their lazy Sons utain'd.
With Words like thee, he carry'd her Deign;
A riing Murmur runs along the Line.
Then ev'n the City Troops, and Latians, tir'd
With tedious War, eem with new Souls inpir'd:
Their Champion's Fate with Pity they lament;
And of the League, o lately worn, repent.
Nor fails the Goddes to foment the Rage
With lying Wonders, and a fale Preage:
But adds a Sign, which, preent to their Eyes,
Inpires new Courage, and a glad Surprize.
For, udden, in the fiery Tracts above,
Appears in Pomp th' Imperial Bird of Jove:
A plump of Fowl he pies, that wim the Lakes;
And o're their Heads his ounding Pinions hakes.
Then tooping on the fairet of the Train,
In his trong Tallons trus'd a ilver Swan.
Th' Italians wonder at th' unuual ight;
But while he lags, and labours in his flight,
Behold the Datard Fowl return anew;
And with united force the Foe purue:
Clam'rous around the Royal Hawk they fly;
And thick'ning in a Cloud, o'rehade the Sky.
They cuff, they cratch, they cros his airy Coure;
Nor can th' incumber'd Bird utain their Force:
But vex'd, not vanquih'd, drops the pond'rous Prey;
And, lighten'd of his Burthen, wings his Way.
Th' Auonian Bands with Shouts alute the ight:
Eager of Action, and demand the Fight.
Then King Tolumnius, vers'd in Augur's Arts,
Cries out, and thus his boated Skill imparts.
At length 'tis granted, what I long deir'd;
This, this is what my frequent Vows requir'd.
Ye Gods, I take your Omen, and obey;
Advance, my Friends, and charge, I lead the Way.
Thee are the Foreign Foes, whoe impious Band,
Like that rapacious Bird, infet our Land:
But oon, like him, they hall be forc'd to Sea
By Strength united, and forego the Prey:
Your timely Succour to your Country bring;
Hate to the Recue; and redeem your King.
He aid: And preing onward, thro' the Crew,
Poiz'd in his lifted Arm, his Lance he threw.
The winged Weapon, whitling in the Wind,
Came driving on; nor mis'd the Mark deign'd.
At once the Cornel rattled in the Skies;
At once tumultuous Shouts, and Clamours rie.
Nine Brothers in a goodly Band there tood,
Born of Arcadian mix'd with Tucan Blood:
Gylippus Sons: The fatal Jav'lin flew,
Aim'd at the midmot of the friendly Crew.
A Paage thro' the jointed Arms it found,
Jut where the Belt was to the Body bound;
And truck the gentle Youth, extended on the Ground.
Then fir'd with pious Rage, the gen'rous Train
Run madly forward, to revenge the lain.
And ome with eager hate their Jav'lins throw;
And ome, with Sword in hand, aault the Foe.
The wih'd Inult the Latine Troops embrace;
And meet their Ardour in the middle Space.
The Trojans, Tucans, and Arcadian Line,
With equal Courage obviate their Deign.
Peace leaves the violated Fields; and Hate
Both Armies urges to their mutual Fate.
With impious Hate their Altars are o'return'd,
The Sacrifice half broil'd, and half unburn'd.
Thick Storms of Steel from either Army fly,
And Clouds of clahing Darts obcure the Sky:
Brands from the Fire, are miive Weapons made;
With Chargers, Bowls, and all the Prietly Trade.
Latinus frighted, hatens from the Fray,
And bears his unregarded Gods away.
Thee on their Hores vault, thoe yoke the Car;
The ret with Swords on high, run headlong to the War.
Meapus, eager to confound the Peace,
Spurr'd his hot Courer thro' the fighting Preace,
At King Auletes; by his Purple known
A Tucan Prince, and by his Regal Crown:
And with a Shock encount'ring, bore him down.
Backward he fell; and as his Fate deign'd,
The Ruins of an Altar were behind:
There pitching on his Shoulders, and his Head,
Amid the catt'ring Fires he lay upinely pread.
The beamy Spear, decending from above,
His Cuiras pierc'd, and thro' his Body drove.
Then, with a cornful Smile, the Victor cries;
The Gods have found a fitter Sacrifice.
Greedy of Spoils, th' Italians trip the dead
Of his rich Armour; and uncrown his Head.
Priet Chorinaeus arm'd his better Hand,
From his own Altar, with a blazing Brand:
And, as Ebuus with a thund'ring Pace
Advanc'd to Battel, dah'd it on his Face:
His britly Beard hines out with udden Fires,
The crackling Crop a noiom cent expires.
Following the blow, he eiz'd his curling Crown
With his left Hand; his other cat him down.
The protrate Body with his Knees he pres'd;
And plung'd his holy Ponyard in his Breat.
While Podalirius, with his Sword, puru'd
The Shepherd Alus thro' the flying Crowd,
Swiftly he turns; and aims a deadly blow,
Full on the Front of his unwary Foe.
The broad Axe enters, with a crahing Sound,
And cleaves the Chin, with one continu'd Wound:
Warm Blood, and mingled Brains, bemear his Arms around.
An Iron Sleep his tupid Eyes oppres'd,
And eal'd their heavy Lids in endles ret.
But good Aeneas ruh'd amid the Bands,
Bare was his Head, and naked were his Hands,
In ign of Truce: Then thus he cries aloud,
What udden Rage, what new Deire of Blood
Inflames your alter'd Minds? O Trojans ceae
From impious Arms, nor violate the Peace.
By Human Sanctions, and by Laws Divine,
The Terms are all agreed, the War is mine.
Dimis your Fears, and let the Fight enue;
This Hand alone hall right the Gods and you:
Our injur'd Altars, and their broken Vow,
To this avenging Sword the faithles Turnus owe.
Thus while he poke, unmindful of Defence,
A winged Arrow truck the Pious Prince.
But whether from ome Human Hand it came,
Or Hotile God, is left unknown by Fame:
No Human Hand, or Hotile God was found,
To boat the Triumph of o bae a Wound.
When Turnus aw the Trojan quit the Plain,
His Chiefs dimay'd, his Troops a fainting Train:
Th' unhop'd Event his heighten'd Soul inpires,
At once his Arms and Courers he requires.
Then, with a leap, his lofty Chariot gains,
And with a ready hand aumes the Reins.
He drives impetuous, and where e're he goes,
He leaves behind a Lane of laughter'd Foes.
Thee his Lance reaches, over thoe he rowls
His rapid Car, and cruhes out their Souls:
In vain the vanquih'd fly; the Victor ends
The dead Mens Weapons at their living Friends.
Thus on the Banks of Hebrus freezing Flood
The God of Battel's in his angry Mood,
Clahing his Sword againt his brazen Shield,
Lets looe the Reins, and cours along the Field:
Before the Wind his fiery Courers fly,
Groans the ad Earth, reounds the ratling Sky.
Wrath, Terror, Treaon, Tumult, and Depair,
Dire Faces, and deform'd, urround the Car;
Friends of the God, and Followers of the War.
With Fury not unlike, nor les Didain,
Exulting Turnus flies along the Plain:
His moaking Hores, at their utmot Speed,
He lahes on; and urges o're the dead.
Their Fetlocks run with Blood; and when they bound,
The Gore, and gath'ring Dut, are dah'd around.
Thamyris and Pholus, Maters of the War,
He kill'd at hand, but Sthelenus afar:
From far the Sons of Imbracus he lew,
Glaucus, and Lades, of the Lycian Crew:
Both taught to fight on Foot, in Battel join'd;
Or mount the Courer that outtrips the Wind.
Mean time Eumedes, vaunting in the Field,
New fir'd the Trojans, and their Foes repell'd.
This Son of Dolon bore his Grandire's Name;
But emulated more his Father's Fame.
His guileful Father, ent a nightly Spy,
The Grecian Camp and Order to decry:
Hard Enterprie, and well he might require
Achilles Carr, and Hores for his hire:
But, met upon the Scout, th' Etolian Prince
In Death betow'd a juter Recompence.
Fierce Turnus view'd the Trojan from afar;
And lanch'd his Jav'lin from his lofty Carr:
Then lightly leaping down puru'd the Blow,
And, preing with his Foot, his protrate Foe,
Wrench'd from his feeble hold the hining Sword;
And plung'd it in the Boom of its Lord.
Poes, aid he, the fruit of all thy Pains,
And meaure, at thy length, our Latian Plains.
Thus are my Foes rewarded by my hand,
Thus may they build their Town, and thus enjoy the Land.
Then Dares, Butes, Sybaris he lew,
Whom o're his Neck his flound'ring Courer threw.
As when loud Boreas with his blut'ring Train,
Stoops from above, incumbent on the Main;
Where e're he flies, he drives the Rack before;
And rowls the Billows on th' Aegean Shore:
So where reitles Turnus takes his Coure,
The catter'd Squadrons bend before his force:
His Cret of Hores Hair is blown behind,
By advere Air; and rutles in the Wind.
This, haughty Phegeus aw with high Didain,
And as the Chariot rowl'd along the Plain,
Light from the Ground he leapt, and eiz'd the Rein.
Thus hung in Air, he till retain'd his hold;
The Courers frighted, and their Coure control'd.
The Lance of Turnus reach'd him as he hung,
And pierc'd his plated Arms; but pas'd along,
And only raz'd the Skin: he turn'd, and held
Againt his threat'ning Foe his ample Shield:

figure.p: To Thomas Hobbs Dr: in Phiic
figure.head: En: 12. l 570.

lg.l: Then call'd for Aid: but while he cry'd in vain,
The Chariot bore him backward on the Plain.
He lies revers'd; the Victor King decends,
And trikes o jutly where his Helmet ends,
He lops the Head. The Latian Fields are drunk
With treams that iue from the bleeding Trunk.
While he triumphs, and while the Trojans yield,
The wounded Prince is forc'd to leave the Field:
Strong Mnetheus, and Achates often try'd,
And young Acanius, weeping by his ide,
Conduct him to his Tent: Scarce can he rear
His Limbs from Earth, upported on his Spear.
Reolv'd in Mind, regardles of the Smart,
He tugs with both his Hands, and breaks the Dart.
The Steel remains. No readier way he found
To draw the Weapon, than t' inlarge the Wound.
Eager of Fight, impatient of delay,
He begs; and his unwilling Friends obey.
Iapis was at hand to prove his Art,
Whoe blooming Youth o fir'd Apollo's Heart,
That for his Love he proffer'd to betow
His tuneful Harp, and his unerring Bow.
The pious Youth, more tudious how to ave
His aged Sire, now inking to the Grave,
Pr • ferr'd the pow'r of Plants, and ilent Praie
Of healing Arts, before Phoebeian Bays.
Prop'd on his Lance the penive Heroe tood,
And heard, and aw unmov'd, the mourning Crowd.
The fam'd Phyician tucks his Robes around,
With ready Hands, and hatens to the Wound.
With gentle Touches he performs his part,
This way and that, olliciting the Dart,
And exercies all his Heav'nly Art.
All oftning Simples, known of Sov'raign Ue,
He prees out, and pours their noble Juice;
Thee firt infus'd, to lenifie the Pain,
He tugs with Pincers, but he tugs in vain.
Then, to the Patron of his Art he pray'd;
The Patron of his Art refus'd his Aid.
Mean time the War approaches to the Tents;
Th' Allarm grows hotter, and the Noie augments:
The driving Dut proclaims the Danger near,
And firt their Friends, and then their Foes appear;
Their Friends retreat, their Foes purue the Rear.
The Camp is fill'd with Terror and Affright,
The hiing Shafts within the Trench alight:
An unditinguih'd Noie acends the Sky;
The Shouts of thoe who kill, and Groans of thoe who dye.
But now the Goddes Mother, mov'd with Grief,
And pierc'd with Pity, hatens her Relief.
A Branch of healing Dittany he brought;
Which in the Cretan Fields with Care he ought:
Rough is the Stem, which woolly Leafs urround;
The Leafs with Flow'rs, the Flow'rs with Purple crown'd:
Well known to wounded Goats; a ure Relief
To draw the pointed Steel, and eae the Grief.
This Venus brings, in Clouds involv'd; and brews
Th' extracted Liquor with Ambroian Dews,
And od'rous Panacee: Uneen he tands,
Temp'ring the mixture with her Heav'nly Hands:
And pours it in a Bowl, already crown'd
With Juice of medc'nal herbs prepar'd to bathe the Wound.
The Leech, unknowing of uperior Art,
Which aids the Cure, with this foments the part;
And in a Moment ceas'd the raging mart.
Stanch'd is the Blood, and in the bottom tands:
The Steel, but carcely touch'd with tender Hands,
Moves up, and follows of its own Accord;
And Health and Vigour are at once retor'd.
Iapis firt perceiv'd the cloing Wound;
And firt the Footteps of a God he found.
Arms, Arms, he cries, the Sword and Shield prepare,
And end the willing Chief, renew'd to War.
This is no Mortal Work, no Cure of mine,
Nor Art's effect, but done by Hands Divine:
Some God our General to the Battel fends;
Some God preerves his Life for greater Ends.
The Heroe arms in hate: His hands infold
His Thighs with Cuies of refulgent Gold:
Inflam'd to fight, and ruhing to the Field,
That Hand utaining the Coeletial Shield,
This gripes the Lance; and with uch Vigour hakes,
That to the Ret the beamy Weapon quakes.
Then, with a cloe Embrace he train'd his Son;
And kiing thro' his Helmet, thus begun.
My Son, from my Example learn the War,
In Camps to uffer, and in Fields to dare:
But happier Chance than mine attend thy Care.
This Day my hand thy tender Age hall hield,
And crown with Honours of the conquer'd Field:
Thou, when thy riper Years hall end thee forth,
To toils of War, be mindful of my Worth:
Aert thy birthright; and in Arms be known,
For Hector's Nephew, and Aeneas's Son.
He aid, and, triding, iu'd on the Plain;
Anteus, and Mnetheus, and a num'rous Train
Attend his Steps: The ret their Weapons take,
And crowding to the Field, the Camp forake.
A cloud of blinding Dut is rais'd around;
Labours beneath their Feet the trembling ground.
Now Turnus, poted on a Hill, from far
Beheld the progres of the moving War:
With him the Latins view'd the cover'd Plains;
And the chill Blood ran backward in their Veins.

l.U: aw th' advancing Troops appear;

lg.l: And heard the hotile Sound, and fled for Fear.
Aeneas leads; and draws a weeping Train,
Clos'd in their Ranks, and pouring on the Plain.
As when a Whirlwind ruhing to the Shore,
From the mid Ocean, drives the Waves before:
The painful Hind, with heavy Heart foreees,
The flatted Fields, and laughter of the Trees;
With like impetuous Rage the Prince appears,
Before his doubled Front; nor les Detruction bears.
And now both Armies hock, in open Field;
Oyris is by trong Thymbraeus kill'd.
Archetius, Ufens, Epulon, are lain;
(All fam'd in Arms, and of the Latian Train;)
By Gyas, Mnetheus, and Achates Hand:
The fatal Augur falls, by whofe command
The Truce was broken, and whoe Lance embru'd
With Trojan Blood, th' unhappy Fight renew'd.
Loud Shouts and Clamours rend the liquid Sky;
And o're the Field the frighted Latins fly.
The Prince didains the Datards to purue,
Nor moves to meet in Arms the fighting few:
Turnus alone, amid the dusky Plain,
He eeks, and to the Combat calls in vain.
Juturna heard, and eiz'd with Mortal Fear,
Forc'd from the Beam her Brother's Charioteer;
Aumes his Shape, his Armour, and his Meen;
And like Meticus, in his Seat is een.
As the black Swallow near the Palace plies;
O're empty Courts, and under Arches flies;
Now hawks aloft, now skims along the Flood,
To furnih her loquacious Net with Food:
So drives the rapid Goddes o're the Plains;
The moaking Hores run with looen'd Reins.
She teers a various Coure among the Foes;
Now here, now there, her conqu'ring Brother hows:
Now with a traight, now with a wheeling flight,
She turns, and bends, but huns the ingle Fight.
Aeneas, fir'd with Fury, breaks the Crowd,
And eeks his Foe, and calls by name aloud:
He runs within a narrower Ring, and tries
To top the Chariot, but the Chariot flies.
If he but gain a glimps, Juturna fears,
And far away the Daunian Heroe bears.
What hou'd he do! nor Arts nor Arms avail;
And various Cares in vain his Mind aail.
The great Meapus thund'ring thro' the Field,
In his left hand two pointed Jav'lins held;
Encountring on the Prince, one Dart he drew,
And with unerring aim, and utmot Vigour threw.

l.U: aw it come, and tooping low

lg.l: Beneath his Buckler, hunn'd the threatning blow.
The Weapon his'd above his Head, and tore
The waving Plume, which on his Helm he wore.
Forc'd by this hotile Act, and fir'd with pight,
That flying Turnus till declin'd the Fight;
The Prince, whoe Piety had long repell'd
His inborn ardour, now invades the Field:
Invokes the Pow'rs of violated Peace,
Their Rites, and injur'd Altars to redres:
Then, to his Rage abandoning the Rein,
With Blood and laughter'd Bodies fills the Plain.
What God can tell, what Numbers can diplay
The various Labours of that fatal Day!
What Chiefs, and Champions fell on either ide,
In Combat lain, or by what Deaths they dy'd?
Whom Turnus, whom the Trojan Heroe kill'd:
Who har'd the Fame, and fortune of the Field?
Jove, cou'dt thou view, and not avert thy ight,
Two jarring Nations join'd in cruel fight,
Whom Leagues of lating Love o hortly hall unite!
Aeneas firt Rutulian Sucro found,
Whoe Valour made the Trojans quit their Ground:
Betwixt his Ribs the Jav'lin drove o jut,
It reach'd his Heart, nor needs a econd Thrut.
Now Turnus, at two blows, two Brethren lew;
Firt from his Hore fierce Amycus he threw;
Then leaping on the Ground, on Foot aail'd
Diores, and in equal Fight prevail'd.
Their lifeles Trunks he leaves upon the place;
Their Heads ditilling Gore, his Chariot grace.
Three cold on Earth the Trojan Heroe threw;
Whom without repite at one Charge he lew.
Cethegus, Tanais, Tagus, fell oppres'd,
And ad Onythes, added to the ret;
Of Theban Blood, whom Peridia bore.
Turnus, two Brothers from the Lycian Shore,
And from Apollo's Fane to Battel ent,
O'rethrew, nor Phoebus cou'd their Fate prevent.
Peaceful Menaetes after thee he kill'd,
Who long had hunn'd the Dangers of the Field:
On Lerna's Lake a ilent Life he led,
And with his Nets and Angle earn'd his Bread.
Nor pompous Cares, nor Palaces he knew,
But wiely from th' infectious World withdrew.
Poor was his Houe; his Father's painful Hand
Dicharg'd his Rent, and plough'd another's Land.
As Flames among the lofty Woods are thrown,
On diff'rent ides, and both by Winds are blown,
The Laurels crackle in the putt'ring Fire;
The frighted Silvans from their Shades retire:
Or as two neighb'ring Torrents fall from high,
Rapid they run; the foamy Waters fry:
They rowl to Sea with unreited Force,
And down the Rocks precipitate their Coure:
Not with les rage the Rival Heroes take
Their diff'rent Ways; nor les Detruction make.
With Spears afar, with Swords at hand they trike;
And zeal of Slaughter fires their Souls alike.
Like them, their dauntles Men maintain the Field,
And Hearts are pierc'd unknowing how to yield:
They blow for blow return, and wound for wound;
And heaps of Bodies raie the level Ground.
Murranus, boating of his Blood, that prings
From a long Royal Race of Latian Kings,
Is by the Trojan from his Chariot thrown,
Cruh'd with the weight of an unweildy Stone:
Betwixt the Wheels he fell; the Wheels that bore
His living Load, his dying Body tore.
His tarting Steeds, to hun the glitt'ring Sword,
Paw down his trampled Limbs, forgetful of their Lord.
Fierce Hillus threaten'd high; and face to face
Affronted Turnus in the middle pace:
The Prince encounter'd him in full Carreer,
And at his Temples aim'd his deadly Spear:
So fatally the flying Weapon ped,
That thro' his Brazen Helm it pierc'd his Head.
Nor Cieus coud't thou cape from Turnus hand,
In vain the tronget of th' Arcadian Band:
Nor to Cupentus cou'd his Gods afford,
Availing Aid againt th' Aenean Sword:
Which to his naked Heart puru'd the Coure:
Nor could his plated Shield utain the Force.
Iolas fell, whom not the Grecian Pow'rs,
Nor great Subvertor of the Trojan Tow'rs,
Were doom'd to kill, while Heav'n prolong'd his Date:
But who can pas the Bounds prefix'd by Fate?
In high Lyrneus, and in Troy, he held
Two Palaces, and was from each expell'd:
Of all the mighty Man, the lat Remains
A little pot of Foreign Earth contains.
And now both Hots their broken Troops unite,
In equal Ranks, and mix in mortal Fight.
Serethus, and undaunted Mnetheus join
The Trojan, Tucan, and Arcadian Line:
Sea-born Meapus, with Atinas, heads
The Latin Squadrons, and to Battel leads.
They trike, they puh, they throng the canty pace;
Reolv'd on Death, impatient of Digrace;
And where one falls, another fills his Place.
The Cyprian Goddes now inpires her Son
To leave th' unfinih'd Fight, and torm the Town.
For while he rowls his Eyes around the Plain,
In quet of Turnus, whom he eeks in vain,
He views th' ungarded City from afar,
In careles quiet, and ecure of War:
Occaion offers, and excites his Mind,
To dare beyond the Task he firt deign'd.
Reolv'd, he calls his Chiefs: they leave the Fight;
Attended thus, he takes a neighb'ring Height:
The crowding Troops about their Gen'ral tand,
All under Arms, and wait his high Command.
Then thus the lofty Prince: Hear and obey,
Ye Trojan Bands, without the leat delay.
Jove is with us, and what I have decreed
Requires our utmot Vigour, and our Speed.
Your intant Arms againt the Town prepare;
The ource of Michief, and the Seat of War.
This Day the Latian Tow'rs, that mate the Sky,
Shall level with the Plain in Ahes lye:
The People hall be Slaves; unles in time
They kneel for Pardon, and repent their Crime.
Twice have our Foes been vanquih'd on the Plain;
Then hall I wait till Turnus will be lain?
Your Force againt the perjur'd City bend:
There it began, and there the War hall end.
The Peace profan'd our rightful Arms requires:
Cleane the polluted Place with purging Fires.
He finih'd; and one Soul inpiring all,
Form'd in a Wedge, the Foot approach the Wall.
Without the Town, an unprovided Train
Of gaping, gazing Citizens are lain.
Some Firebrands, others caling Ladders bear;
And thoe they tos aloft, and thee they rear:
The Flames now lanch'd, the feather'd Arrows fly,
And Clouds of miive Arms obcure the Sky.
Advancing to the Front, the Heroe tands,
And tretching out to Heav'n his Pious Hands;
Attets the Gods, aerts his Innocence,
Upbraids with breach of Faith th' Auonian Prince:
Declares the Royal Honour doubly tain'd,
And twice the Rites of holy Peace profan'd.
Dienting Clamours in the Town arie;
Each will be heard, and all at once advie.
One part for Peace, and one for War contends:
Some wou'd exclude their Foes, and ome admit their Friends.
The helples King is hurry'd in the Throng;
And what e're Tide prevails, is born along.
Thus when the Swain, within a hollow Rock,
Invades the Bees, with uffocating Smoke,
They run around, or labour on their Wings,
Dius'd to flight; and hoot their leepy Stings:
To hun the bitter Fumes in vain they try;
Black Vapours, iuing from the Vent, involve the Sky.
But Fate, and envious Fortune, now prepare
To plunge the Latins in the lat depair.
The Queen, who aw the Foes invade the Town;
And brands on tops of burning Houes thrown:
Cat round her Eyes, ditracted with her Fear;
No Troops of Turnus in the Field appear.
Once more he tares abroad, but till in vain:
And then concludes the Royal Youth is lain.
Mad with her Anguih, impotent to bear
The mighty Grief, he loaths the vital Air.
She calls her elf the Caue of all this Ill,
And owns the dire Effects of her ungovern'd Will:
She raves againt the Gods, he beats her Breat,
She tears with both her hands her Purple Vet.
Then round a Beam a running Nooe he ty'd;
And, faten'd by the Neck, obcenely dy'd.
Soon as the fatal News by Fame was blown,
And to her Dames, and to her Daughter known;
The ad Lavinia rends her yellow Hair,
And roie Cheeks; the ret her Sorrow hare:
With Shrieks the Palace rings, and Madnes of Depair.
The preading Rumor fills the Publick Place;
Confuion, Fear, Ditraction, and Digrace,
And ilent hame, are een in ev'ry Face.
Latinus tears his Garments as he goes,
Both for his publick, and his private Woes:
With Filth his venerable Beard bemears,
And ordid Dut deforms his Silver Hairs.
And much he blames the oftnes of his Mind,
Obnoxious to the Charms of Womankind,
And oon educ'd to change, what he o well deign'd:
To break the olemn League o long deir'd,
Nor finih what his Fates, and thoe of Troy requir'd.
Now Turnus rowls aloof o're empty Plains,
And here and there ome tragling Foes he gleans.
His flying Courers pleae him les and les,
Aham'd of eaie Fight, and cheap Succes.
Thus half contented, anxious in his Mind,
The ditant Cries come driving in the Wind:
Shouts from the Walls, but Shouts in Murmurs drown'd;
A jarring mixture, and a boding ound.
Alas, aid he, what mean thee dimal Cries,
What doleful Clamours from the Town arie?
Confus'd he tops, and backward pulls the Reins:
She, who the Driver's Office now utains,
Replies; Neglect, my Lord, thee new Alarms;
Here fight, and urge the Fortune of your Arms:
There want not others to defend the Wall:
If by your Rival's Hand th' Italians fall,
So hall your fatal Sword his Friends oppres,
In Honour equal, equal in Succes.
To this, the Prince; O Siter, (for I knew
The Peace infring'd, proceeded firt from you,)
I knew you, when you mingled firt in Fight,
And now in vain you wou'd deceive my Sight:
Why, Goddes, this unprofitable Care?
Who ent you down from Heav'n, involv'd in Air,
Your hare of Mortal Sorrows to utain,
And ee your Brother bleeding on the Plain?
For, to what Pow'r can Turnus have recoure,
Or how reit his Fates prevailing force!
Thee Eyes beheld Murranus bite the Ground,
Mighty the Man, and mighty Was the Wound.
I heard my dearet Friend, with dying Breath,
My Name invoking to revenge his Death:
Brave Ufens fell with Honour on the Place;
To hun the hameful ight of my digrace.
On Earth upine, a Manly Corps he lies;
His Vet and Armour are the Victor's Prize.
Then, hall I ee Laurentum in a flame,
Which only wanted to compleat my hame?
How will the Latins hoot their Champion's flight;
How Drances will be pleas'd, and point them to the ight!
Is Death o hard to bear? Ye Gods below,
(Since thoe above o mall Compaion how,)
Receive a Soul unully'd yet with hame,
Which not belies my great Forefather's Name.
He aid: And while he poke, with flying peed,
Came Sages urging on his foamy Steed;
Fix'd on his wounded Face a Shaft he bore,
And eeking Turnus ent his Voice before:
Turnus, on you, on you alone depends
Our lat Relief; compaionate your Friends.
Like Lightning, fierce Aeneas, rowling on,
With Arms invets, with Flames invades the Town:
The Brands are tos'd on high; the Winds conpire
To drive along the Deluge of the Fire:
All Eyes are fix'd on you; your Foes rejoice;
Ev'n the King taggers, and upends his Choice:
Doubts to deliver, or defend the Town;
Whom to reject, or whom to call his Son.
The Queen, on whom your utmot hopes were plac'd,
Her elf uborning Death, has breath'd her lat.
'Tis true, Meapus, fearles of his Fate,
With fierce Atinas Aid, defends the Gate:
On ev'ry ide urrounded by the Foe;
The more they kill, the greater Numbers grow;
An Iron Harvet mounts, and till remains to mow.
You, far aloof from your foraken Bands,
Your rowling Chariot drive o're empty Sands.
Stupid he ate, his Eyes on Earth declin'd,
And various Cares revolving in his Mind:
Rage boiling from the bottom of his Breat,
And Sorrow mix'd with Shame, his Soul oppres'd:
And concious Worth lay lab'ring in his Thought;
And Love by Jealouie to Madnes wrought.
By low degrees his Reaon drove away
The Mits of Paion, and reum'd her Sway.
Then, riing on his Car, he turn'd his Look;
And aw the Town involv'd in Fire and Smoke.
A wooden Tow'r with Flames already blaz'd,
Which his own Hands on Beams and Rafters rais'd:
And Bridges laid above to join the Space;
And Wheels below to rowl from place to place.
Siter, the Fates have vanquih'd: Let us go
The way which Heav'n and my hard Fortune how.
The Fight is fix'd: Nor hall the branded Name
Of a bae Coward blot your Brother's Fame.
Death is my choice; but uffer me to try
My Force, and vent my Rage before I dye.
He aid, and leaping down without delay,
Thro Crowds of catter'd Foes he free'd his way.
Striding he pas'd, impetuous as the Wind,
And left the grieving Goddes far behind.
As when a Fragment, from a Mountain torn
By raging Tempets, or by Torrents born,
Or app'd by time, or looen'd from the Roots,
Prone thro' the Void the Rocky Ruine hoots,
Rowling from Crag to Crag, from Steep to Steep;
Down ink, at once the Shepherds and their Sheep,
Involv'd alike, they ruh to neather Ground,
Stun'd with the hock they fall, and tun'd from Earth rebound:
So Turnus, hating headlong to the Town,
Should'ring and hoving, bore the Squadrons down.
Still preing onward, to the Walls he drew,
Where Shafts, and Spears, and Darts promicuous flew;
And anguine Streams the lipp'ry Ground embrew.
Firt tretching out his Arm, in ign of Peace,
He cries aloud, to make the Combat ceae:
Rutulians hold, and Latin Troops retire;
The Fight is mine, and me the Gods require.
Tis jut that I hou'd vindicate alone
The broken Truce, or for the Breach atone.
This Day hall free from Wars th' Auonian State;
Or finih my Misfortunes in my Fate.
Both Armies from their bloody Work deit:
And bearing backward, form a pacious Lit.
The Trojan Heroe who receiv'd from Fame
The welcome Sound, and heard the Champion's Name,
Soon leaves the taken Works, and mounted Walls,
Greedy of War, where greater Glory calls.
He prings to Fight, exulting in his Force;
His jointed Armour rattles in the Coure.
Like Eryx, or like Athos, great he hows,
Or Father Apennine, when white with Snows,
His Head Divine, obcure in Clouds he hides:
And hakes the ounding Foret on his ides.
The Nations over-aw'd, urceae the Fight,
Immoveable their Bodies, fix'd their ight:
Ev'n Death tands till; nor from above they throw
Their Darts, nor drive their batt'ring Rams below.
In ilent Order either Army tands;
And drop their Swords, unknowing, from their Hands.
Th' Auonian King beholds, with wond'ring ight,
Two mighty Champions match'd in ingle Fight:
Born under Climes remote; and brought by Fate,
With Swords to try their Titles to the State.
Now in clos'd Field, each other from afar
They view; and ruhing on, begin the War.
They launch their Spears, then hand to hand they meet;
The trembling Soil reounds beneath their Feet:
Their Bucklers clah; thick blows decend from high,
And flakes of Fire from their hard Helmets fly.
Courage conpires with Chance; and both ingage
With equal Fortune, and with mutual Rage.
As when two Bulls for their fair Female fight,
In Sila's Shades, or on Taburnus height;
With Horns advere they meet: the Keeper flies;
Mute tands the Herd, the Heifars rowl their Eyes;
And wait th' Event; which Victor they hall bear,
And who hall be the Lord, to rule the luty Year:
With rage of Love the jealous Rivals burn,
And Puh for Puh, and Wound for Wound return:
Their Dewlaps gor'd, their ides are lav'd in Blood;
Loud Cries and roaring Sounds rebellow thro' the Wood:
Such was the Combat in the lited Ground;
So clah their Swords and o their Shields reound.

l.U: ets the Beam; in either Scale he lays

lg.l: The Champions Fate, and each exactly weighs.
On this ide Life, and lucky Chance acends:
Loaded with Death, that other Scale decends.
Rais'd on the Stretch, young Turnus aims a blow,
Full on the Helm of his unguarded Foe:
Shrill Shouts and Clamours ring on either ide;
As Hopes and Fears their panting Hearts divide.
But all in pieces flies the Traytor Sword,
And, in the middle Stroke deerts his Lord.
Now 'tis but Death, or Flight: diarm'd he flies,
When in his Hand, an unknown Hilt he pies.
Fame ays that Turnus, when his Steeds he join'd,
Hurrying to War, diorder'd in his Mind,
Snatch'd the firt Weapon, which his hate cou'd find.
'Twas not the fated Sword his Father bore;
But that his Charioteer Meticus wore.
This, while the Trojans fled, the Toughnes held;
But vain againt the great Vulcanian Shield,
The mortal-temper'd Steel deceiv'd his Hand:
The hiver'd fragments hone amid the Sand.
Surpris'd with fear, he fled along the Field;
And now forthright, and now in Orbits wheel'd.
For here the Trojan Troops the Lit urround;
And there the Pas is clos'd with Pools and marhy Ground.
Aeneas hatens, tho' with heavier Pace,
His Wound o newly knit, retards the Chae:
And oft his trembling Knees their Aid refue,
Yet preing foot by foot his Foe purues.
Thus, when a fearful Stag is clos'd around
With Crimon Toils, or in a River found;
High on the Bank the deep-mouth'd Hound appears;
Still opening, following till, where e're he teers:
The perecuted Creature, to, and fro,
Turns here and there, to cape his mbrian Foe:
Steep is th' Acent; and if he gains the Land,
The Purple Death is pitch'd along the Strand:
His eager Foe determin'd to the Chace,
Stretch'd at his length gains Ground at ev'ry Pace:
Now to his beamy Head he makes his way,
And now he holds, or thinks he holds his Prey:

figure.p: To the Right Honble: Francis North Baron of Guilford
figure.head: Aen: 12. L 1120.

lg.l: Jut at the pinch the Stag prings out with fear,
He bites the Wind, and fills his ounding Jaws with Air.
The Rocks, the Lakes, the Meadows ring with Cries;
The mortal Tumult mounts, and thunders in the Skies.
Thus flies the Daunian Prince: and, flying, blames
His tardy Troops; and calling by their Names,
Demands his truty Sword. The Trojan threats
The Realm with Ruin, and their ancient Seats
To lay in Ahes, if they dare upply
With Arms or Aid, his vanquih'd Enemy:
Thus menacing, he till purues the Coure,
With Vigour, tho' diminih'd of his Force.
Ten times, already, round the lited place,
One Chief had fled, and t'other giv'n the Chace:
No trivial Prize is play'd; for on the Life
Or Death of Turnus, now depends the Strife.
Within the pace, an Olive Tree had tood,
A acred Shade, a venerable Wood,
For Vows to Faunus paid, the Latins Guardian God.
Here hung the Vets, and Tablets were ingrav'd,
Of inking Mariners, from Shipwrack av'd.
With heedles Hands the Trojans fell'd the Tree,
To make the Ground inclos'd for Combat free.
Deep in the Root, whether by Fate, or Chance,
Or erring hate, the Trojan drove his Lance:
Then toop'd, and tug'd with Force immene to free
Th' incumber'd Spear from the tenacious Tree:
That whom his fainting Limbs puru'd in vain,
His flying Weapon might from far attain.
Confus'd with Fear, bereft of Human Aid,
Then Turnus to the Gods, and firt to Faunus pray'd.
O Faunus pity, and thou Mother Earth,
Where I thy foter Son receiv'd my Birth,
Hold fat the Steel; if my Religious Hand
Your Plant has honour'd, which your Foes profan'd;
Propitious hear my pious Pray'r! He aid,
Nor with uccesles Vows invok'd their Aid.
Th' incumbent Heroe, wrench'd, and pull'd, and train'd;
But till the tubborn Earth the Steel detain'd.
Juturna took her time; and while in vain
He trove, aum'd Meticus Form again:
And, in that imitated Shape, retor'd
To the depairing Prince, his Daunian Sword.
The Queen of Love, who, with Didain and Grief,
Saw the bold Nymph afford this prompt Relief;
T' aert her Off-pring, with a greater Deed,
From the tough Root the ling'ring Weapon freed.
Once more erect, the Rival Chiefs advance;
One truts the Sword, and one the pointed Lance:
And both reolv'd alike, to try their fatal Chance.
Mean time Imperial Jove to Juno poke,
Who from a hining Cloud beheld the hock;
What new Arret, O Queen of Heav'n, is ent
To top the Fates now lab'ring in th' Event.
What farther hopes are left thee to purue
Divine Aeneas, (and thou know't it too,)
Fore-doom'd to thee Coeletial Seats is due?
What more Attempts for Turnus can be made,
That thus thou ling'ret in this lonely Shade!
Is it becoming of the due Repect,
And awful Honour of a God Elect,
A Wound unworthy of our State to feel;
Patient of Human Hands, and earthly Steel?
Or eems it Jut, the Siter hou'd retore,
A econd Sword, when one was lot before;
And arm a conquer'd Wretch, againt his Conqueror?
For what without thy knowledge and avow,
Nay more, thy Dictate, durt Juturna do?
At lat, in deference to my Love, forbear
To lodge within thy Soul this anxious Care:
Reclin'd upon my Breat, thy Grief unload;
Who hou'd relieve the Goddes, but the God?
Now, all things to their utmot Iue tend;
Puh'd by the Fates to their appointed End:
While leave was giv'n thee, and a lawful Hour
For Vengeance, Wrath, and unreited Pow'r:
Tos'd on the Seas thou cou'd't thy Foes ditres,
And driv'n ahore, with Hotile Arms oppres:
Deform the Royal Houe; and from the ide
Of the Jut Bridegroom, tear the plighted Bride:
Now ceae at my Command. The Thund'rer aid:
And with dejected Eyes this Anwer Juno made.
Becaue your dread Decree too well I knew;
From Turnus, and from Earth unwilling I withdrew.
Ele hou'd you not behold me here alone,
Involv'd in empty Clouds, my Friends bemoan:
But girt with vengeful Flames, in open ight,
Engag'd againt my Foes in Mortal Fight.
'Tis true Juturna mingled in the Strife
By my Command, to ave her Brother's Life;
At leat to try: But by the Stygian Lake,
(The mot Religious Oath the Gods can take,)
With this retriction, not to bend the Bow,
Or tos the Spear, or trembling Dart to throw.
And now reign'd to your Superior Might,
And tir'd with fruitles Toils, I loath the Fight.
This let me beg, (and this no Fates withtand)
Both for my elf, and for your Fathers Land,
That when the Nuptial Bed hall bind the Peace;
(Which I, ince you ordain, conent to bles,)
The Laws of either Nation be the ame;
But let the Latins till retain their Name:
Speak the ame Language which they poke before;
Wear the ame Habits, which their Grandires wore:
Call them not Trojans: Perih the Renown,
And Name of Troy, with that deteted Town.
Latium be Latium till; let Alba reign,
And Rome's immortal Majety remain.
Then thus the Founder of Mankind replies:
(Unruffled was his Front, erene his Eyes,)
Can Saturn's Iue, and Heav'ns other Heir,
Such endles Anger in her Boom bear?
Be Mitres, and your full Deires obtain:
But quench the Choler you foment in vain.
From ancient Blood th' Auonian People prung,
Shall keep their Name, their Habit, and their Tongue.
The Trojans to their Cutoms hall be ty'd,
I will, my elf, their common Rites provide;
The Natives hall command, the Foreigners ubide.
All hall be Latium; Troy without a Name:
And her lot Sons forget from whence they came.
From Blood o mix'd, a pious Race hall flow,
Equal to Gods, excelling all below.
No Nation more Repect to you hall pay,
Or greater Off'rings on your Altars lay.
Juno conents, well pleas'd that her Deires
Had found Succes, and from the Cloud retires.
The Peace thus made, the Thund'rer next prepares
To force the wat'ry Goddes from the Wars.
Deep in the dimal Regions, void of Light,
Three Daughters at a Birth were born to Night:
Thee their brown Mother, brooding on her Care,
Indu'd with windy Wings to flit in Air:
With Serpents girt alike; and crown'd with hiing Hair.
In Heav'n the Dirae call'd, and till at hand,
Before the Throne of angry Jove they tand.
His Miniters of Wrath; and ready till
The Minds of Mortal Men with Fears to fill:
When e're the moody Sire, to wreak his Hate
On Realms, or Towns deerving of their Fate,
Hurls down Dieaes, Death, and deadly Care,
And terrifies the guilty World with War.
One Siter Plague of thee from Heav'n he ent,
To fright Juturna with a dire Portent.
The Pet comes whirling down: by far more low
Springs the wift Arrow from the Parthian Bow,
Or Cydon Eugh; when travering the Skies,
And drench'd in pois'nous Juice, the ure Detruction flies.
With uch a udden, and uneen a flight,
Shot thro' the Clouds the Daughter of the Night.
Soon as the Field inclos'd he had in view,
And from afar her detin'd Quarry knew:
Contracted, to the boding Bird he turns,
Which haunts the ruin'd Piles, and hallow'd Urns;
And beats about the Tombs with nightly Wings;
Where Songs obence on Sepulchres he ings.
Thus leen'd in her Form, with frightful Cries,
The Fury round unhappy Turnus flies,
Flaps on his Shield, and flutters o're his Eyes.
A lazy Chilnes crept along his Blood,
Choak'd was his Voice, his Hair with Horror tood.
Juturna from afar beheld her fly,
And knew th' ill Omen, by her creaming Cry,
And tridour of her Wings. Amaz'd with Fear,
Her comely Breat he beat, and rent her flowing Hair.
Ah me, he cries, in this unequal Strife,
What can thy Siter more to ave thy Life!
Weak as I am, can I, alas, contend
In Arms, with that inexorable Fiend!
Now, now, I quit the Field! forbear to fright
My tender Soul, ye baleful Birds of Night!
The lahing of your Wings I know too well:
The ounding Flight, and Fun'ral Screams of Hell!
Thee are the Gifts you bring from haughty Jove,
The worthy Recompence of ravih'd Love!
Did he for this exempt my Life from Fate?
O hard Conditions of Immortal State!
Tho' born to Death, not priviledg'd to dye,
But forc'd to bear impos'd Eternity!
Take back your envious Bribes, and let me go
Companion to my Brother's Ghot below!
The Joys are vanih'd: Nothing now remains,
Of Life Immortal, but Immortal Pains.
What Earth will open her devouring Womb,
To ret a weary Goddes in the Tomb!
She drew a length of Sighs; nor more he aid;
But in her Azure Mantle wrap'd her Head:
Then plung'd into her Stream, with deep Depair,
And her lat Sobs came bubling up in Air.
Now tern Aeneas waves his weighty Spear
Againt his Foe, and thus upbraids his Fear,
What farther Subterfuge can Turnus find;
What empty Hopes are harbour'd in his Mind?
'Tis not thy Swiftnes can ecure thy Flight:
Not with their Feet, but Hands, the Valiant fight.
Vary thy Shape in thouand Forms, and dare
What Skill and Courage can attempt in War:
Wih for the Wings of Winds, to mount the Sky;
Or hid, within the hollow Earth to lye.
The Champion hook his Head; and made this hort reply.
No threats of thine, my manly Mind can move:
Tis Hotile Heav'n I dread; and Partial Jove.
He, aid no more: but with a Sigh, repres'd
The mighty Sorrow, in his welling Breat.
Then, as he rowld his troubled Eyes around,
An Antique Stone he aw: the Common Bound
Of Neighb'ring Fields; and Barrier of the Ground:
So vat, that Twelve trong Men of modern Days,
Th' enormous weight from Earth cou'd hardly raie.
He heav'd it at a Lift: and poiz'd on high,
Ran tagg'ring on, againt his Enemy.
But o diorder'd, that he carcely knew
His Way: or what unwieldy weight he threw.
His knocking Knees are bent beneath the Load:
And hiv'ring Cold congeals his vital Blood.
The Stone drops from his arms: and falling hort,
For want of Vigour, mocks his vain Effort.
And as, when heavy Sleep has clos'd the ight,
The ickly Fancy labours in the Night:
We eem to run; and detitute of Force
Our inking Limbs forake us in the Coure:
In vain we heave for Breath; in vain we cry:
The Nerves unbrac'd, their uual Strength deny;
And, on the Tongue the falt'ring Accents dye:
So Turnus far'd: what ever means he try'd
All force of Arms, and points of Art employ'd,
The Fury flew athwart; and made th' Endeavour void.
A thouand various Thoughts his Soul confound:
He tar'd about; nor Aid nor Iue found:
His own Men top the Pas; and his own Walls urround.
Once more he paues; and looks out again:
And eeks the Goddes Charioteer in vain.
Trembling he views the Thund'ring Chief advance:
And brandihing aloft the deadly Lance:
Amaz'd he cow'rs beneath his conqu'ring Foe,
Forgets to ward; and waits the coming Blow.
Atonih'd while he tands, and fix'd with Fear,
Aim'd at his Shield he ees th' impending Spear.
The Heroe meaur'd firt, with narrow view,
The detin'd Mark: And riing as he threw,
With its full wing the fatal Weapon flew.
Not with les Rage the rattling Thunder falls;
Or Stones from batt'ring Engins break the Walls:
Swift as a Whirlwind, from an Arm o trong,
The Lance drove on; and bore the Death along.
Nought cou'd his ev'n-fold Shield the Prince avail,
Nor ought beneath his Arms the Coat of Mail;
It pierc'd thro' all; and with a grizly Wound,
Transfix'd his Thigh, and doubled him to Ground.
With Groans the Latins rend the vaulted Sky:
Woods, Hills, and Valleys, to the Voice reply.
Now low on Earth the lofty Chief is laid;
With Eyes cat upward, and with Arms diplay'd;
And Recreant thus to the proud Victor pray'd.
I know my Death deerv'd, nor hope to live:
Ue what the Gods, and thy good Fortune give.
Yet think; oh think, if Mercy may be hown,
(Thou hadt a Father once; and hat a Son:)
Pity my Sire, now inking to the Grave;
And for Anchies ake, old Daunus ave!
Or, if thy vow'd Revenge purue my Death;
Give to my Friends my Body void of Breath!
The Latian Chiefs have een me beg my Life;
Thine is the Conquet, thine the Royal Wife:
Againt a yielded Man, 'tis mean ignoble Strife.
In deep Supence the Trojan eem'd to tand;
And jut prepar'd to trike repres'd his Hand.

figure.p: To his Grace James Duke of Ormond Chancellor of the niversitys of Oxford and Dublin Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter &c:
figure.head: Aen: 12. L. 1360.

lg.l: He rowl'd his Eyes, and ev'ry Moment felt
His manly Soul with more Compaion melt.
When, cating down a caual Glance, he py'd
The Golden Belt that glitter'd on his ide:
The fatal Spoils which haughty Turnus tore
From dying Pallas, and in Triumph wore.
Then rowz'd anew to Wrath, he loudly cries,
(Flames, while he poke, came flahing from his Eyes:)
Traytor, dot thou, dot thou to Grace pretend,
Clad, as thou art, in Trophees of my Friend?
To his ad Soul a grateful Off'ring go;
'Tis Pallas, Pallas gives this deadly Blow.
He rais'd his Arm aloft; and at the Word,
Deep in his Boom drove the hining Sword.
The treaming Blood ditain'd his Arms around:
And the didainful Soul came ruhing thro' the Wound.

div.head: POSTSCRIPT TO THE READER.
div.p: WHAT Virgil wrote in the vigour of his Age, in Plenty and at Eae, I have undertaken to Tranlate in my Declining Years: trugling with Wants, oppres'd with Sicknes, curb'd in my Genius, lyable to be micontrued in all I write; and my Judges, if they are not very equitable, already prejudic'd againt me, by the Lying Character which has been given them of my Morals. Yet teady to my Principles, and not dipirited with my Afflictions, I have, by the Bleing of God on my Endeavours, overcome all difficulties; and, in ome meaure, acquitted my elf of the Debt which I ow'd the Publick, when I undertook this Work. In the firt place therefore, I thankfully acknowledge to the Almighty Power, the Aitance he has given me in the beginning, the Proecution, and Concluion of my preent Studies, which are more happily perform'd than I could have promis'd to my elf, when I labour'd under uch Dicouragements. For, what I have done, Imperfect as it is, for want of Health and leiure to Correct it, will be judg'd in after Ages, and poibly in the preent, to be no dihonour to my Native Country; whoe Language and Poetry wou'd be more eteem'd abroad, if they were better undertood. Somewhat (give me leave to ay) I have added to both of them in the choice of Words; and Harmony of Numbers which were wanting, epecially the lat, in all our Poets, even in thoe who being endu'd with Genius, yet have not Cultivated their Mother-Tongue with ufficient Care; or relying on the Beauty of their Thoughts, have judg'd the Ornament of Words, and weetnes of Sound unneceary. One is for raking in Chaucer (our Englih Ennius) for antiquated Words, which are never to be reviv'd, but when Sound or Significancy is wanting in the preent Language. But many of his deerve not this Redemption, any more than the Crouds of Men who daily die, or are lain for Six-pence in a Battel, merit to be retor'd to Life, if a Wih cou'd revive them. Others have no Ear for Vere, nor choice of Words; nor ditinction of Thoughts; but mingle Farthings with their Gold to make up the Sum. Here is a Field of Satire open'd to me: But ince the Revolution, I have wholly renounc'd that Talent. For who wou'd give Phyick to the Great when he is uncall'd? To do his Patient no good, and indanger himelf for his Precription? Neither am I ignorant, but I may jutly be Condemn'd for many of thoe Faults, of which I have too liberally Arraign'd others.

'Tis enough for me, if the Government will let me pas unquetion'd. In the mean time, I am oblig'd in gratitude, to return my Thanks to many of them, who have not only ditinguih'd me from others of the ame Party, by a particular exception of Grace, but without conidering the Man, have been Bountiful to the Poet: Have encourag'd Virgil to peak uch Englih, as I could teach him, and rewarded his Interpreter, for the pains he has taken in bringing him over into Britain, by defraying the Charges of his Voyage. Even Cerberus, when he had receiv'd the Sop, permitted Aeneas to pas freely to Elyium. Had it been offer'd me, and I had refus'd it, yet till ome gratitude is due to uch who were willing to oblige me. But how much more to thoe from whom I have receiv'd the Favours which they have offer'd to one of a different Perwaion. Amongt whom I cannot omit naming the Earls of Darby and of Peterborough. To the firt of thee, I have not the Honour to be known; and therefore his liberality as much unexpected, as it was undeerv'd. The preent Earl of Peterborough has been pleas'd long ince to accept the tenders of my Service: His Favours are o frequent to me, that I receive them almot by precription. No difference of Interets or Opinion have been able to withdraw his Protection from me: And I might jutly be condemn'd for the mot unthankful of Mankind, if I did not always preerve for him a mot profound Repect and inviolable Gratitude. I mut alo add, that if the lat Aeneid hine amongt its Fellows, 'tis owing to the Commands of Sir William Trumball, one of the Principal Secretaries of State, who recommended it, as his Favourite, to my Care: and for his ake particularly I have made it mine. For who wou'd confes wearines, when he enjoin'd a freh Labour? I cou'd not but invoke the aitance of a Mue, for this lat Office.

q.l: Extremum hunc Arethua:—
Negat quis Carmina Gallo?

div.p: Neither am I to forget the Noble Preent which was made me by Gilbert Dolben Eq the worthy Son of the late Arch-Bihop of York: who, when I began this Work, enrich'd me with all the everal Editions of Virgil, and all the Commentaries of thoe Editions in Latine. Amongt which, I cou'd not but prefer the Dolphins; as the lat, the hortet, and the mot Judicious. Fabrini I had alo ent me from Italy; but either he undertands Virgil very imperfectly, or I have no knowledge of my Author.

Being Invited by that worthy Gentleman, Sir William Bowyer, to Denham-Court, I Tranlated the firt Georgic at his Houe, and the greatet part of the lat Aeneid. A more friendly Entertainment no Man ever found. No wonder therefore if both thoe Verions urpas the ret, and own the atisfaction I receiv'd in his Convere, with whom I had the honour to be bred in Cambridge, and in the ame College. The Seventh Aeneid was made Englih at Burleigh, the Magnificent Abode of the Earl of Exeter: In a Village belonging to his Family I was born, and under his Roof I endeavour'd to make that Aeneid appear in Englih with as much lutre as I cou'd: though my Author has not given the finihing trokes either to it, or to the Eleventh, as I perhaps cou'd prove in both, if I durt preume to Criticie my Mater.

By a Letter from Will. Walh of Abberley Eq (who has o long honour'd me with his Friendhip, and who, without flattery, is the bet Critick of our Nation,) I have been inform'd that his Grace the
Duke of Shrewsbury has procur'd a Printed Copy of the Patorals, Georgics, and ix firt Aeneids, from my Bookeller, and has read them in the Country, together with my Friend. This Noble Peron having been pleas'd to give them a Commendation, which I preume not to inert; has made me vain enough to boat of o great a favour, and to think I have ucceeded beyond my hopes; the Character of his Excellent Judgment, the acutenes of his Wit, and his general Knowledge of good Letters, being known as well to all the World, as the weetnes of his dipoition, his Humanity, his eaines of acces, and deire of obliging thoe who tand in need of his protection, are known to all who have approach'd him; and to me in particular, who have formerly had the honour of his Converation. Whoever has given the World the Tranlation of part of the third Georgic, which he calls The Power of Love, has put me to ufficient pains to make my own not inferiour to his: As my Lord Rocommon's Silenus had formerly given me the ame trouble. The mot Ingenious Mr. Addion of Oxford has alo been as troubleome to me as the other two, and on the ame account. After his Bees, my latter Swarm is carcely worth the hiving. Mr. Cowley's praie of a Countrey Life is Excellent; but 'tis rather an imitation of Virgil, than a Verion. That I have recover'd in ome meaure the health which I had lot by too much application to this Work, is owing, next to God's Mercy, to the Skill and Care of Dr. Guibbons, and Dr. Hobbs, the two Ornaments of their Profeion; whom I can only pay by this Acknowledgment.
