The whole Faculty has always been ready to oblige me: and the only one of them who endeavour'd to defame me, had it not in his power. I deire pardon from my Readers for aying o much in relation to my elf, which concerns not them: and with my acknowledgements to all my Subcribers, have only to add, that the few Notes which follow, are par maniere d'acquit, becaue I had oblig'd my elf by Articles, to do omewhat of that kind. Thee cattering Obervations are rather guees at my Author's meaning in ome paages, than proofs that o he meant. The Unlearn'd may have recoure to any Poetical Dictionary in Englih, for the Names of Perons, Places, or Fables, which the Learned need not: But that little which I ay, is either new or neceary. And the firt of thee qualifications never fails to invite a Reader, if not to pleae him.

div.head: NOTES and OBSERVATIONS ON Virgil's Works IN ENGLISH.
div.p: PAtoral 1. Line 6. There firt the Youth of Heavenly Birth I view'd. Virgil means Octavius Caear: Heir to Julius: who perhaps had not arriv'd to his Twentieth Year, when Virgil aw him firt. Vide his Life. Of Heavenly Birth or Heavenly Blood; becaue the Julian Family was deriv'd from Julus, Son to Aeneas, and Grand-Son to Venus.
Patoral 2d. Line 65. The Short Narcius, That is, of hort continuance.

Patoral 3d. Line 95. For him, the God of Shepherds and their Sheep, Phoebus, not Pan, is here call'd the God of Shepherds: The Poet alludes to the ame Story, which he touches in the beginning of the Second Georgic, where he calls Phoebus the Amphryian Shepherd, becaue he fed the Sheep and Oxen of Admetus (with whom he was in Love) on the Hill Amphryus.

Patoral 4th. Line 73. Begin Aupicious Boy, &c. In Latin thus. Incipe parve Puer, riu cognocere Matrem, &c. I have Tranlated the Paage to this Sene; that the Infant miling on his Mother, ingles her out from the ret of the Company about him. Erythraeus, Bembus, and Joeph Scaliger, are of this Opinion. Yet they and I may be mitaken. For immediately after, we find thee words, Cui non riere Parentes, which imply another Sene, as if the Parents mil'd on the New-born Infant: And that the Babe on whom they vouchaf'd not to mile, was born to ill Fortune. For they tell a Story, that when Vulcan, the only Son of Jupiter and Juno came into the World, he was o hard favour'd, that both his Parents frown'd on him: And Jupiter threw him out of Heaven; he fell on the Iland Lemnos, and was Lame ever afterwards. The lat Line of the Patoral eems to jutify this Sene, Nec Deus hunc Menâ, Dea nec dignata Cubili et. For though he married Venus, yet his Mother Juno was not preent at the Nuptials to bles them; as appears by his Wife's Incontinence. They ay alo, that he was banih'd from the Banquets of the Gods: If o, that Punihment could be of no long continuance, for Homer makes him preent at their Feats; and compoing a Quarrel betwixt his Parents, with a Bowl of Nectar. The matter is of no great Conequence; and therefore
I adhere to my Tranlation, for thee two Reaons: Firt, Virgil has this following Line. Matri long a docem tulerunt fatidia Menes, as if the Infants miling on his Mother, was a Reward to her for bearing him ten Months in her Body, four Weeks longer than the uual time. Secondly, Catullus is cited by Joeph Scaliger, as favouring this Opinion, in his Epithalamium of Manlius Torquatus.

q.l: Dulcè rideat ad Patrem, &c.

div.p: What if I hou'd teer betwixt the two Extreams, and conclude, that the Infant, who was to be happy, mut not only mile on his Parents, but alo they on him? For Scaliger notes that the Infants who mil'd not at their Birth, were oberv'd to be < in non-Latin alphabet > , or ullen (as I have Tranlated it) during all their Life: And Servius, and almot all the Modern Commentators affirm, that no Child was thought Fortunate on whom his Parents mil'd not, at his Birth. I oberve farther, that the Ancients thought the Infant who came into the World at the end of the Tenth Month, was Born to ome extraordinary Fortune, good or Bad. Such was the Birth of the late Prince of Condé, of whom his Mother was not brought to Bed, 'till almot Eleven Months were expir'd after his Fathers Death: Yet the College of Phyicians at Paris, concluded he was Lawfully begotten. My Ingenious Friend, Anthony Henley Eq deir'd me to make a Note on this Paage of Virgil: Adding what I had not Read; that the Jews have been o Supertitious, as to oberve not only the firt Look or Action of an Infant, but alo the firt Word which the Parent, or any of the Aitants poke after the Birth: And from thence they gave a Name to the Child alluding to it.
Patoral 6. My Lord Rocommon's Notes on this Patoral, are equal to his excellent Tranlation of it; and thither I refer the Reader.
The Eighth and Tenth Patorals are already Tranlated to all manner of advantage, by my excellent Friend, Mr. Stafford. So is the Epiode of Camilla, in the Eleventh Eneid.

This Eight Patoral is Copied by our Author from two Bucolicks of Theocritus. Spencer has follow'd both Virgil and Theocritus, in the Charms which he employs for Curing Britomartis of her Love. But he had alo our Poet's Ceiris in his Eye: For there not only the Inchantments are to be found; but alo the very Name of Britomartis.
In the Ninth Patoral, Virgil has made a Collection of many cattering Paages, which he had Tranlated from Theocritus: And here he has bound them into a Noegay.

Georgic the Firt. The Poetry of this Book is more ublime than any part of Virgil, if I have any Tate. And if ever I have Copied his Majetick Stile 'tis here. The Compliment he makes Augutus almot in the beginning, is ill imitated by his Succeors Lucan and Statius. They Dedicated to Tyrants; and their Flatteries are gros and fulome. Virgil's Addres is both more lofty and more jut. In the three lat Lines of this Georgic, I think I have dicover'd a ecret Compliment to the Emperour, which none of the Commentators have oberv'd. Virgil had jut before decrib'd the Mieries which Rome had undergone betwixt the Triumvirs and the Commonwealth-Party: In the cloe of all, he eems to excue the Crimes committed by his Patron
Caear, as if he were contrain'd againt his own Temper to thoe violent Proceedings, by the neceity of the Times in general, but more particularly by his two Partners, Anthony and Lepidus. Fertur Equis Auriga, nec audit Currus habenas. They were the Head-trong Hores, who hurried Octavius, the trembling Charioteer along, and were deaf to his reclaiming them. I oberve farther; that the preent Wars, in which all Europe, and part of Aia are ingag'd at preent; are wag'd in the ame places here decrib'd: Atque hinc Euphrates, illinc Germania Bellum, &c. As if Virgil had Prophecy'd of this Age.

Georgic. 2d. The Praies of Italy, (Tranlated by the Learned, and every way Excellent Mr. Chetwood) which are Printed in one of the Micellany Poems, are the greatet Ornament of this Book. Wherein for want of ufficient skill in Gardening, Agriculture, &c. I may poibly be mitaken in ome Terms. But concerning Grafting, my Honour'd Friend Sir William Bowyer has aur'd me, that Virgil has hewn more of Poetry than Skill, at leat in relation to our more Northern Climates. And that many of our Stocks will not receive uch Grafts, as our Po • t tells us would Bear in Italy. Nature has conir'd with Art to make the Garden at Denham-Court, of Sir William's own Plantation, one of the mot delicious Spots of Ground in England: It contains not above Five Acres, (jut the compas of Alcinous his Garden, decrib'd in the Odyes:) But Virgil ays in this very Georgic, Laudato ingentia Rura; Exiguum colito.

Georgic 3d. Line the 45th. Next him, Niphates with inverted rn, &c. It has been objected to me, that I undertood not this Paage of Virgil, becaue I call Niphates a River, which is a Mountain in Armenia. But the River ariing from the ame Mountain, is alo called Niphates. And having poken of Nile before, I might reaonably think, that Virgil rather meant to couple two Rivers, than a River and a Mountain.
Line 224. The Male has done, &c. The tranition is obcure in Virgil. He began with Cows, then proceeds to treat of Hores: Now returns to Cows
Line 476. 'Till the new Ram receives th' Exalted Sun. Atrologers tell us, that the Sun receives his Exaltation in the Sign Aries: Virgil perfectly undertood both Atronomy and Astrology.

Georgic 4. Line 27. That when the Youthful Prince. My mot Ingenious Friend Sir Henry Shere, has oberv'd through a Glas-Hive, that the Young Prince of the Bees, or Heir preumptive of the Crown, approaches the King's Apartment with great Reverence; and for three ucceive Mornings demands permiion, to lead forth a Colony of that Years Bees. If his Petition be granted, which he eems to make by humble hummings; the Swarm aries under his Conduct: If the Anwer be, le Roy s'aviera, that is, if the Old Monarch think it not convenient for the Publick good, to part with o many of his Subjects; the next Morning the Prince is found dead, before the Threhold of the Palace.

Line 477. The Poet here records the Names of Fifty River Nymphs. And for once I have Tranlated them all. But in the Aeneis I thought not my elf oblig'd to be o exact; for in naming many Men who were kill'd by Heroes, I have omitted ome, which wou'd not ound in Englih Vere.

Line 660. The Epiode of Orpheus and Eurydice begins here. And
contains the only Machine which Virgil ues in the Georgics. I have oberv'd in the Epitle before the Aeneis, that our Author eldom employs Machines but to adorn his Poem: And that the Action which they eemingly perform, is really produc'd without them. Of this Nature is the Legend of the Bees retor'd by Miracle; when the Receipt which the Poet gives, wou'd do the Work without one. The only Beautiful Machine which I remember in the Modern Poets, is in Arioto. Where God commands St. Michael to take care, that Paris then Beieg'd by the Saracens, hould be uccour'd by Rinaldo. In order to this, he enjoins the Arch-Angel to find Silence and Dicord. The firt to Conduct the Chritian Army to relieve the Town, with o much ecrecy, that their March hou'd not be dicover'd; the latter to enter the Camp of the Infidels, and there to ow Diention among the Principal Commanders. The Heavenly Meenger takes his way to an Ancient Monatery; not doubting there to find Silence in her primitive Abode. But intead of Silence finds Dicord: The Monks, being divided into Factions, about the choice of ome New Officer, were at Snic and Snee with their drawn Knifes. The Satyr needs no Explanation. And here it may be alo oberv'd, that Ambition, Jealouie, and Worldly Interet, and point of Honour, had made variance both in the Cloyter and the Camp; and trict Dicipline had done the Work of Silence, in Conducting the Chritian Army to urprie the Turks.

Aeneid 1. Line 111. And make thee Father of a happy Line.
This was an obliging Promie to Eolus; who had been o unhappy in his former Children, Macareus and Canacè.

Line 196.
The Realms of Ocean, and the Fields of Air
Are mine, not his.

Poetically peaking, the Fields of Air, are under the Command of Juno; and her Vicegerent Eolus. Why then does Neptune call them His? I anwer, becaue being God of the Seas, Eolus could raie no Tempets in the Atmophere above them without his leave. But why does Juno Addres to her own Subtitute? I anwer, He had an immediate Power over the Winds, whom Juno deires to employ on her Revenge. That Power was abolute by Land; which Virgil plainly ininuates: For when Boreas and his Brethren were let looe, he ays at firt terras turbine perflant: Then adds, Incubuere Mari: To raie a Tempet on the Sea was Uurpation on the Prerogative of Neptune; who had given him no leave, and therefore was inrag'd at his Attempt. I may alo add, that they who are in Paion, as Neptune then was, are apt to aume to themelves, more than is properly their due.

Line 450.
O Virgin—&c.
If as you eem the Siter of the Day,
Or one at leat of Chat Diana's Train.
Thus, in the Original.

q.l: O Quam te memorem Virgo—
Aut Phoebi Soror, aut Nympharum Sanguinis na.

div.p: This is a Family Complement, which Aeneas here betows on Venus. His Father Anchies had us'd the very ame to that Goddes when he Courted her. This appears by that very Ancient Greek Poem, in which that Amour is o beautifully decrib'd, and which is thought Homer's: Though it eems to be Written before his Age.

Line 980.
Her Princely Guet was next her ide.
This, I confes, is improperly Tranlated; and according to the Modern Fahion of itting at Table. But the Ancient cutom of lying on Beds, had not been undertood by the Unlearn'd Reader.
Aeneid the Second. The Detruction of Veii is here hadow'd under that of Troy: Livy in his Decription of it, eems to have emulated in his Proe, and almot equal'd the Beauty of Virgil's Vere.

Aeneid the 3d. Vere 132.
And Childrens Children hall the Crown utain. Et Nati Natorum, & qui nacentur ab illis.

Virgil Tranlated this Vere from Homer: Homer had it from Orpheus; and Orpheus from an Ancient Oracle of Apollo. On this Account it is, that Virgil immediately Subjoins thee Words, Haec Phoebus, &c. Eutathius takes notice, that the Old Poets were wont to take whole Paragraphs from one another, which jutifies our Poet for what he borrows from Homer. Bochartus in his Letter to Segrais, mentions an Oracle which he found in the fragments of an Old Greek Hitorian: The Sene whereof is this in Englih; that when the Empire of the Priamidae hould be detroy'd, the Line of Anchies hould ucceed. Venus therefore, ays the Hitorian, was deirous to have a Son by Anchies, tho' he was then in his decrepid Age: Accordingly he had Aeneas. After this he ought occaion to ruin the Race of Priam; and et on foot the Intrigue of Alexander, (or Paris) with Helena: She being ravih'd, Venus pretended till to favour the Trojans; let they hould retore Helen, in cae they hould be reduc'd to the lat Neceity. Whence it appears, that the Controverie betwixt Juno and Venus, was on no trivial account; but concern'd the Succeion to a great Empire.

Aeneid the 4th. Li. 945.
And mut I dye, he aid,
And unreveng'd? 'tis doubly to be dead!
Yet even this Death with pleaure I receive:
On any Terms, 'tis better than to live.
This is certainly the Sene of Virgil; on which I have paraphras'd, to make it plain. His Words are thee; Moriemur Inultae?
div.q: Sed Moriamur ait; ic, ic juvat ire ub mbras.
div.p:
Servius makes an Interrogation at the Word ic; thus, ic? Sic juvat ire ub mbras Which Mr. Cowley jutly Cenures: But his own judgment may perhaps be quetion'd: For he wou'd retrench the latter part of the Vere, and leave it a Hemytic. Sed Moriamur ait. That Virgil never intended to have left any Hemytic, I have prov'd already in the Preface. That this Vere was fill'd up by him, with thee words, ic, juvat ire ub mbras, is very probable; if we conider the weight of them. For this procedure of Dido, does not only contain, that, dira Execratio, quae nullo expiatur Carmine (as Horace oberves in his Canidia) but beides that, Virgil, who is full of Alluions to Hitory, under another Name, decribes the Decii, devoting themelves to Death this way, though in a better Caue, in order to the Detruction of the Enemy. The Reader, who will take the pains to Conult Livy, in his accurate
Decription of thoe Decii, thus devoting themelves, will find a great reemblance betwixt thee two Paages. And 'tis judiciouly oberv'd upon that Vere,
—Nulla fides populis nec foedera unto.
That Virgil ues in the word unto a verbum juris, a form of peaking on Solemn and Religious Occaions: Livy does the like. Note alo that Dido puts her elf into the Habitus Gabinus, which was the girding her elf round with one Sleeve of her Vet, which is alo according to the Roman Pontifical, in this dreadful Ceremony, as Livy has oberv'd: which is a farther confirmation of this Conjecture. So that upon the whole matter, Dido only doubts whether he hou'd die before he had taken her Revenge, which he rather wih'd: But conidering that this devoting her elf was the mot certain and infallible way of compaing her Vengeance, he thus exclaims;
Sic, ic juvat ire ub umbras:
Hauriat hunc oculis ignem crudelis ab alto
Dardanus, & notrae ecum ferat omnia mortis.
Thoe Flames from far, may the fale Trojan view;
Thoe boding Omens his bae Flight purue.
Which Tranlation I take to be according to the Sene of Virgil. I hould have added a Note on that former Vere.
div.q: Infelix Dido, nunc te fata impia tangunt.
div.p: Which in the Edition of Heinius is thus Printed. Nunc te facta impia tangunt? The word facta intead of fata, is reaonably alter'd. For Virgil ays afterwards, he dy'd not by Fate, nor by any deerv'd Death. Nec Fato, meritâ nec morte peribat, &c. When I Tranlated that Paage, I doubted of the Sene: And therefore omitted that Hemytic; Nunc te fata impia tangunt. But Heinius is mitaken only in making an Interrogation point, intead of a Period. The words facta impia, I uppoe are genuine: For he had perjur'd her elf in her econd Marriage. Having firmly reolv'd, as he told her Siter, in the beginning of this Aeneid, never to love again, after the Death of her firt Husband; and had confirm'd this Reolution, by a Cure on her elf, if he hou'd alter it.

q.l: Sed mihi vel tellus optem, prius ima dehicat, &c.

l.hi: Ante, pudor, quàm te violem, aut tua jura reolvam.
Ille meos, primus, qui me ibi junxit, amores,
Abtulit: Ille habeat ecum, ervetque epulcro.

div.p:
Aeneid the 5th. A great part of this Book is borrow'd from Apollonius Rhodius. And the Reader may oberve the great Judgment and ditinction of our Author in what he borrows from the Ancients, by comparing them. I conceive the Reaon why he omits the Hore-race in the Funeral Games, was becaue he hews Acanius afterwards on Horeback, with his Troops of Boys, and would not wear that Subject thread-bare; which Statius, in the next Age decrib'd o happily. Virgil eems to me, to have excell'd Homer in all thoe Sports, and to
have labour'd them the more, in Honour of Octavius, his Patron; who intituted the like Games for perpetuating the Memory of his Uncle Julius. Piety, as Virgil calls it, or dutifulnes to Parents, being a mot popular Vertue among the Romans.
Aeneid the 6th. Line 586.

l.hi: The next in place and Punihment are they,

q.l: Who prodigally throw their Lives away, &c.

l.hi: Proxima orte tenent maeti loca, qui ibi letum

q.l: Projecere animas, &c.

div.p: This was taken, amongt many other things, from the Tenth Book of Plato de Republicâ: No Commentator beides Fabrini, has taken notice of it. Self-Murther was accounted a great Crime by that Divine Philoopher: But the Intances which he brings, are too many to be inerted in thee hort Notes. Sir Robert Howard in his Tranlation of this Aeneid, which was Printed with his Poems in the Year 1660; has given us the mot Learned, and the mot Judicious Obervations on this Book, which are extant in our Language.

Line 734.
Lo to the ecret Shadows I retire,
To pay my Penance, 'till my Years expire.
Thee two Veres in Englih eem very different from the Latine. Dicedam; explebo numerum, reddarque tenebris.

Yet they are the Sene of Virgil; at leat, according to the common Interpretation of this place: I will withdraw from your Company; retire to the Shades, and perform my Penance of a Thouand Years. But I mut confes the Interpretation of thoe two words, explebo numerum is omewhat Violent, if it be thus undertood, minuam numerum; that is, I will leen your Company by my departure. For Deiphobus being a Ghot, can hardly be aid to be of their Number. Perhaps the Poet means by explebo numerum, abolvam ententiam: As if Deiphobus reply'd to the Sibil, who was angry at his long Viit: I will only take my lat leave of Aeneas, my Kinman and my Friend, with one hearty good-wih for his Health and Well-fare, and then leave you to proecute your Voyage. That Wih is expres'd in the words immediately following. I Decus, I notrum, &c. Which contain a direct Anwer to what the Sibill aid before: When he upbraided their long Dicoure, Nos flendo ducimus horas. This Conjecture is new, and therefore left to the dicretion of the Reader.

L. 981.
Know firt that Heav'n, and Earth's compacted Frame,
And flowing Waters, and the Starry Flame,
And both the radiant Lights, &c.
Principio Coelum, & terras, compoque liquentes,
Lucentemque globum Lunae, Titaniaque Atra, &c.

Here the Sun is not expres'd, but the Moon only; though a les, and alo a les radiant Light. Perhaps the Copies of Virgil are all fale; and that intead of Titaniaque Atra, he writ Titanaque & Atra; and according
to thoe words I have made my Tranlation. 'Tis mot certain, that the Sun ought not to be omitted; for he is frequently call'd the Life and Soul of all the World: And nothing bids o fair for a viible Divinity to thoe who know no better, than that glorious Luminary. The Platonits call God the Archetypall Sun, and the Sun the viible Deity, the inward vital Spirit in the Center of the Univere, or that Body to which that Spirit is united, and by which-it exerts it elf mot powerfully. Now it was the receiv'd Hypotheis amongt the Pythagoreans, that the Sun was cituate in the Center of the World: Plato had it from them, and was himelf of the ame Opinion; as appears by a paage in the Timaeus: From which Noble Dialogue is this part of Virgil's Poem taken.

L. 1157.
Great Cato there, for gravity renown'd, &c.
Quis te Magne Cato, &c.

There is no Quetion but Virgil here means Cato Major, or the Cenor. But the Name of Cato being alo mention'd in the Eighth Aeneid, I doubt whether he means the ame Man in both places. I have aid in the Preface, that our Poet was of Republican Principles; and have given this for one Reaon of my Opinion, that he prais'd Cato in that Line,
Secretique piis, his dantem jura Catonem. And accordingly plac'd him in the Elyian Fields. Montaign thinks this was Cato the tican, the great Enemy of Arbitrary Power, and a profes'd Foe to Julius Caear. Ruaeus wou'd perwade us that Virgil meant the Cenor. But why hou'd the Poet name Cato twice, if he intended the ame peron? Our Author is too frugal of his Words and Sene, to commit Tautologies in either. His Memory was not likely to betray him into uch an Errour. Nevertheles I continue in the ame Opinion, concerning the Principles of our Poet. He declares them ufficiently in this Book: Where he praies the firt Brutus for expelling the Tarquins, giving Liberty to Rome, and putting to Death his own Children, who conpir'd to retore Tyranny: He calls him only an unhappy Man, for being forc'd to that evere Action.

q.l: Infelix, utcunque ferent ea facta Minores,
Vincet amor Patriae, laudumque immena Cupido.

div.p: Let the Reader weigh thee two Veres, and he mut be convinc'd that I am in the right: And that I have not much injur'd my Mater in my Tranlation of them.
This Note, which is out of its proper place, I deferr'd on purpoe, to place it here: Becaue it dicovers the Principles of our Poet more plainly than any of the ret.

Tuque prior, tu parce, genus qui ducis Olympo,
Projice tela manu, Sanguis meus!
Anchies here peaks to Julius Caear; And commands him firt to lay down Arms; which is a plain condemnation of his Caue. Yet oberve our Poet's incomparable Addres: For though he hews himelf ufficiently to be a Common-wealth's-man; yet in repect to Augutus, who was his Patron, he ues the Authority of a Parent, in the Peron of Anchies; who had more right to lay this Injunction on Caear than on Pompey; becaue the latter was not of his Blood. Thus our Author cautiouly veils his own opinion, and takes Sanctuary under Anchies; as if that Ghot wou'd have laid the ame Command on Pompey alo, had he been lineally decended from him. What cou'd be more judiciouly contriv'd, when this was the Aeneid which he choe to read before his Mater?

Line 1222.
A new Marcellus hall arie in thee.
In Virgil thus. Tu Marcellus eris.

How unpoetically and baldly had this been tranlated; Thou halt Marcellus be! Yet ome of my Friends were of Opinion, that I mitook the Sene of Virgil in my Tranlation. The French Interpreter, oberves nothing on this place; but that it appears by it, the Mourning of Octavia was yet freh, for the los of her Son Marcellus, whom he had by her firt Husband: And who dyed in the Year aburbe conditâ, 731. And collects from thence that Virgil, reading this Aeneid before her, in the ame Year, had jut finih'd it: That from this time to that of the Poet's Death, was little more than four Years. So that uppoing him to have written the whole Aeneis in eleven Years; the firt ix Books mut have taken up even of thoe Years: On which Account the ix lat, mut of neceity be les correct.

Now for the fale judgment of my Friends, there is but this little to be aid for them; the words of Virgil, in the Vere preceding are thee,
—Siqua fata apera rumpas.
As if the Poet had meant, if you break through your hard Detiny, o as to be born, you hall be call'd Marcellus: But this cannot be the Sene: for though Marcellus was born, yet he broke not through thoe hard Decrees, which doom'd him to o immature a death. Much les can Virgil mean, you hall be the ame Marcellus by the Tranmigration of his Soul. For according to the Sytem of our Author, a Thouand Years mut be firt elaps'd, before the Soul can return into a Humane Body; but the firt Marcellus was lain in the econd Punick War. And how many hundred Years were yet wanting, to the accomplihing his penance, may with eae be gather'd, by computing the time betwixt Scipio and Augutus. By which 'tis plain, that Virgil cannot mean the ame Marcellus; but one of his Decendants; whom I call a new Marcellus; who o much reembled his Ancetor, perhaps in his Features, and his Peron, but certainly in his Military Vertues, that Virgil cries out, quantum intar in ipo et! which I have tranlated,
How like the former, and almot the ame.

By the carelesnes of the Amanuenis, the two next Lines are wanting, which I thus upply out of the Original Copy.
True Viions through tranparent Horn arie,
Through polih'd Iv'ry pas deluding Lyes.

What is pervious to the Sight is clear; and (alluding to this Property,) the Poet infers uch Dreams are of Divine Revelation. Such as pas through the Iv'ry Gate, are of the contrary Nature; polih'd Lies. But there is a better Reaon to be giv'n: For the Iv'ry alludes to the Teeth, the Horn to the Eyes. What we ee is more credible, than what we only hear; that is, Words that pas through the Portal of the Mouth, or, Hedge of the Teeth: (which is Homer's expreion for peaking.)

Aen. the 7th. Li. 109.
Strange to relate, the Flames involv'd in Smoke, &c.

Virgil, in this place, takes notice of a great Secret in the Roman Divination: The Lambent Fires, which roe above the Head, or play'd about it, were Signs of Properity, uch were thoe which he oberv'd in the econd Aeneid: which were een mounting from the Crown of Acanius,

q.l: Ecce levis ummo de vertice vius Iuli.
Fundere lumen apex.

div.p: Smoky Flames, (or involv'd in Smoke) were of a mix'd Omen; uch were thoe which are here decrib'd: For Smoke ignifies Tears, becaue it produces them, and Flames Happines. And therefore Virgil ays that this Otent was not only mirabile viu, but horrendum.

Line 367.
One only Daughter heirs my Crown and State.

This has eem'd to ome an odd Paage: That a King hou'd offer his Daughter and Heir, to a Stranger Prince, and a wanderer, before he had een him, and when he had only heard of his arrival on his Coats: But thee Criticks have not well conider'd the Simplicity of former times; when the Heroines almot courted the Marriage of illutrious Men. Yet Virgil here oberves the rule of Decency; Lavinia offers not her elf: 'Tis Latinus, who propounds the Match: And he had been
foretold, both by an Augur, and an Oracle, that he hould have a foreign Son-in-Law; who was alo a Heroe. Fathers, in thoe ancient Ages, conidering Birth and Vertue, more than Fortune, in the placing of their Daughters. Which I cou'd prove by various Examamples: The contrary of which being now practis'd, I dare not ay in our Nation, but in France, has not a little darken'd the Lutre of their Nobility. That Lavinia was avere to this Marriage, and for what reaon, I hall prove in its proper place.

L. 1020. And where Abella ees, from her high Tow'rs, the Harvet of her Trees. I oberve that Virgil names not Nola, which was not far ditant from Abella: perhaps, becaue that City, (the ame in which Augutus dyed afterwards;) had once refus'd to give him entertainment; if if we may believe the Author of his Life. Homer heartily cures another City which had us'd him on the ame manner: But our Author thought his Silence of the Nolans a ufficient correction. When a Poet paes by a Place or Peron, though a fair Occaion offers of rememb'ring them, 'tis a ign he is, or thinks himelf, much dioblig'd.

Aen. 8. L. 34.
So when the Sun by Day, the Moon by Night,
Strike on the polih'd Bras their trembling Light, &c.

This Similitude is literally taken from Apollonius Rhodius; and 'tis hard to ay, whether the Original or the Tranlation excels. But in the Shield which he decribes afterwards in this Aeneid, he as much trancends his Mater Homer; as the Arms of Glaucus were richer than thoe of Diomedes.
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

Lines 115, and 116.
Aeneas takes the Mother, and her Brood,
And all on Juno's Altar are betow'd.

For I cou'd not turn the word Enim into Englih with any grace. Though it was of uch neceity, in the Roman Rites, that a Sacrifice could not be perform'd without it; 'tis of the ame nature, (if I may preume to name that acred Mytery) in our words of Conecration at the Altar.

The firt of thee Lines, is all of Monoyllables; and both Veres are very rough: But of choice; for it had been eaie for me to have mooth'd them. But either my Ear deceives me, or they expres the thing which I intended in their Sound: For the tres of a Bow which is drawn to the full extent, is expres'd in the harhnes of the firt Vere, clogg'd not only with Monoyllables, but with Cononants; and thee words, the tough Eugh, which conclude the econd line, eem as forceful, as they are Unharmonious. Homer and Virgil are both frequent in their adapting
Sounds to the thing they ignifie. One Example will erve for both; becaue Virgil borrow'd the following Veres from Homer's Odyes.

q.l: nà Euruque Notuque ruunt creberque procellis
Africus, & vatos volvunt ad litora fluctus.
< in non-Latin alphabet > ;
< in non-Latin alphabet > .

div.p: Our Language is not often capable of thee Beauties: though ometimes I have copied them, of which thee Veres are an intance.

Line 1095.
His ample Shield—
Is falify'd; and round with Javelins fill'd.

When I read this Aeneid to many of my Friends, in company together, mot of them quarrel'd at the word falify'd, as an Innovation in our Language. The fact is confes'd; for I remember not to have read it in any Englih Author; though perhaps it may be found in Spencer's Fairy Queen: But uppoe it be not there: Why am I forbidden to borrow from the Italian, (a polih'd Language) the word which is wanting in my Native Tongue? Terence has often Grecis'd: Lucretius has follow'd his Example; and pleaded for it; ic quia me cogit patrii Sermonis Egetas. Virgil has confirm'd it by his frequent practice, and even Cicero in Proe, wanting terms of Philoophy in the Latin Tongue, has taken them from Aritotle's Greek. Horace has given us a Rule for Coining Words, i Graeco fonte cadunt. Epecially when other words are join'd with them, which explain the Sene. I ue the word falifie in this place, to mean that the Shield of Turnus was not of Proof againt the Spears and Javlins of the Trojans; which had pierc'd it through and through (as we ay) in many places. The words which accompany this new one, make my meaning plain; according to the Precept which Horace gave. But I aid I borrow'd the Word from the Italian: Vide Arioto, Cant. 26.
Ma i l'sbergo d' Ambi era perfetto
Che mai poter falarlo in neun Canto.

Falar cannot otherwie be turn'd, than by falify'd; for his hield was faled, is not Englih. I might indeed have contented my elf with aying his Shield was pierc'd, and board, and tuck with Javelins; Nec ufficit mbo Ictibus. They who will not admit a new word, may take the old; the matter is not worth dipute.

Aeneid the 10th. A Choir of Nereids, &c. Thee were transform'd from Ships to Sea-Nymphs: This is almot as violent a Machine, as the death of Aruns by a Goddes in the Epiode of Camilla. But the Poet makes ue of it with greater Art: For here it carries on the main Deign. Thee new made Divinities, not only tell Aeneas what had pas'd in his Camp during his abence; and what was the preent Ditres of his Beieg'd People; and that his Hore-men whom he had ent by Land, were ready to join him at his Decent; but warn him to provide for Battel the next day, and fore-tell him good ucces: So that this Epiodical Machine is properly a part of the great Poem; For beides what I have aid, they puh on his Navy with Celetial Vigour,
that it might reach the Port more peedily, and take the Enemy more unprovided to reit the Landing. Whereas the Machine relating to Camilla, is only Ornamental: For it has no effect, which I can find, but to pleae the Reader, who is concern'd, that her Death hou'd be reveng'd.

The Poet here begins to tell the Names of the Tucan Captains who follow'd Aeneas to the War: And I oberve him to be very particular in the decription of their Perons, and not forgetful of their Manners: Exact alo, in the Relation of the Numbers which each of them Command. I doubt not but as in the fifth Book, he gave us the Names of the Champions, who contended for the everal Prizes, that he might oblige many of the mot Ancient Roman Families, their Decendants; and as in the 7th Book, he Muter'd the Auxiliary Forces of the Latins, on the ame Account; o here he gratifies his Tucan Friends, with the like remembrance of their Ancetors; and above the ret, Mecaenas his great Patron: Who being of a Royal Family in Etruria, was probably repreented under one of the Names here mention'd, then known among the Romans, though at o great a ditance, unknown to us. And for his ake chiefly, as I gues, he makes Aeneas (by whom he always means Augutus) to eek for Aid in the Country of Mecaenas, thereby to indear his Protector to his Emperour; as if there had been a former Friendhip betwixt their Lines. And who knows, but Mecaenas might pretend that the Cilnian Family was deriv'd from Tarchon, the Chief Commander of the Tucans.

Line 662.
Nor I, his mighty Syre, cou'd ward the Blow.

I have mention'd this Paage in my Preface to the Aeneis; to prove, that Fate was uperiour to the Gods; and that Jove cou'd neither defer nor alter its Decrees. Sir Robert Howard has ince, been pleas'd to end me the concurrent Tetimony of Ovid; 'tis in the lat Book of his Metamorphoes; where Venus complains, that her Decendant, Julius Caear, was in danger of being Murther'd by Brutus and Caius, at the head of the Commonwealth-Faction, and deires them to prevent that Barbarous Aaination. They are mov'd to Compaion; they are concern'd for Caear; but the Poet plainly tells us, that it was not in their power to change Detiny: All they cou'd do, was to tetifie their orrow for his approaching Death, by fore-hewing it with Signs and Prodigies, as appears by the following Lines.

q.l: Talia nequicquàm toto Venus aurea Coelo

l.hi: Verba jacit: Superoque movet: Qui rumpere quanquam
Ferrea non pount veterum decreta Sororum,
Signa tamen luctus dant haud incerta futuri.

div.p: Then he Addrees to her Father Jupiter, hoping Aid from him, becaue he was thought Omnipotent. But he, it eems, cou'd do as little as the ret, for he anwers thus.

l.hi: Nata, movere paras? intres licet ipa ororum
Tecta trium; cernes illic molimine vato
Ex aere, & olido rerum tabularia ferro:
Quae neque concurum Coeli, neque fulminis iram,
Nec metuunt ullas tuta atque aeterna ruinas.
Fata tui Generis, legi ipe, animoque notavi,
Et referam: ne is etiamnum ignara futuri.
Hic ua complevit; (pro quo Cytherea laboras,)

q.l: Tempora, perfectis quos Terrae debuit, annis, &c.

div.p: Jupiter you ee is only Library-Keeper, or Cutos Rotulorum to the Fates: For he offers his Daughter a Cat of his Office, to give her a Sight of their Decrees; which the inferiour Gods were not permitted to read without his leave. This agrees with what I have aid already in the Preface; that they not having een the Records, might believe they were his own Hand-writing; and conequently at his dipoing either to blott out, or alter, as he aw convenient. And of this Opinion was Juno in thoe words, tua qui potes ora reflectas. Now the abode of thoe Detinies being in Hell, we cannot wonder why the Swearing by Styx, was an inviolable Oath amongt the Gods of Heaven, and that Jupiter himelf hould fear to be accus'd of Forgery by the Fates, if he alter'd any thing in their Decrees. Chaos, Night, and Erebus, being the mot Antient of the Deities, and intituting thoe fundamental Laws, by which he was afterwards to govern. Heiod gives us the Genealogy of the Gods, and I think I may afely infer the ret. I will only add, that Homer was more a Fatalit than Virgil: For it has been oberv'd, that the word < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Fortune, is not to be found in his two Poems; but intead of it, always < in non-Latin alphabet > .

Aeneid the 12. lines 888, and 889.
Sea-born Meapus with Atinas, heads
The Latin Squadrons; and to Battel leads.

The Poet had aid, in the preceding lines, that Mnetheus, Serethus, and Aylas, led on the Trojans, the Tucans, and the Arcadians: But none of the Printed Copies, which I have een, mention any Leader of the Rutulians and Latins, but Meapus the Son of Neptune. Ruaeus takes notice of this paage, and eems to wonder at it; but gives no Reaon, why Meapus is alone without a Coadjutor.

The four Veres of Virgil run thus.
Totae adeò converae acies, omneque Latini
Omnes Dardanidae, Mnetheus, acerque Serethus
Et Meapus equum Domitor, & fortis Aylas,
Tucorumque Phalanx, Evandrique Arcadis alae.
I doubt not but the third Line was Originally thus, Et Meapus equum domitor, & fortis Atinas:

For the two Names of Aylas and Atinas are o like, that one might eaily be mitaken for the other by the Trancribers. And to fortify this Opinion, we find afterward, in the relation of Sages to Turnus, that Atinas is join'd with Meapus.

l.hi: Soli, pro portis, Meapus & acer Atinas

div.p: In general I oberve, not only in this Aeneid, but in all theixth lat Books, that Aeneas is never een on Hore-back, and but once before as I remember, in the Fourth when he Hunts with Dido. The Reaon of this, if I gues aright, was a ecret Compliment which the Poet made to his Country-men the Romans; the trength of whoe Armies conited mot in Foot; which, I think, were all Romans and Italians. But their Wings or Squadrons, were made up of their Allies, who were Foreigners.

Amata, ever partial to the Caue of Turnus, had jut before deir'd him, with all manner of earnetnes, not to ingage his Rival in ingle Fight; which was his preent Reolution. Virgil, though in favour of his Heroe, he never tells us directly, that Lavinia preferr'd Turnus to Aeneas, yet has ininuated this preference twice before. For mark in the 7th Aeneid, he left her Father, who had promis'd her to Aeneas without asking her conent: And follow'd her Mother into the Woods, with a Troop of Bacchanals, where Amata ung the Marriage Song, in the Name of Turnus; which if he had dilik'd, he might have oppos'd. Then in the 11th. Aeneid, when her Mother went to the Temple of Pallas, to invoke her Aid againt Aeneas; whom he calls by no better Name than Phrygius Praedo, Lavinia its by her in the ame Chair or Litter, juxtaque Comes Lavinia Virgo,—Oculos dejecta decoros. What greater ign of Love, than Fear and Concernment for the Lover? In the lines which I have quoted he not only heds Tears but changes Colour. She had been bred up with Turnus, and Aeneas was wholly a Stranger to her. Turnus in probability was her firt Love; and favour'd by her Mother, who had the Acendant over her Father. But I am much deceiv'd, if (beides what I have aid) there be not a ecret Satire againt the Sex, which is lurking under this Decription of Virgil, who eldom peaks well of Women: Better indeed of Camilla, than any other; for he commends her Beauty and Valour: Becaue he wou'd concern the Reader for her Death. But Valour is no very proper Praie for Womankind; and Beauty is common to the Sex. He ays alo omewhat of Andromache, but traniently: And his Venus is a better Mother than a Wife, for he owns to Vulcan he had a Son by another Man. The ret are Juno's, Diana's, Dido's, Amata's, two mad Prophetees, three Harpies on Earth, and as many Furies under ground. This Fable of Lavinia includes a ecret Moral; that Women in their choice of Husbands, prefer the younger of their Suitors to the Elder; are inenible of Merit, fond of Handomnes; and generally peaking, rather hurried away by their Appetite, than govern'd by their Reaon.

L. 1191, & 1192.
This let me beg; (and this no Fates withtand)
Both for my elf, and for your Fathers Land, &c.

The words in the Original are thee, pro Latio obtetor, pro Majetate tuorum. Virgil very artfully ues here the word Majetas; which the Romans lov'd o well, that they appropriated it to themelves. Majetas
Populi Ramani. this Title apply'd to Kings, is very Modern, and that is all I will ay of it at preent: Though the word requires a larger Note. In the word tuorum, is included the ene of my Tranlation, Your Father's Land: Becaue Saturn the Father of Jove, had govern'd that part of Italy, after his expulion from Crete. But that on which I mot init, is the Addres of the Poet, in this Speech of Juno. Virgil was ufficiently enible, as I have aid in the Preface, that whatever the common Opinion was, concerning the Decent of the Romans from the Trojans; yet the Ancient Cutoms, Rites, Laws, and Habits, of thoe Trojans were wholly lot, and perhaps alo that they had never been: And for this Reaon, he introduces Juno in this place; requeting of Jupiter, that no Memory might remain of Troy, (the Town he hated) that the People hereafter hould not be called Trojans, nor retain any thing which belong'd to their Predeceors. And why might not this alo be concerted betwixt our Author and his Friend Horace, to hinder Augutus from Re-building Troy, and removing thither the Seat of Empire, a deign o unpleaing to the Romans? But of this, I am not poitive, becaue I have not conulted d'Acier, and the ret of the Criticks, to acertain the time in which Horace writ the Ode relating to that Subject.

L. 1224, & 1225.
Deep in the dimal Regions, void of Light,
Three Siters, at a Birth, were born to Night.

The Father of thee, (not here mention'd) was Acheron: the Names of the three, were Alecto, Maegera, and Tyiphone. They were call'd Furies in Hell, on Earth Harpies, and in Heaven Dirae: Two of thee aited at the Throne of Jupiter, and were employed by him, to punih the wickednes of Mankind. Thee two mut be Megaera, and Tyiphone: Not Alecto: For Juno exprely commands her to return to Hell, from whence he came; and gives this Reaon.
Te uper Aetherias errare licentius auras,
Haud Pater ipe velit ummi Regnator Olympi:
Cede locis.

Probably this Dira, un-nam'd by the Poet in this Place; might be Tyiphone, for though we find her in Hell, in the ixth Aeneid, employ'd in the punihment of the damn'd,
Continuo ontes, ltrix accincta flag ello Tiiphone quatit inultans, &c. Yet afterwards he is on Earth in the Tenth Aeneid, and amidt the Battel. Pallida Tiiphone media inter Millia aevit. Which I gues to be Tyiphone, the rather, by the Etimology of her Name; which is compounded of < in non-Latin alphabet >
ulcicor; and < in non-Latin alphabet >
caedes. Part of her Errand being to affright Turnus, with the Stings of a guilty Concience; and denounce Vengeance againt him for breaking the firt Treaty, by refuing to yield Lavinia to Aeneas, to whom he was promis'd by her Father, and conequently, for being the Author of an unjut War; and alo for violating the econd Treaty, by declining the ingle combat, which he had tipulated with his Rival, and call'd the Gods to witnes before their Altars. As for the Names of the Harpies, (o call'd on Earth) Heiod tells us they were Iris, Aello, and Ocypete. Virgil calls one of them Celaeno: This I doubt not was Alecto; whom Virgil calls in the third Aeneid, Furiarum maxima: And in the ixth again, by the ame Name—Furiarum maxima, juxta accubat. That he was the chief of the Furies, appears by her decription in the eventh Aeneid: To which, for hate, I refer the Reader.
